title: A Talking-To
description: Bill Torrey, the Islanders' general manager, called 11 of his veterans into a closed-door meeting Saturday and served notice that trades would be made if their play didn't improve.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;    Careful Cuisine
description: Leslie Newman had just hit her

title: KENTUCKY HOLDS OFF KANSAS
description: Kenny Walker pumped in a career- high 36 points, including two crucial free throws with 8 seconds left, as Kentucky defeated Kansas, 92-89, tonight.

title: BETTER AND WORSE
description: CAIRO Fifteen years from today will be

title: AIRLINES DECLARED 'ON OWN'
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board did something today that major Federal agencies hardly ever do. It went out of existence.

title: What Time Does It Cost?
description: As the seconds till 1985 ticked away last night, the thought arose that for most people, they weren't ticking at all. Clicking, maybe, softly, as numbers flipped over on digital clocks. For all the bands and bells, the seconds, minutes, hour and year changed silently, thus marking New Year's milestones in both high tech and high living.

title: SUPPORTERS OF PASTOR WHO DEFIED CHURCH FOUND IN CONTEMPT
description: A minister's wife and seven other supporters were declared in contempt of court today for defying a judge's order to end their occupation of a church where the pastor preached against ''corporate evil.''

title: SUSPECT SAID TO ADMIT BOMBING 4 ABORTION CLINICS
description: A 21-year-old construction worker has confessed to bombing four Pensacola clinics where abortions were performed, Federal agents testified today at a bond hearing. They also said they had evidence suggesting he belonged to a ''secret-type organization.''

title: HOUSTON HOPING TO SHAKE OFF 2D-CLASS IMAGE
description: The University of Houston football team has been treated with scorn by some, totally ignored by others, and has generally been relegated to the status of an afterthought during the preparations for the 49th annual Cotton Bowl game Tuesday between Houston (7-4) and Boston College (9-2).

title: Howard Richardson Is Dead; Co-Author of 'Dark of Moon'
description: Howard Richardson, a playwright who was the co-author of ''Dark of the Moon,'' a successful drama-fantasy of Southern mountain witchcraft, died Sunday at Roosevelt Hospital after a brief illness. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: New Year, Old Need
description: New Year's Day conjures up the prospect of futures better than the past. For the affluent, more affluence; for the comfortable, greater comfort; for the successful, new worlds to conquer.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am the person they are seeking in New York.'' - Bernhard Hugo Goetz, surrendering to the police in New Hampshire. (31:1.)

title: AUSTRIA OPENS ART CACHE CONFISCATED BY NAZIS
description: Beyond an unobtrusive door on the second floor of the austere, 17th-century Carthusian monastery here, are four rooms containing most of what is left of works of art looted from Jews by the Nazis.

title: Boston Museum Fills European Curator Post
description: The Boston Museum of Fine Arts has appointed Peter C. Sutton its Russell W. Baker Curator of European Paintings. He replaces John Walsh, who left the museum in June 1983 to become director of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif.

title: GAIN OF 72,000 JOBS FOR NEW YORK CITY IN '84 SETS RECORD
description: New York City gained 72,000 jobs in the first 10 months of 1984, a larger increase than any single annual gain since 1950, when the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics started measuring employment in the city.

title: JUDGE REASSERTS RIGHT OF CUBANS TO GET HEARING
description: A Federal judge in Atlanta today refused to lift a court order the Justice Department says could derail a Cuban agreement to take back 2,746 refugees now in American jails and hospitals.

title: ENVIRONEMENTAL IMPLICATIONS OF HENRY GEORGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Peckinpah's Last Film Is to Be Completed
description: The last film project of Sam Peckinpah, who directed ''The Wild Bunch'' and ''Straw Dogs,'' will be completed in the ''style and tradition intended by the legendary director,'' a film company executive has said.

title: A COMRADE COUNTS SNOWFLAKES (IN ZANY MOSCOW)
description: A Soviet scientist predicted the other day that 290 quadrillion snowflakes would fall here on New Year's Eve. A quadrillion, he said, is a million billions.

title: F.B.I. AND THE PHILADELPHIA POLICE FIGHT OVER GUEST LIST IN ART THEFT
description: The Federal authorities have subpoenaed the guest list for a party held at the Philadelphia Museum of Art on Dec. 15, the night a painting was believed to have been stolen.

title: Roper Buys Back Shares Sears Held
description: The Roper Corporation announced the purchase of 815,000 shares of its common stock from the Sears, Roebuck & Company, reducing Sears's stake to 1.3 million shares, or 23 percent of Roper's common stock. Roper, based in Kankakee, Ill., produces outdoor power equipment, including lawn mowers and garden tractors; kitchen appliances, and coated metal products.

title: Article 186488 -- No Title
description: The Irving Bank Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income would be reduced by about $4.5 million as the result of a loss by a Swiss affiliate.

title: U.S. AGENCY HALTS AN OIL LEASE SALE
description: The Interior Department today canceled the second part of a scheduled sale of oil leases off New England, citing lack of industry interest and a court decision that placed much of the area under Canadian jurisdiction.

title: WHAT S.A.T. SCORES CANNOT TELL US
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. FINDS TECHNOLOGY CURB FAILS TO CUT FLOW TO RUSSIANS
description: Despite three years of greatly increased attention, effort and expense, Reagan Administration officials acknowledge that they have not significantly reduced the flow of Western technology to the Soviet Union.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Fiat-Ford Talks Called Routine
description: Fiat S.p.A. said its contacts with the Ford Motor Company were routine consultations about possible joint projects.

title: Challenger Takes A Timeout in Chess
description: The 37th game of the world chess championship match between Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov, scheduled for tonight, was postponed until Wednesday when Kasparov took a timeout, chess officials said today.

title: VIDEO INDUSTRY FINDS MARKET FOR BAD MOVIES
description: Some video cassette producers are making a living from films that died at the box office. In fact, a movie with the stigma ''worst ever made'' is almost sure to be in demand, retailers say. And one promotional effort has the theme ''Rent a turkey.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 10.75-11.25 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Portec Sells Units
description: Portec Inc. said it had sold its railroad freight car manufacturing operations in Atlanta, Winder, Ga. and Clinton, Ill., to a subsidiary of Duchossois Enterprises Inc. for an undisclosed amount. The subsidiary, the Thrall Car Manufacturing Company, agreed to purchase and license certain Portec assets and technologies related to rail car production. Portec said Thrall plans to continue making rail cars at the Portec facilities and would complete Portec's open purchase order commitments.

title: GANDHI, SWORN IN, PLEDGES 'EFFICIENCY ORIENTED' RULE
description: Amid thunderous applause and the pop of hundreds of flashbulbs, 40-year-old Rajiv Gandhi was sworn in today as India's sixth Prime Minister.

title: Don't Just Bow to Mr. Nakasone
description: President Reagan's meeting this week with Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan, like his recent meetings with the leaders of West Germany and Britain, looks to be little more than a courtesy visit. That's too bad, because there's serious business waiting to be done.

title: Growth Seen In Venezuela
description: Venezuela has completed a phase of tough economic adjustment and can now look forward to expansion in 1985 for the first time in five years, President Jaime Lusinchi said today in a year-end address to the nation.

title: LEARNING TO MAKE A BEEPING PAPERWEIGHT USEFUL
description: THE new computer has been unboxed and the snarled cables have been sorted out. But how quickly the excitement ebbs. The instruction manual, it seems, was written for Yugoslavian electronics experts. The neighbors are on their way over to see all the miracles this fancy new gadget can perform, but the most entertaining thing it can be persuaded to do is beep as it is turned on and off. It is, in short, a $2,000 beeping paperweight.

title: 36-Footer Wins Australian Race
description: The 36-foot Sydney sloop Indian Pacific, one of the smallest yachts entered, today was declared the provisional handicap winner of the ill-fated Sydney-to-Hobart ocean race.

title: PAST SHOWS THE PITFALLS OF CRYSTAL GAZING
description: SO here we are, 10 years into the personal computer revolution. The Altair that started it all, after being featured on the cover of the January 1975 issue of Popular Electronics, has vanished into the murky history of the early micro. Apple, the company that, with self-aggrandizing public relations, caused itself to acquire the reputation of being first out of the garage and onto the consumer race track, has exploded into a billion-dollar behemoth. International Business Machines has given micros its stamp of approval, in the process stamping out much of the innovative vigor of the small upstarts in the field.

title: ROBERT PITTMAN BEGINS A NEW MUSIC CHANNEL
description: As a 17-year-old program director for a small radio station in Mississippi in the early 1970's, Robert W. Pittman did what came naturally. He made his selections for the station according to his personal preferences. But the results were disastrous. The audience in rural Mississippi wasn't interested in listening to The Steve Miller Band and other underground rock groups of the time, and the station's ratings plummeted.

title: STATE HIGH COURT BACKS JUDGES' RETIREMENT AT 70
description: New York State's highest court yesterday upheld the State Constitution's requirement that judges retire at the end of the year they turn 70 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Crush at the Wine Stores
description: Stores were empty and Madison

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tom Laidlaw of the Rangers, who suffered a sprained left ankle in the victory over St. Louis Sunday night, was examined yesterday at White Plains Hospital. According to a Ranger spokesman, X-rays revealed the injury was not serious.

title: Heartbroken
description: Racetrack handicappers, already bedeviled by myriad considerations in making their decisions, can now add another. After looking at past performances, the weather, track condition and the rest, they might do well to consider the effect of emotional stress on horses.

title: NEW YORK-BOUND FLIGHT HIJACKED TO CUBA BY CONVICTED MURDERER
description: A man identified as a convict being transported from the Virgin Islands to New York overpowered several guards and hijacked a DC-10 jetliner with 198 people aboard to Cuba, the authorities said.

title: GRAND FINALE FOR DOUG FLUTIE
description: DALLAS

title: AS SICILY GROWS UP, IN PART WITH MAFIA MONEY, IT TURNS AGAINST GODFATHER
description: The Mafia has come under strong attack here as a result of far-reaching changes in Sicilian political and social life, many Sicilians say.

title: Honda Recalls '82 Accords
description: The American Honda Motor Company Friday announced the recall of 178,000 Accord automobiles of the 1982 model year to replace an electrical cable connecting the alternator and the battery. The cable is too small to handle maximum current, which could cause the battery to run down, the company said. Honda said it was making the recall voluntarily and that the repair would be made free by Honda dealers.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   To the Thrift Shops
description: Dozens of bulging shopping bags

title: Angola Rebels Report Taking Diamond Site
description: The Angolan rebels said today that they had taken the northeastern diamond-mining town of Cafunfo and captured 22 foreigners, including two Americans.

title: Musica Sacra to Play Brahms and Sch"utz
description: A concert celebrating the anniversary of the births of Johannes Brahms and Heinrich Sch"utz will be given by Musica Sacra on Jan. 16 at 7:30 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall, Broadway and 67th Street.

title: At Least They'll Say This Name Correctly
description: Frederick Koch lost count of the times he heard his name pronounced ''cotch,'' like the Mayor of New York. It was properly pronounced ''coke.''

title: EUROPE'S NUCLEAR ADVANTAGE
description: A row of huge concrete bunkers under construction on a Normandy cliff top here bears witness to the commanding lead that France's nuclear industry is taking over the United States in one area of nuclear technology.

title: VINTAGE COATS: THE FAD KEEPS GROWING
description: Those American and European designers who showed oversize men's clothes for women have produced a bonanza for old-clothing stores. Men's coats from the 1940's and 50's are being snapped up by young women and young men who either can't afford designer prices or won't pay them, or find the vintage look more attractive.

title: Knee Surgery for Elway
description: John Elway, the Denver Bronco quarterback, will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his left knee this week to

title: SHARE IN DOCTOR'S EARNINGS FOR EX-WIFE IS DENIED
description: The California Supreme Court today refused to order a doctor to share future income with his former wife, who helped him through medical school.

title: WITH 'WILLY,' METCALFE TAKES A NEW DIRECTION
description: In December 1980, after a loner named Mark David Chapman shot the rock star John Lennon to death, a play began to take shape in Stephen Metcalfe's mind. A few months later, after John W. Hinckley Jr. tried to assassinate President Reagan, Mr. Metcalfe started to write. And now, nearly four years later, the resulting play, ''The Incredibly Famous Willy Rivers'' has opened to favorable notices at the WPA Theater.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BKW Inc. , Nashua, N.H., which makes computer systems for financial institutions, announced that John N. Molitor had resigned as president and chief operating officer.

title: STOCKS END ON UPBEAT IN 7.40 RISE
description: Ending a desultory year on a positive note, the stock market rose yesterday, thanks to a modest midday rally.

title: DR. JOHNSON'S DOG
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS STRAINS HEALTH CLINICS
description: Private hospitals may soon have to make room for patients with AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, because of the rapidly increasing number of victims of the fatal disease, an expert says.

title: Striking Back
description: Disgruntled with the manners of

title: Prices Paid to Farmers Off by 2.2%
description: Prices farmers get for raw products declined 2.2 percent in December from November and averaged below levels a year earlier for the first time in 15 months, the Agriculture Department said today..

title: Driver, Angered in Bar, Is Killed in Car Chase
description: A white man, apparently angered at seeing a black patron of a topless bar talking with white dancers, forced the black man's car off the road in a chase and died when his own vehicle struck a tree, the police said.

title: BRIEFS
description: Butler International Inc., an aviation services concern based in Montvale, N.J., said it had completed the sale of International Transport Inc., its motor carrier subsidiary, to Schneider National Inc. for a cash amount to be determined after an audit.

title: VETERAN CANADIAN DIPLOMAT
description: Chester A. Ronning, the Canadian diplomat who carried out a confidential mission to Hanoi in 1966 in an attempt to get peace talks going between the United States and North Vietnam, died of pneumonia yesterday. He had celebrated his 90th birthday on Dec. 13.

title: ISRAELIS SAY SYRIA DOESN'T SEEK DEAL
description: Israeli military officials say they are becoming increasingly convinced that Syria is no longer interested in an agreement for the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon.

title: GIANTS SEEK REINFORCEMENTS
description: When their 1983 season ended with a disastrous 3-12-1 record, the Giants cleaned house. They dropped many veterans, relied on many young players and this season they went 9-7 and made the playoffs.

title: NUCLEAR AGENCY DRAWS CRITICISMS
description: Sweeping changes in the way nuclear power is regulated are needed if the industry is to revive from its current torpor, according to utilities, regulators and the industry's critics.

title: Bonn Bomb Blast Damages Offices of French Embassy
description: A bomb blast damaged a building housing military offices of the French Embassy in Bonn early today but no one was hurt, the police said.

title: Navy Given Approval To Shoot 1,500 Goats
description: A Federal appeals court today gave the Navy approval to kill 1,500 goats that it says are a threat to endangered birds, lizards and plants on an island off southern California, where military exercises are held annually.

title: U.S. JUDGE SENTENCES EX-MAYOR OF ATLANTIC CITY TO 15 YEARS FOR EXTORTION
description: Former Atlantic City Mayor Michael J. Matthews was sentenced today to 15 years in prison for extortion, an unusually stiff term for a political corruption case.

title: CAMBODIAN REBELS BATTLE HANOI'S TROOPS FOR 7TH DAY
description: Artillery and small-arms fire could be heard echoing across the border from Cambodia today, where non-Communist guerrillas fought Vietnamese troops for a seventh straight day.

title: TV: 'WITCHCRAFT AMONG THE AXANDE'
description: Witchcraft Among the Azande'' is straight-on anthropology, a no-frills documentary that wants to elucidate rather than entertain. There is nothing pretentious about this, however, and ''Witchcraft Among the Azande'' is absorbing, even entertaining, on its terms. It will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: Deadline Reset By Northwest CHICAGO, Dec. 31 - Northwest Industries has agreed to
description: extend the deadline until Jan.

title: CROWN ZELLERBACH PLANS $30 MILLION WRITE-OFF
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said yesterday that it would take a pretax charge of about $30 million in the fourth quarter, largely to reflect losses it expects from timber-cutting contracts.

title: Senate Building to Get 55-Foot Calder Work
description: A 55-foot-tall sculpture by Alexander Calder is being built with private funds to fill the lobby of a Senate office building left bare by Federal budget cuts.

title: A JEWISH GROUP CRITICIZES KOCH FOR DIVISIVENESS
description: The Union of American Hebrew Congregations yesterday took Mayor Koch to task for his recent criticism of black leaders, and it called on him to proclaim ''a moratorium on racial rhetoric and polarization, beginning with himself.''

title: LAWYERS IN SHARON CASE TO SEE SECRET APPENDIX
description: Israel today agreed to allow lawyers for Time magazine and former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon to examine a secret document about the Phalangist massacre of Palestinians in Beirut, Israeli radio said tonight.

title: Credit Agreement For Mr. Gasket
description: Mr. Gasket Company said it had entered into a $75 million revolving credit with banks led by National City Bank of Cleveland and including First National Bank of Boston, Security Pacific National Bank and Texas Commerce Bank National Association.

title: GREEKS HAD A WORD FOR REGAN TAX PLAN
description: To the Editor:

title: AnthonyQuayleNamed To Receive Knighthood
description: Anthony Quayle, the 71-year-old actor renowned for his Shakespearean stage roles and for such films as ''Lawrence of Arabia,'' has been named in Queen Elizabeth II's New Year's honors list to become a knight.

title: SUCCESS AND THE DRUG SMUGGLER
description: Reflecting one day recently on two years as Commissioner of the United States Customs Service, William von Raab searched for a way to gauge his agency's achievements in drug enforcement.

title: DEVILS ARE BEATEN BY SABRES
description: Mike Foligno scored two goals and Dave Maloney had three assists as the Buffalo Sabres defeated the Devils, 6-4, tonight, handing them their fifth loss in the past six games.

title: As Always, Rich Was Better
description: It was some year. A liberal woman millionaire ran for Vice President and lost. A 73-year-old conservative millionaire actor was re-elected President. And along the elite social circuit labor leaders became so chic you couldn't have a really good party without one.

title: BEARS LOOK TO 5 KEY PLAYERS
description: The vital players for the Chicago Bears when they compete for the National Conference championship at San Francisco next Sunday will be Steve Fuller, the passer; Walter Payton, the runner; Todd (Taco) Bell, the big-play safety, and Richard Dent and Dave Hampton, the pass rushers.

title: Pouts and Snouts
description: One gloomy aspect of New Year's Eve in Washington, for Redskin fans, was the lingering memory of the unexpected defeat of their team Sunday at the hands and feet of the Chicago Bears.

title: The Empty City
description: During the year-end holidays, life in Washington is transformed in subtle and peculiar ways. Much of this is because many Government employees are from someplace else, and they go back there for Hanukkah, Christmas or New Year's.

title: VIEWS ON HOMEWORK CHALLENGED BY HARVARD
description: AN article of faith among current educational reformers is that American schoolchildren do not do enough homework. The obvious corollary is that more homework will lead to higher achievement.

title: NO JUMP SEEN IN PRICES UNDER DECONTROL OF GAS
description: After 30 years of strict Federal control, price ceilings are being removed Tuesday on about half of the nation's natural gas. But surplus supplies and falling oil prices are expected to keep consumer bills from going up.

title: BY TRAINING THE BRAIN, SCIENTISTS FIND LINKS TO IMMUNE DEFENSE
description: IN the classic experiments of the Russian

title: TUTU DRAWS CROWD IN JOHANNESBURG
description: Bishop Desmond Tutu, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, returned to an emotional homecoming in South Africa from a foreign tour tonight, saying he hoped ''that our country will be free for everyone in 1985.''

title: Underground Movement Continues, Walesa Says
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of the Solidarity movement, said today that hundreds of activists would ignore the Polish Government's amnesty offer and continue working underground.

title: Peru Rebels Said to Maul Peasant Defense Unit
description: Suspected members of the Maoist guerrilla group Shining Path, some wearing police uniforms, shot and beat to death 40 members of a peasant vigilante band in the Peruvian Andes, survivors said today.

title: Where to Send Help for Ethiopia
description: Following are some of the agencies accepting donations for famine relief in Africa. Mark checks ''African Famine Relief'' or as designated in the listing.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   In the Line of Duty
description: Ed Groger said he was not doing it

title: HARLEM CHILDREN'S ART GROUP VENTURES A SHOWCASE
description: At the Children's Art Carnival, on a quiet, tree-lined Harlem street of limestone and brownstone residences, students create collages, make pottery, learn the techniques of silk-screening and offset printing, develop a photographic eye and paint pictures.

title: THE DEBT WAS ONCE RETIRED
description: Today marks a symbolic sesquicentennial that scarcely one American in a million can identify. Nonetheless, it is an event with at least nostalgic value: 150 years ago today, the national debt was extinguished. In an age when it seems wildly improbable that the Government's annual budget will ever again show a surplus, the retirement of the national debt is a mind-stretching concept, akin to general disarmament.

title: Silverstein Is Retiring As an Editor of Times
description: Louis Silverstein, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times and the corporate art director of The New York Times Company, retired yesterday after 32 years.

title: COSMIC POWERHOUSE FINALLY SEEN IN DETAIL
description: AN object considered by many astronomers to be the most remarkable in the universe has been ''photographed'' in great detail for the first time.

title: Letter: On China Deng Has Not Deserted Marxism
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times;   Conversations of Critics
description: ENLARGING THE CHANGE. The

title: Suit Is Filed in Death Of a School Athlete
description: A $20 million lawsuit has been filed charging the city of Yonkers, its Board of Education and nine individuals with negligence in the death of a high school football player in 1983.

title: CON EDISON PLANS TO REFUND $20 MILLION TO GAS CUSTOMERS
description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York announced yesterday that it would refund $20 million to its natural- gas customers over the next three months.

title: MaorDr.King'sBirthday
description: Mayor Koch proposed yesterday that city employees give up Election Day as a paid holiday so that they could celebrate the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on Jan. 15.

title: 2-MONTH U.S. TOTAL TO HELP ETHIOPIANS REACHES $40 MILLION
description: The American public has given at least $40 million in two months for aid to starving Ethiopians, a response that exceeds any outpouring of United States aid in more than a decade, according to relief officials.

title: BRIEFING ;   Whither Whittlesey?
description: Conservative Republicans have begun to advance the name of Faith R. Whittlesey as a replacement for Jeane J. Kirkpatrick as chief United States delegate to the United Nations. Mrs. Kirkpatrick has made it known that she wants to leave the job. Mrs. Whittlesey, a conservative with an outspoken manner, has been the center of some discord in her two years as Assistant to the President for Public Liaison. In the Presidential campaign she was reportedly relieved of duties dealing with women's groups because she and other officials disagreed on tactics. Mrs. Whittlesey, 44 years old, is a lawyer and, before arriving at the White House, she was the Reagan Administration's Ambassador to Switzerland. In recent months, there have been reports that the Administration intended to appoint her to a Federal judgeship.

title: VIRGINIA'S FIELD GOAL WINS PEACH BOWL
description: Virginia's Kenny Stadlin booted a 22-yard field goal with 7 minutes 17 seconds remaining and the Cavaliers stopped Purdue's highly regarded passing attack in the second half for a 27-24 victory in the Peach Bowl today.

title: 54-YEAR-OLD GORILLA, OLDEST IN CAPTIVITY, DIES IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Massa, the oldest gorilla in captivity, died of an apparent stroke late Sunday, shortly after celebrating his 54th birthday with a special meal.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Chase Names Chairman Of Home Mortgage Unit
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had named Harry H. Hummer to the new position of chairman of its Chase Home Mortgage Corporation, its mortgage banking subsidiary.

title: Agency Rifts Hamper Export Curbs
description: From almost the first day the Reagan Administration advocated intensifying controls on high-technology exports, the enforcement agencies have been locked in heated, interagency disputes.

title: 20,000 Evacuated in Mexico
description: An overflowing reservoir forced the evacuation of 20,000 people today, and water cascading toward the Pacific coast cut off the international highway and isolated several small towns. The highway was cut south of Ciudad Obregon, 240 miles from the California border. A spokesman for the state of Sonora said troops were deployed to help the evacuees, who left their homes after the Mocuzari Dam overflowed.

title: Japan Plan On Trade
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said today that he would propose to President Reagan that consultations be started to settle problems of American-Japanese trade, which is expected to show a $30 billion surplus for Japan in 1984. Mr. Nakasone is scheduled to meet Mr. Reagan in Los Angeles on Wednesday.

title: A TENEMENT FIRE, AND THE 148 LIVES IT DISRUPTED
description: The six-story brown tenement on the corner of Park Avenue and 116th Street, in the heart of Spanish Harlem, looks like just another soon-to-be-abandoned building on a block of abandoned buildings. Sheets of metal cover the windows, a padlock hangs at the front door, the odor of smoke lingers.

title: ISRAELI OFFICIAL CRITICIZES BANK STOCK REGULATORS
description: Israel's state comptroller today harshly criticized the Government and the Bank of Israel over the collapse last year of commercial bank shares in which thousands of small investors lost their savings.

title: Bullets Faster With Williams
description: Ever since Gus Williams arrived on the pro basketball scene with the Golden State Warriors for the 1975-76 season, his coaches, and opposing coaches, have cited his rare capacity to control a game. Williams's trademarks are his unbridled speed and ability to split two defenders as he hurtles toward the basket or whips a behind-the-back pass.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Football
description: Oklahoma vs. Washington, Orange Bowl, at Miami. The winner will no doubt put in a claim for the national championship. The Sooners are ranked second in both news-agency polls, behind Brigham Young, and the Huskies are rated third by the coaches and fourth by the writers.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Coast Thrift Unit Picks Chief Officer
description: Philip R. Brinkerhoff has been elected president, chief executive and a director of Financial Corporation of Santa Barbara and its subsidiary, the Santa Barbara Savings and Loan Association.

title: Flutie Beware The Trophy Jinx
description: ''Heisman Jinx'' is an old phrase often applied to the hard luck that greets many Heisman Trophy winners once they reach professional football and fail to live up to the standard of their collegiate heroics. But the jinx - as Doug Flutie of Boston College should be aware today in the Cotton Bowl - often begins with the postseason bowl game immediately after the trophy is awarded.

title: LIFT CAR QUOTAS NOW, PAY HIGH PRICES LATER
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Held in Seizure OfHeroininJersey
description: Law-enforcement officials said today they had confiscated $16.5 million worth of heroin, the largest single seizure in the state's history, and arrested two suspected international drug traffickers.

title: MANY GIVING TO THE NEEDIEST INSTEAD OF EXCHANGING GIFTS
description: ''During this holiday season, I believe that the best thing that I can give to my own children is a gift to a child in need,'' Natalie Fenn of Woodbridge, Conn., wrote in a note accompanying a $200 donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: THIS IS HOW PEACE DREW NEAR
description: Nightmarish scenarios about the sequence of events that might plausibly lead to a superpower nuclear exchange are all too familiar by now. Much less common - indeed, virtually unheard of - are scenarios that could plausibly lead to nuclear disarmament.

title: HITLER EXPLAINS THE 1933 ELECTIONS TO THE INDUSTRIALISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: ;   THE NEED TO TAKE A MORAL STAND
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Moos, 94, Activist IndictedDuringMcCarthyEra
description: Elizabeth Moos, a peace activist who was arrested during the McCarthy era on charges of failure to register as a foreign agent, died Sunday in her apartment on Riverside Drive. She was 94 years old.

title: PUBLICITY AND MEDICINE: THE HUMAN FACTORS
description: In March 1983, in an act of intense frustration, Dr. William C. DeVries burned the diary he started keeping soon after he implanted the first permanent artificial heart in Dr. Barney B. Clark at the University of Utah in December 1982.

title: Bridge:New York's Player of Year For '84 Is a Married Couple
description: For the first time, the title of New York Player of the Year has been won jointly by a married couple. The 1984 titlists are Matthew and Pamela Granovetter, although they played quite infrequently - less frequently than any previous winners.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: BED TO VERSE Here is a challenge for those who need yet another late night directly after celebrating New Year's Eve into the wee hours. After a late sleep today, you can run over to St. Mark's Church in The Bowery, 131 East 10th Street, and sit in from 7 P.M. to 2 A.M. at the annual marathon benefit for the church's Poetry Project.

title: Computer Rule Shift
description: The Commerce Department plans to ease controls on the shipment of personal computers to the Soviet Union and other Communist countries while tightening restrictions on more sophisticated computer equipment, officials said today.

title: PETER KIHSS, REPORTER
description: Peter Kihss called himself ''just a reporter.'' But to my generation at this newspaper - and to anyone who ever saw him at his craft - he was awesome. He died last Friday night at the age of 72 of a heart that tried and failed to fell him many times but finally wore out.

title: Dynamo Wins
description: Vladimir Durdin scored a tiebreaking goal midway through the second period Sunday night, and the Soviet Union's touring Dynamo hockey club went on to a 6-2 victory over the Canadian Olympic team. It was the fourth victory in four games for the Moscow team in its 10-game exhibition tour.

title: TV SPORTS ;   DREARY WINTER, SPECTACULAR SUMMER
description: Nineteen eighty-four was an extraordinary year in American sports television, which brought two extravaganzas to the screen. One fell flat, but the other captivated the nation like almost nothing else since Lindbergh landed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, JANUARY 1, 1985
description: The Economy

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: New stores open, and close, in this city with the regularity of a heartbeat. In the past four weeks, 10 stores have opened and two are worth a detour. One may even cost you a small fortune.

title: SWITZER WARY OF 'NO. 1' TALK
description: Whether they like it or not, football coaches often remember the bad things that happened to them.

title: SUIT ENEBLES DIVERS TO SEE HIDDEN WORLD
description: IN tests off shore in California's

title: MAN TELLS POLICE HE SHOT YOUTHS IN SUBWAY TRAIN
description: A Manhattan man surrendered to the Concord, N.H., police yesterday, saying he was the gunman who wounded four teen-agers on a subway car 10 days ago, police officials said.

title: Iraq Says It Damaged Another 'Naval Target'
description: Iraq said today that its warplanes had crippled a large vessel in the Persian Gulf, but marine salvage companies in the region had no confirmation of such an attack.

title: Combustion Inc. Receives Contract
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. said it had received a contract from the Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority valued at $154 million for the design and construction of a resource recovery plant. The project is subject to financing and approval from the 33 towns it will serve in the greater Hartford area, Combustion Engineering said. If approved on schedule, the plant would begin operating in 1988 and would generate 68.5 megawatts of electricity.

title: President of Swensen's Resigns Over Dispute
description: E. Christian Schoenleb resigned yesterday as president of Swensen's Inc. following a dispute with the company's directors. Swensen's, which owns and franchises ice cream stores nationwide, named 35-year-old Patrick J. Doughty, its chief financial officer, to replace Mr. Schoenleb.

title: Eastern Extends Wage Givebacks
description: Eastern Airlines chairman, Frank Borman, told employees today that he was extending the airline's yearlong wage giveback plan because Eastern could not afford the $22 million a month it would cost to reinstate salaries.

title: Kean Approves Asbestos Funds
description: Governor Kean signed legislation today appropriating $10 million to remove asbestos from public school buildings.

title: JOCKEY'S EARNINGS PASS $12 MILLION
description: Chris McCarron, going down to the final day of the year in his duel with Angel Cordero Jr., captured the 1984 national earnings title for jockeys by riding four winners at Santa Anita today.

title: Sheryl A. Siegel Is Married To Larry Wyman, Lawyer
description: Sheryl Alyse Siegel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Siegel of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Larry Jay Wyman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Wyman of Springfield, N.J. Cantor Meir Berger officiated at the 24 Fifth Avenue Restaurant.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Interest Rates Continue Up
description: Interest rates continued rising yesterday, ending 1984 on a bearish note. But trading activity was extremely thin as the credit markets closed early in advance of the New Year's holiday.

title: Talking Businesswith Jarecki of Mocatta Metals ;   Gold's Future: Cautious View
description: When 1974 turned into 1975, there was more to celebrate than the beginning of a fresh year. It was also the start of a new financial era in the United States, for it marked the legalization of investing in gold for the first time in 41 years, and the effective birth of the American gold market.

title: Singapore Government Is Given a Younger Look
description: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew announced a new Cabinet today that consolidated the power of a group of young leaders.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Light Spirits at Fisher Hall
description: Bubbly music flowed in Avery

title: Reagan's Message of Hope
description: If you feel that 1984 was a truly Orwellian year, you are in disagreement with President Reagan. In remarks taped for delivery to the Millennium Society at its New Year's Eve party at the National Press Club Building, the President said: ''One need only to have witnessed the closing ceremonies of the Olympics, or watched as men and women flew untethered in space, to understand that in sharp contrast to Orwell's predictions, 1984 was a year of new steps forward.

title: DOLLAR SURGE DEFIES THEORIES
description: Dr. Henry G. Jarecki, chairman of the Mocatta Metals Corporation, is more cautious now about the future of gold as an investment. Page 36.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;    Tooter
description: All around midtown, that indispensable aid to the

title: Richardson Honored
description: Micheal Ray Richardson , having led the injury-plagued Nets to four victories with his all-round play, was named the player of the week in the National Basketball Association for the week ended Sunday. In those four games, Richardson averaged 28.7 points, 4.5 rebounds, 6.7 assists and 3.5 steals.

title: B.A.T Case Is Dropped WASHINGTON, Dec. 31
description: The Federal Trade

title: WRITERS' CONGRESS IN CHINA DEMANDS ARTISTIC FREEDOM
description: A congress of 800 Chinese poets, novelists and playwrights has called on the Communist Party to reject past restrictions on artistic freedom and restore China to the forefront of world culture.

title: MANY AGENCIES ARE SET UP AND NOW AND AGAIN ONE DIES
description: From the authority for the production and sale of abaca (1950-60) to the W.P.A. (1935-42), the United States Government Manual lists several score agencies and functions that have been eliminated, renamed or subsumed by other offices over 50 years.

title: MEDICAL MACHINERY MONITORED FOR HAZARDS
description: A BABY in Atlanta dies in an incubator from overheating.Three children are crushed to death by electric hospital beds. A dentist undergoing coronary bypass surgery dies when air is sucked into his bloodstream through the arterial line.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 1, 1985 International

title: Tyco's Bylaws
description: The board of directors of Tyco Laboratories Inc. changed the concern's bylaws to make a hostile takeover more difficult to accomplish. Under the new bylaws, adopted Dec. 11, a hostile takeover would require the approval of 80 percent of the company's voting stock rather than 50 percent. Irving Gutin, vice president of the fire protection, cable television and solar power concern, which is based in Exeter, N.H., said he was unaware of any efforts to take it over.

title: Bills Fans Like Flutie
description: The Bills, who have the first choice in the National Football League's draft this spring, should use it to select

title: Allegheny and NL To Sell Metal Unit
description: Allegheny International Inc. and NL Industries, partners for the last 30 years in the nation's largest integrated producer of titanium, said they would sell most of the unit to an investors' group.

title: Farmers Home
Hard Times
description: Dan and Kathy Duva were not celebrating New Year's Eve last night, even though 1985 is starting off very well indeed for the boxing promoter and his wife, with six scheduled television shows in the first month and a half.

title: ERA OF BIG SCIENCE DIMINISHES ROLE OF LONELY GENIUS
description: BORN out of the complexity of modern technology, the era of the vast, big-budget research team came into its own with its scientific achievements of 1984. The trend diminishes the impact of the lone, creative genius, who for centuries was considered the driving force behind the important revolutions of science.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;    Staying Dry
description: For those who cannot drink, New

title: NEW STATE LAWS DEAL WITH SEAT BELTS, STOVES AND A FOSSIL
description: Scores of new laws, ranging from the designation of an official state fossil to legislation affecting wood stoves, U-turns and occupational diseases go into effect Tuesday.

title: Harness-Driver Record
description: Pat Crowe broke a Canadian record and tied a North American mark by driving eight harness horses to victory Sunday at Kingston Park Raceway in Kingston, Ontario.

title: Howard McMorris 2d Weds Clare Tweedy
description: Clare Bradford Tweedy, an associate in the New York firm of Lihn & Menaker, and Howard McMorris 2d, an assistant treasurer at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, were married yesterday at the Brewster, N.Y., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Bradford Tweedy. The Rev. Robert A. Bryan, a cousin of the bride, performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Success and fame have their price.
description: Steve Fuller, the Chicago Bears' quarterback, was awakened at 4:15 A.M. yesterday by a telephone call from someone at ''Good Morning America'' who wanted him to appear on the television show. Only eight hours before, the Bears had returned to Chicago from Washington after their 23-19 playoff victory over the Redskins.

title: Court Upholds Licensing Of Coast Nuclear Plant
description: A Federal appeals court today ruled that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission acted within its power in issuing an operating license to the troubled Diablo Canyon nuclear plant in California.

title: A STEELER FORGES LINK TO PAST
description: DENVER

title: Lottery Prize Now Worthless
description: A year-old Pennsylvania lottery ticket valued at $973,000 became worthless today after its owner failed to step forward by 4:30 P.M. despite appeals by lottery officials.

title: NEW SNAGS DELAY STEEL TRADE PACT
description: The United States and the 10-nation European Common Market have hit last- minute snags in negotiating limitations on shipments of European steel pipe and tube to this country, officials on both sides said today.

title: Rebels in Sri Lanka Shoot Four as 'Traitors'
description: Separatist guerrillas have killed four youths who they said betrayed the Tamil cause, the radio reported today.

title: No Headline
description: Don't Just Bow to Mr. Nakasone President Reagan's meeting this week with Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan, like his recent meetings with the leaders of West Germany and Britain, looks to be little more than a courtesy visit. That's too bad, because there's serious business waiting to be done.

title: $20 Million Fund In
description: A total of $20 million will be paid to about 1,300 former owners of homes in the contaminated Love Canal area to settle lawsuits over chemical dumping there, a lawyer in the case said today.

title: Arson Suspect, 23, Is Found Hanged in a Westchester Jail
description: A man awaiting trial on a charge that he set fire to his family's home was found hanged in his cell in the Westchester County jail today, authorities said.

title: OLD CHICAGO AIRPORT RILES NEIGHBORS
description: Alverta E. Figari and her neighbors do not need a weatherman to tell them which way the wind is blowing.

title: A TOUGH-SENTENCING JUDGE
description: In his four years on the Federal bench, District Judge Harold A. Ackerman has been tough in sentencing wrongdoers.

title: OFFENSES ARE PREDICTABLE IN ROSE BOWL
description: Mike Tomczak and Tim Green, the opposing quarterbacks, strongly suggest what can be anticipated offensively when Ohio State and Southern California meet Tuesday in the Rose Bowl.

title: Jazz Coach Mulls Drew's Return
description: Frank Layden, the coach and general manager of the Utah Jazz, says he will consider giving John Drew another chance with the Jazz if the veteran forward can again overcome his drug and alcohol problems.

title: ISLANDER RALLY HALTED BY STARS
description: A power-play goal by Brian Bellows at 7 minutes 59 seconds of the second period gave the Minnesota North Stars the score they needed to beat the Islanders, 4-3, tonight.

title: Chicago Factions Facing Impasse on 1985 Budget
description: Mayor Harold Washington and opposition aldermen were trying to resolve an impasse over the city budget for 1985 before a midnight deadline tonight, but plans were being discussed to protect vital services if the negotiations failed.

title: 1984 Gainers and Losers on the N.Y.S.E.
description: -listed common stocks that showed the largest percentage gains and declines in 1984. Prices are adjusted for any splits, and listings include no stocks that had fewer than 1,000 shares traded or that traded for less than $2 a share.

title: BRUIN KICK SINKS MIAMI, 39-37
description: John Lee kicked a 22-yard field goal with 51 seconds left to give U.C.L.A. a 39-37 victory today over Miami in the 14th Fiesta Bowl.

title: NAZI WAR CRIMINALS INSPIRE TV MELODRAMAS
description: It was probably inevitable that news stories of the last few years regarding Nazi war criminals finding refuge in the United States would eventually inspire a batch of television movies. Now the first two of these Nazi-hunting movies have been made, not as earnest docudramas, but as pop melodramas.

title: An Unsportsmanlike Wagon
description: Oklahoma was assessed a 15-yard penalty against its Sooner Schooner covered wagon during Washington's 28-17 victory in the Orange Bowl tonight. But the Oklahoma coach, Barry Switzer, blamed the officials for a 5-yard illegal-procedure penalty that nullified a 22-yard field goal prior to the unsportsmanlike-conduct penalty against the red- and-white pony-drawn wagon.

title: SCREEN: 'SUN'S BURIAL,' EARLY OSHIMA
description: THOUGH he is considered by many critics, especially in Europe, as the most important Japanese film maker of the post-Ozu, post-Kurosawa generation, Nagisa Oshima remains relatively unknown in this country, except for ''In the Realm of the Senses'' (1976), a seriously erotic love story with patches of hard-core porn, and ''Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence'' (1983), a World War II drama in which David Bowie and Tom Conti co- star with Japanese actors.

title: Gas Victims in India Protest Payment Delays
description: More than 7,000 victims of the gas leak at the Union Carbide plant here last month blocked traffic for six hours today to protest welfare payment delays.

title: Advertising;   Jeep Gets A Bonus For Image
description: FOR an advertiser, wouldn't the

title: TAX PLAN WOULD HURT NEW YORK COMPETITIVELY
description: To the Editor:

title: CLINICAL ECOLOGY: UNCERTAIN QUANTITY
description: IF a group of physicians who call

title: CHARLES J. KENNEDY, MAGAZINE PUBLISHER WHO LED NEWSWEEK
description: Charles J. Kennedy, publisher of Town and Country magazine and former publisher of Newsweek, died of cancer on Monday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 49 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Upset by Cassidy
description: Dan Cassidy, a 23-year-old Floridian ranked No. 126 in the world, upset John Fitzgerald of Australia today, 7-6, 7-6, in the final of the Victorian Open.

title: LIFE AT TOP UNCERTAIN IN BRITISH SOCCER
description: There aren't many surprises in the names at the top of the standings as Britain's soccer teams head into the second half of their nine-month season. But week after week of inconsistent performances have deprived any of them of the right to be called a favorite for the title.

title: THE DAY OF FIRSTS: SOME ARE PAINFUL, AND SOME DELIGHT
description: Jan. 1, 1985, was Peter Powers's first day back on the track, Simone Garvey's first day without coffee and Juliana Harkavay's first day.

title: 3 FRESHMEN GET READY FOR CONGRESS
description: They will not be sworn in or put on the payroll until tomorrow, and they do not officially have offices or staffs.

title: ITALY'S YOUNG CHEFS SHOWCASE THEIR REGIONAL CUISINE
description: ''CUCINA GENUINA'' is not a new phrase in Italy, but it has been gaining fresh currency lately. Cucina genuina means cooking that is genuine, in the sense of authentic, unadulterated and natural. It also means cooking that is closely tied to the traditions of a particular region. In Italy that meaning is as manifold as the 19 separate regions into which the country is divided.

title: Ohio Minister Slain in Church
description: An 84- year-old minister was killed early today in a New Year's Eve service at a storefront church by what the police said was random gunfire from a holiday reveler on the street. The Rev. Hosea Conner, an associate minister at Rock Hill Missionary Baptist Church, was at the pulpit when a bullet struck him in the head, said Detective Robert Moore. Late tonight, a 44-year-old man who lives near the church surrendered at police headquarters and admitted to firing a weapon as part of a New Year's celebration, Mr. Moore said.

title: 1984 Gainers and Losers on the Amex
description: Amex-listed common stocks that showed the largest percentage gains and declines in 1984. Prices are adjusted for any splits, and listings include no stocks that had fewer than 1,000 shares traded or that traded for less than $2 a share.

title: FORCEFUL JAPANESE LEADER
description: Over lunch with American reporters at his official residence last week, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone suddenly began talking about his personal political style. It is ''presidential'' rather than ''parliamentary,'' he said. The implication seemed to be that, unlike most of the 15 other Prime Ministers of postwar Japan, he preferred to take direct charge of government rather than to wait for broad political agreement to develop slowly on issues.

title: LURING A WARY STEER TO ITS LAST JOURNEY
description: Roy Reed, a former New York Times reporter, teaches journalism at the University of Arkansas in Fayetteville, and farms.

title: SOVIET SAID TO PUT MIG-23'S IN VIETNAM
description: Thailand's National Security Council chief says the Soviet Union has stationed 14 MIG-23 fighter-interceptors at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam, the first such advanced planes to be based in the region.

title: WASHONGTON ABORTION CLINIC DAMAGED BY BOMB
description: A bomb exploded outside a Washington abortion clinic today just after midnight, causing extensive damage but no deaths or injuries.

title: Mrs. Church Urged to Run
description: Bethine Church, widow of former Senator Frank Church, is being urged by friends and Democratic activists to run in 1986 for the Idaho seat her husband held for 24 years. She says her present inclination is to explore the idea over the next year, trying to determine how much support she would have as a candidate, both in the party and the state, and whether she would face primary competition.

title: OPTIMISM GIVES WAY TO CAUTION ON STOCKS
description: Stock market investors are edging into 1985 as they cast nervous backward glances at 1984 - a puzzling and disappointing year for equities - and wonder if history will repeat itself. Thus, contrary to the usual start-of- the-year optimism, caution reigns as the operative word on Wall Street.

title: Peter Serkin Concert
description: The pianist Peter Serkin will appear with the Los Angeles Philharmonic on Jan. 19 at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues. Tickets range from $10 to $20. Information: (718) 434-1900.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 2, 1985 International

title: 49ERS ARE CONCERNED BY BEAR PASS RUSH
description: In their favorite pass-rushing formation, the Chicago Bears do something no other team in the National Football League does. They line up all three of their linebackers on the side across from the tight end and bring the strong safety, Todd Bell, close to the line on the other side.

title: Chopped Liver by the Bay
description: For several days, Mayor Koch fantasized about a feast from San Francisco, the payoff on a bet with San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein that the Giants would beat the 49ers in the National Football League playoffs last Saturday.

title: A MADISON DECANTER STIRS TEAPOT TEMPEST
description: An antiques collector who paid $1,100 for a wine decanter that he says was used by three of the earliest Presidents has raised the ire of the White House curator, whose bid of $4,350 was lost in a mix-up.

title: People
San Francisco St. To Forfeit Games
description: San Francisco State must forfeit three football games because two players were ineligible, the Northern California Athletic Conference said today.

title: 500 Guests Flee a Hotel Fire, Called Suspicious by Officials
description: Five hundred New Year's guests were evacuated into the predawn cold today when a four-alarm fire broke out in a 73-year-old hotel here.

title: RAY BRADBURY FANTASY A 'WONDERWORKS' FILM
description: ONE of the more substantial series devised for public television this season is ''Wonderworks,'' a family entertainment project put together by five production centers outside New York. The weekly schedule has ranged from accomplished original productions such as ''Booker,'' a dramatization of Booker T. Washington's youth, to worthwhile acquisitions such as the two half-hour films that can be seen on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: IRT SUSPECT IS CHARGED AS FUGITIVE
description: The man who told the Concord, N.H., police Monday that he shot four teen-agers on a Manhattan subway train last month was charged yesterday as a fugitive, police officials said.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jim Donnan, who was dismissed as an assistant football coach at the University of Missouri and then rehired, is leaving Missouri to become offensive coordinator for Oklahoma. . . . The Washington Capitals recalled the goalie

title: Rita Mannheimer Wed To Donald N. Stolper
description: The Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Rita P. Mannheimer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Mannheimer of Bethesda, Md., to Donald N. Stolper, the son of the late Maurice and Mae Stolper of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Louis C. Gerstein performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Arthur Koret, the bridegroom's foster father.

title: Young Fighters
description: Boxing has always been very, very good to ESPN, the 24-hour sports cable television network. But then, ESPN has been kind to boxing, running television's only regular weekly ring show, in association with Bob Arum's Top Rank promotional company.

title: 450 Passengers Stranded In Dallas and Chicago
description: Nearly 450 passengers were stranded at two airports when crew shortages at American Airlines forced the cancellations of at least 275 flights, airline officials said.

title: A NEW 'CONTRA' PROBLEM STARTS
description: Sometimes in Central America, you wonder who hates the Americans more - their allies or their enemies. It doesn't matter whether or not you agree with United States policy in the region - I certainly do not - but you can't help observing that the Americans are often as disliked by their allies as by their adversaries.

title: FLUTIE PASSES FOR 3 SCORES AS BOSTON COLLEGE WINS
description: Doug Flutie had said it for days: ''I want to end my college career with an exclamation mark in the Cotton Bowl.''

title: Singapore Economy Up
description: Singapore's economy grew an estimated 8.5 percent in 1984, but is likely to slow next year as growth slows in the United States, Japan and other nations, Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew said today.

title: ASSESSING TECHNOLOGY LEAKS
description: Two years ago, a group of Boy Scouts walking along the beach in the State of Washington spotted a red-and- white sphere bobbing in the water. On its sides, written in Russian and English, was the phrase ''USSR Academy of Sciences,'' suggesting that it was an innocuous research buoy.

title: Markets Closed Stock and commodity markets, banks and Government
description: offices were closed yesterday

title: Arnold P. Rubin Weds Ann Fleisher Hoffman
description: Ann Fleisher Hoffman, counsel for the New York, New Jersey and New England district of the Communications Workers of America, and Arnold Perry Rubin, an assistant Nassau County district attorney, were married yesterday. Rabbi Elizabeth Rolle, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at the Food Business, caterers in Manhattan.

title: OPERA: METROPOLITAN IN STRAUSS'S 'ARIADNE'
description: NEW Year's Eve is sometimes treated as a jolly throwaway by our major classical-music institutions - an occasion for beery (or champagny) good cheer at which any serious artistic intentions are postponed to the new year. Not so Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera, however: the company brought back its old (1962) but still honorable production of Richard Strauss's ''Ariadne auf Naxos,'' cast it lavishly and made it into one of the company's triumphant evenings of the season.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 2, 1985

title: INDUSTRIAL RISE SEEN SLOWING
description: The economy will be somewhat less vigorous, but most industries will expand output and earn higher profits in 1985, the Commerce Department said Monday in an annual report on the industrial outlook.

title: JERSEY'S RULES ON GUARDIANS FOR THE RETARDED ARE UPHELD
description: The Appellate Division of Superior Court has upheld state regulations that allow a caseworker to become the guardian of a mentally retarded child and has dismissed an argument by the Public Advocate that the rules interfere with parental rights.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Boston Celtics, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The Nets are hoping to have some healthy bodies back for this game, and they'll need them.

title: IN ONE YEAR, SAHARA ENGULFS MUCH OF CHAD
description: The Sahara has been extending its desert barrenness southward at the rate of 6 to 12 miles a year for more than a decade, gradually incorporating the Sahel, the semiarid belt at its southern fringe.

title: Eastern 727 Is Missing On a Flight to Bolivia
description: An Eastern Airlines flight from Asuncion, Paraguay, to La Paz, Bolivia, with 33 people aboard was more than five hours overdue, and a ground search was launched for the missing jet, airline officials said early today.

title: SEYMOUR PECK, TIMES EDITOR FOR 32 YEARS, KILLED IN CRASH
description: Seymour Peck, an editor of The New York Times for 32 years, was killed early yesterday when the car he was driving was hit head on by a car traveling the wrong way on the Henry Hudson Parkway.

description: Total share volume on the American Stock Exchange for each year

description: William H. Kolberg, president of the National Alliance of Business, writing in the group's monthly publication, Work America:

title: DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST CASES EXPRESS THEIR DESIRE TO SHARE
description: The holiday season is a time of sharing,'' wrote Mrs. Charles T. Mederrick of Roslyn, L.I., expressing the spirit of solidarity that many people feel at this time of the year.

title: DATES TO REMEMBER
description: -five marks the 40th anniversary of two important dates in the history of U.S.-Soviet relations: the end of the Second World War and the beginning of the United Nations' long, tormented search for peace.

title: Ties and Symbolism
description: Will ties be the yuppie symbol of

title: Wet Weather of 1984 Helped Tower of Pisa
description: Unusually wet weather last year stabilized the subsoil under the leaning tower of Pisa and reduced its additional tilt to 0.019 inch off the vertical compared with an annual average of 0.047 inch, officials said today.

title: Northeast Jersey Adds 100,000 Jobs
description: employment in New Jersey reached a record level of nearly 3.4 million jobs in November, an increase of more than 100,000 over the year before, Federal and state officials have announced.

title: Phibro-Salomon Coup Gives Gutfreund Reins
description: On Wall Street the appointment of John H. Gutfreund as sole head of Phibro-Salomon was seen as a major executive coup.

title: A.T.&T. to Consolidate Its Consumer Business
description: As a result of the divestiture and reorganization, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company finds itself with three agencies all working in its consumer products area.

title: Spoken Too Soon
description: It may have been a classic case of hubris on ice.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday misstated the date that the boxer Tony Ayala Jr. was arrested. It was New Year's Day 1983.

title: Market Place;   Mixed View Of Gas Stock
description: WHEN the Texas Oil and Gas Corporation reported some time ago that profits for its fiscal year ended Aug. 31, 1984, rose 17 percent, to $1.65 a share, management noted that this marked the 27th consecutive year of record earnings.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: EVERY now and then a ray of rationality breaks through the unfathomable bureaucracy of the forces that rule our lives. Consider a young woman we know, who, late one recent night, was in Grand Central Terminal, urgently in need of making a long-distance call. The problem was she had only a $50 bill, no coins and no wish to reverse the charge. The solution seemed simple: charge the call to her own Manhattan telephone. She dialed 0, followed by the long distance number, bringing her into direct contact with the voice of New York Telephone.

title: One-Act Comic Plays Presented in Repertory
description: Eight one-act comic plays will be presented in repertory by Manhattan Punch Line beginning Jan. 19 at 8 P.M. at the Judith Anderson Theater, 422 West 42d Street.

title: SENIORS STRENGTHEN BIG EAST
description: One question circulating among the region's college basketball fans this fall was which of the Big East's weaker teams would crack the conference's upper echelon before March.

title: Topics ;   Homeless at Home and Abroad ;   Room at the InnThree words describe the Sudan: poor, huge and generous. This largest of African nations, a third the size of the continental United States, has trouble feeding its own 22 million people. Yet with international help it has fed and sheltered more than a million refugees from Chad, Uganda, Zaire and now Ethiopia.
description: Fleeing war and starvation, they come by foot, camel and donkey.

title: Quick Thinking
description: Jerry Berndt has won the Ivy League football title in three of his four years as the Penn coach. Whether or not that record suggests, among other things, an ability at quick thinking on the sidelines, it was certainly a matter of quick thinking that limited the severity of an injury the other day at Berndt's suburban Philadelphia home.

title: ROME'S MAGISTERIUM
description: To the Editor:

title: GOAL OF RHODE ISLAND LEADER: ECONOMIC REVIVAL
description: A few blocks from the stage where Edward D. DiPrete today became Rhode Island's Governor stands an old red- brick mill that was recently converted into offices for small high-technology companies.

title: PANEL FAVORS CUT IN NEW YORK DEBT
description: Before cutting taxes, New York State should start to pay off a short-term debt that has grown to more than $4 billion, the Citizens Budget Commission said yesterday.

title: Not 'Worth,' Maybe, but Equity
description: There's been a storm of confusion in the last year about something called ''comparable worth.'' That's been the slogan of those who think men and women performing nominally different jobs should receive equal pay if those jobs are of ''comparable'' value to an employer. The idea has become so controversial that the phrase itself is probably no longer useful.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No country can now develop by closing its door. We suffered from this and our forefathers suffered from this.

title: Richard L. Stroup Married To Jane Steidemann Shaw
description: Jane Steidemann Shaw, a senior writer at the Political Economy Research Center in Bozeman, Mont., and Richard L. Stroup, a professor of economics at Montana State University, were married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in Bozeman. The Rev. John McGrory performed the ceremony, assisted by the bride's father, the Rev. Arthur R. Steidemann, also an Episcopal priest.

title: Topics ;   Homeless at Home and Abroad ;   One Night a Month
description: To help the homeless, most New Yorkers think in terms of money, whether by donating a few dollars' worth of canned goods or supporting a billion-dollar program of low-income housing. Yet right now there's also an urgent need for contributions of another kind: time.

title: Capitol Hill's Job Market
description: Speaking of the impending session, new members are currently filling 2,000 Senate and House staff openings that were created in the offices of lawmakers who retired or were defeated. One of the most popular and realistic self- help books for those seeking to fill those openings is ''Capitol Jobs: An Insider's Guide to Finding a Job in Congress.''

title: STEEL INDUSTRY AWAITS BETTER TIMES
description: Although the economy appears to be reviving, the nation's depressed steel industry is still waiting to enjoy the benefits. .

title: CLOUDS OF DOUBT OVER SWEDEN'S GARDEN OF EDEN
description: The Tower of Babel stood in Uppsala, and wandering Swedes spread order and civilization afar. Greek goddesses were really Swedish women who had trekked south, their language becoming the tongue of perfection, the vernacular in paradise.

title: A NO-BOTHER SEAT BELT HAS BEEN DESIGNED
description: To the Editor:

title: BABY, HAIL ME A CAB
description: Dear Maggie: Mom and I are delighted you can get to New York for a few days and bring Koko, and no - don't be silly - of course we don't think you were silly to name the baby Koko. As I told your mother last night, Koko is a perfect name for a 2-month-old baby. Anyhow, weird names are all the rage these days.

title: Mental Health for Flatbush, Too A psychiatrist is a fully trained medical doctor who specializes in mental illness. In New York City a psychiatrist's service now costs $80 an hour or more. Yet many mental health problems don't call for that level of care or expense. Those arising from marital troubles, a child's difficulty in school or a crisis at work may require no more than a few months of sessions with a psychiatric social worker, who charges less than half as much.
description: Despite the need, access to the more affordable therapy in New York has been limited because psychiatrists, insurers and business groups held up legislation to require medical insurance to cover social workers' fees. Governor Cuomo, however, has faced down the lobbyists and signed such a requirement into law.

title: HOLIDAY CARD RATE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ''EMERGENCY,'' the title tune on the latest album from Kool and the Gang, describes a ''serious love reaction.'' The group's lead vocalist, James Taylor, pleads, ''I need your love . . . this is an emergency.'' But this isn't the only emergency the nine- man group from Jersey City is concerned with. ''There's a real emergency, a crisis in American education,'' says the group's bassist and spokesman, Robert (Kool) Bell. ''And the United Negro College Fund is trying to do something about it.''

title: Tremor Near Palm Springs
description: A mild earthquake tonight struck the area where President Reagan is spending the New Year's holiday, but there were no reports of injury or damage. The earthquake struck about 9:27 P.M. and measured 4.1 on the Richter scale, according to the seismological laboratory at the California Institute of Technology. Police dispatchers said the quake was hardly noticeable but said that they had received several calls.

title: Cotton Bowl Gets 5 Marks
description: Five records were set today in the 49th Cotton Bowl, won by Boston College over Houston, 45-28.

title: NEW HEMINGWAY BOOK ON MATADORS
description: In the late summer of that year, 1960, Life magazine published three consecutive installments of ''The Dangerous Summer,'' excerpts from a lengthy manuscript by Ernest Hemingway. The complete book, Life said in a preface, ''will be published by Scribner's next year.''

title: TAX PLAN IS ALREADY ALTERING SOME MARKETS IN REAL ESTATE
description: Despite its uncertain fate, the Treasury's tax simplification plan is having a chilling effect on some real estate investments as economists predict that the plan, if enacted, would depress home values and make many types of new construction unprofitable.

title: 'Very Ragged'
description: DALLAS

title: ABOUT PHILADELPHIA
description: The weather delivered a crushing blow to 15,000 Mummers and the hundreds of thousands of Philadelphians when it prompted a postponement of their traditional New Year's Day parade.

title: Trial Is Ruled Fair Despite Shackles
description: The Connecticut Supreme Court has ruled that a Somers prison inmate received a fair trial despite having to wear leg shackles during a portion of the jury selection.

title: NEW ROLE FOR EMPLOYEE PLANS
description: The idea behind an employee stock ownership plan, or ESOP, is straightforward: Give workers a major block of stock in their company and it will foster corporate loyalty, improve labor-management relations and ultimately help profits.

title: Theater's 18th Season
description: The American premiere of ''Orinoco,'' by the Mexican playwright Emilio Carballido, will open the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater's 18th season on Jan. 9 at at its new location, 304 West 47th Street.

title: New Partner
description: A little-known tennis player is certain to earn some measure of fame as

title: Economic Scene;   Finding Fault With Economists
description: ''WHATEVER economics was in the past,'' Sir Alec Cairncross, a distinguished British economist, told the American Economic Association in Dallas last week, ''it is now virtually an industry.'' It stretches from the building of models by the theorists, to the supply of advice, forecasts, and programs by the practitioners who cater to policymakers in business and government.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Joseph Scott, of 1385 Fifth Avenue in Harlem, died of two gunshot wounds in the stomach early yesterday, the police said. Michael Peterson, 35 years old, who lived in the same building as Mr. Scott, was charged with shooting him in a hallway at 70 Lenox Avenue in Harlem . . . . Michael Robinson, 20, of 54 Rogers Avenue in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, was stabbed once in the chest and killed at his home early yesterday during an altercation.

title: Five Die in Alaska Crash
description: A tractor-trailer collided with a minibus taking eight passengers to work at an oilfield today, killing five of the workers and injuring three others, state troopers said.

title: RAOUL PENE DU BOIS, DESIGNER FOR BROADWAY AND MOVIES
description: Raoul P ene du Bois, a theatrical set and costume designer who created visual excitement for dozens of Broadway shows and twice won a Tony award, died following a stroke yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: Knapp's Empire Crumbles
description: Charles W. Knapp, former chairman and chief executive officer of the Financial Corporation of America, had long been lauded as one of the most innovative savings and loan executives. That praise, however, disappeared last summer, as his company, which had moved too far, too fast, started crumbling around him.

title: TOWN FEARS U.S. PLAN FOR LAND SWAP
description: When friends come to southern Utah for a visit with Ward and Gloria Roylance, their hosts take them first to a knoll of Federal land just west of town, where Highway 24 makes a little rise.

title: YOUTH-RUN COURTS IN STATE GROWING BEYOND NOVELTIES
description: The 14-year-old boy was walking rapidly up the main street here, Broadway, with two older youths and a stolen hot-water heater, when the police arrested them.

title: TOWN BATTLES MILITARY DRAFT IN NICARAGUA
description: Piles of rocks at several street corners are all that remain of the barricades residents erected last Thursday to prevent Sandinista army recuiters from entering this country town.

title: AUTHORS SEEK PAY FOR LOAN OF BOOKS
description: American writers' groups have started a campaign to persuade Congress to study the possibility of paying authors with Government funds when their books are loaned from public libraries, a practice that is already in effect in 10 countries.

title: WINE TALK
description: ROBERT MONDAVI is one of those people who transcend the relatively limited fields in which they make their mark. Thousands who may never drink his or any other wines think of him when they think of California wine. There are people in California who make more wine and there are people in California who from time to time make better wine. But none of them have achieved Mr. Mondavi's stature as an innovator, as a leader, as a generous teacher and dedicated proselytizer, not just of his own wines but of all the wines of California.

title: POPE SAYS ARMS TALKS ARE A 'BEAM OF HOPE'
description: Pope John Paul II today called the arms talks between the United States and the Soviet Union planned for next week ''a beam of hope on the horizon of the world'' and urged the two nations to realize that ''they share the same risk.''

title: O'Neill Recommends New Democratic Chief
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill has recommended that Representative Timothy J. Moynihan of East Hartford be named Democratic state chairman.

title: IF DOG SEEKS CHIC, MAN IS BEST PAL
description: DOG may be man's best friend, but frequently it's man who comes in pretty handy when a pooch needs a pal.

title: HOBNOBBING IN PALM SPRINGS
description: It is an annual rite of winter: President Reagan leaves Washington and reappears here where the desert and the mountains share the landscape with more than 50 golf clubs and more than 7,000 swimming pools.

title: SHIFTING PHONES TO 2 AREA CODES DELAYED IN CITY
description: The partitioning of New York City into two telephone area codes, scheduled to take effect officially yesterday, will not be completed until this weekend or later, officials of the New York Telephone Company said yesterday.

title: NEW GOVERNOR AN ANOMALY IN DEMOCRATIC RHODE ISLAND
description: ''A lot of people tell me there's no such thing as an Italian-American Catholic Republican in Rhode Island,'' Edward D. DiPrete likes to joke.

title: NEW RAINCOATS: SHINY, BRIGHT
description: ASK a woman at any time of the year to name the most useful item in her wardrobe and the chances are, after shoes, she will say, ''My raincoat.'' Still, spring is the time when most raincoats are purchased, in deference to the proverbial April showers, and because of the need for a good lightweight coat that can go over spring clothes.

title: FIRE DETSROYS A MUSEUM AND KITCHEN OF FIRST TOLL HOUSE COOKIE
description: A New Year's Eve fire reduced a museum here to charred remains and destroyed millions of dollars in paintings, art objects and manuscripts, including letters by Lincoln and Dickens.

title: THE CONSERVATION CORPS IS ABOUT JOBS
