title: U.S. IS PRESSING TEMPORARY JOBS IN A NEW POLICY
description: In a policy that takes effect Wednesday, the Reagan Administration is encouraging Federal agencies to hire temporary employees because they receive fewer fringe benefits and can be dismissed much more easily than career Civil Service workers.

title: RELIEF AND RECOMPENSE IN THE BHOPAL DISASTER
description: To the Editor: The newsworthy speed with which some of our celebrated lawyers have embraced the cause of the unfortunate families of the Bhopal disaster should not be regarded as a sign of profes

title: Grinspun Gets Pact
description: A few months after Argentina's fledgling democratic Government took office in December 1983, Economics Minister Bernardo Grinspun said his country needed a new ''Marshall Plan'' to pull itself out of the economic and financial morass left by eight years of military rule.

title: Demotion of Ogarkov Is Confirmed by Soviet
description: The Soviet Union has confirmed the demotion of Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, who was ousted in September as Chief of the General Staff. According to the latest information from Moscow, he has become a political commissar.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A Wealth of Information

title: NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE ISSUES
description: Most Active N.Y.S.E. Issues in 1984

title: Nigerian Military Orders Release of 2,551 Inmates
description: Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari said today that his military Government had ordered the release of 2,551 prison inmates, including 144 political prisoners, to mark the first anniversary of a military coup.

title: Continental Bank Crisis Tested Isaac, Agency
description: When the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company teetered on the edge of insolvency last May, few felt dizzier than William M. Isaac, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: N.Y.S.E. Volume
description: Total share volume on the New York Stock Exchange for each year

title: AVOIDING A COLLISION WITH JAPAN
description: When Japan's Prime Minister, Yasuhiro Nakasone, met President Reagan two years ago in Washington, the subject most requiring their attention was the same as it is now: trade. There was much resentment in America over Japan's substantial trade surplus. Since then, matters have deteriorated: the Japanese trade surplus with the United States has doubled.

title: DOW STOOPS TO CALM CONGRESS AND PUBLIC OPINION
description: Events in the nation's capital can have a profound impact on a big, powerful and aloof corporation even when such events have little to do directly with laws and regulations.

title: Odds Favor 49ers
description: The Cowboys were long regarded as first in the hearts of the nation's small bettors, who for years wagered so much on them that the pointspread of a given week's game was frequently tilted toward Dallas in a manner inconsistent with the quality of that week's opponent. But, if word coming out of Nevada yesterday was any guide, it may be time to crown a new champion: the San Francisco 49ers.

title: Fighting Over Spoils
description: When the brand-new 99th Congress officially convenes tomorrow, House Republicans are expected to begin protesting about their share of committee seats. Their numerical argument is simple and compelling: after the November elections, the Democrats have 58 percent of the House but they have already assigned themselves 61 percent of the Appropriations Committee, 64 percent of the Ways and Means Committee and 69 percent of the Rules Committee, the three most powerful committees in the House.

title: 1984 O.T.C. Gainers and Losers
description: Over-the-counter common stocks that showed the largest percentage gains and declines in 1984. Prices are adjusted for any splits, and listings include no stocks that had fewer than 1,000 shares traded or that traded for less than $2 a share.

title: PHILHARMONIC: STRAUSS
description: THE New York Philharmonic saw the old year out in traditional fashion Monday evening with a progrm of Mozart, Kreisler, Saint-Sa"ens, and Opuses 214, 257, 314, 354, 362, 373, 410 and 437 of Johann Strauss Jr.

description: MARKING TIME

title: DENG ASSERTS TIES TO WEST ARE VITAL TO FIGHT POVERTY
description: China's pre-eminent leader, Deng Xiaoping, has told fellow Communist Party officials that his ''open door'' policy to the West is the only way to overcome the legacy of ''poverty, backwardness and ignorance'' the country brought on itself by hundreds of years of isolation.

title: HIJACKER, ALONE IN JET RESTROOM, EMERGED WITH GUN, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: A convicted murderer used a hidden pistol to hijack an airliner to Cuba Monday night, a Virgin Islands prison official said yesterday.

title: U.S. Restricts Alaska Fishing
description: The United States is cutting by more than half the amount of fish that Japanese, Korean and other foreign fleets can take in United States-claimed waters off Alaska, the State Department said.

title: All Is Well
description: Amid all the hoopla of New Year's Eve celebrating, the basic agreement between baseball's club owners and the Major League Baseball Players Association quietly expired at midnight Monday.

title: JACKSON WEIGHS MIDDLE EAST TRIP TO SEEK RELEASE OF ABDUCTED MEN
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that he was considering making another trip to the Middle East, this time to seek the release of three Americans kidnapped by gunmen on the sidewalks of Beirut.

description: DALLAS

title: POSTAL SAVINGS SYSTEM IN JAPAN MAY CHANGE
description: Japan's mammoth postal savings system, which for decades has financed industrial growth and Government deficits, is facing pressure to change from officials at home and abroad.

title: CURBS SET BY AUSTRIA HELP U.S.
description: The Austrian Parliament has approved legislation enabling it to stop illegal shipments of United States technology to Soviet bloc countries.

title: YEMEN TRIES TO PRESERVE CHARMS OF OLD CITY
description: Inside the mudbrick walls of this ancient capital, a narrow passageway leads to an inauspicious dwelling. Inside the lantern-lit cave of a house, a 400-year-old oil press slowly revolves, turned by a camel.

title: Bridge:Computer Programs to Vie In Tournament Next Week
description: The first-ever contest between bridge-playing computer programs will be staged in New York City next week. It will begin at 7.30 P.M. Tuesday at the Midway Club, 97- 13 64th Road, Rego Park, Queens.

title: Careers;   Age Bias Varies By Field
description: BIAS against hiring people who are age 50 or over has not died, according to Wesley Poriotis, the 40-year-old chairman of Wesley Brown & Bartle Company, a New York company that specializes in management recruiting for the communications industry.

title: WASHINGTON RALLIES TO OVERCOME OKLAHOMA
description: The Washington Huskies bumbled their way to an exciting but messy 28-17 victory over Oklahoma in the Orange Bowl tonight, but may have lost their chance for the final No. 1 college football ranking.

description: 1.*Tropical Glitter

title: SOVIET IS HOPEFUL BUT CAUTIOUS ON NEW U.S. TALKS
description: The planned resumption next week of discussions about arms limitation has raised hopes among Russians for improved relations with the United States. But Soviet officials appear to be approaching the talks cautiously.

title: A CALIFORNIA FARM WITH ROOTS IN JAPAN
description: Amanda Mayer Stinchecum is a writer and art historian who specializes in Japanese textiles.

title: CHICAGO BUDGET SET AFTER WEEKS OF CONFLICT
description: A compromise $1.9 billion city budget was adopted by the City Council Monday night just hours before a midnight deadline and after weeks of confrontation between Mayor Harold Washington and his opponents on the Council.

title: LEAKS OF URANIUM DUST AN OHIO ISSUE
description: In the midst of a controversy over leaks of radioactive dust at a uranium processing center, the company that manages the center for the Federal Government has decided not to bid to renew its contract, according to the Department of Energy and a company official.

title: KEPPING THINGS HANDY
description: A GOOD cook is an organized cook, whether in a professional or home setting. Before preparing a dish it is always advisable to have all the ingredients within arm's reach.

title: Dismissal Comes As a Surprise
description: Ralph Baker says he is not bitter, but he does admit to being ''shocked'' that his five-year tenure as the Jets' linebacker coach ended suddenly last week.

title: CLARK TO RESIGN HIS CABINET POST TO RETURN HOME
description: Secretary of the Interior William P. Clark has told President Reagan that he intends to resign to return to his ranch in California, a White House spokesman said tonight.

title: Surplus Grows In Connecticut
description: The projected budget surplus for the state has grown $63 million since November, to more than $188 million, state officials said.

title: Fewer Whistles
description: Coach

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHILE there are fads, fashions and vogues in food, there are also dishes that have been with us for a hundred years and never go out of style. I can readily recall the mashed potatoes my mother prepared in Burgundy: They were feather light and velvety, though she did nothing special other than put hot milk and freshly churned butter in them.

title: Egypt Confirms Plan To Free Coptic Leader
description: The Government officially announced today that Pope Shenuda III, patriarch of the Coptic Orthodox Church, would be allowed to resume his duties and leave the desert monastery to which he was banished three years ago.

title: CAPITALS ROLL, 5-1
description: Bob Carpenter scored two goals today, giving him 30 for the season, as the streaking Washington Capitals defeated the Boston Bruins, 5-1.

description: Suspense hung in the air yesterday

title: SOUTHERN CAL STOPS OHIO STATE, 20-17
description: Southern Cal blunted a fourth-quarter threat by Ohio State with less than a minute remaining and held on for a 20-17 upset victory in the 71st Rose Bowl today.

title: Knox Is Staying
description: With their loss to the Miami Dolphins last Saturday, the Seattle Seahawks' season was a thing of the past.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE: 1984'S NEWSMAKERS IN FINANCE ;   Regan on Defensive Over Tax Proposal
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan has been on the offensive most of the year against the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker. But he found the tables turned recently when he presented his proposal to overhaul the nation's tax system.

title: Chemical Leak Stopped; 2,500 Return to Homes
description: About 2,500 people were allowed to return to their homes here today after railroad workers sealed a tank car that was leaking a volatile and toxic chemical.

title: Malone's 30 Points Help 76ers Triumph
description: Moses Malone scored 12 of his game- high 30 points in the fourth quarter as the Philadelphia 76ers held on to defeat the Portland Trail Blazers, 111- 106, Tuesday night.

title: REAGAN CONFERS ON ARMS STAND
description: President Reagan and his top foreign policy advisers completed discussions today on the United States position in arms control talks with the Soviet Union next week in Geneva.

title: How to Honor Dr. King
description: Congress designated Jan. 15 as a holiday to honor the memory of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., bringing to 10 the number of annual paid holidays for Federal civilian employees. New York City's workers already celebrate 11 holidays, giving City Hall good reason to question a request for another, even for so laudable a purpose.

title: Israel Announces Offer On Palestinian's Burial
description: Israel made public today an offer to allow a leading Palestine Liberation Organization official to be buried in the occupied West Bank in return for the repatriation of four Israeli soldiers reported missing in Lebanon.

title: REAGAN IN DISPUTE WITH CONGRESS ON LAW FOR REVIEW OF BIDS
description: The White House and Congress are in a dispute over a law that authorizes the General Accounting Office to review whether Government contracts have been properly awarded.

title: TELEPHONE REMINDER
description: New York City is now divided into two telephone area codes: 212 (Manhattan and the Bronx) and 718 (Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island). The area code is

title: NOTABLE PERFORMANCES OF 1984 ON WALL STREET
description: For most investors, 1984 is likely to be remembered as a trying year: Hardly the best of times, but with the Dow Jones industrial average down a little less than 4 percent, far from the worst.

title: NEBRASKA RALLIES TO DOWN L.S.U., 28-10
description: The dramatic changes in two passing games - Nebraska's success and Louisiana State's sudden failure in the second half - changed the direction of the 51st Sugar Bowl and gave the Cornhuskers a 28-10 victory over the Tigers tonight.

title: China Deal For Burroughs
description: The Burroughs Corporation has signed a $20 million agreement for the assembly of desk-top business computers at a factory in southern China, the company said. The contract was signed Dec. 28 in Kunmingby representatives of Burroughs, the Yunnan Province Import-Export Corporation, the Yunnan Electronic Equipment Factory and the Peking Ever Bright Industrial Corporation.

title: BUILT TO ACCOMMODATE NATURALLY ROCKY SITES
description: BUILT in a century that romanticized nature, and on a promontory over the Hudson River that had imposing rock formations, the houses of Park Hill took every advantage of the rock on their sites.

title: 4 Governors in Accord On Radioactive Waste
description: Governors from Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Delaware and Maryland have agreed to a compact for the disposal of low-level radioactive waste, Gov. Dick Thornburgh announced today.

title: SANDINISTA SAYS REBELS FAIL TO BLOCK COFFEE CROP
description: Bureaucratic problems within the Sandinista Government have harmed the Nicaraguan coffee harvest more than rebel attacks, a senior Sandinista official said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday about the University of Washington football team misstated its pre-bowl ranking in a news-agency poll. It was ranked third by United Press International but fourth by The Associated Press.

title: Flash Elorde Is Dead at 49;Held Boxing Title in the 60's
description: Gabriel (Flash) Elorde, a Filipino who rose from poverty to become world junior- lightweight boxing champion in the 1960's, died in a suburban hospital early today. He was 49 years old and had suffered from lung cancer for seven months.

title: MEMPHIS ST. WINS AS LEE SCORES 26
description: Keith Lee scored 26 points and grabbed 12 rebounds tonight to lead Memphis State to a 73-61 victory over Delta State.

title: Quiche Grows in Ridgewood
description: A year ago, the idea of quiche being offered by restaurants and cafes in Ridgewood, Queens, was just one among the many dreams of trendiness Paul Kerzner harbored for his working-class neighborhood.

title: CASTLE & COOKE TO SELL BUMBLE BEE
description: Castle & Cooke Inc., the marketer of Dole pineapples and bananas and Bumble Bee tuna, agreed yesterday to sell most of the assets of Bumble Bee Seafoods to a group of investors that includes four managers of the seafood processor.

title: I.B.M. Reported To Lend $6 Million
description: Computer Memories Inc., the sole supplier of hard disk drives for the International Business Machines Corporation's PC-AT computer, has reportedly received a $6 million loan from I.B.M. to help it stay viable.

title: GLUTSMANSHIP
description: WASHINGTON The most important price in the

title: Columbus Circle To Be Acquired
description: Thomson McKinnon Inc. said it would buy Columbus Circle Investors, the unit of Gulf and Western Industries that acts as the asset manager for the company's pension and employee benefit plans. Columbus Circle would continue as principal manager for the Gulf and Western benefit plans and would seek other tax-advantaged asset management accounts, the company said.

title: Most Ethiopian Jews Reported Now in Israel
description: A majority of the estimated 25,000 Jews in Ethiopia, known as the Falashas, are now in Israel, an Israeli official said in an interview published today.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: Mulch City
description: Alas, the holiday season is over. The sidewalks are laden with abandoned Christmas trees lying forlornly on their sides, awaiting the garbage truck.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
DONORS TO THE FUND FOR NEEDIEST CASES FONDLY RECALL CITY
description: An enduring affection for New York City, among former residents and visitors alike, inspires many contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Apollo Cuts Prices On Work Stations
description: Apollo Computer Inc. said it had cut prices up to 38 percent on various work stations and related disk subsystems.

title: North Dakota Dispute: Who Is the Governor?
description: The North Dakota Supreme Court has been asked to settle a dispute over who, for now, is the rightful Governor of the state.

title: Yitshaq Ben-Ami, 71; Zionist Active in U.S.
description: Yitshaq Ben-Ami, a former steel-industry executive who was active in efforts to establish the State of Israel, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Manhattan. He was 71 years old.

title: FRITZ WINFRED ALEXANDER 2D
description: Fritz W. Alexander 2d, the first black named to a full term on the New York State Court of Appeals, moved into his new chambers yesterday and began his new life as a member of the state's highest court. As he did so, he spoke of his long career and of the great honor of his new appointment.

title: PROGRAMS PROTECT ELDERLY FROM COLD
description: CARL PAYNE and Anne Coleman, emergency medical technicians for the American Red Cross, entered the apartment on East 15th Street in Manhattan through the open front door last winter. Inside, where the room temperature was 5 degrees, they found 83-year-old John Martin, recently released from the hospital, slumped half in and half out of bed.

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
Doing Justice to the Court
description: Sol Wachtler, a member of New York's highest court for 12 years, was outstanding on a list of able candidates to be Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals and thus head of the state judiciary. His selection by Governor Cuomo is a triumph for quality - and for the way New York now picks its highest judges.

title: HUMAN SPECIES THREATENS THE EARTH'S ABILITY TO SUPPORT LIFE

title: FIGHT APARTHEID, TUTU TELLS INVESTORS
description: Bishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, urged foreign investors today to exert ''persuasive pressure'' for racial change in his country within the next 18 to 24 months.

title: Generals In Battle For Flutie
description: The New Jersey Generals will reserve the rights to Doug Flutie and several of his Boston College teammates today at the United States Football League's draft of eligible college players.

title: CHOICES IN IRT CASE
description: With the surrender of the man who admits he shot four teen-agers on a Manhattan subway train last month has come a host of complicated legal problems for the Manhattan District Attorney. Prosecutors in Manhattan have begun studying the lengthy statement to the police by the suspect, Bernhard Hugo Goetz. The prosecutors have been weighing their options on issues of whether they should seek bail and what criminal charges they should seek from the grand jury.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: EQUAL DISTANCE. By Brad Leithauser.

title: Coaches' Poll
description: The United Press International Board of Coaches top 20 college football ratings, with first-place votes and records in parentheses. Points based on 15 for first place, 14 for second, etc.

title: Blacks Quit Squad
description: Four Holy Cross basketball players, the only blacks on the 13- player team, left the squad Saturday, charging that they had been targets of repeated racial abuse by their coaches and teammates. Yesterday, after a series of meetings with the four, Coach

title: 2 WOMEN CHARGED AS ACCESSORIES IN BOMBING OF 3 ABORTION OFFICES
description: Federal agents today arrested the wife and the fiancee of two men already charged with the Christmas bombings of three medical clinics offering abortion services. The two women were charged as accessories.

title: Botway And Libov Combine
description: CLIFFORD A. BOTWAY INC., which has specialized in buying TV network and radio advertising time for 15 years, has acquired Ed Libov Associates, specialists in buying spot TV, radio and print.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: American Brands Inc., a diversified packaged goods and services company, has elected Peter Reed Jr. and John T. Ludes vice presidents. The company also said its Swingline Inc. subsidiary, a manufacturer of staplers in Long Island City, Queens, had elected Kenneth X. Miles chief executive officer.

title: Western Union Plan on Debt
description: The Western Union Corporation, which has been beset by losses, said yesterday that it had completed the first part of a restructuring of its outstanding bank debt, thereby helping the company to meet its immediate cash needs.

title: The Flight From Regulation
description: The death of the Civil Aeronautics Board after 46 years warrants a commemorative marker, but it's a milestone, not a gravestone. Federal regulation doesn't yield easily to market competition, yet the example of the C.A.B. shows it can be done and that it works.

Howe, who is trying to come back after a year's suspension for recurring problems with drugs, will undergo an operation that will adjust the position of the ulna nerve. Dr.

title: Donaldson Executive Chosen
description: John K. Castle, who has served as president and chief operating officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. for the last five years, has been elected chief executive officer, the investment banking and securities firm announced yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: PUPPET STATES The actors may be wooden, but the acting promises not to be in ''The Age of Invention,'' which starts tonight at 8 in Theater for the New City, 162 Second Avenue, at 10th Street (254-1109). This puppet epic created by Theodora Skipitares celebrates Yankee ingenuity and uses 300 puppets against backgrounds reminiscent of work by Red Grooms.

title: Municipal Bliss
description: Just a handful of people are ever married at City Hall. But nearly half the couples who wed last year were married by City Hall - that is, in one of the five borough chapels tended by the City Clerk.

title: BUCKS WIN WHILE BUILDING
description: Paul Pressey is playing a newly created position that Don Nelson, the Milwaukee Bucks' coach, has termed ''a point forward,'' and Terry Cummings is developing into an outstanding power forward now that he is learning that there is more to pro basketball than scoring.

title: Steelers' Lambert Back
description: Jack Lambert, the veteran linebacker sidelined most of the season by a career-threatening toe injury,

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about an Ernest Hemingway manuscript misidentified a publishing company official. He is Charles Scribner 3d, executive vice president of Charles Scribner's Sons.

title: GOETZ, AT HEARING, TOLD OF ANGER WITH SYSTEM
description: Asserting that ''you cannot ask me to defend New York City's incompetence,'' Bernhard Hugo Goetz told a police hearing in 1982 of his frustration with the criminal justice system after he was mugged in a subway station the year before.

title: Chrysler Plants
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would invest $120 million to automate and upgrade its stamping plants in Michigan and Ohio. It said new transfer- type presses, synchromatic lines and other equipment would be installed during the next three years to increase capacity at plants in Sterling Heights and Warren, Mich., and Twinsburg, Ohio.

description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Held in Jersey In Cocaine Seizure
description: Federal officials today announced the arrests of two Colombian nationals in connection with the seizure of 61 kilos - or 134.2 pounds - of cocaine valued at $40 million to $50 million.

title: GRAHAM SAYS POLITICAL CLERICS 'WENT TOO FAR'
description: The Rev. Billy Graham said yesterday that some of his fellow Christian ministers and evangelists ''went too far'' by getting involved in partisan politics in the 1984 Presidential elections.

title: Transactions
description: Named Leanne Grotke acting athletic director. LOUISVILLE - Named Jack Burns assistant football coach. MIAMI - Named Paul Jette defensive coordinator and secondary coach; named Tony Wise offensive line coach.

title: FIRST PORTRAIT OF THE VERY OLD: NOT SO FRAIL
description: The first comprehensive statistical portrait of Americans aged 85 or older is emerging from new research on the elderly. This group, called by various scholars the old old, the oldest old and the extreme aged, numbers 2.6 million and is growing more rapidly than any younger segment of the population.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
LARGE DIVERSITY OF TECHNIQUES IN GLASS
description: GLASS AMERICA 1985 is the Heller Gallery's third cross- section of studio glass in its inherited and brand-new forms. Every imaginable technique may be seen in over 125 works by 90 artists: glass blown, cased, sandblasted, painted and combined, sometimes happily, with other materials. There are flat-glass wall hangings in Pop style.

title: SECOND ABDUCTOR OF POLISH PRIEST SAYS ORDER CAME 'FROM THE TOP'
description: The second of three former security officers who have admitted killing the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko testified today that their leader had been authorized ''from the top'' to proceed even if the pro-Solidarity priest appeared to be dying.

title: AT REMOTE PUEBLO, ANCIENT DRUMBEATS GREET NEW YEAR
description: The first sound of the drums in the New Year's dance seemed to come from deep in the past.

title: ST. JOHN'S TRIUMPHS IN BIG EAST OPENER
description: After finishing its pre-conference schedule with a flurry of impressive victories, St. John's eagerly anticipated a smashing Big East Conference debut. The Redmen proceeded, instead, to stumble through one of their worst opening halves of the season.

title: THE PROCEDURES IN EXTRADITION
description: The extradition of a criminal suspect requires the governor of the state where the crime was committed to make a formal request to the governor of the state where the suspect has fled.

title: OVEN-TO-TABLE CASSEROLES
description: BECAUSE she didn't like the way ''casseroles related to their hot plates,'' Carla Goldstein, right, designed a collection of oven-to-tableware. ''I wanted pieces that would be both usable and classic,'' said Miss Goldstein, who used to be a potter.

title: Batus Head to Succeed Retiring Chief Officer
description: Henry F. Frigon has been elected chief operating officer of Batus Inc., the company said yesterday.

title: Gandhi Dismisses Mother's Top Aides
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today removed the top aides who served his mother for years, including Rajinder Dhawan, long considered the second most powerful figure in Indira Gandhi's Government.

title: U.S. ASSERTS CLINIC BOMBINGS AREN'T WORK OF SINGLE GROUP
description: Treasury Department officials said today that they believed the recent cases of arson and bombing at abortion clinics represented the work of individuals rather than an organized conspiracy.

title: SOME SUBURBAN PIONEERS IN YONKERS FIND CREATIVE WAYS TO OCCUPY BIG HOUSES
description: DR. BRUCE FADER, a psychiatrist, and Kim Brown Fader, an editor, may still work in Manhattan and often socialize there on weekends. But from Grand Central they are only half an hour by train from the arugula, watercress, bok choy and bibb and Boston lettuce growing in the heated greenhouse of a large house they recently bought in the Park Hill area of Yonkers. On the acre of land around their home the couple have planted an orchard of dwarf fruit trees and a vegetable and fruit garden.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Local College Games: Brown at Manhattan, 8 P.M.; Rhode Island at Rutgers, 8 P.M. (Radio - WCTC, 1450; WRSU-FM, 88.7; both at 8 P.M.)

description: A 69-year-old woman jumped 16 floors to her death today from her East Side apartment, the police said.

title: FURNITURE: TO RESTORE OR REFINISH?
description: WE have all seen an oil portrait on which the top coat of varnish was old, discolored and badly crazed and no longer protected the painting. Old varnish can make a portrait look dark and gloomy. The old varnish can be removed and new applied, restoring the portrait's fine appearance.

title: 2 COURT APPOINTEES FROM DIFFERENT BACKGROUNDS: SOL WACHTLER
description: In December 1967, Sol Wachtler, who was named Chief Judge of the State Court of Appeals yesterday, was the 37-year-old Supervisor of the Town of North Hempstead, L.I., and a recently defeated Republican candidate for Nassau County Executive. At that time he announced that he would seek appointment to the State Supreme Court. ''I am leaving politics for now,'' he said. ''I cannot foresee any circumstance at this time that would propel me on the political scene.''

title: O. Burtch Drake Returns to Foote, Cone
description: O. Burtch Drake, 43, who left Foote, Cone & Belding to return to Dancer Fitzgerald Sample three years ago, is now leaving Dancer to return to Foote, Cone. It will require, once more, a stretch of the bicoastal muscles, since it will mean a return to New York from his San Francisco post.

description: The ranch manager opened the pen, tilted a wheelbarrow full of enriched ground catfish heads on the concrete floor, and moved on, with 35 pens to go.

title: OIL FUTURES PLUNGE ON OPEC DOUBT
description: Prices for future delivery of crude oil and heating oil plunged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, as oil traders predicted that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would be unable to prevent prices from crumbling further.

description: The Internal Revenue Service published regulations today designed to give employers and employees guidance on how to calculate income tax liability on certain taxable fringe benefits, such as personal use of company automobiles and airplanes.

description: A.G. Edwards & Sons, the biggest brokerage house based outside of New York City, has managed to do quite well far from the Wall Street crowd - and it believes its distance from that canyon is one of the main reasons.

title: Leonard Injured In Auto Accident
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, the former boxing champion, suffered minor injuries tonight in an auto accident.

description: Tuesday Cotton - Boston College 45, Houston 28. Fiesta - U.C.L.A. 39, Miami 37.

title: CITIES SAY THEY CAN'T AFFORD MORE FEDERAL AID CUTBACKS
description: Despite ''token surpluses'' in their budgets, cities are facing a pent-up demand for services and are in no shape to absorb further reductions in Federal aid, the director of the National League of Cities said today.

title: AWAITING DATA JUDGE ADJOURNS TIME LIBEL TRIAL
description: The libel trial of Ariel Sharon against Time magazine resumed briefly yesterday and then adjourned until Tuesday to await key evidence from Israel.

title: Fat Clauses Shrink Pay
description: New incentive and penalty clauses for players who tend to gain weight are emerging more and more often in National Basketball Association contracts. The ability to maintain certain weight levels can earn the 6-foot-11- inch, 240-pound Jeff Ruland of the Washington Bullets extra money - or a fine if his weight goes above an agreed-upon level. Lonnie Shelton, who is listed at 250 pounds, had a weight clause added to his Cleveland Cavalier contract last season, and before he went out with an injury this season, his daily weight was recorded on a big chart next to a scale in the dressing room. Darryl Dawkins, the Nets' injured center who is listed at 250, is also subject to a weight clause. None of the teams nor any of the players would reveal at what weight the penalties might begin.

title: BLAME OLD AGE, NOT MEDICARE
description: Volumes have been written about the problems of Medicare, but almost nothing from the viewpoint of patients. What's it like for us?

title: PHONE RATE IS TRIPLING FOR SOME
description: In what may be the largest such increase since the Bell System breakup, the New York Telephone Company is informing its 32,000 Connecticut customers that the price of their local phone service is more than tripling, to $14.65 a month for flat-rate service and to $10.03 for measured service, in which customers pay by the call after exceeding an allotted amount.

title: KEEPING HEAT INDOORS WITH WEATHERSTRIPPING
description: WEATHERSTRIPPING products that prevent the flow of cold air into the home are available at Wankel Hardware and many other hardware stores.

title: NOW, ABOUT THOSE FINE RESOLUTIONS...
description: -resolutions man knocked on the back door the other day. ''How many can I put you down for this year?'' he asked. His warehouse of discount resolutions is famous: secondhand 84's and 83's - even some vintage 82's - snapped up from the original owners minutes after they were first broken. The firm is called the Best of Intentions Ltd.

Coming True
description: The dream begins today in the indoor batting cage at Shea Stadium for 45 people, ranging in age from 35 to 74 years, who spent $2,695 to be part of the ''Mets' Dream Week'', scheduled for Feb. 3 through 10 in St. Petersburg, Fla. Today they will take the first of four Thursdays of batting practice, against Bud Harrelson and Ed Charles, before heading south to live the life of major leaguers with Tommie Agee, Ron Hunt, Ron Swoboda and Donn Clendenon of the 1969 Mets and Frank Thomas, a member of the original 1962 Mets.

title:
GARDENING;

ORCHIDS POPULAR AS CUT FLOWERS
description: ONCE orchids were seen only in specialist gardeners' greenhouses or reserved, in jumbo size, purple or white, for wedding corsages and prom nights. But the world of orchids is changing dramatically. ''Our sales of corsage orchids have been dropping,'' said Craig Hackenburg, manager of Hillcrest Gardens, a major New Jersey wholesaler, ''but we sell more spray orchids every week; about 300 percent more than we did five years ago.''

title: Mad About the Raj
description: Washingtonians of the governing class, miscellaneous Anglophiles and many other people who live in or near the capital seem to be particularly enthralled by the television series ''The Jewel and the Crown,'' about the decline of British rule in India. The people who say they have read the sequence of novels on which it is based, Paul Scott's ''The Raj Quartet,'' have a conversational edge over those who have not. Sunday night hosts and hostesses must adjust their parties to take account of the needs of Raj watchers.

title: TESTS ON STIMULATING GROWTH
description: A synthetic brain chemical released by an implanted pump can cause the body to produce missing hormones and spur growth in children otherwise destined to be midgets, a study shows.

title: System Extended For Hospital Bills
description: The Federal Health and Human Services Department has granted New Jersey a three-year extension of its unusual hospital payment system, which is designed to reduce medical costs, Governor Kean announced today.

title: IT'S A SKY WAR ON SPEEDING IN CONNECTICUT
description: Sgt. Lee J. Adams, riding shotgun on a state police airplane circling over Interstate 84 here, had his eye on a dark blue, subcompact sedan passing a van 400 feet below.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS RISE 1.1% IN MONTH
description: Construction spending climbed 1.1 percent in November as strong building activity for factories, offices and shopping centers offset a drop in single-family home construction, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Two Medieval Dramas Scheduled at Church
description: ''Herod'' and ''Slaughter of the Innocents,'' two medieval dramas, will be presented with music accompaniment by the Mannes Camerata on Jan. 11 at 8 P.M. at Christ Church, Park Avenue and 60th Street.

title: Transition Announced At Fairchild Camera
description: Donald W. Brooks has been named president and chief executive officer of the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation, the semiconductor manufacturer said yesterday.

title: Volkswagen Rights Suit In Pennsylvania Settled
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. announced today that it had settled a lawsuit with the family of a black executive who committed suicide after leaving a note contending he was being blackmailed over a racial discrimination suit.

title: K"athe Dassler, Co-Founder Of Adidas, Dies in Germany
description: K"athe Dassler, co-founder of the Adidas sporting goods company, died Monday of a heart attack, a company spokesman said today. She was 67 years old.

title: An Outing by the Court
description: A solid majority of the Supreme Court is scheduled to make a rare social appearance together tomorrow night, according to the Association of American Law Schools. The appearance is to be at a reception in the Jefferson Building of the Library of Congress that will mark the opening of the association's three-day annual meeting in Washington.

title: Car Output Up 14%
description: The United States auto industry built more than 7.6 million cars in 1984, a gain of almost 14 percent from its 1983 output and the highest production volume since 1979, the companies reported today. General Motors, Ford and Chrysler each had their best annual car output since 1979.

title: G.I.'S ON GRENADA WHIP A POLICE UNIT INTO SHAPE
description: The American soldier and the Grenadian police recruit crouched face to face, hands poised, ready to fight.

title: Coast Mayor Wins Time On Surprise Witness
description: A San Diego judge agreed to give Mayor Roger Hedgecock's lawyer more time today to prepare for a surprise prosecution witness, a real estate investor who is expected to testify about the Mayor's campaign fund.

title: FOR ADULTS WHO CAN'T READ, VULNERABILITY AND A LOND WAIT
description: ALTHOUGH she spent 12 years in New York City public schools, Debra J. Wilson reads about as well as the average fifth grader. She is 33 years old, has three children and has been on welfare, she said, ''for umpteen years.'' She yearns to change her life, and she thinks that learning to read is the key.

title: GAULT IS REFUSING TO BE FAST FORGOTTEN
description: The pass was a simple 10-yard out, designed only to gain a first down. But after he caught it, Willie Gault spun out of a tackle by the Redskins' cornerback, Darrell Green, and ran for a touchdown, completing a 75-yard play that gave the Chicago Bears a 16-3 lead in their 23-19 playoff victory last Sunday.

title: THURSDAY, JANUARY 3, 1985   Companies
description: Crocker National will report a $215 million loss for the fourth quarter, and $324 million for the year, among the biggest ever for an American banking organization. Loans to agriculture and real-estate ventures played important roles, the chairman said. Midland Bank of London, which controls Crocker, covered the loss by making a $375 million infusion of funds. (Page D1.)

title: THRIFT UNIT FUND MAY RAISE FEES
description: In an unusual move to buttress the shrinking Government fund that insures savings and loan deposits, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has told the industry that it is likely to impose a special assessment on thrift institutions to raise as much as 1 billion.

title: SYRACUSE UPSET BY VILLANOVA
description: Dwayne McClain scored 21 points and Gary McLain added 18 to lead Villanova to an 82-70 upset of Syracuse tonight at the Palestra in the Big East Conference opener for both teams.

title: PHONE COMPANY IN A PUSH TO FINISH AREA-CODE SHIFT
description: In telephone company offices around the city yesterday, technicians snipped at wires and typed new instructions into computers as they worked to complete the division of the five boroughs into two area codes.

title: Howard Haines, 58, ManagerOf 'Evita' and Other Musicals
description: Howard Haines, the general manager for the producer-director Harold Prince since 1971, died of pneumonia on Wednesday at St. Luke's Hospital.

title: Compucorp Has Loan Agreement
description: Compucorp said it had reached agreements with bank lenders and a private investor that end a default on previous loan covenants and that should help it return to profitability.

title: KOCH AIDES AND STATE OFFICIAL CLASH ON PRODUCTIVITY CLAIMS
description: The Koch administration and the executive director of the State Financial Control Board clashed yesterday over the city's claim that it has improved its record of saving money by increasing the productivity and management of its workers.

description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, seeking to ease some trade barriers, agreed today to arrange high-level talks on finding ways to open several Japanese markets to American products.

description: A 17-year-old Danbury (Conn.) High School student was fatally stabbed yesterday at the school and a 17-year-old classmate was arrested and charged with the killing, the police said.

description: President Reagan has instructed Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in his meetings next week with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, to spurn any Soviet proposal to negotiate limits on developing new antimissile defenses, White House officials said today.

title: UNIFORM STANDARDS NEEDED FOR ALL ADOPTIONS

title: Bridge:Problem of a 4-4 Trump Fit In Considering Minor Suits
description: A four-four trump fit is highly attractive for a major suit but highly unattractive if the suit is a minor: For an 11-trick contract a better fit is needed. But there are exceptions to almost every bridge generalization, and one of them came up on the diagramed deal, from the life master men's pairs in the recent Fall Nationals in San Diego.

description: Aetna Life and Casualty Co. said it had concluded the previously announced sale of its subsidiary, the Urban Investment and Development Co., for $45 million in cash and notes valued at $131 million.

title: MASSACHUSETTS LAWMAKERS VOTE TO OUST LONGTIME HOUSE SPEAKER
description: The Massachusetts House, for the first time in recent history, voted today to oust a sitting Speaker, replacing him with the former majority leader he dismissed a year ago in a power dispute.

title: BRAMBLE MISSES CHANCE TO ALTER IMAGE
description: News is usually the last thing one expects at boxing news conferences, which are generally exercises in conviviality. But today's news conference at Gallagher's Restaurant could be an exception, even if Livingstone Bramble does not bring his snakes or pit bulls.

title: PUSH IN HOUSE MILITARY PANEL TO DEPOSE PRICE IS REPORTED
description: A junior member of the House Armed Services Committee said today that a strong effort was under way to depose Representative Melvin Price as committee chairman despite support for Mr. Price from the Democratic leadership.

title: SPIRIT OF GOOD WILL
description: BOSTON One of the astonishing things about the American Constitution is its freshness, its contemporary relevance, in every age. We constantly rediscover the meaning of its great general principles in concrete new circumstances. So, just now, we have been shown the reason for separation of church and state.

title: BRAZIL TO RESUME TALKS ON RESTRUCTURING DEBT
description: Brazil resumes crucial debt talks with leading commercial banks Thursday, with both sides seemingly anxious to complete a major renegotiation package before this country holds indirect Presidential elections on Jan. 15.

title: Husky Asset Sale
description: Husky Oil Ltd. has a new agreement to sell its three refineries and substantially all of its franchised marketing outlets in the United States to Grambling Energy Inc. Husky Oil's president, Arthur Price, said the sale was for less than $100 million, but he declined to release further details.

title: BFI COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: To the Editor:

title: THE INDIANA IMBROGLIO
description: When the 99th Congress convenes Thursday, 434 members of the House of Representatives will be sworn in for their two-year terms. The 435th seat, representing the Eighth District of Indiana, is likely to remain vacant while the House tries to unravel one of the closest election contests in many years.

title: STAGE: FAMILY STRIFE IN 'HOME FRONT'
description: CARROLL O'CONNOR has bounced back fast and well from ''Brothers,'' the vanity production that sputtered out after a single performance last season. In James Duff's ''Home Front,'' the new play at the Royale, the star is relaxed and giving; he's acting - not hyperventilating. But if this time Mr. O'Connor has admirably left behind the irascible Archie Bunker, his role is still that of an embattled paterfamilias and his script is still a would- be theatrical equivalent of ''All in the Family.'' True, ''Home Front'' is far superior to ''Brothers'' - what isn't? - yet television it remains.

title: Salute to Auerbach
description: The Celtics are scheduled to play the Knicks tomorrow night, but the game will be little more than a footnote to a big basketball weekend in Boston. The main attraction will be

title: REPUBLICAN JUDGE IS NAMED BY CUOMO TO TOP COURT POST
description: Sol Wachtler, a member of the State Court of Appeals since 1973 and a Republican, was named today by Governor Cuomo to become the 21st Chief Judge of New York.

title: Somalia Says Ethiopians Raided Garrison Town
description: Somalia said today that Ethiopian troops attacked Somali defenses around the western garrison town of Balambale early Tuesday but were repulsed with 200 Ethiopians killed and many wounded.

title: KOCH BIDS CON EDISON ALTER FISCAL STRUCTURE TO CUT RATES
description: Mayor Koch and other public officials yesterday called on the state to order the Consolidated Edison Company to modify its financial structure to help reduce utility rates.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Caterpillar Tractor Elects Top Officer
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, the heavy equipment manufacturer beset by years of losses, yesterday elected George A. Schaefer as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: KENAI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $336,000 for the quarter and $2,930,000 for the 9 months and provisions for the quarter of approximately $1.6 million for the writeoff of deferred financing costs related to the company's exchange offer which was completed Nov. 15. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $134,000.

title: RAPID BUYS LINDNER'S STAKE
description: After five years, the American Financial Corporation has withdrawn from its partial ownership of the Rapid-American Corporation and sold its 40 percent interest to Rapid for $110 million, both companies said yesterday.

title: WITH '84 A SUCCESS, NEXT WAVE PLANS KEY EVENTS
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival, the country's major showcase for avant-garde performing artworks, showed a strong increase in attendance in 1984, and Harvey Lichtenstein, president of the academy and the festival's director, has revealed plans for several major new events in its 1985 schedule.

title: Information's Plan
description: Information Displays Inc. said it had reached an agreement in principle with its official creditors committee on the main elements of a reorganization plan.

title: STOCKS DECLINE SHARPLY ON INTEREST RATE FEARS
description: Stock prices dropped sharply in slack volume yesterday on trader concern over the outlook for interest rates.

title: Youth in Murder Case Returns to High School
description: A 17-year-old youth charged with murdering his father with a hatchet was quietly welcomed back to Hingham High School today by students who said their main concern was making him feel comfortable.

title: Peat Marwick Loses Plea
description: Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court refused today to shield Peat Marwick from having to disclose an internal study of its 1981 audit of an Oklahoma City bank that was closed the next year.

title: ACADEMIC FRAUD INQUIRY IS DROPPED
description: The American Historical Association has canceled an investigation of an academic dispute that involves charges of scholarly fraud and countercharges that several historians have used unseemly tactics to drive a younger colleague from the profession.

title: 'MIAMI VICE': ACTION TV WITH SOME NEW TWISTS
description: On the surface, it has all the familiar elements of the standard action program: a pair of undercover detectives, one black, one white, in pursuit of drug dealers in an exotic locale. But ''Miami Vice,'' NBC's police series on Friday nights at 10 P.M., has become the most talked-about dramatic series in the television industry since ''Hill Street Blues.''

title: Pornography Ordinance In Minnesota Faces Suit
description: The Minnesota Civil Liberties Union said today that it would challenge in court a city ordinance requiring bookstore owners to keep sexually provocative books and magazines wrapped in opaque covers.

title: SUSPECT IN IRT SHOOTINGS AGREES TO RETURN TO CITY TO FACE CHARGES
description: Speaking softly and staring at the courtroom floor, Bernhard Hugo Goetz told a judge here today that he would return to New York to face charges of attempted murder in the subway shooting of four teen-agers.

title: Baby Sitter Slain in Georgia
description: Laura Newman, 13 years old, was stabbed to death Monday night while the three next-door neighbors she was baby-sitting slept in an adjoining bedroom, Sgt. Tom Izzo of the police said. Terry and Debbie Cleland reported discovering the body upon their return home. There were signs that she had also been choked by her attacker, Sergeant Izzo said.

title: ISLANDERS TROUNCE WINGS, 7-2
description: In the press box and in the press room sat some famous old Islanders - Denis Potvin, Clark Gillies, Butch Goring - all healthy but out of uniform by decision of team management.

title: 29 REPORTED DEAD IN BOLIVIA JET CRASH
description: The wreckage of an Eastern Airlines jet was located late yesterday on the side of a mountain southeast of La Paz, Bolivia, 20 hours after it disappeared on a flight to La Paz from Asuncion, Paraguay, airline officials said.

title: Leo Robin, the LyricistWho Won 1938 Oscar
description: Leo Robin, the Oscar-winning song lyricist, died of heart failure on Saturday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in suburban Los Angeles. He was 89 years old. Mr. Robin received nine Academy Award nominations for best song between 1934 and 1953.

title: Debt
JAZZ: CHICK COREA LEADS TRIO
description: CHICK COREA has an expressive and stylistic range that is as open-ended as any contemporary jazz pianist, but his virtuosity never obscures a musical personality that balances lyricism and earthiness in equal measure. Mr. Corea, who opened a six- night engagement at the Blue Note on Tuesday, is leading an excellent trio that includes the bassist Miroslav Vitous and the drummer Roy Haynes, two musicians who share his impressionistic refinement, his interest in bringing a classical kind of precision to jazz forms and the ability to elaborate the Spanish dance rhythms and colors that are continuing undercurrents in his pianism.

title: Hijacker May Have Had Help
description: A convicted mass murderer who hijacked an American Airlines DC-10 to Cuba on New Year's Eve apparently had an accomplice here who provided him with a pistol, Virgin Islands officials said today.

title: THE SHOGUN, 1985: HE'S A WORKINGMAN
description: Centuries ago, feudal lords were forced to travel from all over Japan to take up residence every other year in Edo, as Tokyo was then called.

title: CSX Earnings Decline by 25%
description: The CSX Corporation, the nation's second-largest railroad operator, today reported fourth-quarter earnings of $78 million, or 52 cents a share, down 25 percent from $104 million, or 76 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I doubt they'll ever have an amendment on the abortion issue.

title: Democrat Backed For Council Seat
description: Walter H. Crowley, a Queens Democratic district leader and a lawyer, was recommended yesterday to fill a vacant City Council seat by Borough President Donald R. Manes, the Queens Democratic leader.

title: TSR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALL too often the sense of accomplishment to be derived from doing home repairs and maintenance will be dampened when accidents and injuries result from carelessness or ignorance - or both. Such accidents can be avoided if basic safety rules are followed when working with tools. Here are some pointers that should be kept in mind when undertaking tasks around the house or in the workshop:

title: ALTEX OIL CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: The latest year loss includes $1,578,609 in depletion and depreciation and $468,399 in writeoffs of non- productive assets.

title: O.&M. Ends Venture
description: Ogilvy & Mather International made the rumors official yesterday. It has ended its year-old Japanese joint venture with the Tokyu Group.

title: Account
description: * Genesco Inc., to Kobs & Brady Advertising, Chicago, for a number of direct marketing programs.

title: Zhao Tries to Ease Fears On Decontrol of Prices
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang said that plans to decontrol prices had caused concern in China, but he said changes in the price system would be the key to success of the new economic program.

title: Two World Premieres At Symphony Space
description: Two world premieres will be presented by the Solaire Ensemble on Jan. 15 at 8 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street.

title: BRIGHAM YOUNG IS VOTED TOP TEAM IN MAJOR POLLS
description: Despite criticism centering on the relative weakness of its schedule, Brigham Young University, the nation's only undefeated major-college football team, was the overwhelming choice for the No. 1 ranking yesterday in the season's final polls of both The Associated Press and United Press International.

title: C.D. Yields Fall Again
description: Yields on money market accounts and six-month certificates of deposit continued to fall in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: No Headline
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 3, 1985 International

title: NORTHERN DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
STATUS GAME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Rath Shuts Down In Temporary Step
description: The Rath Packing Company said it had stopped processing meat temporarily and would sell the remaining inventory.

title: Mexican Drilling Plan
description: The state petroleum monopoly, Pemex, announced today that it would drill 1,000 new wells as part of a five-year program to increase Mexico's crude oil production by 1.6 million barrels a day, or 58 percent, to meet increased domestic consumption. Mexico currently produces 2.75 million barrels a day and exports an average of 1.4 million daily. It is the largest foreign supplier of oil to the United States.

title: VIETNAMESE SHELL CAMBODIA FOES
description: Vietnamese troops hammered Cambodian rebel positions along the Thai-Cambodian border today with a 40-minute artillery and mortar attack, and some fighting was reported in the Rithisen camp.

title: SOME PEOPLE PROVE AGE HAS LITTLE TO DO WITH BEING OLD
description: ''I KNOW of many people in their 90's who are very active,'' Representative Claude Pepper said. ''I think age has little to do with being old.'' Mr. Pepper, a Florida Democrat, is 84.

title: UNITED TOTE reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
RECTISEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
BIOMET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Mrs. Paul's Shifts To Needham Harper
description: In what is being called a consolidation move by the Campbell Soup Company, Needham Harper Worldwide is picking up still another assignment from that longtime client.

title: CELTICS ROUT NETS
description: There are times when a team can rush through its offense with haphazard abandon, hit fewer than half its shots, play lackluster defense and still win a game in the National Basketball Association. But not against the Boston Celtics.

title: United Financial Foresees Gain
description: United Financial Group Inc. said it expected to record a one-time fourth- quarter gain of about $80 million as a result of the sale of 20 savings and loan branch offices.

title: VIRGIN ISLANDS PRESSING U.S. ON SOUTH AFRICA POLICY
description: Politicians in this United States territory are trying to put pressure on Washington to take a stronger position against South Africa's policies of racial separation.

title: CLARK TO STAY ON FOR 2 OR 3 MONTHS
description: Interior Secretary William P. Clark, who submitted his resignation to President Reagan this week, said today that he would remain in office two or three months until his successor was ready to take over.

title: U.S. AIDES SUSPECT PARAGUAY OFFICIALS OF A NARCOTICS LINK
description: A recent seizure in Paraguay of chemicals used to manufacture cocaine has led United States officials to believe that senior members of the Paraguayan military Government may be involved in drug trafficking, according to Administration officials.

title: 2d 'TV Blackout' Begins in a Town
description: Townspeople began their second ''TV Blackout'' today with many youngsters determined to read books instead of watching television for the rest of the month and adults vowing to sacrifice such favorite shows as ''Dallas.''

title: RANGERS WIN IMPRESSIVELY
description: Mercy was not a factor at the Garden last night.

title: First Flu Cases Of Winter Appear
description: The first outbreak of influenza in New York City this winter was reported yesterday by Dr. David J. Sencer, the city's Health Commissioner.

title: M.S. Walker Plans Campaign for Liqueur
description: M.S. Walker Inc. of Somerville, Mass., is in the spirits business, but unlike the giants it competes against it has been using very little advertising. Paul Shuman, its ad director, characterizes its marketing method as good products at moderate prices that sell on their price value.

title: NOW, THE HALF-GAINER SOMERSAULT BACKGROUNDER
description: Shortly before noon Thursday dozens of reporters will gather in an auditorium at the Old Executive Office Building near the White House for a briefing that will follow a familiar Washington ritual, up to a point.

title: No Headline
description: Unfinished Job at Interior James Watt was not a hard act to follow as Secretary of the Interior, but William Clark has been more than a Watt in sheep's clothing, as some of his critics allege. He has adroitly defused the confrontations Mr. Watt had engineered on all sides, while pursuing an essentially similar policy of favoring resource development over conservation.

title: Decker Married
description: Mary Decker made it down the aisle without falling, but when the 26- year-old middle-distance runner got to the altar at the First United Methodist Church in Eugene, Ore., on Tuesday,

title: Books: The Mexicans
description: DISTANT NEIGHBORS. A Portrait of the

title: CRAZY EDDIE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DELAY ON INCREASE IN BENEFITS ASKED
description: Three former top Presidential economic advisers told Congress today that a cut in the cost-of-living increase for Social Security recipients must be part of any package to reduce the Federal deficit.

title: ENTER FEARLESS DIRECTOR, PURSUED BY PLAYWRIGHT
description: IN his texts Samuel Beckett is exactingly specific about where

title: ;   VINES, LAMBS AND HAGGLING AT THE E.E.C.
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW PUERTO RICAN GOVERNOR VOWS BETTER U.S. RELATIONS
description: Rafael Hernandez Colon was sworn in as Governor today, returning to office after eight years. He promised to improve Puerto Rico's relations with Washington and abandon his past efforts to win more autonomy for this United States commonwealth.

title: Good Deal
description: The Baltimore Stars will have an extra territorial selection today in the United States Football League's draft of college players, getting 26 picks instead of the 25 that the other 13 teams get.

title: Morgan Knitting Mills Counting on Cold Snap
description: The J.E. Morgan Knitting Mills down in Hometown, Pa., will take advantage next fall of the ability of newspapers and radio ability to act quickly for an advertiser. It will be advertising only during cold snaps.

title: COLECO GIVES UP ON THE ADAM
description: Coleco Industries abandoned its beleaguered Adam home computer yesterday, and said it would concentrate on what it seems to do best: selling low-tech Cabbage Patch dolls.

title: BOND PRICES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: A weeklong trend toward higher interest rates in the credit markets accelerated yesterday, with bond prices opening the new year by tumbling sharply.

title: BUDDHIST SHRINE REBUILT AFTER VETERANS' ARSON
description: With the help of Vietnam veterans from across the country, a new, larger temple has risen from the ashes of a Buddhist shrine that was burned on New Year's Eve, 1983, by three angry veterans of the war.

title: Writers' Poll The top 20 teams in The Associated Press's college football poll of sportswriters and broadcasters, with first-place votes in parentheses. Points based on 20 for first place, 19 for second, etc. *1, Brigham Young (38)13-0-0 1,160 1 *2, Washington (16)11-1-0 1,140 4 *3, Florida (6) 9-1-1 1,092 3 *4, Nebraska10-2-0 1,017 5 *5, Boston College10-2-0 932 8 *6, Oklahoma 9-2-1 883 2 *7, Oklahoma State10-2-0 864 9 *8, S.M.U.10-2-0 761 10 *9, U.C.L.A. 9-3-0 613 14 10, Southern Cal 9-3-0 596 18 11, South Carolina10-2-0 557 7 12, Maryland 9-3-0 552 12 13, Ohio State 9-3-0 497 6 14, Auburn 9-4-0 432 16 15, L.S.U. 8-3-1 314 11 16, Iowa 8-4-1 228 -- 17, Florida State 7-3-2 207 15 18, Miami, Florida 8-5-0 166 13 19, Kentucky 9-3-0 152 -- 20, Virginia 8-2-2 119 -- Others receiving votes: West Virginia 109, Georgia 67, Army 44, Air Force 26, Notre Dame 26, Nevada-Las Vegas 17, Texas Christian 9, Arkansas 8, Rutgers 7, Wisconsin 7, Texas 5, Purdue 4, Fullerton State 1.
description: Coaches' Poll The United Press International Board of Coaches top 20 college football ratings, with first-place votes and records in parentheses. Points based on 15 for first place, 14 for second, etc.

title: Article 190354 -- No Title
description: The Crocker National Corporation announced yesterday that it will report a loss of $215 million for the fourth quarter, bringing its loss for all of 1984 to $324 million, one of the biggest ever by an American banking organization. The loss was caused by huge loan charge-offs.

title: Chess: And the Draws Go On
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov agreed to a draw today after 15 moves in the 37th game of their world chess championship match.

title: 5 AT TRANSIT AUTHORITY EARN $100,000 OR MORE
description: The five top executives at the New York City Transit Authority are receiving annual salaries of at least $100,000, far more than their predecessors and among the highest in public transit, the authority said yesterday.

title: Eban Opposes a Transmitter Wanted for Voice of America
description: Abba Eban, chairman of Parliament's foreign affairs and security committee, said today that he opposed setting up a transmitter on Israeli soil to relay Voice of America broadcasts to the Soviet Union.

title: STAUB AND METS AGREE ON A PACT
description: The Mets will make an announcement today, but in the category of surprise, it will not match their last announcement - the acquisition of Gary Carter from the Montreal Expos.

title: 'STRANGER THAN PARADISE' WINS AWARD
description: Jim Jarmusch's ''Stranger Than Paradise'' was voted best film of 1984 last night by the National Society of Film Critics, a 40-member group representing critics from New York, Los Angeles, Boston, Chicago and other areas. The group voted Steve Martin best actor for his performance in ''All of Me'' and Vanessa Redgrave best actress for her work in ''The Bostonians.''

title: CURRENCY MARKETS ;   Dollar Reaches Highs; Gold and Silver Down
description: The dollar, which soared during 1984 despite predictions by economists that it would fall, began 1985 on the same contrary note yesterday by reaching a record high against the British pound and the highest level against the West German mark in more than a decade.

title: A FITNESS CENTER FOR PROFESSIONALS
description: IT is a wet and chilly 7:30 A.M., the sort of morning when

title: HOW TO HELP MEDICARE
description: Medicare is in trouble, but those who harp on the program's impending bankruptcy are diverting attention from the real problem. They want us to believe that benefit cuts are unavoidable. The real choice is not whether to raise taxes or cut benefits, but whether to apply a Band-Aid solution and let Medicare's deficits recur or to get at the root of the problem and bring health-care inflation under control.

title: HERS
description: ''IS this real life?'' asked my 6-year-old son, Timothy, as he, clad only in his Superman underwear, appeared in the kitchen doorway one morning. I didn't know what to tell him. This life may or may not be real; it certainly isn't what I expected.

title: Travels With Hart
description: Senator Gary Hart has not disclosed his political plans for

title: ABC'S ''20/20'' LOOKS AT CHILD ABUSE
description: ABC's ''20/20'' examines depravity tonight. The program is solemn, but not serious, and it pretends to a dignity it does not really have. How does one sexually abuse a small child? Brainwash the child first, and just possibly you can get away with it. ''20/20'' is giving us titillation disguised as a pseudo-intellectual pursuit. The program will be seen on Channel 7 at 10 P.M.

title: Every Dog Does Not Have Its Day
description: Dogs that rescue their owners are a

title: Cram Course on Congress
description: More than two dozen freshman members of the new Congress are to gather in Williamsburg, Va., today for the start of a four-day cram course in lawmaking, something like the intensive classes would-be lawyers take just before the bar examinations.

title: A RAISE FOR PAUL VOLCKER
description: To the Editor:

title: WEATHER MELTS RESORTS' HOPES
description: December, with its long spells of springlike weather, was a cruel month for the ski areas of the Northeast.

title: Girl Scout Cookies Get Clearance From F.B.I.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has found no evidence of tampering with Girl Scout cookies, which became the subject of an investigation after the consumers reported finding glass, needles and other foreign objects in the cookies, an official said Wednesday.

title: NO NEW OPTIONS RULES
description: Three Federal agencies told Congress today that there was no need for additional regulation of the commodity options and futures markets.

title: Yale's Noble Gesture
description: Smokey Joe Wood , the pitcher who won 34 games for the Boston Red Sox in 1912, received an honorary doctorate of humane letters yesterday from Yale University, where he spent 20 years as baseball coach after retiring from the major leagues in 1922. ''You became one of the game's greatest pitchers,'' Yale's president,

title: GOLD BRIEFLY FALLS BELOW $300 LEVEL
description: The price of gold fell briefly below $300 an ounce in London trading yesterday, its first drop below that critical psychological level in a major market since June 1982, during the worldwide recession.

title: Generals Select Flutie Among 5 Quarterbacks
description: The Generals selected not only Doug Flutie but also three other quarterbacks early in the United States Football League's draft of college players yesterday, and Coach Walt Michaels said the team would try to sign each.

title: THEATER: 'DANCING IN THE END ZONE'
description: YOU know a play is inert when its only moving part is an electric wheelchair. Such is the case, sad to say, with Bill C. Davis's ''Dancing in the End Zone,'' a muddled campus drama that has come to rest at the Ritz. The wheelchair is driven by Pat Carroll and, in fairness, one must add that this forceful actress's resonant voice is almost as theatrical as her means of transportation. Almost, but not quite. When Miss Carroll wheels around, we forget about her lines and fantasize that a mechanical glitch might send her sailing into the auditorium to stir up some excitement.

title: Change in Trainers
description: Livingstone Bramble , the mercurial boxer who won the World Boxing Association's lightweight title from

title: Swiss Envoy Reported Kidnapped in Beirut
description: The Swiss charge d'affaires was kidnapped by gunmen in West Beirut today, the state radio reported.

title: Sympathetic Ear
description: Life can be lonely for the 40-some referees and linesmen officiating in the National Hockey League. They are encouraged not to stay in the same hotels as the teams, and their profession leaves them with few sympathizers among the players and coaches anyway.

title: LTV Idling Mills
description: The LTV Corporation's LTV Steel unit said it would indefinitely idle its continuous weld and electric weld pipe mills at the Aliquippa, Pa., works.

title: ART: DIVIDED EXHIBITION PRESENTS OLD AS NEW
description: IN England, streets and buildings

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Food for Thought
description: Saddled with almost seven pounds

title: German Terrorists Raid U.S. Consul's Home
description: Terrorists, in renewed attacks on foreign installations, firebombed the residence of the United States consul in Frankfurt and a guardpost at an American Army airfield in Heidelberg, the police said today. No one was hurt in the attacks, but the police put damages at several thousand dollars.

title: A 400-PUPPET VIEW OF U.S. INGENUITY
description: THOMAS EDISON brings electric lights to New York, looming like King Kong over miniature Manhattan buildings and streets. Benjamin Franklin flies a kite during a thunderstorm. A self-taught surgeon wields tiny scalpels and sponges in an operating room of grisly reality.

title: PUBLISHING: FINAL VOLUME OF BOOKER T. WASHINGTON PAPERS
description: A NOTABLE publishing project ended last week when the University of Illinois Press published Volume 13 of ''The Booker T. Washington Papers,'' covering the final two years of the educator's life. These were years of prosperity for Tuskegee Institute, the black educational institution that Mr. Washington organized and led to prominence, and of personal conflict because of opposition from many black leaders who disagreed with his insistence that economic independence be given priority over social equality.

title: HOW THE MUTUAL FUNDS FARED
description: Investors who played it safe in 1984 by buying mutual funds that emphasized dividend and interest income and conservative stocks had good reason to celebrate on New Year's Eve.

title: AUCTIONS
description: DURING half a century of world travel, Mildred and Rafi Y. Mottahedeh have acquired an extraordinary collection of 16th- through 19th-century China Trade porcelain, ranging from colorful platters embellished with European coats of arms and an ox-head soup tureen to a toddy jug decorated with George Washington's portrait and a plate from the dinner service of Catherine the Great.

title: DEFICIT AND DEBT
description: The newly convened 99th Congress is in conflict with President Reagan over the politically difficult domestic spending cuts he has proposed to reduce the Federal deficit. All eyes seem strangely averted from a more productive alternative: a combined gasoline tax and crude oil import fee to raise perhaps $50 billion a year in new revenues.

title: Democratic Race Narrows
description: The campaign for chairman of

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I condemn, in the strongest terms, those individuals who perpetrate these and all such violent, anarchist activities'' - President Reagan on bombings of abortion clinics. (A1:3.)

title: FOR MUSIC, NEW YORK IS WORLD'S CAPITAL
description: ASK any musician who plies the international circuit the location of the music capital of the world. The immediate answer, almost a conditioned reflex, will be ''New York.'' Then there is a pause. ''Well, maybe London, also.''

title: POSTAL SERVICE URGED TO MOVE TRAINING CENTER TO NEW YORK
description: Members of New York State's Congressional delegation have been trying to persuade officials of the United States Postal Service to move their training center to the vacant campus of Eisenhower College in Seneca Falls.

title: A WHITE HOUSE REPORT ARGUES FOR 'STAR WARS'
description: The White House issued its first public report today on President Reagan's proposal to develop a defense against nuclear missiles, arguing that the time had come to move away from reliance on weapons of mass destruction to deter a nuclear war.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   The Languages in Flushing
description: ''They're putting a ticket on your

title: Too Fast a Start
description: A pretty fast crowd gathered at the Hall of Fame Club at Madison Square Garden yesterday to promote the start of the 1985 Grand Prix indoor track season, but for all the world- class runners in the room, it was a public relations man who jumped the gun.

title: ARABS: NATION OR STATE?
description: CAIRO The threnody of Arabs is still the

title: Big Soviet Arms City Renamed for Ustinov
description: The large arms-manufacturing center of Izhevsk, in the western Urals, 600 miles east of Moscow, has been renamed Ustinov, for Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov, who died Dec. 20 at the age of 76.

title: Woman Slain, 2d Hurt; A Neighbor Is Arrested
description: One woman was killed and another critically injured when they were apparently bludgeoned in a alley in Mt. Vernon yesterday morning.

title: PAYTON'S HUNGRY FOR A TITLE
description: It's not as if Walter Payton has never been to the Super Bowl. He has. He stood around Tampa Stadium last year, as players for both teams were being interviewed.

title: 2 Held in Jersey In Attack on Nun
description: A Paterson man and a 16-year-old boy were being held today in connection with a sexual assault on a Roman Catholic nun last month, the police said. The arrests came after the nun recalled her ordeal under hypnosis.

title: Weinberger Stays Execution Of Goats on Island Off Coast
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger ordered a two-month stay of execution today for hundreds of goats on San Clemente Island off the West Coast less than 24 hours before a biologist was to begin shooting them from a helicopter.

title: RICHARD J. RITCHIE
description: Richard John Ritchie, a former vice president and director of laboratories of Pepsi-Cola, died Wednesday at the Troy Hills Center, a nursing home in Parsipanny-Troy Hills, N.J. He was 76 years old and lived in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: JERSEY AND CONNECTICUT SET BACK ON ATOM DUMP
description: New Jersey and Connecticut have suffered a major setback in their plans to establish a joint regional dump for low-level radioactive waste with the agreement by two of their partners to join with Pennsylvania instead.

title: XEBEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. The company said results for the latest quarter and year include a series of earnings adjustments, special charges, writedowns and restatements of earlier quarterly results.

title: Del-Fuegos and Combo
description: The Del-Fuegos, a rock band from Boston, and the Ben Vaughn Combo will share the bill tonight at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place at East 15th Street (212-477-3728). Music will begin at about 11:30 P.M., and tickets are $10.

title: Dolls of the Past
description: More than 100 dolls from the 18th century to the present will be on display at the Antique Doll Show on Sunday at the Aspen Hotel, 808 Route 46W, Parsippany, N.J. Hours are 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Admission is $3. Information: (201) 887-3092.

title: China Leaps Forward The biggest news of 1984 and perhaps even 1985 may turn out to be the piecemeal revolution that is transforming China. Change and reform have gone so far that the Chinese Writers' Association now demands the once-unthinkable: real artistic freedom. In the moving words of the group's 80-year-old chairman, Ba Jin: ''We yearn for China's Dante, Shakespeare, Goethe and Tolstoy to appear.'' More remarkably, Mr. Ba's sentiments were seconded by a Communist leader who assured writers that ''literary creation must be free.''
description: Given recent history, these stirrings in the Middle Kingdom need to be weighed cautiously. In 1957, Mao called for a hundred flowers to bloom; then came the sickle. During the Cultural Revolution in the 1960's, writers who yearned for a Chinese Shakespeare were turned into plumbers, as happened to Ba Jin. Just six years ago Mao's heirs permitted a ''democracy wall'' in Peking, then jailed those who used it.

title: Why Surrender on the Subway? Is Bernhard Goetz a hero for allegedly shooting four teen-agers he thought were about to mug him on a subway train? Or is he a trigger-happy vigilante? The questions, reverberating in New York and beyond, serve mostly to confuse the issue. The choice is not between taking the law into one's own hands or no law at all. In fact, much can feasibly be done about subway crime. The Goetz case makes clear the need to do it.
description: Reported crimes in the subways increased by about 3.5 percent in 1984, while going down about 3.7 percent on the street. With the city police regaining manpower and morale, the muggers and chain- snatchers now prefer the trains.

title: A.M.C. to Show A Profit for 1984
description: The American Motors Corporation said today that it would post its first profitable year since 1979 when its 1984 balance sheet is made public in February.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: PHILHARMONIC: GIDON KREMER, VIOLINIST
description: THE only real item of interest on this week's New York Philharmonic subscription program - the first installment of which took place last night at Avery Fisher Hall - is the American premiere of ''Offertorium,'' an orchestral work with a prominent solo violin part by the Soviet composer Sofia Gubaidulina.

title: U.S. JEWS' ROLE IN A THAW
description: Because of the way it has treated Soviet Jews, including ''refuseniks'' and even Hebrew teachers, the Soviet Union has made a cold warrior of the Jewish people. Many Jews tend to regard any thaw in relations between the Soviet Union and United States with apprehension and mistrust.

title: KASPAROV INNOVATION STYMIES KARPOV AND LEADS TO A DRAW
description: Once again, in the world championship chess match in Moscow, ingenuity was on the side of the defense. Gary Kasparov, the 21-year-old challenger, revealed an opening innovation for Black that stymied the 33- year-old titleholder, Anatoly Karpov, and led to an early draw on Wednesday in the 37th game.

title: South Africans to Visit
