description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is bringing 11

title: CHINA PLANS MORE MANPOWER CUTS IN THE MILITARY
description: China's highest- ranking officer was quoted today as saying that that there would be new manpower cuts in the armed forces.

title: New Drug Statute Used to Charge 23
description: Twenty-three people arrested in Harlem will be among the first prosecuted in New York under a new Federal statute that provides stiff penalties for selling drugs near schools, law-enforcement authorities said yesterday.

title: Story of Disney Studio
description: The history of the Walt Disney Animation Studio will be told with clips from vintage animated features on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Museum of Cartoon Art, Comly Avenue, Port Chester, N.Y. Some highlights are ''Steamboat Willie,'' in which the character of Mickey Mouse first appeared in a sound cartoon, and ''Ferdinand the Bull,'' the 1939 film that won Disney his seventh Academy Award. Admission is $1.50 ($1 for those 12 to 18; 75 cents for the elderly). Information: (914) 939-0234.

title: Grimes Gets 24 in Iona Rout
description: Rory Grimes tossed in 24 points, and five other Iona players posted double figures as the Gaels romped to a 103- 73 victory over La Salle in a Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference game tonight.

title: Singapore Futures Laws
description: Singapore plans to introduce laws to prevent its fledgling financial futures market from turning into a ''casino,'' the Minister for Trade and Industry, Richard Hu, said. The legislation is one of several measures planned to lift Singapore's image as a major financial center.

title: YALE DEFEATS UNDERMANNED HOLY CROSS
description: Holy Cross, playing tonight for the first time without its four black players after a fight in practice last week stirred charges of racism, was beaten by Yale, 59-55.

title: FINNS HUNT FOR AN OBJECT THOUGHT TO BE A MISSILE
description: Finnish border guards searched rugged, snow-covered terrain today for what Norway said may have been an errant Soviet cruise missile.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES RELIEF FOR AFRICA BE RAISED BY $411 MILLION IN '85
description: President Reagan proposed today that the United States spend an extra $411 million on food aid for Africa, an amount that would bring total American Government assistance for famine victims to more than $1 billion.

title: BUCKS CAPTURE NINTH IN ROW
description: Paul Pressey, Craig Hodges and Kenny Fields combined for 17-of-19 shooting from the floor in the first half and Milwaukee coasted to an easy 111-87 victory over the Los Angeles Clippers tonight.

title: JACKSON BIDS POPE VISIT SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson urged Pope John Paul II today to visit South Africa and speak out against apartheid.

title: Impact on Jewelry Prices
description: It is too early to tell whether the recent drop in the price of gold will affect interest in owning the metal for investment. And retailers are not yet willing to predict when lower jewelry prices will reach consumers.

title:
THE TALK OF CHICAGO;

BEARS MAY GIVE CITY SWEET REVENGE
description: Chicago likes to think of itself as the city that works, one way or the other. But in recent years, what with political wars, racial politics and strikes, more things seemed not to. Then last year this city of three million people lost its Second City ranking to Los Angeles. And the Chicago Cubs, on the brink of departing from the cherished local baseball tradition of losing, reverted to form at the last minute, at the hands of a team from another sunny southern California city with a Spanish name.

title: LATE PLUNGE SENDS DOW DOWN BY 9.05
description: PHILLIP H. WIGGINS Stock prices plunged in late trading yesterday, once again battered by fears of higher interest rates.

title: A SCHOOL THE THIRD WORLD ADOPTS AS ALMA MATER
description: A term at one of Washington's more unusual schools has just ended.

title: AFTER A YEAR, UPSTATE AREAS STILL RESISTING BUILDING CODE
description: A year after a stiff building and fire code went into effect in New York State, many villages and towns in rural parts of the state are having problems with enforcement or are ignoring the new standards, according to contractors and local officials.

title: FORMER POLISH OFFICER CALLS PRIEST'S KILLING 'LONG NIGHTMARE'
description: A former Polish security police lieutenant today described as ''absurd'' and ''a long nightmare'' his part in the kidnapping and killing of a pro-Solidarity priest,

title: REAGAN PHYSICIAN BEGINS JOB
description: Dr. Burton Smith, a Los Angeles urologist, today began his new job as White House physician, replacing Dr. Daniel Ruge.

title: DEPARTURES AT THE TOP
description: Two high-level resignations from the Reagan Administration reflect a continuing cleavage that has developed within President Reagan's inner circle and may soon leave him without any of his longtime California associates among his top staff. Although resignations are common at the start of a President's second term, some close political allies pointed out that the departures would highlight the rivalry and feuding that has gone on between ideological conservatives and pragmatists at high levels of the Administration. They also privately voiced concern that Mr. Reagan's loss of longtime high-level associates reflects a certain loss of momentum and enthusiasm within the Administration compared with four years ago.

title: REAGAN MAY JOIN SUPER BOWL CEREMONIES AFTER TAKING OATH
description: The committee planning President Reagan's second inauguration has suggested to ABC and the National Football League that Mr. Reagan, by a remote broadcast from Washington, participate in ceremonies before the start of the Super Bowl in Palo Alto, Calif., on Jan. 20, hours after he takes the oath of office.

title: LAWYER FROM ISRAEL LEARNING U.S. ROPES ON CIVIL LIBERTIES
description: One thing the state of Israel and the District of Columbia have in common is a generous supply of lawyers. But the comparison ends when it comes to civil rights lawyers.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday HISTORY BETWEEN COVERS

title: No Headline
description: Under tight security, Bernhard Hugo Goetz was returned to Manhattan yesterday and charged with attempted murder in the shooting of four teen-agers on an IRT subway train. He was held in $50,000 cash bail and placed in protective custody at Rikers Island.

title: DEVILS' COMEBACK FIZZLES
description: The Devils' defense, which has been the strength of the team this season, had a horrendous performance tonight, allowing Vancouver to score a 6-4 victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Corea at Blue Note
description: The pianist Chick Corea, the bassist Miroslav Vitous and the drummer Roy Haynes will play jazz trios through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M. tonight and tomorrow, and at 9 and 11 P.M. Sunday; there is a $17.50 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, and a $5 cover and one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: WHAT TO DO ABOUT THE HOMELESS, STARTING NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics;   Fast Shuffles;   Dummies
description: Once computers learned to play bridge, it was only a matter of time before they organized a tournament. According to The Times's bridge columnist, Alan Truscott, it's happening next week in Queens.

title: Washington 78, Stanford 69
description: Chris Welp, a sophomore center, scored 24 points and helped Washington break open a close game late in the first half of a Pacific-10 Conference opener.

title: 'LOST' FILM TREASURES IN JAPAN SOCIETY SERIES
description: Under a crumbling gate in the old Japanese capital of Kyoto sit three men - an American moviegoer, a film critic and a reporter. They are hiding from a rainstorm, and they are arguing.

title: Stolen Jesus Figurine Is Returned to Cr eche
description: A statue of the Christ child stolen Christmas Day from a cr eche near Town Hall was put back in the manger today after it arrived in the mail from New York.

title: 'No Best Better Way'
description: The choreographer Sally Silvers will appear with 16 dancers and 10 musicians in ''No Best Better Way'' tonight, tomorrow and Sunday at 9 o' clock in the Merce Cunningham Studio, 55 Bethune Street.

title: Factory Orders Up 4.3% in Reversal
description: Orders to American factories for manufactured goods rose 4.3 percent in November, the biggest increase in 17 months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: U.S. AIDE SEES LONG ROAD IN ARMS TALKS
description: The White House national security adviser said today that because of the great differences between them, the United States and the Soviet Union faced ''a long road'' in trying to achieve new arms control agreements.

title: Reagan Renominates Meese WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 - President Reagan today resubmitted for Senate confirmation the appointment of Edwin Meese 3d to replace William French Smith as Attorney General and asked the Senate majority leader for help in winning speedy confirmation.
description: Marlin Fitzwater, a deputy White House press secretary, said Mr. Meese's nomination was sent back to the Senate with five pages of other names representing previous Presidential appointees who did not complete the confirmation process in the last Congressional session.

title: DRUG OVERDOSE KILLED 8 BABIES, INQUIRY FINDS
description: A royal commission reported today that a 15-month investigation of the deaths of 36 infants at a pediatric-care hospital here had found that at least eight of the deaths were the result of deliberate overmedication.

title: Numbers Game
description: At first it was kind of a joke. Dave Wolf, the boxing manager, wanted to see just how high Randy Stephens, his cruiserweight, would rise in the World Boxing Association rankings.

title: EXCERPTS FROM STATEMENT BY REAGAN ON AFRICA FAMINE
description: Following are excerpts from a statement by President Reagan made public by the White House today on United States aid to famine victims in Africa:

title: 32 People Are Arrested In South Africa Protest
description: Rep. Mervyn M. Dymally, a California Democrat, was among 32 people arrested outside the South African Embassy today in the latest round of marches protesting that nation's racial policies.

title: Vintage Farm Life
description: American farm life in the 18th century is the subject of a tour on Sunday at 2 P.M. at Washington's Headquarters Museum, Virginia Road in North White Plains.

title: OUT OF MANCHURIA: ORPHANS OF '45 SEEK OUT PAST
description: Her name was Ze Jiaying, and she said she was Japanese, an accident of birth not reflected in her life.

title: REAGAN CONDEMNS ARSON AT CLINICS
description: President Reagan today condemned the recent rash of bombings at abortion clinics around the country as ''violent, anarchist activities'' and pledged to see that the perpetrators were brought to justice. He did not order any change in the way the inquiry was being pursued.

title: Ford Won't
Bridge:Women Are Making Impact On Administration of Game
description: Women make up slightly more than half the bridge-playing population of the United States, and no doubt there are far more woman-hours devoted to playing than there are man-hours. Nevertheless the administration of the game for half a century has been almost entirely a male prerogative.

title: Miami Police Chief Out; Ex-Chief Might Get Job
description: Miami's police chief and assistant chief have resigned less than a year after the chief's predecessor was abruptly dismissed.

title: E.E.C. Inflation Eases
description: Consumer prices in the European Economic Community rose four-tenths of 1 percent in November from the previous month, the trading bloc's statistical agency, Eurostat, said today. Prices were up 6.5 percent on average in the 10 Common Market nations for the 12-month period, the lowest inflation rate for the community in more than 12 years.

title: Debt Issues
Fannie Mae Offers
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association announced the pricing on a $2 billion offering of debentures to be sold today.

title: Star-Studded List
description: Pete Rozelle , the commissioner of the National Football League, has been nominated along with 13 former players and one former coach,

title: Grenade Kills Thai Children
description: A hand grenade exploded at an elementary school in northern Thailand on Wednesday, killing 16 children and wounding at least 31 others. The police said today that the blast occurred as children of the rural Ban Laem Rang School were lining up after lunch to return to classes. They said the hand grenade had apparently been found by one of the students.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: THE BEANS OF EGYPT, MAINE. By

title: Military Contracts
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A. won a $214.7 million contract for jet fuel from the Defense Logistics Agency, the Defense Department said.

title: 12TH NIGHT: 9 WAYS TO CELEBRATE
description: THE holiday season may seem to have come to a close New Year's Day. But there's more celebrating to be done this weekend, which marks the Epiphany or ''Little Christmas'' on Sunday, 12 days after Christmas, and Twelfth Night or the eve of the Epiphany tomorrow. The commemoration of the visit of the Three Wise Men or Magi to adore the newborn Jesus, the Epiphany is actually a far older feast than Christmas, and in some cultures a more important holy day. Here in New York, eight organizations will be celebrating the feast.

title: GEN. R.E. CUSHMAN, EX-MARINE HEAD, DIES
description: Gen. Robert E. Cushman Jr., a former Commandant of the Marine Corps and deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, died Wednesday at his home in Fort Washington, Md., apparently of a heart attack, a Pentagon spokesman said. He was 70 years old.

title: Bomb Blast in Netherlands
description: A bomb severely damaged a power relay station near this northwestern Dutch town today, but the police said electricity supplies were not affected. No one claimed responsibility for the bombing and no arrests were made.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Baker Instruments Corp., Allentown, Pa., a subsidiary of Richardson-Vicks Inc., has appointed Gene E. Lewis president.

title: CLASSIC SKI MOVE IS REVIVED
description: Old-time skiers might recall making telemark turns down hillsides long before Alpine skiing became a popular sport. Thus it should come as no surprise that this classic ski maneuver is making a revival among younger skiers today.

title: Anne Klein Chooses McCaffery & Ratner
description: McCaffery & Ratner has become agency for Anne Klein Fragrances, which are marketed in this country under a licensing agreement by Parlux Inc.

title: Diner's Journal
description: S.O.B.'s (Sounds of Brazil) at 204 Varick Street is well-known among the musical set for its thundering Latin percussion combos and other exotic bands, but people realize that it also offers some intriguing Brazilian food. The club is open Wednesday through Sunday evenings and dinner is served from 7. The chef specializes in the cuisine of Bahia, which is an amalgam of African, Indian and Portuguese influences. It is characterized by seafood, particularly shrimp, cooked with palm oil and coconut milk.

title: OPERA: LEONTYNE PRICE'S FINAL STAGE PERFORMANCE
description: THE farewell appearances of great singers are generally exercises in patience for their admirers. Happy to say, last night's performance of ''A"ida'' at the Metropolitan, billed in the program as ''Leontyne Price's farewell to opera,'' might just as well have been entitled ''Patience Rewarded.'' The 57-year-old soprano took an act or two to warm to her work, but what she delivered in the Nile Scene turned out to be well worth the wait. In her most taxing aria, ''O patria mia,'' there were powerful reminders of the Price that we remember best and want to remember, a Price beyond pearls. It was, intermittently but often enough to make the evening a memorable event, the singing of an artist of distinctive vocal timbre and personality.

title: TRIAL ORDERED IN OFFICE TOWER DISPUTE
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ordered a trial to determine whether New York City acted arbitrarily in canceling an agreement designating a developer for a vacant site in lower Manhattan.

title: GOETZ DROVE ACROSS NEW ENGLAND FOR SEVERAL DAYS BEFORE SURRENDER
description: Although police officials here and in New York City said today that they were still not sure where Mr. Goetz spent about four of the nine days between the Dec. 22 shooting and the day of his surrender, they said receipts found in his car indicated that he had kept moving and had not always used his real name when registering in motels.

title: People
description: Peter F. DeVaux named executive vice president at Young & Rubicam USA.

title: KAHANE IN THE KNESSET
description: To the Editor:

title: Clarence J. Laughlin;Photographer, Essayist
description: Clarence John Laughlin, one of the first Surrealist photographers in the country and a writer of poetic essays, died here Wednesday in Touro Infirmary after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: PACKWOOD AND FAMILY ARE GUARDED AFTER THREAT
description: Bob Packwood, the new chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and his family received intensive police protection for the past week after they were threatened by a neo-Nazi group, an aide to the Senator said today.

title: Jazz on Celluloid
description: Vintage jazz films from the collection of David Chertok will be shown tonight at 8 at St. Peter's Church, 54th Street and Lexington Avenue in the Citicorp Center (935-2200). There will be footage of Cannonball Adderley, Art Blakey, John Coltrane, Miles Davis, Eric Dolphy, Charles Mingus, Thelonious Monk and Wayne Shorter. Admission is $5.

title: BROADWAY
description: WORD is that Lily Tomlin is headed for Broadway, via the Santa Fe Theater Festival, where she will try out a one- woman show called ''Works in Progress . . . No Costumes, No Scenery, No Props, No Refunds.'' That seems to take care of credits, other than Jane Wagner, who is apparently set for directorial chores. For anyone riding into the sunset, Jan. 16 to Feb. 3 are Miss Tomlin's dates in New Mexico. The festival there has also lined up Don Meredith and Frank Gifford for 11 performances in May to benefit the festival. The redoubtable duo will temporarily forsake football for the indoor sport known as bickering. They'll play the leads in ''The Odd Couple.''

title: No Headline
description: In Energy Deal By The Associated Press W.R. Grace & Company, a

title: Greens and Blossoms
description: Several herbal and floral displays marking the holiday season will be on view through Sunday at the Cloisters, Fort Tryon Park.

title: Moves at New Republic
description: Hendrik Hertzberg is leaving the editorship of The New Republic after four years to become a fellow at the Kennedy Institute of Politics in Cambridge, Mass. Succeeding him as editor, according to Martin Peretz, editor in chief and president of the magazine, is Michael E. Kinsley, now a senior editor, who will continue to write the TRB column.

title: Coast Mayor Sworn In To Shouts of 'Whoop!'
description: Bud Clark settled into the Mayor's office today after a swearing-in ceremony that rang with shouts of ''Whoop, whoop!'' his campaign battle cry.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY VOTES INCOME-TAX RELIEF BILL
description: The New Jersey Assembly today passed a bill that would allow homeowners and tenants to deduct property taxes from their state income taxes despite charges by the Republican minority that it was an ''election-year gimmick.'' Carl Golden, press secretary to Governor Kean, said the Governor would veto the bill if it passed the Senate and reached his desk. ''He considers it fiscally irresponsible,'' Mr. Golden said.Mr. Kean last month signed a bill establishing a commission to study state and local taxes, including the state income tax, and to recommend changes to the Legislature. The growing debate between the Republican administration and the Democratic-controlled Legislature comes during a year when the governorship and all 80 seats in the Assembly are up for election. The tax deduction proposed by the Democrats would cost the treasury about $145 million a year. The Democratic majority said the program could easily be financed this year out of the budget surplus, which is expected to reach about $700 million by the end of the fiscal year on June 30.

title: Fourth-Quarter Charge Of $195 Million at Amax
description: Amax Inc. yesterday announced a $195 million write-down in the value of its depressed agricultural chemical business.

title: STUDENTS POOL EFFORTS TO AID THE NEEDIEST
description: Encouraged by teachers or parents, youngsters are contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in an effort to help ease the poverty and distress that they read about or see around them.

title: Philadelphia Mayor Sees An Edge for His City
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode says Philadelphia will enter the next century with a ''competitive edge'' over other Northeastern cities if it builds on the accomplishments of his first year in office.

title: Foote, Cone in Chicago Gets United Telecom
description: Foote, Cone & Belding's Chicago office and Golin/Harris Communications, a public relations subsidiary, have been retained to handle the $20- million-plus promotion account of United Telecom Communications of Westwood, Kan.

title: Money Fund Assets Decline
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined for the first time in 17 weeks, falling $2.14 billion, to $211.38 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: CASINO-UNION AIDE GETS 10-YEAR TERM
description: An official of a casino union was sentenced today to 10 years in prison and fined $10,000 for his role in a conspiracy to use the Atlantic City Mayor's office to benefit organized crime and businesses in return for payoffs.

title: ART: 'REPRESENTATION AND SEXUALITY,' MIXED MEDIA SHOW AT NEW MUSEUM
description: FOR those of us who believe that art should be seen and not read, the exhibition ''Difference: On Representation and Sexuality,'' at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, will not be a high-priority attraction. Organized by Kate Linker, a freelance art writer and critic, it's a mixed media show - including photographs-cum-texts, video pieces and films - purporting to deal with the way gender distorts the perception of ''reality'' in our culture. The 31 participants are male and female artists from England and the United States who have created, according to Miss Linker, ''a significant body of work'' in the ''complex terrain triangulated by the terms sexuality, meaning and language.''

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Xerox Names President For International Units
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that Robert F. Reiser had been named to the new position of president, international operations.

title: Tobacco Imports Issue
description: Tobacco imports should be restricted before they ruin the Federal tobacco program and drive the nation's leaf farmers out of business, lawmakers told the United States International Trade Commission today.

title: LUIGI B. VERCELLI
description: Luigi B. Vercelli, the retired director of the Savoy Grill in London, died Tuesday at his home here. He was 86 years old.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: -to- earth, inexpensive bistros, informal spots where one can have a homey casserole or grilled entree, a bottle of simple wine and dessert for about the price of an appetizer in some of the more stratospheric Gallic temples around town. Cafe 58, an unpretentious and amiable spot on the East Side, is about as close as one gets to that these days. Its prix fixe meals run in the $13 to $17 range and, while there is much room for improvement, one should be grateful that it is making the effort.

title: Pickens Sued Over Phillips
description: A class-action has been filed against T. Boone Pickens and the Phillips Petroleum Company, challenging a settlement that ended Mr. Pickens's hostile bid for control of Phillips.

title: Bogus Jeans for Charity
description: Twenty thousand counterfeit designer jeans from Mexico that were seized by customs agents will be distributed to charities, an Assistant United State Attorney, Richard Poe, said today. The bogus Jordache jeans, valued at more than $306,000, have been in a warehouse for over a year, since a judge ordered them forfeited to the Federal Government.

title: KOCH IS DEFENDED AGAINST CRITICS BY ANTI-DEFAMATION LEAGUE AIDS
description: The executive director of the Anti- Defamation League said yesterday that Jewish leaders who had accused Mayor Koch of irritating race relations in the city were ''contributing to black- Jewish abrasions, rather than soothing them.''

title: Economic Scene ;   Dismal Views And Remedies
description: It was Thomas Carlyle who, in 1850, called economists ''Respectable Professors of the Dismal

title: DEAVER TO LEAVE WHITE POST FOR PRIVATE LIFE
description: Michael K. Deaver, President Reagan's deputy chief of staff and his closest personal adviser, will resign in the spring, the White House announced today.

title: Jerry Lewis Sues Studio For Distributing Video
description: The comedian Jerry Lewis has filed a $10 million suit against Paramount Pictures Corporation claiming the studio violated Federal copyright laws by distributing videos of his 1963 movie ''The Nutty Professor.''

title: NEW-HOME SALES DOWN BY 10.6% IN NOVEMBER
description: Despite falling mortgage rates, sales of new homes dropped 10.6 percent in November, the sharpest monthly decline in almost three years, the Government reported today.

title: AssessmentRange Called Too Broad
description: The average home in New York state is assessed at either $12,000 above or below its market value, tax official said today.

title: Dupree Set in Portland
description: Marcus Dupree, the running back who is the Portland Breakers' most expensive player, flew here Wednesday and ended speculation that he would try to get out of his contract and play for another team.

title: Complaint Starts at Top
description: A bag Eastern Airlines lost New Year's Day turned out to belong to the person newly invested with authority over such matters: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole.

title: Key Rates
description: Split rate 10.75-11.25 * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PENTAGON WILL INCREASE ITS USE OF POLYGRAPH TESTS
description: The Defense Department announced today it would use polygraph, or lie-detector, tests to screen up to 3,500 employees and contractors whose jobs required access to the Pentagon's most highly confidential information.

title: Spain Will End Restrictions On Exchanges With Gibraltar
description: Spain will lift all restrictions on the passage of people and goods between the Spanish mainland and British-held Gibraltar on Feb. 5, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: SENARE BILLS SEEK RELEASE OF TRANSPORT FUNDS
description: Among the first measures offered in the Senate as the 99th Congress convened today were two bills, one with bipartisan support, aimed at releasing billions of dollars in Federal highway and mass transit funds.

title: Georgia Football Put on Probation
description: The University of Georgia said today that its football program had been placed on probation by the Natonal Collegiate Athletic Association for one year over recruiting violations. The penalty, the school said, would not affect television or bowl appearances.

title: Textron, Avco
description: Textron Inc. said it had received about 24 million shares of the Avco Corporation, or 84 percent of the common stock outstanding, in response to its tender offer for all shares at $50 each. The company also extended its offer, which was to expire last Wednesday, until next Wednesday. In trading today on the New York Stock Exchange, Avco closed unchanged at $49.50.

title: Judge Bars Law On Work Hazards
description: A Federal judge ruled today that part of New Jersey's ''right to know'' law requiring manufacturing companies to list hazardous substances in the workplace is superseded by Federal laws and regulations.

title: Ward President Moving to McCrory
description: The Rapid-American Corporation confirmed published reports yesterday that Stephen L. Pistner would be taking over as chairman and chief executive officer of the McCrory Corporation, Rapid's retail subsidiary, effective Feb. 1.

title: MADISON AVE. HOTEL RENOVATED WITH FOREIGN FUNDS
description: Four years ago, several major New York hotels passed into foreign ownership, and E. William Judson saw an opportunity to make a statement.

title: Three Marks Set in Swim
description: Three world bests, including a pair by relay teams from the United States, highlighted the first day of the United States Swimming Interational Meet at the University of Arkansas.

title: FOR ETHIOPIAN JEWS, ISRAEL IS ANOTHER WORLD
description: When Ethiopian Jews first arrived at Shaare Zedek hospital in Jerusalem, nurses in the isolation ward where the Ethiopians were being treated started noticing a lot of bread crumbs around.

title: Quintet at Vanguard
description: The pianist John Hicks is leading an all-star quintet through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South below 11th Street (255- 4037). In the group are Chico Freeman and Branford Marsalis on saxophones, Ray Drummond on bass and Idris Muhammed on drums. Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is an $8.50 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: 49ER LINEMAN BLUNT ABOUT FINESSE TALK
description: The San Francisco 49ers have been called a finesse team on offense, but their linemen take issue with that label.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''THE REAL McCOYS'' turns up briefly during ''The Flamingo Kid'' as a television program being glanced at by a wealthy car salesman named Phil Brody. But Richard Crenna, who was once best known for his ''Real McCoys'' role and has now been highly praised for his performance as Brody, cites another of his previous portrayals as the model for this one.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Bonds Rally in Light Trading;    20-Year Issue Brings 11.86%
description: The bond market yesterday reclaimed some of the territory it gave up in its big decline on Wednesday, pushing interest rates down slightly after a week of increases.

title: 2 Indicted inDeath Of Woman on L.I.
description: A grand jury has indicted two men charged with running over and killing a 17-year-old woman in a parking lot last November after an argument, Nassau County District Attorney Denis Dillon said today.

title: McDonald Is Out
description: In what the club said was a ''mutually agreed upon decision''

title: Bank Loss Put
description: At $11 Million LUGANO, Switzerland, Jan.

title: BRIEFS
description: Bergen Brunswig Corp. , a drug and health care company, said it had completed the acquisition of Synergex Corp., a wholesaler of drugs and medical products, for a total of $79 million, or about $18 a share.

title: 99TH CONGRESS OPENS SOMBERLY IN DEFICIT SHADOW
description: In a somber and serious mood, the 99th Congress opened for business today, and leaders from both parties agreed that their top priority would be a legislative package aimed at reducing budget deficits that are now approaching $200 billion a year.

title: EXPORT RESTRAINTS LEAD TO COMPETITION
description: To the Editor:

title: New Zealand Painters
description: An exhibition by contemporary painters from New Zealand will be on view through Jan. 26 at the 22 Wooster Gallery, 22 Wooster Street. The artists are Gretchen Albrecht, Stephen Bambury, Jeffrey Harris, Richard Killeen, James Ross and Philip Trusttum. Hours are Tuesday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: STAUB RETAINED BY METS
description: Dave Johnson, the Mets' manager, was not there to speak for himself yesterday when the Mets formally announced they had signed Rusty Staub to a one-year contract. But Frank Cashen, the general manager, explained Johnson's role in Staub's return.

title: Crum & Forster
description: The Xerox Corporation's Crum & Forster unit said it had sold five of its office properties to two limited partnerships organized by Integrated Resources Inc. for $127 million. The transactions cover two properties in Morris Township, two in the San Francisco area and one in Dallas. Crum & Forster, which will hold long-term leases on the properties, said the sale would help generate long-term capital to support its insurance operations.

title: Big Brothers, Little Apples
description: Western societies have taken to the personal computer as easily as to video recorders. For the Soviet Union, it poses awesome problems. In a society that keeps even copying machines under lock and key, the personal computer challenges the state's monopoly of information.

title: Vandalism Closes Schools
description: The slashing of 303 school bus tires forced the cancellation of classes for a second day in the Neshaminy School District, district officials said today. Kenneth Chattin, 18 years old, of Levittown, a Neshaminy High School senior, was arrested in connection with the vandalism, the police said. Also arrested was a juvenile, whose name and age were withheld.

title: $250,000 for Africa
description: It was standing room only at the offices of Catholic Relief Services as Paul Newman went there to donate $250,000 for emergency and agricultural rehabilitation programs in drought-stricken Africa.

title: Control Data
description: The Control Data Corporation plans to introduce three computers later this month with memories four times larger than current models.

title: General Felt, Michigan General
description: General Felt Industries told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in the Michigan General Corporation to about 1,868,000 shares, or 16.5 percent of the total outstanding. General Felt, a Saddle Brook, N.J., floor products concern, said its GFI Nevada unit bought 219,800 shares on Dec. 24.

title: POP:TODD RUNDGREN SOLO
description: AN admired cult figure for more than a decade, Todd Rundgren has anticipated by several years many of the innovations in synthesizer and video technology that have changed the face of pop music. But despite his visionary outlook, Mr. Rundgren has remained a marginal figure commercially, leaving it to others to reap the full benefits of his technological foresight.

title: MILLIONAIRE ANTIPOVERTY PROGRAM OF THE AIR
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics ;   Fast Shuffles ;   Youth Creep
description: When people told Gloria Steinem at her birthday party last spring, ''You don't

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 4, 1985

title: VINEYARD SERIES SPANS 'FIVE CENTURIES AND A BIT'
description: -catching and slightly mind-boggling title for a series of nine concerts that it will present this month, starting on Sunday: ''The Five-Century Jazz Series.''

title: Kicker for Steelers Seeks Consistency
description: Gary Anderson is still upset over his failure to make three of the four field goals he attempted in the Pittsburgh Steelers' 24-17 American Confernce playoff victory over the Denver Broncos Sunday.

title: Claude Pepper Avenue
description: While he was a member of the Senate in the 1940's, Claude Pepper of Florida sponsored a resolution calling for the return of the Dodecanese Islands from Italy to Greece. The citizens of Rhodes, the largest of the islands, were so grateful when the transfer was made that they named one of the streets in their capital city Claude Pepper Avenue.

title: St Germain on Deregulation
description: Representative Fernand J. St Germain, the chairman of the House Banking Committee, declared today that he intends to frustrate Administration-backed efforts to further deregulate the financial services industry in the 99th Congress.

title: Trial of Lambsdorff Is Postponed Indefinitely
description: The trial of former Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff on corruption charges, which was scheduled to begin Jan. 10, has been postponed indefinitely on legal grounds, the Bonn district court said today.

title: Article 192371 -- No Title
description: California astronomers today announced a private grant of $70 million that they said would enable construction of the world's largest optical telescope.

title: Abraham & Straus Has a New Chief
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. said yesterday that Chaim Edelstein had been named chairman and chief executive officer of its Brooklyn- based Abraham & Straus division.

title: ISRAEL HAS AIRLIFTED 10,000 ETHIOPIANS
description: The Government, acknowledging for the first time that it has been secretly airlifting Ethiopian Jews from their drought- stricken country to Israel, said today that more than 10,000 had been brought out in the last few years.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Phoenix Suns, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The Suns, playing much of the season without the injured Walter Davis, have nonetheless managed to stay reasonably close to the first-place Los Angeles Lakers in the Pacific Division.

title: Auction Held in New Orleans To Recoup Some Fair Losses
description: The United States pavilion at the world's fair, a prefabricated steel structure that cost $5.5 million to build, was sold today for $130,000 at the start of a three- day auction intended to recoup some of the money the exposition lost.

title: EXODUS OF JEWS FROM SOVIET IS REPORTED TO DECLINE TO 896 IN 1984
description: The number of Jews permitted to emigrate from the Soviet Union dropped below 1,000 last year for the first time since 1970, American Jewish officials said yesterday.

title: Opponents of Iraqi President Accuse Him of Killing Troops
description: Leaders of the opposition to Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, accused him today of imprisoning and killing hundreds of Iraqi soldiers.

title: Jobless Rate in Britain
description: The unemployment rate in Britain in December was 13.4 percent, unchanged in December from a month earlier, the Department of Employment said today.

title: Production Set For McDonnell Jet
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it plans to begin commercial production of its MD-87 aircraft after receiving orders for 12 of the jets.

title: COMPUTER SEEKS LOST FRIENDS
description: A grandmother in Arkansas is looking for the niece she has not seen in years to tell her she is an heir. A 21- year-old woman in New York wants to find the pen pal she shared secrets with when they were 12. And two men who traveled to the Vietnam Memorial in Washington did not find the name of their commanding officer in Vietnam, who they thought was dead. Now they are looking for him.

title: SOVIET PHYSICIST IN EXCHANGE VISIT GRANTED U.S. ASYLUM IN CHICAGO
description: A Soviet physicist participating in an exchange program at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory near Chicago has been granted asylum in the United States, State Department officials said today.

title: Heir Apparent at TRW Was Seen as Long Shot
description: TRW Inc. said yesterday that Joseph T. Gorman had become its president and chief operating officer.

title: Advertising ;   First TV For Sorg Printing
description: The Sorg Printing Company,

title: AIDS-RELATED VIRUS FOUND IN BRAINS OF CERTAIN VICTIMS
description: Scientists reported today that they had found the virus suspected of causing acquired immune deficiency syndrome in the brains of AIDS victims who suffered memory loss, impaired concentration and other signs of dementia.

title: Gas Decontrol Benefits Cited
description: The Energy Department today said total decontrol of natural gas prices would lead to lower consumer prices than the partial decontrol that took effect Tuesday.

title: EASTERN MEETS TODAY ON PAY DISPUTE
description: The dispute between Frank Borman, the chairman of Eastern Airlines, and union leaders over his extension of substantial wage concessions will be thrashed out at a special board meeting today.

title: CUOMO TO SEEK A CUT IN TAXES AND DEBT IN '85
description: Shrinking New York State's swollen short-term debt and cutting taxes will be key features of the coming year's budget, Governor Cuomo promised yesterday.

title: Singing a Song Of Red Auerbach
description: Singing a song of sixth men, the Boston Celtics will hon'r Arnold (Red) Auerbach, their guiding genius for 35 years, this weekend. The activities begin tonight with a ceremony in which a jersey, with No. 2 on it, will be hoisted to the top of the Boston Garden before the game against the Knicks.

title: CONGRESS WARNED THAT PROJECTIONS ON DEFICIT ARE UP
description: The Administration warned the new Congress today that deficit projections were higher than anticipated a month ago, when President Reagan approved a deficit-reducing plan. The latest projections indicate the deficits over the next three years will be $8 billion to $11 billion larger than planners had expected.

title: 'BERRINGER'S,' STARRING WANAMAKER
description: LORIMAR PRODUCTIONS has brought to the world of entertainment the evening soaps ''Dallas,'' ''Knots Landing'' and ''Falcon Crest.'' The studio's latest venture into what it prefers to call ''the nighttime continuing drama genre'' is titled ''Berrenger's'' and it gets under way tomorrow at 9:30 on Channel 4 with a special 90-minute segment. It's all about a trendy New York department store, bearing a calculated resemblance to establishments like Bloomingdale's, and the producers - David Jacobs, Stuart Sheslow and Diana Gould - promise to go ''behind the mannequins, display cases and tables for an intimate look'' at the owners and employees.

title: ART: MICHAEL LUCHS IN ONE-MAN EXHIBITION
description: MICHAEL LUCHS'S signature form is a rabbit. Not the gravity-defying rabbit of the sculptor Barry Flanagan. Not the meticulously rendered squat specimen of Albrecht D"urer, although Luchs's rabbits are also seated. Rather, his rabbits tend both to occupy the pictorial field and remain almost unrecognizable, like shadows on inner-city walls. In Luchs's first one-man show in New York, at the Oscarsson Hood Gallery, 41 West 57th Street, through tomorrow, the bounding, bountiful creatures of fairy tales and myths become themselves fields through which Luchs burns his way like General Sherman through the South.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Heart Patient's Status Changed to Satisfactory
description: The condition of William J. Schroeder, the artificial heart recipient, was changed today to satisfactory for the first time since he suffered three strokes Dec. 13, a spokesman said.

title: Savings Bank Sets Eurobond
description: The Centrust Savings Bank of Miami announced yesterday that it was offering zero coupon Eurobonds to be worth $1.2 billion at maturity in 25 years.

title: Columbia Aide Moving to Fox
description: Jonathan Dolgen, president of the domestic operations of Columbia Pictures and president of Columbia's pay cable- home entertainment division, will join the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation Monday in the new position of senior executive vice president.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 4, 1985 International

title: Required Reading;   The Law as a Ship
description: Why should constitutional law constantly be catching colds from the intellectual fevers of the general society?

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''RESOLUTIONS?'' Claudette Colbert exclaimed. ''I gave them up 50 years ago without ever having kept one. Have

title: A Bill on City Hopping WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) - Senator Arlen Specter introduced
description: today a bill that would block the movement of professional football

title: Philippine Grenade Kills 8
description: A grenade exploded in a cock-fighting pit in a central Philippine town, killing eight people, including the two soldiers who smuggled it in, the state-run press agency said today. Twelve other people were wounded in the New Year's Day blast on eastern Samar Island, 370 miles southeast of Manila. It was not known if the soldiers detonated the grenade on purpose or by accident.

title: Cosmos Get Liveric
description: The Cosmos, having lost four recent games by one-goal margins, have moved to increase their scoring punch by acquiring

title: Market Place ;   Metals Issues Gaining Favor
description: Last year was anything but a winner for nonferrous metal stocks, mainly because a weak

title: INVESTMENT IN ULSTER OPPOSED
description: Some members of the City Council are seeking to prevent the New York City pension system from investing in American corporations that they say discriminate against Roman Catholics in Northern Ireland.

title: SEVERE WINTER STORM MOVING INTO SOUTHEAST
description: Winter storms that were blamed for 18 deaths in the Southwest and the Middle West pushed into the Southeast yesterday with freezing rain, sleet and snow that closed schools and highways.

title: CBS JURY IS TOLD OF OFFICER'S LETTERS CITING 'LIES' ABOUT ENEMY STRENGTH
description: The jury in the trial of Gen. William C. Westmoreland's libel suit against CBS was shown a series of letters yesterday in which an intelligence analyst in South Vietnam wrote to his wife in 1968 that ''outright lies'' and ''truly gargantuan falsehoods'' were involved in estimates of enemy strength.

title: CONDEMNED KILLER OF 4 ELECTROCUTED IN LOUISIANA
description: David Dene Martin, a former youth conselor who said stress and drugs led him to murder his wife's lover and three other people, was executed early today after the State Pardon Board refused a last-minute plea to spare him from the electric chair.

title: Pagel Seeks a Trade
description: After spending the season as one of three quarterbacks for the Indianapolis Colts,

title: Bond Issue in Hungary
description: A Budapest stocking factory has issued this Communist country's first public bonds, the state-run press agency said today.

title: Dining Out Guide: Risotto
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: Noah Tops Lendl
description: With his serve working and his attacking style paying off in the final set, Yannick Noah of France beat Ivan Lendl, 7-6, 6-7, 6-1, today in the $1.3 million Challenge of Champions.

title: NIGERIA, A YEAR AFTER THE COUP
description: A year ago this week saw the overthrow of Nigerian democracy. The symbolic loss of a beacon of open government in Africa is still to be deeply lamented, but the coup and the experience of a year of military rule raise difficult questions about the very real limitations of democracy in developing countries.

title: KOREA'S UNPOPULAR GIANTS
description: In the showroom where the Daewoo Corporation proudly displays its wares, giant panda dolls stand next to shelves of jogging shoes. Grand pianos bump up against scale-model tractors, cranes and ships. Personal computers vie for space with video recorders and stuffed toy rabbits.

title: EXCERPTS FROM WHITE HOUSE PAMPHLET ON SPACE-ARMS RESEARCH PROGRAM
description: Following are excerpts from a pamphlet issued today by the White House titled ''The President's Strategic Defense Initiative'':

title: Bridge Entrance Shut in Brooklyn
description: The Tillary Street entrance to the Brooklyn Bridge walkway in Brooklyn was closed yesterday for replacement of railings and roadway barriers.

title: 4 U.S. Companies Vie for Saudi Pact
description: Four major American companies have proposed a total of 50 projects in Saudi Arabia in their bid to win multibillion-dollar military contracts in the kingdom, the Saudi Arabian newspaper Arab News reported.

title: WOMEN FIDDLE WHILE IRISH DANCE JIGS AND REELS
description: Traditional Irish dance music, which has been passed down from father to son for generations, will be performed tomorrow night - by women.

title: Rescuers Try to Reach Plane Wreck in Bolivia
description: Red Cross rescue workers began the arduous ascent of a snow-covered Andean mountain today to the wreckage of an Eastern Airlines jetliner that crashed with 29 people aboard.

title: U.S. STUDYING THE HANDLING OF '81 HIJACKING CASE
description: A Federal investigation is under way to determine if there were irregularities by F.B.I. agents and Justice Department officials in the prosecution in 1981 of a Bronx hijacking ring.

title: Derailment in Kentucky
description: Thirty-one cars of a freight train derailed Wednesday night, and a tanker car containing a hazardous chemical overturned, prompting officials to evacuate 110 people, police and rail officials said. No injuries were reported in the derailment of the Seaboard System train in Emlyn, three miles south of this town, said Police Officer Troy Sharp. He said there was no immediate danger.

title: Jazz at Sweet Basil
description: The bassist Richard Davis and a quintet including Hannibal Peterson on trumpet, George Adams on saxophones, Kenny Barron on piano and Frederick Waits on drums will perform tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: MAN AND TWO WOMEN FOUND SLAIN IN TUDOR CITY
description: Three people were found slain yesterday in an apartment in Tudor City on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: WHAT TO DO ABOUT THE HOMELESS, STARTING NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG BOARD PANEL URGES EASED LISTING STANDARD
description: The New York Stock Exchange, which has faced growing competitive pressure from other markets, should loosen its standards for the companies whose trading it supervises, a Big Board study group recommended yesterday.

title: RESTAURANT CHAIN CHIEF RESIGNS
description: Diversifoods Inc., which has been in turmoil since October, said today that its chief executive was leaving the company at the request of the board and that the fourth-quarter dividend was being omitted.

title: HEAD OF DRUG AGENCY QUITS
description: Francis M. Mullen Jr., head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, has told the White House he intends to resign as of March 1, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: U.S. CITES HAZARDS FROM FUNGICIDES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, expressing concern over possible health hazards from fungus-fighting chemicals, announced today that it was submitting three of the chemicals to accelerated safety reviews.

title: Dec. 11-20 Auto Sales Fell 3% Shortage of Inventory Seen
description: Sales of new cars by the nation's six major auto manufacturers fell a slight 3 percent in the Dec. 11-20 period, the companies reported today.

title: JAZZ: HARRY WHITTAKER
description: THE pianist Harry Whittaker, who has performed around New York with such musicians as Jackie McLean, led his own trio Wednesday at Seventh Avenue South. Perhaps in deference to the club's usual pop-jazz policy, he played some passable funk along with intelligent, consistently imaginative jazz.

title: Boston Arsonist Given Up to 60 Years in Prison
description: A 28-year- old fire enthusiast who the authorities said led a band of fire buffs on a 14- month arson spree was sentenced today to up to 60 years in Federal and state prisons for his conviction on multiple charges.

title: TALBOTT TOPS SQUASH FIELD
description: Mark Talbott of Boston, who has yet to be beaten on the tour of the World Professional Squash Association this season, will try to extend his winning streak to seven tournaments at the $10,000 Greenwich Open this weekend.

title: Nordiques Loses Star
description: Michel Goulet , the Quebec Nordiques' high-scoring wing, broke his right thumb in a fist fight with

title: DOLPHIN DEFENDERS: NO TIME TO RELAX
description: The Dolphins' defense might have been so awed by the offense's ability to score this season that it simply relaxed when it got on the playing field.

title: PROGRAM IMMERSES PUPILS IN SPANISH
description: On the classroom wall a mural depicts Aztecs worshiping the sun. Children spin a Spanish-language globe and teachers rattle off numbers in Spanish.

title: State of Union Speech Feb. 6
description: President Reagan will deliver his State of the Union Messageto a joint session of Congress on Feb. 6, the House Majority Leader, Representative Jim Wright of Texas, announced today. Meanwhile, the House agreed unanimously to give the President until Feb. 4 to submit his budget for the 1986 fiscal year, extending the current deadline of Jan. 18. Mr. Reagan is scheduled to be sworn in for his second term on Jan. 21.

title: THOSE TWO 5-9 DOLPHINS
description: MIAMI

title: NICARAGUAN URGES U.S. TO REIN IN REBELS
description: A leader of Nicaragua's political opposition urged today that Congress renew aid to anti- Government guerrillas, but also suggested that the United States should do a better job of controlling the rebels' behavior in the field.

title: West German Output
description: Industrial production in West Germany was unchanged in November from October, the Economics Ministry said today. It said that manufacturing output was little changed, while production of power and gas companies increased and output of the construction industry fell slightly.

title: THE NEW RESTAURANTS: SPACE AND GRACE
description: Ten years ago, it seemed that no restaurant could open in New York unless it had white walls, unforgivingly spare furniture and industrial lighting, the more unflattering the better. Perhaps spurred by the success of the One Fifth restaurant, the first of the 1970's all-white restaurants with a subtle tiled interior featuring ocean views through fake portals, New York restaurants pared down and turned pale.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday misstated the status of two units of the Western Union Corporation: the E.F. Johnson Company and the Field Service Organization. Western Union is negotiating to sell the units.

title: CELTICS THRIVE ON AUERBACH NIGHT
description: Playing the Celtics in the Boston Garden was difficult enough. Playing them on a night they honored their beloved Red Auerbach made things that much harder.

title: AN 'OLD-FASHIONED' MAN KEEPS ADIRONDACK LORE ALIVE
description: A cloud of steam billowed from the vat of water simmering on the blackened wood stove as Bill Smith dunked splints of ash wood frosted with snow.

title: Powell Has Operation For Cancer of Prostate
description: Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr., underwent surgery today for cancer of the prostate, the Supreme Court's public information office announced today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is a real feeling that we have been impotent in providing alternatives on defense policy. This was an expression of that frustration.'' - Representative Leon E. Panetta of California. (7:5.)

title: BOND MARKETS DISCOUNT BIG MONEY SUPPLY RISE
description: The credit markets fluctuated indecisively yesterday, but finished on a positive note by shrugging off a larger-than-expected jump of $6.7 billion in the basic money supply.

title: HEAVY HEAT, LIGHT WORKOUT
description: They look like the world's biggest summer campers.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;    Campaign Scenarios
description: Who will finally decide to run

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER IN MACMILLAN'S 'ROMEO'
description: Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet'' is the most familiar and popular dance version of Sergei Prokofiev's score - not only because Britain's Royal Ballet performed it repeatedly to great acclaim on its American tours in the 1960's and 1970's, but also because it became an internationally distributed dance film with Rudolf Nureyev and Dame Margot Fonteyn.

title: ADMINISTRATION TO PRESS CONGRESS FOR NEW AID TO NICARAGUAN REBELS
description: The Reagan Administration plans to issue a white paper describing an arms buildup in Nicaragua in an extensive new campaign to persuade Congress to renew aid to Nicaraguan rebels, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Favor Revealed
description: Tyrone Sorrells, a receiver who signed with Georgia in 1982 but later transferred to Georgia Tech, has identified himself as the player whose acceptance of favors from a booster was primarily responsible for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's decision to place the Bulldogs' football program on probation for a year. Sorrells told a Georgia radio station that the booster had helped him get a bank loan to buy a used car and had then paid off the loan.

title: OCCIDENTAL, SHAMROCK STUDY LINK
description: Scovill Inc. appears close to accepting an improved $515 million takeover offer from the Belzberg family. Page 29.

title: A Few Good Women, Too
description: The Marine Corps recruiting ad

title: BLOCK WINS ON FARM SUSIDIES PLAN
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block has won modifications in the Reagan Administration plan to end dairy price supports next year and to slash the amount of Federal crop subsidies each farm may receive.

title: I WON'T REGISTER FOR THE DRAFT
description: On Tuesday, I will go on trial here for refusing to register for the draft. I am the 17th person nationwide and the first in New York State to be prosecuted for resisting draft registration. According to Selective Service, currently one-half million young men have refused to register.

title: Nebraska Court Upsets Minister's Jail Sentence
description: The Nebraska Supreme Court today overturned an eight-month jail sentence for contempt imposed on a fundamentalist minister after he refused to close an uncertified church school.

title: Flutie Talks to Begin Monday
description: Negotiations between the Generals and Doug Flutie's newly appointed agent, Bob Woolf, have been scheduled to begin Monday in Boston, Woolf's hometown. The team will be represented by its president, Jayson Seltzer, and perhaps also by Donald Trump, the owner.

title: Bucks' Streak Halted at 9
description: Quintin Dailey scored 26 points and Michael Jordan 22 tonight to spark the Chicago Bulls to a 106-101 victory over Milwaukee that ended the Bucks' winning streak at nine games.

title: SCHOLARSHIP IN ARTS FORMED IN MEMORY OF EDITOR AT TIMES
description: The formation of the Seymour Peck Scholarship in the Arts was announced yesterday at a memorial service for Mr. Peck, an editor of The New York Times Book Review and the paper's former cultural news editor. Mr. Peck died in an automobile accident Jan. 1. The service at the Park West Chapel, on Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, was attended by more than 800 people, including many prominent in the arts.

title: FRIGITRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DONORS LIST REASONS FOR INCREASING GIFTS TO FUND FOR NEEDIEST
description: For a variety of reasons - the celebration of a joyful event, the awareness of a greater need, even the mere passing of the years - many longtime contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are giving more this season than ever before.

title: Belgian Jobless Dip
description: Belgium's unemployment rate stood at 12 percent in December, down slightly from the 12.1 percent in both November and in December 1983, the National Labor Office said today. The agency said 505,505 people were out of work at the end of December, down 4,448 from November.

title: NORDIQUES DEFEAT SURGING CAPITALS
description: J.F. Sauve had two power-play goals and Wilf Paiement scored twice, including once when his team was short-handed, as the Quebec Nordiques defeated the Washington Capitals, 5-3, tonight.

title: NORTH DAKOTA JUSTICES BACK NEW GOVERNOR OVER OLD ONE
description: The State Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that North Dakota has a new Governor.

title: PRICE LOSES POST
description: In a surprise jolt to the seniority system, House Democrats defied their leaders today and ousted 80-year-old Representative Melvin Price as chairman of the Armed Services Committee.

title: SCOUTING ;   Last Is First
description: Dan Marino, the former University of Pittsburgh star who will lead the Dolphins in the American Football Conference championship game tomorrow, set three National Football League records this season by throwing for 48 touchdowns, completing 362 passes and passing for 5,084 yards. But in the 1983 National Football League draft, Marino was the last of six quarterbacks selected in the first round.

title: HANOI COMMUTES SENTENCE FOR 2 IN TREASON CASE
description: Two of five men condemned to death in a highly publicized subversion trial in Vietnam have had their sentences commuted to life imprisonment, Vietnam's official press agency reported.

title: THE ACCLAIMED ORATOR OF PENNSYULVANIA STAION
description: Daniel Simmons does not, simply cannot, take requests from the audience, no matter how much his fans wave and cry out for their favorites. These people just have to understand that he cannot, for example, just belt out his ever-popular ''All aboard!'' unless a train is actually about to leave the station.

title: Temporary Government The Reagan Administration says it's just good management to encourage Federal agencies to hire more temporary employees. And there's no question that it's useful to have ''temps'' on any large payroll, to expedite an unexpected workload or fill jobs that will soon expire.
description: But coming on top of the President's proposal to cut Federal pay 5 percent this year, the new hiring directive raises suspicions that the move is designed to produce shortsighted cost savings and greater political influence over the Civil Service.

title: Block's Farm Partner Defaults on U.S Loan
description: The business partner of Agriculture Secretary John R. Block has defaulted on a $400,000 emergency disaster loan from the Farmers Home Administration, the Government says.

title: SIMPLER PARKING SIGNS APPEAR TO BE WORKING
description: Give a driver a sign he can understand and he won't park illegally. That is the tentative conclusion city officials have reached after a year of a new sign-simplification program.

title: '85 Outlook For Honeywell MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 4
description: (Reuters) - A spokesman for

title:
PATENTS;

Number of Patents Rises to 72,149 in Year
description: The number of patents issued has increased substantially. The 1984 report of the Patent and Trademark Office, to be published soon, will show issuance of 72,149 patents during its fiscal year ended Sept. 30, compared with 59,715 in the previous fiscal year.

title: Amsterdam Train Halted
description: Twenty-five supporters of the Red Army Faction halted the Amsterdam- to-Munich express train near here today and spray-painted it with slogans backing a hunger strike being staged by members of the terrorist gang imprisoned in West Germany. One supporter of the West German gang was on the train and halted it by pulling an emergency brake, the police said.

title: SCOVILL TAKEOVER SEEN NEAR
description: Scovill Inc. appeared close yesterday to accepting a $515 million takeover offer from a company controlled by the Belzberg family.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: -born composer and musician who loved New York, where he died in 1924, is not exactly having a revival in town, but there are two places that are playing his music this weekend, one in his light mood, the other from his classical repertory.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in The Home Section on Dec. 27 with an article about an exhibition of Soviet ceramics in Oxford, England, mistranslated the Cyrillic characters on a plate. The translation should have been, ''Long Live Soviet Power.''

title: ADVISER WORKS ON, UNDER A SHADOW
description: ''I'm not chairman, I'm not even acting chairman, I think I'm de facto chairman,'' says William A. Niskanen Jr., smiling after a moment.

title: GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BUYING CONTACT LENSES: NEW WORLD OF CHOICES
description: In 1887, when they were first invented in Switzerland, there was one kind of contact lens, which was made of glass and covered the entire eye.

title: FLOWERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 15
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in October.

title: Bridge:Eight Teams in Contention ForSpotinLas VegasEvent
description: The eight teams due to battle today at the Cavendish Club in the Grand National Team Championship have more reason for optimism than they would have had in any previous year. The winning team, after three rounds of knockout play, will compete in Las Vegas in July without having to compete, as formerly, at a zonal level.

title: THE DANCE: SUSAN MARSHALL AND COMPANY
description: The stormy dances that Susan Marshall and Company presented Thursday night in the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater had only the sketchiest of plots. Yet Miss Marshall always managed to establish implicitly dramatic situations, and the way she wrestled with emotions brought to mind the intensity of a real wrestling match.

title: Government-Rebel Pact Is Reported in Colombia
description: Guerrillas reportedly signed an agreement today to withdraw from one of their bases, ending a three-week confrontation with the army.

title: Oil Prices Fall Again
description: Prices of crude oil and heating oil plummeted again yesterday on markets around the world, and traders talked of light crude oil slipping below $25 a barrel sometime soon.

title: ETHIOPIA ATTACKS JEWS' DEPARTURE
description: The airlift of Ethiopian Jews to Israel was condemned today by the Ethiopian Government, which called the Israeli project ''a gross interference'' in this country's affairs.

title: Colorado Governor Says He Will Not Run in 1986
description: Gov. Richard D. Lamm has announced that he will not run for any office in 1986.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Chicago Bulls, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Traveling with Michael Jordan, says Orlando Woolridge, one of his Chicago teammates, is a bit like being one of Michael Jackson's brothers on the victory tour. Still, Woolridge has moves of his own, as was affirmed when he was invited along with Jordan to the slam-dunk contest at the All-Star Game. The invitation was an unusual one, because a team ordinarily sends no more than one representative. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT, 930; WFAS, 1230; WGBB, 1240; all at 7:20 P.M.)

title: JAILED PASTOR'S BACKERS OUSTED FROM THE CHURCH
description: Sheriff's deputies burst into a small church here today and arrested seven supporters of its jailed minister who had barricaded themselves inside to protest his ouster and to support his militant campaign to end high unemployment in the region.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 26.

title: Dow Falls 4.86 as Decline Continues
description: Stocks declined yesterday, for the third day in a row, as concern over the true course of interest rates, corporate earnings and the Federal deficit continued to worry traders, analysts said.

title: Time-Life Books Head
description: William Henry has been named president and chief operating officer of Time-Life Books Inc., the publishing subsidiary of Time Inc. announced yesterday.

title: GEORGE A. BRAGA
description: George A. Braga, a former sugar- company executive, died Tuesday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived in Alpine, N.J.

title: A SUMMER OF SCANDALS IN THE LAND DOWN UNDER
description: Most of the four million people in this harbor city have eased into vacation routines, slipping away from their high-rise offices early on Fridays in search of the perfect beach. Their coolers brim with beer; their bodies, scorched by the sun, are beginning to assume the gloss of dark mahogany.

title: BRIEFS
description: American Software Inc., Atlanta, said Prutech Research and Development Partnership had agreed to provide about $1.2 million in financing for American Software's development of manufacturing and inventory control software.

title: Gare Is Suspended
description: The National Hockey League imposed a three-game suspension yesterday on

title: Bulls Center Hurt
description: Caldwell Jones, the Chicago Bulls' starting center, broke a bone in his right hand during the loss to the Atlanta Hawks on Wednesday night and will be out four to five weeks. The fracture, which was discovered when X-rays were taken Thursday, was a significant blow to the Bulls, who are trying to stay within hailing distance of first place and the streaking Milwaukee Bucks in the Central Division.

title: CITY SALES UP 2.1% IN DECEMBER
description: New York City retail sales in December rose just 2.1 percent compared with the same month in 1983, the smallest business gain for that month in almost a decade, a spot-check found yesterday. The Nov. 25- Dec. 29 retail accounting period included nearly the entire Christmas season.

title: HELD HIGH POSTS WITH POLICE
description: Lloyd G. Sealy, a 28-year veteran of the New York City police department who was the first black man to hold a number of top positions on the force, died of a heart attack yesterday, a police spokesman said. He turned 68 years old yesterday and lived in Brooklyn.

title: G.O.P. GROUP URGES HARD LINE IN TALKS ON ARMS CONTROL
description: A group of conservative Republican senators called on President Reagan today to counter what they said were Soviet violations of arms control agreements.

title: NOISES OFF' CAST REHEARSES MAYHEM
description: Nine silent, homicidal maniacs appear to be attacking each other on stage with any weapon close to hand: an ax, a whisky bottle, a potted cactus, a plate of sardines.

title: TRADITIONAL YET INNOVATIVE TOWER FOR ST. BART'S
description: To the Editor:

title: NORWAY AND FINLAND REPORT MOSCOW APOLOGY ON MISSILE
description: The Soviet Union, in its first statement on reports two days ago that an errant Soviet missile had passed over Scandinavia, was quoted today as saying that the object was an old, unarmed cruise missile that went off course last week when it was being used as a target in a naval exercise.

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WILLIAMS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: NEW BUDGET CHAIRMAN AN UNSWERVING FIGHTER
description: Representative William H. Gray 3d, the liberal North Philadelphia Democrat who was elected today as chairman of the House Budget Committee, is described by his colleagues as a superb politician, adept at building coalitions and unafraid to risk rejection.

title: Ex-Mayor to Go To Prison in Texas
description: Former Mayor Michael J. Matthews of Atlantic City, who was sentenced to 15 years in prison Monday for extortion, will begin serving his term in the Federal prison in Seagoville, Tex., his attorney said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SATURDAY, JANUARY 5, 1985 International

title: U.S. REACHES ACCORD WITH E.E.C. ON STEEL
description: After weeks of sparring, the United States and the European Common Market resolved a dispute over ceilings on steel pipe and tube shipments to this country, officials of both sides said today.

title: Key Rates
description: Split rate 10.75-11.25 * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SENATORS TO OFFER A REPUBLICAN PLAN TO CUT THE DEFICIT
description: Senate Republicans decided today to write their own set of proposals to reduce the Government budget deficit, an extraordinary move that could put the Senate, rather than the White House, in the lead on fiscal policy.

title:
PATENTS;

Catalysts Help Make Pipeline Gas From Coal
description: The Gas Research Institute, Chicago, received a patent this week covering means of producing pipeline gas from coal.

title: GOLD CLOSES UNDER $300 ON COMEX
description: Gold prices continued to slump yesterday, closing on the Commodity Exchange in New York below $300 for the first time in more than two years.

title: OUTSIDE DIRECTORS BACK EASTERN CUTS

description: Samuel R. Milbank, an investment banker and philanthropist, died Thursday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 78 years old.

title: Memphis Digging Out From 10-Inch Snowfall
description: Residents dug out today from a 10-inch snowfall that paralyzed the city, forcing motorists to abandon their cars and closing schools and businesses.

title: UNION DROPS EFFORT FOR EARLY TALKS WITH CHRYSLER
description: Union leaders from Chrysler Corporation plants reversed themselves today, voting not to seek early contract talks with the company. They decided instead to wait until closer to the Oct. 15 expiration of the current agreement.

title: RICHARDSON LEADS NETS OVER SUNS
description: At the end of most seasons, Micheal Ray Richardson has taken a long rest before starting his routine of getting into shape for the next one. But last spring, at the end of the Nets' most successful season since they joined the National Basketball Association eight years ago, he says that instead of waiting he ''just kept on running.''

title: Pistons 134, Hawks 111
description: Isiah Thomas scored 25 points and Kelly Tripucka 20 as Detroit raced to an easy victory. The Pistons had a 23-6 surge that helped them build a 38-14 lead at the end the first period. Thomas scored 8 points and had 4 assists in the rally.

title: Man Faces Prison In Donovan Case
description: A Federal judge today sentenced a trucking executive from the Binghamton area to six months in prison for lying about the role of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan in contributions to a Presidential campaign.

title: CORRECTION

title: TWO BOYS CHARGED IN DEATH OF A 6-YEAR-OLD
description: Two of four boys suspected of fatally beating a 6-year-old boy with hearing and speech impairments were charged in the case today, the authorities said.

title: BANTAM'S PUBLISHER NAMED PRESIDENT OF POCKET BOOKS
description: Jack Romanos, the publisher of Bantam Books since June 1981, was named president of the rival Pocket Books yesterday. Bantam, in turn, promoted Linda Grey from editorial director of adult books to publisher and editor in chief.

title: For Portland, Me., Gift List Gets Results
description: More than a year ago the city published a gift catalogue in reverse, a list of things residents could buy for their city. A result has been about $25,000, enough to pay for items ranging from park flowers to electricity for lighting the clock atop the City Hall tower.

title: HANDLING OF GUN STUDIED IN SLAYING BY POLICEMAN
description: A police investigation into the fatal shooting of an unarmed Brooklyn man by a police officer is centering on whether the officer had cocked his weapon in violation of department instructions, authorities said yesterday.

title: Byron Plant
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company said its plan to have a chain reaction begin at its Byron nuclear plant by early January had been delayed by about two weeks because start-up tests have taken longer than expected. A spokesman described the delay as ''a bit typical.'' She said the company had not changed its planned late February date for bringing the facility into service.

title: American Can Ends Sonoma Tie
description: The American Can Company sold its entire 9.8 percent stake in Williams-Sonoma Inc., American Can disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: SCOUTING ;   Player and Fan On Injured List

title: A 10th Justice In his annual Report on the Judiciary, Chief Justice Warren Burger again calls attention to the Supreme Court's workload and calls for establishment of a junior court that would free the justices to concentrate on ''questions with even greater import to the nation.'' Similarly, in an interview with the American Bar Association Journal, he describes all the administrative duties that burden the Chief Justice and calls for creating ''a tenth justice added to the Court, who would be Associate Justice for Administration.''
description: The remedies are imaginative but they invite two questions: Are they necessary? Can the problems be solved without altering the judicial structure in ways not contemplated by the Constitution?

title: MET OPERA: PRICE SINGS IN FAREWELL
description: The farewell appearances of great singers are generally exercises in patience for their admirers. Happy to say, Thursday night's performance of ''A"ida'' at the Metropolitan, billed in the program as ''Leontyne Price's farewell to opera,'' might just as well have been entitled ''Patience Rewarded.'' The 57-year-old soprano took an act or two to warm to her work, but what she delivered in the Nile Scene turned out to be well worth the wait. In her most taxing aria, ''O patria mia,'' there were powerful reminders of the Price that we remember best and want to remember, a Price beyond pearls. It was, intermittently but often enough to make the evening a memorable event, the singing of an artist of distinctive vocal timbre and personality.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, still feeling a bit shaky, was released from a Maryland hospital two days after he suffered cuts, bruises, a bump on the head and a broken front tooth in a car accident. . . . .

description: Iran said Iraqi warplanes killed 9 people and wounded 25 in attacks today on towns and villages in the southern sector of the war front.

title: WHAT INSENSITIVITY TO MINORITY CONCERNS?
description: All my life I have been concerned about the problems of racial and religious bigotry, and have sought to remove the shadows they cast on the promise of America. Twenty years ago, I went to Mississippi to aid in the struggle for civil rights and human dignity there. I cared then. I care now. That is one reason why I have found it particularly vexing to be attacked by people who call me ''racist'' and 'insensitive'' to minority concerns, people who make these unfair charges for self-serving and demagogic reasons.

title: BUDGET OFFICE ROLE IN REVIEWING NEW RULES EXPANDED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan today authorized the Office of Management and Budget to review many new Government regulations before they are made public, an action that would further centralize the Federal rule-making process. Mr. Reagan said in a statement that he was convinced the increased authority granted the budget office would produce ''substantial improvements in Federal regulatory policy'' and would ''help ensure that each major step in the process of rule development is consistent with Administration policy.''

One individual who has emerged as likely to help fill that void is Vice President Bush. The two men, who were bitter foes in the 1980 Presidential primary, drawing their support from opposite ideological ends of the Republican Party, have developed a warm personal relationship in the last four years.

title: THE THEATER: 'BLUMFELD'
description: Franz Kafka's short story ''Blumfeld, an Elderly Bachelor'' is a wistful tale about a lonely man. Blumfeld thinks about buying a dog, but decides the companionship would not compensate for the responsibility. Magically, two small celluloid balls appear in his apartment. The objects bounce playfully around the room, then stay to ''adopt'' him as their master. The story follows Blumfeld's life with his celluloid pets and later shows him, still compartmentalized, in his office. One might consider the character an equivalent of Melville's ''Bartleby''; when it comes to commitment, he prefers not to.
