description: The Atari Corporation, which is believed to be short of cash after disappointing Christmas sales, is expected to exhibit at least three new computers this weekend at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Coast Bank Cuts
description: First Interstate Bank of California plans to cut up to 875 jobs amounting to about 7 percent of its work force, a bank spokesman said. The cuts are an effort to reduce costs, which have been growing in California about twice as fast as assets, the spokesman said. The reductions, which may be completed by the end of March, will affect only the Los Angeles-based bank's California organization and no other banks in First Interstate's 11-state system.

title: New Kirkpatrick Role?
description: Associates of Edwin Meese 3d, the President's counselor, say he has told Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, that there may eventually be a job for her at the White House. Mr. Meese, the associates say, told Mrs. Kirkpatrick the job might open after he was approved as Attorney General by the Senate. He is said to have pointed out that several other White House officials may soon be leaving and that she should wait until his nomination is approved before leaving her post. Mrs. Kirkpatrick has said she wants to leave. She is expected to talk to President Reagan about her future after the Inauguration.

title: CBS PRODUCER DEFENDS USE OF LETTERS AT LIBEL TRIAL

title: OPEC FALLS TO HALT FALLING PRICE OF OIL
description: OPEC's decision to narrow the differential between prices of light and heavy grades of crude oil was supposed to help shore up falling oil prices. Instead, it sent oil futures plunging to their lowest level since trading began on the New York Merc. Narrowing the differential was necessary to make light crude oil more attractive to buyers, analysts say, but OPEC did not go far enough. But the refusal of Nigeria - one of the biggest OPEC producers - and Algeria to sign the pricing accord has made other OPEC moves appear less than decisive. Instead of the oil price increase that OPEC wants to see, analysts are predicting a continuing fall, to perhaps as low as $25 a barrel, as the oil glut persists. Indeed, late Friday more American oil companies cut the price they will pay.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;

A ROMANTIC WHOSE CAMERA INESCAPALBY CAPTURED REALITY
description: Doris Ulmann's photographs of country people in the American South taken in the early 1930's have a simple, old-fashioned charm that is miles away from the hard-edged clarity and documentary realism of the better-known Farm Security Administration photographs taken later in the same decade. Only a few years separated her work from that of such FSA photographers as Walker Evans and Ben Shahn, and the lives of the people she photographed were not very different from those of the people they photographed. Yet her photographs are softer and more romantic in atmosphere. The people in them seem more dignified and self-possessed.

title: APOLLO'S FINANCING PLAN COMPLETE
description: Since the Apollo Theater closed its doors in 1976, several unsuccessful efforts have been made to revive the 72-year-old Harlem landmark. Now the final piece of a financing package to put a cable-TV studio and performing-arts center in the legendary theater has been put into place: a commitment by the State of New York Mortgage Agency to insure 75 percent of a $2.9 million permanent mortgage from Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: MCKINNEY TAKES CUP SLALOM RACE

title: WHAT'S NEW AMONG INDEPENDENT BOOKSELLERS
description: In the last two years, B. Dalton Bookseller, Waldenbooks, and several regional discount chains have opened more than a dozen outlets in and around Albany. The spate of new book stores, many with bargain prices, spelled good news for avid readers in the area. But for owners of independent bookstores, the encroachment of the giants into their territories meant hard times. ''We've been surrounded-it's like a state of seige,'' said Barbara Shohet, co-manager of the Book House of Stuyvesant Park, a 10-year old Albany bookstore. ''We're doing very nicely, but it's an uphill fight.''

title: AN INTRODUCTION TO A VARIATION
description: The Czechoslovak writer Milan Kundera, whose latest novel is ''The Unbearable Lightness of Being,'' left his country for France in 1975. His play ''Jacques and His Master'' - which he calls a variation on Denis Diderot's ''Jacques le Fataliste,'' an 18th-century novel of the road about novels of the road and the relations between masters and servants - was first produced in Zagreb, Yugoslavia, in 1980. It has since been staged in Greece, Germany, Switzerland and France. Mr. Kundera's ''Jacques'' will have its English-language premiere Jan. 16 at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., under the direction of Susan Sontag. The text of the play and the following introduction have been translated by Michael Henry Heim and will be published next month by Harper & Row.

Today, we call them classics and consider them in no way controversial in either form or content.

title: FOR LIFE Ethiopian ExodusFew Jews have paid longer or dearer for their faith than the ''Falashas,'' the scornful Ethiopian word meaning ''unwanted stranger.'' The 10,000 Ethiopian Jews who have been secretly airlifted to Israel are surely entitled to this decent exodus; their villages were threatened by famine and civil war in a country that cared little whether they lived or died.
description: But, after their rescue has been confirmed, Ethiopia's Communist regime is furious.

title: PALESTRINA-THE TOWN
description: LOUIS INTURRISI teaches English at the University of Rome. Most people familiar with the name Palestrina associate it with the 16th-century composer of church music and creator of polyphonic harmony, Giovanni Pierluigi Palestrina, who assumed the name of his birthplace, a pastoral village built on the rugged slopes of Mount Ginestro in the central Apennines 24 miles south of Rome. Fewer people, however, are aware that Palestrina is one of the oldest towns in Italy, that it predates the founding of Rome and that it was once the site of one of the largest and most renowned temples of the ancient world.

An evening begins in the lounge, one of many elaborate and finely furnished rooms, where, over a drink, guests peruse a menu and order dinner. A small dish of hors d'oeuvres arrives. No doubt about it, the place is special.

title: A WRITER STALKS THE HOLLYWOOD MYTH
description: ''You'd never go to Hollywood, would you?'' they used to say to serious young writers. Indeed serious young writers used to say the same thing to themselves, seeking to inoculate themselves against a contagion they secretly hoped they might not be wholly spared. (''Lord, make me chaste,'' prayed St. Augustine, ''but not yet.'') Hollywood was not a geographic location; it was a Fate Worse Than The Reader's Digest. We all knew that unspeakable things happened to talent once it had crossed the Rockies. The loud example of Scott Fitzgerald (and what Joe Manckiewicz did to him) would keep us forever from The Warner Brothers' commissary, and similar places where they eat writers along with the Caesar salad. (Actually the food alone is adequate deterrent, unless you're very heavily into two-scoop tuna or best leather pastrami.) In fact, of course, Fitzgerald's decline (and frequent falls) began in Paris and on the Riviera, and even in New York, places where those dedicated to literature have never hesitated to congregate, without any obvious attempt to avoid the local maladies - sloth, envy, greed and journalism.

title: FINDING FIRST-RATE STEAKS IN BRITAIN
description: ''A dish that I do love to feed upon,'' remarks Kate to Petruchio's manservant, Grumio, in ''The Taming of the Shrew,'' when he offers her a piece of beef and mustard. The British adored steak in Elizabethan times - the nickname Beefeaters for the Yeomen of the Guard dates from that era - and they continued to adore it in Victorian times. Nathaniel Hawthorne, reaching for a simile, wrote, ''Dr. Johnson's morality was as English an article as a beefsteak.'' Not for nothing is the British equivalent of Uncle Sam called John Bull.

title: PRESERVING A CULTURE WITH YIDDISH
description: THE chatter rising from the roomful of children sounds something like German, but a sprinkling of expressions in Hebrew, Polish and Russian give it a more unfamiliar ring. The scene is a small Sunday morning preschool and primary school for Jewish children in New York City called Pripetshik that is typical in all respects save one: the children speak in Yiddish, a language that was spoken originally by the Jews of Eastern Europe.

title: MADONNA'S SIREN SONG
description: No phenomenon illustrates more pointedly how pop music history seems to run in cycles than the overnight success of the 24-year-old pop siren known as Madonna. The month before Christmas, Madonna's second album, ''Like a Virgin'' (Sire 1-15157) sold more than two million copies. Teen-agers were lining up in stores to purchase the album the way their parents had lined up to buy the Beatles records in the late 60's. And the title song, a mildly titillating dance-rock ditty about how true love can make a girl feel ''shiny and new, like a virgin,'' is one of the fastest- selling singles in the history of Warner Bros. Records.

title: Dolphins Disregard Early-Season Rout of Steelers

Somehow I knew that rewriting my address book would take me through my life and force re-evaluation of the years, much like reading through a diary might.

REMEMBERING WINTER
description: This afternoon at 2 o'clock, a winter's day 1700's- style will be re-created at Washington's Headquarters Museum on Virginia Road in North White Plains. Since 1916, it has been owned by the county, which operates it in conjunction with the White Plains chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution.

title: KATONAH DEBATES PLANS IN ITS HISTORIC DISTRICT

Then located on the Cross River, the little hamlet of 500 people was in the path of waters from the New Croton Dam. There, in 1897, the new Katonah emerged.

Nine years ago, Walter Looper contacted The Kansas City Times to comment on a small news item mentioning that there was a chance that Americans had died in the first atomic-bombing of a populated target.

title: AS STATES TAKE CHARGE OF SCHOOLS: A NEW PLAN
description: LOCAL CONTROL of public education is on the way out, as the states take charge of school standard-setting, prescribe curriculum content and teacher qualifications, impose elaborate mechanisms of pupil testing and school accountability, equalize resources and offerings throughout their borders, and furnish the major portions of the school dollar. Until now most states delegated control to local school boards, retaining only loose control in the state capital. That arrangement suited a stable agrarian society with a tolerance for local eccentricities, uneven outcomes, and school resources that varied with village property values and tax rights. Now governors and legislatures are vigorously asserting themselves. One consequence is that local school boards and superintendents are becoming obsolete: the ''organizational dinosaurs of American education in the late 80's,'' a friendly observer calls them.

A REDISCOVERED MOZART SYMPHONY TO HAVE ITS MODERN DEBUT
description: Steve Schneider frequently reports on developments in cable.

ART;

Lavelle came down to this: During her tenure as chief of the Federal toxic-waste cleanup program, when did she find out that her former employer, the Aerojet-General Corporation, was dumping hazardous wastes at the Stringfellow Acid Pits in California?

title: 339 CONDOMINIUMS
description: After eight years of often acrimonious debate over a proposal to develop 34 remaining acres of the defunct Englewood Golf and Country Club, the Englewood, N.J., City Council has tentatively approved a plan that will permit construction of 339 condominium units on the site while leaving two-thirds of the land open.

title: REFUNDS ARE URGED FOR TAINTED DOLLS
description: State officials are considering legal action to force stores to give refunds for imitation Cabbage Patch Kids dolls that have been found to contain kerosene and a potentially cancer-causing substance.

title: FOR THE JOYS OF DO-IT-YOURSELF SINGING
description: NO passive listening can compare with the joy and satisfaction of doing it yourself. So if you like to sing, why not consider the possibility of joining a chorus, especially now that a call for new members has gone out from three of the fine ensembles in the county. The Pleasantville Cantata Singers, founded 30 years ago by area residents, continues to function primarily as a community ensemble, giving local concerts and serving as chorus-in-residence at Pace University. Auditions, therefore, tend to be less stringent here than with most similar groups, and if you can carry a tune, you'll probably qualify to participate in the Cantata Singers' April 13 Handel birthday programs. To find out, go to Room 300 of Lienhard Hall on the Pace campus in Pleasantville tomorrow at 7:30 P.M., or call 337-4034 to set up a later appointment.

title: Lisa Louise Gasstrom Wed to Michael W. Mascari
description: Lisa Louise Gasstrom, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Evald Herman Gasstrom of White Plains, was married there yesterday to Michael William Mascari, the son of Mrs. Hubert MeWhinney of Terre Haute, Ind., and the late Paul Michael Mascari. The Rev. Clifford Lawrence performed the Congregationalist ceremony at the Church in the Highlands.

CONNECTICUT OPINION;

title: THE WAR BETWEEN WRITERS AND REVIEWERS
description: Thomas Fleming is the author of 14 novels, the latest of which, ''The Spoils of War,'' will be published in March. NE winter night on New York's West Side, the attractive blonde wife of a best-selling novelist was circulating around a literary party. She encountered a professional reviewer who struck up a lively conversation with her. ''So help me,'' she says, ''I did not flirt with him.'' Nevertheless, going home in the taxi, her husband excoriated her for talking to the man.

title: NORTH CAROLINA BUSTLES WITH PEOPLE AND MONEY
description: A few days before today's inauguration of James G. Martin as Governor of North Carolina, a nationally known moving company reported a small but telling fact that helps illustrate this state's happy economic bustle.

title: Correction
description: The Music View column in the Arts and Leisure section on Dec. 30 misstated the year in which the Pulitzer Prize for music went to a woman for the first time. The award, to Ellen Taaffe Zwilich, was in 1983; the 1984 winner was Bernard Rands.

title: ' 'NIGHT, MOTHER'
description: '' 'Night, Mother'' was first staged at Harvard's American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., in January 1983, and Frank Rich, reviewing it in The New York Times, called it ''one of the most disturbing American plays of recent seasons.''

title: Gustavo Matamoros Is Dead; Colombia's Defense Minister
description: Gen. Gustavo Matamoros, the Colombian Defense Minister, died early today after a long illness, his family said.

title: Rowan T. O'Riley Becomes a Bride
description: Rowan Teresa O'Riley and William Stuart Kaiser were married yesterday at the Houghton Memorial Chapel of Wellesley College. The Rev. William S. Schulthess, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Richard Malone, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: FASHION ;   ON THE BRIGHT SIDE
description: BLAME CLAUDE MONTANA for the outburst of intensely colored short coats that so many women are wearing on the streets of New York. After years of somber black, the coats of the Paris designer display a bold use of brash color that seems to stop just short of being overly theatrical.

title: HITLER DIARIES TRIAL STIRS JUDGE TO DISBELIEF AND IRE
description: Under prodding by the judge, the four-month-old trial in the Hitler diaries fraud case has shifted away from the actual defendants - a disgraced reporter, a confessed forger and his female companion - and onto a West German publishing concern and its flagship weekly, Stern magazine.

title: BERGERN DEDICATES HOME FOR THE HOMELESS
description: HACKENSACK ALTHOUGH it has had a shelter for the homeless for the last two winters, Bergen County has dedicated a new one. It provides not only shelter, but also help in returning the homeless to the mainstream of society.
Good Guys'In Poland

title: WHO'S WATCHING TV? IT'S GETTING HARD TO TELL
description: fe,al1:601After years of submitting passively to the tyranny of television programmers, viewers are taking charge. With the video-cassette recorder - now in nearly 20 percent of American homes - viewers can tape programs off the air to watch later, they can use their fast-forward button to ''zap'' or whiz past commercials when they play back programs, or they can ignore the evening's television schedule entirely and play a movie rented from a local video store. And using hand-held channel selectors - now available with one-third of all new television sets sold - viewers can hop-scotch around the dial, deftly avoiding commercials that may intrude on their enjoyment.

title: STAMP ART: MIXING PAINT AND PATRIOTISM
description: ''ARTISTS are always interested in seeing their art reproduced,'' said Stevan Dohanos, a Westport artist, illustrator and stamp designer. ''Imagine seeing your work reproduced 4 1/2 billion times.''

title: Kison to Boston
description: Bruce Kison, an injury-plagued pitcher, has reached agreement with the Boston Red Sox, and his decision marks the second time that he has spurned the Yankees as a free agent. A Yankee source said yesterday that George Steinbrenner, owner of the Yankees, had been interested in signing the 35-year-old Kison, just as Steinbrenner had been interested five years ago when Kison was a free agent the first time.

title: NOW THE COMPUTERS ARE DOING THE TESTING
description: the answer to the shortcomings of pencil- and-paper tests, long considered by students, teachers and parents poor barometers with which to measure what a student ''really knows.'' The answer: computerized testing.

title: WEST VIRGINIA FALLS
description: Nearly five minutes after the game ended, officials disallowed a slam- dunk by Lester Rowe of West Virginia at the buzzer and declared St. Joseph's a 50-49 winner in an Atlantic 10 game today at the Palestra.

description: In a ceremony this evening in the tiny town of Nenana, the 60- year-old Alaska Railroad was transferred from the Federal Government to the state.

title: BEARS AREN'T BOWLED OVER BY THE 49ERS' STRENGTHS
description: By late in the week, oddsmakers had made the San Francisco 49ers a 12-point favorite to defeat the Chicago Bears in the National Conference championship game Sunday. When Steve McMichael, the Bears' defensive left tackle, heard that, he said, ''I wish I could put about $10,000 on us.''

title:
ABOUT MEN;

A MAY-DECEMBER MARRIAGE
description: A FRIEND OF MINE once told me the most beautiful marriages of all were the May-December kind. My sister agreed. She pleaded with me to marry the young redheaded woman I had been living with for five years in California, the one who was 22 years my junior. She was afraid I would procrastinate and lose the Redhead and, with her, any last chance for happiness. My mother disagreed. May- December, Shmay-December was her attitude. Older men, she said, married young women to satisfy some not-so-stable itch, a wobbly vanity, a retarded ego - not such good reasons. Then you know what happens? The man

description: Dominique Wilkins scored 10 of his game- high 29 points in a torrid first quarter, helping the Atlanta Hawks to a 124-114 victory over the Nets tonight.

title: DEFT KARPOV AVERTS LOSS IN CHESS TITLE GAME
description: Anatoly Karpov deftly dodged danger to reach the haven of a draw in the 38th game of his world chess title defense match with Gary Kasparov in Moscow on Friday.

description: Joel Quenneville scored his second goal of the season early in the second period tonight to give the Hartford Whalers a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

title:
ANTIQUES;

WHEN POTTERS PLIED THEIR TRADE HERE
description: OTHER than some wooden plates and bowls, the most inexpensive kitchen utensils used in early Connecticut were those turned out by the redware and stoneware potters who settled here. Potters' sheds were scattered across the state from Greenwich to Hartford, from Norwalk to Norwich to Litchfield and Goshen. Although a few were established before the Revolution, there is little record of their work. The best known today are those potters who worked from the late 18th century until the 1870's, representing, in all, only a century of work.

title: CUSTOM FIT IN COMPUTER COURSES
description: ''I HAD a classic case of computer fright,'' said Jane Starr. ''Nothing in my work experience gave me an opportunity to get to know computers.'' So last summer, Miss Starr, who is a literary agent, spent some of her vacation time at Radcliffe College where she and other professionals in her field were introduced to computers at a five-day Computer Publishing Course. She was so excited by what she learned that she subsequently signed up for another computer course at New York University.

title: RACIAL CHARGES SPLIT HOLY CROSS
description: WHEN the Holy Cross basketball players took to the practice floor the Saturday afternoon following Christmas, the team was off to the worst start, 1-7, of any Crusader team since the 1940-41 season. But when the day was over, the problems facing the squad had gone beyond a matter of victories and defeats.

title: COURSE FOR PREGNANT WOMEN SEEKS TO EXPAND
description: THREE years ago Ann Cowlin came to Connecticut with the idea that women can ''dance'' through pregnancy.

title: Hilary B. Rand Plans To Wed J.P. Adams Jr.
description: Hilary Born Rand, a public-affairs analyst in charge of philanthropic programs for the Bankers Trust Company, and Joseph Porter Adams Jr., an associate in the corporate finance department of Drexel Burnham Lambert, plan to be married March 30 at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan.

title: SAVE AFRICAN CHILDREN
description: I feel ashamed now remembering that when I first saw death among the children lying on the cold earth, I did not want to be affected by it. I held my breath, lest I too inhale death. Close by, I noticed that others, much stronger than myself, touched, and even smiled at, death. ''See,'' one of them seemed to say to me, ''I can touch death, and life takes on more vigor in me to bring life to others.''

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;

 WINTER MUSIC CARNIVAL
description: While it may not exactly be arboretum weather, the Carriage House Loft of the Bayard Cutting Arboretum in Oakdale still provides an ideal setting for a ''Winter Carnival of Chamber Music and Song.'' So today at 2 P.M. the Islip Arts Council begins its annual free concert series with the soprano Margaret Willig in a program of Schubert, Kern, Ravel and Bach. The weekly concerts continue through Feb. 24. The arboretum is off Montauk Highway. GREAT OUTDOORS

title: WESTPORT PLAYHOUSE MAY BE SOLD
description: WHO will buy the Westport Country Playhouse and what will become of it? Whatever the answers are, such questions have provided the town with a guessing game for more than a month. For many people, the very idea of selling ''America's foremost summer theater,'' as it advertises itself, and the possibility of converting it to another use have triggered reactions ranging from disbelief to outrage.

title:
LEISURE;

LUSH GREEN PLANTS THAT CAN GROW INDOORS
description: Hatsy Taylor is a lecturer and columnist.

title: OVERBLAMING THE U.S. FOR CAMBODIA
description: The invading army of Vietnam is stepping up its attacks on the Cambodian guerrilla resistance and the civilian population that helps sustain it. As the torment of Cambodia enters its 16th year, it is time Americans re- evaluated the relative responsibilities of Communist Vietnam and the United States for that continuing tragedy.

title: YOUNG ACTIVIST FACES DRAFT TRIAL
description: EVERY high school seemingly has its own Andy Mager. He is the angry young man whose outrage at what he sees as social injustice has been honed to a finely tuned personal dogma that is apparently impervious to earthly considerations - at least at the outset.

title: POLL FINDS LATIN MASS FAVORED
description: Almost gone but hardly forgotten, the traditional Roman Catholic mass conducted in Latin would be welcomed by many Catholics in the United States, a new survey suggests.

title: Miss Brainard to Wed William Van N. Philip
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Brainard Jr. of Hartford have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Cameron Brainard to William Van Ness Philip, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Van Ness Philip of New York and Bedford, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

description: Trees have been known to grow in big cities like Chicago. But forests?

title: A REVOLUTION OF FALLING EXPECTATIONS IN MIDEAST
description: In a year of intricate shifts in the Middle East, one constant has been that frustrations, disappointments and demands are still routinely addressed to the United States. Despite the loss of American influence after the Lebanon debacle, and the new Jordanian and Egyptian contacts with Moscow, the tendency remains to approach almost any regional argument in terms of what Washington must or must not do about it.

title: CHINA PROMISES CREATIVE FREEDOM TO WRITERS
description: China's writers were given a new constitution today that spoke of their right to ''democracy and freedom'' in developing a literature that served a readership beyond workers, peasants and soldiers.

title: HOME CARE SET FOR CHANGE
description: PATIENTS are leaving hospitals earlier, and staying out of nursing homes longer, to avoid soaring health care costs, a trend which has meant greater demands for new types of home health-care.

title: COLOMBIA TURNS OVER TO U.S. 4 FACING DRUG TRIAL
description: The Government of Colombia today turned over to the United States four men who face Federal charges for drug trafficking and money laundering, the Justice Department said.

title: Barnard Savors Its Independence
description: As a second-semester senior at Barnard College, I was most interested to read Georgia Dullea's article, ''Barnard Savors Its Independence'' (Dec. 2).

title: THE DANCE: MULVIHILL IN CONCERT
description: How They Make Hawaiian Music,'' which Colleen Mulvihill presented Friday night at Performance Space 122, was a kinetic cacophony. And its discords were presumably intentional. Most of the work consisted of solos performed without any pauses between them, and Miss Mulvihill kept herself so busy that simply to list the things she did might require every column on this page.

title: MASSACHUSETTS EXPANDING AID FOR HOMELESS
description: Massachusetts plans to spend $10.8 million on an expansion of its two-year-old program to aid the homeless by providing benefits for medical and mental health care.

title: LEGISLATURE TO CONVENE AMID CHANGE
description: HARTFORD WHEN the 1985 session of the General Assembly convenes here Wednesday morning, it will signal a major shift of political power in Connecticut.

title: CAN MEDICINE RELY ON THE RULES OF THE MARKETPLACE?
description: This winter's shortage of whooping cough vaccine has revived and broadened the debate over a question that has troubled health-care officials for a long time: Can the free market be depended on to provide the drugs used for mass immunization against serious diseases?

title: FINDING THE RIGHT STOCKBROKER...
description: Like many investors, Harvey J. Horowitz, a partner in the New York law firm of Squadron, Ellenoff, Plesent & Lehrer, had a difficult time finding a stockbroker with whom he was satisfied.

title: NEW SOUTHERN GOVERNOR: MASTER OF THE UNEXPECTED
description: Every politician has to confront the unexpected, and for James G. Martin, who today took office as the second Republican elected Governor of North Carolina in this century, the unexpected was a musical instrument.

title: TV VIEW ;   AS VIEWERS BECOME MORE DISCERNING
description: Anyone who follows television closely is more than willing to concede that the business has been changing drastically. The Big Three networks are still with us, but their combined share of the national prime-time audience has been sharply eroded, down from over 90 percent in their virtually monopolistic heydays to around 70 percent in some recent weeks. Cable TV has not brought the abundance of programming riches promised by its assorted entrepreneurs, but it has afforded viewers expanded choices. Public television and independent commercial stations have been actively carving out their special shares of the overall market. And video cassettes have been liberating audiences from the viewing constraints of fixed schedules.

title: HOW A NEW SCHOOL FOR THE GIFTED BEGAN
description: OLD BRIDGE

title: PRINCETON: 'POP' ARCHITECTS
description: THE Abstract Expressionism that marked America's entry into the international art scene was over almost as soon as it began.

title: World Methodist Peace Prize Will Be Presented to Carter
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 5 (UPI) Former President Jimmy Carter has been named the first American recipient of the World Methodist Peace Award.

title: MUSIC: BROOKLYN PHILHARMONIC IN CONCERT
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Lukas Foss, may have occasionally presented an overly ambitious or an unsuccessful concert but it has never, to my knowledge, presented a dull one. Indeed, the orchestra has been responsible for some of the most imaginative programming in New York, and Friday night's performance, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, was no exception.

title: East Germans Excel With 5 Swim Victories
description: East Germany dominated the United States Swimming International tonight with five victories and set a world best, a United States Open and a meet record in the men's 800- meter freestyle relay.

title: Megan Heffron To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Megan Mary Heffron to Theodore Karl Trautwein has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Heffron of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and Westhampton, L.I., parents of the bride to be. Her fiance is the son of Judge and Mrs. Theodore W. Trautwein of Franklin Lakes, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: $20 Million Is Awarded To Boy Mauled by Tiger
description: A 5-year-old boy, mauled by a tiger that escaped from its cage at Lion Country Safari in 1982, will receive up to $20 million in an out-of-court settlement, his attorney said Friday.

title: HONDURAS ARRESTS A LEADER OF INDIAN REBELS FROM NICARAGUA
description: The Honduran police have arrested an anti-Sandinista Indian rebel leader after a Government warning that Nicaraguan guerrillas had overstayed their welcome in Honduras, the authorities said today.

title: RESPECTED CRITIC OF MILITARY: LESLIE ASPIN JR.
description: On the face of it, Les Aspin is a radical departure from the procession of Congressmen who have overseen the military from the chair of the House Armed Services Committee. He won his Congressional seat as an antiwar liberal and made his name in Washington by cranking out weekly press releases criticizing the Pentagon brass as living in high style. He commutes to work in a decidedly unofficial-looking Gremlin, accompanied by his sheepdog Junket, a refugee from a Wisconsin dog pound.

title: CITY IN PLEA TO REROUTE BROOKHAVEN NUCLEAR WASTE
description: WITH an eye on the expiration of a year-end moratorium, Mayor Koch, Senator Daniel P. Moynihan and about a dozen Representatives from Queens and the Bronx have made last-ditch pleas to halt the shipment of nuclear waste products from the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton to a Federal reprocessing facility in Idaho via New York City.

title: Miss Tannenbaum to Wed
description: Ellen Tannenbaum, a student at the Brooklyn Law School, and Dr. Robert Blank, a fellow in gastroenterology at Yeshiva University's Albert Einstein College of Medicine, plan a summer wedding. The future bride is the daughter of Elmer Tannenbaum of Brooklyn and the late Edna Tannenbaum. Dr. Blank, a son of Mr. and Mr. Jack Blank of Wesley Chapel, Fla., graduated from the St. George's University School of Medicine in Grenada.

title: Falwell Says Bombers Are 'Deranged' People
description: Jerry Falwell, the leader of Moral Majority, says the bombings of abortion clinics are being carried out by ''deranged'' people who are diverting attention from the ''real atrocity.''

title: Emily Rubin to Marry Chris Jennewein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan A. Rubin of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter Emily Farber Rubin to James Christopher Jennewein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Jennewein of Tampa, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

description: New York should increase and speed compensation payments to crime victims, a state panel has recommended.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

FAREWELL TO OUR PRIVATE WILDERNESS
description: WHEN I first saw Woodside Lane, it was a quiet street ending in a cul-de-sac. Thirty houses already lined it like duplicated soldiers standing at attention. The houses stood empty, awaiting the touch that would give them their own individual personalities. Each had emitted the damp smell of wet cement that is the trademark of a new house.

title: SchoolsinJerseyUrged ToStudytheHolocaust
description: The New Jersey Board of Education has adopted a resolution urging the state's public schools to teach courses on the Holocaust.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;

A LOUVRE TO LURE COLLECTORS
description: PHYLLIS LEE LEVIN is a writer who lives in New York.

title: Union Head Faults Company In Deaths of 27 at Utah Mine
description: The president of the United Mine Workers today blamed the Emery Mining Company for the deaths of 27 coal miners trapped by a mine fire last month, but a company spokesman denied the charge.

title: JOB EXCHANGE FOR TEACHERS IN COLLEGE
description: SHIRLEY KASSMAN has always lived in upstate New York. She was born and raised there; she graduated from college there and has taught studio art there for 33 years, 26 of them at State University College at Buffalo. But this year, as a participant in the National Faculty Exchange, she is at California State College at Bakersfield.

title: Forest Preserve And Power Lines
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SHIFTING TO DEFENSE
description: Assuming his public position reflects his private determination, President Reagan's instructions to George Shultz for the forthcoming Geneva talks appear to mean that he wants to shift from a strategy of deterrence by offensive nuclear forces to greater - if not total - reliance on a space-based defensive screen.

title: CAMBODIANS SAY VIETNAM APPEARS TO DIG IN
description: Officials of the Cambodian rebel group under attack by Vietnam say that Vietnamese troops appear to be digging in for a long stay along the border of Thailand and Cambodia.

title: THERE'S A BULL MARKET FOR STOLEN SECRETS
description: Richard W. Miller was not the kind of F.B.I. agent the late J. Edgar Hoover would have been proud of. According to court documents, Mr. Miller was overweight, sold Amway household products from the trunk of his official car and filched candy bars from 7-Eleven stores. The Government contends that he also had an affair with a Russian emigre who talked him into spying for the Soviet Union.

title: 237,232,805 People in U.S.
description: The United States began the new year with 237,232,805 people, just over 2 million more than a year earlier, the Census Bureau estimates. The population estimate is based on 3.7 million births, 2 million deaths and 499,000 immigrations over the year, the bureau's population division reported. The increase for the year amounted to nine-tenths of 1 percent, the same rate as the previous year.

title: Cheryl Kratz Marries
description: Cheryl Ann Kratz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Kratz of Sayville, L.I., was married in New York yesterday to Marc D. Koenigsberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin M. Koenigsberg of Haworth, N.J. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony at the Park Lane Hotel. Mrs. Koenigsberg is a second vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank. Her husband is an assistant vice president of Citibank.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Metro vs. Island, Puerto Rico Winter League All-Star Game, at Bayamon, P.R. Jose Oquendo of the Mets is among the players in this game dedicated to Willie Hernandez of the Detroit Tigers, winner of the Cy Young award and voted the most valuable player in the American League, who is a native of Puerto Rico.

title: A COMMON ENEMY UNITES HOSTILE FACTIONS IN CAMBODIA
description: ''It happened so fast they didn't have time to grab their shoes,'' said a nurse treating the lacerated feet of Cambodians who fled to sanctuary in Thailand as Vietnamese artillery bombarded their camp late last month.

title: Lisa D. Zallinger To Marry in July
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Zallinger of North Haven, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Lisa Day Zallinger to Bernard J. David, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Israel A. David of Wilmington, Del. A July wedding is planned.

title: BHOPAL
description: To the Editor:

title: A SLOW-PACED WEEKEND RETREAT
description: GORDON MOTT is a writer who lives in Mexico City.

title: IMPROVING OUR TEACHERS
description: Unlike General Motors or Chrysler, Eastern Washington University has no provision for recalling its product, but the university is trying to do the next best thing with the schoolteachers it graduates. From now on, its education majors will in effect carry a warranty, and any superintendent dissatisfied with the new teacher's performance may call on the institution to remedy the problem.

title: SHE WAS A MOVABLE SALON
description: Julian Moynahan teaches in the English department at Rutgers and is completing a book on the origins and development of Anglo-Irish literature. MABEL DODGE LUHAN

title: Gustav Ross, 94, Developer Of Cooperative Apartments
description: Gustav Ross, a former governor of the Real Estate Board of New York and a developer of cooperative apartment buildings after World War II, died of pneumonia Thursday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 94 years old.

title: Tia Tsavaris Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Carol T. Savage of Harrington Park, N.J., and New York, and Dr. Louis J. Tsavaris of Sarasota, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Tia Tsavaris, to Charles F. Green, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Green of Ardsley, N.Y. A May wedding is planned. The future bride's mother is director of communication services for the American Express Company in New York. Her father is a psychiatrist. Mr. Green's father is a vice president of the Marschalk Company, the New York advertising agency.

title: WATER LINE RUPTURES IN JERSEY CITY
description: Workers surveying the damage caused by a water main that broke at the corner of Huron and St. Paul's Avenues, cutting off water or lowering pressure to about two- thirds of the city for six hours. Officials said it was the sixth time a main in the city's aging water system had broken in the last three years. Water lines are being gradually repaired, they said, but this one had not been.

title: AMERICAN VICTIMS OF HIROSHIMA
description: As a student of Japanese- American history, I find it disconcerting that a piece entitled ''American Victims of Hiroshima'' chooses only to focus on 10 soldiers and handily dismisses the 3,000 other Americans in Hiroshima, simply because they were of Japanese descent. More disturbing, however, was the article's conclusion, with a

title: BRIGHAM YOUNG'S CREDENTIALS ARE PERFECT FOR NO. 1
description: ONE year ago, a University of Nebraska football team regarded by some as invincible went to Miami to play against the University of Miami Hurricanes in the Orange Bowl. At the end of a memorable game, a Miami defensive back named Ken Calhoun batted away a Nebraska pass for an attempted 2-point conversion. Miami won, 31-30. The following morning, the voters in the polls conducted by United Press International and The Associated Press chose Miami as the No. 1 college football team in the United States.

title: RECORDING A HISTORY OF MUSIC
description: VIVIAN PERLIS admits that she is surprised when someone introduces her as an oral historian. ''I think that's a rather strange-sounding thing,'' Mrs. Perlis says. ''I have gotten used to being called a writer by now, but I'm somewhat shy of feeling that I'm involved in the field of oral history.''

title: A MODEL JOB TRAINING PLAN IN BROOKLYN
description: -school students from Brooklyn's poorest neighborhoods spent last summer unemployed or among the ranks of fast-food workers, Andrea Barnes spent July and August as an assistant computer programmer. Back in the classroom now for her senior year, Miss Barnes, 18 years old, spoke with authority about logistics and inventory checking and routing as she recalled the details of her job, with Prime Computer Inc.

title: New Caledonian Leader Denounces French Plan
description: A New Caledonian political leader who opposes independence for the South Pacific territory today termed a reported independence plan involving a contract of association with France ''a monstrous idiocy.''

title: STATE STUDY SEEKS TO SAVE FROG
description: RESIDENTIAL and other potentially disruptive development near the breeding sites of the Pine Barrens tree frog may be strictly limited or prohibited as a result of a study released last week by Rutgers University and the state's Department of Environmental Protection.

title: Miss Cory to Wed Peter W. Smith
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Robert Hanright of Singer Island, Fla., and Paul Cory of Saddle River, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Susan Elizabeth Cory to Peter Whitall Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Smith of Meadowbrook, Pa. The wedding is to be March 2.

title: SUNNY-SIDE DRESSING
description: UNTIL A FEW YEARS AGO, THERE WERE essentially only two seasons for men's clothing: fall and spring. But no longer. A new category - resort wear - has emerged that, in some quarters, has become just as important. Thus, despite the snow drifts outside, store windows across the country display lightweight suits, shorts, swim trunks, T-shirts and polo shirts.

title: KENNEDY IS JEERED IN JOHANNESBURG
description: White police officers scuffled with protesters tonight as Senator Edward M. Kennedy arrived in South Africa and was met by black demonstrators chanting, ''Kennedy go home!''

title: Mummers Parade Delayed
description: The Mummers Parade, rained out New Year's Day, was postponed today for the second time because of weather. It was rescheduled for Sunday. In the event of bad weather Sunday, the parade will be postponed again until Jan. 12.

title: TO BOUGUEREAU, ART WAS STRICKLY 'THE BEAUTIFUL'
description: Adolphe William Bouguereau. It's hard to exaggerate the popularity in 19th-century France - and in America, too - of this quintessentially salon painter (1825-1905), whose high-minded historical, mythological, religious and genre scenes were showered with official honors and sold for top prices during his lifetime. True, his name was always a joke to the avant-garde. Degas and his friends used the term ''bouguerated'' to derogate a finicky, overly finished painting surface, and van Gogh put him down as a well- paid maker of ''soft, pretty things.'' And by the end of World War I, their vanguard scorn was vindicated by public taste. Bouguereau's paintings, along with those of such academic contemporaries as Ger^ome, Cabanel and Alma-Tadema, faded away to the basements of museums.

title: EASLEY BLACKWOOD: MAN OF THE YEAR
description: Within recent years the Roman Catholic Church has gently moved to rehabilitate Galileo and this newspaper has apologised to Robert Goddard for sneering at his rocket experiments 60 years ago. If Ely Culbertson's organization still existed, it might well follow these examples and retract a letter written half a century ago.

title: SHIFT IN JURISDICTION ON VIOLENT YOUTHS ASKED
description: New York State should remove jurisdiction over violent juvenile offenders from the criminal-court system and return it to a Family Court with strengthened sentencing powers, a civic group has recommended.

title: FLUTIE OUTSHONE AS HULA HERO
description: Frank Reich of Maryland, playing in the shadow of Doug Flutie, the Heisman Trophy winner, threw two touchdown passes to cap a pair of long first- half drives and Flutie passed for one score and ran for another today to lead the East to a 34-14 victory over the West in the 39th Hula Bowl.

title: LONG WHARF DIRECTOR SETS A FAST PACE
description: FOR most directors, an opening in New York City is a big deal. But since Arvin Brown, the artistic director of the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, seems to be a directorial dervish of late, today's scheduled premiere of ''Joe Egg'' at Manhattan's Roundabout Theater is just another opening of another show.

title: Starting Over in Geneva Two things are essential for any deal on limiting nuclear weapons: a forum for bargaining and plausible proposals. America and Russia are miles from the latter, but inches from the former. So when they finally meet tomorrow in Geneva, it will be a success if they agree only to meet tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow. If they can achieve even that much, Secretary Shultz and Foreign Minister Gromyko will have earned their fare, and the thanks of a worried world.
description: There have been no bilateral arms talks since December 1983, when the Soviet Union broke off dual negotiations on intercontinental and intermediate missiles. The purpose was to portray President Reagan as a warmonger, playing to the fears of Western Europe's peace movement. But then leaders changed in Moscow, Mr. Reagan took up the peace issue during the campaign and the Russians began to clear the path to Geneva.

description: To the Editor:

title: ZACCARO WEIGHING PLEA OF GUILTY IN REALTY CASE, HIS LAWYER SAYS
description: John A. Zaccaro is considering pleading guilty to a reduced charge involving a falsified sales contract for five apartment buildings in Queens, one of his lawyers said yesterday.

title: CORRUPTION REPORT IMPERILS BAHAMAS LEADER
description: A long investigation into drug smuggling and corruption in the Bahamas has left Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling facing the gravest political crisis of his 17 years in power, with momentum building for his ouster.

title: GOETZ: A PRIVATE MAN IN A PUBLIC DEBATE
description: To his admirers, Bernhard Hugo Goetz is a personable, scholarly, self- reliant man who cares about his neighbors and his community, despises hoodlums and has long been frustrated by what he sees as a drift toward criminal anarchy.

title: CRITICS'CHOICES
description: It used to be that people just got up and tap-danced to the music at hand. But the field has broadened considerably in the days since the the ''tap-happening'' revivals in the early 1970's.

title: Jane Watson Irwin Wed To Larry Droppa
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday, Jane Watson Irwin, the daughter of John N. Irwin 2d of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Jane Watson Irwin, was married to Larry D. Droppa, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Droppa of Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: Thomas Artale, Tax Official For New York City in 1960's
description: Thomas Artale, a New York City Tax Commissioner in the 1960's, died Tuesday in Calvary Hospital in the Bronx after a long illness. Mr. Artale was 72 years old and had lived in Hollywood, Fla., until he became ill.

THINKING ABOUT THE UNTHINKABLE
description: WHILE governments wrestle with the realities of the nuclear age, how do individuals come to grips with the same issues on a more- personal level?

title: Dutchman Claims Credit for Keel
description: I T has been more than a year since the Australians won the America's Cup. Yet questions of foul play still haunt members of the New York Yacht Club, who at the last minute were ready to cancel the 1983 races in Newport, R.I., over what they believed to be improprieties.

title: ATTRACTING THE BEST WITH INCENTIVE PLANS
description: IN California, outstanding teachers are awarded$4,000 bonuses to be ''mentors'' to their colleagues.

title: SOME PROGNOSTICATIONS ON TOMORROW'S PHONOGRAPH
description: Stepping into a new year always stirs the urge to prognosticate. Just why the future should be more transparent around the first of January has never been properly explained, but maybe things to come are more visible in the dark of those long, ruminative winter evenings.

title: ETHIOPIA'S OTHER SCOURGE: REBEL WAR
description: A nurse in the northern Ethiopian city of Makale complained recently that the nearby hospital was often so filled with wounded soldiers that there was hardly room for the sick.

title: INFLATION GETS BACK TO NORMAL
description: Gordon Williams is business correspondent for ABC News, and author of several books on investments and finance.

title:
WINE;

TAKING YOUR OWN BOTTLE TO RESTAURANTS
description: RESTAURANTGOERS intimidated by lengthy wine lists, patronizing sommeliers and often overpriced low-end products should consider bringing their own, ordering beaujolais or frequenting establishments featuring top-quality house wine.

title: A POCKET FULL OF SALAD
description: FOR THE LAST SEVERAL DECADES, COUNTLESS borrowings from other cultures have been available to American cooks who take the kitchen seriously - such dishes as gazpacho and bouillabaisse, sushi and sashimi, croissants and vitello tonnato, gravlaks and guacamole. Our enthusiasms have not always worn well, as witness the generally low esteem now accorded beef Wellington, Swiss fondue and Ni,coise salad. One of the borrowings for which we maintain a keen appetite is pita bread, a Middle-Eastern contribution. It can be broken into bits and dipped into countless good things, including eggplant caviar and a well-seasoned chickpea or sesame spread. But our favorite use for pita, or pocket, bread is as a container for various fillings. Almost any kind of salad goes admirably well with it.

title: FLORIDA DEBATES MANAGING GROWTH
description: Planners in Florida are fond of speculating what the state would do if tomorrow Georgia's 5.4 million residents should decide to move south.

title: PERCEPTIONS OF A STUDENT TEACHER
description: WHEN Frank R. Decelie Jr. was growing up on Staten Island, he regarded teaching in elementary school as a job that was just for women. The tall, dark-haired youth never considered such a career because boys like Mr. Decelie, who were talented in mathematics, were expected to enter business. So he went to work as a Telex operator for a Manhattan bank after having graduated from high school.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

THANK GOODNESS IT'S JANUARY AGAIN!
description: AS sure as a Dec. 26 diet resolution, it happens. About the first week in January there is a plethora of articles in magazines and newspapers, reassuring readers that the post-holiday depression they must be suffering is normal and is to be expected. Women's magazines will feature articles with titles such as ''Post Holiday Blahs? Here's How to Beat Them.''

title: CABARET: HUGHES SINGS
description: Rhetta Hughes is a singer who is also an actress - or possibly it is vice versa. She has played leading roles that involve both acting and singing in New York productions of such musicals as ''Raisin'' and ''Take Me Along'' and in a television production of ''Purlie.''

title: STRONG GROWTH SEEN FOR CONNECTICUT ECONOMY
description: Connecticut's economic growth will continue to outpace that of the country and the region in 1985, the state's Economic Development Commissioner says.

title: Jaye Scholl Weds Charles E. Bohlen Jr.
description: At St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Manhattan yesterday, Jaye R. Scholl, the West Coast editor of Barron's, the business and financial weekly, was married to Charles E. Bohlen Jr., vice president and general counsel of Kleinwort, Benson Cross Financing in Los Angeles. The Rev. Gary P. Fertig performed the ceremony.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

VOTING SHOULDN'T BE COMPLICATED
description: HAVING recently completed another quadrennial exercise in electoral democracy, we are once again hearing the inevitable laments about the dismal level of participation.

title: Home Banking Computers
description: In 1984, major banks only threatened to take a bigger share of the securities brokerage business through home computer networks. In 1985, they actually hope to pull off the feat. The Chase Manhattan Bank, for example, last month expanded its ''Spectrum'' home banking system to include 24-hour stock and option brokerage and quote service for a $5 monthly fee, plus discount transaction commissions. ''For a $10 fee, the customer can also instantly track portfolio positions and get extracts from 130 market letters,'' said Kenneth A. Mills, a spokesman.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Akeem Olajuwon, the 7-foot rookie center for the Houston Rockets, has been named the National Basketball Association's player of the month for December, after averaging .558 (22.2 points a game); 11.4 rebounds and 2.5 blocked shots. . . .

title: ATLANTIC CITY TO UPDATE MASTER PLAN
description: ATLANTIC CITY THIS resort's third administration since casino gambling was legalized six years ago has begun searching for a planning consultant to lead a state-mandated ''re-examination'' of the city's master plan and accompanying land-use ordinance.

title: COLLEGE STUDENTS IN VOLUNTEER EFFORT
description: ''THERE are a lot more students involved in volunteering than get credit for it,'' said Joanne Boyce, president of the student government at Iona College in New Rochelle. Her judgment was echoed by students and staff members at other colleges in the county, where students have become involved in community service through campus organizations, internships and more loosely organized activities.

title: A TRIMMER YEAR, AN EYE ON THE BUDGET
description: TODAY, the Twelfth Day of Christmas, marks the end of the holiday season. For the next several weeks it would probably be a good idea to tighten both the belt and the budget. Of the two, the budget is the easier to tackle. After a period of parties and feasting, the belts might actually have to be let out.

title: AGAINST THE ODDS
description: IN A MANNER OF SPEAKING, KAREN Valenstein discovered her passion for business in Filene's Basement, with all its fractious jostling and pawing. Now a 38-year-old first vice president at E. F. Hutton & Company and one of the pre-eminent women in investment banking, Mrs. Valenstein was then a rebellious college student whose family offered to reimburse her if she shed her jeans for a more ladylike wardrobe. She would shop for Villager or John Meyer outfits at the Boston bargain bazaar, accept repayment at the retail price and then resell most of the clothes to classmates at a 10 percent discount. ''Arbitraging Filene's,'' she calls it, butchering the financial jargon and delighting in her novel coinage.

title: SHE'S BEATING THE ODDS IN SCIENCE
description: AT the age of 39, Karen Bulloch has been beating the odds in scientific circles for more than a decade. She began publishing in scientific journals without ever having earned an undergraduate degree. Then she entered a doctoral program in the midst of a divorce and raising two children. And now, just six years after beginning her graduate work ''as a provisional student,'' she has been chosen as one of ''America's Brightest 100 Scientists under 40'' in the December issue of Science Digest magazine.

title: ANGOLA'S BRAZILIAN CONNECTION: SURGING TRADE
description: Two thousand Brazilian workers are to build Angola's largest hydroelectric dam under the terms of a $500 million contract that has been signed here.

title: CORRECTION
description: As a result of an editing error, an article last week on heart surgery gave the incorrect annual number of cardiac-surgery patients that would be required of hospitals after three years under a proposed state regulation. The number is 200.

description: Randall Cunningham, a quarterback from Nevada-Las Vegas, caught a touchdown pass on a flea-flicker play and threw for another to lead the West team to a 21-10 victory in the 60th East-West Shrine All-Star Game.

title: MEDITERRANEAN FOOD IN A STYLISH SETTING
description: BISTRO METRO in Forest Hills, Queens, is contemporary and stylish. Lighting softens and enhances the minimalist decor of the simple storefront restaurant. Pools of light focus on the tables, candles flicker, frosted glass fixtures shed a dim glow and, for the holidays, winking pinpoints of light have been adorning the glass doorways and large central potted ficus tree.

description: ''PEOPLE are looking for more quality entertainment,'' said Richard Smith, a lawyer and businessman who opened the Milford Pub and Cinema in 1982. ''We offer a better way of spending an evening than just going out to a movie or dinner.''

description: After 30 bombings of abortion clinics, including six in the Washington area, President Reagan has finally spoken out in denunciation, but he chose his words carefully. He condemned the bombers' ''violent, anarchist activities,'' thereby distinguishing himself from the National Organization for Women, which has called the bombings a ''campaign of terrorism and intimidation'' against women seeking to exercise a constitutional right.

title: KRAKOWIAKS, MAZURKAS AND THE WORLD OF MAZOWSZE
description: The great Romantic ballerina Fanny Elssler scored a hit in the mid-19th century with a solo called the ''Cracovienne,'' a fanciful version of a Polish folk dance, the krakowiak. And even today, the mazurkas and polonaises seen in, say, ''Swan Lake'' or ''Sleeping Beauty,'' tend to be inauthentic divertissements. But the real thing will fill the stage of Carnegie Hall, for six performances starting Wednesday, in the whirl of color, humor and sheer high spirits that audiences have come to associate with Mazowsze, the Polish folk troupe.

title: MUSIC: THE EMERSON STRING QUARTET
description: Here is an interesting bit of news: A young string quartet, proficient and polished, best known for its excellence in contemporary music, gave a program of Beethoven, Bach, Berg and Tchaikovsky at Tully Hall Friday - and made the strongest impression with Tchaikovsky.

title: The Mastery Of Robert Motherwell
description: Back in 1971 at the University of Oklahoma, I wrote a master's thesis on Robert Motherwell (''The Mastery of Robert Motherwell,'' by Grace Glueck, Dec. 2). In it, I attempted to demonstrate that, in those early years of formation (when there was lots of talking and writing), the New York School painters put together a kind of standard about what was and was not to be painted and how it was to be done.

title: THE LIBERAL ARTS AND WORLD OF WORK: DIFFERENT APPROACHES
description: WHEN Diana Ho was in college, she little thought her study of studio art would lead to a career in management consulting. But Miss Ho, now a private consultant in Los Angeles, credits her liberal-arts education for what she views as her advantage over the competition. ''I think I have a different kind of awareness,'' she said. ''Liberal-arts graduates are able to communicate with a wider spectrum of peers, subordinates and managers, and that's always going to be a help.''

title: CHANGES IN MARRIAGE WHEN A BABY IS BORN
description: How does having a baby affect the quality of a marriage? Does it substantially worsen a couple's relationship? What kinds of marriages are likely to be most disrupted by the arrival of a baby?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There has arisen the need to adopt urgent and effective measures to prevent a further destabilization of the strategic situation and preclude further rounds of the arms race.'' - Konstantin U. Chernenko. (1:6.)

title: Miss Troeger Engaged To Jeffrey Thompson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Curtis R. Troeger of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Elaine Troeger to Jeffrey Fulcher Thompson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Webb Thompson of New Vernon, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

CONNECTICUT OPINION;

LIFE WITH THE 'CABBAGES'
description: NOBODY ever said parenting was easy. In truth, nobody said much about it at all. There is no good preparation for the job. It is something that, until you are doing it, you are not doing it.

title: Miss Sweetser to Wed W. G. Gollner in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alan Sweetser of Minneapolis of the engagment of their daughter Lydia St. Laurent Sweetser to William Guy Gollner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Guy Gollner of Bronxville, N.Y., and Bondville, Vt. A June wedding is planned.

title: SCHOOL DEVOTED TO PERFORMING ARTS
description: AT a recent concert, Margaret Chaves had the opportunity to sing the solo part of ''Go Tell It on the Mountain'' before an audience of about 9,000 at the Hartford Civic Center. The 15-year- old soprano from Simsbury is hoping a new school will help make the experience a harbinger of her career.

title: THE MAN WHO HAS BROADWAY IN LOVE WITH THE CLASSICS
description: When Terry Hands, the joint artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, arrived here three months ago to make his directorial debut on Broadway, he had considerable reason for apprehension. The R.S.C.'s last Shakespearean import, ''All's Well That Ends Well,'' had not succeeded in New York, closing after only seven weeks, and this time around the company was sending not one but two elaborate, expensive productions to an arena notoriously inhospitable to the classics.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: LONG ISLAND CITY
description: ON weekdays, Long Island City looks mostly like a factory town. Trucks rumble in early, crowding the streets. Some 10,000 people empty out of the subways on their way to manufacturing jobs bottling soda, baking bread and churning cement. At day's end, they head the other way, and the Queens neighborhood comes to a standstill.

title: WORKING WOMEN BUOY L.I. ECONOMY
description: FAMILY responsibilities prompted Pat Peters to return to work. With a son getting ready to enter college, Mrs. Peters, who recently took a job as an office manager in her hometown of Yaphank, said it became apparent that ''one salary in the family wasn't going to make it.''

title:
ABOUT CARS;

Belt Laws a Cinch To Save Lives
description: What it says is that drivers and their front-seat passengers have to buckle up. Otherwise, there is a $50 fine. And, while the Federal silliness of a 55-mile-an-hour speed limit is honored primarily in the breach, the nice thing about this new law is that people seem to be abiding by it.

title: ART ENDOWMENT GIVES $2 MILLION TO 100 WRITERS
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has awarded a total of $2 million to 100 writers in 30 states. Each of the awards, called Fellowships for Creative Writers, is for $20,000. The purpose, according to the Endowment, is to enable ''published writers of exceptional talent'' to set aside time for writing, research or travel.

title: Rare Eurasian Goose Is Visiting Nebraska
description: A rare Eurasian bean goose is resting at a wildlife refuge near here, far from its natural migration routes.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

TO COPE WITH AGING, ACCEPT IT
description: THERE'S nothing we can do to slow down aging. We can only adjust our attitudes to make our reactions fit what's happening. We can accept our years as something to be proud of - like a sergeant flaunting his hash marks - or we can refuse to accept them, thereby sentencing ourselves to the futility of chasing elusive youth.

title: WHERE MEXICO PLAYS
description: RICHARD J. MEISLIN is the Mexico City bureau chief of The New York Times. After years of decline, Acapulco is beginning to sparkle again. The waters of the sweeping bay of Mexico's oldest and most famous resort have been returned to a royal blue; taxi drivers seem to have learned not to be surly or overcharge their passengers; names like Ralph Lauren, Fiorucci and Ocean Pacific have been added to what had become a generally humdrum selection of shops on the Costera Miguel Aleman.

The Austrian-born Miss Morath was living in Paris, working as a translator and freelance magazine writer, and frequently asking Magnum to procure the photographs to accompany her stories.

title: HELPING FAMILIES AFTER DIVORCE
description: CALLED suddenly out of the room in the middle of a discussion on parenting, the mother walked quickly into a nearby room to calm her rambunctious 8-year-old son in the play therapy group.

title: UNSOUND REASONS TO QUIT UNESCO
description: It is curiously fitting that the United States has chosen to withdraw from Unesco in 1984. Nothing in recent years has more closely resembled the Newspeak of which George Orwell wrote in ''Nineteen Eighty-Four'' than the reasons given for quitting Unesco.

title: KNICKS SURVIVE BULLS' THREAT
description: A crowd of 17,865 turned out at Madison Square Garden last night, the biggest Saturday night crowd of the season. The attraction was not the Knicks, who had lost their previous six games, but Michael Jordan, the exciting Chicago rookie.

title: CONSTERNATION BREAKS OUT AMONG THE CONSTELLATIONS
description: Everybody knows what a planet is. Our Earth, a rocky body with oceans of water, is one. So are cold, arid Mars and hot, cloud-enshrouded Venus. And those gigantic balls of dense gas, Jupiter and Saturn. Planets come in many sizes and compositions, but everybody knows they have one thing in common: they orbit a star. This seemed a sufficient definition of a planet as long as astronomers stuck to the major bodies orbiting our own star, the Sun. Now, when the long search to find planets around other stars has met with its first apparent success - the discovery of a body about the size of Jupiter, though much denser, orbiting a faint star 21 light years away - astronomers are in a semantic turmoil. They are not sure what to call it. Is it truly a planet or more like a star? Or something in between, a would-be star that failed to achieve stardom? The point may seem too precious to be taken seriously. But as astronomers look into the heavens with increasingly sensitive instruments such as the $80 million telescope that the California Institute of Technology said last week it was building high up on an extinct Hawaiian volcano, or for that matter with spacecraft-borne telescopes soon to be launched, they are finding phenomena that stretch not only their imagination but the nomenclature of their profession. The Arizona astronomers who made the discovery through infrared telescopes tried to have it both ways.

title: Iraq Reports Air Attacks Against Iranian Troops
description: Iraq said that its aircraft flew 51 combat missions today against Iranian troops east of the southern port of Basra, Iraq.

title: MY LIFE AS A WRONG NUMBER
description: A LOT OF PEOPLE RECOGnize my name. Some, in fact, do more than that; they seek me out by mail or, more often, by telephone. They confess admiration for my work, then ask me for favors. I try to accept their praise. However, I can't do anything for these people. The guy they want is someone else, a photographer known for his elegant fashion work, who also lives in New York. I found out about him several years ago. I was just out of graduate school, a teacher in a private high school living on a teacher's salary in Manhattan, which is to say I had a roommate. We split expenses. He paid for the heat; I took care of the phone, so it was listed in my name. A common enough arrangement, and a pretty good one.

The S.P.D., as the Socialists are known, can either accustom itself to a long stretch in the opposition or think hard about a coalition in Bonn with the five-year-old anti-establishment movement known as the Greens.

title: Verbatim: Warning in South Africa

title: NEW DISKS REVEAL THE INDIVIUALITY OF FINNISH COMPOSERS
description: A little provincialism can be good for the soul. Finland, separated by both geography and indigenous culture from the European and American mainstreams, has managed, in the past quarter century, to produce some of the most distinctly original music of our time. Despite the many differences in their music, composers such as Aulis Sallinen, Einojuhani Rautavaara and Joonas Kokkonen share a craggy and idiosyncratic individuality, little affected by shifts of esthetic fashion.

Wearing jeans and jogging shoes, their books stowed in backpacks on the floor, they listen as Ronald Speirs, the teacher, discusses the checks-and- balances system of the United States Constitution.

title: THE GREENING OF ORBIS BOOKS
description: FIFTEEN years ago, Philip J. Scharper, a veteran editor, was offered a job: to found a publishing company under the auspices of Maryknoll, the Catholic missionary order. Mr. Scharper, a former Fordham University professor and Commonweal editor, had his doubts, fearing that he would be mixed up in public relations and fund raising. But the Maryknoll priest making the offer, the Rev. Miguel d'Escoto Brockmann, was persuasive, and he took the job. The company, which Mr. Scharper called Orbis Books, made its home in the shadow of Maryknoll's headquarters near Ossining.

Such strongholds tend to be isolated, yet New York City can claim at least one musical outpost of its own. That's the downtown area variously known as Loisaida, the East Village, the Lower East Side and, in recent years, Alphabet Town.

title: OPERA DESIGN IS GOING NEO-BAROQUE

Vast, shadowy structures rear up on stage, born of a long-dormant willingness to indulge in untrammeled fantasy. There is a new interest in age-old theatrical trickery (flying props, trap doors, revolving stages). And everything is illuminated by a new kind of subtly complex lighting, films, neon and projections.

title: A GUIDE TO LEARNING PROJECTS ABROAD

For women, she concluded, it often means learning to cook several meals at a time so ''you can feed your kids faster and go out and gather more wood.''

title: NEW FIGHT ON DRUG TRAFFIC
description: SMUGGLERS have been attracted to Long Island for a long time. In the days of Prohibition, the bays, inlets and hidden shorelines provided ideal landing spots for bootleg whisky shipments headed for New York City. In more recent years, drug smugglers from South America and the Caribbean have shown an increasing interest in this shoreline and have also been taking advantage of the dozens of small airports scattered throughout Suffolk County.

description: -1965 caused some 11,500 infants to be born deaf, more than doubling the number of children deaf at birth in a normal three-year period. This group, known as the ''rubella bulge,'' is now of college age; and as a result, postsecondary programs across the nation for the hearing-impaired now face the problem of accommodating a large, though temporary, increase in students.

title: THE NO-NEED SCHOLARSHIP REKINDLES A HEATED DEBATE
description: UNTIL 1976, when free tuition was abandoned at the City College of New York, every student who was admitted enjoyed the equivalent of a full scholarship. Up to the end of free tuition, throughout the college's 129 years of prior operation, all its students thus had enjoyed what in current language is known as ''no-need'' scholarships. True, most of its students actually were poor enough to have qualified for need-based grants - but nobody asked. The only criteria were the high school grades needed to qualified applicants for admission.

title: Gunman Kills 3 Men In St. Louis Tavern
description: A man brandishing a .45-caliber gun walked into a crowded tavern early today and opened fire, killing three men and wounding two others before fleeing, the police said.

title: PREPARING FOR WINTER EMERGENCIES
description: ALTHOUGH the weather in this area has been relatively mild so far this winter, homeowners may yet have to contend with occasional power failures, icy walks, blocked roads and other emergency situations caused by winter storms or heavy accumulations of ice and snow during bitter cold spells. While there is not much that can be done about controlling the weather, there are steps the prudent homeowner can take to prepare for these unpleasant winter emergencies - and to minimize the inconvenience that such winter storms can cause.

title: Cee Cee Cunning, James Wilbur 4th Marry in Albany

title: DISDAIN FOR TENNIS THAT WON'T DIE
description: W HEN I was in college I found myself being actively recruited for the varsity tennis team. It was not something I might have anticipated since I had, after all, never played the game. In truth, I had never even seen it played and had only a passing acquaintance with its rules. But the time was the early 50's, and the place was a relatively small college in the northwest section of the Bronx, and those two circumstances account for the oddity of my recruitment.

title: The Streets Belong to the City
description: Ever since horse cars started carrying passengers on New York streets in the early 19th century, the city has decided who would be allowed to provide such service and on what terms. Now Albany and Washington, rolling back history and over the city's objections, assert the power to let streams of vans and express buses clog Fifth Avenue and block crosstown streets. It's an intolerable intrusion.

title: ARE THE CURRICULUM REFORMS ELITIST?
description: THE many reports in the last two years on the parlous condition of the nation's schools spurred legislators to action. States from New York to Arkansas to Wisconsin passed stricter requirements for high school diplomas. These requirements were meant to make such diplomas valuable documents - valuable because they really mean something.

title: BAY CLAMMERS BATTLE GIANT DREDGERS
description: MICHAEL PEMBER, an East Northport bayman, brought his 21-foot Steiger clamming boat to rest in the middle of Northport Bay as a searing 20- knot wind tossed the small vessel about in the frigid waters on one of the coldest days of the winter season. While he fought the wind to assemble the sections of his 80- foot manual clamming rake, his companion, Casey, a black Labrador retriever, seemed anxious to help but merely skidded along the ice-lined floorboards of the clamming rig.

About 13,000 people have descended on this patch of hard ground called, without apparent irony, ''the reception area'' for Makale's refugee camps.

title: STIMULI FROM INSIDE AND OUT
description: ''I CULTIVATE my hysteria with joy and terror.'' ''Poetry is a destructive force.'' ''Poetry, when it dies, will be self-slain, murdered by its own strength.'' All the extravagant lines - like these from Baudelaire, Wallace Stevens and Harold Bloom - apply to Delmore Schwartz, who died in 1966. In memoirs by William Barrett, Dwight Macdonald, Eileen Simpson and William Phillips, in ''Humboldt's Gift,'' by Saul Bellow and the biography by James Atlas, Schwartz seized our imagination. We'll read his letters, which have just been published, because he has come to stand for that legendary generation of poets, including Robert Lowell, John Berryman and Randall Jarrell, who

title: Magic Johnson Out
description: Magic Johnson, the Los Angeles Laker star, will miss today's game against the San Antonio Spurs after spraining his right index finger in the victory over the Portland Trail Blazers Friday night. Johnson missed 16 games last season after dislocating the same finger, but Laker officials said they hoped he would be back in the lineup this week. X-rays showed no fracture, but the finger was placed in a splint and doctors planned to examine it again tomorrow.

title: TWILIGHT OF THE MARCOS ERA
description: HIS MORE STRIDENT CRITICS call him a dictator. If so, the dictatorship of Ferdinand E. Marcos is one with a very loose weave. In the Philippines, people don't suffer authoritarian rule in quiet moroseness, pinioned by fear, as they do in, say, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner's Paraguay. Instead, street protesters decry the ''Marcos dictatorship'' - and, just as often, the ''U.S.-Marcos dictatorship'' - with brightly colored banners, sometimes ending their demonstrations with a ritualistic burning of the effigies of Marcos and Uncle Sam in front of Malacanang Palace, the presidential residence.

Roach, also of Houston, took place yesterday at St. Austin's Roman Catholic Church in Austin, Tex. The Rev. Peter Conaty performed the ceremony.

description: It takes about three years, Sol Wachtler said, for a politician to evolve into a jurist. ''Only then,'' he said, ''do you stop thinking every Election Day about what might have been; do you start thinking, acting and feeling like a judge, does judging become a part of your essence.''

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SHULTZ PROMISES A 'REASONABLE' U.S. AT ARMS MEETINGS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he was carrying ''some very interesting and reasonable positions'' to present to Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko when Soviet-United States arms control talks resume here on Monday.

title: HUNGARY ENCOURAGES INTEREST IN COMPUTERS
description: The hand-painted sign over the cluttered cubicle read Computer Butik, forcing a French word into Hungarian.
