description: The post-election ''Victory

title: 3 Dead, One Wounded In Kansas City Dispute
description: An argument over a business apparently caused shootings that left three people dead and one wounded, the authorities reported today.

title: PHILADELPHIA IS 'ON THE MOVE,' MAYOR SAYS OF HIS FIRST YEAR
description: W. Wilson Goode likes to describe Philadelphia as ''a city on the move,'' an expression that many people here would also apply to the outgoing, perpetually busy man who has now served a year as Mayor.

title: VILLAGES IN SALVADOR RESIST PLANS FOR SELF-DEFENSE
description: The villages of Santa Clara and La Palma are separated by a range of imposing volcanic mountains and dozens of miles of broken brushland. But their people have something in common: they do not want to form civil defense units to guard their towns.

title: The Heart of the Experiment
description: ''We need a dynamic, forceful fighter, a guy like Schroeder who wants to live.'' That's heart surgeon William DeVries seeking a third candidate to receive an artificial heart. It's good news that his second patient, William Schroeder, is now enjoying the new year he never expected to see. But in the search for patients it's important not to lose sight of the experiment.

title: Misprint in California Legalizes Hallucinogen
description: Because of a misprint, a drug known as ''angel dust,'' which can produce violent behavior and hallucinations, can now be legally made and sold in California, embarrassed officials acknowledged today.

title: OUTDOORS ;   Advice for Those Who Fish Through Ice
description: With ill-restrained exuberance, I report that even in the northern reaches of New York State and New England there is little or no ice fishing to be had.

title: 15 Years of Talks
description: Charts and tables summarize the negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union. Page A9.

title: Iraq's War Poster Contest
description: Iraq is offering thousands of dollars in prize money to artists depicting the brutality that Iraq says Iran is inflicting on war prisoners. Prizes for posters are as high as $8,000, according to an advertisement for the international contest in a Washington newspaper last week.

title: LOGAN SETS MARK IN WEIGHT THROW
description: Jud Logan set an American record in the 35-pound weight event and Joe Patrone set a meet record in the high jump in the windup of the Dartmouth Relays today.

title: Futures/Options;   Market Unity Still a Dream
description: WHEN the New York Futures Exchange and the Commodity Exchange announced Friday that yearlong merger negotiations had been ended, none were as saddened as those in the brokerage community. For many years, brokers have said unifying New York's five future markets would lead to increased efficiency.

title: Australian Leader's Economic Policy Facing Test
description: In March 1983, the Government of Prime Minister Bob Hawke swept to power on a pledge that it would bring an economic recovery and relative peace to Australia's strife-ridden industrial sector.

title: TRAFFIC BUREAU: TALES OF LIFE IN SLOW LANE
description: It is a place where, every week, New Yorkers recount tales of broken lights, invisible signs, mysterious diseases and miraculous coincidences - each story offered as proof that a motorist did not deserve a traffic ticket.

title: A Kern Film Series
description: A film series observing the centennial of the birth of Jerome Kern will be held at the Regency Theater, at Broadway and 67th Street, begnning Jan. 20.

title: ATLANTA CONSIDERS BUILDING A 'TARA' FOR TOURISTS
description: For legions of tourists and conventiongoers who travel to this booming capital of the Southland, the mythology remains as persistent as it is irresistible: Somewhere among the city's thicket of new glass and steel skyscrapers, they hope and they reckon, they will find Tara.

title: Clinic Bombers Discuss Acts
description: Two confessed bombers of abortion facilities said Saturday that they would be ''thrilled'' if their attacks here led to changes in the law and saved ''unborn children.''

description: Petroleum Corporation and the

title: Bridge ;   Grand National Team Event Moves Into Semifinal Stage
description: The semifinal stage of the New York Grand National Teams began at the Cavendish Club, 148 East 48th Street, yesterday with groups led by Michael Rosmarin and Allen Kahn competing in one match and Brian Glubok and David Berkowitz facing off in the other.

title: Oilers 7, Jets 2
description: Glenn Anderson scored two goals and collected his 400th career point to lead Edmonton to its 20th straight victory over Winnipeg.

New Game in Town

title: VINCENT D. DAMIANI, AN EX-STATE JUSTICE IN APPELLATE COURT
description: Vincent D. Damiani, a former justice of the Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 71 years old.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ;   Wenzel Triumphs In Slalom Event
description: Andreas Wenzel of Liechtenstein, negotiating extremely icy conditions that caused 55 skiers to fall, won a World Cup slalom ski race today at this Pyrenees resort.

title: CONSUMER ELECTRONICS GAIN SEEN
description: The consumer electronics industry is expected to increase sales by about 10 percent in 1985, to $24.9 billion, according to a projection released here this weekend by the Electronics Industry Association.

description: Flora Bartlett couldn't get there

title: Chairman Is Appointed At Flowers Industries
description: Amos R. McMullian, vice chairman and chief executive of Flowers Industries Inc., has been named chairman of the specialty food company. He succeeds Langdon S. Flowers, 62, a son of the founder, who is retiring. Mr. Flowers will continue as a director and member of the executive committee.

title: PURCHASERS SEE DROP IN GROWTH
description: New orders, production and employment fell in December, from November, according to a survey of industrial purchasing managers that painted a more dismal picture of the economy and its future course than other recent economic reports.

title: F.T.C. Backs Carnation Sale
description: The Federal Trade Commission has approved the acquisition by Nestle S.A. of the Carnation Company for $3 billion.

title: Slayer of Coast Mayor Is Free After Six Years
description: Dan White became a free man today, six years after he killed George Moscone, the Mayor of San Francisco, and Harvey Milk, a member of the Board of Supervisors.

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 7, 1985 International

title: Mortgage Lending Off
description: Mortgage lending by savings institutions fell to $10.2 billion in November, from $11.7 billion in October, and $11.6 billion in November 1983, the United States League of Savings Institutions said.

title: Poland Offers 3 Plans For Raising Food Prices
description: Poland's Communist Government has said it will raise food prices in March, but has offered the prospect of ending some rationing.

title: Baby Is Killed in Fall; His Mother Is Charged
description: A 6-month-old boy was killed yesterday when his mother threw him from the bedroom window of their third-floor apartment in Queens, the police said.

title: Report on Margin Requirements
description: The increasing domination of the securities markets by institutions, which tend to avoid buying on credit, has helped to diminish the importance of Government-set margin requirements. The margin for stocks, convertible bonds and short sales has, in fact, not been altered from the 50 percent level since January 1974.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: WHITE NOISE. By Don DeLillo. 326

title: ANGRY CITIZENS IN MANY CITIES SUPPORTING GOETZ
description: The shooting took place on a New York City subway, but what Bernhard Hugo Goetz did on Dec. 22 after he was harassed by four teen- agers has become something greater than a local phenomenon.

title: PROBLEM IN BUSING IS DRIVERS
description: When the driver of a Boston school van, used to transport special education pupils, was arrested in the van and charged with possession of heroin and marijuana, it caused concern about the kind of people transporting Boston's school children.

title: SUNDSTROM WORTHY HEIR TO BORG
description: They grew up in different towns and were from different backgrounds, but they were brought together by a common ambition. They were the tennis progenies of Bjorn Borg, having followed the career of their famous countryman on television and in the newspapers. Borg was someone to look up to, Henrik Sundstrom said, a big hero in a small country. His success prompted a sports revolution of sorts in Sweden, resulting in the growth of tennis clubs and the development of a generation of potential successors.

title: MONDAY, JANUARY 7, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Leslie Jill Mirken Is Bride Of Mitchell Rubin, C.P.A.
description: The marriage of Leslie Jill Mirken, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Mirken of Roslyn, L.I., to Mitchell Jay Rubin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton N. Rubin of Wantagh, L.I., took place yesterday at the Tavern on the Green in Manhattan.

title: VILLANOVA TO TEST ST. JOHN'S TONIGHT
description: If the point wasn't made in an upset loss to Niagara Dec. 15, it's now become clearer that St. John's will be an inviting target for the remainder of the 1984-85 season.

title: Head for Economic Committee
description: Representative Gillis W. Long, a Louisiana Democrat, has taken over as chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, replacing Senator Roger W. Jepsen.

title: ANGOLAN GUERRILLAS, SMUGGLERS TAKE PROFITS OUT OF DIAMONDS
description: Guerrilla sabotage, thinning yields and rampant smuggling have taken the profit out of Angola's diamond mines here.

title: WINDOWS FOR ART'S SAKE
description: They're just the kind of thing that could jolt the most self-absorbed passer-by out of a reverie and might even convince a taxi driver that the red light had turned green too quickly. The riveting distraction is a series of nine-and-a-half-foot-high windows on the corner of Broadway and 10th Street that act as a setting for a selection of oversize sculptures of vegetables and fruits by Ming Fay.

title: Gail Wynters, Upstairs At Chelsea Place
description: Gail Wynters is a singer with two heritages of which she makes ample use in her performance upstairs at Chelsea Place, Eighth Avenue near 17th Street, where she will be singing until early February. One is her undiluted Appalachian accent - a mixture of drawl and twang that makes her sound like a husky-voiced Dolly Parton.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: KENNEDY TOURS BLACK SOUTH AFRICA AREA
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy toured South Africa's biggest black township today and pronounced some living conditions here ''appalling.''

title: Companies Upset By Tax Credit Plan
description: A few obscure paragraphs in the Treasury's tax proposals are seen by tax lawyers and Washington lobbyists as threatening the interests of some big banks, multinational oil companies and manufacturers with investments overseas.

title: Erudite Graffiti
description: On the downtown side of the West

title: HEAD OF CORRUPTION INQUIRY IS SLAIN IN EL SALVADOR
description: The head of a Government commission investigating official corruption was shot to death early today, and President Jose Napoleon Duarte said followers of a far-right party were responsible.

title: Worries Are Emerging Early
description: The bond market, with its generally dismal performance last week, was showing an early preoccupation with the issues that are likely to engage it for the next several months at least.

title: EX-CURATOR OF YALE MUSEUM
description: Dr. Cornelius Osgood, a former professor of anthropology at Yale University and a leading scholar of the cultures of the Arctic and East Asia, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, while walking on a New Haven street. He was 79 years old and lived in Hamden, Conn.

title: SANDINISTAS MARK RAID THAT PRESAGED VICTORY
description: Soon after dark on a December evening 10 years ago last week, a band of masked Sandinista commandos stormed an elegant Managua Christmas party and seized some of the country's most prominent figures as hostages.

title: 'MOUSSE MANIA' IN HAIR CARE
description: Chocolate mousse has been joined by strawberry, lemon and blueberry, on a menu that features hair products, not desserts.

title: ARMS TALKS: THE RECORD SO FAR;   Setting the Scene
description: There are three main arenas for nuclear negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union: medium- range nuclear forces stationed in and around Europe; strategic or intercontinental-range missiles and bombers, and space-based weapons including antisatellite weapons.

title: CONCERT: IRISH FOLK ART
description: The younger generation of Irish-American folk musicians has a new constituency - women. Tunes are now being passed on from father to daughter and husband to wife, broadening a field that used to be virtually all- male. The Ethnic Folk Arts Center presented its first ''Cherish the Ladies'' concert of female Irish traditional performers Saturday in its loft at 179 Varick Street, headlined by a brilliant fiddler from Chicago, Liz Carroll. The two remaining concerts in the series take place Feb. 23 and April 20.

title: STAGE: DALE AND CHANNING IN NICHOLS'S 'JOE EGG'
description: uf812

title: FAMINE IN AFRICA GRIEVES ETHIOPIANS IN NEW YORK
description: They are a small community of perhaps 3,000 people clustered mainly on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, an ocean and a world apart from their drought-stricken homeland.

title: PHILANTHROPY'S STAKE IN TAX REFORM
description: If the current momentum for fundamental tax reform is sustained, the nonprofit sector may well become its most conspicuous unintended victim. Because proposals to reform the income tax would have the effect of reducing the incentive to make contributions, such Charles T. Clotfelter, professor of public policy studies and economics at Duke University, is author of the forthcoming ''Federal Tax Policy and Charitable Giving.'' proposals are likely to dampen the level of giving at the very time that Federal budget cuts are making private support more important. The Treasury tax plan unveiled last month is only the most recent of a series of proposals designed to alter the existing Federal income tax. Conceived in response to what is seen as the complexity, inefficiency and capriciousness of the current income tax, these tax-reform proposals would modify the existing income tax in two basic ways. First, they would bring down tax rates. The Treasury proposal would reduce the top rate from the current 50 percent to 35 percent. Top rates in other proposals are even lower: 30 percent under the Bradley-Gephardt plan and 25 percent under Kemp-Kasten.

title: Norwegian Takes Ski-Jump Finale
description: Hroar Stjernen, who is not a member of Norway's top group of ski jumpers, reached 359 feet 8 inches and 361 feet today to win the final event of the Four Hills tournament.

title: OFFICIALS OF ART MUSEUMS CRITICIZE TAX PROPOSAL
description: The United States Treasury Department's recent proposal for revising the Federal tax structure would sharply limit the ability of art museums to increase their art collections and to maintain present levels of operating funds, according to art museum officials.

description: The resignation of Michael K.

description: BOSTON

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Pantry Pride Head To Join Dominick's
description: Daniel E. Josephs has resigned as chief operating officer and president of Pantry Pride Inc.'s food store operations, effective Jan. 18, to become president and chief operating officer of Dominick's Finer Foods Inc., a Chicago-based supermarket chain.

title: ;   NEW YORK STATE'S DAYS OF OIL GLORY
description: To the Editor:

title: A Female Dunker
description: She had heroes, not heroines. Her role models were not the best female players of the last generation but rather the male leapers of the National Basketball Association.

title: Subverting Titoism
description: Writing a master's thesis at Brandeis University can be a risky business if you are a Yugoslav. Milan Nikolic, a 37-year-old sociologist, is threatened with jail in Belgrade because he ''falsely asserted'' in his thesis two years ago that Yugoslavia's Communist Party was ''firmly Stalinist'' in 1945.

title: CAN AN ARTIFICIAL HEART HAVE ITS REASONS?
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics Flavor / Favor
description: Sweet Justice

title: Mexican Train Derails, Killing 7 and Injuring 182
description: A passenger train derailed near Calpulalpan, killing at least 7 people and injuring 182, the police and the Red Cross said today.

title: NEW DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST PLAN TO MAKE GIFT A TRADITION
description: A tradition of giving is a major force in the flow of donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Every year, a new generation of donors pledges to make such contributions a tradition.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ;   Erving to Sign One-Year Pact
description: Julius Erving, the Philadelphia 76ers' all-star forward, has ended speculation about his retirement by announcing he will sign a one-year contract for next season.

title: Viola Wells Evans Dies at 82;Singer Called Miss Rhapsody
description: Viola Wells Evans, a blues, jazz and religious singer known as Miss Rhapsody whose professional career spanned 60 years, died Dec. 22 at Clara Maass Medical Center in Belleville, N.J., after a short illness. She was 82 years old.

title: STRAUSS WINS 4TH SWIM TITLE
description: Astrid Strauss of East Germany picked up her fourth first-place finish in as many days as she captured the women's 400-meter freestyle today in the finale of the United States Swimming International indoor meet at the University of Arkansas.

title: Cambodian Rebels Fight Vietnamese at Camp
description: Cambodian rebels opened fire with mortars and rockets today in an attack on Vietnamese troops who were poised to assault the guerrilla military headquarters at Ampil.

title: Emily Remler, Guitarist, And 2 Singers Perform
description: The program with which the ''Highlights in Jazz'' series completed its 11th year on Friday evening at Loeb Auditorium was a departure from its usual presentations. On the surface, the departure might seem to be that, to live up to the concert title, ''Women in Jazz'', the headliners were all women - the contemporary guitarist Emily Remler, the folk singer Odetta, and the jazz-influenced singer Chris Connor - the first time that ''highlights'' has taken a feminist stance.

title: Two Strikes
description: Ed Keating, who lost in the competition to become Doug Flutie's agent, found himself disappointed but hardly surprised.

title: A Few Good Skiers
description: Do you know a 12-year-old girl who can do 45 sit-ups? Or a 14-year-old boy who can run a mile in 5 minutes 55 seconds? How about a 15-year-old girl who can do a 440-yard dash in 71 seconds? Have you got a 19-year-old who can do 60 push-ups?

title: IN INDIA, A HINDU REVOLUTION
description: A conservative, Hindu revolution has swept India. Ignoring their discontent over the Congress Party's five years of misrule and corruption, Indian voters have given 40-year-old Rajiv Gandhi a sweeping mandate that they withheld from his mother, Indira Gandhi, and even from his grandfather, Jawaharlal Nehru. While the extent of this mandate is reassuring, its nature seems quite ominous.

title: WATER THAT ENRICHED VALLEYBECOMES A PERIL IN CALIFORNIA
description: Farmers in the Central Valley of California are facing a cruel irony: the irrigation water that transformed a desert into the nation's most bountiful agricultural area is now threatening to make much of it worthless again.

title: Chief of Lucky Stores Taking Less Active Role
description: S. Donley Ritchey, who has been chairman and chief executive at Lucky Stores Inc. for five years, has informed the company's board that as of June he intends to take a less active role in managing the firm.

title: DEMOCRATIC FEARS AND FRAZZLES
description: Since the November election, Democrats on Capitol Hill have been thrashing around in a state of fear and frustration. Yes, they kept control of the House of Representatives, and they did win back two seats in the Republican-dominated Senate. But the crushing defeat of Walter F. Mondale, the man who best exemplified the Democratic tradition of the last 50 years, a candidate widely supported by the party's Congressional delegation, has brought on a period of soul- searching.

title: Abbott Loses Its President
description: G. Kirk Raab, president and chief operating officer at Abbott Laboraties since July 1981, has resigned.

title: MusicNoted in Brief;   Cast Changes at Met For 'Cos i Fan Tutte'
description: Several cast changes have substantially improved the current Metropolitan Opera production of ''Cos i fan tutte,'' and with the eighth performance of the year, which took place Saturday night at Lincoln Center, this staging of Mozart's masterpiece has evolved into one of the season's triumphs.

title: Levine, Huntley Ads For British Computers
description: Talk about bringing coals to Newcastle. There is a company in Birmingham, England, that is bringing computers to America.

title: League Inquiry On Disputed Shot
description: Charlie Theokas, the Atlantic 10 Conference commissioner, will examine the decision that disallowed an apparent game-winning basket by West Virginia on the last shot Saturday against St. Joseph's.

title: A CHILD'S ROLE AFTER A DIVORCE
description: JANE McDERMOTT of Boston

title: FOR SHULTZ, ARMS CONTROL TALKS OFFER FRESH PROMINENCE AND NEW PURPOSE
description: Nearly a year ago, when the White House announced the pullback of American marines from Lebanon, it was an open secret that Secretary of State George P. Shultz was deeply discouraged. There was even talk that he might resign and go back to California.

title: Sallie Mae Offers Euroyen Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, plans to offer about $100 million, or 25 billion yen, in seven-year Euroyen notes. The offering is Sallie Mae's first in the Euromarket and will be targeted for foreign investors.

title: Flach and Seguso Capture Doubles
description: Ken Flach and Robert Seguso of the United States won the World Doubles tennis tournament at Royal Albert Hall today with a 6-3, 3-6, 6-3, 6-0 victory over Heinz Gunthardt of Switzerland and Balazs Taroczy of Hungary.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have no illusions that progress will be easy to achieve.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz. (A1:6.)

title: At Freddy's, Carol Bruce And Bernie Wayne
description: The Broadway singer and television performer Carol Bruce and her sometime mentor, the pianist and songwriter Bernie Wayne, are hardy show-business veterans who trade rather too heavily on nostalgia. Their act, which plays at Freddy's Supper Club through Sunday, is a dual retrospective that, with much sentimentalizing, glosses the highlights of both careers.

title: MUSIC: DUNN, SOPRANO
description: Sunday, Jan. 6, will be remembered as the day when the soprano Susan Dunn took her first majestic step into the annals of musical history. A little before 4, Miss Dunn, not yet 30 years old, made a staggering impression in a concert performance of the first act of Wagner's ''Walkure'' at Carnegie Hall. With a huge, flexible voice that easily cut through any fortississimo the American Symphony Orchestra could dish out, yet that was also capable of exquisite gentility, Miss Dunn made a thrilling Sieglinde - now sweetly surrendering, now thundering forth with a power and grandeur that could shake Valhalla.

title: Isidore & Paulson
description: Isidore & Paulson will handle the advertising for the gas and electric ranges produced by Caloric, a division of Raytheon. The 1984 budget was reportedly $1 million. The previous agency was Elkman Advertising of Bala Cynwyd, Pa.

title: Israeli Cabinet Orders Inquiry in Bank Scandal
description: The Israeli Cabinet today ordered an inquiry by a state commission into a bank-shares scandal that wiped out the savings of hundreds of thousands of Israelis.

title: Methodists Take A Backward Look
description: In January 1785, members of the

title: BLUE BUILDING MAKES SOME CHICAGOANS SEE RED
description: For every person who thinks the new State of Illinois Center is ''exciting,'' or ''dazzling,'' there are those like Dominick Prohm.

title: NO TIME TO MAKE EXECUTIVE ORDER 50 AN ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Saffron, 66, an Author And Ex-Newspaperman, Dies
description: Robert Saffron, an author and former newspaperman, died of pneumonia Friday at the Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NICARAGUA SEEKS JAILED REBEL
description: Nicaragua has asked Honduras to extradite Steadman Fagoth M"uller, the anti-Sandinista Indian leader who was arrested in Honduras last week.

title: Artie Baby Wins
description: Artie Baby led from the start to post a 2 1/4-length victory yesterday in the $66,700 Montauk Stakes for New York-bred 3-year-olds at Aqueduct. Artie Baby, ridden by Gregg McCarron, covered the mile and a sixteenth in 1:46 3/5. The son of Hatchet Man and Getoffmycloud scored his first stakes victory, earned $40,020 for his owner, Gilbert E. Campbell, and paid $23.80 for $2 to win.

title: THE MUCH USED KENYAN PHONE (EVEN FOR CALLS)
description: When residents of this country use a public telephone, they do so in ways that speak more to the ingenuity of a developing nation than to manners established by convention. The clothes that are drying in this temperate climate may be hanging from ''liberated'' telephone wires. The rectangular panes of glass in phone booths may end up as picture frames. And, according to The Sunday Nation, a local newspaper in this Texas-sized nation, the ''ingenuity and the entrepreneurship of the vandals is particularly remarkable on the parts inside'' the receiver.

title: Masback Wins
description: Craig Masback, who admits that 1984 was a disappointing running year for him, is working his way into shape for what he hopes will be more successful in 1985. Today, he took a step in that direction when he won the 3-mile run at the Metropolitan Athletics Congress track and field meet in Jadwin Gym.

title: BONDS MAY BE LOSING FAVOR
description: Stock market investors have plenty of worries, ranging from the size of the Federal deficit to the longevity of the economic advance. But more money managers these days are creeping back into stocks for one simple reason: bonds have become less competitive.

title: The Trio Gotham Sings Together Again
description: After breaking up four years ago and going their separate ways, the singing trio Gotham is back together again, plundering the harmony groups of the past to comic effect and drawing on them for their own tightly voiced performances.

title: OLDER FATHERS: BECOMING A PARENT AFTER 50
description: It is a sight that is becoming more common in the city's parks and supermarkets: balding, gray-haired men toting infants on their chests in Snuglis or earnestly conversing in baby talk with 2-year-olds clutching lollipops.

title: Judge Orders Bucks County To Resume a Water Project
description: A Common Pleas judge has ordered Bucks County to resume construction of a project to supply Delaware River water to a utility and two water-supply agencies.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: EXECUTIVES
ISRAEL-RUN AIRLIFT OF ETHIOPIA'S JEWS FROM SUDAN HALTS
description: The covert airlift of Ethiopian Jews to Israel has been halted because of the publicity given to the operation, a spokesman for the Jewish Agency, a semiofficial Government body, announced today.

title: 'A REASON TO LIVE,' WITH FONDA AND SCHRODER
description: There has been a spate of television movies dealing with the subject of teen-age suicides. One or two of them have been quite good. Now, tonight at 9 on NBC, ''A Reason to Live'' offers the story of a teen-ager trying to pull his father back from the brink of suicide. It is a simply dreadful movie.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: COMPARED WITH NATO, ISRAEL AID IS A BARGAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: IRISH SUR'S VICTORY INDICATES WEAK CROP OF DERBY HOPEFULS
description: It was not a promising omen for a new year of racing: the colt who won the Tropical Park Derby here Saturday, the first Kentucky Derby prep, was nursed by a cow.

title: Lakers Top Spurs For 9th in a Row
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar hit a 12-foot jumper as time expired tonight to give the Los Angeles Lakers a 99-98 victory over the San Antonio Spurs.

title: TODAY Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Boston Celtics , at Madison Square Garden, 8:05 P.M. The Knicks dropped a 105-94 decision to the Celtics on Friday night in Boston, but rebounded Saturday night to beat Chicago and end a six-game losing streak.

title: VIETNAMESE ANTI-COMMUNIST GROUPS GAIN MEMBERS IN U.S.
description: An anti-Communist resistance movement that provoked complaints from the Hanoi Government in late December has been rapidly gaining adherents among Vietnamese refugees in America, though many of them question its effectiveness.

title: Nissan U.S. Car Plans
description: The Nissan Motor Company said that it would produce its first car in the United States on March 26, ahead of schedule. The company had said it would start making two-door Sentra front-wheel-drive sedans in late April or early May at its Smyrna, Tenn., factory, which has made only light trucks since it opened 18 months ago.

title: WHITE HOUSE COMPUTER LINE TO PROVIDE 'UNFILTERED' NEWS
description: The White House, guided by President Reagan's repeated complaints that his views are distorted by the reporters who cover him, is starting a service to distribute Presidential speeches and announcements.

title: GENEVA MEETING IS AN ENCOUNTER ON THREE FRONTS
description: The superpower meeting here on arms control is taking shape in three arenas: a public propaganda battle as a backdrop to businesslike private exchanges, intertwined with throngs of journalists ready to record and judge success and failure.

title: Jordan Says It Will Get Advanced Soviet Arms
description: Jordan will receive advanced ground- and air-defense weapons from the Soviet Union early this year, the army commander, Gen. Zeid bin Shaker, has announced.

title: Betty Gee Mah, Officer OfWed
description: At St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan yesterday Betty Gee Mah, a vice president of Salomon Brothers, was married to Jim C. Chang, an associate product manager with the Maxwell House Division of the General Foods Corporation in White Plains. The Rev. Andrew Mullins performed the ceremony.

title: Advertising;   Creative Czar at SSC&B
description: SERIOUS students of the advertising business should keep an eye on the advertising coming out of SSC&B:Lintas to see if having the supreme creative leadership in the hands of an art director changes the agency's product.

title: STALLWORTH SETS TWO RECORDS
description: When the pressure was on, the Steelers went to John Stallworth, whose 11th season ended today with two playoff records in Pittsburgh's 45-28 loss to the Miami Dolphins in the American Conference championship game.

title: ZACCARO INDICTMENT IS TO BE ANNOUNCED TODAY, LAWYERS SAY
description: The Manhattan District Attorney is to announce the indictment of John A. Zaccaro today on several misdemeanor counts involving a failed real estate deal in Queens, lawyers close to the case said yesterday.

title: Decker Planning Dramatic Return
description: Mary Decker, the nation's leading female middle-distance runner who suffered two stunning upsets last year, has fully recovered from the dramatic collision that knocked her out of the Olympic 3,000 in August and has set her sights on an even more dramatic return to competition this month.

title: STORY OF A MEXICAN IMMIGRANT 'HERO'
description: As a young, restless boy Pedro J. Gonzalez would watch the local telegraph operator send messages to faraway places and dreamed that one day he too would be the link between his remote, dusty village in Chihuahua, Mexico, and the rest of the world.

title: Another Vista Becomes History
description: One good thing about Manhattan's

title: Sun Shines on Mummers
description: Thousands of revelers turned out in crisp, sunny weather today to watch 25,000 marchers strut up Broad Street in the 85th Mummers Parade. Bad weather on New Year's Day and Saturday had forced two postponements.

title: OLD FAVORITES AND NEW CHALLENGERS JOIN PGA TOUR
description: Fuzzy Zoeller, the reigning United States Open champion, will not be able to play when the 1985 PGA Tour opens Wednesday with the Bob Hope Classic on four courses in Palm Springs, Calif. Nevertheless, Zoeller is delighted, because he can swing his clubs again. He even thinks he can rejoin the tour when it reaches Florida in the second week of February.

title: Trends in Burglaries Reported
description: In 42 percent of 7 million household burglaries included in a Justice Department study, the perpetrator was a relative, acquaintance or someone recognizable to the victim, the department said today.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT DEVILS IN OVERTIME
description: Tomas Sandstrom scored 1 minute 14 seconds into overtime last night at the Garden to give the Rangers a 5-4 victory over the Devils. The goal ended one of the most furious chapters in the burgeoning rivalry between the two teams.

title: RANGERS WOUNDED AND WORRIED
description: It felt like night, but it was afternoon, and the afternoon had exploded in ways that were so implausible they must have been ordained. The chill of the New England winter had crept into the Ranger locker room. The coach slumped in a wooden chair in a corner, beneath the hooks of an empty coat rack, in a cement room removed from his players.

title: ATARI TAKES ON APPLE'S MACINTOSH
description: A slimmed-down Atari Corporation this weekend introduced its first of a new line of powerful home computers. The machines, shown at the Winter Consumer Electronics Show here, are similar to Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh model, but less than a third of the price.

title: CUOMO TO ASK LEGISLATURE FOR $1.2 BILLION TAX CUT
description: In his State of the State Message on Wednesday, Governor Cuomo will ask lawmakers to cut taxes by $1.2 billion over the next three years.

title: Washington Watch;   An Aloof Role At Basel Bank

title: Fatal Barn Fire Still a Mystery
description: Arson investigators sifted through the rubble of an Airdrie Stud barn today, but failed to determine the cause of a fire that killed 15 thoroughbred broodmares and yearlings Saturday night.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CITY HALL AND THE CAMPAIGN
description: The beginning of a new year is generally a quiet time around the city. But not in that piece of lower Manhattan that houses city government - not this year.

title: 'A MOUTHFUL ON MARINO'
description: During his 22 seasons as a coach, Don Shula inherited two of pro football's best quarterbacks - Bob Griese with the Miami Dolphins and before that Johnny Unitas with the Baltimore Colts. But in Dan Marino, the Miami Dolphins' coach has drafted and developed the quarterback who might be the best yet. Dan Marino is his quarterback, nobody else's. And perhaps that is why Don Shula's jutting jaw melts into a soft smile when he talks about his 23-year-old passer.

title: ARMS TALKS: THE RECORD SO FAR;   The Key Americans Secretary of State. He came into that post in 1982 with admittedly no experience in arms control. He has said his priority has been to get a grasp on arms control material to help direct policy in that area. His background was in academic, labor relations, business and economic fields. He has also held two other top Cabinet posts, that of Secretary of Labor in 1969-70 and Secretary of the Treasury in 1972-74. He is 64 years old.
description: Paul H. Nitze

title: RIVALS LESS FEARFUL OF AGING ISLANDERS
description: They say they are not tired. Motivation, they also profess, isn't a problem. Inconsistency and uptight play are what they have targeted as their nemeses.

title: JENNIE MacMAHON
description: Jennie Simon MacMahon, an actress who began her professional career when she was 53 years old, died in her home in Beverly Hills, Calif., on Dec. 29.

title: Favorite Pastimes
description: Chances are you're in a hurry to get to the swimming pool, go for a bike ride or get in some fishing, but before you do, you might want to take a moment to check how your favorite sports and recreational activities rate among those of fellow amateur athletes.

title: ALBERT KING TRIES TO SHAKE OFF INJURIES
description: Comparisons are nothing new for Albert King. Despite earning nationwide acclaim as a player in high school and college, he has long lived with the fact that he isn't the best player in his own family. That honor belongs to older brother Bernard.

title: 2 ADULTS AND 6 CHILDREN KILLED IN 2 FIRES IN JERSEY
description: Eight people, including six children, were killed in fires in two New Jersey homes Saturday night and early yesterday, fire officials said. They said both blazes had started accidentally.

title: PICTURE NICARAGUA AS A KIND OF ALAMO
description: To the Editor:

title: Bowling Ball Used in Killing
description: A woman who told the police her boyfriend beat her faces charges of killing the man, the owner of a bowling supply company, by dropping a bowling ball on his head while he slept. The police said Glendon Wininger, 40 years old, of Bloomington, said she dropped the ball several times from about waist height on Steven Detmer, 37, Friday night. He died the next day.

title: CITY TO HIRE CONSULTANT TO CUT JAIL OVERTIME
description: The Department of Correction, unable to control surging overtime costs over a period of years, is hiring an outside consultant to try to figure out what to do about the problem.

title: Computer Design Cards For F-4 Jet Are Stolen
description: Design specifications and sketches on computer cards for the F-4 Phantom fighter were stolen from a company under investigation on charges of illegal shipment of F-4 parts, the authorities said Saturday.

title: Market Place;   A Top 10 List With Cautions
description: WHAT are the stock market's prospects for the period immediately ahead? The view from the technician's chart room at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company remains cautious.

title: AMERICAN AND BRITISH ACTORS DISCUSS EXCHANGES
description: ''We speak the same language,'' the American actor F. Murray Abraham said. ''It's absurd we can't get along.'' He made the rueful comment last week as nearly 35 American and British actors gathered in the Manhattan offices of Actors Equity for a rare and candid discussion about the barriers that limit them from working in theater in one another's countries.

title: HIGHER BID ACCEPTED BY SCOVILL
description: Scovill Inc., a consumer products company that makes everything from kitchen cabinets to corn poppers, yesterday agreed to be acquired for $517 million by a company controlled by the Belzberg family of Canada.

title: A Less Drastic Budget Cut
description: Soon after President Reagan appointed Terrence M. Scanlon to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission, the new chairman was able to get the Administration to back away from large cuts it planned in the commission's budget.

title: For the 49er Defense, a Sweet Triumph
description: The Chicago Bears' defense ranked first this season in the National Football League. The 49ers' defense knew that, because its players had read about it all week.

title: CONCERT: Y CHAMBER SYMPHONY
description: Chamber orchestras are adjustable bodies; the 92d Street Y's is listed in the program at a strength of 43 players (26 strings), and is sometimes augmented beyond that. But for most of the enjoyable concert devoted to Handel and two Bachs Saturday it was a modest string ensemble of about 14.

title: Four in Family Killed; Son Arrested on Coast
description: A couple, their daughter and grandchild were shot to death while a family friend listened over the telephone.

title: Phillips Seeks Wage Decision
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company has asked employees to defer the wage increases negotiated last spring until it can finish reconstructing after Mesa Partners' aborted takeover bid, officials said. Union members in Borger were scheduled to vote today and tomorrow on Phillips' request. Phillips employees in at least five other cities have also been asked to defer the raises.

title: Sawdon & Bess Gets Black & White Scotch
description: Sawdon & Bess Advertising, the retail-oriented subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, now has something to drink to, and with - Black & White Scotch.

title: POINT FROM DEFEAT, TALBOTT WINS FINAL
description: Down by 4-1 in overtime, a point from defeat, Mark Talbott of Boston ran off 4 points and beat Ned Edwards of New York in the final of the Greenwich Open squash racquets championship today. The scores were 12-15, 17-16, 18-16, 12-15, 18-17.

title: DOLPHINS AND 49ERS ROMP TO GAIN SUPER BOWL
description: The San Francisco 49ers, who had more trouble with themselves than they did with the Chicago Bears in the first half, scored 17 points in the second half to win the National Conference championship today, 23-0, and advance to the Super Bowl game for the second time in four seasons.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Have any basketball players led the N.C.A.A. in scoring in one season and the N.B.A. in another?

title: Corporate Offerings Remain Scanty
description: The schedule of corporate debt offerings continues thin, in line with the fall-off in business at the turn of the year. But the flow of tax-exempt issues remains steady.

title: INTERRUPTED EXODUS
description: WASHINGTON The reason for Israel's existence

title: Ducking the Foster Care Issue
description: Judges don't like second-guessing educators about what should happen in the classroom. That's why the New York Court of Appeals has ruled that a child in foster care who got a poor education cannot collect damages because of ''educational malpractice.'' Yet by focusing on that issue, the court majority missed the point. Society may or may not be served by court review of educational practice; it certainly benefits from court enforcement of accountability for the 17,000 New York City children in custodial foster care.

title: Account
description: * Everstyl, a French-made recliner, to B&B Direct.

title: Jailed Pastor's Allies Hold Outdoor Service
description: About 100 supporters of a jailed pastor worshiped outside his church today as sheriff's deputies who seized the church last week watched from inside.

title: INMATES THWART CLOSING OF L.I. PRISON
description: Inmates fighting to keep open a 1,000- bed prison here have stymied Governor Cuomo's attempts to fulfill a campaign pledge to close it.

title: MUSIC: ROREM 'ORATORIO'
description: We hear a little bit of America in the cleanliness of his vocal writing and even more in the frank passion of his autobiographical writings, but what is perhaps most American about Ned Rorem is his ambition and his industry. New music continues to pour from him, and he knows how to promote it and get it played. Other composers who complain of neglect might look to Mr. Rorem's example. He is, if anything, a working professional, and one can only admire his success.

title: CUOMO AT MIDTERM
description: NewsAnalysis

title: DANCE: 'NUTCRACKER'
description: The seasonal run of George Balanchine's ''Nutcracker'' wound to a close over the weekend with a delightful debut and other good performances Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater. The debut was that of Carlo Merlo, one of the New York City Ballet's most promising young dancers, in the role of the Cavalier to the Sugar Plum Fairy, danced by Nichol Hlinka. Though both seemed slightly apprehensive at the start of the pas de deux, the partnering was secure and even daring. Mr. Merlo gave the lovely Miss Hlinka, one of the company's most exciting turners, ample chance to display her open, clear arabesque, which makes her look as if she will float off any moment. The role of the Cavalier is a small one, and one was left wanting to see much more of the engaging Mr. Merlo. His ballet manners were occasionally a little rough - as in one ambling entrance - but typically, he combined a fine, innate-looking classical technique and attack with an infectiously joyous expansiveness. Mr. Merlo is a dancer who looks as if he loves to dance.

title: WALSH TO REMAIN AS COACH OF 49ERS
description: With his team comfortably in Super Bowl XIX after its victory in the National Conference championship game, Bill Walsh said today that he would return to coach the San Francisco 49ers for at least two more seasons and possibly three.

description: b-After a charge of $20 million for the quarter and the 9 months associated with an asset redeployment plan.

description: Israel and Lebanon resumed their negotiations today, but it became quickly apparent that the two sides were still far apart and that the talks were probably doomed to fail, Israeli officials indicated.

title: WHITE HOUSE PLANNING DIRECT LINK TO TV STATIONS
description: The White House said today that it was working out arrangements to help local television stations conduct direct interviews with President Reagan and high-ranking Government officials.

title: Dormitory Chief Leaves
description: George D. Gould, chairman of the State Dormitory Authority, announced his resignation yesterday in order to devote more time to his responsibilities as a partner at Wertheim & Company, the investment firm, and as chairman of Madison Resources Inc., another investment firm. Mr. Gould was appointed to the board in 1982 to direct its recovery from difficulties resulting from the bankruptcy of Lombard-Wall Securities Inc., with which it had substantial investments. Bradford J. Race Jr., the authority's vice chairman, will serve as acting chairman.

title: Boston Ballet Appoints Bruce Marks as Director
description: Bruce Marks has been named director of the Boston Ballet. Mr. Marks's appointment will take effect in June, under a three-year contract. Mr. Marks is currently the director of Ballet West in Salt Lake City.

title: SEARCH FOR ARTISTIC CHIEF EXTENDED AT BEAUMONT
description: The board of the Vivian Beaumont Theater has been given permission to extend its deadline, perhaps as long as six months, for selecting an artistic manager and developing a detailed statement about the theater's goals.

title: NEW UTAH LEADER SAYS LESS GOVERNMENT WILL AID ECONOMY
description: Norman H. Bangerter took the oath of office as Utah's 13th Governor here today and pledged to limit the role of his administration to helping Utahans help themselves.

title: Cowboy Retires
description: Bob Breunig, the Dallas Cowboy linebacker who missed half of the season because of a recurring back problem, will announce his retirement today, the team said. A 10-year pro from Arizona State, Breunig started in 119 consecutive games for Dallas before the back injury forced him from the lineup in the third week of this season.

title: Early Endorsement
description: When David N. Dinkins formally announces his candidacy for Manhattan Borough President, he can count on one thing: an unqualified endorsement from Carol Bellamy, the City Council President.

title: HUSBAND'S GUILTY PLEA SEEN DAMAGING FERRARRO'S CAREER
description: New York Democratic politicians and political consultants said yesterday that Geraldine A. Ferraro's political career had been damaged by the indictment and guilty plea of her husband, John A. Zaccaro. But they disagreed on how much.

title: 'Puerto Rico Sings' Celebrates Island Music
description: ''Puerto Rico Sings,'' a celebration of Puerto Rican popular song from the 19th and 20th centuries, makes a strong case for the vitality and sophistication of music by an interesting assortment of pop and semiclassical composers. A Repertorio Espanol production, the show was conceived and directed by Rene Buch.

title: MENACHEM BEGIN'S HEAVY LEGACY
description: Paris The Middle East is approaching

title: Wilhelm, Brock Elected to Hall
description: Hoyt Wilhelm and Lou Brock, two of the great specialists in modern baseball, were elected to the Hall of Fame last night. But in the closest losing margin on record, the late Nelson Fox was denied election. He fell 2 votes shy of the required 75 percent of the votes cast, getting 74.6.

title: ZACCARO ADMITS GUILT IN SCHEME FOR REALTY DEAL
description: John A. Zaccaro pleaded guilty yesterday in Manhattan to an indictment charging him with scheming to fraudulently obtain financing for a multimillion-dollar real-estate deal.

title: HARVARD REVERSES TENURE DECISION
description: Harvard University has offered tenure to Theda Skocpol, a sociologist who charged university officials with sex discrimination four years ago.

title: Wrong Winner
description: The seven television stations of the Mountaineer Sports Network, which televises basketball and football games of West Virginia University, signed off on a happy note Saturday, only to discover moments later they had the wrong team winning and the wrong score.

title: Chip Design Registration
description: The Federal Copyright Office today received the first formal applications to register designs for semiconductor chips, under legislation enacted last year to stem the production of chips based on ''stolen'' designs. At the ceremony in the foyer of the Copyright Office, officials of the Intel Corporation, Motorola Inc. and the Harris Corporation, all major manufacturers of semiconductors, submitted applications forregistration.

title: President Adds Title At Sterling
description: Sterling Drug Inc. said yesterday that John M. Pietruski Jr., its president, would assume the additional position of chief executive on Feb. 1. In his new position. Mr. Pietruski, 51, will replace Dr. W. Clarke Wescoe, Sterling's chairman. Mr. Pietruski joined Sterling seven years ago as a corporate vice president and head of its pharmaceutical group.

title: 3-Year Old With Herpes Is Alone in Classroom
description: A 3-year-old boy with herpes spent his first day of school yesterday with a substitute teacher and a public health nurse in a classroom in Pasadena, Md.

title: CIGARETTE TAX USE IN MEDICARE ASKED
description: Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human Services, has recommended that part of the revenue from the Federal excise tax on cigarettes be earmarked for Medicare's hospital insurance trust fund.

title: THE 'EYES' OF ALGAE OFFER A VIEW OF MAN
description: yes, these single-cell aquatic organisms have complete visual systems - biophysicists have discovered a striking family resemblance between algae and cows. They share the same kind of light-sensitive protein, rhodopsin, making it a rare vestige of the common evolutionary origins of plants and animals.

title: Coptic Pope Says Mass, Ending His Banishment
description: To cheers from more than 10,000 Coptic Christians, Pope Shenuda III formally ended more than three years of banishment today by officiating at a midnight mass in central Cairo.

title: Chess Game Is Adjourned
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov adjourned the 39th game of their world chess championship match today with Kasparov, playing Black, sealing his 41st move.

title: Conrail Plan Submitted
description: Directors of the Consolidated Rail Corporation have sent the Secretary of Transportation a management proposal for a public sale of Conrail and asked that it be considered on the ''same basis'' as the offers of three parties with whom the Secretary has been considering a negotiated sale.

title: 2 Held in Crime Spree Sentenced in Kidnapping
description: A Federal judge today sentenced Alton Coleman and Debra Brown to 20 years in prison on kidnapping charges, and the two were immediately taken to Cincinnati to face murder charges.

title: MUSIC: WASHINGTON OPERA'S MENOTTI
description: The double bill with which the Washington Opera has represented American musical theater at the Edinburgh Festival, and which is slated to go to the Jerusalem Festival later this year, is one item in a long and fruitful association between Gian Carlo Menotti and opera in his adoptive country's capital. In this season's revival at the Kennedy Center Terrace Theater (heard at the final performance Sunday afternoon) it shows the best and worst of Menotti, both in an unusually good light.

title: Reagan to Name Four To Kennedy Center
description: The White House announced today that President Reagan plans to name four new members to the board of trustees of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts to terms expiring Sept. 1, 1994.

title: KOCH URGES BETTER SECURITY FOR APARTMENT HOUSES
description: Mayor Koch proposed yesterday that many older, smaller apartment buildings be required to have intercoms and locked front doors, making the buildings more secure. He said he would increase the number of city housing inspectors to make sure all security measures were enforced.

Reporters were feverishly asking questions and checking the many rumors - some rumors being spiked immediately, others receiving the coy, ''We aren't confirming, we aren't denying.'' Reporters were told, though, that an announcement would be made soon: On Monday morning at 11 o'clock Eastern Standard Time. Tension continued to mount.

title: Surgery for Mahre
description: Steve Mahre , a silver medalist at the 1984 Winter Olympic Games in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, is on crutches at his home in Yakima, Wash., after undergoing knee surgery caused by a skiing injury.

title: No Headline
description: Bargaining With New York's Labor After months of talk, New York City and its employees cannot even foresee the terms for renewing the wage contracts that expired over the past year. The city's Collective Bargaining Board therefore seems ready to declare an impasse to permit binding arbitration. That would be preferable to an illegal strike, but it is hardly a sound approach.

title: THEATER: JACQUES BREL
description: THE songs of Jacques Brel are slabs of melody with lyrics that often take a single idea and develop it with rough, stream-of-consciousness variations into a big dramatic climax. With their overflowing emotions, Brel's songs are designed more for actors who sing than the reverse. In order to interpret them effectively, singers must be able to deal with extremes of sentimentality, earthiness and morbidity that often dwell in the same lyric.

description: An investor group seeking to buy Northwest Industries is close to finally arranging financing for the $1 billion deal, Wall Street sources said today.

title: THE PLIGHT OF ORPHAN COMPUTERS

It was the latest casualty of the home computing wars of the 1980's, having been preceded in mortality by the Osborne, the Texas Instruments 99, Mattel, Timex-Sinclair, Franklin Ace and others, and leaves only Atari and Commodore to slug it out in the low-end computer arena.

description: Interest rates on home mortgages continued to drop in early December, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday in Washington.

Mr. Coryell made his reputation as one of the first - and fastest - jazz-rock guitarists in the late 1960's, impressing rock fans with machine-gun scales and riffs. Lately, however, he has returned to the subtler pleasures of jazz.
