title: DISMISSAL FROM ORDER HAS HUMAN COSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: ORATORIO: AMOR ARTIS
description: BACH'S CHRISTMAS ORATORIO is less an oratorio than a collection of cantatas - six in all - written for different days of the Christmas season but bound together by the unfolding story of Jesus' birth. The Amor Artis Chorale and Orchestra conducted by Johannes Somary performed Bach's great choral piece Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall, celebrating both the end of the Christmas season and the beginning of Bach's 300th anniversary year.

title: EDITING AND LIBEL
description: Long after the issue of libel has been decided in Ariel Sharon's $50 million suit against Time Inc., journalists are likely to be debating questions raised in the case regarding Time magazine's standards of reporting and its complex editorial process. The journalistic issues have been sharpened by the announcement yesterday that, contrary to what had been reported in Time, a secret appendix to an Israeli commission report apparently did not contain some information damaging to Mr. Sharon, according to the Israeli jurist who headed the commission.

title: Boesky Sells Stake In 2 Concerns
description: Ivan F. Boesky, the New York investor, and a group of companies he controls have sold their shares in ARA Services Inc. and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. in separate deals valued at more than $131.4 million. according to Securities and Exchange Commission filings.

title: MALAYSIA DISCLOSES DETAILS OF BANK SCANDAL
description: A report by a three- man investigative panel has bared details of the biggest financial scandal in Malaysia's history, calming fears by opposition parties of a Government cover-up.

title: Jacksonville's Electric Bonds
description: In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the Jacksonville Electric Authority in Florida is issuing $150 million of electric revenue bonds.

title: College Loses Bid To Overturn Law
description: The United States Supreme Court today let stand a New Jersey law under which a fundamentalist Christian college in Cape May was barred from awarding degrees for refusing to submit to a state licensing review.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CURRENCY MARKETS ;   Yen at Two-Year Low; Dollar Declines in U.S.
description: The yen fell to a two-year low in trading against the dollar today, reaching 254.90 yen to the dollar before rising slightly to close at 254.60.

title: KASLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SUDAN BLAMES ETHIOPIA FOR THE AIRLIFT TO ISRAEL
description: A Sudanese statement issued here today accused Ethiopia of trading its Jews for Israeli arms and money.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: A AS IN ARCHIVES

title: SOVIET SCIENTIFIC PAPER CALLS U.S. SPACE-BASED DEFENSE VULNERABLE
description: A Soviet scientific report says that the space-based defense system proposed by President Reagan would disturb the strategic balance, set off a chain reaction of countermeasures and ultimately make nuclear war more possible.

title: General Dynamics Wins Navy Deal
description: The United States Navy would buy 14 F-16 jet fighters from the General Dynamics Corporation, the Pentagon said today. The planes would be used as ''enemy'' fighters in pilot training.

title: Price Tactics By British Oil
description: The British National Oil Corporation has sold at spot-market-related prices virtually all of the 800,000 barrels a day of crude oil that it has available for January delivery, oil industry sources said today.

title: Burlington Road Plans Offering
description: Burlington Northern Inc. announced yesterday that one day this week it would offer $50 million of equipment trust certificates, due serially from Jan. 15, 1986, to Jan. 15, 2000.

title: Area Code Split Nearly Done
description: Dividing the city into two area codes was more than 71 percent complete yesterday and will be finished tomorrow, a New York Telephone company spokesman said yesterday.

title: Citicorp Offering Of London Notes
description: Citicorp Person-to-Person Inc., a personal finance subsidiary of Citicorp Inc. that offers first and second mortgages, issued $250 million of 12- year floating-rate notes in London.

title: Switzer a Target
description: So now they're even. Much of Utah was angry after Oklahoma's football coach,

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Gulf States Utilities Co. , Beaumont, Tex., has promoted E. Linn Draper Jr. to executive vice president, external affairs and production.

title: Salvadorans Uncertain On Who Shot Official
description: Salvadoran officials said today that they were uncertain about the exact circumstances surrounding the assassination of the Government's chief corruption investigator Sunday.

title: EXCHANGE PROGRAMS AS A PLACE TO START
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS ;    Common Stock
NEWBERRY MEDAL AWARDED FOR BEST CHILDREN'S BOOK
description: The John Newbery Medal for the outstanding children's book of the year was awarded yesterday to Robin McKinley, author of ''The Hero and the Crown'' (Greenwillow Books). The Randolph Caldecott Medal, honoring the year's most distinguished American picture book for children, was awarded to Trina Schart Hyman, illustrator of ''Saint George and the Dragon'' as retold by Margaret Hodges (Little, Brown).

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 8, 1985 International

title: RESIGNATION OF COMPTROLLER SEEN
description: The Comptroller of the Currency, C. Todd Conover, is expected to announce his resignation on Tuesday, according to Administration officials, opening the way to the complete replacement of three-member Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation board, which includes the Comptroller.

title: Chief Executive Named By Allegheny Power
description: Allegheny Power System Inc., an electric utility holding company, has named Klaus Bergman, its executive vice president, as president and chief executive effective April 1.

title: CONDUCTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $80,000 for the quarter and $605,000 for the year. c-After a nonrecurring charge of $2,003,000 from the writedown of certain assets.

title: Fire Destroys Clubhouse At Resort in Poconos
description: A fire over the weekend destroyed a clubhouse at the Tanglwood resort in this community in the Pocono Mountains, fire officials said.

title: N.B.A. Salaries Ride Gamut
description: Salaries in the National Basketball Association range from $60,000 to $2.5 million but often are not comparable to how a player performs, according to a published report.

title: German Payments Gap
description: West Germany's balance of payments deficit narrowed in November to 220 million marks, or about $69.3 million, from 818 million marks in October, the Bundesbank said today. West Germany's total balance of payments deficit from January through November last year widened to 2.17 billion marks, or $683 million, from 1.44 billion marks in the period a year earlier, the Bundesbank said.

title: STRANGE, SCROLL-LIKE WAVE IS LINKED TO BIOLOGICAL PROCESSES
description: A STRANGE class of waves that unrolls as paper does from a scroll appears to have a key function in many biological processes, from heart attacks to the behavior of social amoebas and attacks of epilepsy, according to a recent analysis by researchers at Purdue University. Some physicists suspect that they may also control the behavior of subatomic particles.

title: HELP WANTED, TEMPORARILY
description: NORTH BERGEN, N.J.

title: ADOLFO'S SPRING COLLECTION: FITTED, LIVELY AND COLORFUL
description: For women attending a fashion show, the friendly thing to do is to wear a style by the designer whose clothes are being presented. Almost every woman at an Adolfo opening feels that the designer is a close friend. This is one reason why the number of women wearing Adolfo clothes at his shows is higher than at any other designer's opening. Another is that they trust him implicitly.

title: MCENROE, FAVORED, IS STILL LAMENTING
description: He drummed the table nervously with his fingers and often looked down when he spoke, as if trying to see his chin. Commenting as he was on perceived injustices in professional tennis, such as too many tournaments and the pressure placed on the top players to enter most of them, the expression on John McEnroe's face suggested he was suffering from an upset stomach. His tone was the familiar McEnroe lament.

title: PUBLICIZED VIOLENCE TIED TO HOMICIDE RATE
description: WIDELY publicized news accounts in which violence is rewarded - for example, a championship boxing match - are followed by a brief but significant rise in the national homicide rate, according to a report in the current issue of The Journal of Communication.

title: Wrong He Says
description: Washingtonians often see their city on film, and they are quick to praise accuracy and to criticize mistakes in depictions of life in the capital. Many officials, for example, feel that the zingers aimed at the State Department are on the mark in the movie ''Protocol.''

title: THE STAGE: YUL BRYNNER IN 'THE KING AN I'
description: the longest-running theatrical star turn of our time - can no longer be regarded as a feat of acting or even endurance. After 30-odd years of on-and-off barnstorming in the Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d classic, Mr. Brynner is, quite simply, The King. Man and role have long since merged into a fixed image that is as much a part of our collective consciousness as the Statue of Liberty. One doesn't go to Mr. Brynner's ''farewell engagement'' at the Broadway to search for any fresh interpretive angles - heaven forbid! One goes to bow.

title: BRIEFS
4 in Family Slain; Father Is Charged
description: A 42- year-old man was charged today with killing his wife, daughter and two adopted children at their home in this suburb of Rochester.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday with a picture of the ice rink at Rockefeller Center misidentified the skaters. They were Brooks and Joanne Jones with their niece, Julie Karlson.

title: Topics This Old House
description: Poison Peelings

title: Ingersoll-Rand
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company said that it had mutally agreed with SPS Technologies Inc. to cease negotiations on the sale of the Ingersoll-Rand Tool Group.

title: HUMAN-RIGHTS PROBLEM IN CAMBODIA
description: To the Editor:

title: Smith Burke & Little Agency Set for Atlanta
description: Thomas Little, co-founder in 1969 of McDonald & Little in Atlanta, is returning to that city from Baltimore to open up a new shop.

title: CLUBS OFFER ADVICE, SOLACE
description: It was ''Dear Abby'' - high-tech style. Members of the I.B.M. Personal Computer club of New York stood up, one after another, to relate their latest tribulation with the desktop machine. Other club members, many with years in the computer field, offered advice and solace.

title: Equity Group Bids To Acquire Easco
description: The Easco Corporation said it had received an unsolicited takeover offer from Equity Group Holdings for $18.50 a share.

title: BECK AND BROOKS IN ARGUMENT
description: The Rangers, finally showing signs that they can overcome their mounting injuries and piece the season back together, were confronted today with more turmoil. Coach Herb Brooks and Barry Beck, the team's captain, engaged in a loud argument at the outset of practice this morning, according to Beck and several other Rangers.

title: ST. JOHN'S TRIUMPHS AS MULLIN GETS 20
description: Chris Mullin's cold streak came to a resounding end last night, and Villanova was the victim of the thaw as St. John's came from behind to defeat the Wildcats, 76-71.

title: Price-Fixing Complaint Names 6 Title Insurers
description: The Federal Trade Commission staff filed price-fixing charges today against six major title insurance companies that it said accounted for half of the industry's business in 1983 and more than $900 million in premiums.

title: INAUGURATION ANTICIPATION: IT'S WILD
description: It's almost inaugural time, so this city is going into its quadrennial frenzy.

title: JOSEPH A. MAYNARD
description: Joseph A. Maynard, a former advertising executive, died Friday of a heart attack near his home in Gloucester, Mass.

title: No 'Common Ground' For Kennedy in Pretoria
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy met with Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa for an hour today to discuss apartheid, but they were unable to reach ''common ground.''

title: Swedish Profit Forecast
description: Swedish corporate earnings will continue to rise in 1985, but at a slower pace than in 1984, executives at leading publicly traded companies predicted. The daily newspaper Svenksa Dagbladet said today that its survey had found that nearly half of the executives at 70 major industrial companies expect pretax profits to rise at least 10 percent in 1985.

title: Washington Traded
description: U. L. Washington, the Kansas City Royals' starting shortstop from 1979 until last year, was traded to the Montreal Expos yesterday for two minor leaguers. Washington, age 31, won the starting job midway through the 1979 season, then batted .273 as the Royals won the American League pennant the next year.

title: JOHN BIRCH SOCIETY'S FOUNDER
description: Robert H. W. Welch Jr., the founder and patriarch of the John Birch Society, died Sunday at the Winchester Nursing Home in Winchester, Mass. He was 85 years old and had been in poor health since suffering a stroke in 1983.

title: SEEING CABALS EVERYWHERE
description: There is nothing like a snoot-full of

title: HEART DISEASE: BIG STUDY PRODUCES NEW DATA
description: FRAMINGHAM, Mass. A MAN in his early 40's in this quiet New England town stands one chance in eight of developing heart disease within 14 years. For a man in his late 40's, the risk is one in six. And for a man in his early 50's, one in five.

title: GOOD LEADERSHIP IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON WHEN Sid Smith became headmaster of English High School here last year, it was a job few administrators coveted.

title: B.Y.U. vs. Who?
description: Brigham Young University, voted No. 1 in the final wire service college football rankings, will meet either Boston College, Army, Ohio State, Maryland or Notre Dame in the third annual Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands Aug. 27, according to a source close to the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.

title: The Key to Those Clubs
description: IN the early 70's, Los Angeles

title: TAX PLAN REVISIONS WORKED ON
description: The tax proposal that President Reagan intends to outline in his State of the Union Message next month is likely to differ in several important respects from the plan presented by the Treasury Department last fall, according to Administration officials.

title: MOTHER TERESA PRAISES ETHIOPIAN REFUGEE PLAN
description: Mother Teresa, founder of the Missionaries of Charity, praised the Ethiopian Government today for making ''a very good beginning'' in its effort to resettle victims of the famine that has stricken much of the African continent.

title:
WAHT AMERICA SHOULD DO AFTER THE GENEVA TALKS;

MOVE TOWARD A TEST BAN
description: The arms control talks in Geneva provide the first major news story of 1985. What are the prospects that the news will be happy? Not very good. At best, the Shultz-Gromyko meeting is only the first in a long series of discussions about holding future talks.

title: Boise Cascade's European Sale
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation issued $50 million of seven-year callable Eurobonds in London yesterday.

title: LTV Steel Venture
description: The LTV Steel Company and Sumitomo Metal Industries Ltd. said they had agreed on a previously announced plan for a partnership to produce rust-resistant steel at LTV's Cleveland works. LTV Steel, a unit of the LTV Corporation, and Sumitomo, Japan's third-largest steel maker, plan an electrogalvanizing line that would cost more than $125 million.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Holiday Inns Repurchase Plan
description: Saying ''we think it's a good investment,'' Holiday Inns Inc. announced yesterday that it might buy back up to 10 million of its 35 million shares at a price between $46 and $49 each.

title: VISIONTECH reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because this was the company's first year of operations.

title: VIETNAMESE ATTACK CAMBODIA CAMP
description: A force of 4,000 Vietnamese soldiers backed by tanks and artillery attacked the headquarters camp of the largest Cambodian rebel group today, according to the guerrillas and Thai Army officers.

title: Slalom Canceled
description: A World Cup men's slalom, already moved from Spain to France because of lack of snow, was canceled today because of too much snow at this Pyrenees resort. By race time, visibility was almost nil on the course. No decision had been made on when the race would be held.

title: Swiss Post for Reagan Aide
description: Faith Ryan Whittlesey, the highest-ranking woman on President Reagan's staff, will leave the White House to return to her post as Ambassador to Switzerland, officials said today. Mrs. Whittlesey, 45 years old, has served since March 1983 as director of public liaison, responsibile for maintaining contact with women, minorities, labor, religious and other constituent groups.

title: Rozier's Plans
description: Mike Rozier , the Heisman Trophy winning running back, will announce today his plans for his immediate future in pro football, his agent said yesterday.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   For the Love of Music At Merkin Concert Hall
description: For the Love of Music listed only two artist members in its program of chamber music at Merkin Concert Hall Sunday afternoon. That the other three players were guests may explain something about the nature and the quality of the proceedings.

title: REPORT BY ISRAELI SUPPPORTS SHARON
description: A Federal judge obtained a report yesterday that contradicts a key section of a Time magazine article on Ariel Sharon.

title: MERLE HAAS, BABAR TRANSLATOR
description: Merle S. Haas, known to three generations of children for her translation from French to English of dozens of Babar books, the beguiling stories of the debonair elephant, died of pneumonia yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88 years old.

title: HALLEY'S COMET TO PASS JUPITER
description: Halley's comet will cross the orbit of Jupiter on Thursday, but it will not be visible through most optical telescopes until early this fall.

title: CUOMO WILL EMPHASIZE ENVIRONMENT
description: Governor Cuomo will make the environment a priority in this year's legislative session, calling for increases in hiring and spending to enforce environmental regulations, aides to the Governor said today.

title: Boston College Gets Lambert EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.,
description: Boston College,

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST CASES CITE PLIGHT OF THE HOMELESS
description: The glaring visibility of New York City's homeless citizens and street people in contrast to the comfort and luxury enjoyed by many of their immediate neighbors is often cited by contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund as the inspiration for their gifts.

title: A Portrait of Mitchell
description: Former Attorney General John

title: U.S. Unworried Over Jordan
description: Alan Romberg, a State Department spokesman, said today that Jordan's purchase of air defense equipment from the Soviet Union ''does not appear to represent any fundamental change in Jordan's traditional defense procurement practices.'' Reports from Amman said the purchase was believed to involve shoulder-held ground- to-air missiles.

title: Cards Eyeing Move
description: The owner of the St. Louis Cardinals football team,

title: GRUNTAL FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income. Year-ago share earnings are on a pro-forma basis because the company went public in December 1983.

title: 50TH-BIRTHDAY TRIBUTES TO PRESLEY
description: ELVIS PRESLEY would have been 50 years old today and the occasion has inspired a number of specially packaged tributes, some of them being marketed by the Elvis Presley Estate. By far the best is ''Elvis: One Night With You,'' an RCA Video/ Presley Estate production that can be seen on pay-cable's Home Box Office this evening at 8.

title: GTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
description: b-Net loss.

title: INAUGURAL ROLES OPEN FOR ALL-NONUNION CAST
description: The committee planning President Reagan's inaugural is looking for 200 ''attractive, clean-cut, all-American'' actors who do not belong to a union. It wants them to rehearse for four days and entertain for four days. It will pay their expenses, but no more.

title: Quartet Plans Concert
description: A concert by the American String Quartet on Jan. 29 at 8 P.M. will open a three-concert series sponsored by the Peabody Conservatory of Music at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

title: Levi Strauss Net Off 96.9%
description: Levi Strauss & Company yesterday reported that its net income for the fourth quarter plunged 96.9 percent, to $1.6 million, or 5 cents a share, from $51.6 million, or $1.22 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: HIGH COURT WILL DECIDE REGIONAL BANKING CASE
description: The Supreme Court, accepting a case that could affect the course of interstate banking mergers throughout the country, today agreed to hear a challenge to the regional banking zone that Connecticut and Massachusetts set up to prevent banks from outside New England from merging with local banks.

title: Church Dissidents Given 30 Days for Contempt
description: Four supporters of a dissident minister, saying they would not give up their freedom of religion, refused today to promise not to disrupt church services and were sentenced to 30 days in jail.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Official at Hewlett Joins Convergent
description: Convergent Technologies Inc., the beleaguered electronics company, announced yesterday that Paul C. Ely Jr., executive vice president at the Hewlett-Packard Company, would become its president and chief executive officer, effective immediately.

title: Sanford in the Running
description: Political associates of Terry Sanford, the former Governor of

title: U.S.-SOVIET MISSION IN SPACE IS SOUGHT
description: The United States is prepared to make a high-level overture to the Soviet Union for a simulated space rescue in which American and Russian astronauts would transfer between spacecraft.

title: 'Listening Room' Gala
description: Emanuel Ax, Jaime Laredo and the Juilliard String Quartet are among performers appearing in a free concert today at 10 A.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. The two-hour concert marks the 15th anniversary of the radio program ''The Listening Room,'' heard on WQXR-FM (96.3) and AM (1560); Robert Sherman, host of the show, will also be at the concert. Tickets to the concert will be distributed beginning at 9.

title: What Law Requires For Tenant Security
description: The city now requires landlords to install various protective devices in apartments, including peepholes, locks and chain guards on doors and mirrors in self-service elevators.

title: SPREAD OF DESERTS SEEN AS A CATASTROPHE UNDERLYING FAMINE
description: The famine now coursing through Africa poses an immediate crisis of vast proportions. But underlying today's tragedy is a more deep- seated problem that threatens the future of arid lands throughout the world.

title: Storage Corp. Lays Off 1,000 LOUISVILLE, Colo., Jan. 7
description: Another 1,000 to 1,200

title: POLL SHOWS SKEPTICISM ON ARMS PACT
description: As talks begin in Geneva, the American public is deeply skeptical that President Reagan will achieve an arms agreement with the Soviet Union during his second term, although it backs his handling of relations with Moscow and voices confidence that he wants an agreement, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News survey.

title: SUIT AGAINST CBS REJECTED
description: The Supreme Court rejected today without comment an appeal from a conservative Washington research organization to consider whether CBS News was biased in a 1981 five-part series called ''The Defense of the United States.''

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Salomon Deal Offers U.S. Notes for Marks
description: Salomon Brothers, an innovator in marketing Government securities, announced yesterday a novel Euromarket offering of warrants. Under the terms of the deal, 400,000 warrants exercisable into 10-year Treasury notes were offered at a fixed price in West German marks.

title: Key Rates
IRA KLEIN WORKED ON OTHER NETWORK PROJECTS
description: Ira Klein, the film editor who testified yesterday for Gen. William C. Westmoreland, is a 33-year-old New Yorker who has worked as a freelance editor since leaving CBS News in 1983.

title: ITT Contracts
description: The ITT Corporation said that the Air Force had renewed two contracts, valued at about $418 million, with Felec Services Inc., a subsidiary of ITT's Federal Electric Corporation.

title: AT CBS TRIAL, FILM EDITOR CITES HIS COMPLAINTS CONCERNING DOCUMENTARY
description: General Westmoreland, who commanded American forces in Vietnam from 1964 to 1968, contends that CBS defamed him by saying he had deceived President Johnson and the Joint Chiefs of Staff about the true size and nature of North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces in the year before the Tet offensive of January 1968. Mr. Klein said yesterday that that was indeed the premise of the program.

title: Flutie Getting Better Coverage
description: Since winning the Heisman Trophy, Doug Flutie has become so preoccupied with activities both on and off the football field that he didn't even realize he had injury insurance covering him in the Hula Bowl all-star game last Saturday.

title: IT'S DAY ONE IN GENEVA: JOKES AND NO COMMENT
description: At the end of seven hours of talks today between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, a notice was chalked on the blackboard at the overflowing American press center here: ''Official: No Briefing.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Tallahassee, Fla., on Dec. 2 about a Florida tax on multinational corporations incorrectly described the accounting method used to calculate it. The method examines a corporation's operations within a taxing state, comparing them with its global operations to determine what fraction of its profits were earned in the state.

title: Bridge:A Grand National Semifinal Proves Exceptionally Close
description: One of the semifinal matches in the Grand National Team Championship, played Sunday at the Cavendish Club, was among the closest ever played on such an occasion: after each quarter the score was in single figures.

title: Dow Up 5.63 in First Advance of '85
description: The stock market notched its first advance of the new year yesterday, after three successive declining sessions.

title: HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including gains of $11,000 for the qurater and $280,000 for the 6 months from equity in earnings of Raymark Corp. and a gain of $4,524,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of Raymark stock. c-After losses of $337,000 for the quarter and $1,339,000 for the 6 months from the spinoff of pressure piping components unit and gains of $208,000 for the quarter and $508,000 for the 6 months from equity in earnings of Raymark Corp.

title: BARRETT RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Including a tax credit of $100,000. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Prices Rise in Greece
description: Consumer prices in Greece rose 1.1 percent in November from October and were up 18 percent from a year earlier, the Government reported today.

title: CLAIBORNE SHOWS FALL SEPARATES
description: The first fashion collection for fall 1985 to make its official debut on Seventh Avenue was that of Liz Claiborne.

title: Western Union Cut
description: About 8,000 unionized employees of the Western Union Corporation have agreed to a six-month, 10 percent pay cut to help the financially troubled communications concern, officials said today.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: AS NEW SHOPS REPLACE THE OLD IN BROOKLYN HEIGHTS, BOOKSELLER FIGHTS BACK
description: With its creaking floors and curving iron staircase, the Community Book Store of Brooklyn Heights seems an unlikely flash point for a citywide conflict.

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION PLAN OF NEW YORK STANDS
description: Over three vigorous dissents, the Supreme Court today turned down a challenge to a decision by New York State to raise the scores of black and Hispanic prison officers who took a test for promotion to captain.

title: Woman Killed by Truck
description: An unidentified woman was killed by a tractor-trailer yesterday that hit her as she crossed West 58th Street at Eighth Avenue, the police said. The truck, described as having a silver trailer and dark cab, did not stop. The woman was said to be in her 50's.

title: New Signs of the Subways
description: Across from the token booth on the upper level of the subway station at Lexington Avenue and 68th Street, a group of passengers sat comfortably, their eyes raised to a red electronic sign. On it flashed messages:

title: A GLANCE BACK TO 1984
description: ONE week into the new year it would be foolhardy to predict how education will fare in 1985, but a look back on the best and the worst events of 1984 may at least suggest some possibilities of how to do better - or worse.

title: KEAN PROPOSING A $450 MILLION FUND FOR ENVIRONMENT
description: Governor Kean will ask the New Jersey Legislature on Tuesday to create a $450 million trust fund to meet the state's growing waste- treatment problems.

title: A New Paper Plane Contest
description: promotions of the late 1960's is

title: 4 Extradited Colombians Are Held Without Bond
description: Four Colombians who were secretly extradited to the United States were ordered held without bond today on Federal charges of participating in a scheme to smuggle drugs and launder money.

title: Dominion Wins
description: Medina Dixon fired in 27 points to lead undefeated and top-ranked Old Dominion to an 84-71 victory tonight over Long Beach State, rated No. 2. The victory improved Old Dominion's record to 13-0. Cindy Brown paced Long Beach State (8-1) with 25 points.

title: REAGAN AND BUSH ARE RE-ELECTED IN A LANDSLIDE, 525 VOTES TO 13
description: President Reagan won re-election by a landslide today in an anticlimax required by the Constitution: the counting of the 538 Electoral College ballots at a joint session of Congress.

title: ;   WHAT AMERICA SHOULD DO AFTER THE GENEVA TALKS
description: MATCH MOSCOW'S POWER

title: GENE-ALTERED PESTICIDE READIED FOR FIELD TEST
description: THE Monsanto Company plans to field test the first genetically engineered experimental pesticide this spring.

title: Smoking Ban Due on Trains
description: Smoking will be forbidden in commuter trains and on platforms beginning Jan. 20, the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority announced today.

title: No Headline
description: John Zaccaro's Plea John Zaccaro explained his plea of guilt to real estate fraud by blaming at least some of his legal troubles on the fame of his wife, former Representative Geraldine Ferraro. He said he hoped the plea would end ''the inquiries and the microscopic attention given to my personal and business affairs since July,'' when she became the Democratic candidate for Vice President, and that he chose not to defend himself against the indictment so as to spare his family any further notoriety.

title: NEW GOVERNOR SEEKS GOALS BY BUILDING COALITIONS
description: While Norman H. Bangerter, the new Governer of Utah, a Republican, was attending a national governors' conference in South Carolina shortly after his election victory, the incumbent Governor, Scott M. Matheson, a Democrat, invited him to sit in on discussions for the state budget that would come into effect when Mr. Bangerter took office. Under law Mr. Matheson was required to draw up the budget by the end of 1984.

title: Federated Stores Issues Eurobonds
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. issued $100 million of five-year Eurobonds in its first offering of such securities.

title: FRANCE OFFERS LIMITED INDEPENDENCE TO PACIFIC ISLE
description: France offered a form of limited independence today to its strife-torn Pacific territory of New Caledonia.

title: BLUE RIDGE REAL ESTATE CO/BIG BOULDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JUDGE GIVES FINAL APPROVAL TO ACCORD ON AGENT ORANGE
description: A Federal judge gave his final approval yesterday to the settlement under which seven manufacturers of Agent Orange had created a $180 million fund for Vietnam War veterans and their families who contend that the herbicide harmed them.

title: TALK IS BETTER THAN 'STAR WARS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bruins Top Kings
description: Charlie Simmer scored at 4 minutes 21 seconds of overtime tonight to give the Boston Bruins a 5-4 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: SETTING ASIDE URANIUM PACT
description: ONCE again, uranium is making lawyers glow. An extraordinary arbitration has concluded by setting aside a long-term supply contract for uranium, in part because the price collapsed soon after the contract was made. The case raises troubling questions on the frontiers of contract law: in particular, whether courts should set aside long-term contracts because of dramatic price changes in the market.

title: PHIL DONAHUE, NOW FROM NEW YORK
description: PHIL DONAHUE did his first show from New York yesterday, and it was clear the move from Chicago had not changed him. Mr. Donahue, as always, was a caution, the liveliest television host around. He bullied, soothed and cajoled. In fact, he's awfully good at what he does, but how one wishes he didn't work quite so hard doing it. He's still not interviewing other people; he's still interviewing himself.

title: SHAMROCK VULNERABILITY CITED
description: The sudden termination late yesterday of an agreement in which the Diamond Shamrock Corporation would have merged with the far larger Occidental Petroleum Corporation sent shock waves through the oil industry.

title: FRAUD CHARGED IN ELECTION OF HOSPITAL WORKERS' CHIEF
description: A former vice president of the New York hospital workers union has charged that there was fraud, in which he participated, in the 1984 union election in which Doris Turner won a second term as president.

title: Decision on Westway Is Postponed 2 Weeks
description: A decision by the Army Corps of Engineers on whether to recommend a landfill permit for the Westway project has been postponed for two weeks at the request of Federal environmental officials.

title: ;   HIS NAME, HER NAME AND THE LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: West Virginia Upheld By The Associated Press Commissioner
description: Charlie Theokas of the Atlantic 10 Conference ruled

title: Barna Kiss, Who Aided Jews During Holocaust, Dies at 72
description: Barna Kiss, a former Hungarian Army officer who was honored by Israel for saving Hungarian Jews from the Holocaust during World War II, died of cancer last Thursday at the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center in New Hyde Park, L.I. He was 72 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday in SportsMonday about Mary Decker's return to competition this month misidentified the 1980 track and field meet at which she set a world indoor record in the 1,500-meter run. It was the Wanamaker Millrose Games.

title: People Express Phone Shift
description: People Express Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it was opening a $3 million reservations center in Jacksonville, Fla., that would eventually result in the phasing out of 1,200 jobs held by college students at its center at Newark International Airport.

title: CLARK, J L MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
100 Policemen Surround Seoul Dissident's House
description: More than 100 police officers surrounded the home of a leading South Korean dissident for three hours today but withdrew, his aides said.

title: INAUGURATION READING
description: Political Art Documentation/Distribution and the Basement Workshop in Chinatown, at 22 Catherine Street, between East Broadway and Henry Street, will sponsor an evening of performances and readings on Jan. 15 related to the Presidential Inauguration and the Presidential term. Artists and poets schedule to appear are Margo Lee, Blaise Tobia, Gina Wendkos, Fay Chiang, Nigel Gibson, Jason Hwang, Teru Kanazawa and Virginia Scott.

title: WALL STREET STUNNED AS SHAMROCK CANCELS GIANT OCCIDENTAL MERGER
description: In a move that stunned Wall Street, the Diamond Shamrock Corporation of Texas, one of the nation's lesser-known oil companies, yesterday called off a $3.3 billion merger with the Occidental Petroleum Company only hours after the companies' managements had agreed on the deal.

title: BIRD SETS PACE FOR CELTICS
description: It took Larry Bird the entire first half before he unleashed his usual scoring fury against the Knicks. But once he did, it made it easier for the Boston Celtics to defeat the Knicks for the fourth straight time this season, 108-97.

title: JOE RAUH: 50 YEARS, AND COUNTING, OF CAUSES
description: Fifty years ago, Joseph L. Rauh Jr. came to Washington to, in his words, ''work for the New Deal.'' He has been doing it ever since.

title: NEW TYPING TUTOR PROVES EASY TO USE
description: BUYING a computer in order to learn how to type does not make much sense. On the other hand, owning a computer and not learning how to touch- type makes even less sense in most cases, which probably explains the popularity of the various typing-skills software on the market.

title: Eastern Union In Court Plea
description: Eastern Airlines' largest union today asked for a Federal court

title: U.S.-SOVIET PARLEY ON ARMS CONTROL BEGINS IN GENEVA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko opened the first significant Soviet-American arms talks in 13 months today.

title: Senate Panel Criticizes C.I.A. On Supervision in Nicaragua
description: The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence criticized the Central Intelligence Agency today for ''inadequate supervision and management'' of covert operations in Nicaragua, including the mining of harbors.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Cleveland Cavaliers at Richfield, Ohio, 7:30 P.M. The Nets blew out the Cavaliers, 131-106, in the last game between these team. (Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.)

title: DOLPHINS' SECRET WEAPON
description: MIAMI

title: SHAMROCK PLUNGES IN 3D MARKET
description: News late yesterday afternoon that the planned merger of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation and the Occidental Petroleum Company had been called off sent the shares of Diamond Shamrock plunging in third-market trading on the West Coast.

title: DRUG USE IN HIGH SCHOOLS DOWN
description: The Federal Government's annual survey of drug abuse among high school seniors, released today, indicates a small decline in the use of drugs over all, but a slight increase in the use of cocaine.

title: COINS FROM SEA MIGHT SOLVE A PIRATE MYSTERY
description: State marine archeology officials are divided over whether thousands of gold and silver coins recovered by a treasure hunter are from the pirate ship Whidah, which wrecked off Cape Cod in 1717.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: EVERYONE who headed south

title: Wilhelm Meets Brock at Last
description: They faced each other over a cluster of microphones

title: Suit at Denny's
description: Denny's Inc. said a shareholder had filed a suit challenging a proposed leveraged buyout of the company by Denny's management, Merrill Lynch & Company and various other financial institutions.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Nuggets, at Denver This is the first stop on a three-game Knick trip. When they played the Nuggets in their only other meeting this season, at Madison Square Garden Dec. 4, the Knicks won, 100-98, on a jump shot by Darrell Walker with three seconds to go. It was only the second time this season that the Nuggets had been held under 100 points. The Knicks' next two games are in Chicago Friday night and in Indianapolis Saturday night. (Television - Channel 9, 9:30 P.M.)

title: QUICK & REILLY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Central Soya Picks Ex-Beatrice Leader
description: Donald P. Eckrich, a director of the Central Soya Company, yesterday was named the company's president and chief executive officer.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Jan. 9, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: CARROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a gain of $348,000 for the quarter and 6 months primarily from the sale of eight Burger King Restaurants. Results for the latest periods reflect an additional 1.5 million shares outstanding.

title: Thrift Unit Recovery Plan
description: The Financial Corporation of America said today that it intended to cut its total assets by about $5.5 billion, to $24.5 billion, by the end of 1985 as part of a detailed plan to recover from its brush with failure last August.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ALLI SEEKS REPUTATION TO GO WITH TITLE
description: Terrence Alli started on the wrong foot in this country. His name is spelled wrong, the title he holds is the subject of jokes and the one he is going for Saturday is only marginally more serious. But Alli, nee Halley, the ESPN lightweight champion and International Boxing Federation challenger, has come a long way from Guyana, by way of Trinidad and Canada.

title: Soviet Ban on Smoking Extends to Red Square
description: The Moscow city council has decided to ban smoking on Red Square, the city's major tourist attraction, according to an announcement in the evening newspaper Vechernyaya Moskva. The ruling said smoking did not fit the reverent atmosphere appropriate to the burial place of Lenin. Smoking is already banned in movies, theaters and on public transport.

title: Judiciary Committee to Open Hearings on Meese on Jan. 29
description: Hearings on the nomination of the White House counselor Edwin Meese 3d to be Attorney General are scheduled to begin Jan. 29, the Senate Judiciary Committee announced today.

title: MUSIC: SCOTT JOHNSON
description: TO open its music season, by now one of the most prestigious in town, the Dance Theater Workshop on West 19th Street has turned to a composer- performer who has achieved a considerable popularity of his own on the downtown scene, Scott Johnson.

title: Laos Assails Thais at U.N.
description: Laos denounced Thailand today for shelling and attacking two Laotian militia positions near three disputed border villages last week. Laotian militias repelled the attacks last Wednesday and Thursday, the chief Laotian delegate to the United Nations, Kithong Vongsay, told Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar in a letter.

title: WHO'S IN CHARGE?
description: WASHINGTON The one thing you can be fairly

title: LAIDLAW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including an investment gain of $4,344,000.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture appeared erroneously yesterday with a report about whooping cranes in the Science Watch column of Science Times. The bird shown was a great blue heron.

title: BARBARA MANDRELL IN A CBS SPECIAL
description: A SIZABLE chunk of the country singer Barbara Mandrell's first network television special, scheduled for 8:30 tonight on CBS, is given over to testimonials by devoted fans of every stripe commenting on the absolute wonderfulness of the star. ''I think she's as cute as a freckle on a hog's ear in a winter snowstorm,'' effuses one fan. ''She thinks about her fans all the time,'' explains another. ''A Barbara Mandrell special is everything,'' says a female admirer who's almost too choked up to speak.

title: FILM: NAGISA OSHIMA'S 'NIGHT AND FOG IN JAPAN'
description: ''NIGHT AND FOG IN JAPAN,'' which opens today at the Film Forum, is the third of three films that Nagisa Oshima, the Japanese director, then 32, made in 1960 - the others being ''Cruel Story of Youth,'' which had its premiere here last year, and ''The Sun's Burial,'' which has just ended its Film Forum run.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SOUTH AFRICA PROTEST MOUNTS AS CHURCHES ASK CORPORATE PUSH
description: Religious groups and colleges stepped up their protests against South Africa's policies of strict racial separation yesterday in an organized national drive that began in November.

title: ISRAEL TO SKIP NEXT TALKS WITH LEBANON
description: Israel said today that it would not return to the withdrawal talks with Lebanon on Thursday because of what it called Lebanese stalling.

title: Iraq Announces Attacks On Three Cargo Vessels
description: Iraq said its jet fighters attacked three ''naval targets'' today in the Persian Gulf.

title: Break-Dance Contest
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem will sponsor a break-dancing contest, Sunday at 3 P.M. at the company's headquarters, 466 West 152d Street.

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago results include an insurance loss recovery of $794,763 for the quarter and 6 months and tax credits of $365,591 for the quarter and $451,101 for the 6 months.

title: Flyers Win by 5-3
description: Todd Bergen scored two goals in his first National Hockey League game, including the winner, as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated the Vancouver Canucks, 5-3, tonight.

title: Dept. of Paternity
description: When David A. Stockman resigned his House seat after the 1980 election to become President Reagan's chief White House budget officer, he took with him three aides, Donald W. Moran, Frederick N. Khedouri and David B. Gerson. They have since managed to follow the same course as their leader, one small step ahead of him in most cases, with a dedication impressive even to the most loyal Reaganauts.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Charter Federal Savings and Loan Association , Bristol, Va., said it had agreed to acquire First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Danville, Va.

title: Letter: On Time
description: Taking Organization by the Wrist

title: Ratings
Lord, Geller Hires Two From Other Agencies
description: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, one of the JWT Group, has got an infusion of high-priced talent, John Sheedy, 51, and J. William Wardell, 46.

title: TRADING JOBS AT THE TOP: DONALD THOMAS REGAN
description: Donald T. Regan, the loyal Treasury Secretary whom President Reagan made his chief of staff today, has been an enigma through the first four years of the Administration. It has never been clear, as his views on issues have shifted and changed over that period, where he really leans.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE story is reminiscent of a Shakespeare play or a Verdi opera without the music. It starts with two California wine makers, who, after battling for a dozen years over the right to a famous California winery name, have joined against a new group of claimants to the same name.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY WINS MORE LEEWAY IN HIRING OF 1,189
description: New York City's Transit Authority won the right today to hire more than 1,000 supervisors outside the Civil Service process for jobs that will also be outside union jurisdiction.

title: CAVALIERS TURN BACK NETS
description: An asthma attack sidelined the New Jersey Nets' center, Mike Gminski, at the Richfield Coliseum tonight, and caused even more disarray - if that was possible - to the player deployment of Coach Stan Albeck.

title: ABOUT BOSTON
description: There was a snow warning Monday night, and as the city's work force funneled onto the jammed expressways and inched out of Boston under leaden skies, the slow flood of cars caught up a dark Ford station wagon with the Mayor of Boston, Raymond L. Flynn, at the wheel.

title: FORM L.I. MAN ON TRIAL AS A DRAFT RESISTER
description: Jury selection began today in the trial of a former Long Island man who has refused to register for the military draft.

title: A HISTORIC EXCUSE FOR A CLUB
description: For more than a century the Alibi Club has offered some of this city's most prominent men just what its name implies, an excuse to escape into a fraternal world of their own.

title: SAFETY BOARD URGES MANDATORY CHANGES TO COMMUTER PLANE
description: The National Transportation Safety Board recommended yesterday that Bandeirante airliners get further inspections and that structural changes be required in their tail sections.

title: Buildings Wrecked Without Permits
description: Two mid-Manhattan buildings were destroyed Monday night and two others badly damaged by a demolition crew that had no work permits, the city's Buildings Commissioner said yesterday.

title: EWING'S 33 LEAD GEORGETOWN ROUT
description: Perhaps the most poignant thing that can be said about Georgetown's 90-70 rout of Seton Hall tonight is, poor Seton Hall.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Goring Is Acquired by Bruins
description: Butch Goring's days as an Islander ended today when the Boston Bruins, desperately seeking help at center, claimed the 35-year-old veteran for the $2,500 waiver price.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: EVERYBODY'S MAN. A Biography of

title: G.M. CUTS ESTIMATE ON PROFIT SHARING
description: Production workers at the General Motors Corporation, who were told in contract negotiations last summer that they could expect to receive about $1,000 in profit sharing for 1984, will get only about half that amount, company officials said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We can't be sure where these negotiations will lead and, clearly, we have a long road ahead of us.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS BRIEF DETENTIONS
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the police may act without a warrant to stop and briefly detain a person they know is wanted for investigation by a police department in another city.

title: NORTEK MAKES BID FOR UNIDYNAMICS
description: Nortek Inc., an industrial and consumer products manufacturer based in Cranston, R.I., offered $20 a share yesterday, or a total of about $132 million, for all shares of the Unidynamics Corporation.

title: The Answer to Subway Robbers: Cops It's not enough to denounce vigilantism, says Mayor Koch in response to the case of the man who shot four teen-agers on the subway because he feared a mugging. The case also dramatizes the need for criminal justice reforms.
description: That's commendable statesmanship; it's too bad the Mayor follows up with such a diffuse program. It includes some good ideas, like adding criminal court judges and special transit courts. But why such reserved judgment on the Transit Police, the most urgent issue?

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: DESIGNING LETTERS

title: Cyclists Accused Of 'Blood Doping'
description: Some members of the United States cycling team received controversial ''blood doping'' transfusions hours before their Olympic events last summer in Los Angeles, according to a team physician.

title: WHY THE POLICE HAVE HAD TO BUY ADS
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Up 1.11 as Earlier Gains Fade
description: Stock prices, aided by continuing strength in the bond markets at mid- afternoon, finished a bit ahead yesterday in stepped-up trading.

title: Sky Kazoo
description: Passengers on Virgin Atlantic Airways got a little surprise en route from Newark to London. They were entertained (or amused or annoyed, depending on one's taste) by a kazoo player, Barbara Stewart.

title: FISCAL POLICY EXPECTED TO REMAIN UNCHANGED
description: Republican leaders in the Senate said today that they did not expect a change in fiscal policy or an effect on budget deliberations to arise from the job-swapping of James A. Baker 3d, now White House chief of staff, and Donald T. Regan, the Treasury Secretary.

title: JOHNNY GUARNIERI, 67, PIANIST WHO PLAYED WITH BIG BANDS
description: Johnny Guarnieri, one of the leading jazz pianists of the swing era, who played in the bands of both Benny Goodman and Artie Shaw in the early 1940's, died of a heart attack Monday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 67 years old.

title: Baseball Rejects Ranger TV Bid
description: Baseball's club owners showed their wariness on television superstations yesterday when they rejected a bid by the Gaylord Broadcasting Company to buy into the Texas Rangers.

title: Heisman Whodunit
description: The Heisman Trophy that was awarded to the University of Georgia tailback

title: CAMBODIA REBEL UNIT ORDERS PULLOUT FROM ITS MAIN CAMP
description: Cambodian rebels, under heavy attack from Vietnamese artillery and tanks since early Monday, were ordered today to withdraw from their headquarters camp at Ampil, guerrilla spokesmen said.

title: Chief Expects Franklin To Stay in Business
description: Last June, when the Franklin Computer Corporation, beset by a crushing debt and internal disarray, filed for protection under the Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, it looked as if the company would soon be just a memory. But now Morton E. David, its chairman and chief executive officer, says that the small-computer manufacturer intends to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings rather than go out of business.

title: TEAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: POLE IN KILLING TELLS OF HINTS OF TOP-LEVEL BACKING
description: The central figure in a murder trial of secret policemen here portrayed himself today as an inexperienced, reluctant and even squeamish killer who inexplicably beat a pro-Solidarity priest to death after having been enticed into kidnapping the cleric with suggestions of support from ''the top.''

title: Morgan Unit Denied Post
description: The Labor Department has issued a tentative denial of the application by Morgan Stanley Asset Management Inc. to act as manager for a $2 billion stock portfolio of the teamsters' union's Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Pension Fund.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ASIDE from blowing or powdering it from time to time, most people pay little attention to how the nose functions. Such neglect can be their undoing - especially in winter, with its combination of cold dry air, indoor pollutants and respiratory infections.

title: CINTAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Trump Buys the St. Moritz
description: Add another gem to the real-estate

title: A SPENDING FREEZE UNDER G.O.P. STUDY
description: Senate Republicans Wednesday will begin considering a proposal to reduce the Federal deficit by freezing spending across the board and eliminating all cost-of-living increases next year, Congressional sources said today.

title: Nixon Suffering Pain In Shingles Outbreak
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon is suffering ''an awful lot of pain'' because of shingles, an aide said today.

title: New Laurels
description: Two Olympic equestrian stars added to their list of laurels for 1984 yesterday, when they won the Mercedes-Benz Horeseman and Horsewoman of the Year awards at the American Horse Shows Association's convention in Williamsburg, Va. Joe Fargis of Petersburg, Va., a show jumping rider, and Karen Stives of Dover, Mass., a three-day eventer, won the awards, for which any rider, driver or trainer is eligible.

title: FUELING AT SHOREHAM: A GINGERLY OPERATION
description: With a soft whir, a slender triangular boom sliced down through 40 feet of crystal- clear water, its tip manuevered by a crane operator to latch on to the handle atop a 14-foot-long bundle of uranium fuel.

title: APACHES STRIVING FOR SELF-SUFFICIENCY
description: A well-groomed road cuts across the White Mountain Apache Reservation through steep canyons and timbered hills. In the distance rises Mount Baldy, which the White Mountain Apaches regard as the sacred abode of the Gaan, or mountain spirits. Some Apaches still make a yearly pilgrimage to the mountaintop.

title: EIGHT MORE MOVES LEAD TO ANOTHER CHESS DRAW
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov played eight more moves of the adjourned 39th game of their world chess championship match in Moscow before agreeing to a draw yesterday.

title: Prices Drop in Taiwan
description: Consumer prices in Taiwan fell three- hundredths of 1 percent in 1984 from the previous year, the first decline since 1965, the Government said today.

title: Ex-Detective Held In Queens Slaying
description: A 50-year-old retired detective was charged with murder in the Dec. 25 slaying of a Queens woman who was found shot to death in her home, District Attorney John J. Santucci said yesterday.

title: REGAN SAID TO HAVE INITIATED JOB SHIFT WITH BAKER
description: An inquiry by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan provided the spark for his exchange of jobs with James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, White House officials said today.

title: My Wallet 'Tis of Thee
description: The inauguration of a President

title: A BRONX PARTY OPENS NEWEST POLICE PRECINCT
description: The city's newest police precinct - the 49th, in the Morris Park section of the Bronx - opened for business yesterday morning amid a community celebration that kept its new station house bustling for hours.

title: MANDATORY RETIREMENT AT 32 FOR BOXERS, WITH A 40-FIGHT LIMIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Careers;   Engineers And Quest For M.B.A.
description: YOUNG engineers may be taking

title: HOLMES, ALTHOUGH 92, WAS WISE FOR HIS AGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Mother in Killing Case Still Held for Contempt
description: Federal District Judge Carl Bue ruled today that the stepmother of a 17-year-old boy charged with murder must stay in jail because a contempt citation was having the ''desired effect'' of compelling her to testify in the case.

title: Conover Will Leave as Comptroller in Spring
description: C. Todd Conover, the Comptroller of the Currency, said today that he will leave office this spring, but in the meantime he will approve many more applications by banks to operate limited- service offices across state lines.

title: JARRYD, KREIK WIN IN MASTERS
description: In the first match of the Volvo Masters tennis tournament that features the 12 leading players on the world tour, Anders Jarryd and Henrik Sundstrom held what also amounted to an audition for their Davis Cup coach last night. The Swedes are teammates in cup play, but opponents on the Grand Prix tour, in which they are separated by a net and ambition.

title: The Second-Term Swap Cabinet government: it's a notion that, typically, flares up for about 15 minutes after a new President takes office, eager to show that
description: he won't hog power the unhealthy way his predecessor did. But in the United States, cabinet government either means nothing, just empty, romantic platitude, or it means that a President has given up.

title: 2 Surprise Winners In Eclipse Awards
description: A trainer, Jack Van Berg, and a jockey, Pat Day, were the only surprising winners among 10 horses, 5 people and a farm who were voted Eclipse Awards today as champions of thoroughbred racing in 1984.

title: Tower Cuts Fares
description: Tower Air cut its fares on some one- way flights between New York and Los Angeles, to $99, from $119. The $99 fare must be purchased by Jan. 31, and travel must take place Mondays through Thursdays between Jan. 9 and March 31, traditionally a slow season for most airlines.

title: PRESIDENT DESIGNATES REGAN WHITE HOUSE CHIEF OF STAFF, SWITCHING HIM WITH BAKER
description: President Reagan unexpectedly announced today that the White House chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, and the Treasury Secretary, Donald T. Regan, were to switch jobs.

title: Kansas Offers Highway Bonds
description: In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the State of Kansas offered $152.7 million of highway bonds at competitive bid.

title: PRESSURE ON BRITISH OIL PRICING
description: Britain's oil pricing system is under intense pressure, with increasing amounts of its North Sea oil being sold at spot prices instead of at its official price. The weakness of the North Sea oil pricing structure threatens to undermine OPEC's effort to maintain its $29- a-barrel benchmark price for Saudi Arabian Light crude.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET TRADE TALKS
description: A United States delegation began talks with officials of the Soviet Foreign Trade Ministry today, in the highest-level trade contacts in seven years.

title: President Adds Title at Insurer David R. Carpenter, president and chief executive of the
description: Transamerica Occidental Life

title: Baker: On Economics
description: Nov 8, 1981, ''Meet the Press.'' Less than a year after Mr. Reagan took office, the country was sliding into what would become the deepest recession since World War II. Mr. Baker was asked whether the President's economic program was foundering. Admittedly, we see a recession today, but the foundation has been laid to recover from that. I don't think it's fair to ask whether the program is working this early, and I think the vast majority of the American people are willing to give the President a fair period of time to test his program.

title: Freddie Mac Plan Questioned
description: The Office of Management and Budget confirmed today that it had raised questions about the legality of a plan to distribute preferred stock in the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, the quasi-public Government agency, to the nation's savings and loan industry.

title: Prof. Alexis Rannit, 70, Poet And Retired Curator at Yale
description: Prof. Alexis Rannit, an Estonian poet and retired curator of the Slavic and East European collections at the Yale University library, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in New Haven. He was 70 years old.

title: New Computer From Fujitsu
description: Fujitsu Ltd. said today that it had developed a super computer capable of performing one billion operations a second, making it twice as fast as the company's existing fastest model. Fujitsu said the speed, which was measured by the National Aerospace Laboratory of the Science and Technology Agency, would make the new computer, the VP-400, the fastest in the world.

title: DAMAGE TO SHAMROCK CHIEF HELD SEVERE
description: In the aftermath of his withdrawal from a merger with the huge Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Wall Street is saying that William H. Bricker, the chairman of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, has carried his impulsiveness too far.

title: PRINCE LEADS CRITIC'S LIST OF TOP 10
description: CRITICS never seem to agree on the year's best records. That is what makes 10-best lists so interesting, and so much fun: They tell as much about a critic's tastes as they do about the year in pop. With that caveat in mind, here is this critic's list of 1984's top 10 albums and singles and top 5 EP's, listed by title, artist and label. The column will be followed by the top-10 album lists of two colleagues.

title: U.S. COURT UPHOLDS LOWER AUTO BUMPER STANDARD
description: An appeals court today upheld the Reagan Administration's easing of Federal standards on how much protection must be provided by car bumpers.

title: Charges Are Dropped Over Killing of a Cat
description: A judge yesterday dismissed cruelty charges against a state conservation officer who shot to death a neighbor's cat. The officer cited a rarely invoked state law requiring game wardens to use deadly force to prevent cats from hunting protected species.

title: Japan and Soviet Will Limit Whale Catches in Antarctic
description: In the face of mounting pressure from environmentalists, Japan and the Soviet Union have agreed to reduce their catches of minke whales in the Antarctic, but both will still exceed international quotas, officials said today.

title: CBS OPENS LIBEL TRIAL DEFENSE, ASSERTS VIETNAM DOCUMENTARY WAS TRUE
description: Lawyers for CBS yesterday opened their defense of a disputed 1982 documentary on the Vietnam War, saying they would prove both that it was true and that the people who made it believed it was true.

title: Mubarak to Visit Reagan
description: President Reagan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt will confer in Washington on March 12, the White House announced today.

title: STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rozier Eyes Oilers
description: Mike Rozier has bought out the personal-services contract that bound him to the Baltimore Stars of the United States Football League and claimed yesterday he would become a free agent. A representative for Rozier said the former Nebraska star would be able to negotiate with the Houston Oilers of the National Football League or any team in the U.S.F.L. However, the interpretation was challenged by the U.S.F.L. after a news conference was held to announce that the 1983 Heisman Trophy winner had bought out his $3.1 million personal-services contract with the owner of the defunct Pittsburgh Maulers of the U.S.F.L. ''Mike Rozier has not been placed on waivers by the U.S.F.L.,''

title: FRENCH STYLE ENLIVENING NATIVE FOODS OF SOUTHWEST
description: SOME of the most remarkable mixings of food styles I have ever witnessed were demonstrated in my kitchen recently by 30-year-old John Sedlar, chef and part owner of the Saint Est ephe Restaurant in Manhattan Beach, Calif., about 15 miles south of Los Angeles. The ingredients he used were from the American Southwest, but his techniques were solidly anchored in the French tradition.

title: Choosing Up
description: It's natural to choose up teammates in the schoolyards and sandlots, but unheard of to choose a partner at random with half a million dollars at stake. Yet that is precisely what the top women's tennis players will do in the new $500,000 Chrysler women's tennis doubles championship in Carlsbad, Calif., March 1-3.

title: Deputy Postmaster Named
description: Jackie Anderson Strange was named today as Deputy Postmaster General. Postmaster General Paul N. Carlin said he selected Miss Strange because of her performance as regional postmaster general for the Southern region.

title: RESTAURANT SCENES: DINING WITH NOISE OR DINING IN PEACE
description: THE contemporary New York City restaurant scene falls roughly into three categories that have nothing to do with food: the crowded and very noisy, the crowded and audibly bearable, and the roomy and tranquil.

title: Pearson Eyes Return

title: SHUFFLE IN ADMINSTRATION: SIGN OF RESTLESSNESS, RAHTER THAN OF STRATEGY
description: It is restlessness and flagging morale after four years in office, rather than a grand strategy to reshape the Government and its policies, that have suddenly brought a string of changes and a sudden sense of upheaval to the Reagan Administration. Typical of President Reagan's detached style of leadership, top officials say, a string of high-level changes were initiated from below, rather than being ordered by the President himself. Continuity was one of the constant refrains of the Reagan campaign, and Mr. Reagan made a point after his re-election of asking top officials to stay on for his second term.

In the wake of ''The Claw and the Tooth,'' a startlingly candid documentary about African predators, the theater now presents ''The Plague Dogs,'' which is distinguished by its unusually lifelike animation. Its opening scene depicts a Labrador retriever nearly drowning, the victim of a group of wicked vivisectionists, and does so with exceptional vividness. This realism, while impressive, is not an unqualified advantage.

The 49ers allowed the fewest points, 227, and ranked second with 475 points scored.

description: Jan. 31, 1982, ''Face the Nation.'' Responding to a question about how he had urged President Reagan to call for one type of tax increase and then had to go around the country selling another type. So to the extent that the President may have gone against the advice of his advisers on that one, look, I've been chief executive officer of a major company for years. You don't always take the advice of your subordinates. And by the way, that doesn't downgrade your subordinates either; they keep trying. You give the leader, the President, the options. And when he selects that option, then you get behind it because you are a team player.

title: THE I.M.F. AS A PATH FOR ISRAEL
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz wrote Israel's Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, two weeks ago that Israel's austerity program had not gone far enough to warrant the additional $800 million in aid requested for fiscal 1985. If this aid remains uncertain, and Israel's leaders cannot devise a realistic economic program, why is it that no one Penelope Hartland-Thunberg is a fellow in international business at the Georgetown University Center for Strategic and International Studies. Joyce R. Starr is director of the Near East Program there. has considered calling in the International Monetary Fund? In circumstances less dire than those of Israel, other sovereign debtors like Mexico and Brazil - with great hesitation and internal opposition - have sought I.M.F. guidance and aid. The Israeli Government is reluctant to ask for either, but it could be in the country's best interest. Certainly, Israel is in no better shape than Mexico and Brazil were when they requested help. The Israeli inflation rate is well over 400 percent annually; when Mexico and Brazil started negotiations with the fund in 1983, inflation in both countries was near 100 percent. Israel's external debt exceeds $7,000 per capita; in Mexico and Brazil at the height of their crises, the comparable figures were about $1,000 and $700. Most worrisome for Israel are its highly volatile non-Government foreign loans, which amounted to some $7 billion at the close of 1984. The possibility that such lending would not be extended was precisely what triggered the crises in Mexico and Brazil, and it was not until both countries agreed to restructure their economies along lines laid down by the fund that the banks agreed to maintain credits.

title: LIEBERMAN ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SMITHSONIAN'S 'DESK IN THE JUNGLE'
description: CONSIDER the life of a Smithsonian scientist; it is not a bad way to live. The world is his, or her, oyster, with academic pursuits going hand in hand with adventures in far-flung places. We see some of this tonight on ''A Desk in the Jungle,'' the ''Smithsonian World'' special on Channel 13 at 8.

title: AFRICA'S 'UPRIGHT PEOPLE': STILL NO CLEAR ANSWERS
description: The official slogan here proclaims, ''The country or death - we shall conquer.'' And that says something about the style of one of Africa's newest military-led governments, a blend of nationalism tinged with bloodshed and an absolutism that some outsiders call impetuosity, or na"ivete.

title: TRADING JOBS AT THE TOP: James Addison Baker 3D
description: Mr. Baker's statements tend to reflect Administration policy; Mr. Regan often takes the bit in his teeth on economic issues. Page A19.

title: Noel Don Wycliff Appointed To Editorial Board of Times
description: Noel Don Wycliff, a reporter and editor most recently at The Chicago Sun- Times, will join the editorial board of The New York Times next month.

title: American Capital Convertible Notes
description: The American Capital Bond Fund priced $50 million of five-year convertible extendible notes.

title: VENTURE CAPITALISTS WARY OF TAX PLAN
description: To America's entrepreneurs, the Treasury's tax simplification plan threatens to bring to an end the venture capital boom that has kept their cash-hungry businesses well nourished in the last several years.

title: German Jobless Rate
description: Seasonal factors pushed the number of unemployed West German workers to 2.32 million in December, from 2.18 million in November, the Labor Office said today. It said the jobless rate rose to 9.4 percent, from 8.8 percent in November. The agency said the average monthly number of unemployed West Germans rose to a post-World War II high of 2.26 million in 1984.

title: MORE BRITONS TRYING HOLISTIC MEDICINE
description: At the 150th-anniversary dinner of the British Medical Association two years ago the well-fed physicians who settled back for a speech by Prince Charles had a jolt. ''I would suggest that the whole imposing edifice of modern medicine, for all its breathtaking successes is, like the celebrated Tower of Pisa, slightly off balance,'' Charles said, departing from the royal family's policy of avoiding controversy. ''It is frightening how dependent on drugs we are all becoming and how easy it is for doctors to prescribe them as the universal panacea for our ills.''

title: U.S.F.L. Wins Approval
description: The Justice Department told the
