description: TWO years after the completion

title: Bridge:Tri-State Regional to Open NewYorkourney
description: The annual tournament calendar for players in the metropolitan area begins with a tournament that has become increasingly popular, the Tri- State Regional, staged at the Rye Town Hilton in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 9, 1985 International

title: People
ROCKOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TEXT OF THE COMMUNIQUE
description: Following is the official text of a communique issued today by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko:

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Bond Prices Climb In Active Trading
description: Bond prices rose smartly for the second consecutive trading session yesterday, as traders were encouraged by additional signs of further softening in commodity prices. Trading activity, which had been light earlier in the day, picked up by midafternoon, market participants said.

title: NATIONAL GOLD DISTRIBUTORS reports earnings for Year to Sept 25
Washburn's Case Goes to Grand Jury
description: An overflow crowd in Wake County District Court listened today to a 27-minute taped interview in which a North Carolina State University basketball player, Chris Washburn, admitted to the Raleigh police that he had removed stereo equipment from a fellow student's dormitory room without permission.

title: THE INVASION OF THE VCR OWNER
description: ''It's like a disease!'' said Lucy Martin Gianino, surveying the scene in the Tower Video store, filled to overflowing with customers jostling for position at the racks of movie cassettes and waiting in a long line to buy, rent and return them.

title: COMPANY'S BOARD HAD ITS DOUBTS
description: The ruptured merger that stunned Wall Street on Monday left it mystified yesterday.

title: Budget Official Resigns
description: The Office of Management and Budget today announced the resignation of its chief economist, J. Gregory Ballentine, effective at the end of January. Mr. Ballentine joined the budget office in September 1983 after serving at the Treasury Department as a deputy assistant secretary for tax policy.

title: Bronx Leopard Going to Moscow
description: The Bronx Zoo is sending a female snow leopard to the Moscow Zoo and receiving a male in return, continuing a series of exchanges that began with Przewalski horses and Siberian tigers.

title: Squash Foes Set to Meet
description: The rivalry between Mark Talbott, the top North American squash-racquets player, and Jahangir Khan of Pakistan, the world champion, will resume when the $50,000 Fleischmann's world professional championships open today in Toronto.

title: E.E.C. Near Steel Pact
description: The European Economic Community is close to an agreement with 15 trading partners on limiting imports of several steel products to the community, a spokesman said today. The agreements were expected to limit imports to 5.6 million metric tons, about 70 percent of the Common Market's total imports of the products, the spokesman said.

title: IN U.S., DIFFICULT NEGOTIATIONS ARE FORESEEN
description: Former United States Government negotiators and academic specialists in Soviet affairs yesterday greeted the agreement in Geneva to resume arms talks as an encouraging first step. But they also cautioned that agreement on the substantive issues dividing the two superpowers would be slower and much more difficult to achieve.

title: TRADING INCREASES
description: Expectations of lower interest rates helped push stocks strongly ahead yesterday with both prices and volume reaching their best levels of the new year.

title: REALEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including gains of $62,000 for the quarter and $423,000 for the year from tax law changes.

title: MGM-UA HOME ENTERTAINENT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BATTLING AN UNWELCOME IMAGE AS LEAST WONDERFUL U.S. TOWN
description: When Elizabeth Scott told friends last year that she was leaving Chicago for a job with the Detroit Symphony, they were skeptical of the outlook.

title: Chemical's U.N. Business Chemical Bank may not always be completely comfortable with the customers it attracts. In confirming that it
description: holds an account for the Palestine Liberation Organization,

title: C.D. Yields Off a Bit
description: Yields on money market deposit accounts and six-month certificates of deposit dropped modestly for the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported. The Monitor's national index for six-month C.D.'s dropped to 8.68 percent, from 8.77 percent.

title: G.O.P. SENATORS FROM NEW YORK CITY AND L.I. GET NEW POWER
description: Republicans in the State Senate from New York City and its suburbs were given more authority under leadership changes announced today by the Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson.

title: Graham May Leave
description: Michael Graham, a highly regarded freshman last season on Georgetown's national championship basketball team who is sitting out this season because of academic problems, is transferring to the University of the District of Columbia, according to a report by The Associated Press.

title: Honors From Britain
description: The British Ambassador, Sir Oliver Wright, is to present to five

title: Cargill Cancels Wheat Plan
description: Cargill Inc. said today that it had canceled a plan to import nearly one million bushels of wheat from Argentina after the proposal was sharply criticized by American grain organizations.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Mixed Performance for Bonds
description: Bond prices turned in a mixed performance in the credit markets yesterday, with short-term maturities outperforming the long end of the market.

title: No Headline
description: Mr. Cuomo's Precarious Balance With the current year's handsome cash surplus generating demands for New York tax cuts on one side and enhanced social programs on the other, Governor Cuomo stresses the theme of ''balance'' in his annual message. Achieving it is likely to be far trickier then proposing it.

title: Italian Policeman Killed; Red Brigades Claim Role
description: A policeman was shot dead today in a town south of Rome, and a group claiming to be part of the Red Brigades took responsibility.

title: PRATT LIFTS ITS SHARE OF JET CONTRACT
description: The Air Force announced today that the General Electric Company would continue to produce the majority of its combat jet aircraft engines in 1986.

title: Iona Defeats Detroit in Overtime, 87-82
description: Tony Hargraves scored 8 points in overtime to lead Iona to an 87-82 victory over Detroit tonight.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: NEW DIMENSION Last year Patrick Meyers, a playwright in the Circle Repertory Company's stable of talent, reached the heights of Broadway with ''K-2,'' a drama that took place on a mountain peak. Now Mr. Meyers, having conquered space, is taking on time. ''Dysan,'' his new drama that starts previews today at Circle Rep, 99 Seventh Avenue South at West Fourth Street (924-7100), plunges boldly through the ages of man.

title: TACO VIVA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 9
O'NEILL PROPOSES A SALES-TAX CUT STARTING APRIL 1
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill called tonight for a reduction in Connecticut's sales tax to 7 percent from 7.5 percent on April 1, three months earlier than he had previously proposed.

title: F.A.A. TO ORDER CHECKS OF AIRLINER TAIL SECTIONS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday it would order stringent new inspections of the tail sections of any Bandeirante airliners that have not been reinforced as a result of an earlier inspection order.

title: MEDICARE TO PAY HEALTH GROUPS IN ADVANCE
description: The Government approved new regulations today that will allow Medicare to pay in advance for medical care provided by health maintenance organizations, a change expected to bring hundreds of thousands of elderly people into the prepaid health programs.

title: RULE KEEPS COACHES IN PLACE
description: The final results are not clear yet, but judging from early findings the newly legislated coaching box is doing an excellent job of keeping college coaches in their places. A sample survey of six conferences - the Atlantic Coast Conference, the Big East, the Big 8, the Big Ten, the Pac 10 and the Atlantic 10 - reveals that four coaches have been hit with seven technical fouls for venturing beyond the 28-by-3-foot area to which the rules restrict them.

title: INVESTORS BUY STAKE IN PETRO
description: An investment group yesterday said that it had acquired a stake in the Petro-Lewis Corporation, the beleaguered oil and gas production company, and was ''exploring several options,'' including seeking to take it over.

title: JAMES BALDWIN REFLECTS ON 'GO TELL IT' PBS FILM
description: At the start of the final section of James Baldwin's first novel, ''Go Tell It on the Mountain,'' is an epigraph for the 14-year-old protagonist that foreshadows the long, difficult journey that will lead him from his bitter childhood into whatever he makes of his life: ''Then I buckled up my shoes,/And I started.''

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: LUSTROUS wood floors are a beautiful counterpoint for any room, but not if the boards are rough, cracked, split, badly warped or buckled.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Ford and G.E. Units Set Eurobond Offerings
description: Enticed by much lower borrowing costs, American corporations continued to flood the Euromarkets with new debt issues yesterday.

title: Author at Ballet Guild
description: The New York City Ballet Guild will present '' 'Balanchine: A Biography,' A Conversation with Bernard Taper, Author'' on Monday at 6:30 P.M. at the New York State Theater. Mr. Taper will sign copies of his book, on sale at the theater, at the end of the hour-long program, which is open to the public.

title: RECORD NUMBER IN JOBS IN STATE, CITY AND JERSEY
description: Unemployment rates last month in New York City and State and in New Jersey held steady or showed little change from November, while the number of people employed in both states and the city reached record levels, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: SENATORS LIKELY TO BACK TOTAL FREEZE
description: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, said today that Republican committee chairmen and other Senate leaders would probably agree to an across-the-board budget freeze as the centerpiece of their package to reduce the deficit.

title: Unidynamics Chief Sees Shifts Drawing Suitors
description: The Unidynamics Corporation, led by H. Ridgely Bullock, has been quietly transforming itself from a match and vending machine maker into a diversified manufacturer with four main businesses, including strong positions in engineered materials and defense.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Fordham at Columbia, 7:30 P.M. Since he switched from Columbia to Fordham as head coach for the 1978- 79 season, Tom Penders has led his Rams to six straight victories over the Lions. As Columbia coach he was 2-2 against Fordham, winning his last two meetings before switching, but the series is always tight. There have been two 1-point games and two overtime victories for Penders in the last six seasons, all over his former assistant at Columbia, Buddy Mahar, who took over as the Lions' coach when Penders left Morningside Heights for Rose Hill. Mahar is now Penders's assistant again at Fordham. Wayne Szoke took over as Columbia coach this season. (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 7:30 P.M.)

title: WE'RE LOSING IN COMPETITIVENESS TO EAST ASIA
description: To the Editor:

title: RANGERS FALL IN OVERTIME
description: Back and forth they went. The Winnipeg Jets scored twice, then the Rangers twice, then the Jets twice, and then the Rangers scored three goals for their first lead of the game, late in the third period.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF RALEIGH reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: A STATEMENT BY GROMYKO ON THE TALKS
description: Following is the official text of a statement issued today by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, before he left for Moscow:

title: BLACK PLAYER RETURNS AT HOLY CROSS
description: Walter Coates, one of the four black players who walked off the Holy Cross basketball team after a white player punched a black teammate during a Dec. 29 practice session, has returned to the squad, the college announced today.

title: Court Backs Penalty for Late Taxes
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a taxpayer who files a late tax return is liable for a penalty even if the delay was caused by an attorney.

title: Reagan Doesn't Plan To Offer Nixon Post
description: President Reagan said tonight that he had no plans to offer Richard M. Nixon a post in his Administration. He said the former President had never indicated an interest in any such position.

title: A Copper Foil
description: Because there are so many agents in Washington from so many governments with so much to say and so much to hide, there is no end to the high-technology intrigue of bugging, counter-bugging, de-bugging and jamming.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Finance Briefs column of Business Day yesterday misnamed the company that affirmed the senior debt rating of the Montana Power Company. It was Standard & Poor's.

title: DECOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: OSBORNE COMPUTER FORESEES '85 PROFIT
description: The Osborne Computer Corporation of Fremont, Calif., said yesterday that it would complete its court- approved reorganization plan on Jan. 18 and predicted that it would return to profitability this year.

title: EUROPEANS WELCOME GENEVA ARMS-TALKS ACCORD
description: European leaders today welcomed the United States- Soviet agreement to resume negotiations on arms control, but they sought to stress that the road to positive results would be a long one.

title: NUCLEAR DATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: Penthouse Parody Scheduled for April 1
description: Taylor/Shain, the unit of TSM Publishing that previously published parodies of both Cosmopolitan and Playboy, is now threatening to publish a parody of Penthouse as well.

title: GERULAITIS IS BEATEN BY NYSTROM
description: There are times when he is still a golden retriever on the tennis court, his blond, shoulder-length hair flapping as he outruns a ball that most players would watch pass like a train pulling out of a station. But Vitas Gerulaitis is 30 years old now, and he waves goodbye to a few more shots than he once did. He has been on the tour long enough to call his opponent a kid, as he did last night, and to evaluate a new generation of players.

title: CBS JURORS HEAR EX-OFFICERS SAY ENEMY'S STRENGTH WAS DISTORTED
description: Four former military intelligence officers who said they witnessed or participated in the arbitrary reduction of Vietnamese enemy strength estimates in 1967 testified by means of depositions and filmed interviews yesterday at the trial of Gen. William C. Westmoreland's libel suit against CBS.

title: SHARON JURY GETS ISRAELI REPORT REBUTTING ARTICLE
description: A key Israeli report was presented yesterday to a jury as evidence contradicting a Time magazine article about Ariel Sharon.

title: A Stalled IRT Train
description: Veteran subway riders are expected to take a hint by now.

title: Baseball Talks Curtailed Baseball's labor negotiators, meeting for the first time since the
description: basic agreement expired at midnight Dec. 31, encountered a complication yesterday that cut short the meeting and prompted postponement

title: MUSIC: TENNSTEDT AND PHILADELPHIANS
description: KLAUS TENNSTEDT'S program with the Philadelphia Orchestra Tuesday night in Carnegie Hall was at once homogeneous and heterogeneous. Both Bruch's Violin Concerto No. 1 in G minor (Op. 26) and Bruckner's Symphony No. 7 in E come out of the Germanic cultural world of the mid- late 19th century: the concerto was first performed in Koblenz in 1866, the symphony in Leipzig in 1884.

title: DISPUTE OVER 'L.S.D.' APPEARS ENDED
description: A yearlong dispute between the playwright Arthur Miller and a leading experimental theater company that wanted to incorporate material from ''The Crucible'' into a work entitled ''L.S.D.'' appears to have ended with another cancellation of ''L.S.D.''

title: GEORGIAN, ASSERTING INNOCENCE, PUT TO DEATH
description: Maintaining his innocence in the murder of a college student and charging unfair treatment for blacks, Roosevelt Green was executed in Georgia's electric chair this morning as his mother calmly watched.

title: Topics Bumping Along
description: Collision WorkIt's not the job of the judiciary to second-guess technical decisions of regulatory agencies, says a Federal appeals court. It thus refused to overturn a 1982 ruling by the Transportation Department reducing the Government's standard for auto bumpers.

title: PERSERVING, COLLECTING AND DISPLAYING OLD LACE
description: ''IN the last 10 years I've seen a renewed interest in old handmade lace,'' said Julie Collier, head of the textile department at Christie's East. ''Now there's more interest in the late 19th and early 20th centuries - pretty laces, still handmade, that can be used for decorating clothing and linens. Before World War II, there were many lace shops in the city. Then they disappeared, but now we're seeing a return.''

title: UNESCO ENTANGLED IN AN EAST GERMAN'S PLIGHT
description: The Director General of Unesco has accepted a resignation request from an East German employee who has been held in his country since he was charged with treason in 1980, according to Western diplomats here.

title: Hondurans Agree to Pay American in Land Case
description: The Government said today that it would pay an American businessman for land it seized for construction in July 1983 of a United States- funded military base used to train troops from El Salvador.

title: RIGGS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LaFontaine Has Mononucleosi
description: Less than 24 hours after Butch Goring was trimmed from their roster, the Islanders yesterday lost another center, Pat LaFontaine. Goring went to Boston on waivers. LaFontaine went to bed with mononucleosis.

title: SOURCES FOR LACE AND REPAIRS
description: OLD handmade lace can be found

title: MORE VOICES, NOT LESS TO DO, FOR ESTIMATE BOARD
description: To the Editor:

title: TREADWAY WILL LEAVE S.E.C. IN NEXT 90 DAYS
description: James C. Treadway Jr. announced yesterday that he would resign as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission in the next 90 days. He no longer feels fully committed to the five-member commission, he said, but has no new job in sight.

title: TEMPERATURES PLUMMET TO WINTER'S LOWEST
description: A blast of Arctic air plunged the temperature in the New York area to the winter's lowest levels, bringing complaints from thousands of residents without heat, stalling commuters whose cars would not start and sending record numbers of homeless men and women to shelters.

title: Transactions
description: Re-signed Jim Kern, pitcher, and assigned him to Vancouver of Pacific Coast League.

title: WELL-BALANCED MEAL IS MOMENT OF GLORY
description: Four years have passed since Ada

title: G. BARRACLOUGH, 76, HISTORIAN
description: Geoffrey Barraclough, a historian of medieval and contemporary Europe who had distinguished teaching careers in Great Britain and the United States, died Dec. 26 of lung cancer in the village of Burford, England. He was 76 years old and had lived in Great Britain in recent years.

title: ;   TAXES NEVER ENTERED SOLON'S MIND
description: To the Editor:

title: XTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chesebrough Executive Named Del Monte Head
description: Charles J. Chapman, an executive at Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., has been named president and chief operating officer of the Del Monte Corporation, the foods and beverages subsidiary of R.J. Reynolds Industries.

title: FOUR EX-SECRETARIES OF STATE CONFER
description: FOUR former Secretaries of State offer counsel to the Reagan Administration tonight on ''Secretaries of State in Conference - 1985,'' an earnest one-hour discussion on Channel 13 at 10. The counsel is restrained, and so are the former Secretaries. Occasionally, however, passion breaks out.

title: PICK A PRESIDENT FOR '88: ALREADY?
description: On the theory that there are no accidents in politics, only developments, Republicans today pondered the impact that personnel changes in the Reagan Administration will have on the battle for their party's Presidential nomination in 1988.

title: Andrew on Falkland Mission
description: Prince Andrew, who flew helicopter missions in the 1982 Falkland War against Argentina, will return soon to the British islands in the South Atlantic for a five- month tour of duty on naval patrol, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: BARBARA WHITE, FORMER DIPLOMAT
description: Barbara M. White, who in 1973 became the first woman to attain ambassadorial rank in the United Sttes delegation to the United Nations, died of cancer on Dec. 30 at a nursing home in Duxbury, Mass. She was 64 years old and lived in Washington, D.C..

title: POLE ACCUSED OF PRIEST'S MURDER TELLS OF BITTERNESS IN SECRET POLICE
description: A key defendant on trial here for killing an activist priest described the ranks of the secret police today as frustrated, bitter and demoralized because they were prevented from moving against Roman Catholic priests who collaborated with the Solidarity underground.

title: U.S. Studies Steel Imports
description: The Commerce Department said today that it had begun an investigation into whether steel from eight countries was being sold in the United States at less than fair value.

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 16
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in November.

title: Burlington Road Trust Certificates
description: In New York, the Burlington Northern Railroad Company offered $50 million of serial equipment trust certificates, with maturities ranging from Jan. 15, 1986, to Jan. 15, 2000.

title: Easco Rejects Bid By Equity Group
description: The Easco Corporation said that its board had rejected Equity Group Holdings' proposal to acquire Easco for $171.5 million because the offer was inadequate.

title: Stay Tuned
description: In this week's installment of the Dallas Cowboys' ''Danny and Gary Show,'' the restless young quarterback,

title: Maryland Sanitary District Bonds
description: In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the Washington Suburban Sanitary District of Maryland offered $57 million of guaranteed obligation bonds at competitive bid.

title: Mays Studying Investors' Offer
description: J.W. Mays Inc. management has asked shareholders ''to take no action at his time'' in response to a $20 million tender offer for the retailer. A group of investors led by Sol Goldman, a New York real estate investor, has offered $12 a share. Mr. Goldman's group holds about 23 percent of the 2.2 million shares outstanding.

title: A SALES TAX BUT NO INCOME TAX
description: With tax reform being discussed in earnest, it is time to debunk the sanctity of the income tax system, which is the root cause of many financial and social ills. A better alternative is a national sales tax.

title: Bills Retain Coach
description: Kay Stephenson , the Buffalo Bills' second-year coach who appeared to be on the way out after turning in a 2-14 record, the worst in the National Football League, has been retained for another season, according to the club's owner,

title: FREE NEW YEAR'S RIDES ARE GOOD FOR THE CITY
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Richard Ferrante has joined Rumrill-Hoyt/New York as senior vice president, associate creative director.

title: STOPPING MARINO IS NOT EASY
description: The subject was how to stop Dan Marino, the Miami Dolphins' quarterback, and John Madden was holding court.

title: REAGAN IS REPORTED SET TO NAME ENERGY SECRETARY TO INTERIOR POST
description: President Reagan is expected to nominate Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel as Secretary of the Interior and to consider merging the Energy and Interior Departments, White House officials said today.

title: 'A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC' SETS BEST SELLER RECORD
description: A children's garden of preposterous poems and droll drawings, by an author best known to adults for his cartoons in Playboy magazine, has been on The New York Times best seller list longer than any hard-cover book in the list's 50-year history.

title: Ethiopia Said to Accept Israeli Aid for Famine
description: The Ethiopian Government has accepted an Israeli offer of food and medicine for its famine victims, a spokesman for Magen David Adom, the Israeli equivalent of the Red Cross, announced today.

title: FOR MAYAS OF GUATEMALA, CALAMITY STRIKES AGAIN
description: To an outsider it appears to be sadness, sharpened by fear, that lines the faces of Indian peasants who can be seen bent double under loads of firewood and dried corn in the highlands of Guatemala, where the horse and wheeled vehicles are still luxuries.

title: HOME BEAT
description: THE idea, according to Ralph Gambaro, who is seated at top right, was to present an all- New York collection of new furnishings. ''I see the pieces as extensions of their interior design work,'' said Mr. Gambaro, who is president of Les Prismatiques, a furnishings source to the trade.

title: Suffocation in Suitcase
description: An apparent stowaway whose body was found in a suitcase at Los Angeles International Airport died of asphyxia because force applied to the outside of the luggage hampered her breathing, coroner's officials said Tuesday.

title: AMERITRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
German Steel Output
description: West Germany's steel production came to 39.4 million metric tons in 1984, up 10.2 percent from 1983's output, the Federal Statistics Office said today. It was the first annual increase in West German steel production since 1979. A metric ton is equal to about 2,204 pounds.

title: LEADER IN BANK ARCHITECTURE
description: Charles Evans Hughes 3d, the architect who played the major role in the design of the Manufacturers Hanover Bank on Fifth Avenue and 43d Street, a four-story glass box built in 1954 that was widely believed to set the architecture of banks in a new direction, died Monday in New York. He was 69 years old.
