description: Maureen R. Connelly, former press

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: SURVEY INDICATES A SHARP CONTRAST IN VIEWS ON MISSILE DEFENSE PLAN
description: The American public holds sharply contrasting views about President Reagan's proposed defensive nuclear system in space, displaying confidence that the system could work but worry about its cost and its impact on the arms race, the latest New York Times/CBS News survey indicates.

title: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
HEARING FOR GOETZ IS DELAYED
description: The teen-ager whose spine was severed when Bernhard Hugo Goetz shot him on a subway train last month stopped breathing briefly yesterday, but was revived and placed on a respirator, a spokesman for St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center said.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Jan. 10, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: MARINES HAVE LANDED
description: WASHINGTON At a Cabinet meeting two years

title: SUN BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
USLIFE INCOME FUND CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: CITY'S ARAB BANKING SURGE
description: Only four years ago, New York's financial potpourri had only one Arab ingredient: the UBAF Arab American Bank. Today there are more than 20 Arab banks in New York, beneficiaries of liberalized banking laws and of their own vision of this city as their new frontier.

title: WHEN AGE DOES NOT COME GENTLY
description: WHILE I was growing up in Minnesota my father went off every day to his office wearing a dark suit and white shirt and with a fresh white handkerchief protruding from his breast pocket. It was my job to iron and fold those handkerchiefs and arrange them in his top drawer next to his gold tie clips, some set with diamonds to indicate decades of service to his company. I considered the handkerchiefs an important responsibility, for they seemed a badge of status like a general's stars and ribbons.

title: Child's Play
description: It was considered one of the greatest sports upsets in history: Gene Rossides throwing the touchdown pass to a diving Bill Swiacki that gave Columbia a 21-20 victory in 1947 and ended Army's 32-game undefeated streak. The only thing that could be a bigger upset, Rossides said yesterday, was if his 17-year-old daughter, Eleni, could defeat Martina Navratilova in the Virginia Slims of Washington tennis tournament.

title: AT SEASON'S END, 'NOBODY'S GETTING ANY DUCKS'
description: Each season, for more than 30 seasons, Daniel Boone Bullock has been guiding duck hunters into the flooded rice fields that straddle his home in nearby Crockett's Bluff. ''Used to be there were jillions of ducks here,'' recalled Mr. Bullock, whose friends call him Boone.

title: Asked About Goetz, Reagan Cites the Law
description: President Reagan was asked at his news conference tonight for his views on citizens who use deadly force to defend themselves against attacks. The question noted the shooting by Bernhard Hugo Goetz of four youths on a New York subway train.

title: FIRST CONNECTICUT BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A REVIVAL OF THE SHAPELY DRAWING-ROOM CHAIR
description: IT has been said that great rooms begin with great custom-made upholstered furniture. To make great rooms, when fireplaces must be flanked and nooks must be filled, decorators have long relied on two basic chair shapes, the Lawson and the Bridgewater.

title: Security Pacific, Duff Merger Off
description: The Security Pacific Corporation and Duff & Phelps Inc. said that they had called off their planned merger because of conditions imposed by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Maine Utilities in Seabrook Appeal
description: The Central Maine Power Company, one of the three Maine utilities ordered last month to sell their shares in the Seabrook nuclear project by tomorrow, said yesterday that the three were preparing a court appeal of the decision.

title: THOUGH JUSTICE IN SALVADOR IS RELUCTANT, DON'T BLAME DUARTE
description: To the Editor:

title: PRINTERS AND GRAPHIC WORKERS DRAFT MERGER PLAN
description: The International Typographical Union has reached a tentative agreement to merge with the Graphic Communications International Union, a spokesman for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. confirmed today.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF CUOMO STATE OF THE STATE ADDRESS TO LEGISLATURE
description: Following is a transcript of Governor Cuomo's State of the State Address to the Legislature yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: RIGHTS COMMISSION PLANS A STUDY ON BIAS IN EHTNIC NEIGHBORHOODS
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights today agreed to conduct a preliminary examination of whether white neighborhoods exclude minority residents in violation of fair housing standards.

title: 10 YEARS OR 100
description: BOSTON Robert Kennedy visited South Africa in June 1966. In a few days he had an impact that the cynics of this world could never understand, giving thousands of South Africans of all colors a vision of freedom and justice that they had almost forgotten. Some who were students then have told me how he changed their lives.

title: HOME FIRE FIGHTERS
description: WHILE home fire extinguishers are fairly common, fire hoses for use at home are not. A miniature fire hose, First Response, made by S. & S. Industries, is available for home use.

title: Wife of Ex-Gov. Carey In Chicago Tax Accord
description: Evangeline Gouletas-Carey, wife of former Gov. Hugh L. Carey of New York, and her brother, Nicholas Gouletas, agreed last week to pay an estimated $953,000 in back real estates taxes owed on a Chicago apartment building.

title: CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: b-Including a gain of $62,000 for the quarter and a loss of $138,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Including a gain of $352,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Marine Gets 12 Years At Spy Court-Martial
description: A marine accused of trying to sell nuclear, biological and chemical warfare information to Soviet and East European spies was convicted at a court- martial last year and is serving a prison term, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced Tuesday.

title: FIRST EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MORTGAGE & REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $29,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: Technology;   Phone Device For the Deaf
description: IN what could be an important development for

title: Soviet Wrestlers Seek Reversal
description: In 1984, freestyle wrestlers from the United States won 7 of the 10 gold medals at the Los Angeles Olympics. Of course, the Soviet team, which had won 7 of 10 events at the 1983 world championships, was not there.

title: NIGHTTIME DEMOLITION LEAVES A 44TH ST. MYSTERY
description: As glass, brick, mortar and dust littered West 44th Street, city officials tried yesterday to figure out why four buildings there were partly demolished in the dark.

title: Surrogate Mother's Baby In English Court Custody
description: The High Court has taken temporary custody of a 5-day-old girl, the first child known to have been born in Britain to a woman who was paid to serve as a surrogate mother.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: B.F. Goodrich Co., Akron, Ohio, said it planned to sell its Off-Highway Braking Systems division, which employs 290 and had 1984 sales of about $30 million. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 2 STOTTLEMYRE SONS ARE PICKED IN DRAFT
description: When his two sons were younger, just beginning to show an aptitude for the sport in which he had made his career, Mel Stottlemyre, the former Yankee pitcher, figured both would eventually start professional careers of their own. He never believed, however, that the careers would start simultaneously.

title: French Fire Kills 24 In Old People's Home
description: Twenty-four elderly people died in a fire that destroyed an old people's home in this northern French village during the night, local officials said today.

title: Housing Unit Offering Made
description: The New York Housing Development Corporation offered $31.75 million of multifamily development bonds.

title: WEST BANK UNIVERSITY FAULTS ISRAELI ARMY ACTION ON PROTEST
description: A university in the West Bank today issued the results of an investigation into the behavior of Israeli Army soldiers in putting down a demonstration last year in which a student was shot and killed by Israeli troops.

title: NORTHWEST STOCK OFF SHARPLY
description: The stock of Northwest Industries plunged today amid reports that an investor group's plan to buy the Chicago-based conglomerate for $1 billion was nearly dead.

title: U.S.O.C. CHECKING USE OF TRANSFUSIONS
description: Several members of the United States Olympic cycling team, including five medal winners, were given secret and potentially harmful blood transfusions designed to increase their performance levels, according to the team physician, who said last night that he had witnessed some of the tranfusions in a California motel room four days before the Games began. Although the United States Olympic Committee is opposed to the practice, it is not clear if it is illegal under International Olympic Committee rules.

title: Celtics, 76ers Win
description: Larry Bird hit for 28 points and Kevin McHale had 24, and the Boston Celtics withstood a scoring blitz by Michael Jordan tonight in outdueling the Chicago Bulls for a 111-108 victory.

title: Key Rates
SUIT CITES TEXAS OVER REGULATION AT CARE FACILITY
description: Two women who say their mother died as a result of inadequate treatment at a Houston nursing home charged today that the state of Texas was negligent in enforcing minimum nursing home standards.

title: 3 Die in Cargo Plane Crash
description: A cargo plane loaded with automobile parts crashed into a 100-foot concrete water basin near the Missouri River today, killing all three crewmen aboard, officials said. The plane, a four-engine Lockheed Electra turboprop owned by TPI International Airways Inc., of Miami was carrying car parts from Detroit for the Ford Motor Company.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC ISSUES;
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Miami Appoints a Black As Its New Police Chief
description: A 24-year veteran of the police force today became the first black to head the Miami Police Department, which has had three chiefs in less than a year.

title: Drug Inquiry Spreads
description: Vanderbilt's strength-training coach,

title: A Bernhard Goetz Letter
description: A letter to Herbert J. Sturz, the City

title: BANKRUPTCY HELD A POLLUTER SHIELD
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that under some circumstances an industrial polluter can invoke the protection of Federal bankruptcy law to avoid an order to clean up a toxic waste site.

title: EDUCOM CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $88,496.

title: The Oldest Generation
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: A SOVIET AVIATOR
description: Vladimir Kokkinaki, one of the best- known Soviet fliers and holder of more than a dozen world aviation records in the pre-jet age, died Monday in Moscow, according to the Soviet press agency Tass. He was 80 years old.

title: ISRAELI JETS BOMB P.L.O. IN LEBANON
description: Israeli jets bombed suspected Palestinian guerrilla positions today in the Syrian- controlled sector of the Bekaa region of Lebanon, the Israeli authorities and Lebanese radio stations said.

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET RESUMES SEASON
description: THE New York City Ballet, resuming its repertory season after a month-long run of ''The Nutcracker,'' gave us one of its business-as-usual reopenings Tuesday night at the State Theater.

title: EUGENE LYONS, 86, EARLY U.S. REPORTER IN THE SOVIET UNION
description: Eugene Lyons, one of the first American correspondents to report from the Soviet Union and in later years a staunch critic of the Soviet system, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86 years old.

title: CYBERMEDIC INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Lost Picks
description: Three of the Boston Bruins' highest draft picks have become entwined in a macabre tale of injury and physical disability, the latest episode of which may jeopardize the promising career of 23-year-old Barry Pederson.

title: UNIFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
BIOSENSOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-No year-ago sales figures were provided because the company did not go public until November 1983.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RISES SLIGHTLY DESPITE CREATION OF NEW JOBS
description: Despite a solid gain in the number of people working, the national unemployment rate edged up slightly in December, to 7.1 percent from 7 percent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   International Paper Appoints Chairman
description: The International Paper Company said yesterday that John A. Georges, president and chief executive, had been named chairman effective April 9. Paul H. O'Neill, senior vice president, was named president.

title: Four Share Lead At 66 in Hope Golf
description: Despite the many crowd distractions created by playing in a foursome with Bob Hope and former President Gerald Ford, John Mahaffey took a share of the first-round lead today in the Bob Hope Classic, which he won last year.

title: Bridge:Microcomputer Programs Compete at Club in Queens
description: Unlike chess players, bridge players are not in serious danger of being outplayed by computers. That seems to be the lesson to be drawn from the first competition between bridge-playing microcomputer programs, played Tuesday night at the Midway Club, 97-13 64th Road, Rego Park, Queens.

title: BANCO DE PONCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $2,488,459.

title: A City Ballet Floor
description: For years, linoleum makers promised non-scratch, ever-smooth, perpetually gleaming floors that could resist an onslaught of tanks.

title: Harlem Dance Theater On Four-Borough Tour
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem will begin its four-borough tour of New York City with performances on Jan. 19 and 20 at 8:30 P.M. at Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College. Information: (718) 544-2996.

title: American Medical Eurobond Issue
description: In a somewhat unusual offering, American Medical International Inc. issued $:40 million of five-year Eurobonds.

title: NEW JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $727,000 for the quarter and $2,171,000 for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $1,289,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''From the beginning of this nation's history New York has always been the place where people come to fulfill their dreams.'' - Governor Cuomo. (B5:3.)

title: Fed Approves Suntrust Plan
description: A plan to merge Sun Banks Inc. of Florida and the Trust Company of Georgia into a regional concern known as Suntrust Banks Inc. has been approved by the Federal Reserve Board, the companies said. The Fed approved the merger on Tuesday, more than three months after the banks'boards approved the plan, officials said.

title: LAWMAKERS' RETURN STIRS A CHILLY CAPITAL
description: In this city, whose pulse quickens and slows to the beat of the Legislature, State of the State Day is like Memorial Day in the Hamptons - the official start of the season, a day to sit through ceremonies and stand through cocktail parties.

title: UNITED CABLE TELEVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Beatrice Sells 3 of Its Bakeries
description: The Beatrice Companies announced the sale of its bakeries in Lakeland, Fla., Birmingham, Ala., and Orangeburg, S.C., to Southern Bakeries Inc. of Lakeland for $31 million.

title: Promotion at G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation today named William Lane general manager of its Oldsmobile division and a corporate vice president. Mr. Lane, 55 years old, was previously general sales and service manager for G.M.'s Pontiac division. He succeeds Joseph Sanchez, who was appointed on Tuesday as president of G.M.'s new Saturn Corporation subsidiary.

title: 700 PAGING SYSTEM PETITIONS DENIED
description: A Federal administrative law judge today denied petitions by four companies for nearly 700 new one-way paging systems on the ground that they had been acting as fronts for the nation's largest radio paging company, the Graphic Scanning Corporation, which had filed competing applications.

title: PRETORIA BARS KENNEDY VISIT WITH BLACK
description: The South African authorities today turned down a request by Senator Edward M. Kennedy to meet Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned nationalist figure who is regarded by many black people as their leader.

title: Quaker Oats Officer Resigns CHICAGO, Jan. 9 - The
description: Quaker Oats Company announced today that Robert N.

title: DANCE: DECADE AT RIVERSIDE FESTIVAL
description: THE programming at the Riverside Dance Festival is the most eclectic in town. On Tuesday, the Theater of the Riverside Church opened its 1985 season with a 10th anniversary celebration that offered a typically wide- ranging sample of Riverside fare over the years. It was certainly too generous a sampling, with 24 full dances and excerpts from ballet, modern dance, jazz and ethnic works. But the celebration, which continues through Sunday, had its share of transcendent moments.

title: PROTEIN CLUE TO MYSTERIOUS BRAIN DISEASE REPORTED
description: A protein previously found in a brain disease of animals has been detected in the brains of two patients who died of one of the most mysterious known human diseases, scientists reported yesterday.

title: REAGAN SEES HOPE OF 'NEW DIALOGUE' WITH THE RUSSIANS
description: President Reagan said today that he hoped the agreement with the Soviet Union on holding arms talks would produce ''a new dialogue'' and better relations between the two countries.

title: COLUMBIA CHASE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
THE NEXT BIG STEP TO HELP AFRICA
description: While the large- scale outpouring of emergency food to Africa is a worthwhile and dramatic first step toward saving lives, it is merely a first step. Alone it will not save the continent's stricken people, nor break the cycle of their dependency on imported food for survival. The crucial next step, which must be taken now, is to determine what long-term development aid will best lay the groundwork for the recovery of Africa's environment and agriculture. Its goal should be to help Africans begin feeding themselves.

title: KOCH ADMINISTRATION PLANNING TO INCREASE ITS OFFER OF A 3% RAISE FOR UNIONS
description: The Koch administration yesterday gave the first indication that it was preparing to raise its public offer to the municipal labor unions, even as both sides moved to resolve a deadlock of more than six months through binding arbitration.

title: PARKER PEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Tidewater Rejects Bid From Jacobs
description: The board of Tidewater Inc. has rejected a buyout offer of $415 million from an investment group headed by Irwin L. Jacobs of Minneapolis, saying the offer of $25 to $28 a share was too low.

title: MRS. HECKLER URGING SYNDROME WARNING AS AN ASPIRIN LABEL
description: The Secretary of Health and Human Services, Margaret M. Heckler, today asked the manufacturers of aspirin products to warn consumers that use of aspirin under certain conditions appeared to be associated with the development of Reye's syndrome, a potentially fatal ailment. She asked manufacturers to put warning labels on their products.

title: PICK A GAME: MUSICAL CHAIRS, CHESS, DOMINOES?
description: The grandstands for Ronald Reagan's second inauguration are being built out in the cold and wind of Pennsylvania Avenue, lending the current White House scene the look of a game half- started, or half-finished.

title: Swimmer Defects
description: Jens-Peter Berndt , a 21-year-old world-class swimmer from East Germany, told authorities in Oklahoma City that he did not want to return to his homeland and remained behind when his teammates departed Monday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 10, 1985

title: C.I.A. Chief Says Tide Is Now Against Soviet
description: The Director of Central Intelligence said yesterday that resistance to Soviet military aggression imposed directly or by proxy was growing and offered the Western countries an opportunity that must not be ignored.

title: CONTOLLER ERROR SUSPECTED
description: A Soviet airplane and a Dominican jet airliner came within about a quarter- mile of a collision about 450 miles off the Florida coast yesterday, apparently because of an error by an air traffic controller in Miami, according to a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed to shareholders of record Dec. 15.

title: Nutri System
description: Nutri System Inc. said the investor group that had agreed to acquire it for $9 a share, or a total of about $87 million, subject to adjustment, was unwilling to proceed with the transaction. The group is headed by Leslie Charm and advised by Salomon Brothers Inc. The company had given the group an extension until Jan. 18 to obtain the financing required in the transaction. Nutri System's stock fell 75 cents, to $5.625 a share, for the second-largest percentage loss today on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Resolved: More Publicity
description: It goes almost without saying on

title: HERS
description: ''THE whole affair,'' my mother wrote all the relatives after she got home from Philadelphia, ''was beautiful.'' What she meant was my wedding,

title: ELITISM VS. POPULARIZATION IN CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: WHAT is one to make of the recent news that more Americans than ever before attended arts events last year? I wish my heart had leapt higher for joy. The quest for a wider audience has always been deemed crucial, especially in America, to cultural advancement. And heaven knows it's a noble goal. But there are those who feel that the classical- music profession (I do not want to generalize beyond my own field) is in some danger of diluting the qualities that make great music the experience it can be - of shortchanging the audience it already has - in the effort to make art more palatable to a wider public.

title: Thomson McKinnon Censure
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had censured Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. in connection with its stock- loan program.

title: OIL PITS MOVE TO CENTER STAGE
description: Michael Milano is in the oil business. He is enough of a presence there that - if pressed - he would acknowledge he can be just as important as Saudi Arabia.

title: AN OLD PHILOSOPHER TAKES UP A NEW CAUSE
description: ''I'm happy to see you. You have entered the cottage of a man who is literally out of this world. He has been called unique in the history of the world.

title: COSMOS RALLY TO WIN
description: After 18 games of the Major Indoor Soccer League season, Karl-Heinz Granitza of the Chicago Sting, not Steve Zungul, is the league's leading scorer.

title: Dominican Units Sold by G.&W.
description: Gulf and Western Industries said it had completed the sale of its sugar business and related operations in the Dominican Republic and Florida to an investor group.

title: No Headline
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 10, 1985 International

title: CALENDAR: HOME REPAIRS FOR WOMEN
description: Women Teaching Women: Basic

title: Trophy Is Found
description: The 1942 Heisman Trophy, which was stolen from a display case in the lobby of a University of Georgia athletic dormitory last Thursday, has been retrieved after an anonyomous caller told the campus police where to find it. There were no immediate arrests, but

title: NEW CATALOGUES ARE BECKONING
description: THE new seed and nursery catalogues are beginning to arrive. Probably no other type of catalogue causes so much frustration: gardeners want to plant practically everything in the gorgeous pages, until reality strikes and the dreamers are forced to face budget or space limitations.

title: DOUGLAS JACOBS
description: Douglas Jacobs, an antiquarian-book dealer for many years, died of congestive heart failure Sunday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.

title: 'CALL TO GLORY' IS GIVEN SHIFT IN THEME AND DAY
description: ''Call to Glory,'' ABC's weekly prime-time series about a military family during the 1960's, has been revamped and is being given a second chance to find the audience popularity that has eluded the program so far this season.

title: 'PRAYING MANTIS,' A 3-PART 'MYSTERY!'
description: PUBLIC television's ''Mystery!'' series has acquired a three-part romp through amorality that, right up to its overly pat ending, is bound to fascinate devoted viewers. ''Praying Mantis,'' which begins tonight at 9 on WNET/Channel 13, has been adapted quite skillfully by Philip Mackie from a novel by the French writer Hubert Monteilhet. So despite the preponderance of British accents, the flavor of the nasty machinations is strictly Gallic.

title: Textron-Avco
description: Textron Inc. said that the California Insurance Commissioner had approved its acquisition of the Avco Corporation.

title: Lawyer From Queens Joins the City Council
description: A lawyer who is a former member of the City University board was sworn in as a member of the City Council yesterday to complete the term of Thomas J. Manton, Democrat of Queens. Mr. Manton was elected to the Congressional seat vacated by Geraldine A. Ferraro.

title: TRUST COMPANY OF GEORGIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUILDINGS OF THE PAST: 2 VIEWS
description: Visions of an America past that is still present fill recent publications by two historical-preservation societies. Both books - one on New York State landmarks and the other on country schools - explore aspects of the nation's architectural history.

title: Special OPEC Meeting Seen
description: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will hold an extraordinary conference in Geneva Jan. 28, the official Algerian press agency, monitored in Paris, said today.

title: THE CUSTOM UPHOLSTERERS
description: THE world of custom upholstered furniture is a tightly knit one, open only to interior designers, decorators and architects. Together, the designer and upholsterer modify and detail stock pieces for each client.

title: Deal's Collapse Cools Trading Trading in shares of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation
description: Corporation returned to normal yesterday on the New York

title: Oregon Bank Ruling
description: A Federal judge has overturned a jury's verdict and ruled in favor of an Oregon bank in an antitrust lawsuit that contended the bank had acted improperly in setting its prime lending rate. District Judge James A. Redden ruled that First Interstate Bank of Oregon had set its prime rate to remain competitive with other banks, not by conspiring with them to overcharge customers. An attorney for one of the four groups of plaintiffs, Henry A. Carey, said today that the ruling would be appealed.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ENERGY AGENCY: A SHORT HISTORY
description: The 1973-74 Arab oil embargo and the shortages it caused prompted the Government to create a separate agency for energy.

title: ISRAEL AND U.S. FACING HURDLES ON TRADE PACT
description: The United States and Israel have entered rough waters in efforts to negotiate a free-trade pact in which tariffs between the two countries would eventually be wiped out.

title: NICARAGUA INSTALLS ELECTED ASSEMBLY
description: Nicaragua's new National Assembly was installed today, the first elected body to take office since the Sandinista- led revolution in 1979.

title: CENTRAL PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. c-After loan and other loss provisions including discontinued operations of $15,929,000. d-Net income after loan and other loss provisions including discontinued operations of $3,553,000.

title: Waiting for Weinberger
description: At least two prominent Republicans are said to entertain hopes that the reshuffling of the Reagan Cabinet may yet include the departure of Caspar W. Weinberger as Secretary of Defense. John Tower of Texas, who was chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee for four years before his retirement, is said to be interested in any such opening, although he has been promised the post of Ambassador to West Germany when Arthur F. Burns returns to Washington this spring.

title: ALEXANDER ERLICH, 72, ECONOMIST
description: Dr. Alexander Erlich, professor emeritus of economics at Columbia University and an authority on economic development in the Soviet Union, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72 years old.

title: NATIONAL BANCORP OF ALAAMA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VOLUNTEER GROUPS TAILORING PROGRAMS FOR CAREER WOMEN
description: T HESE are not the best of times for the League of Women Voters. For as more women have moved into the paid work force, fewer have been interested in volunteer work at the league. Indeed, according to Lenore Chester, president of the New York City league, membership here has dropped 15 to 20 percent over the last decade. And nationally, membership has decreased by almost a quarter during the same period.

title: ON THE ROAD TO THE 19TH HOLE
description: He's been playing golf for so lcng, he claims he washes his golf balls with Epsom salts. He confesses that his swing has been described as that of a polo player without a horse. And he needs scorecards that aren't allergic to erasers. These one-liners have been teed up from ''Bob Hope's Confessions of a Hooker: My Lifelong Love Affair With Golf,'' soon to be published by Doubleday as a comic antidote for all those tortuous tomes on how to hit the ball slightly straight.

title: Congressmen to Visit Cuba
description: Representatives Bill Alexander, Arkansas Democrat, and Jim Leach, Iowa Republican, will fly to Cuba on Thursday for a week's visit for talks with Fidel Castro on prospects of easing United States-Cuban tensions.

title: Talking Again
description: It is indisputably better for Americans and Russians to be talking about their nuclear arms race than to be running it in feverish isolation. Having to explain weapons programs reduces the chance of calamitous miscalculation. Talking may also usefully calm - or confirm - mutual suspicions. It preserves hope for restraining the nuclear competition and also for negotiating more reasonably about other issues.

title: KING HELD TO 15 AS KNICKS LOSE, 100-95
description: Alex English scored 29 points tonight, 12 in the final quarter, as the Denver Nuggets sent the Knicks to their 10th straight loss on the road, 100-95.

title: Debt
Hammond Turning To Advertising
description: Hammond Inc., an 84-year-old, family-owned cartographer company, has been doing nicely with very little advertising. That is about to change because of the growth aspirations of Caleb Dean Hammond 3d, grandson of the founder and son of the chairman, who has convinced his uncle, Stuart, the president, of the propriety of such a move.

title: Depression Glass
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Market Place;   Energy Stocks Played Down
description: THERE may be a stock market rally about to

title: Appeals Court Rules Indians May Kill Bald Eagles for Rites
description: A Federal court ruled today that centuries- old treaties give members of Indian tribes the right to hunt protected species, including bald eagles, on Indian reservations.

title: New Cigarette Is 'Midpriced' Liggett & Myers Inc., the
description: sixth-largest cigarette maker,

title: 'Talking' Gorilla Cries After Pet Cat Is Killed
description: Koko, a gorilla that researchers say has a vocabulary estimated at more than 500 sign-language words, cried after it was told that its pet cat had been killed, officials said Tuesday.

title: Boy Missing 21 Months Reunited With Father
description: A tearful 13-year-old boy hugged his father today for the first time since the boy disappeared from his California home 21 months ago. A man was arrested in the disappearance.

title: PRESIDENT SAYS SOCIAL SECURITY MAY BE ALTERED
description: President Reagan said tonight that he would consider adjustments in Social Security cost-of-living increases if the Administration was faced with an overwhelming Congressional mandate.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: SOLSTICE. By Joyce Carol Oates. 243

title: Chess Game Is Adjourned
description: The 40th game of the world chess championship was adjourned today after 40 moves, with the challenger, Gary Kasparov, holding what was effectively a pawn advantage over the titleholder, Anatoly Karpov.

title: OFFERS TO SPEED UP AID TO THAIS
description: The United States today ''categorically'' condemned Vietnamese military action along the Thai-Cambodian border and offered to speed up military aid to Thailand if the Bangkok Government should request it.

title: HEALTHGROUP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MOSCOW PORTRAYS TALKS AS SUCCESS
description: The Soviet press today portrayed the agreement between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko as a success, describing the accord to open new arms talks as a victory for Moscow.

title: DECISION DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $114,000 for the quarter and $321,000 for the year.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the effective date of Vanity Fair's 18 percent advertising rate increase. It takes effect with the magazine's July issue.

title: 4 YOUTHS SHOT BY GOETZ FACED CRIMINAL COUNTS
description: Each of the four teen-agers shot on a subway train last month by Bernhard Hugo Goetz had been arrested or convicted at least once and each was facing a trial or a hearing on criminal charges at the time of the incident.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: The Arrow Co. , the shirt division of Cluett, Peabody & Co., an apparel concern, announced that Harris R. Hester had been appointed president.

title: A Little Help From Carter
description: For the inauguration of Jimmy

title: BOSTON ARTISTS WIN HARBOR LOFTS
description: For seven years, Paola Savarino and her son, Jason, hid their clothes and beds if the doorbell rang unexpectedly. To camouflage traces of their residency, they ferried groceries and laundry in cardboard boxes. ''I worried about developing a ghetto mentality,'' said Miss Savarino, recalling seven years of moving in and out of industrial buildings not zoned as residences.

title: Kill Him, 4-4
description: Roosevelt Green, a convicted murderer who died yesterday in Georgia's electric chair, supplied the second surprise in the case by inviting his mother to his execution. She accepted, advancing a trend in participatory punishment. In Louisiana recently, the family of a murder victim watched the execution, and liked it.

title: CUOMO PLAN SEEKS REVIVAL OF SPIRIT OF THE NEW DEAL
description: With a call to revive the spirit of the New Deal, Governor Cuomo set out a wide-ranging legislative program today in his annual State of the State address.

title: PLAN FOR UNWED FATHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising;   Michelin's Broader Approach
description: THE Michelin Tire Corporation of

title: CUOMO SEEKING SPECIAL SCHOOLS FOR THE TALENTED
description: Governor Cuomo called upon lawmakers today to spend $1 million to create ''high schools of excellence'' around the state modeled on such schools as the Bronx High School of Science.

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST CITE PROBLEM OF HUNGER
description: Stirred by news of suffering and need in faraway lands, many people have contributed to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund this season in hope of easing the poverty in their own communities.

title: DOCTORS FIGHT DISCLOSURE RULE
description: A new financial disclosure requirement for physicians in New York City's municipal hospitals was attacked yesterday by a physicians' union leader as a move by Mayor Koch to ''embarrass doctors and invade their privacy.''

title: JOHN HORNE, EX-FEDERAL AIDE
description: John E. Horne, an official of the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Alexandria, Va. He was 76 years old.

title: MANILA SAYS REBELS GAINED IN '84, KILLING 2,000
description: The Philippine Defense Minister warned today that the Communist insurgency in this country was becoming increasingly bold and effective. He said a ''serious upsurge'' in rebel activities resulted in the deaths of 2,000 civilians and military personnel last year.

title: 70 MOVES, AND ANOTHER CHESS DRAW
description: Sterling defensive end-game play by Anatoly Karpov, the 33-year-old world chess champion, let him escape with a draw in the 40th game of his title match with Gary Kasparov in Moscow yesterday.

title: Correction
description: A film review of ''The Plague Dogs'' on Wednesday incorrectly described the film's animation. It was executed by hand.

title: Scarsdale Man Wounds Intruder
description: A Scarsdale resident, alerted by a burglar alarm, shot and wounded an intruder in his living room before dawn today, the police reported.

title: REVERSAL ON INAUGURAL LISTCORRECTION
description: A spokesman for President Reagan's inaugural committee reversed himself today and said the names of donors of $8 million to $9 million raised to pay for the celebrations would be made public.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   World Bank Offerings
description: The World Bank, in its first issues of the new year, yesterday offered a total of $750 million of bonds and short-term discount note instruments in London and New York.

title: CMC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MCENROE RALLY DEFEATED JARRYD
description: For the first hour, John McEnroe was beating the tar out of the crowd. Dressed appropriately enough in black shorts and a blue shirt, McEnroe advised a slow moving woman to ''drop 25 pounds,'' told a fan shouting encouragement to ''shut up,'' and saved his best glares for the courtside papparazzi, whose shutters make him cringe. It was no contest.

title: Steel Accord Completed
description: An accord to limit European steel pipe and tube exports to the United States has been completed, and letters of agreement will be exchanged Friday, United States trade officials said today. Reports last week said the exports would probably be limited to about 700,000 tons a year.

title: FILM: 'EMMANUELLE 4'
description: ''EMMANUELLE 4,'' which opens today at the Eastside and UA Twin Theaters, is the third sequel to be spun off the 1974 exploitation hit ''Emmanuelle,'' which starred Sylvia Kristel. If the first sequel had been titled ''Daughter of Emmanuelle'' instead of ''Emmannuelle 2,'' the new film might well be called ''Great- Granddaughter of Emmanuelle,'' which sounds a bit geriatric but wouldn't be entirely misleading.

title: Pianist to Perform
description: The pianist Dave McKenna will perform on Sunday at 5 P.M. at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street (369-8040). Tickets are $7.

title: Octet at Sweet Basil
description: The saxophonist David Murray will lead his octet - with Craig Harris on trombone, Olu Dara on cornet, Hugh Regan on trumpet, John Purcell on saxophones, Curtis Clark on piano, Wilbur Morris on bass and Steve McCall on drums - perform tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil , 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Thailand and Vietnam Agree to Set Up a DMZ
description: Thailand and Vietnam agreed today to establish a demilitarized zone along a stretch of the Cambodian border, a Thai general said.

title: Federal Reserve All data in millions of dollars
description: LatestPreviousYearWeekWeekAgo

title: SHARP LEGISLATIVE STRATEGIST FOLLOWING BAKER TO NEW JOB
description: When the Reagan Administration came together in 1981, James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, hired a young workaholic named Richard G. Darman as his top deputy.

title: Condemned Man Rejects Further Appeal Efforts
description: Joseph Carl Shaw, condemned to death for killing two teen-agers, asked for a last meal of pizza today and told his attorneys to file no more appeals aimed at halting his execution, scheduled for 5 A.M. Friday.

title: April Trial Expected for 7 Charged in Plot on Pope
description: The trial of three Bulgarians and four Turks charged with complicity in a plot to kill Pope John Paul II is expected to start in early April, a lawyer for one of the defendants said today.

title: SMOKING DANGEROUS TO NONSMOKERS ALSO
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 May Be Named in Spy Case
description: Two more foreigners may be included as unindicted co-conspirators in the espionage case involving a Soviet couple and an F.B.I. agent, a prosecutor said in court Wednesday.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Morgan Stanley Shifting Merger Unit Leadership
description: After handling a record $50 billion in mergers and acquisitions last year, Morgan Stanley & Company is shuffling the leadership of the department that pulled in that business.

title: PUBLISHING: AN AWARD IN HONOR OF HEMINGWAY
description: AT a noon news conference today at the Hotel Ritz in Paris, Pierre Salinger and Jack Hemingway, the eldest son of Ernest Hemingway, are scheduled to announce the establishment of the $50,000 Ritz Paris Hemingway Award. The annual award is open to authors of all nationalities and, according to a Hotel Ritz spokesman, will be given for the novel published in English that best exemplifies the Hemingway tradition of excellence. In addition, $100,000 will be given annually to the organizations or institutions that best further the study of the life and works of Hemingway.

title: CB&T BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Track Is Clear
description: James J. Jeffries never fought there. Neither did Jack Johnson, Jack Dempsey, Benny Leonard, Sugar Ray Robinson, Joe Louis, Rocky Marciano or Muhammad Ali.

title: Twin Bill at Folk City
description: The singers and songwriters Eric Andersen and David Massengill will share a double bill tonight at 8:30 and 11:30 at Folk City, 130 West Third Street (254-8449). Tickets are $8.

title: 'THE INHERITORS'
description: ''THE INHERITORS,'' Walter Bannert's German-language, Austrian film that opens today at the Cinema Studio, comes to us supported by some solemn credentials. These include a press-kit essay by Gerald Margolis, Ph.D., director of the Simon Wiesenthal Center, who certifies the accuracy of the film's presentation of the methods and the goals of the increasing number of neo-Nazi groups in Germany and Austria.

title: 500 DANCE AND DONATE TO ASSIST POLICE FORCE
description: With the flourish of balloons and the skirl of bagpipes, a businesslike Police Department auditorium was turned into a ballroom last night for 500 guests who donated money to help improve the effectiveness of the police.

title: WAS THERE A MESSAGE IN THE IRT SHOOTINGS?
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Cigarettes Pay Starting in October, smokers are scheduled to pay less for something that's a pleasure for them and a health risk for everyone. The Federal excise tax on cigarettes is scheduled to drop to 8 cents. But why should it?
description: When the tax went up to 16 cents in 1983, cigarette consumption went down 5 percent - primarily because teen-agers who might otherwise have started smoking chose not to. The price of cigarettes has little effect on people who already smoke, but it does discourage kids from following this particular rite of passage.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   3 Groups Formed In GTE Revamping
description: In another repercussion of the deregulation of the nation's telephone system, the GTE Corporation yesterday announced a major realignment of the company into three operating groups, and the elevation of the group presidents to the board of directors.

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
DESIGNATED SECRETARIES OF THE INTERIOR, EDUCATION AND ENERGY DEPARTMENTS
description: In three years as chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, William J. Bennett has been such a staunch advocate of the classical approach to the studies of humanities that he has stirred a loud debate not expected to be found in those staid precincts.

title: EX-C.I.A. ANALYST TAKES STAND FOR CBS
description: Samuel A. Adams, whose thesis that the military had lied about enemy strength estimates in the Vietnam War formed the basis for a disputed CBS documentary, took the stand yesterday in the Westmoreland-CBS libel trial and told of the long road that led him to believe the underestimates placed American soldiers in jeopardy.

title: HOW A 7TH AVE. DESIGNER SELLS SUMMERTIME
description: Temperatures dropped to the teens, New Yorkers shrank into their down coats, but in the garment

title: ART: MODERN SHOWS OFF SOME OF BEST DRAWINGS
description: UNLIKE connoisseurs of the medium, most of us don't really consider drawing in the same league as painting. A work on paper - the time-honored definition of a drawing - is subordinate to a work on canvas, we feel; less robust in terms of image, color, texture. But artists today have a quite different view. With limitless freedom of execution, they can make a drawing a major event in itself. It can be rendered with a pencil or a mop, range in size from postage stamp to mural, stand alone or in a series. What's more, it might be laid down on anything from the traditional sheet of paper to - well, a wall.

title: ART: TROMPE l'OEIL IN CORONA PARK
description: THERE is no art more elementary (or more seductive) than trompe l'oeil. Truly a people's art, it requires skill to produce, but no conditioning to appreciate and, as a branch of pie-in- the-face humor, it must be one of civilization's oldest jokes.

title: F.C.C. REJECTS A COMPLAINT BY C.I.A. ON AN ABC REPORT
description: The staff of the Federal Communications Commission ruled today that the Central Intelligence Agency had submitted insufficient evidence to merit a full inquiry into the agency's charge that ABC News distorted a series of reports about the agency.

title: Barrasso Shuts Out Bruins in Boston
description: The Buffalo Sabres and their goalie, Tom Barrasso, became the first to shut out the Boston Bruins in Boston Garden in 298 regular-season games, dating to 1977, in a 3-0 victory here tonight.

title: POLE DENIES APPROVING PLAN TO HURT ACTIVIST PRIEST
description: A security policeman on trial here with three subordinates in the killing of a pro-Solidarity priest denied today that he or high-ranking Interior Ministry officials had approved any physical violence against the clergyman.

title: PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
RAIDERS SOBER THE OIL INDUSTRY
description: On the whole, the American oil industry has been able to operate relatively loosely for a decade. Oil prices jumped tenfold during the period, and company coffers brimmed. But, aside from some increased dividends, much of the money was not returned to stockholders. Instead, it was poured into disappointing diversification efforts, as well as drilling projects that had limited returns.

title: UNDER MAJOR BANKS, LAND MINES
description: Despite some good financial news on the international front - the rescheduling of Argentina's debt, for example - America's banking system is still in trouble. Every major bank is sitting on a land mine of bad domestic loans, largely to farming and oil-related industries - a land mine ready to explode and shake investor confidence in the banking system.

title: Comings and Goings
description: LaVell Edwards, who guided Brigham Young to an undefeated season and unofficial acclaim as the nation's top college team, has been named coach of the year in balloting by more than 2,400 members of the American Football Coaches Association. . . .

title: CASTRO DROPS IN
description: Daniel Ortega Saavedra was inaugurated as President of Nicaragua today in a ceremony marked by the unexpected arrival of the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro.

title: ISRAEL PLANS NEW SETTLEMENTS
description: Sites for six new Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank were approved today by the Government, an Israel official involved in the decision said.

title: Freight for Ferraro
description: The subterranean passages that

title: TRAVELERS PRESIDENT RESIGNS
description: In a move that caught the insurance industry and Wall Street analysts by surprise, the Travelers Corporation said yesterday that its president, Alva O. Way, had resigned for ''personal reasons.'' Mr. Way, who is 55 years old, gave up the presidency of the American Express Company in January 1983 to join Travelers, one of the nation's largest multiline insurance companies.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   O'Connor to Visit Ethiopia
description: Archbishop John J. O'Connor, who

title: Police in El Salvador Said to Guard Prelate
description: Officials uncovered a plot to assassinate the Roman Catholic Archbishop of San Salvador, and he has reluctantly accepted a police escort, church and Government sources said today.

title: Extra Practice Ordered for Nets
description: Coach Stan Albeck was so discouraged by what he saw in the Nets' recent lopsided losses to Atlanta and Cleveland, two mediocre teams, that he ran the players through two practices today and announced he would make one change in his starting lineup for Friday night's game here with the Hawks.

title: GROMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $3,370 for the quarter and $23,100 for the year on the purchase of 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures in excess of a one year sinking fund requirement. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $7,120 on the purchase of 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures in excess of a one year sinking fund requirement.

title: TRUST RAISES STAKE IN COWLES MEDIA
description: The Cowles Media Company announced yesterday that a family trust had increased its holding in the diversified communications company to more than 50 percent in order to prevent the company from becoming a takeover target.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''THIS is just like a reunion of all my friends, and I feel as if I were still the First Lady introducing everyone,'' Phyllis George said as she hugged and kissed a remarkably diverse group of people at a ''Welcome to New York'' dinner given for her by Dr. Lee Salk, the child psychologist, in his apartment the other evening.

title: DeLorean Aide Pleads Guilty
description: The personal secretary to John Z. DeLorean has pleaded guilty to charges of possession of cocaine with intent to distribute, authorities said.

title: ARIZONA BANCWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Terex Proposal Gains Ground
description: Creditors of the Terex Corporation have agreed to proceed with a reorganization plan that tentatively calls for a group of investors to acquire the company and merge it with its former operations in Scotland.

title: SUPPORT FOR GOETZ
description: By one public-opinion barometer - a weekly digest of letters written to Mayor Koch almost everyone is preoccupied with the recent shooting of four teen-agers on the IRT.

title: CHEREAU'S 'HOMME BLESSE'
description: AT the beginning of Patrice Chereau's ''L'Homme Blesse,'' a young man named Henri (Jean-Hugues Anglade) goes to the railway station with his parents to bid farewell to his sister, who is leaving on a vacation. The train is late, Henri has time to linger, and on a trip to the men's room he discovers what is suddenly of great and passionate interest to him: men. One man in particular, a thug who implicates Henri in a robbery and then gives him a violent kiss, becomes for Henri a figure of enduring erotic fascination.

title: Activist Is Guilty In Draft Case
description: A peace activist living in Syracuse was found guilty today of failing to register for the draft.

title: BLOOD TEST FOR AIDS VIRUS IS EXPECTED SOON
description: Cautious optimism advanced on two fronts today that a reliable blood test might soon be available that would detect the virus believed to cause acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: ANGOLA'S SECOND CITY: A FADED POSTCARD OF 1975
description: Four colonial- era statues, representing Patience, Temperance, Justice and Fortitude, lie abandoned in a field here. Presiding in their place at the former Portuguese Governor's Palace is a solitary, Soviet-issue bust of Lenin. The statue switch is one of many changes that have come to this city, once the showcase of Portuguese Africa. In early 1976, the Marxist Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola extended its control to Huambo, largely sealing off Angola's second-largest city to Western reporters for a decade.

title: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hockey Honors
description: Jack Butterfield and the late Arthur Wirtz, both of whom helped build hockey in the United States, have been named recipients of the 1985 Lester Patrick Award.

title: DEKALB AGRESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, JANUARY 11, 1985
description: Markets

title: MERRICK RESUMS CONTROL OVER BUSINESS AFFAIRS
description: A justice of the State Supreme Court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that David Merrick, the producer of ''42d Street'' and several other hit musicals, was capable of resuming control of his business and personal affairs.

title: New Value Line Options
description: An options contract based on the Value Line stock market composite index began trading at the Philadelphia Stock Exchange today.

title: USING VIDEO EQUIPMENT TO CAPTURE CITY SCENES
description: To judge by spurting sales of video cameras, making your own video movies is in vogue. The appeal of videography, as the new hobby is sometimes called, has been spurred by the recent appearance of lightweight cameras and recorders that take video out of the living room and into the field, where the equipment can be used to capture the aura of the city in winter.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: JANE ALEXANDER, who has appeared in films from ''Testament'' to ''All the President's Men,'' is becoming a producer, and she isn't starting small. In Miss Alexander's next four films, after she completes acting in ''Sweet Country'' for Michael Cacoyannis, she will take on part or all of the producer's chores.

title: Eastern Airlines Trial Is Ordered
description: A Federal judge today ordered that a trial be held to determine whether the employee wage-concession program at Eastern Airlines should be extended.

title: Dig at Sheridan Square
description: ''Community Dig,'' an 18-minute documentary about an archeological excavation in Sheridan Square, will be screened tonight at 6:30 at the Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue.

title: HADCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-After a charge of $1 million for the quarter and year related to receivables due from Storage Technology Corp. prior to its filing for protection under Chapter 11 of the U. S. Bankruptcy Law.

title: EX-FOX EXECUTIVE SUES FOR BREACH OF CONTRACT
description: Norman Levy, the former vice chairman of 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation who was forced to resign during a management shake-up last September, has sued the company for breach of contract.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Home, Home in the Park
description: To find a home on a park is often a

title: RECORD NUMBER SEEK SHELTER ON FRIGID NIGHT
description: As the winter's worst cold held its grip on New York City, record numbers of homeless men, women and children took refuge in public shelters, community centers, churches and synagogues.

title: A SUSPECT VANISHES AS POLICE SIEGE FAILS
description: The driver of a silver Mercedes-Benz shot three men on a street in Bay Shore, L.I., yesterday after the driver appeared to stop his car to ask directions, the police said.

title: Sri Lanka Rebel Leader Killed by Security Forces
description: A top Tamil guerrilla leader and 13 other rebels were killed in an attack by security forces on Sri Lanka's strongest rebel group, the National Security Minister said today.

title: U.S. NUN DETAINED BRIEFLY BY REBELS IN NICARAGUA
description: An American nun was seized by anti- Government insurgents Tuesday but was released several hours later, Government officials said today. In separate attacks the same day, the group of rebels killed 14 civilians, according to the officials.

title: Four at Fat Tuesday's
description: Two musicians from Kansas City, the pianist Jay McShann and the violinist Claude (Fiddler) Williams, will lead a quartet through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets are at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M. tonight and tomorrow, with a $12.50 cover and a $5 minimum; on Sunday, sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., with a $10 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: CHARTER SETTLES S.E.C. CHARGE ON INFLATED PROFITS
description: The Charter Company, which filed for protection from its creditors last April, yesterday settled charges challenging its accounting practices by agreeing that it had inflated its profits for a three-year period by almost 30 percent.

title: BROADWAY
description: AN anniversary, an inauguration, Synge and a Burton - not a bad way for a theatrical company to begin a new year. In this case, it's the Roundabout Theater, celebrating its 20th anniversary with a brand-new 500- seat house at 100 East 17th Street. The inaugural on Jan. 30 will be the first performance of John Millington Synge's ''Playboy of the Western World'' with a cast headed by Kate Burton and Ken Marshall. Miss Burton will play Pegeen Mike, the innkeeper's daughter who competes with Widow Quinn (Karoline Kava) for the affections of the mysterious Christy Mahan (Mr. Marshall). The drama is being staged by Joe Dowling, artistic director of the Abbey Theater in Dublin , where the play had its premiere in 1907.

title: FRONTIER TRADING DELAY
description: Trading in the stock of Frontier Holdings Inc., parent of Frontier Airlines, was delayed for about three hours yesterday by the American Stock Exchange. The delay was caused by a report that the parent company's top executives and a key director had discussed the possibility of the carrier filing for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code within the next few weeks.

title: DATATRAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
OHIO MATTRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 5-to-4 stock split in January 1984. Results reflect the acquisitions of the Stearns & Foster Co. early in 1984 and the mid-year acquisition of Lifetime Foam Products Inc.

title: Young Entrepreneur Taps College Market
description: Many young people experience a major outbreak of the entrepreneurial spirit during their college days.

title: Topics ;   Cold / Cash ;   Guilt
description: There are people in this world who prefer cold weather, and one of them tuned into the late news Wednesday. It told of the 7,000 New Yorkers who sought beds in the city's shelters that night, among them a small boy who, when asked if he had a home, said ''Somewhere.''

title: U.S. CYCLISTS TESTED CAFFEINE AS AN AID
description: Some of the American cyclists under investigation for receiving blood-doping transfusions before their Olympic events last summer also experimented with caffeine to see whether whether it would enhance their performance, according to Dr. Irving Dardik, a top medical official of the United States Olympic Committee.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   A Political Note
description: Politics makes strange musical

title: DEL TORRO ANNOUNCES PLANS TO RUN FOR PRESIDENT OF CITY COUNCIL
description: Assemblyman Angelo Del Toro announced yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination for City Council president, declaring that his candidacy stood for ''the reconciliation of all people.''

title: WROK OF WARREN AND DUBIN EXAMINED IN SERIES
description: IN the summer of 1970, when

title: Ford Raises Its Dividend The Ford Motor Company
description: said that it had raised its regular quarterly dividend by 10

title: U.S. SENDS WARNING OF POTENTIAL THREAT TO ABORTION CLINICS
description: The Federal Government has issued a warning that is going to abortion clinics and medical offices around the country of a potential for violence Jan. 20-22.

title: Ex-G.E. Credit Official Joins Signal Companies
description: John W. Stanger, who recently resigned as vice chairman of the General Electric Credit Corporation, has joined the Signal Companies, where he will assume the new post of chairman of the Signal Capital Corporation, the company's financing and leasing arm.

title: HOW TO PHOTOGRAPH THE CITY IN WINTER
description: NEW YORK has long been a city of contrasts, and for the photographer - amateur or professional - the contrasts of the city in winter can have a very special appeal. From Central Park, a photographer's paradise no matter what the season, to Rockefeller Center, from Fifth Avenue's shops and strollers to a walk in SoHo, with its fascinating architecture of another era, the possibilities are endless.

title: SENATOR BLAMES CONGRESS FOR HIGH COST OF MILITARY
description: The chairman of a Senate subcommittee on military spending today denounced the increasingly popular idea of a freeze on the Pentagon budget and said Congress itself was largely to blame for the growing cost of the military.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dr. Joseph Haas Dead at 94; Served as Physician in Army
description: Dr. Joseph Haas, an Army physician who rose to the rank of brigadier general, died Wednesday at his home in Rye Brook, N.Y. He was 94 years old.

title: Power at an Exhibition
description: An unusual exhibition of photographs of prominent Washington personalities will have its press preview today at the Corcoran Gallery. It features portraits of more than 500 people who, according to promotional material, ''hold the reins of power in Washington,'' from President Reagan to lawmakers and judges to representatives of the news media.

title: Maker to Note Aspirin Risk
description: Plough Inc., which produces the St. Joseph line of aspirin products, said today that it would cooperate with a Government request that bottles warn consumers of a possible link between the pain reliever and the children's disease Reye's Syndrome, whose symptoms are sudden vomiting, often with fever. Other manufacturers said they were waiting to review scientific studies. The manufacturer of Bayer aspirin said the changes warned of a problem that has not been established.

title: National Museum Gets 311 Art Works
description: The National Museum of American Art announced today that it has received a gift of more than 300 works of modern art by the Container Corporation of America, a subsidiary of Mobil Corporation.

title: SHULTZ URGES U.S. NOT TO CUT BACK ON ARMS OUTLAY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told Congress today that progress in the new arms negotiations with the Soviet Union required continued spending for the MX missile and the $26 billion space-defense research plan.

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
People
description: Russell J. Melvin has been named director of international affairs for the Magazine Publishers Association.

title: Trio in Brooklyn
description: The bassist Reggie Workman will lead a trio, with Ken McIntyre on saxophones, clarinets and flutes and Akbar Ali on violin, tonight at 8 P.M. at BACA (Brooklyn Arts and Culture Association) Downtown, 111 Willoughby Street in Brooklyn (718) 596- 2222. Tickets are $5.

title: MARYLAND IN LINE TO GET GRAHAM
description: The University of Maryland apparently is one of two schools in the running for Michael Graham, the 6-foot- 9-inch forward who recently withdrew from Georgetown University, the school with the nation's top- ranked basketball team.

title: Rockettes Picket Radio City Music Hall
description: Chanting ''Save the Rockettes'' and waving placards, representatives of the dance group staged a demonstration outside Radio City Music Hall yesterday afternoon to protest their exclusion from next summer's shows.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE poet Oliver Wendell Holmes wrote that the only things that keep their youth ''as far as I know, are a tree and truth.'' Had he been a restaurant reviewer, he might have added the corollary: ''and only the rarest of restaurants.''

title: POP: KOOL AND THE GANG IN FISHER HALL
description: AT a time when pop-soul music is more dependent than ever on rigid instrumental and songwriting formulas, Kool and the Gang transcend the cliches of the moment while managing to keep their collective finger on the pulse of the commercial mainstream. One of the secrets of their music's freshness is its strong underpinnings in jazz.

title: CAMERON IRON WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: SMOKING DANGEROUS TO NONSMOKERS ALSO
description: To the Editor:

title: KAFFEEKLATSCH, YEMENI-STYLE
description: Jet black eyes peered from above a veil, as the young woman, dressed in black from nose to toes, rang the doorbell of her friend's house.

title: LAWMAKERS FAULT KEY PART OF CUOMO'S FISCAL PACKAGE
description: Even as Governor Cuomo today began his campaign to win support for ''comprehensive financial reform,'' key lawmakers said the central element of his plan stood little chance of passage.

title: BURNHAM SERVICE CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
WAS THERE A MESSAGE IN THE IRT SHOOTINGS?
description: To the Editor: With a rare unanimity, New York

title: ACTORS' UNION CHARGES BIAS BY INAUGURATION COMMITTEE
description: The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists has charged the Presidential Inaugural Committee with discrimination for its decision to use nonunion entertainers at the inaugural festivies.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 11, 1985 International

title: Volcker Optimistic On Outlook
description: Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve's chairman, said today that the nation seems to have turned the corner in the fight against inflation, giving the central bank more flexibility in managing credit conditions.

title: DATAMETRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TEXACO'S OFFERED PRICE FOR U.S. OIL CUT BY $1
description: Texaco Inc. yesterday cut the price it will pay for the most common kind of American oil by $1 a barrel, reflecting continued weakness in the markets and the expectations of many traders that prices will drop further.

title: LAIDLAW TRANSPORTATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a special gain of $5,023,000.

title: Rexnord Offer Oversubscribed
description: Rexnord Inc. said that about 3.7 million shares of Electronic Modules Corporation common stock had been tendered in response to Rexnord's offer to buy 2.5 million shares at $18.50 a share.

title: WORLD BANK TAKES SEX DISCRIMINATION SERIOUSLY
description: To the Editor:

title: DOW UP BY 20.76, TO 1,223.50
description: Stocks soared yesterday in heavy trading after Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, reiterated at a luncheon meeting that inflation was continuing under control.

title: Fear of AIDS Cancels Blood Drive on Coast
description: Despite a critical blood shortage in southern California, a Red Cross official says he has canceled a lesbian blood drive because he does not want to lose the good will of other donors over the fear of contracting acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: Sentimental Vote
description: D. Wayne Lukas was not pleased with the outcome of the Eclipse Award balloting for champion trainer this week. Lukas's runners won nine Grade I stakes last year and earned a record $5.1 million, but that was only good enough for third place in the voting. Lukas finished behind Jack Van Berg, who led the nation with 278 victories but was fifth on the earnings list, and Woody Stephens, who was second in earnings.

title: MEDIEVAL MUSICAL DRAMA FOR NOW
description: ''NOW most people think of matins as getting up at 5 in the morning - you know, monastic hours,'' Paul C. Echols said, ''but I can assure you that if you were going to enhance matins with a play and music, you didn't do it at 5 in the morning.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: 123 pages. Farrar Straus Giroux.

title: THE BUMPURS CASE
description: To the Editor:

title: 234-Mile U.S. Waterway Opens for Shipments
description: The Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway opened to commercial traffic today as four barges carrying petroleum products passed the dock where President Nixon announced the $2 billion project nearly 14 years ago.

title: A BLOODBATH DEEPENS
description: When the Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment in 1976 - 38 states now authorize it, including four by hanging and four by firing squad - I believed there would be few executions, that the public wanted criminals

title: VERMONT'S NEW GOVERNOR CONFRONTS DEVELOPMENT AND BUDGET PROBLEMS
description: Madeleine M. Kunin, the first woman to be Governor of Vermont, took the oath of office today, pledging to balance fiscal prudence with a humane concern for creating more jobs for the poor, improving education and protecting the environment.

title: The Mets' Move
description: It's the Mets' move in the negotiations for a new contract for Dwight

title: WIFE SAYS EX-F.B.I. AGENT HELD AS SPY IS INNOCENT
description: The wife of the only agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation ever to be charged with espionage denies the bureau's contention that her husband was motivated by ''financial problems.''

title: WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FAMILIES CELEBRATE THE SEASON WITH GIFTS FOR NEEDIEST CASES
description: Buoyed by the joy of holiday gatherings, many families choose to celebrate the season by contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: TIPS ABOUT CAMERAS FOR A COLD DAY
description: A few decades ago, using garden- variety 35-millimeter single-lens reflex cameras in freezing weather was chancy. Commonly, lens mounts would lock and shutters stick. But today's lubricants have eliminated many of the problems of mechanical reliability, and special ''winterizing'' is no longer necessary. Still, you should keep your camera, lenses and other equipment from freezing by keeping them under a parka and close to your body when not in use to protect your batteries.

title: CONSERVATIVES SEEKING STOCK OF CBS TO ALTER 'LIBERAL BIAS'
description: Senator Jesse Helms is helping to organize an effort by conservative investors to buy sufficient stock in CBS to change what the North Carolina Republican says is the ''liberal bias'' in coverage by CBS News of ''political events, personages and views.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The clientele of the Human Resources Administration is like no other.

title: WEST GERMANY SAID TO APPROVE MULTINATIONAL SPACE STATION PLAN
description: The West German Government has agreed to approve a multibillion-dollar space development program that would pave the way for European participation in a United States project to put a manned space station in orbit by the end of the century, officials said today.

title: Dining Out Guide: Four-Star Restaurants
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

Trustees May Sell Hughes Aircraft
description: Trustees of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute indicated today that they were moving ahead with plans to sell part or all of the Hughes Aircraft Company, either to another company or through a public offering.

title: GENERAL TO LEAVE TOP LATIN POSITION
description: Gen. Paul F. Gorman, the commander of United States forces in Latin America and a major strategist of the Administration's military activities in Central America, will retire this year, the Defense Department said today.

title: CITY IS PLANNING TO REOPEN LANE ON W. 44TH ST.
description: A cleanup crew will have cleared enough rubble to allow the reopening of at least one lane of 44th Street between the Avenue of the Americas and Broadway by late today, the Buildings Commissioner said yesterday.

title: TROTTIER GOALS PACE ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders were challenged strongly throughout by the Devils at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight, and had to play mistake-free hockey after scoring a late goal to secure a 3-2 victory.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. A listing for the my-how-time-flies department: Darryl Dawkins, one of the very few players who have joined the National Basketball Association right out of high school, will be 28 years old today.

title: Transactions
description: Released Rodney Craig, outfielder. Sold Juan Espino, catcher, to the Yankees. Signed Butch Benton, catcher, Orlando Sanchez, first baseman-outfielder, and Dave Von Ohlen and Craig Pippin, pitchers, to contracts with Maine of the International League.

title: Publisher Is Wed To Miss Tannen
description: Melissa Tannen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon J. Tannen of New York, was married yesterday to Stephen Henry Weitzen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Weitzen, also of New York. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony in his study at Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan.

title: BRIEFS
description: Anheuser-Busch Inc., St. Louis, the brewing subsidiary of Anheuser- Busch Companies Inc., said 1984 beer sales rose 5.8 percent, to 64 million barrels, from 60.5 million barrels in 1983.

title: Douglas Dales, 77, Reporter With The Times for 21 Years
description: Douglas S. Dales, a reporter for The New York Times for 21 years and later director of public relations for the New York state police, died Wednesday at his home in Schenectady, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

title: 'Last Dance'

title: Flutie Leaning Toward Generals
description: Doug Flutie is close to making a deal with the Generals, because the offer they have made is ''extraordinary,'' Bob Woolf, the quarterback's lawyer, said yesterday.

title: Theft-Ring Sweep Brings 18 Arrests
description: Federal authorities in New Jersey and New York today arrested 18 people accused of participating in a burglary ring reputedly headed by members of the Genovese and Colombo organized-crime families.

title: Korean Songs
description: Pansori songs of Korea - operatic solos - and Korean instrumental music will be heard tonight at 8 at the Alternative Museum, 17 White Street (966-4444), and Sunday at 2:30 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Uris Auditorium, Fifth Avenue. at 81st Street (663-0584). Tickets are $8, or a Theater Development Fund voucher plus $3.50, at the Alternative Museum, and $7 ( or a voucher plus $2.50) or $5 for students and the elderly at the Metropolitan Museum.

title: VON SCHAMANN FINDS REASON FOR HOPE
description: There is no poll to prove that the man in the street has stopped sneering at Uwe von Schamann of the Miami Dolphins, who had the worst record this season among full-time place-kickers in the National Football League.

title: FIRST WOMEN TAKES OVER THE TOP JOB IN VERMONT
description: Madeleine May Kunin's new office is lined with portraits of somber, unsmiling men in dark frock coats, men with side whiskers, men in modern business suits. They are the former Governors of Vermont, stretching back almost two centuries.

title: ROGERS CABLESYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $10,171,000 for the latest year and $1,028,000 for the previous year and a loss of $3,744,000 for the latest year on the sale of the company's Irish operations.

title: TIME DENIES IT LIBELED SHARON DESPITE ERROR
description: Time magazine's chief lawyer told a jury yesterday that a disputed article contained a mistake about Ariel Sharon but that it did not libel him.

title: IN TORONTO, THE JOKE IS ON THE LEAFS
description: Once, the Toronto Maple Leafs strode across this northern city like giants. Kids got up before dawn to stand in line for tickets, Saturday night parties were scheduled to begin only after Leaf games had ended, and season tickets were coveted inheritances.

title: 1984 REVENUES DISAPPOINT EXECUTIVES OF ATLANTIC CITY CASINOS
description: Despite record business in December, casino revenues in 1984 fell substantially short of forecasts.

description: The Violent Universe,'' a film narrated by Vincent Price, opens today at the Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 81st Street.

title: NUNS' SUPERIORS ASK MODERATION BY THE VATICAN
description: The heads of the orders of 24 nuns whom the Vatican has threatened with expulsion because of their views on abortion issued a joint statement of concern yesterday for the nuns that stopped short of taking any side.

title: Near Miss
description: Trent Tucker and Darrell Walker, the Knick guards, hardly look alike. But a case of mistaken identity almost put an end to Tucker's 3-point basket streak as he was on his way to tying the National Basketball Association season mark of eight in a row Wednesday night in Denver.

title: Testimonial Drive For Newspaper
description: On Monday, USA Today will begin to run the first phase of a new campaign from Lois, Pitts, Gershon in which George Lois, its chairman, has once again resorted to the multiple-testimonial ploy he successfully used in the distant past on behalf of the brokerage firm of Edwards & Hanley and Braniff Airways.

title: Back in Lineup
description: Curtis High, the Nevada-Reno guard who leads the Big Sky Conference in scoring, was suspended from the team Dec. 26, having been arrested on charges of beating his a female friend. But now he has been returned to the lineup, less than a week before his arraignment on three misdemeanor counts of battery.

title: SALVADOR SAID TO BREAK GUNSHIP PACT
description: The Salvadoran Air Force is said to have used a second American-supplied aircraft as a gunship this week, apparently undercutting an understanding between the Reagan Administration and Congress.

title: Youth Shot by Goetz Remains in a Coma
description: One of the four teen-agers shot by Bernhard Hugo Goetz on a subway train last month remained in a coma yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center.
