title: 'THE REAL WORLD NOW'
description: When the police investigator took the college basketball star into the interrogation room in December, he used some of the carrot-and-stick techniques that most people see only on television crime shows.

title: TREATING THE HONDURAS AS A VASSAL STATE
description: When he walks on to his elegant balustraded terrace, the new United States Ambassador to Honduras will look down on the dingy houses of the shabbiest capital of the poorest country on the American continent. Dominating the squalid city below, the ambassadorial mansion symbolizes perfectly the relationship between Honduras and the United States. It is a relationship that Hondurans of all classes increasingly resent.

title: A Record Rise for Money Funds
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds continued their advance of the last quarter of 1984, rising by $6.69 billion, to $218.08 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: A New Chance at Interior Donald Hodel, the designated Secretary of Interior, is an avid skier, effective administrator and likable fellow. But there's a worrisome flaw in his judgment: He's a pushover for white elephants.
description: One of his major efforts while Secretary of Energy was to fight for the Clinch River breeder reactor, an $8 billion project whose technology and economics were so outmoded that even the nuclear industry wasn't prepared to shoulder more than a token fraction of its costs.

title: Fire Kills 4 Brothers
description: Four young brothers died in a fire early Wednesday after a neighbor and a passing truck driver, trying to rescue them, were stopped by intense heat and heavy smoke. The brothers were Shane Robert Essex, 5 years old, Jeremy Allen Essex, 3, and Randall Dean and Derry Lee Essex, twins who were 2 years old.

title: REPRISE FOR 'SECRET PASTURES,' A POPULIST SCORE
description: DURING a typical New York arts season, dozens of musical works are written and performed, then disappear into limbo. They are scores for plays, dances, films, videotapes or an ever-widening assortment of multimedia projects, many of which are mounted only a few times. The scores, meanwhile, get shelved in a composer's archives while the next project is completed; only a small percentage of the music reaches recording studios.

title: CHEMICAL UP 19.8% IN FOURTH QUARTER
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, the first of the major banking companies to report its fourth-quarter results, yesterday announced a 19.8 percent gain in net income, to $105.5 million, from $88.1 million in the comparable period of 1983. On a per-share basis, net income climbed 16 percent, to $2.03, from $1.75.

title: New England Life Unit Eurobonds

description: A Federal district judge today ruled unconstitutional a Louisiana law requiring that the biblical theory of creationism be given equal time in public schools alongside Darwin's theory of evolution.

AUCTIONS
description: A BRASS band will play and loudspeakers will blare at the festive preview Feb. 14 of a two-day auction of the vintage displays from Circus World, an amusement park built by Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey in Orlando, Fla. Arlan Ettinger, who heads Guernsey's, organizer of the auction, describes the sale - Feb. 16-17 at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street - as the largest auction ever held of rare old circus, carousel and arcade carvings and equipment.

title: CYPRUS FOES SAID TO AGREE ON OUTLINE OF PACT
description: Greek and Turkish Cypriot leaders have agreed on the outline of an agreement to establish a federal republic, senior diplomats reported today, but important issues remain to be resolved.

title: A.T.&T. ASKS INCREASE FOR PRIVATE CABLE RATES
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday sought permission to increase rates on private lines - the big, dedicated communications cables used by thousands of corporations - if A.T.&T.'s own cost of providing the cables goes up in February, as it expects.

description: Alfred Smith Forsyth, a retired New York lawyer, died of emphysema last Saturday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 76 years old.

description: A new kerosene heater on the market has achieved a ''breakthrough'' in safety, reducing certain hazardous air pollutants by 50 percent to 90 percent, the Consumer Product Safety Commission reported today.

Trip for Swimmer
description: Don Gambrill , 1984 Olympic swimming coach, said that a former member of the East German swim team who defected to the United States was en route last night to Tucaloosa, Ala., where he may be offered a scholarship at the University of Alabama.

title: Skins Game Out
description: Plans for a weekly Skins Game at various PGA Tour sites during 1985 have been cancelled for lack of sponsorship for now, according to Deane Beman, the tour's commissioner. However, the annual four-man Skins Game in November will continue for the third straight year.

description: The head of an American trade delegation said today that he was optimistic about the possibilities for a meeting between Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige and the Soviet Foreign Trade Minister, Nikolai S. Patolichev.

description: No regrets. True or not, that always seemed to be the Transit Authority's attitude when it came to delays plaguing thousands and thousands of riders.

description: The Federal Election Commission today gave five of the Democrats who lost their campaigns for the Presidency an extra month to submit their final requests for matching money to defray their campaign debts.

title: DEMOCRATS SHUN IDEA OF BLOCKING SOCIAL SECURITY INCREASE FOR 1986
description: Congressional Democrats today opposed the idea, gaining support among some senior Republican senators, that Social Security recipients should forgo any cost- of-living increase in 1986.

description: President Reagan today announced the appointment of three new Cabinet officers and the shift of a top assistant to the No. 2 job in the Treasury Department.

title: CHERRY ELECTRICAL PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Market Place ;   Some Caution On Food Issues
description: Shares of packaged and diversified food companies were regarded not too long ago as stodgy investments that suffered from high inflation and other pressures. But that view began to change in the autumn of 1980, as commodity costs started to decline for the producers. As a result, their cash flow improved and balance sheets became stronger, while both profits and profit margins rose. Many food issues responded by forging ahead on a sustained basis.

title: DANCE: BART COOK'S 'SEVEN BY FIVE' AT CITY BALLET
description: ONE of the balmiest places in town on Wednesday night was the New York State Theater, where the New York City Ballet presented Bart Cook's new ''Seven by Five'' for the first time in New York City. Mr. Cook is a popular principal dancer with the City Ballet. The work, which is set to Saint-Sa"ens's Septet, (Op. 65), is his first ballet. And to judge from the cheers that greeted the five dancers at their curtain calls, City Ballet has a hit on its hands.

title: Economic Scene ;   5-Year Budget Projections
description: At his news conference Wednesday night, President Reagan urged the press to ''rally around and help with a few editorials'' in support of his position that the Administration should no longer be required by Congress to submit five-year budget projections.

title: FORDHAM HOLDS OFF COLUMBIA

Mr. Reagan's See-Through Budget In the 1980 campaign, John Anderson said Ronald Reagan's plan to cut taxes, raise defense spending and also balance the budget could only be done with mirrors. At his press conference Wednesday night, Mr. Reagan held the mirror up for all to see. It was transparent.
description: As the 1984 campaign ended, the Administration was forecasting a $174 billion deficit in the next fiscal year. A few days after Mr. Reagan's landslide triumph, budget officials suddenly discovered that a $210 billion deficit was more likely, and the estimates may be headed still higher.

title: Topics ;   Cold / Cash ;   Two CommasWhat do Fred Smith, the founder of Federal Express, and Michael Jackson, the spectacularly popular singer, have in common? Each made more than $50 million in 1983, according to Forbes magazine, and that puts both at the top of a new category of workers.
description: The Ford Motor Company's Philip Caldwell, who earned $7.3 million, belongs in the same category. So do George Foster of the New York Mets and Dave Winfield of the New York Yankees, who are each making about $1.8 million this year.

The conservative ones, at least, are just the sort of music that Zubin Mehta conducts best. And play them well he did, with a noble assist from the orchestra.

description: A look at contemporary Chinese movies will be offered on Fridays at 8, starting tonight, at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue at 70th Street. Those from China begin the series, starting with ''The River Without Buoys'' (1983), about three loggers who raft down the Xiao River in Hunan. The beautiful scenery contrasts with the harsh stories that emerge, partly in flashback, about their experiences in the Cultural Revolution. title: ESTIMATE BOARD APPROVES PLAN FOR UNION SQUARE
description: The Board of Estimate early today approved a special zoning district for Union Square, once Manhattan's grandest residential and shopping district but now considered by the city to be one of the most blighted. It also approved the first special permit for a new building within the district, a 26-story residential and commerical complex on the site of the old S. Klein store. The approval came on a 9-to-2 vote shortly after 1 A.M., with Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin voting against it. It was a compromise between some community members who opposed it and William Zeckendorf, Jr., the developer of the new building. Opponents had said that a special zoning district, intended by the city to encourage development in vacant and underused sites, would lead to overcrowding, displacement, soaring propery prices and destruction of historic buildings.

description: Talks between Brazil and its bank creditors about rescheduling the country's debt were expected to continue over the weekend, as both sides tried to wrap up a multiyear rescheduling agreement for about $50 billion in borrowing, a banker close to the talks said yesterday.

title: PRODUCER PRICES ROSE BY ONLY 0.1% DURING DECEMBER
description: The Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, the leading measure of industrial price changes, edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in December, the Labor Department reported yesterday. The increase put the inflation rate for producer prices at only 1.8 percent for all of 1984.

description: Kent T. Healy, Thomas DeWitt Cuyler Professor Emeritus of Transportation at Yale University, died Wednesday at the Sound View Convalescent Center in West Haven, Conn. He was 82 years old and had been convalescing after a heart attack in the autumn.

The real story of Operation Pressure Point, though, concerns the residents of this scourged area, the people who hung on, who fought and who eventually reversed the degeneration of their neighborhood. Unless the city acts quickly, however, the last chapter may ultimately explain that their great victory was Pyrrhic after all.

The Carl Lewis seen on television last summer during the Olympics was less sartorially resplendent. That Carl Lewis cavorted in red shorts and a red U.S.A. undershirt. The Carl Lewis today is and is not the same one who at age 23 in Los Angeles won four gold medals in track and field - tying Jesse Owens's mark - and did it amid cheers but also boos.

title: The Hard Year for Argentina

Yet here he is heading into his second year with his popularity - and Argentina's credit - intact. He has skated superbly over the thinnest of ice by postponing the reckoning that will now be the real test of his leadership.

That momentum must continue in 1985.

DE GUSTIBUS ;   CRISIS CALLS FROM A BRIDE'S KITCHEN
description: Occasionally my daughter will call me from Boston for some cooking advice. She may want a collection of diet recipes or a recipe for a fancy cake. But she never asks how to make egg salad or how to cook a hamburger. (In the days when my son called, it was only to find out what combinations of vegetables and grains provided complete protein for a vegetarian.) My daughter's calls are a far cry from the ones my best friend placed to her mother when she was a bride - a bride who had not cooked more than 10 or 15 times before marriage. She made her first long-distance call within a week or two of setting up housekeeping. Her questions involved a whole chicken. She had received an indoor rotisserie as a wedding gift, one of those so-called portable appliances that weigh so much it takes two people to lift them. My friend's mother explained in seemingly endless detail about rinsing the chicken, salting it and arranging it on the skewer. Her father, who filled the traditional role of outdoor cook, had to get on the line to explain how the chicken should be placed so that it was evenly balanced. But neither could tell precisely how long to cook the chicken because they had no experience with an indoor rotisserie (the accompanying directions did not include recipes). As it turned out, they omitted another, even more significant, piece of information.

It said the domestic nuclear industry and the state of New Jersey were the final two of a total of nine sources in the financing plan. The industry contribution was obtained under the auspices of the Edison Electric Institute, an electric utility industry trade group that has started a program in which utilities throughout the country are paying $25 million a year for six years to help finance the cleanup.
