description: NBI Inc., a major producer of computers and office equipment, will acquire Computer Consoles Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $160 million, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Snow Job
description: Tom Nieporte, the 56-year-old head pro at the Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y., plays a little hooky from his primary job during the year to play in tournaments, and one he has not missed is the Bob Hope Classic, which he won in 1967, shortly after giving up playing on the PGA Tour on a regular basis. Nieporte has played in all 26 Hope Classics, including the one under way at Palm Springs, Calif.

title: STADLER POSTS A 64, LEADS BY 3 STROKES
description: Craig Stadler tied the Bermuda Dunes Country Club course record of eight-under-par 64 today to gain a three-shot lead after three rounds of the 26th annual Bob Hope Classic.

title: Czech Defense Chief Retires
description: Martin Dzur, who had been Czechoslovak Defense Minister since 1968, retired today because of ill health, the official Czechoslovak press agency reported. Milan Vaclavik, 56 years old, first deputy chief of the army General Staff, replaced him, the agency added.

title: MUSIC: MINNESOTA OPERA, 'ANIMALEN'
description: The Ordway Music Theater, St. Paul's dramatic attempt to draw the city's physical and artistic elements into one clear and central light, opened to the public this week with presentations by the people who will use it most.

title: Iraq Says Its Jets Strike 2 Targets in Gulf
description: Iraq said its warplanes attacked two ''naval targets'' today in the Persian Gulf near the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg Island. There was no immediate word from shipping sources in the gulf of any ships in difficulties today.

title: Claudia Cohen, Reporter, Weds Ronald Perelman
description: Claudia Cohen and Ronald O. Perelman were married yesterday at the bridegroom's home in Manhattan. Judge Marie M. Lambert of the Manhattan Surrogate Court officiated, assisted by Cantor Joseph Malovany.

title: FOR THE PUBLIC IN CANADA, THE PRIVACY WATCHDOG
description: When an employee of Canada's Employment and Immigration Commission requested a disability parking permit, she was instructed to fill out a blanket medical form, including such details as her mental health, alcohol intake and family medical problems.

title: Books of The Times;   The Real and Fantastic
description: THINGS INVISIBLE TO SEE. By Nancy Willard. 263 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95.

title: And Thanks, but. . .
description: It might have been minor sabotage

title: WTC INTERNATIONAL N.V.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year ago results are stated on a pro forma basis due to the merger of WTC Inc. into WTC International N.V. on March 31.

title: DATAPOINT ASKS CLARIFICATION OF BID
description: A New York investor who has made an informal offer to buy the Datapoint Corporation, a San Antonio-based computer company, has been asked to put his offer in writing, insiders said yesterday.

title: A.T.&T. IS REDUCING PRICES ON SLOW-SELLING TELEPHONES
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is cutting prices on its most advanced home telephones to sell off unsuccessful products and to shore up its position in the telephone market.

title: After the Party in Hartford
description: Opening day in the Connecticut Legislature usually belongs to the Governor, but this year's belonged to the new Republican majority. Back in power after 10 years of Democratic domination and itching to take on Gov. William O'Neill, the Republicans brought in bands, choristers, bright red boutonnieres and a jewel-studded ebony elephant from Sri Lanka. Now the fun is over. The time for accountability has arrived.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: JAZZ The Heavenly Jazz series gives every indication of living up to its name with the performance scheduled for 5 P.M. tomorrow at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street (369-8040). Dave McKenna, who rarely comes to town, but for a gig at Hanratty's, will be at the center of the program. His partners, luminaries who stand in nobody's shadow, will be Al Cohn and Zoot Sims, the virtuosos of the tenor saxophone.

title: ANTHEM ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORVUS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: DISPUTE FLARES OVER HARVEST OF PRISTINE NATIONAL FORESTS
description: McKENZIE BRIDGE, Ore. - This is the forest primeval. But whether it should remain that way is a matter of intense dispute between the Reagan Administration, which wants to speed the harvest of virgin timber from the National Forests, and conservationists who seek an emphasis on recreation and protecting wildlife.

title: KING HURTS ANKLE AS KNICKS LOSE
description: The Knicks never had a chance tonight against Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls. They lost Bernard King with a sprained right ankle midway in the first period, and with no one to pick up the scoring slack, the Knicks were beaten, 113-97, at Chicago Stadium.

title: TOTAL SYSTEM SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S and Europe in Steel Pact
description: The United States trade representative, Bill Brock, confirmed today that the United States and the European Economic Community had agreed to a plan to restrict exports of steel pipe and tube to the United States.

title: COVERING THE CASE OF BERNHARD GOETZ
description: ''Enough already!'' snapped a middle-aged man, waving off a reporter and striding into his apartment building.

title: KANSAS CITY MAY LOSE KINGS
description: Gregg Lukenbill, the real-estate developer who bought the Kansas City Kings with a group of associates in June 1983, has given the clearest indication yet that he plans to seek permission from the National Basketball Association to move the team next season to Sacramento, Calif., his hometown.

title: SNOW DISRUPTS JERSEY TRAFFIC
description: A low-pressure system from Virginia brought snow to the New York metropolitan area yesterday, lightly dusting the city and Connecticut but blanketing parts of New Jersey with more than six inches.

title: LENDL DEFEATS NYSTROM TO ADVANCE TO SEMIFINAL
description: In 1984, Ivan Lendl lost about 15 pounds and the added weight of never having won a major championship. But if winning the French Open made him less defensive and a new diet added spring to his step, he still looked very much the same to opponents who had to confront his intimidating hard flat serve and the bullwhip forehand that Lendl uses as the great equalizer.

title: RECHARGED NETS TOP HAWKS
description: On the heels of their first two- a-day practice session since the exhibition season, the Nets brought one of their healthiest lineups to Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight and played one of their strongest games, routing the Atlanta Hawks with a terrorizing defense, 122-103.

title: Theater Benefit For Mabou Mines
description: A benefit for the Mabou Mines theater collective will be held Monday at 7:30 P.M. at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Sundberg Stays Put
description: Jim Sundberg , the talented catcher who wanted to return to the Rangers, will remain with the Milwaukee Brewers instead because a trade could not be completed, the Texas club announced yesterday. Sundberg played for the Rangers for 10 years before being traded to Milwaukee in 1983, but his efforts in recent weeks to return to them got bogged down in three-way talks.

title:
PATENTS;

Using Voice to Adjust An Air-Conditioner
description: Apparatus for controlling an air- conditioner by voice was patented this week by two Japanese inventors.

title: PETROLEUM & RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Results reflect capital gains distributions of $2.27 paid in February 1984 and $1.87 in 1983.

title: PIER 1 IMPORTS INC.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $487,000. c-Including a tax credit of $2,718,000. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of a nursery concern in July 1983.

title: PLANT'S COLOR SHIFTS TIED TO ATTRACTING POLLINATORS
description: Experiments by biologists in Arizona have revealed that some flowering plants will change the color of their flowers to attract insects to pollinate their blooms.

title: INTECH INC reports earnings for 12wks to Dec 7
description: b-After extraordinary credits for the quarter and 9 months. c-After a one-time gain of $145,000 from reversal of accrued taxes on the company's DISC.

title: CLAYTON HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid Oct. 18, 1984.

title: SORG PRINTING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, JANUARY 12, 1985
description: The Economy

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: KELLER OF TEEN-AGERS IS EXECUTIED IN CAROLINA
description: Minutes after asking God to ''bless and forgive'' those who wanted him to die, Joseph Carl Shaw was electrocuted early today for two murders he admitted committing in 1977. He was the first person to be put to death in South Carolina in nearly 23 years.

title: McCallum of Navy Awarded Extra Year
description: Napoleon McCallum, the senior running back who was only 84 yards away from a Navy career rushing record when he broke his ankle in the second game of the 1984 season, will be allowed to play another year of football, the Naval Academy announced today.

title: A Former Convict Is Indicted In Coast Boy's Imprisonment
description: A former convict was indicted today on charges of kidnapping and child molesting in the 1983 abduction of a California boy discovered by the police and reunited with his family this week.

title: White-Collar Vandalism on 44th St.
description: Under cover of darkness, vandals with powerful machinery stole this week into the center of Manhattan and ripped apart four old low-rise buildings. They violated municipal codes and used forbidden techniques, risking their workers' lives. They blithely ignored gas pipes, thereby endangering the public. The rubble they left continues to block part of 44th Street.

title: SCOUTING ;   Drive to Win
description: There's obviously a future in Fords. Or perhaps J. Walter Thompson, Ford's advertising agency, could make almost as much money betting in Las Vegas as it makes on Madison Avenue.

title:
Patents;

Computer Network System
description: A multi-computer communications system was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The inventors listed in patent 4,493,021 are Anil K. Agrawal, Philip G. Mullen and V.V. Vadakan, engineers at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif.

title: SMALL PAPERS FEEL THE CHILL OF LIBEL SUITS MOST
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
GENERAL MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
description: Results for the 9-month period are for 39 weeks for the latest period and 40 weeks for the period a year ago.

title: 'Home Front' to Close
description: The play ''Home Front,'' starring Carroll O'Connor and Frances Sternhagen, will close following tonight's performance at 8 o'clock at the Royale Theater, 242 West 45th Street.

title: Printers' Union Announces Merger Pact in the Industry
description: The International Typographical Union said today that a merger agreement had been reached with the Graphic Communications International Union that would create a 250,000-member organization of printing industry workers.

title: No Headline
description: SATURDAY, JANUARY 12, 1985 International

title: ABORTION CLINIC OWNER WARNS OF ARMED DEFENSE
description: A leading advocate of abortion rights said today that abortion clinics had posted armed guards and stocked guns as part of a plan to prevent the bombing of their facilities.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF GENERAL JARUZELSKI
description: I note with interest that the Polish General Jaruzelski, as pictured on the cover of The New York Times Magazine of Dec. 9, wears his Russian medals ahead of the Polish Virtuti Militari (blue and black ribbon).

title: SCHOOLS RESISTING SELECTIVE SERVICE
description: FREDERICK W. PALOMBA, the state director of the Federal Selective Service, says his intention in asking Connecticut high schools to provide him with lists of seniors in November was to provide a service to the students.

title: JERSEY-BATTERY FERRY
description: To the Editor:

title: SUDDENLY, TWO 'ROMEO AND JULIETS'
description: In case you don't know the story of ''Romeo and Juliet,''

title: AGENT ORANGE STUDIES GO ON
description: ''THE wind would blow the oily spray back on you through the open doors of the helicopter,'' Frank Garofalo said, recalling his seven months with a chemical platoon in Vietnam.

title: CARIBBEAN CRUISES WITH A SOMBER PURPOSE
description: This is the time of balmy weather and smooth seas in the Caribbean and the Gulf of Mexico, the peak season for vacation cruises. It is also the time for Soviet and United States naval maneuvers. Late last month, five Soviet ships sailed into Havana harbor for what American intelligence officers expect will be several weeks of joint exercises with the Cuban Navy. Last week, the nuclear-powered aircraft carrier Nimitz left Norfolk, Va., for the Caribbean to show the flag off the coast of Central America. Also planned is another United States combat exercise in the region, involving 5,000 members of the Army, Navy, Coast Guard, Marines and Air Force.

title: THE WORLD ;   El SalvadorTries Gunships
description: Despite warnings from human rights groups that attacks from the air often mean civilian casualties, the Reagan Administration has been buiding up El Salvador's Air Force in hopes of shifting the balance in the guerrilla war. Last week, the buildup seemed to be spinning out of Washington's control.

title: 46 MORE SPECIES ARE PUT ON ENDANGERED LIST
description: The Interior Department's Fish and Wildlife Service has announced that it has added 46 native and foreign species to the endangered list, including the woodstork and the woodland caribou in this country and the giant panda in China.

title: New Fighting Reported In Cambodia Rebel Camp
description: New fighting was reported today in the Cambodian rebel camp of Rithisen.

title: Explosion in a Polish Market Is Reported to Kill At Least 6
description: A gas explosion ripped through a crowded meat market in a Warsaw suburb Saturday, killing at least six people and injuring about 30 others, official news organizations reported.

title: 'Mysterious Shakespeare'
description: To the Editor:

title: DEVILS WIN, 5-3, FROM THE CAPITALS
description: An unexpectedly strong game from a seldom-used goalie, Hannu Kamppuri, helped the Devils score a 5-3 victory over the Washington Capitals today and allowed New Jersey to continue a curious streak.

title: ;   TOPICS
description: I received homemade cookies as gifts this past holiday season. They were absolutely delicious cookies. ''I'm grateful and appreciative for such a lovely gift,'' I wrote in my thank-you notes.

title: FLIP A COIN: MOTHER OR TEACHER?
description: HEADS: I'm a teacher. Tails: I'm a parent. Deep in contemplation, I gently palm my two-sided coin back and forth, from hand to hand.

title: Headliners ;
description: Touchy Visit White officialdom, and some blacks, gave

title: THE IGNORANT GENIUS
description: Technological genius is one of the

title:
ART;

SHOWCASE FOR 16 DIVERSE, CHALLENGING YOUNG ARTISTS
description: EVERY young artist hopes for recognition and seeks opportunities for public display. With this in mind, the Wunsch Arts Center, aided by a grant from the North Shore Community Art Endowment Fund, recently undertook a competition open to all artists under 30 who are unaffiliated with a gallery. The selection committee, headed by Jeanne Paris, chose 16 applicants from the metropolitan area to participate in an awards exhibition, titled ''Young Faces Going Places.''

title: REAGAN'S NEXT TERM
description: William Safire is a columnist for The New York Times.

title: F.B.I. Official Cites Depletion Of Crime Leaders in Cleveland
description: Only a few leaders of Cleveland's Mafia are left to run what was once one of the most powerful organized crime units in the nation, an official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation says.

title: SLUGGER WITH A SWORD
description: The first robin of spring has

title: STEPCHILDREN ON PANEL TELL PARENTS HOW IT IS
description: The 14-year-old boy in the T-shirt and unlaced running shoes shifted nervously in his swivel chair, leaned forward to face a room filled with people who had remarried and began to tell what it was really like to grow up in a stepfamily.

title: F.B.I. AGENT SAYS HE INTENDED TO INFILTRATE K.G.B.
description: A former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, accused of spying for the Soviet Union, testified today that he told his superiors about his contacts with two Russian emigres because he thought he was making history by infiltrating the Soviet secret police.

title: GOING TO SCHOOL IN YELLOWSTONE
description: JIM ROBBINS contributes to The New York Times from Helena, Mont.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN HONOLULU
description: ROBERT TRUMBULL, a former foreign correspondent for The New York Times, lives in Honolulu.

title: VILLAGE AND M.T.A. AT ODDS OVER RIVERFRONT LAND IN CROTON
description: A STRIP of Hudson riverfront land, unwanted for years and strewn with junk, has suddenly become a valuable prize and is being fought over by the village of Croton-on-Hudson and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: THE FALTERING 44 WALL STREET FUND
description: DAVID H. BAKER Jr. has at times been called one of Wall Street's superstars. As fund manager of the 44 Wall Street Fund, he has had remarkable years in bull markets - 1971 and 1979 in particular, when the fund rose in value by 71.7 percent and 71.3 percent, respectively.

title:
TINDERBOX FOR TRADE;

THE LOOMING WORLDWIDE JOB SHORTAGE
description: UNLESS we start now to create new jobs by the millions in scores of countries, some of the most difficult years that man has ever known may be facing us. This is not opinion; it is simple arithmetic.

title: LOST IN AFRICA And This WomanDana Manno calls the Nigerian Security Organization ''a Gestapo in black.'' She has reason. It seized her mother, Marie McBroom, a Jersey City businesswoman, last February and now threatens her with execution for ''conspiring to deal with petroleum products without lawful authority.'' Nigeria's oil could scarcely be cruder than its justice.
description: The military leaders who seized power last year vowed they would end corruption in Africa's most populous country. Mrs. McBroom allegedly failed, before the coup, to obtain an export license while negotiating an oil contract.

title: THE LEADINGECONOMISTS OF THE RECENT PAST WASHINGTON
description: The economists who emerged in the 1960's and 1970's to assume high Government posts came mostly from universities. They were an articulate band of men and often wielded great power with their respective presidents.

title: 10 GIVEN SENTENCES IN WEST FOR VIOLATION OF THE WILDLIFE LAWS
description: Ten people charged with violations of Federal wildlife laws as a result of a three- year undercover investigation have been fined up to $10,500 and placed on probation for up to three years.

title: International
description: SUNDAY, JANUARY 13, 1985 Aid to Nicaraguan rebels is coming principally from Honduras and El Salvador, which have replaced the United States as the main provider, according to Reagan Administration officials and members of Congress. They said Israel had also stepped up aid to the rebels. (Page 1, Col. 6.)

title: Smith Lives On In His Writing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: For Halo Romps In Gulfstream Dash
description: For Halo, who is looking more and more like the top sprinter in training, rallied strongly to win the $50,000 Hallandale Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

title: CHRISTMAS OBSERVANCE AND A STATE RULING
description: Public school officials, the Suffolk Chapter of the American Jewish Congress, and the Nassau chapter of the New York Civil Liberties Union apparently are unaware that the New York State Department of Education adopted in 1963 an official position on the singing of traditional Christmas carols, the utilization of Christmas trees, the display of sets depicting the Nativity of Christ, and the presentation of tableaux and plays depicting the historical traditions relating to the birth of Christ. (''Holiday Displays in Schools Questioned'', Dec. 16, 1984.) The department's official position has not changed since it was first promulgated. Here are some paragraphs from the department's ruling.

title: SOME GOOD EQUIPMENT CAN BE HARD TO FIND
description: After the holidays, a number of readers complained about my not writing a Christmas memoir, as in previous years, and chided me for having written instead about Nipper, the dog on RCA's record label. I was gratified to know that my personal remembrances were so appreciated, but after years of writing about myself, I felt that it was only fair to give equal billing to another species.

title:
ON LANGUAGE;

BEAUCOONS OF WORDS
description: Jim Wayne Miller is a poet and professor at Western Kentucky University, Bowling Green, Ky.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

ART AND NATURE
description: VAN GOGH had Arles. Monet had Giverny. And Westchester residents seeking that special spot to capture on canvas have the Marshlands Conservancy in Rye.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

HOPING (IN VAIN) TO EMPTY THE NEST
description: YEARS ago, children grew up and left home. About the time I became a parent, this practice changed and children started hanging around their houses till they were well past 35. Oh, I did hear some murmurs in the nursery about this trend - ''Hey, let's live at home and get everything free'' - but I ignored the rumors until it became my turn to ''let one of them fly away.''

title: JAZZ: THREADGILL'S CLASSICAL STYLE
description: The idea of a music called ''jazz'' has always included both composition and improvisation. But one of the more fascinating trends in avant- garde black jazz of recent years has been a tendency toward a kind of compositional rigor ever more indistinguishable from classical contemporary music.

title: FRIENDSHIP LEADS TO ART GIFT
description: ALAN RADCLIFF has a special fondness for Frank Kleinholz, a Port Washington artist. So much so that he recently donated a collection of 66 works by Mr. Kleinholz to the State University College at Old Westbury.

title: Upstate anufacturer Is Denied Rail Contract
description: The New York Air Brake Company has lost a $6.5 million contract for brakes on rail cars for the PATH system after having been told it was the low bidder, the company said.

title: Ellen Dziedzic to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter S. Dziedzic of Southington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ellen Dziedzic to Dr. Burt R. Downes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul C. Downes of New York. The wedding is to take place in May. The future bride is the fiscal manager of Elderly Services of Berkshire County in Pittsfield, Mass. Dr. Downes is a psychologist at the Berkshire Children's Community in Great Barrington, Mass.

title: A LOOK BACK AT AL DELBELLO'S 20 YEARS IN POLITICS
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: KNOWING HOW FAR TO GO TOO FAR
description: JEAN COCTEAU AND THE FRENCH SCENE

title: STAGE DIRECTORS TALK OF THEIR PROBLEMS
description: THEATER directors and representatives of several theater organizations met in Waterford last weekend to discuss ways to alleviate the problems facing American stage directors. They left with a resolve to help newcomers in the field, and a plan to establish a regular institute for stage directors.

title: WHAT THEY FEAR ACROSS THE IDEOLOGICAL DIVIDE
description: To the Editor:

title:
CAREFUL SHOPPER;

From Candleholders To Rockinghorses
description: New England Trading Company in Armonk sells one-of-a-kind custom furniture, hand-painted folk art welcome signs and rockinghorses made in the adjoining shop along with wrought-iron chandeliers and candleholders, stenciled floor canvases, baskets, framed pierced-tin sections from the doors of ''pie safes'' (cupboards for baked goods) quilts and quilted pillows and a few antique pieces. Cider is kept warm on the woodstove each Saturday.

title: A SEWER TIE TO ROUTE 110 IS DEBATED
description: A plan to tie businesses, industries and new housing along the Route 110 corridor in Melville into the Southwest Sewer District is under debate in the Town of Huntington.

title: Endangered Species
description: ''The glass container makers, who have been losing customers to both the plastic and metal container industries for years, are now fighting for survival,'' said H. Edward Schollmeyer, who monitors the struggle for Paine Webber Inc. ''By the end of 1985, we believe only a few will still be around.''

title: CONDUCTING THAT IMBUES MUSIC WITH PERSONALITY
description: Few conductors have enjoyed as precipitate a rise as Giuseppe Sinopoli. Since conducting ''A"ida'' at Venice's Teatro La Fenice in 1978, this now 38-year-old Italian composer (and medical doctor) has become the new darling of opera houses, orchestras and record companies worldwide. He is leading Verdi operas for Deutsche Grammophon (and, when DG choses to release him to a sister company for special projects, for Philips) and recording the complete Mahler symphonies and much other symphonic repertory for DG. The recently appointed chief conductor of the Santa Cecilia Orchestra in Rome and the Philharmonia Orchestra in London, he guest-conducts incessantly, in all the best places - including the new Franco Zeffirelli production of ''Tosca'' at the Metropolitan Opera this March.

title: ECONOMIST OFFERS VIEWS ON THE FUTURE
description: NEWARK

title: HOW D.R.G. WAIVER WAS NEGOTIATED
description: THE granting of the new Medicare waiver capped nearly a year of debate between Trenton and Washington over the effectiveness of New Jersey's D.R.G. system.

title: Separate Tables
description: John Schlesinger's production of ''Separate Tables,'' presented on the Home Box Office cable TV service in 1983 and now available on video cassette, is an evocative realization of the Terence Rattigan play. This is a pair of overlapping one-acts that take place in an English seaside hotel and deal with the theme of middle-aged loneliness.

title: CAR QUOTAS
description: To the Editor:

title: Hilary Pierce Will Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Laurence A. Pierce of Marblehead, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Hilary Pierce to Charles Barrett Jackson, the son of Charles H. Jackson and the late Olive C. Jackson of Madison, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: BHOPAL: A LESSON FOR NEW JERSEY
description: THERE IS a lesson for New Jersey in the Bhopal disaster in India last month. As the nation's most densely populated state and home to scores of chemical companies, New Jersey can derive comfort from the fact that we have a ''Right- to-Know'' law that, if implemented as planned, would be likely to eliminate the possibility of the kind of disaster that cost nearly 2,500 Indians their lives.

title: Shift in Top Personnel Is Announced by Kean
description: Governor Kean today announced his appointment of Insurance Commissioner Kenneth D. Merin as Director of Policy and Planning and his intention to nominate Hazel F. Gluck, Lottery Executive Director, to replace Mr. Merin.

title: MAILBAG
description: OF MUSEUMS AND DIVAS

title: MISS HENRY TO MARRY LIEUT. W.O. WADE 3D
description: Melanie Celeste Henry, a national credit representative at Dean Witter Reynolds, and Lieut. William Orlando Wade 3d of the Army, plan to be married in April, her parents, Charles O. Henry of Corona, Queens, and Lida L. Watson of Flushing, Queens, have announced.

title: POLITICS LIKELY TO DELAY SALVADOR PEACE TALKS
description: Senior Salvadoran officials say growing political pressure has made it unlikely that President Jose Napoleon Duarte will pursue peace talks with leftist rebels until after national elections are held in March.

title: COAST TALKS OPEN ON WATER PERIL FOR DIALYSIS
description: State and local health officials have opened talks with representatives of California's water suppliers to discuss an outbreak of illnesses among kidney dialysis patients that led to a statewide suspension of the use of a chemical water purifier, choloramine.

title: Penguins Down Oilers, 4-3
description: The Pittsburgh Penguin rookies Troy Loney and Mario Lemieux each scored two goals while Denis Herron made 45 saves tonight to lead the Penguins to a 4-3 victory over the Edmonton Oilers before a sellout Civic Arena crowd of 16,033.

title: HEADLINERS;
description: Southern History To those who point to

title: Edwin D. Eshleman, 64, Dies; 5-Term G.O.P. Congressman
description: Edwin D. Eshleman, a former Republican Congressman from Pennsylvania's 16th Congressional District, died of cancer Thursday at his home. He was 64 years old.

title: Lita Christensen Weds Grace's Vice Chairman
description: Harold R. Logan, the vice chairman of W. R. Grace & Company, and Lita Christensen of Weston, Conn., were married yesterday at his home in Weston by the Rev. Robert Greene, a Congregational minister.

title: APPELLATE COURT BARS DEPORTATION
description: A Federal court has blocked the Justice Department from deporting a man accused of collaborating with the Nazis in Latvia in World War II.

title: PATRICIAN QUARTERS WHERE RUBENS PAINTED
description: THEODORE JAMES Jr. is a writer with a special interest in gardening.

title: HARD QUESTIONS ABOUT SOFT BEDS
description: GUY HENLE, a magazine editor, writes occasionally on food and travel.

title: Counterfeit $100 Bills Mailed to Floridians
description: Plain brown envelopes full of $100 bills are turning up in residents' mailboxes in central Florida, according to Federal agents, who say the money is counterfeit.

title: UCONN GREENHOUSES NO LONGER 'SECRET'
description: TO those familiar with the Storrs campus of the University of Connecticut, the three greenhouses behind the life- sciences building are a common sight. Dr. Carl Rettenmeyer, however, likes to refer to them as ''UConn's best-kept secret.''

title: WeTeo Clifford Kornfield
description: Wendy Lee Thorpe, a daughter of Carole Shapiro of North Miami Beach, Fla., and Larry Thorpe of Atlanta, was married yesterday to Clifford A. Kornfield, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kornfield of New York. Rabbi Robert Frazen performed the ceremony at the Hollywood Hilton Hotel in Florida.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: A grant from ''Meet the Composer'' will enable Patti Bown, who is a jazz composer, pianist and singer, to give a concert Sunday night at 7 at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, exploring the work of other women who have had jazz careers as singers and/or pianists and as composers.

title: THEATER: 'ON THE LAM'
description: As a former actor with the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, Georg Osterman has studied many of Charles Ludlam's comic devices, including the uses of exaggeration in performance and the recycling of popular culture. However, it is evident from ''On the Lam,'' the first musical of Mr. Osterman's authorship, that he is far from mastering the Ridiculous form. ''On the Lam'' (at Theater for the New City) is a hodgepodge of bad jokes and unprofitable attempts at show business breeziness. The show runs on and on, a three-act backstage treadmill from Des Moines to New York.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: DR. GLENN L. PAULSON, former assistant commissioner for science in the state's Department of Environmental Protection and now the National Audubon Society's vice president for science, is one of 13 professionals chosen to run a private voluntary association to help clean up abandoned hazardous-waste sites.

title:
DINING OUT;

CHINESE WITH A CONTINENTAL TOUCH
description: IN the Chester Heights section of Eastchester,

title: Dr. Yvedt MatoryTo Be June Bride
description: Dr. Yvedt Love Matory, a research fellow at the National Cancer Institute of the National Institutes of Health in Washington, and Randall LeRoy Kennedy, an assistant professor at the Harvard Law School, plan to be married in June.

title: Penelope Naylor,Artist, Is Married
description: Penelope Owen Naylor, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester O. Naylor of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Sarasota, Fla., was married yesterday to David M. Teitelbaum, a son of Esther Teitelbaum of Los Angeles and the late Abraham Teitelbaum. The Very Rev. James P. Morton, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, performed the ceremony in St. Saviour Chapel at the cathedral.

title: RESTORED VILLAGE GIVEN BY COUPLE TO CAPE MAY
description: COLD SPRING THE Cape May County Board of Chosen Freeholders will begin deciding this week what to do with its unusual Christmas present: 20 acres of restored 18th- and 19th-century buildings and a farm.

title: Sandra Stern Wed To a Psychiatrist
description: Sandra Stern, a vice president and associate general counsel of the Republic National Bank of New York, and Dr. Sheldon Michael Frank, chief of psychiatry at Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, N.Y., were married yesterday. Rabbi Balfour Brickner officiated at the couple's home in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: LITERARY SUMMITRY
description: Martin Duberman, Distinguished Professor of History at Lehman College, C.U.N.Y., is at work on a biography of Paul Robeson. ENLARGING THE CHANGE

title: CHARGES OF WAREHOUSING DEBATED
description: ANDREW J. STEIN, the Manhattan Borough President, has scheduled a public hearing next Thursday on the issue of warehousing apartments - keeping rental units vacant for long periods of time before a cooperative or condominium conversion.

title: AFFLUENT SHOPPERS AND YOUTHS' VALUES
description: As a senior at Great Neck North, I was deeply shocked by the sweeping generalizations that were presented in ''They Go Shopping, Browsing, Splurging.'' The article intimated that all adolescents who live on the North Shore recklessly spend their money on clothing. This is absolutely false. It gives a distorted and denigrating view of Long Island and especially Great Neck.

title: CHANGES AT TOP SIGNAL A POWER SCRAMBLE
description: ONE key to understanding power in Washington is knowing which election - the one to come, or the one just past - counts most. In 1981, President Reagan had a high-riding honeymoon because the capital was in the thrall of the Republicans' 1980 sweep. By early 1982, with the midterm elections approaching, his party was in a defensive mood. This year, normal rhythms seem upset. With astonishing speed, Washington - if not the public - is discounting Mr. Reagan's 1984 landslide, and power, initiative and political talent are ebbing away from the White House.

title: RELIGIOUS GROUP FACING INQUIRIES ON ETHIOPIA AID
description: The California Attorney General's office said last night that it would investigate a group that has raised millions of dollars for famine relief in Ethiopia but apparently has not delivered any aid to the country.

title: Martha Moore Has Nuptials
description: The marriage of Martha Moore, a researcher with Hill & Knowlton, a public relations concern in New York, to Robert Timothy Battles, manager of promotion for the Movie Channel, a national pay cable service in New York, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York. The Rev. Nicholas Reid performed the ceremony.

title: THE REGION ;   Governors StartYear With HighExpectations
description: Good times breed bold ideas. That was the message last week in Albany, Trenton and Hartford, where the region's Governors each opened legislative sessions with their annual ''state of the state'' speeches. With economies surging and state budgets piling up large surpluses, the Governors proposed new programs that would be financed, in part, by the unanticipated revenues. Cleaning up the environment and improving public schools stood high on each agenda. In New York and Connecticut, some of the spoils will go directly to the taxpayers, in the form of reductions in state income or sales taxes.

title: WHEN MERGER PLANS CRASH ARBITRAGERS RUSH TO BAIL OUT
description: These are not the best of times for Wall Street's risk arbitragers, those daring investors who send stocks flying on the word of a takeover and pray the deals will come to pass. Lately, more and more expected mergers have been falling apart. Another big one collapsed last week when Diamond Shamrock Corporation's board of directors declined to go along with their chairman's agreement to merge with the Occidental Petroleum Corporation.

title: Car Quotas
description: To the Editor:

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF GENERAL JARUZELSKI
description: Michael T. Kaufman's article is concerned with how history will judge General Jaruzelski - as a traitor or as a nationalist. Mr. Kaufman assumes the two views are mutually exclusive. They are not.

title: Robert Joseph, 77, Ex-Broker In Industrial Properties, Dies
description: Robert Joseph, an industrial realestate broker, died of cancer Friday at his home in Sarasota, Fla.

title: BEHIND REAGAN'S ECONOMIC SHUFFLE
description: WHEN President Reagan announced the surprise job-swap of Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and White House chief of staff James A. Baker 3d, two of his closest aides, most of the immediate reaction centered on the personal chemistry each would bring to his new role and the relative power each would exert.

title:
GARDENING;

GROUND COVERS FOR A DRY, SUNNY SLOPE
description: TO continue our discussion on ground covers, it would seem appropriate to begin with those best suited to the most difficult site - the dry, south-facing slope. The number of suitable plants is limited and it does not pay to stray too far afield in search of others perhaps more favored by the gardener. To do so is to invite failure.

title: Tax Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: TRIBUTE TO DR. KING

title: Mayor Approves Drilling Off Los Angeles Coast
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation's 18- year bid to drill for oil along the Pacific Palisades shore was approved today by Mayor Tom Bradley, who had vetoed the project twice before.

title: U.S. IS CAUTIOUS ON AMBIGUITIES IN GENEVA TALKS
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that the Geneva agreement to begin three sets of arms negotiations had left unresolved the key question of whether a failure in one set of talks could derail progress in the others.

title: UP TO 4 MILLION IN SUDAN SAID TO FACE STARVATION
description: Sudanese officials and relief workers in this chronically impoverished country say the drought-related famine here could reach Ethiopian proportions by midsummer.

title: rine Bumiller, an Artist,To Be Married on May 25
description: Mrs. John K. Rose and Theodore R. Bumiller, both of Cincinnati, have announced the engagement of their daughter Trine R. Bumiller to Kurt R. Monigle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn W. Monigle of Golden, Colo. The wedding is to take place May 25.

title: PROSECUTORS PUSH FOR A CHANGE IN GRAND JURY WITNESS LAW
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, last week faced a dilemma familiar to most New York State prosecutors: whether to place witnesses to a crime before a grand jury. The case, the shooting of four teen-agers on a subway train, had already drawn enormous publicity. The legal problem was somewhat less celebrated.

title: 'STAR WARS'-COSTLY,FUTILE
description: The arms control talks in Geneva last week identified the strategic defense initiative, known as ''Star Wars,'' as a major topic of East-West negotiations. But what is a citizen to think of Star Wars? Can an effective defense system be built? If not, does a partial system intended to defend land-based missiles make any sense? If implementing a partial system would be dangerous, should the program to develop Star Wars be maintained as a bargaining chip as we enter negotiations with Moscow? The answers to these questions are no, no and basically no.

title: SHE DIGS THE STAGE INSTEAD OF ARTIFACTS
description: AMY JORRISCH did not plan on becoming an actress, or a singer, or co-leader of a show and dance band with which she is always on the road in unlikely areas. At the University of Michigan, the Massapequa Park resident earned a degree in anthropology, but she never dug for an artifact after graduation in 1972. Instead, she began to chase an elusive and long-suppressed goal - a career in the theater.

title: BELL ASKS WAIVER ON DATA SERVICES
description: IF THE Bell Atlantic Company has its way, personal and corporate users of computers in rst in the company's market area to be offered inexpensive data- transmission services.

title: MAILBAG
description: OF MUSEUMS AND DIVAS

title: Article 212672 -- No Title
description: The Harvard Campaign, the five-and- a-half-year capital drive to increase the endowment of Harvard College, has surpassed its goal of $350 million, the campaign's national co-chairman has announced.

title: A European Boom
description: Their currencies may be worth less each day, in terms of dollars, but investors in European stock markets are enjoying booming times. Since last Dec. 1, for example, stock averages have jumped 30 percent in London, 40 percent in the Netherlands, 22 percent in Switzerland and 15 percent in West Germany, says David D. Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services, Chicago.

title: SECURITY TIGHTENED AT ABORTION CLINICS
description: ABORTION providers throughout the state have begun to increase security, after two bomb threats at a West Hartford clinic earlier this month.

title: Kathleen Troia, Ex-Defense Aide, Is Wed In Captial
description: Kathleen Troia, a doctoral candidate in political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Alan Roberts McFarland Jr., a general partner in Lazard Fr eres & Company in New York, were married yesterday at the National Cathedral in Washington. The Rev. Malcolm Foster performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: FAITH AND SUFFERING IN THE SOVIET UNION
description: THE JEWS OF HOPE

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: The main article in The Times Magazine today analyzes President Reagan's program for his second term. On page 28 it discusses a desire by James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, to transfer to ''any good Cabinet post'' or to the directorship of central intelligence. The magazine went to press before the announcement on Tuesday that Mr. Baker and Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan would exchange jobs.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
description: MUSICAL BARGAIN

title: Tennis Demands Lots of Courage
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 100 PROTEST AGAINST N.Y.U. PLAN TO BUILD 2 DORMS IN EAST VILLAGE
description: About 100 people, many waving ''Stop N.Y.U.'' pennants, demonstrated yesterday against plans by New York University to build dormitories on two lots in the East Village.

title: THE PALACE CLINGS TO ITS SWISS LEGEND
description: BARBARA CANSINO, a writer who lives in Winnipeg, Manitoba, is a frequent visitor to Switzerland.

title: Paying the Agent Orange Lawyers ''Why is there always a secret singing when a lawyer cashes in?'' asked the poet Carl Sandburg. ''Why does a hearse horse snicker hauling a lawyer away?'' The American lawyers who descended on Bhopal, India, enlisting clients to sue Union Carbide, shared some of the shame in the wake of the disaster there. Every calamity seems to draw a swarm of lawyers eager to line their pockets with huge contingency fees.
description: At least that's the way many Americans see it. Others, more charitably, just see lawyers as a necessary evil.

title: PROTAGONISTS WHO SUBSTITUTE SELF-PITY FOR COURAGE
description: Outwardly, the two plays are dissimilar. James Duff's ''Home Front'' is a family play about the homecoming of a psychologically wounded veteran of the war in Vietnam. The family is of a prospering Texas variety to which patriotism and television are a dual way of life. Bill C. Davis's ''Dancing in the End Zone'' deals with the American passion for athletic prowess and the price - physical as well as emotional - that a star quarterback pays for his goals. The scene is a midwestern university.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: MOUNT VERNON
description: LYING just across the Westchester

title: THE REGION ;   Toward SaferApartments
description: At a time when many public officials and New York City residents have been talking about crime, Mayor Koch weighed in last week with a few proposals that he thinks would make city life a little safer. He suggested that the city require locked front doors and intercom systems in all apartment buildings with eight apartments or more.

title: SIMON RATTLE WON'T BE RUSHED
description: Simon Rattle, who - as principal guest conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic - makes his New York debut this week will turn 30 in the process. His birthday falls on Saturday, when he will he and the Californians will appear at Brooklyn College; on Friday, there will be a concert at Carnegie Hall and on Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: WHAT SOME REPUBLICANS FEAR
description: Among the tangle of motives that drive people in power, a concern for how they are regarded today is, at least among the more thoughtful, accompanied by a concern about how they will look tomorrow - when the judgment of history begins to be delivered and their performance is assessed in light of the results it has produced. This concern is both idealistic and practical.

title: FIRST-TIME DONORS FIND JOY IN GIVING TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: Many of those who give to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are first-time donors who express satisfaction at having decided, for a variety of reasons, to contribute.

title: NATIONALIST ANTI-NAZI
description: Norman K. Gottwald , a professor of biblical studies at the New York Theological Seminary, is the author of ''The Hebrew Bible: A Socio-Literary Introduction,'' to be published in June. MARTIN NIEMOLLER

title:
GARDENING;

GROUND COVERS FOR A DRY, SUNNY SLOPE
description: TO continue our discussion on ground covers, it would seem appropriate to begin with those best suited to the most difficult site - the dry, south-facing slope. The number of suitable plants is limited and it does not pay to stray too far afield in search of others perhaps more favored by the gardener. To do so is to invite failure.

title: AMERICA'S SUPERSECRET EYES IN SPACE
description: James Bamford, a writer who specializes in national-security issues, is the author of ''The Puzzle Palace,'' a book on the National Security Agency.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ;   Injury and Law
description: After a 4-year-old boy, Shawn Kramer, was run over by a horse- drawn stagecoach at Knott's Berry Farm in Buena Park, Calif., his parents sued the amusement park, charging negligence because there was no barrier to keep small children from walking under the coach. In a cross-complaint, Knott's accused the parents of ''negligent parenting.''

title: KEAN HAILS HOSPITAL ACCORD
description: TRENTON

title: Alison H. Clarkson, Producer, Marries
description: Alison Hudnut Clarkson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Melbourne Elliott Clarkson of Buffalo and North Creek, N.Y., was married yesterday to Oliver Ramsdell Goodenough, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ward H. Goodenough of Wallingford, Pa. The Rev. Robert K. Hudnut, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: MAILBAG
description: OF MUSEUMS AND DIVAS

title: 3 STAND TRIAL FOR NEGLIGENT HOMICIDE IN DEATH OF MAN IN A QUARREL
description: In an unusual application of the negligent homicide statute, three people are standing trial here on charges they provoked a man's fatal heart attack by quarreling with him.

title: AFTER 35 YEARS ON STAGE, ROBERTA PETERS FEELS LIKE GOING ON FOREVER
description: Observers of the vocal scene like to lecture young singers on the virtues of patience and restraint and tend to cluck in unison when they fade before their time. So what do they make of Roberta Peters, who sang first at the Metropolitan Opera at the age of 19 and is still there 35 years later?

title: PENTAGON SCREENING PROGRAM SETS OFF SOME ALARMS
description: EVER since a polygraph machine was used during World War II to screen scientists hired to help develop the atomic bomb, the military has been taken with the ''lie detector.'' Under President Reagan, the Pentagon has almost doubled its use of the instrument to screen applicants for jobs in the intelligence agencies, to investigate security breaches, to test foreigners hired as agents and, on at least one occasion, to track down the source of a news leak.

title: BEST SELLERS Jan. 13, 1985
description: Fiction*1

title: THE REGION ;   Sign of ChangeIn the Subway
description: The New York City Transit Authority last week posted an apology to subway riders for delays caused by a fire Monday at a station in Brooklyn. It was the first time the system's management had told riders ''We're sorry'' in at least 30 years, according to employees who have been around that long, but it may have been a preview of a new style of running the trains.

title: CAMPAIGN SPENDING ASSESSED
description: REPRESENTATIVE Robert J. Mrazek and Robert P. Quinn, in their heated campaign for Long Island's 3d Congressional District seat last November, called each other big spenders.

title: MAILBAG
description: OF MUSEUMS AND DIVAS

title: WOMEN IN THE MAINSTREAM
description: To the Editor:

title:
ANTIQUES;

WHEN ROAD SIGNS WERE DECORATIVE
description: MOST commuters believe America's great age of turnpike and expressway building was during the Eisenhower Administration. But even more spectacular was the creation from scratch, so to speak, of the first great network of toll roads from about 1800 through 1850.

title: NEW ISSUE MARKS COMPOSER'S CENTENNIAL
description: A 22-cent commemorative honoring the composer Jerome Kern is the first stamp to meet the new First Class postage rate announced by the United States Postal Service. The current 20 cent First Class rate is valid through Feb. 17. The new stamp is the eighth in the Performing Arts Series and will be issued Jan. 23 at Lincoln Center in New York City. It appears in the 100th anniversary year of Jerome Kern's birth.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE MAN WHO LIVED ALONE

title: CATHOLIC BISHOP SUES ON ABORTIONS
description: The Roman Catholic Bishop of Albany has obtained a temporary court order blocking efforts by two Planned Parenthood clinics to begin providing abortions.

title: ARE POLITICAL CHANGES ALSO IN CHINA'S CARDS?
description: In the speech that everybody in China has been reading since the new year, Deng Xiaoping addressed urgent fears circulating in the Communist Party. No, he told party elders, China is not heading for a restoration of capitalism, though a little bit would do no harm. Old comrades who had fought all their lives for communism could be confident that the Marxist system was secure.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

WHATEVER HAPPENED TO MANNERS? WHERE'S THE GOLDEN RULE?
description: MY feelings were hurt. I felt disrespected. My 5-year-old grandson stirred more inimical thoughts in me than even I could accept. How easily he destroyed my image as a loving, doting grandmother who held references from others to prove it! Unwilling to accept this unpleasant, atypical state of affairs, I reviewed the extenuating circumstances with serious concern; the evidence of ''who did what to whom.'' On the basis of this effort, I declared myself the ''injured party.'' During his visit to my home, I had been consistently ignored and unanswered by him whenever the opportunity arose. I was aggrieved.

title: Another View On the Rankings
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IN winter - even a bland, muddy

title: KEAN MAKES DEBUT AS TALK-SHOW HOST
description: The producer in the radio control room held up signs that said ''Sally from Sussex,'' ''Jim from Atlantic City'' and ''Barbara from Princeton'' so the new talk show host could address the callers by name when he picked up the phone.

title: DALLAS DEVELOPER TESTS PARSIPPANY AREA
description: OVER the last dozen years, the Lincoln Property Company of Dallas has built more than 28 million square feet of commercial office space in nearly every major market in the country except the New York metropolitan region.

title: WHEN TO REFINANCE A HOME MORTGAGE
description: -interest

title: THE NATION ;   Court UpholdsLighter Bumpers
description: A Federal appeals court ruled last week that the Department of Transportation acted properly when it relaxed the Government's standards for automobile bumpers. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia last year blocked the department's efforts to undo two other auto-safety legacies of the Carter Administration: air-bags for new cars and a grading system that would indicate to buyers how long their tires would last.

title: Sheryl Lynn Steinberg To Be Wed Next June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Steinberg of Howard Beach, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter Sheryl Lynn Steinberg to David Steven Machlowitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy A. Machlowitz of Glenside, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Jan. 13, 1985Fiction*1

title: Montgomery Ward Will Close 300 Stores
description: The nation's sixth-largest retailer, Montgomery Ward & Company, said Friday that it was closing its 300 catalogue stores around the country in a move that would cost about 1,200 jobs.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

GUMMED LABELS: AN INDESTRUCTABLE NUISANCE
description: THE sticky price labels on products cause an unnecessary problem for the consumer. These labels, about the size of a standard postage stamp, are sometimes impossible to remove without damaging the item to which they are affixed.

title: Flutie's Team Loses in Japan
description: Ron Pitts of U.C.L.A. intercepted a desperation pass by Mike Tomczak of Ohio State and returned it 99 yards for a touchdown with 1 minute 41 seconds left to play, preserving the West's 28-14 victory over the East in the Japan Bowl all-star game.

title: OPERA: 'RAKE'S PROGRESS' PERFORMED
description: The rake, in the person of Jerry Hadley, had to withdraw from ''The Rake's Progress'' due to a throat ailment when the Washington Opera revived Zack Brown's beautifully realistic production Tuesday night. On short notice David Eisler, who had understudied Mr. Hadley in the part at City Opera last season, was summoned from Toronto where he was rehearsing ''Candide.'' His performance was a personal triumph, and in its way the highlight of a most rewarding visit to the company in its Terrace Theater winter season.

title: EXPERIENCES CLOSE TO DEATH
description: -year- old mother of five from Storrs, remembers when, 10 years ago, she watched from the corner of an emergency room as surgeons quickly worked on her body, trying to pump life back into her malfunctioning heart. As they tried resuscitating the comatose person before them, Mrs. Nelson tried to say something from her vantage point near the ceiling.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times Magazine last Sunday about women on Wall Street incorrectly described Salomon Brothers Inc. It is a wholly owned subsidiary of Phibro-Salomon, a company held publicly, not privately.

title: LIBERALS' POSITION ON ABORTION IS EXPLAINED
description: Why, asks Dorothy McLaughlin, are liberals who defend the civil rights of a wide variety of people and animals unable to apply those rights to the unborn as well? Obviously, some liberals, such as the two cited at the beginning of her article, do feel that a fetus has civil rights.

title: A SUPER BOWL TICKET FOR ALL TO ADMIRE
description: The flat sheen of the ticket is a wonderful

title: HUMAN FIGURE IS BACK IN UNLIKELY GUISES
description: The history of the human figure is all but inseparable from the history of Western art. Our sense of Classical Greece, Republican Rome, 6th-century Byzantium and 15th-century Florence has a great deal to do with the artistic images of men and women those periods have passed down to us. We can still read ourselves on the face of art through the 1950s, when the ravaged and defiant images of Francis Bacon, Jean Dubuffet, Alberto Giacometti and Willem de Kooning tell us nearly everything we need to know about life in the wake of modern war.

title: Zampone
description: To the Editor:

title: THE COMPUTER AS A TOOL FOR LEARNING TO WRITE
description: LAWRENCE SCHWARTZ

title: BRIGHT BLOOMS MAKE THE NEW CAPE PRIMROSE HYBRIDS SHINE
description: Theodore James Jr. has written many books on gardening.

title: Patricia Bell Engaged
description: The engagement of Patricia Bell to Douglas Andrew Keller has been announced by her parents, Joyce Stephenson Bell of Summit, N.J., and Rodney McNabb Bell of Essex Fells, N.J. Her fiance is a son of Mrs. Paul J. Christiansen of West Orange, N.J., and the late Frederick A. Keller Jr. The future bride and Mr. Keller are both account executives with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in Short Hills, N.J. She graduated from the University of Colorado, and he from Colgate University.

title: ETHIOPIANS ARE A JOY AND A CHALLENGE FOR ISRAELIS
description: There is an old saying here that Israel is a country that loves immigration but hates immigrants. The arrival in the last few months of almost 10,000 Ethiopian Jews has demonstrated just how true, and how false, that saying is.

title: For Special Elections To Fill Board Terms
description: After reading your article (Westchester Journal, Dec. 30) about the appointment of Stephen Tenore as a County Legislator, I'm even more convinced that there is a need to change the County Charter to mandate the election rather than appointment of public officials who replace those who are unable to complete their term of office.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: TOBA By Michael Mark. Illustrated by Neil Waldman. Scarsdale, N.Y.: The Bradbury Press. $10.95. (Ages 7 to 10)

title: 5TH-GRADER'S INSPIRATION RESULTS IN AN EDUCATION IN BUSINESS
description: It started as an assignment for Wendy Johnecheck's fifth-grade class in the spring of 1984. But the young girl's fancy turned to thoughts of jumping rope and a result was an invention that is being marketed around this country and abroad.

title: LAUREN BETH MATTLEMAN IS BETROTHED
description: The engagement of Lauren Beth Mattleman to John Wilton Hoopes 2d, a son of Lucy Burkett Hoopes of Baltimore and Dr. John E. Hoopes of Gibson Island, Md., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Nathan Mattleman of Jenkintown, Pa., parents of the bride- to-be.

title: THWARTED MERGER STUNS WALL STREET
description: The Diamond Shamrock board thwarted a merger with Occidental Petroleum only hours after it had appeared that the deal was set. The Shamrock directors reportedly had misgivings about the outlook for Occidental and voted unanimously against joining Dr. Armand Hammer's empire. As stunned arbitragers toted up some hefty losses, the general opinion on Wall Street seemed to be that the affair had left Shamrock highly vulnerable to new takeover offers.

title: Cosmos Defeat Strikers As DiBernardo Scores 2
description: Angelo DiBernardo scored two goals and set up another tonight to lead the Cosmos to a 4-3 Major Indoor Soccer League victory over the Minnesota Strikers.

title: ORWELLIAN SAGA
description: Just in time to begin 1985, the film of ''1984'' has finally made to the United States. But even getting George Orwell's grim fictional classic to the screen was a nightmarish ''Orwellian odyssey'' lasting four years for its executive producer, Marvin J. Rosenblum. ''I'd almost rather go to Room 101 than go through it again,'' the 42- year old Chicago lawyer said the other day.

title: WHY TV WON'T LET UP ON VIOLENCE
description: ''Violence is alive and well on television,'' Steven Bochco, executive producer of ''Hill Street Blues,'' said in a recent interview. Mr. Bochco, whose award-winning dramatic series has been praised for its sensitive, albeit gritty depiction of the world of urban police, was speaking partly in jest. But his words are as true as they have ever been.

title: Dallas Police Recruiters Seek Prospects in Boston
description: The Dallas Police Department came looking for recruits today in Boston, where there are few law-enforcement openings and many candidates.

title: Cie Frazier Dead at 81; New Orleans Musician
description: Josiah (Cie) Frazier, a drummer who began playing in the early years of traditional jazz in New Orleans and toured with the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, died of pneumonia Thursday at Touro Infirmary. He was 81 years old.

title: The World ;   Fresh StartFor NicaraguanGovernment
description: In protocol-conscious Latin America, sending low-level emissaries to a presidential inaugural, as happened last week in Nicaragua, amounts to a snub. More than 40 countries sent delegates to swearing- in ceremonies for President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the Sandinista leader, but Cuba's Fidel Castro, a surprise guest, was the only foreign head of government to attend.

title: PALO ALTO: IN THE EYE OF A SUPER STORM
description: The eye of the storm, we all know, is the very center of the disturbance, where all is motionless and serene while the fierce winds of the hurricane itself swirl all around with horrifying force.

title: Liberals' Position On Abortion Is Explained
description: The ''Right to Life'' position should not be a liberal cause, as Dorothy McLaughlin wrote in her Opinion Page article (Dec. 23).

title: COUNSELORS CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE
description: -school seniors participated in a recent University of Connecticut survey, the results were shocking. Only about 6 percent of the students questioned claimed to have used the guidance facilities of their schools for college counseling.

title: POWER LINE WINS P.S.C.'S APPROVAL
description: The Public Service Commission has given finalstate approval for the construction of a $509 million power line through central New York State.

title: Martin Sets Back Roth In Los Angeles Bowling
description: Steve J. Martin of Kingsport, Tenn., averaged 231 pins for four games today to capture the $125,000 Greater Los Angeles Open.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE state's Department of Commerce and Economic Development is distributing without charge reprints of a four-page cover story, ''Small State, Big Market,'' from the Nov. 29 issue of the magazine Engineering News- Record.

title: Cynthia Maypole Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Maypole of Mountain Lakes, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Anne Maypole to Scott Grant Hunt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hunt of Ellenwood, Ga.

title: DISHES WITH A HEARTY PEASANT FLAIR
description: -FASHIONED peasant dishes are the most warming antidote to cold weather. Now is the season for hearty meals centered around a plate of simple stuffed cabbage, or a rabbit stew flavored with cognac and mushrooms, or, that splendid Alsatian dish, choucroute garni.

title: Election-Year Taxis
description: The traditional taxi scenario : A battered cab slows and the driver asks, ''Where ya going?'' through a partially opened window. ''Harlem.'' ''No way,'' he snarls, and speeds off.

title: CHINESE ORGANIZED CRIME SAID TO RISE IN U.S.
description: Led by a man posing as an agent of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, four Chinese men kidnapped a wealthy 26-year-old Chinese woman from her home in this Los Angeles suburb last fall. Then they called from Japan to demand ransom of $1 million, to be paid in Tokyo.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

DINING FOR DOLLARS
description: Dining Out for the March of Dimes is going national.

title: Keeping Politics Out of the Court
description: Isn't it just like liberals, after they have cheered the Supreme Court for its politicization of the Constitution these last 22 years, to warn conservatives against the same thing, now that they are in a position to undo the damage (''Keeping Politics Out of the Court,'' by Irving R. Kaufman, Dec. 9)?

title: A DIRECTOR TAKES O'NEILL ALL THE WAY TO CHINA
description: George C. White is president and founder of the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center.

title: A PRINT SHOW ONLY BY APPOINTMENT
description: THE June I Gallery, in Bethlehem, Conn., draws print collectors from all over the country - but only by appointment. It could scarcely be otherwise, given the schedule of the gallery's proprietors, Norman and June Kraeft, who have just produced their second book, ''Great American Prints 1900-1950'' (Dover, $9.95, softcover).

title: MONTCLAIR TEEN-AGER SETS HER SIGHTS ON '88 OLYMPICS
description: MONTCLAIR WHEN the Winter Olympics open in Calgary, Alberta, in 1988, Allison Oki of Montclair will be 21 years old - 4 years older than Elaine Zayak of Paramus was when she skated in the 1984 winter games in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia.

title: APOSTLE OF PERSONALITY
description: FORGOTTEN PROPHET

title: From 'Never'To 'Maybe' onSocial Security
description: Presidents should never say never, said President Ronald Reagan in a pre-election debate with his Democratic challenger, Walter F. Mondale, last year. Last week provided a good example of why. Mr. Reagan indicated that in the case of changing the Social Security benefit structure, ''never'' might mean hardly ever, or only under pressure - from, for instance, ''a possible Congressional mandate.'' The reaction was stiff backs and stern words among possible, if unusual, Congressional allies.

title: PORCELAIN BY HAND IN COPENHAGEN
VANITY AND ABASEMENT, LUST AND PIETY
description: Claude Rawson is the author of ''Order From Confusion Sprung: Studies in 18-Century Literature,'' to be published this spring. JAMES BOSWELL

title: A NEW SETTING AND A NEW CHEF
description: THERE is much that is new about Galleria in Westbury. After a fire last year the restaurant relocated in new quarters about a block away, and a sleeker, more modern look has replaced a rather rococo setting. The chef has also departed to open his own place, Eugen's, on the same street.

title: FROM HARVARD, A NEW BUSINESS PRESS
description: -year hiatus, the Harvard Business School has re-established its book publishing arm, which it has named the Harvard Business School Press. It will not publish how-to or pop management books, of course, and no text or case books. Instead, ''It will be to book publishing what the school's prestigious Harvard Business Review is to magazine publishing,'' said Joanne F. Segal, director of the new press.

title: Miss Payne Texas Bride
description: Miriam Wilson Payne, the daughter of Mrs. Leon Mather Payne of Houston and the late Mr. Payne, was married there yesterday to Charles Horry Prioleau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Means Prioleau of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Dr. John William Lancaster performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: LILCO GETS READY TO TURN UP THE HEAT
description: The nuclear power industry has jumped hundreds of hurdles in its 25 years, but each time it conquered one it found another in its way. This month the Long Island Lighting Company is again exploring the limits of its stamina as it carefully loads fuel at the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station to see if the reactor operates properly at extremely low power.

title: RECOGNITION LEFT POET 'NUMB'
description: WHEN Toi Derricotte of Essex Fells learned recently that she was one of four New Jerseyans to receive a $20,000 fellowship from the National Endowment for the Arts, she confessed to ''being numb.''

title: COLLEGE-SPONSORED TOUR PROGRAMS
description: Some of the richest travel experiences these days are being offered through American colleges and universities. Some are in campus classrooms, others in posh resorts. Still others take their participants on exotic cruises or remote safaris or treks to virtually anywhere in the world that is open to tourism.

title: Pakistan Sets Elections For Parliament Feb. 25
description: President Mohammad Zia ul- Haq announced today that elections would be held Feb. 25 to replace the Parliament that was disbanded in July 1977 with the imposition of martial law, which is still in force.

title: March Wedding For Ellen Lubell
description: Ellen Carol Lubell, a third-year student at the Harvard Law School, and Dr. David Matthew Nathan, director of the Diabetes Clinic and Research Center at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, plan to be married March 23.

title: Shira Spielman Engaged To Robert A. Feuerstein
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Irving Spielman of Fort Lee, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Shira Aliza Spielman, to Robert Allen Feuerstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Feuerstein, also of Fort Lee.

title: KENNEDY TO ASK CONGRESS TO PUNISH SOUTH AFRICA
description: -West Africa, Jan. 12 - Senator Edward M. Kennedy said here today that he did not believe the white authorities in South Africa were committed to ''meaningful progress'' on changing their racial policies, and he indicated he would seek punitive legislation designed to force change.

title: THE REGION ;   Warming TrendIn Labor Talks?
description: It might have been the declaration of an impasse that finally produced at least the hope of movement in New York City's labor negotiations. Just five days after the city's chief labor arbiter formally declared the impasse in the six-month-old talks - a step that paves the way to binding arbitration - Mayor Koch suggested last week that the city was considering raising its offer.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER/BRONZE METTLE
description: RECENTLY, Liz Codola went to Aruba. But there were no swinging palms, no white sands, no turquoise seas. There was only an eerie lavender glow, four lavender painted walls, and a constant hum of machine.

title: BOEHM SALUTING REAGANS By States News Service
description: WASHINGTON

title: KEY HOUSING ISSUES CONFRONT THREE STATE LEGISLATURES
description: FOR the New York State Legislature,

title: TRAPPED BETWEEN GREATNESS AND NICENESS
description: Clancy Sigal's most recent novel is ''Zone of the Interior.'' FACES OF PHILIP

title: GENEVA TALKS FOSTER HOPES FOR EASING OTHER STRAINS
description: WASHINGTON AT his news conference on Wednesday night, President Reagan was asked if the agreement to resume arms control negotiations with the Soviet Union might lead to a new era of detente. ''Yes,'' replied the man who had, in effect, removed that term from the White House lexicon. ''We would welcome such a thing as long as it was a two-way street.''

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: BIT OF A MOVE FOR LONDON LANDMARK, VENEZUELAN MYSTERIES
description: Statue of Eros Moves South In Piccadilly

title: ;   The Plight Of Striped Bass
description: In his Dec. 9 letter to the editor, Assemblyman Patrick G. Halpin commented on two recent articles on the striped bass situation. He wrote: ''Until 500 or so striped bass fishermen on Long Island's East End admit there is a serious problem, no acceptable solution will be forthcoming.'' Mr. Halpin admits there is a serious problem, but apparently he doesn't know what it is.

title: Daniel Walsh to MarryAlison Rabin on July 4
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jules Rabin of Valley Stream, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Alison Beth Rabin to Daniel J. Walsh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Walsh of Des Peres, Mo. The wedding is to be July 4.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;

THEY'RE MAKING MUSIC TOGETHER
description: OLD images often die hard, but the members of the North Shore Pro Musica believe that in the four years since they organized their ensemble, they have come a long way in dispelling the notion that only local music teachers - ''little old ladies in tennis shoes,'' said a founding member, Tamara Slobodkin - perform chamber music on Long Island.

title: MUSIC: VITTORIO RIETI
description: Vittorio Rieti is becoming something of a wonder. He will be 87 years old on the 28th of this month, but he is still composing music that is as sprightly and cheerful as anything he ever wrote. Or at least he was doing so as recently as 1984. At Goodman House on Tuesday night, St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble gave a concert of his works - five all told - and all but one of them dated from the past two years.

title: Topics ;   Lost in Africa
description: Let These People Go

title: Data Update
description: * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: ALONG THE KONA COAST
description: JAMES D. HOUSTON's most recent book is ''Californians: Searching for the Golden State'' (Knopf). He lives in Santa Cruz, Calif., and last year was Distinguished Visiting Writer at the University of Hawaii.

title: HOMETOWN TALENT CREATES A CHARISMA
description: It seems that everyone has a theory about the success of the St. John's University basketball program.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

PORNOGRAPHY AND THE ISSUES FACING SUFFOLK
description: THE war against pornography makes for odd bedfellows. In several places, including Suffolk County, radical feminists found themselves allied with conservative politicians in a joint effort to curb the spread of ''adult'' materials. While some feminists have withdrawn their support from the proposed ordinance, the issue remains.

title: A TOURIST'S LOOK AT LIFE IN THE U.S.S.R.
description: ''Inside Russia'' looks a little like a superior home movie. It is personal and idiosyncratic, and sometimes self-conscious. This is notto say it is amateurish or naive. But the tone and content of ''Inside Russia,'' a production of Metromedia News, suggest that the documentary has been made not so much by television journalists as by inquisitive tourists. Presumably, this is intended. We are meant to see the Soviet Union and its citizens the way we would if we were walking around Moscow, say, or lolling about in Sochi on the Black Sea. At the same time, ''Inside Russia,'' on Channel 5 at 9 tonight, has a deeper purpose: It wants to measure Soviet freedom. How does one live in a totalitarian or authoritarian (the documentary does not split hairs) regime?

title: A GOOD YEAR AT BRADLEY AIRPORT
description: WHEN the final figures on passenger traffic at Bradley International Airport are tallied, state officials think they will show that 1984 was the busiest one ever for the 33-year-old former Army Air Corps facility.

title: The Quest for Stalemate
description: If arms control were chess, the objective would be best defined as stalemate: I can't knock out your king without jeopardizing my own, and vice versa. Where the only possible move is suicidal, both sides are stuck - deterred - provided no other pieces can be deployed to upset the balance.

title: STATE OF THE STATE: CAMPAIGN'S FIRST SALVO
description: TRENTON WHEN Governor Kean entered the State Assembly chamber for his State of the State address last Tuesday, and when he left it afterward, Republican lawmakers chanted ''Four more years!'' - a scene reminiscent of President Reagan's recent campaign.

title: UCONN PROFESSOR AIDS FRENCH PANEL
description: AN expert in medical ethics from the University of Connecticut Health Center will spend the next two months helping a committee in France grapple with new moral issues surrounding medicine.

title: Supportive Service In Anorexia Cases
description: As the founder, in 1979, of Supportive Parents of Anorexics and Bulimics (S.P.A.N.), which meets the third Saturday of each month at the Sloan- Kettering Institute in Rye, I was pleased to see the articles on anorexia nervosa and bulimia.

title: Dark Deeds In Baltimore
description: Baltimore's loss of the Colts was a seduction (''The Seduction of the Colts,'' by Jeffrey Kluger, Dec. 9)? No way! Baltimore did nothing to lose its team - it meant far too much to us.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;

 THE TROUPERS
description: At first glance, the groves of academia would seem far removed from the nightclub stage. But David Axelrod, poet and professor, and Lou Stevens, singer and comedian, have found a common ground. It's called ''The Troupe,'' a multimedia, two- man performance that the Rocky Point residents - Mr. Axelrod teaches at Suffolk Community College, and Mr. Stevens is a familiar figure on the local nightclub circuit. They have been perfecting their routine for some four years now, projecting themselves as ''singing bards,'' or ''court jesters'' and employing music, poetry, mime, magic and comedy to comment on contemporary culture. This afternoon at 2:30 P.M. they bring their lighthearted act to the South Huntington Public Library, 2 Melville Road in Huntington Station. Sponsored by Poets and Writers, Inc., the performance is free. CHASE COLLECTION

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Cable TV

title: HOLY BEAUTY OR DEGRADATION?
description: THE BEANS OF EGYPT, MAINE

title: High Court Clerk Retiring
description: Alexander L. Stevas, the Clerk of the Supreme Court, will retire in July, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger announced Friday. No successor to the 62- year-old Mr. Stevas has been picked. He joined the Court staff in 1980. Mr. Stevas will continue to teach at the George Washington University law school.

title: Resorts Executive Replies to Muziani
description: On the Nov. 25 Opinion Page, Assemblyman Guy R. Muziani contended that casino gaming was having a negative impact on Shore resort hotels. He wrote that casinos, by providing complimentaries for their better customers, were taking business from noncasino hotels and motels and from restaurants and shops, especially in the peak summer tourist season.

title: Point of Clarification On Hospital Program
description: The article ''New Clinic for Eating Disorders'' (Dec. 16) contained a misstatement about the Eating Disorders Program at The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, Westchester division. I refer to the sentence, ''A difference in approach (between the Phelps program and The New York Hospital program) is in the treatment and the fact that patients who fail to complete treatment at New York Hospital will not be readmitted.'' While repetition of a formalized in-hospital treatment program is generally not recommended for patients suffering from anorexia nervosa or bulimia, when clinically appropriate, patients may be and are readmitted to The New York Hospital's Eating Disorde0s Program as part of comprehensive, individualized treatment plans.

description: JOHN BRANNON ALBRIGHT is an editor on the staff of the Travel Section.
