title: Ana Kelton Is MarriedTo Fellow Psychologist
description: At Temple Beth Shmuel in Miami Beach, Fla., yesterday Ana Kelton and Arthur H. Brand, doctoral candidates in clinical psychology at the University of Florida, were married by Rabbi Barry Konovitch. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Aron Kelton of Miami Beach and Mr. and Mrs. Robert Brand of Bayonne, N.J.

title:
ABOUT MEN;

APOCALYPSE CONTINUED
description: LIKE 17 MILLION OTHER MEN WHO CAME of age during Vietnam, I did not serve in the armed forces. It was a blessing, then, to have escaped; it is a burden now. I find there is something missing in me. I have unwanted feelings that nag me in unexpected ways and at unexpected times.

title: BOARD HEAD DISBANDS COMMITTEE ON HOUSING
description: AS Westchester's Board of Legislators went back into session last Monday, one of its committees went out of existence - but not without issuing its first and final report, and not without a fight.

title: HAWAII'S LUNAR LAND
description: MARCIA SELIGSON is a writer who lives in Los Angeles.

title: O'NEIL TO NOMINATE 2 JUDGES TO SUCCEED HIGH COURT JUSTICES
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill says he will nominate two Superior Court judges to the Connecticut Supreme Court when seats become available through retirements.

title: Gary Fishman to Wed Bethany Lynn Kandel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Myron Kandel of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bethany Lynn Kandel, to Gary M. Fishman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Fishman of Pittsford, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

THE GOLDEN YEARS OF THE COLLECTOR'S HOBBY
description: Ten years have passed since restrictions were lifted on the private ownership of gold by United States citizens. During that time the coin market witnessed the most dramatic growth in its history. Some observers see a direct, cause-and-effect correlation.

title: Elaine M. Angelides To Wed P.J. Kopp 3d
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. Louise M. Dantuono of Jamaica Estates, Queens, of the engagement of her daughter Elaine M. Angelides to Philip J. Kopp 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kopp Jr. of Flushing, Queens. A spring wedding is planned.

title: ROUTE 4 OFFICES
description: Except for a two-mile-long bucolic stretch through Teaneck, N.J., most of Route 4 is densely commercial. As it runs through Bergen County from Fort Lee to Paterson, it offers an almost unbroken panorama of gas stations, shopping malls, fast-food restaurants and office buildings.

title: Kathleen Reilly to Wed
description: The engagement of Kathleen Ann Reilly to Anthony J. Spinella, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Spinella of Millwood, N.Y., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Reilly of Bedford Village, N.Y., parents of the prospective bride. Miss Reilly and her fiance are seniors at Lynchburg College and Pace University, respectively.

title: MEDICAL SERVICES UNDER SCRUTINY
description: AMID a growing controversy within Nassau County's Emergency Medical Service system, state and local officials are beginning to start formal inquiries into the effectiveness and efficiency of the system.

title: EVER-PRESENT PAST OF THE SAHARA
description: PETER KLEBNIKOV, a reporter for The New York City Tribune, is a former Peace Corps volunteer in Morocco.

title: LIBERALS' POSITION ON ABORTION IS EXPLAINED
description: Dorothy McLaughlin says pro-choice advocates ''ignore the rights of the people living in utero'' and argues that it would be logical for those who have generally taken the side of others hard- pressed to fight for themselves to espouse the ''Right to Life'' cause.

title: Bottom-Line Effect
description: In his news conference last week, President Reagan said, as he has before, that Social Security spending does not affect the Federal balance sheet. The implication is that a reduction in the cost-of-living adjustment would not reduce the deficit.

title: THE WORLD ;   Missile AccidentKills Three G.I.'s
description: The United States is deploying Pershing 2 medium-range missiles in Western Europe against the Soviet Union, but in West Germany last week the Pershing's first victims were American soldiers.

title: Julia P. Barlow Wed in Capital
description: Julia Powers Barlow and Thomas Van Husen Vail Jr., both lawyers in Cleveland, where his father is publisher and editor of the The Plain Dealer, were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Robert W. Dickey Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: HASTINGS BOOKSTORE A FOLK CONCERT HALL
description: ON the first Monday evening of each month, the strumming of guitars, twang of banjos, and sweet lilt of a penny whistle may be heard in the streets outside the Riverun Bookstore in Hastings-on-Hudson. That is when folk musicians and enthusiasts gather in the front room of this inconspicuous but unusual store to play, sing and listen to folk music, enjoying the conviviality that has grown out of their traditional ''hootenanny.''

title: PENTAGON-COMMERCE DEPT. DISPUTE RESOLVED
description: President Reagan has approved new procedures that spell out how the Defense Department will exercise its increased authority to block the export of high-technology products to non-Communist countries, Administration officials said today.

title: OFFICE GAMES
description: OUR OFFICE BUILDing has dozens of photocopying machines. All day, all night - ours is a round-the-clock business - workers are busy at these machines making copies of letters, newspaper clippings, book pages, blueprints, flow charts and Lord only knows what else.

title: AID TO EDUCATION IN A STATE OF FLUX
description: TOWN officials across the state are worried about explaining state-mandated increases in local education budgets of as much as 30 percent next year.

title: Kassebaum May Shift Her Plans on 3d Term
description: Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, who said in her recent re-election campaign that she would not run for a third term, said today that she was keeping her options open.

title: BLACKOUT IN WEST LAID TO NAVY TEST
description: Metallic particles spread into the atmosphere during Navy exercises Thursday off the Pacific Coast were blamed by civilian officials Friday for knocking out power to 65,000 customers and interfering with radar at airports in southern California.

title: A WINNER OF MEDAL OF HONOR
description: Charles E. Kelly, the World War II hero known as Commando Kelly, died Friday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Pittsburgh after a bowel operation. He was 64 years old.

description: Honduras and El Salvador have replaced the United States as key sources of aid to Nicaraguan rebels, according to Reagan Administration officials and members of Congress.

title: Miss Torrance to WedAlexander Turrentine
description: Lucie Todd Torrance, an assistant vice president of the Chemical Bank, and Alexander Thomas Turrentine, an associate with Morgan Stanley & Company, plan to be married June 15, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Torrance Jr. of Woodbury, Conn., have announced.

title: Zurbriggen Triumphs
description: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland today won his second World Cup downhill within 24 hours.

title: TAKING AN AIR SHOW TO CHINA
description: HARRISON HANS HOLLANDER has spent his entire adult life ''associated with aviation.'' A collection of 30 aircraft models ranging from Boeing's 747 0o McDonald Douglas's F-15 fighter plane occupy the shelf space of his Harrison office. Three Concorde certificates awarded to frequent fliers are prominently displayed on a wall, including one for his French poodle, Cognac. And Mr. Hollander, who commutes between his Westchester and Paris homes aboard the supersonic jet at least once a month, has recently returned from his first trip to Peking.

title: LEBANON DEPLOYS ARMY SOUTH OF BEIRUT
description: The Lebanese Army began deploying its forces down the coastal road south of Beirut today in a much-heralded step in the Government's attempt to extend its authority beyond a few neighborhoods in the capital.

title: Marcy Steinbrecher to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Steinbrecher of Weston, Conn., and Middlefield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marcy Lynn Steinbrecher to Alan Jeffrey Puklin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Puklin of Hamden, Conn. The future bride and Mr. Puklin, who graduated from Clark University, plan to be married in May.

description: the semifinals of the Volvo Masters yesterday, but his ire was raised by

title: JAZZ: SIMS AND COHN
description: Zoot Sims and Al Cohn have been playing together for 37 years, first as members of the saxophone section of Woody Herman's big band and for more than three decades in a variety of small groups of which they were usually the joint leaders. They have been together again for the last week, through tonight, at the Blue Note where, backed by an excellent rhythm section - Ben Aronov, piano, Steve Gilmore, bass, and Billy Hart, drums - they are playing with a relaxed, responsive assurance that is a distillation of their long experience as a team.

title: Jody Kreitchman Wed To Bruce A. Friedman
description: At Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J., yesterday, Jody B. Kreitchman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Kreitchman of South Orange, N.J., was married to Bruce A. Friedman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Friedman of Union, N.J. Rabbi Barry Friedman and Rabbi Joachim Prinz performed the ceremony.

title: Richard W. HollingsworthMarries Melanie C. Zriny
description: Melanie Catherine Zriny, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Zriny of Berkeley Heights, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard W. Hollingsworth, a son of Mrs. William L. Hollingsworth and the late Mr. Hollingsworth of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Finbarr Corr performed the ceremony at St. Vincent the Martyr Roman Catholic Church in Madison, N.J.

title: THE NATION ;   Advisers CouncilMay Survive
description: The White House's Council of Economic Advisers, created by Congress in 1946 to provide the President with nonpartial analyses and the lawmakers with testimony about the executive branch's policies, has its ups and downs. But it has never been so down as in the Reagan Administration, which has left it chairmanless and lacking one of its three members since July.

title: His Son, The Artist
description: I realize now that my personal and youthful experience of growing up in Brooklyn and learning to be an artist was not necessarily unique (''His Son, the Artist,'' by Gene Light, About Men, Dec. 9). However, Gene Light's reminiscences of his father struck too close to home for me not to comment and compare.

title: BOOKSELLERS BLEND A LOVE OF LITERATURE WITH PURSUIT OF PROFIT
description: Dan Balaban, a New Jersey writer, dreamed of a Byronesque life. He opened Balaban's Books in Teaneck ''to be around my dear books.'' Lewis Meyer, ''a failure as a lawyer,'' now owns a bookstore in Tulsa, Okla.

title: Susan Funk, a Consultant, Married to Victor Trovati
description: The marriage of Susan Funk, the daughter of Grace Griffenberg of New York and the late Robert Griffenberg, to Vincent Trovati, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Felice Trovati of Cranbury, N.J., took place yesterday.

title: 'BELL, BOOK AND CANDLE' ALIGHT
description: JOHN VAN DRUTEN'S frothy romantic comedy ''Bell, Book and Candle'' is best known because of Hollywood's charming movie version of the play, which starred Kim Novak and James Stewart. The original comedy, about modern-day sorcerers, is being staged by the Arena Players Repertory Company in East Farmingdale.

title: DETROIT CAR DEALERS FACE U.S. CHARGES
description: The Federal Trade Commission has accused 105 automobile dealers in the Detroit area of violating Federal antitrust laws by closing their showrooms on Saturdays and most evenings.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;

THREE PROGRAMS PONDER THE CONSEQUENCES OF NUCLEAR WAR
description: Steve Schneider frequently reports on developments in cable.

title: TWO SINGERS DISPLAY THEIR DURABLE ART
description: Anita O'Day is one of the sturdiest remaining pillars of the period of pop singing that stemmed from the swing era. The big bands of that day, at least those that were identified as swing bands - played jazz-influenced arrangements of pop songs and instrumental compositions, and their singers usually had some feeling for jazz. Of the women who sang with bands then - with sweet bands as well as swing bands - the only ones who have had any longevity were swing band singers.

title: UNSCRAMBLING THE FOUNDING FATHERS
description: Benjamin R. Barber , a professor of political science at Rutgers University, is the author most recently of ''Strong Democracy'' and ''Marriage Voices,'' a novel. THE LOST SOUL OF AMERICAN POLITICS

title: THE WORLD ;   More Violence inNew Caledonia
description: France offered limited independence last week to its South Pacific colony of New Caledonia as a way out of the occasionally violent political war between nationalist Melanesians and French settlers. But the compromise proposal by Edgard Pisani, the special French envoy, provoked more violence and he declared a state of emergency.

title: JOHN PAUL CHIDES NATIONS ON RIGHTS
description: Pope John Paul II used sharp language today in remarks on defending human and religious rights around the world.

title: DOLE SEES NO CHANCE THIS YEAR FOR A TAX RISE TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, said today that there was no chance of a tax increase this year.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ;   A Polluter's Way Out
description: When Ohio officials went to court to compel the Chem-Dyne Corporation to remove toxic wastes from its property, the corporation's president decided it was time to go under. Last week, the Supreme Court sided with the company, unanimously ruling that under certain circumstances a corporation can invoke the protection of Federal bankruptcy law to avoid a cleanup order.

title: CONTRACT READY ON TURNPIKE FOOD
description: THE contract for 10 McDonald's restaurants on the Connecticut Turnpike is expected to be signed by state officials by the end of the month, and the facilities are expected to be open by May or June.

title: HE DEALS IN MONEY AND JAPANESE FOOD
description: LIFE doesn't always turn out the way it's expected to, which goes a long way toward explaining why, at the age of 39, Edward C. Baltes of New Hyde Park is president of an international money brokerage concern on Wall Street and an owner of two Japanese restaurants.

title: Verbatim: Art and Taxes
description: 'The desire to give to worthy causes is inherent in American character, but the tax laws do affect

title:
CAREFUL SHOPPER;

Quilts: The Making And Care Thereof
description: Quilting can provide longtime satisfaction and keep fingers limber for those who accomplish the task attempted, or for those who admire, collect, display or inherit the artistic work of strangers or relatives. It can also be frustrating when a project in progress cannot be completed, when an old and treasured quilt begins to deteriorate, or when the owner does not know a hanging technique for displaying an acquisition otherwise stored in a trunk.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Ann-Margret is a performer full of surprises. Last year, she won deserved praise for her Blanche Dubois in Tennessee Williams's ''Streetcar Named Desire.''

title: Trapping Roaches
description: Many a New Yorker took heart last September on learning that researchers at Yale University had chemically reproduced a cockroach aphro- disiac given off by the female American roach. When a trap is baited with the stimulant, it was noted, the males fight to get in, and the frenzied commotion lures in the females.

title: Miss Mobley Has Nuptials In Oklahoma
description: Dru Ann Mobley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas L. Mobley of Tulsa, Okla., was married yesterday to Michael Armand Hammer, the son of Julian Armand Hammer of North Hollywood, Calif., and Sue Kane of San Marcos, Calif. The Rev. Dr. James Buskirk performed the ceremony at the First Methodist Church of Tulsa.

title: THE DANCE: GAIL CONRAD
description: Gail Conrad is a brave soul. Everyone knows that tap is meant to be individually improvised, danced to familiar jazz and pop music and performed, once it has left the street corners where it traditionally developed, in a setting as intimate and participatory as possible. Miss Conrad breaks those rules.

title: JACOB'S PILLOW PLAN SET
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival selected an architectural plan Friday for the renovation of the 27 buildings on the 72-acre site of its school and theater in Becket, Mass.

title: OLYMPIC TRAINING A HELP TO PLAYER
description: Two not currently available years ago, Scott Fusco was one of two reasons Harvard was the surprise of Eastern college hockey and runner-up for the N.C.A.A. chasmpionship. The other reason was Scott's brother Mark, then a senior, who won the Hobey Baker Award as the nation's best hockey player.

title:
GARDENING;

GROUND COVERS FOR A DRY, SUNNY SLOPE
description: TO continue our discussion on ground covers, it would seem appropriate to begin with those best suited to the most difficult site - the dry, south-facing slope. The number of suitable plants is limited and it does not pay to stray too far afield in search of others perhaps more favored by the gardener. To do so is to invite failure.

title: U.S. SAID TO PLAN TO SELL NAVAL WEAPONS TO CHINA
description: The Reagan Administration has reached a preliminary understanding with China to provide that Government with modern antisubmarine warfare gear, a Reagan Administration official said today.

title: LOOKING AT RECENT TAX RULE CHANGES
description: THE Internal Revenue Service started off the

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ;   'Stop and Frisk'Rules ExtendedBy High Court
description: If recent judicial decisions can be said to have tied the hands of the police, then a ruling last week by the United States Supreme Court loosened the ropes a bit. By a unanimous vote, the High Court decided that law enforcement officials do not need a warrant to stop and briefly question a person they know is wanted by the authorities in another jurisdiction.

title: MISSING PERSONS: THE TOLL MOUNTS ON L.I.
description: CONCETTA NAPOLI and her family spent 24 days in their Lynnbrook home suspended in sadness and fear, hoping only that the phone would ring and that her daughter, 15-year-old Theresa, would be on the other end, blurting out some teen-age excuse about why she had been away so long. The call never came.

title: NEW PLAY IS RIPE BUT ROUGH
description: LABELING a play or a playwright ''promising'' can smack of condescension. Regarding ''Beloved Friend'' at the Hartman Theater in Stamford, such an appellation is not intended as paltry praise.

title: PAUL DUNKEL: FREEDOM BEHIND THE BATON
description: THE youthful conductor sat on a stool in the auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, rehearsing Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 21 with the orchestra and soloist.

title: Iranian Ship Crippled By Iraqi Jet Attack
description: An Iranian bulk carrier, the 18,000-ton Iran-Emdad, was attacked and crippled by an Iraqi jet fighter in the northern Persian Gulf, shipping executives here said today.

title: BIG AND BOXY BAGS FOR WINTER GEAR
description: Uptown and downtown, wrapped in scarfs and long coats against the bite of the city's cold snap, many pedestrians are carrying something new: overscaled leather luggage bags and carpetbags in flowered patterns.

title: IN NEW JERSEY: KEAN SEEKS MORATORIUM ON MR. LAUREL CONSTRUCTION
description: A PROPOSED moratorium on ''builders' remedies'' under the State Supreme Court's Mount Laurel II decision will be the key housing issue before the New Jersey Legislature during this year's session.

title: KOCH SEEKING MEETINGS WITH BLACK LEADERS
description: Mayor Koch is trying to set up meetings this week with black public and Democratic Party officials in Manhattan and Brooklyn in an effort, he said, to ''bring as much harmony as possible'' to the city.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

A GAUGE OF RAIL PERSONALITIES
description: THE other morning my commuting train was late. My fellow commuters, who huddle in groups in designated areas along the platform - began to exhibit their ''looking-down-the-track'' personalities.

title: WORKER-OWNED PLANT FIGHTS FOR SURVIVAL IN COURT IN IOWA
description: More than 100 Rath Packing Company workers filled a bankruptcy courtroom this week as lawyers outlined proposals for salvaging what remains of the company, once a major meatpacker.

title: 'White Noise,' by Don DeLillo
description: The fiction of Don DeLillo is no longer the well-kept secret of a dedicated following. In such novels as ''Ratner's Star,'' ''Great Jones Street'' and ''The Names,'' Mr. DeLillo has dealt not so much with character as with culture, survival and the subtle, ever-increasing interdependence between the self and the national and world community. The he-man against the elements, the outlaw, the superhero exist only as myths in the modern world; we are nature's elements, a technologically oriented people nonetheless caught in the sieve of history. There are suspense and an urgent intelligence to Mr. DeLillo's writing, a sense of the widening gyre and the tight-drawn net. ''White Noise,'' his eighth novel, is the story of a college professor and his family whose small Midwestern town is evacuated after an industrial accident. In light of the recent Union Carbide disaster in India that killed over 2,000 and injured thousands more, ''White Noise'' seems all the more timely and frightening - precisely because of its totally American concerns, its rendering of a particularly American numbness.

title: TURNING A RAILROAD AROUND
description: Winston Williams reports on business for The New York Times.

title: WRONGS IN THE NAME OF RIGHTS
description: Louis Winnick is the author of several books on housing and urban policies, including ''American Housing and Its Use.'' DISABLING AMERICA

title: Doria Sequel
description: Three years of speculation over the contents of a locked safe recovered from the sunken liner Andrea Doria ended in August, when the safe was opened in a splash of national publicity at New York City's Aquarium.

title: Spending for Welfare Put Near $600 Billion
description: The Federal Government and state and local governments spent $592.6 billion on social welfare programs in the fiscal year 1982, or 19.3 percent of the combined value of all goods and services produced in the nation, according to a study by the Social Security Administration.

title: PATRICE CHEREAU-FRANCE'S TRIPLE THREAT TO THE ARTS
description: In Europe, and increasingly in the United States, Patrice Chereau is considered one of the most innovative, versatile and controversialartists working today. Best known for his iconoclastic staging of Wagner's ''Ring of the Niebelung'' for the Bayreuth Centenary - aired on PBS - he is also a renowned actor, theater director as well as administrator, and filmmaker.

title: THE LANGUAGE OF HOME
description: Why do writers write about the same place over and over again? There are probably as many answers to this question as there are writers obsessed with a city, a county, a village or a community. Rather than try to speak for others whose one certified virtue is speaking well for themselves, I'll focus my thoughts on the turn my own work has taken, my excursions home again, home again in fiction and nonfiction, to Homewood, a black neighborhood in Pittsburgh.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: NOW that the holidays are over, state, county and local traffic-enforcement agencies are able to breathe a little easier. Over all, traffic deaths on state and county highways in 1984 were down, compared to past years, as were drunken-driving reports and minor accidents.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Sports Pages Friday about the opening of the New York National Boat Show gave the incorrect admission fee for adults. It is $6.

title: OUT OF THE ORDINARY CHINESE
description: FROM inauspicious storefront beginnings in Norwalk a few years ago, a new and promising Chinese restaurant has ripened in a roomier, more impressive locale in Westport.

title: BORN AND BORN AND BORN ON A REPEATEDLY DARKLING PLAIN
description: William Cole is the editor of numerous poetry anthologies.

title:
THE MIGHTY DOLLAR;

BEWARE OF ITS SHORT-TERM BENEFITS
description: THERE is no silver lining for

title: TRICENTENARIES CREATE A SHOWCASE FOR BAROQUE SPECIALISTS
description: Barrymore Scherer writes frequently about the arts.

title: HEADLINERS;
description: Back Taxes It was just a $20 million ''misrepresentation of facts,'' a Chicago real estate assessor said, explaining why condominium converter

title: IN THE CRATER OF HALEAKALA
description: FLETCHER KNEBEL's most recent novel is ''Poker Game'' (Doubleday).

GARDENING;

GROUND COVERS FOR A DRY, SUNNY SLOPE
description: TO continue our discussion on ground covers, it would seem appropriate to begin with those best suited to the most difficult site - the dry, south-facing slope. The number of suitable plants is limited and it does not pay to stray too far afield in search of others perhaps more favored by the gardener. To do so is to invite failure.

title:
ANTIQUES;

GEORGE WASHINGTON SLEPT HERE
description: WAYNE EXTENDING the museum concept to include the adaptive use of facilities to meet community needs is a significant step in encouraging preservation and financing.

title: MEATBALLS: UNIVERSAL APPEAL
description: IT HAS ALways been a source of fascination to think that most people in this country seem convinced that meatballs are as American as clam chowder, Philadelphia scrapple, eggs Benedict or cornbread. And those who think they did not originate on these shores swear that they are of Italian origin, having dined most of their lives on spaghetti and meatballs.

title:
THE MIGHTY DOLLAR;

THE NEW MONETARY STANDARD OF THE 80'S
description: THE American dollar goes from

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Sadness as a Vocation

title: FOR STATE'S BALLPLAYERS, OFF-SEASON'S ANOTHER GAME
description: TWO television sets beam sporting events to the noontime crowd at the Stamford restaurant. Above the screens, an electronic ticker runs a steady stream of sports statistics from events the night before. The walls are crowded with photographs of sports stars and team portraits.

title: KIDNAPPING IN CALIFORNIA IS FINALLY UNTANGLED
description: The case of the kidnapping of Bobby Smith, which began in California nearly two years ago, has been resolved here in a day.

title: Gay Luster Married to Frederick Lack Sawabini
description: Gay Luster, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl J. Luster of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Frederick Lack Sawabini, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Wadi I. Sawabini of Burlington, Vt. The Rev. William Eddy performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: R. K. Cadwalader Weds Miss Curry
description: Susan Heron Curry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Milo Curry 3d of Sewickley, Pa., was married there yesterday to Richard Kent Cadwalader, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gouverneur Cadwalader Jr. of Unionville, Pa. The Rev. Robert D. Nix Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church.

title: INTRIGUE AND COUNTERCHARGES MARK CASE OF PUPRPORTED SPIES
description: It was, the Federal Bureau of Investigation says, a cat-and-mouse game designed to trap a Soviet-bloc spy, identified by authorities as Karl Frantisek Koecher.

title: Women in the Mainstream
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT
description: FICTION

title: NO, THERE'S NO WAY WE COULD HAVE HEARD THE SAME CONCERT
description: The most common line that occurs in letters of objection received by music critics, according to a small, privately financed poll, is this one: ''I really can't believe we heard the same concert.'' It is such a stock response that it tends to dull whatever sharp points the complainant may have tried to make. That is because the trouble with most cliches is not that they are false but that they simply are too old and tired to sing anymore. They are too true to be good.

title: JERSEY UPHELD ON REGULATING DEGREES OF RELIGIOUS COLLEGES
description: New Jersey won a long battle with Shelton College last week when the United States Supreme Court let stand a lower court's ruling that state regulation of degree-granting religious schools does not interfere with the free exercise of religion.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

A YEAR'S WORTH OF VIRTUE
description: FOR one year, my daughter was a paper girl. She delivered the local newspaper - an afternoon paper on weekdays that becomes a morning edition on weekends and holidays.

title: Going Deeper Into Hock
description: If consumers seemed to be doing more browsing than buying last month, it was probably because they had been on a yearlong shopping binge for big-ticket items such as cars and appliances and thus were unwilling to assume more debt. That, at least, is the conclusion of Nancy J. Kimelman, a Salomon Brothers economist.

title: A FEW WORDS WITH NORMAN, TRUMAN AND GORE
description: CONVERSATIONS WITH AMERICAN WRITERS

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ;   A New ClueTo Senility?
description: A protein linked to a common fatal disease of the nervous system in sheep and hamsters may also bring on some forms of senility in humans, scientists from the University of California at San Francisco and Berkeley reported last week. But the mysterious agent is so new to the investigators that they do not yet even agree on a name for it. It is so small that it cannot be detected except in clusters even under the most powerful microscopes. And it contains none of the genetic material - DNA or RNA - that allows all other forms of life to reproduce.

title: Dr. Ernani D'Angelo, Psychiatrist in Queens
description: Dr. Ernani D'Angelo, a retired psychiatrist who had a private medical practice in Jamaica, Queens, for 40 years, died Jan. 2 at the Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Boynton Beach, Fla., after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Boynton Beach.

title: WATER LAWSUIT STIRS EAST END
description: A LAWSUIT filed against the Suffolk County Water Authority, aimed at preventing the extension of water mains into an environmentally sensitive area of East Hampton township, could have a significant effect on public water policies throughout the county and in other parts of the state.

title: Simpleton Peter; The Well of the World's End Volume I of ''Walt Disney Stories and Fables''
description: Walt Disney Home Video 50 minutes. $49.95

title: PROSPECTS
description: To Save or to Spend

title: OFFICIALS SHOPPING FOR A PRISON SITE
description: THE state is in the market for a site for a new prison. It hopes it pays to advertise. Finding a town in Connecticut willing to have a prison in it is not easy, and the State Correction Commissioner, Raymond M. Lopes, will not say if he has a specific community in mind. He said that naming a site would be ''the kiss of death,'' and that ''most people do not want a prison in their particular town.''

title: GUATEMALA CRUSHES REBELS ITS OWN WAY: RUTHLESSLY
description: In sharp contrast to neighboring El Salvador, the Guatemalan military has defeated an extensive guerrilla insurgency, and it has done so without the assistance of American advisers and equipment. Virtually all United States military aid ended in 1977 when the Guatemalan Army refused to meet the Carter Administration's human rights standards. The Reagan Administration ended the seven-year embargo by giving Guatemala $300,000 for military training this year, a symbolic sum that is unlikely to influence Guatemalan tactics.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FOSTER SONGS

title: LOTS OF SHOTS, BUT RANGERS TIE
description: The goaltender's job, as difficult as it is, should not be so complicated. But there was Glen Hanlon kicking away a slap shot from the blue line in one instance, and in the next, laying on his back after an opponent had crashed into him.

title: WAS OUR TIME WORTH MORE BEFORE IT CAME IN QUARTZ?
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE THE EAST BLOCK'S AFRICAN OUTPOST
description: Col. Viktor V. Gorbatko of the Soviet Army relaxed on a lawn chair by a hotel pool here and regaled his companions with his most recent visit to ''Budapesht.'' Even through an interpreter, the tale made an East German officer slap his thigh, a North Korean smile appreciatively and an Angolan lieutenant colonel chuckle.

title: INDIANS RESIST SHIFT IN ECONOMIC GOALS URGED BY U.S. PANEL
description: Indian tribal leaders have voiced strong opposition to proposals from a Presidential panel to direct economic development efforts on reservations away from social goals and toward private ownership and the profit motive.

title: JOHN DEERE, THROUGH THE YEARS
description: John Deere's Company: A History of Deere & Company and Its Times, by Wayne G. Broehl Jr. Doubleday, N.Y., 880 pages, $24.95.

title: Q&A
description: The landlord of my rent-controlled apartment wants me to move one floor so he can renovate in preparation for converting the building to condominium ownership. The new unit has none of the improvements I made. What rights do I have? . . . A. H., Manhattan

title: BEST RESTAURANTS (CONTINUED)
description: THE turn of the calendar to a new year is always a time to reflect on seasons past. Looking back over the scores of restaurants we have reviewed in the last five years, there are many that come to mind as special.

title: FANS FOR MARK TWAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Tsianina Redfeather Blackstone, an American Indian who sang on the Metropolitan Opera stage and on the battlefields of France in World War I, died Thursday in San Diego.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

THE BUILDING OF CHARACTER, 1980'S-STYLE
description: NOT once did I plod five miles to school through driving hail and blizzards, as so many of my parents' generation brag of doing. This character-building feat is undoubtedly enshrined on their early resumes under achievements: ''Trudged five miles to school (and back) through snow, floods, tornadoes, you name it.''

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ;   Great Tree Hunt
description: As do people, many of New York's 2.6 million trees struggle to survive. Last September, the Department of Parks and Recreation began what it called ''a Great Tree Search'' to find the city's more valiant trees.

title: SHOREHAM LOADING: 'SHUFFLE' BEGINS
description: A FEW years ago when the companies that manufacture nuclear reactors were looking for a way to explain the advantages of nuclear power, they began mass-producing a souvenir for plant visitors, an inert piece of ceramic material about the size of an eraser on the end of a pencil, meant to simulate a uranium fuel pellet. The pellet, according to the card to which it is attached, has the same amount of energy as three and a half 42-gallon barrels of oil, or 157 gallons of regular gasoline, or 1,800 pounds of coal.

title: STUDY OF POWER AGENCY URGES AN OUTSIDE AUDIT
description: The budget and audit procedures of the New York Power Authority are inadequate and the agency should undergo an independent and extensive management review, a legislative panel has recommended.

title: Carolina Klan Agrees Not to Harass Blacks
description: A North Carolina Ku Klux Klan leader has agreed not to hold demonstrations by his group in predominantly black neighborhoods, not to operate paramilitary camps in the state and not to harass blacks or whites who associate with blacks.

title: HEATING-OIL SALES SAGGED IN DECEMBER'S WARMTH
description: Dealers in home heating oil in the New York metropolitan region said last week that the warmest December on record had reduced their business by as much as 20 percent so far this winter.

title: SON AND MIDWIFE TO STRAVINSKY
description: PRESENT PERSPECTIVES

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: New & Noteworthy

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ;   Less for LawyersOn Agent Orange
description: A Federal judge last week awarded lawyers in the Agent Orange case fees that totaled less than a quarter of what they had requested. Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn gave final approval to the settlement of the lawsuit, under which seven manufacturers of Agent Orange created a $180 million fund to compensate Vietnam War veterans and their families who contend that their health was damaged because of exposure to the herbicide.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article last Sunday about the award of 100 writing fellowships by the National Endowment for the Arts omitted the names of four recipients.

title: Pamela D. Stanton Is Married to Barry D. Mayer
description: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday Pamela Dawn Stanton, the daughter of Mrs. Robert E. Stanton of Vernon, N.Y., and the late Mr. Stanton, was married to Barry Dean Mayer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry M. Mayer of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth Jones performed the ceremony.

title: A BRITISH PROJECT
description: Following the lead of other foreign real-estate companies that have found New York City to be lucrative territory for office development, a British-based company, Heron International, will erect an $80 million, 30-story office building on East 55th Street.

title: EAST VILLAGE GETS ON THE FAST TRACK
description: No doubt about it, the East Village scene is a howling success. In the three years since the first gallery, the Fun, opened up there, the tough turf of drugs, punk rock and prostitution that characterizes the blocks from Houston to 14th Streets, from Second Avenue to the East River, has posed a challenge to mighty SoHo as a breeding-testing ground for young art. Now, with its mean streets and dingy clubs still providing a sense of adventure, it's the place to show, go and be seen. So hot, in fact, is this artists' milieu, many of whose more-or-less improvisatory galleries are themselves artist-run, that it's taken on the dimensions of a Movement.

title: DR. SUZANNE ROGACZ WED IN CAMBRIDGE
description: Dr. Suzanne Rogacz and Dr. Steven Toshihiro Kariya, fellows in endocrinology and in pulmonary medicine, respectively, at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, were married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday. The nondenominational ceremony at the Harvard Memorial Church was performed by the Rev. Elizabeth B. Krantz-Wee, a Lutheran minister, and the Rev. Thomas Powers, director of Catholic chaplain services at Harvard University.

title: Jana Singer Plans Wedding in April
description: Dr. and Mrs. Ellis Singer of Edison, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jana Singer to Vincent F. Prada, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Prada of Edgartown, Mass. An April wedding is planned.

title: WALL STREET'S NEW INVENTOR CLASS
description: EXCEPT for a handful of financial mavericks such as the legendary Sidney Weinberg, Robert Lehman and Andre Meyer, Wall Street investment bankers were for years wedded to long-term fixed-rate bonds, straight common stock, and a handful of other financial standbys.

title: ON THE PROPER CARE AND TREATMENT OF PAINT BRUSHES
description: IN many cases, the difference between a

title: SALARY ARBITRATION BECOMES A GAME WITHIN THE GAME
description: Rickey Henderson, who last year failed to surpass Fernando Valenzuela's salary arbitration record of $1 million, does not need salary arbitration this year. He has a new $8.6 million contract with the Yankees, and his $1.3 million salary for 1985 plus his $850,000 signing bonus will do nicely.

title: Wendi F. Weill, Lawyer, Weds Matthew I. Seiden
description: The marriage of Wendi Fern Weill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Weill of Westfield, N.J., to Matthew Ian Seiden, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hank Seiden of New York, took place yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in Westfield. Rabbi Charles Kroloff performed the ceremony.

title: KNICKS LOSE 12TH STRAIGHT ON ROAD
description: The Knicks set a club record of 12 consecutive road losses tonight by losing to the Indiana Pacers, 100-95, at the Market Square Arena.

title: THE TREND SETTING TRADITIONALISM OF ARCHITECT ROBERT A.M. STERN
description: Carol Vogel is the home design editor of this magazine.

title: BROKERING DEALS BETWEEN EAST AND WEST
description: WASHINGTON IN Dalien, a town in northern China,

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Television news coverage of Long Island will take another step tomorrow evening at 7:30 when ''The Long Island Report'' makes its debut on WLIW-TV, Long Island's public television station, Channel 21.

title: DEFINITION TELEVISION IS BRIGHTENING THE HORIZON
description: The new year will be decisive for video and television. An international committee representing virtually every country with television services convenes in September in Geneva, Switzerland, to recommend new worldwide standards for television transmission that will eventually supplant those in current use. It is expected that the CCIR (Comite Consultativ International des Radiocommunications) will favor high-definition television (HDTV, for short) as the video standard of the future.

title: THE WORLD ;   Thais FaceVietnamese
description: One of the biggest concerns about the six-year-old Cambodian war has been the risk that it might spread to other countries. For a brief moment last week, the risk became acute as Vietnamese troops crossed into Thailand and came face to face with Thai troops.

title: AFFLUENT SHOPPERS AND YOUTHS' VALUES
description: It was with great dismay that I read the article ''They Go Shopping, Browsing, Splurging.'' (Dec. 16)

title: KING CELEBRATION
description: Tuesday marks what would have been the 56th birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. In tribute to the slain civil rights leader, Herbert H. Lehman College plans several hours of gospel music, modern dance and dramatic readings at 2 P.M. next Sunday at its Center for the Performing Arts.

title: LAWSUITS KNOCK HOLES IN FORCED RETIREMENT
description: The nine Justices of the United States Supreme Court - five of them in their late 70's - took sides last week with a group of former Trans World Airlines pilots who wanted to keep working after 60. Although Federal aviation regulations provide that pilots must stop flying at that age, the Court ruled that the airline was guilty of illegal age discrimination when it refused to transfer them to the lower-ranking job of flight engineer, in which they could have continued to work for another 10 years. In a unanimous decision, the Court said that, since the airline provided automatic transfers for younger pilots who became disabled and wished to work as flight engineers, older pilots had to be given the same opportunity.

title: TEXT OF O'NEILL'S STATE OF STATE ADDRESS
description: HARTFORD

title: The Importance Of General Jaruzelski
description: To Michael Kaufman's interesting article, ''The Importance of General Jaruzelski'' (Dec. 9), I would like to add that the General is only one of three acrobats presently walking parallel tightropes in Poland. The other two are Joseph Cardinal Glemp and Nobel Prize winner Lech Walesa.

title: BUDGET SURPLUS DEFINES O'NEILL'S AGENDA
description: HARTFORD

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The non-Indian approach is, you go into business with one motive, which is the profit motive. The Indian way is to go into business to provide income for tribal members, to provide employment for as many tribal members as you can.'' - Elmer Savilla, executive director of the National Tribal Chairmen's Association. (16:1.)

title: TOPICS
description: It's a new year, and time to clean house. Clear out the tattered remains of all those Christmas catalogues. What's this? The mailbox is filling up again.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:

title: A June Wedding For Miss Duggan
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald D. Duggan of Kinnelon, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Donna Danielle Duggan to Paul Andrew Redmond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Redmond of West Orange, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Ellen Greenspan Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard L. Greenspan of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Amy Greenspan, to David H. Wells, a son of Sheila Wells of Downey, Calif., and Charles Wells of Anaheim, Calif. A June wedding is planned. Miss Greenspan, a graduate of Smith College, is a rabbinical candidate at Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion in New York. Mr. Wells, a graduate of Pitzer College, is a photojournalist for the Syracuse Newspapers.

title: 7 VYING TO LEAD THE DEMOCRATS SOMEWHERE
description: The major point of consensus among the seven candidates for the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee is that the party must reshape its message to the voters. But so far there is no agreement on what that appeal ought to be or, for that matter, what it is right now. ''Whatever it is, it's confused,'' Nancy Pelosi acknowledged on Wednesday when a group of reporters pressed her to define the party's message.

title: Zaccaro Admits Attempted Fraud
description: John A. Zaccaro entered a guilty plea in a Manhattan courtroom last week to a charge that he attempted to defraud a New Jersey mortgage broker. He then tried to re-enter the private life he had enjoyed as a real estate investor before he sprang onto the national scene last summer when his wife, Geraldine A. Ferraro, became the Democratic candidate for Vice President.

title: TIGHTER REIN ON INCENTIVES FOR BUSINESS
description: The 1,200 employees who worked at the Playskool toy factory in West Chicago in 1980 were delighted when the City of Chicago issued $1 million in low-interest industrial revenue bonds to help modernize the plant.

title: BLOOD-DOPING UNETHICAL, U.S. OLYMPIC OFFICIAL SAYS
description: The executive director of the United States Olympic Committee yesterday condemned as unethical the practice of athletes' undergoing blood transfusions to improve their performances.

title: Susan Silberstein To Wed a Doctor
description: Dr. and Mrs. Charles E. Silberstein of Brooklandville, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Amy Silberstein, to Dr. Jonathan Peter Jarow, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Jarow of Merrick, L.I. The wedding is to take place in June.

title: ACES AT GAMEBOARD COLLECTING
description: Folk art enthusiasts continue to pioneer in acquiring the artifacts of everyday living that amateur artisans devised for their pleasurable use a half century or more ago. Now, another category of such collectibles - the painted boards made for playing checkers, Parcheesi, backgammon, darts and ring toss - has been identified in a lighthearted exhibition, ''Winning Moves: Gameboards of North America,'' at the Museum of American Folk Art, 125 West 55th Street, through March 3.

title: FOR MYRNA LOY, A LATE BUT LOVING TRIBUTE
description: Among those stellar film actresses

title: A MOTHER TELLS GOVERNOR SEAT-BELT ACT SAVED SONS
description: A Massachusetts woman has written Governor Cuomo to say that New York's new seat-belt law saved her two sons' lives.

title: HOOPLA AND HULLABALOO ON THE LONDOAN LITERARY SCENE
description: John Gross is a book critic for The New York Times.

title: CHANGES AFFECTING CO-OPS
description: SEASONED officials of New York City

title: Amnesty in Togo
description: President Gnassingbe Eyadema has reduced by a quarter the prison sentences of 1,026 common criminals to mark the 18th anniversary of his coming to power, which is Sunday, an official statement said today.

title: Institution Population Found to Be 2.4 Million
description: More than one American in 100 lives in a prison, a home for the aged, a mental hospital or other type of institution, the Census Bureau has reported.

title: MEET CARL JONES-ACTOR, AGENT, EDITOR, AUTHOR
description: AT THE age of 16, Carl Johnes appeared with Bess Meyerson in a production of ''Tea and Sympathy'' in Somers Point, Atlantic County.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

IN GUARDING AGAINST FUTURE BHOPALS, PRESENT HAZARDS SHOULD NOT BE IGNORED
description: IN the last few weeks, much attention has

title:
DINING OUT;

FAMILY-STYLE DINING IN NEW JERSEY
description: THERE have been many articles in recent years about the revitalization of New Jersey's urban areas. One of the outward signs of change is the opening of exciting new stores and restaurants.

title: THE LAUGHTER OF HIS MOTHER'S GHOST
description: Raymond Rosenthal is a critic and translator from Italian and French. ARACOELI

title: ;   THE POOR AREN'T LOOKING ANY YOUNGER
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN THE QUEST FOR TACTICAL CHANCES BACKFIRES
description: Marlo Micayabas, an international master from the Philippines, won the Labate's Chess Center Open Tournament in Anaheim, Calif., scoring 3 1/2- 1/2 in the four-round Swiss-system event to capture the $400 first prize. Three American international masters, Vincent McCambridge, John Donaldson and David Strauss, shared second place with 3-1 each.

title: A PLAYER ON THE RISE
description: For more than a decade Bob Hamman of Dallas has been the top American in world rankings. He has steadily gained ground on the Italian stars Giorgio Belladonna and Benito Garozzo and may one day be the world's top-ranked player.

title: Youth Orchestra Deserves Mention
description: We were delighted, at the Westchester Conservatory of Music, to find Roberta Hershenson's article (''A Busy Time for Youth Orchestras,'' Dec. 9). The experience of musical-group involvement is invaluable to students.

title: MAILBAG
description: OF MUSEUMS AND DIVAS

title: JETLINER IS SAID TO CRASH OFF IRAN BUT OFFICIALS SUSPECT A HOAX
description: The Kuwait airport control tower received a distress signal today purportedly radioed by a ''crashing jetliner'' in the Persian Gulf, but airport officials said later that they believed the report was a hoax.

title: A DIFFERENT TUNE
description: The weeks between the re-election of President Reagan and his inauguration have been marked in Washington by a different tune. The campaign itself, as usual, was a noisy riot of strong passions and weak reason, but lately there has been a revival of common sense.

title: West Side Apartment House Is Evacuated Over Gas Leak
description: Forty-three people were evacuated from a West Side apartment building last night after a gas leak was reported, officials said.

title: POLICEMAN SHOT IN BROOKLYN RAID
description: An undercover police officer was wounded in a shooting last night during a narcotics raid on a bar in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, the police said. Three men were arrested in connection with the shooting.

title: CITY SCHOOLS GET NEW FISCAL CHIEF DESPITE FIGHT OVER TITLE
description: Jerald Posman, a candidate proposed by City Hall, will take up new duties tomorrow as deputy chancellor for financial affairs to oversee the $3.8 billion budget of the New York City schools.

title: Rating The Colleges
description: When discussing selectivity ranking in Barron's ''Profiles of American Colleges,'' Michael Winerip names one college - coed - whose ranking has improved, and three colleges - women's - whose rankings have declined (''Hot Colleges and How They Get That Way,'' Nov. 18).

title: AS MISSILE STEP NEARS, BELGIAN DEBATE GROWS
description: As Belgium's Prime Minister prepares to meet with President Reagan on Monday, pressure is increasing on the Government to reject the immediate deployment of NATO cruise missiles, officials and diplomats here say.

title: On Uses and Abuses Of Land in North
description: In their article ''Plans Are Needed for Development in North of County,'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 6), as in their ''open letter'' to County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke published in The Patent Trader in November 1984, Stuart R. Shamberg and George M. Raymond attempt to make a case for drastic and widespread downzoning of land in northern Westchester in order to build many more houses and thus solve the county's ''housing crisis.'' The reason for the crisis that they cite is the construction of millions of square feet of new office space in central and northern Westchester.

title: SMALL GROUPPS SIGN PACTS
description: While opera and the symphony make the most impact by the very large and grand nature of those ventures, music-making by smaller groups in the concert hall has also shown remarkable growth in popularity in recent years. And, while one would guess that smaller-group records lag behind those larger forces in sales, the record companies nevertheless have continued to add to their catalogues of music by smaller ensembles, and two new recording agreements testify to that interest.

title: Normandy
description: To the Editor:

title: Anne O'Herron, a Graduate Student, To Marry Jonathan Burleigh, Banker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan O'Herron of Darien, Conn., and Woods Hole, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne O'Herron to Jonathan B. Burleigh, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Burleigh Jr. of Atlanta. A June wedding is planned.

title: A CHAMBER ENSEMBLE AND TWO SINGERS PRESENT RECITALS
description: Two singers and a chamber ensemble from Italy gave debut concerts last week. Robert Hoven, a bass-baritone, and Caroline Stewart, a soprano, sang programs at Carnegie Recital Hall, and last Saturday night, the Quartetto Guglielmi di Roma played music from 18th-century Italy.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: There aren't many folksingers who can boast commendations from the likes of both Johnny Cash and the venerable Country Dance and Song Society. But then John McCutcheon, who will perform on Friday in the Pinewoods Folk Music Club series at P.S. 41 at Sixth Avenue and 11th Street, covers a lot of musical ground, accompanying himself with engaging simplicity on a wide variety of instruments. On Friday he'll stick to the fiddle, banjo, guitar and auto harp, as well as the hammered dulcimer, for which he is best known.

title: MAILBAG
description: OF MUSEUMS AND DIVAS

title: IDEALISM AT THE HARTMAN
description: or a playwright - ''promising'' can smack of condescension. Considering ''Beloved Friend'' at the Hartman Theater, such an appelation is not intended as paltry praise.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Bookshelf

title: AMBULANCE SERVICE 'UNFAIRLY' SINGLED OUT
description: My name and story appeared in the article ''Ambulance Service Debated'' (Dec. 9). When I agreed to help with this article, I understood that my experience was one of several that had occurred to others as a result of calling 911.

title: CONSUMER RATESIn percent
description: Passbook Savings*5.50 At savings institutions

title: Nassau's System
description: The emergency medical service system in Nassau County is a combination of three systems: the Police Department, volunteer fire departments and volunteer ambulance corps.

title: CLINIC WITH DORMS
description: After a delay of nearly two years, a row of abandoned turn-of-the- century brownstones at the edge of Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem is being transformed into a mental health clinic and residence.

title: ;   TOPICS
description: The cast iron wood stove that sits proudly in our family room is certainly not what I had in mind when I first dreamed of a house back in the 60's.

title: Tracy Lynn Brod Becomes a Bride
description: Tracy Lynn Brod, a daughter of Irven J. Brod of New York and Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. Raphael Vogel of Greenwich, was married in New York yesterday to Paul Edward Taylor 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., and Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Robert Randall performed the ceremony at the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church.

title: STADLER KEEPS LEAD IN HOPE TOURNEY
description: Craig Stadler held onto the lead after four rounds of the 26th annual Bob Hope Classic today, although his margin dropped from three strokes to one.

title: Blood Shortage in California Draws Wide Plea for Donors
description: A blood shortage that the Red Cross describes as critical in southern California has forced some hospitals to delay operations and to plead for donors.

title: IN CONNECTICUT: PROPERTY TAX CUTS APPEAR LIKELY
description: WITH Connecticut's government enjoying economic prosperity for a change, the General Assembly appears ready to share the wealth by providing some property-tax relief to homeowners and businesses.

title: Development And Drinking Water
description: In a recent Opinion page column (Long Island Weekly, Dec. 16), there appeared an article entitled ''Development and Drinking Water: The Dangers of the Mix.'' The article did a fine job at highlighting the degrees to which land development poses a threat to the integrity of Long Island's vulnerable groundwater system. I feel it is important however to clarify one of the important statements in the article to more accurately put into context the efforts to date of Suffolk County.

title: Tanzanian Leader Says He Will Step Down
description: President Julius K. Nyerere says he will not run for re-election when his term expires at the end of the year, the official Tanzanian radio reported today.

title: FROM THE BRONX, ENSEMBLES STRIKE UP
description: THE next couple of weeks provide a number of good musical reasons to take the short ride across the Bronx border, starting today at 3 P.M. when an unusual programming split brings both the Western Wind Ensemble and the Bronx Arts Ensemble String Quartet to the Ethical Culture Society at 4450 Fieldston Road. The United States premiere of the String Quartet by the Bronx composer John Freeman and the Debussy G minor make up the instrumental segment, while Western Wind, one of the country's pre-eminent vocal groups, attends to unaccompanied works of Monteverdi and other early Italian baroque masters.

title: Future Events
description: Winter Parties

title: PROPOSAL FOR 5TH AVE. SPARKS DISPUTE
description: A proposal to raze two five-story buildings in the middle of midtown's Fifth Avenue shopping area has sparked a dispute between preservationists and the developers, who want to replace the buildings with a skyscraper.

title: SPOKESMEN WITHOUT INFLUENCE
description: THE GOVERNMENT/ PRESS CONNECTION

title: CANADA BY RAIL IN A NEW LIGHT
description: The mist is finally lifting for those who have traveled across Canada on the Candian and other trains operated by Via Rail and have been frustrated in trying to appreciate the remarkable variety of pastoral and urban scenes that pass ever so swiftly.

title: Miss Letts PlansWedding in April
description: Announcement has been made by Judge and Mrs. Gavin Graham Kenyon Letts of Palm Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Sophia McGavin Letts, to Courtlandt Bromwell Ault, a son of Bromwell Ault Jr. of New York and Edgartown, Mass., and Faith van Clief Meredith of Palm Beach and Edgartown. The wedding is to be April 20.

title: OUTDOOR WINTER FESTIVAL TO BE HELD
description: FOR cases of winter doldroms, postholiday blues and cabin fever, the county's Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation has an antidote. The Winter Fun Festival Jan. 27, from 1 to 4 P.M. at the Saxon Woods Golf Course on Mamaroneck Road in Scarsdale is designed ''to get families out of the house for fun activities that won't cost a fortune,'' according to Kathleen O'Connor, supervisor of the leisure, sports and fitness division of the Parks Department.

title: ARROYO RETAINS LIGHTWEIGHT CROWN
description: For a frozen moment, the hectic action stopped today in what was the first nominee for 1985's fight of the year. But when it resumed, Harry Arroyo landed a booming right hand to the chin of Terrence Alli and moments later registered an 11th-round knockout to defend his International Boxing Federation lightweight title at Bally's Park Place Casino Hotel.

title:
CAMERA;

PROPER FILTERS CAN SOLVE MANY PROBLEMS
description: Bob Nadler is a freelance writer and photographer. Filters are among the most widely misunderstood photographic accessories. Anything put between the lens and the subject stands as good a chance of degrading the image as it does of improving it. The secret is to use the right one at the right time.

title: PALISADES RENTALS
description: In eastern Bergen County, much of the new residential development these days is in the form of expensive single-family homes, town houses or high-rise condominiums.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

BARKING UP AND DOWN THE FAMILY TREE
description: GENEALOGY may sound like a rather bland pursuit relegated to the terminally dull, but don't believe it. It can easily become an addiction for which there is no known cure.

title: ALICE W. LEE TO MARRY J.M. GROTON 3D IN MAY
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John K. Lee of Princeton, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Alice Wetmore Lee, to John M. Groton 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Groton Jr. of Stonington, Conn. The wedding is to be in May.

title: CONNECTICUT SCHOOL-LAW CHANGE SOUGHT
description: The State Board of Education wants the General Assembly to mandate that public elementary schools include art, physical education and science as required subjects.

title: WADKINS WINNER ON 5TH EXTRA HOLE
description: Trailing by 4 shots with five holes to go, Lanny Wadkins charged back to tie Craig Stadler on the 90th and final regulation hole of the 26th annual Bob Hope Classic today, then birdied the fifth hole of a playoff with a 20-foot putt to win the $90,000 first prize.

title: SHARE OFFERED IN LOUISVILLE NEWSPAPER COMPANY
description: In a break with family tradition, a member of the Bingham family of Louisville, Ky., has said that she would consider offers from outsiders for her shares in family-owned holdings that include the Louisville Courier-Journal, one of the nation's best- known newspapers.

title: SIGNS OF ECONOMIC VIGOR
description: As recently as the middle of last month, credit market participants seemed convinced that the best of all possible worlds - slow economic growth accompanied by low inflation - was likely to persist well into 1985. They are not so sure anymore.

title: Formaldehyde Limits To Be Studied by U.S.
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration has rejected a request by the United Automobile Workers for an emergency standard to reduce the allowable limit of formaldehyde in the workplace.

title: FAST START FOR A STATE'S ATTORNEY GENERAL
description: When people in Rhode Island call their state's Attorney General simply ''the General,'' the term seems tailor made for Arlene Violet. A former nun who in November became the first woman to be elected Attorney General in the United States, she has taken on her new job with the zeal of a field marshal.

title: Korean Folk Epics Are Sung in 2 Shows
description: In the Korean folk epics known as Pansori songs, one performer - accompanied only by a drummer - sings, acts and narrates all the roles in a narrative that might last nine hours. New Yorkers had a rare opportunity to hear Pansori excerpts and other Korean folk music in a two-hour concert Friday at the Alternative Museum.

title: SHULA SON WORKS HIS OWN WAY
description: On the Dolphins' practice field under a hot sun, Don Shula dismisses the players and starts to do laps, sideline to sideline. Across the field, David Shula takes the long route, end to end.

title: ;   FOR MORE TOWERS OF GLASS ON FIFTH AVE.
description: To the Editor:

title: Mogul Master
description: The streets of New York have produced many extraordinary athletes, but few people are aware that a world champion skier hails from Manhattan. This top-ranked skier is a student of business at the University of Pennsylvania and works on Wall Street during summer breaks.

title: LAND OFFER UNSETTLES TRIBE IN MEXICO
description: In this small, gritty village 80 miles south of the border, where the loudest sound is the gurgling of a crystalline brook, the Texas band of Kickapoo Indians is keeping its secret winter traditions alive.

title: Texas Convict Linked To 5 Louisiana Killings
description: The police have announced, after questioning Henry Lee Lucas, a convicted mass murderer, that they have linked him to five killings in this area.

title: Gala for a Floor
description: More than 40 avant-garde performers will appear on Jan. 25 and Jan. 26 at 8 and 11 P.M. in ''Floor It!'' at Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue at Ninth Street.

title: VARIETY IS THE SPICE OF 49ERS' DEFENSE
description: They haven't given themselves any exotic nicknames, like the Monsters of the Midway II, or the Killer B's, probably because no one from the San Francisco 49ers' defense ever had the time to think of one. The players have enough to worry about, remembering who is supposed to be on the field at the right time.

title: MUSIC: 'HINDEMITH: THE VIOLA LEGACY'
description: Paul Hindemith's works for viola are, to date, the last large body of works by a composer/virtuoso (unless one counts the piano music of Bartok, who began earlier). Samuel Rhodes, the violist of the Juilliard Quartet, opened a three-program survey entitled ''Paul Hindemith: the Viola Legacy'' with an admirable concert Saturday at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Pittsburgh Militants Picket Catholic Church
description: Militant groups that have been disrupting services at Presbyterian and Lutheran churches since last spring to protest unemployment picketed a Roman Catholic church today.

title: 434 CASES IN STATE IN '84
description: The number of confirmed cases of Lyme disease - a tick-borne infection that can cause recurring arthritis - set a record last year in New York State, according to health officials.

title: REPUBLICAN WAS TAX LAW EXPERT
description: John W. Byrnes, who was once the ranking Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee, died Saturday night at St. Joseph's Hospital in Marshfield, Wis. Mr. Byrnes, who was 71 years old, suffered a stroke Tuesday.

title: Briton Ends Nicaragua Trip
description: Neil Kinnock, the leader of the opposition Labor Party, returned today from a visit to Nicaragua urging that Britain increase its aid to that country and calling on President Reagan to end United States support for right-wing rebels there.

title: Count Pennies Returns $37.80
description: Count Pennies, one of the outsiders in a field of 10, all 3-year-old fillies, led from the start to score by 4 1/2 lengths in the $72,300 Busanda Stakes yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: PROBLEMS OF SINGLE FATHERS
description: Coping on a daily basis is far from easy for the single father, according to a survey of the growing number of divorced men who are taking on the responsibilities of raising their children. There is usually no one around to lighten the load when the children are small or to bake cookies for the class picnic. And there may be no one to offer advice about the suitability of clothes or to be there when the children get sick.

title: Bad Smell Wakens Memphis
description: Some Memphis residents awoke today to the stench of rotten eggs when a leak developed in a tank trunk containing mercaptan, a malodorous agent that can be added to natural gas so leaks can be detected. The additive escaped from the tanker at the Delta Refining Company, said Fire Department Capt. Benny McDowell.

title: Saul Bellow to Read From His Works at Y
description: Saul Bellow, winner of the 1976 Nobel Prize for Literature, will make his first New York City public appearance in more than 20 years when he reads from his work at the West Side Y.M.C.A. Arts Center at 8 P.M. on Friday.

title: U.S. CUTS NEW DEAL IN A FOREST
description: Sixty-five- year-old Roberto Dalton still smiles as he recalls the day nearly two years ago when the Federal Government sent six strong men up into the remote hills of northern New Mexico to arrest him.

title: MARRIAGE: DOES DISTANCE MAKE THE HEART FONDER?
description: Predictability. Routine. Boredom. These qualities are the bane of marriage. But new research that looks into the lives of couples in long-distance relationships suggests that there are important positive benefits to the mundane in marriage.

title: HOSPITAL CARE OF THE DYING: EACH DAY, PAINFUL CHOICES
description: Two schoolteachers, four drug addicts, a retired opera singer, a college student, a butcher, a former police officer, three housekeepers, a homeless alcoholic, a wealthy executive, three dressmakers, a retired longshoreman, a convicted thief and 123 other patients died in one month at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

title: GIRARDELLI TAKES FIFTH SKI VICTORY
description: Marc Girardelli, overcoming a deficit of 1.28 seconds from the first heat, won a World Cup ski slalom today for his fifth victory of the season.

title: Shultz Denies U.S. Aid Goes to Managua Foes
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that American foreign aid money had not been diverted to support the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: PRISONER, 16, IS SLAIN ON RIKERS I.
description: A 16-year-old jail inmate on Rikers Island was slain in a crowded television room Saturday night, and yesterday two other inmates were charged with the murder.

title: Borg-Warner Filling Vice Chairman Vacancy
description: James J. Gavin Jr. has been named vice chairman of the Borg-Warner Corporation. But the 62-year-old executive, who has been senior vice president for finance since 1975, is not expected to succeed James F. Bere as chairman.

title: HEARST-DAVIES AFFAIR AND HOLOCAUST
description: Two fairly ambitious television movies being broadcast this evening, both at 9 o'clock, fall disappointingly flat. ''The Hearst and Davies Affair'' on ABC manages to make what it bills as ''the scandalous love affair between one of the richest and most powerful men in America and the obscure Ziegfeld girl he promoted to stardom'' seem like just another ordinary story about a man and his mistress. And ''The Execution'' on NBC tries to say something significant about the Holocaust but unfortunately comes too close to suggesting an old Myron Cohen joke, complete with Middle European accents, about Jewish housewives playing mah-jongg.

title: DEMOCRATS SAY THEY WILL LET REPUBLICANS TAKE BUDGET INITIATIVE
description: Democrats in the House and the Senate say they will let the Republicans take the lead in formulating the budget, a strategy they acknowledge could hurt their efforts to re-establish the party's leadership role.

title: TREASURY OFFERING SCHEDULE IS LIGHT
description: With no new issues of longer-term Government debt expected until early next month, the Treasury will hold two auctions of short-term bills this week.

title: SEAT-BELT SURVIVOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Problems Troubling Harlem
description: Harlem has some of the sickest people in New York but not enough health care to go around, its medical leaders say.

title: DR. NORTON DOWNS
description: Dr. Norton Downs of Trinity College, the author and editor of many works on medieval history, died Friday at Hartford Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Canton Center, Conn.

title: Texas Ranger Rescues Kidnapped Girl, 13
description: A Texas ranger ran through gunfire today to rescue a bank employee's 13- year-old daughter, who had been held for $100,000 ransom, the authorities said.

title: RESTORING A SYNAGOGUE AND A PAST
description: Forty years ago, a small girl named Kay Kaufman accompanied her mother to the Dohany Synagogue in the Budapest ghetto, bringing food to fellow Jews who were interned there by the Nazis.

title: Baker's International Powers
description: When he becomes Secretary of the Treasury, James C. Baker 3d will inherit substantial international economic policy-making authority.

title: MUSIC: PETER GORDON'S 'SECRET PASTURES'
description: Peter Gordon's abrasive, witty score for ''Secret Pastures,'' one of the dance highlights of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival last fall, struts, scrapes and squeals in a dozen different musical vocabularies. At the first of two weekend concert performances on Friday at La Mama, where the composer conducted his 15-member Love of Life Orchestra, the ''ballet suite'' of ''Secret Pastures'' seemed at once more intense and sprawling than at the Brooklyn Academy, where Bill T. Jones's and Arnie Zane's frisky choreography and Keith Haring's set evoked a never-never land of accelerated frolic.

title: States Trying To Lure Plant DETROIT, Jan. 13 - The
description: General Motors Corporation's

title: LAWYERS' PANEL WOULD LIMIT F.B.I.'S INQUIRIES INTO GROUPS
description: A committee of the American Bar Association recommends in a new study that the Justice Department amend its guidelines governing investigations of domestic groups that use violence for political or social ends.

title: A GREAT BALANCE OF OFFENSE AND DEFENSE
description: San Francisco 49ers

title: 871 Corporate Names Were Changed in 1984
description: Now for the bright side of the news: Of 871 corporate name changes in 1984, only 10 were the result of companies going into Chapter 11 reorganization.

title: FOLK: PHOEBE SNOW SINGS
description: Miss Snow, who arrived for two nights at the Lone Star Cafe with a five- man band on Wednesday, has toughened her singing style in recent years. At Wednesday's early show, her best performances were her excursions into soul and funk that emphasized her declamatory chest voice.

title: Workers Vote At Frontier Four of the unions at Frontier Airlines have agreed to let
description: their members vote on a tentative agreement to give the

title: LYNNE CARTER, IMPERSONATOR
description: Lynne Carter, a female impersonator, died of pneumonia in Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases Friday. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MANY SET TRADITION OF GIVING DONATIONS TO BENEFIT NEEDIEST
description: A second year of assisting The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund often establishes a personal tradition, enhancing the donor's pleasure in helping others.

title: French Restaurant With American Accent
description: There is nothing as American as a

title: MENTAL HEALTH IN THE MARKETPLACE
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 14, 1985 International

title: Staley Sells Soybean Arm
description: The A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company announced yesterday that it has sold its soybean processing operations to a newly formed Illinois partnership that will lease the operations to the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SLEEPING WITH SOLDIERS: In Search of the Macho Man. By Rosemary Daniell. 259 pages. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $14.95.

title: Joint Chiefs' Chairman Talks With Peking Military Leaders
description: Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, held two hours of talks today with Yang Dezhi, Chief of General Staff of the Chinese Army.

title: PROPP LEADS FLYERS' 7-1 ROUT
description: Brian Propp scored three goals, including two of Philadelphia's three short-handed goals, to lead the Flyers to a 7-1 victory over the Calgary Flames today.

title: MISSOURI GETTING 'A STRAIGHT ARROW' FOR GOVERNOR
description: John D. Ashcroft, the Republican who will become Governor of Missouri Monday, is described as ''a straight arrow'' by commentators and friends alike.

title: EVOLUTION OF THE PASS: LUCKMAN TO MARINO
description: Outside, it was raining hard. In the locker room, Don Shula glanced at Dan Marino, then a rookie, and pointed to a few plays listed on the Miami Dolphins' game plan that 1983 day in Baltimore.

title: HOUSE REPORT CLEARS AGENCIES OF AIDING KILLERS IN SALVADOR
description: A House Intelligence Committee report has concluded that the United States intelligence agencies operating in El Salvador ''have not conducted any of their activities in such a way as to directly encourage or support'' the activities of right-wing death squads.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: St. John's at Pittsburgh. The Redmen are 3-0 in the Big East, and Pittsburgh is 1-1. The teams split two meetings last season, with each school winning at home. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 8 P.M.): Monmouth at L.I.U., 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 7:30 P.M.); Columbia at Lehigh, 7:30 P.M.; City College at Hunter, 8 P.M.; Hofstra at Wagner, 8 P.M.; Mercy at New York Tech, 8 P.M.; St. Francis (Brooklyn) at Maine, 8 P.M.; Southampton at Mercyhurst, 8 P.M.; Old Dominion at DePaul (Television - ESPN, 10 P.M. one-hour tape delay). Hockey

title: The U.N. Today
description: Jan. 14, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Adam Walsh of Notre Dame,Led Four Horsemen Team
description: Adam Walsh, captain of the undefeated 1924 Notre Dame football team that featured the Four Horsemen and won the national title, died Saturday night while traveling by plane from Boston to Providence, R.I. He was 83 years old.

title: WHAT HONDURAS WANTS FROM US
description: Whatever President Reagan's objectives may be in Central America, they are a mystery to Honduras's Commander in Chief, Gen. Walter Lopez. Since the ouster at pistol point of his autocratic predecessor, Gen. Gustavo Alvarez, last year, Lopez is the man who has had to play a crucial role in carrying out those objectives.

title: The Long Foreleg Of the Law
description: Duke, it seemed, could not wait to

title: ARMS TALKS: 'STAR WARS' BECOMES THE KEY ISSUE
description: In linking the success of the new arms control negotiations to a willingness in Washington to curb the space weapons program, Moscow appears to be trying to persuade both the Administration and American public opinion. In a way, the airing of differences on Soviet and American television today by top officials on both sides represents public posturing that is to be expected in advance of actual negotiations. But the intensity of the argument over the long- range American plan for research into antimissile defenses suggests that this initial debate will persist well into the negotiations themselves, and into debates on Capitol Hill.

title: Japanese Leader Leaves On South Pacific Trip
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone left tonight for a weeklong trip to the South Pacific that is likely to underline that region's concerns about Japan's policies on trade and dumping of nuclear waste.

title: COLLEGE STUDENTS FLOCK TO COMPUTER SCIENCE
description: Computer science, a field in which there was no major at most colleges and universities before the 1970's, is fast becoming one of the most popular majors as enrollments grow so rapidly that some schools must limit admissions.

title: Holy Cross Player Ponders Transfer
description: Doug McCrory, who quit the Holy Cross basketball team last week in the wake of allegations of racial tension, says he may transfer to the University of Hartford.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 14, 1985

title: PLAN FOR PENNSYLVANIA TOXIC DUMP GAINS SUPPORT
description: Legislative leaders in Pennsylvania are leaning toward support of a strategy outlined by Gov. Dick Thornburgh this month as a way to dispose of the state's nuclear waste without having to accept large amounts of radioactive material from its neighbors.

title: Ehrlichman on Perquisites
description: Sometimes powerful Washington

title: OUR DEFICIT AND INTEREST RATES ARE SHAPING THE WORLD ECONOMY
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG BOARD IN MERGER DISCUSSION
description: The New York Stock Exchange confirmed reports yesterday that it had been holding discussions with the Pacific Stock Exchange about ''a possible joint venture that could include a merger of the two stock markets.''

title: No Headline
description: Turn Good to Better in Africa
