title: GETTING IT WRONG
description: BOSTON A lawyer who cares deeply about

title: A BUSINESS PAPER IN FRENCH
description: An attempt to give French-speaking European business executives high-quality business news in their own language starts Monday, when a new economic daily hits newsstands in France, Belgium, Switzerland and Luxembourg.

title: Advertising;   Lois Pitts Agrees to A Merger
description: THE word that the GGK Group, a

title: CHAMBER: LEONARD HINDELL
description: Leonard Hindell, a bassoonist with the New York Philharmonic, went to Goodman House on Wednesday night to present a program emphasizing the role of the bassoon in chamber music. As things turned out, however, the singing of John Cheek overshadowed everything else.

title: Washington Watch;   Officials Battle For Trade Turf
description: WASHINGTON

title: MUSIC: DRAMAS BY MANNES CAMERATA
description: The Fleury Playbook, a 12th- century collection from northern France, is one of our principal sources for medieval liturgical music dramas. Two such dramas from the playbook, ''Herod'' and ''The Slaughter of the Innocents,'' were combined by the late Noah Greenberg of the New York Pro Musica in 1963 as ''The Play of Herod.'' They have now been recombined, re-edited and restaged by the Mannes Camerata under their original titles, and were presented Friday and Saturday nights at Christ Church United Methodist.

title: Melanesia Leader's Body Given Second Autopsy
description: The authorities conducted a second autopsy on the body of a Melanesian militant today after his family charged that he was shot in the back by the police during rioting here.

title: SOWETO PROTEST BLOCKS KENNEDY SPEECH
description: Black demonstrators forced Senator Edward M. Kennedy to cancel plans for a major speech today that was to have been the climax of a one-week visit to South Africa.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   President Resigns At Burger King
description: Jerome B. Ruenheck, president and chief operating officer of the Burger King Corporation, is resigning, a spokesman for the Miami- based company confirmed yesterday.

title: START PAY EQUITY IN PUBLIC JOBS
description: To the Editor:

title: American Restaurant With Korean Accent
description: There may be nothing as American

title: Jobless Rate In Canada
description: The Canadian unemployment rate fell to a seasonally adjusted 10.8 percent in December, down from 11.3 percent in November, the Government said Friday. The rate is the lowest jobless figure since May 1982, when it was 10.4 percent.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Austin Co. , an engineering and construction concern based in Cleveland, has named Thomas J. Judge executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Doctors Change Blood For a Fetus in France
description: French doctors say they have successfully exchanged the blood of a fetus whose life was at risk because its blood was incompatible with the pregnant woman's.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 14, 1985: *2*MONDAY Gifford-Hill&Co Johnson &Johnson *2*TUESDAY Acme Elec Scott Paper Honeywell Inc Security Pacific Corp K Mart Corp Southern Ind G & E Lehman Corp Storage Equities *2*WEDNESDAY Burlington Indus Norstar Bancorp Dow Jones&Co PNB Mtge&Rlty Invs Dun&Bradstreet Tokheim Corp Hartmarx Corp Zero Corp *2*THURSDAY Niagara Share PPG Indus *2*FRIDAY Combined Intl Lomas & Nettleton

title: Woman Will Get Welfare Aid For Children Traded for Beer
description: A 60-year- old woman who has reared two children since their mother gave them away in exchange for two glasses of beer will be getting welfare aid now.

title: EXPERT ON MIRO'S STYLE DETECTS FAKE ARTWORKS
description: With appropriate care, a visitor last week laid a $50,000 Miro on the floor in front of Jacques Dupin. With a piercing gaze, Mr. Dupin scrutinized the painting's colors, its signature, its composition, its brushstrokes.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: S.M.U. HOLDS OFF N. CAROLINA, 84-82
description: The senior Buzz Peterson missed two free throws with 1 second left today and Southern Methodist escaped with an 84-82 victory over North Carolina.

title: TRANSIT POLICE TRY EJECTIONS FOR SOME SUBWAY OFFENSES
description: The transit police are experimenting with an unusual tactic against passengers who smoke, drink alcoholic beverages, carry blaring radios or commit other quality-of-life offenses on the subway: They are ejecting them.

title: DR. HARRY ALFRED FELDMAN, 70, RESEARCHER IN EPIDEMIOLOGY
description: Dr. Harry Alfred Feldman, the chairman of the preventive medicine department at the Upstate Medical Center in Syracuse and a nationally known epidemiologist, died of complications caused by diabetes at the New England Medical Center in Boston last Sunday. He was 70 years old and lived in Syracuse.

title: AUDIT CHARGES SCHOOL BOARD PAID EXCESSIVE FEES TO ITS CONSULTANTS
description: The Board of Education has been paying more than $1 million a year in excessive fees to consultants by routinely circumventing its own hiring policy, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charges in a new audit.

title: DAYTON COUNTING ON MILITARY
description: Many people here think of this as a General Motors town. The General Motors Corporation's 10 big manufacturing plants dominate the industrial landscape, and G.M.'s employment levels - now more than 20,000 workers, or one out of five manufacturing jobs - are closely monitored as a gauge of the local economy.

title: Navratilova Wins
description: Martina Navratilova routed Zina Garrison, 6-1, 6-2, tonight and joined Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria in the final of a $150,000 Virginia Slims tournament.

title: SCIENTISTS DEBATE A RAIN OF COMETS
description: In three days of often vehement debate, astronomers meeting here have challenged and defended the hypothesis that a dwarf star called Nemesis, in a distant orbit around the Sun, periodically plunges into the cloud of comets encircling the solar system, sending some of them crashing into the Earth with devastating effect.

title: CHICAGO UNION STUDY URGES PEER EVALUATION FOR TEACHERS
description: The president of the Chicago Teachers Union has proposed that teachers be evaluated by their peers and be given salary increases based on performance.

title: French Tourism Gain
description: With a weak franc drawing in bargain-hunting foreigners and exchange controls keeping French travelers at home, France rolled up a record tourism trade surplus in 1984 of about $2.7 billion, the Government said Friday. Michel Crepeau, Minister of Commerce and Tourism, said the 1984 surplus was up 20 percent from 1983, the previous record year. As a foreign-exchange earner, tourism now ranks second only to France's food export industry, which earned about $2.8 billion last year.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: 'EIGHTH DAY,' ABOUT NUCLEAR WINTER
description: ''On The Eighth Day'' is chilling, a result entirely consistent with its aim. The one-hour documentary explores the possible ecological and atmospheric consequences of nuclear war, particularly as they would be expressed in a ''nuclear winter.'' Darkness would shroud the Northern Hemisphere; temperatures would fall. The planet would survive, but not as a hospitable place. ''On the Eighth Day,'' originally produced for the BBC, will be seen tonight on the cable network TBS at 8:05.

title: Debt Issues
KAMPPURI CREDITS RESCH FOR TRIUMPH
description: Hannu Kamppuri has discovered that working with Glenn (Chico) Resch and listening to his observations afterward can do wonders for a 27-year-old rookie goaltender from Finland.

title: Statistician Retires
description: George Jaszi, who has devoted much of his professional career to keeping politicians from influencing Government statistics, has retired at the age of 79 as director of the Bureau of Economic Analysis of the Commerce Department.

title: G.M.'S INNOVATIONS AT SATURN
description: In a kiss-and- tell book about life in the executive suite at the General Motors Corporation, John DeLorean complained about the burden that paperwork imposed on top G.M. managers when he was a vice president there.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: IN FOCUS The photographs of Berenice Abbott, whose job sheet goes back to the 1920's, never scream at you and are always distinct and almost sedate. But even before a second look one realizes that they are different, composed with a regard for sensitive perception that makes art out of mechanics.

title: ISRAELIS PUT OFF DECISION ON LEBANON
description: The Israeli Cabinet today discussed a proposal by Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin for a phased withdrawal from Lebanon, but then delayed a final decision probably until Monday, a Cabinet source said.

title: YOUTH SAID TO SOLVE SEX CODE
description: A 15-year-old boy who once broke into a bank's computer has eased his conscience by helping the police to crack a computer code that led to evidence sought in a child sex abuse investigation, the authorities say.

title: Dept. of Lost and Found
description: One morning last week an 8 o'clock telephone call shattered the stillness of the office of Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the new chairman of the Finance Committee. It was the Capitol Police reporting that the District of Columbia Police had recovered the Senator's missing bag.

title: ISLANDERS WIN 4TH STRAIGHT, 6-5
description: First they were feisty. Then they were feeble.

title: GROMYKO ASSERTS TALKS MUST DEAL WITH SPACE ARMS
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, declared today that Soviet-American negotiations on nuclear missiles would be impossible if they were separated from talks on space weapons.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Footnote to a Subway Shooting
description: Fred Clarke's involvement with New York courts began in 1981, when he was 16, with a botched mugging in Manhattan. Because the property was recovered and the facts were confused (Clarke said the victim had provoked him), the incident was treated as minor. Both parties were issued summonses and released.

title: BRAZIL PICKS A LEADER TOMORROW, RETURNING PRESIDENCY TO CIVILIANS
description: Brazil will take an important step toward the return to full democracy Tuesday when the Electoral College chooses the country's first civilian President since the army seized power in 1964.

title: SECOND INAUGURAL ADDRESS
description: MIAMI What will be at the center of Ronald Reagan's concerns this week? What will he be spending his time on?

title: THE FINE ART OF MUSEUM FUND RAISING
description: TO Diana Vreeland and the

title: All: Whither Kirkpatrick?
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick is receiving far

title: MCENROE TAKES 3D MASTERS TITLE
description: He was about to claim the first set, but given the circumstances, it was clearly ''disadvantage McEnroe.'' John McEnroe had become impatient with photographers on his side of the net and was glaring at them, bouncing the ball on his racquet like a street-corner tough guy flipping a coin. One bounce was a little higher than he expected, and the ball struck him in the right eye.

title: Carnation's New Chief
description: When the Carnation Company announced last week that its president, Timm F. Crull, would become its chief executive officer on Feb. 1, succeeding H. Everett Olson, it chose a marketing-oriented executive to see the company through an important transition: its $3 billion sale to Nestle S.A., the Swiss food conglomerate.

title: Plan to Aid Meatpacker Aired
description: Workers at the employee-owned Rath Packing Company were asked today to give $4,500 each to reopen the plant, and backers of the plan got 535 of the 700 signatures they need.

title: MENTAL HEALTH IN THE MARKETPLACE
description: To the Editor:

title: 76ERS' WINNING STREAK AT 11
description: Andrew Toney scored 9 of 15 points in the final 6 minutes 30 seconds as the Philadelphia 76ers overcame a 16- point deficit in the final 13 minutes today and defeated the Washington Bullets, 115-104. The victory extended their National Basketball Association winning streak to 11 consecutive games.

title: RECITAL: SOEDERSTROEM PERFORMS AT TULLY HALL
description: Elisabeth Soederstroem is a great-heart, and her public loves her for it: That was clear right away from the warmth of the applause that greeted the Swedish soprano before she had sung a note yesterday afternoon at her Tully Hall recital. And that it was a public, not just a faction of brava-shouters amongst a normally receptive audience, could be gauged by the unanimity and even distribution of the tribute.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   A Small Victory In the War on Litter
description: Some litter that blankets the city

title: CASTRO TAKES OFF FROM NICARAGUA AFTER KEEPING HIS PLANS A SECRET
description: Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, left for home today after a three-day visit to Nicaragua.

title: CUT THE MILITARY BUDGET? OH, SURE
description: Representative William L. Dickinson, the top Republican on the House Armed Services Committee, had this to say about the military budget President Reagan is preparing to send Congress next month:

title: Khan Gains Final, Escaping Upset
description: An upset loomed in the Fleischmanns World Professional Squash Championships today when Jahangir Khan of Pakistan, the defending champion, trailed Mario Sanchez of Mexico by two games to one in the semifinals.

title: Demonstrators Protest Plans to Shoot Deer
description: About 50 animal rights activists demonstrated today against a plan to shoot 65 deer at a reservation. The reservation's trustees say the plan is necessary to save the rest of the herd from starving this winter.

title: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW BY GROMYKO ON ARMS TALKS
description: Following are excerpts from Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko's television interview about the arms talks today as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: WEST STOPS FLUTIE IN JAPAN BOWL VICTORY
description: Doug Flutie had trouble against the pass rush in his last collegiate game today, and his East team's hope of a last-minute victory over the West All- Stars was ended when Ron Pitts ran 99 yards with an intercepted pass for a touchdown.

title: FOLK: BEN VAUGHN COMBO ON A TRIPLE BILL AT FOLK CITY
description: Folk City has inaugurated another of its bargain-priced Wednesday night showcases - the Big Combo series of early-evening triple bills. It opened, appropriately, with the Ben Vaughn Combo, a wry four-piece band that mocks most current pretensions to hipness.

title: METHODS USED IN TAKING POLL
description: This New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 5 through 10 with 1,329 adults in all parts of New York City.

title: CONRAIL SELECTION SEEN NEAR
description: The Department of Transportation is expected to select the Norfolk Southern Corporation as its choice to purchase the Government's 85 percent interest in the Consolidated Rail Corporation, according to railroad industry, investment community and Government sources.

title: Futures/Options;   Stock Index Activity
description: ONE odd thing about the booming market in stock index futures is that the exchange that introduced them in February 1982, the Kansas City Board of Trade, has been less successful in attracting traders than all the other exchanges that followed its example. The Kansas City exchange trades the Value Line Index futures.

title: SETTLEMENT IS OFFERED IN LAKER SUIT
description: Lawyers representing the 12 defendants in the case brought on behalf of the creditors of Laker Airways have offered $40 million to $50 million to the various groups of creditors in an attempt to settle the suit.

title: No Headline
description: Even Out the Free Trade Pain Why should sweater makers in Hong Kong be permitted to drive New York City garment workers to the unemployment lines? Why should Chile's nationally owned copper company be allowed to force mines in Arizona out of business? Why must steelworkers in Gary have to compete with those in South Korea who make $2 an hour?

title: POLL INDICATES HALF OF NEW YORKERS SEE CRIME AS CITY'S CHIEF PROBLEM
description: Half of New York City's residents believe that crime is the worst thing about living in the city, and almost as many think it justifies taking matters into their own hands, according to a New York Times Poll.

title: Gminski Meets The Future
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: JEROME HOLLAND, FORMER U.S. ENVOY
description: Dr. Jerome H. Holland, an educator, civil-rights advocate and former United States Ambassador to Sweden, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The talks were not easy and sometimes very complicated if not tense in the political sense.

title: Recycled Development Aid
description: Nearly $200 billion is to be pumped into developing countries over the next five years by multilateral lending institutions such as the World Bank, but much of the money will come back to the rich countries in contracts for equipment and know- how.

title: Close as Can Be
description: The Hall of Fame is for hitters and pitchers, but it may take linguists and mathematicians to settle the dispute that arose last week when Nellie Fox fell two votes short of gaining entry into the Hall.

title: VIETNAMESE FACES COAST TRIAL IN KILLING OF COLLEGE TEACHER
description: A 20-year- old Vietnamese immigrant is to go on trial Monday in the death by shooting of a California State University professor who had close professional and political ties with Vietnam.

title: Alfredo Kraus Sings 'Tales of Hoffmann'
description: The disappointed poet in Offenbach's ''Tales of Hoffmann'' has long been one of Alfredo Kraus's specialty roles on the international opera circuit, but Friday's performance at the Metropolitan marked the 58-year-old tenor's first New York appearance in the part.

title: No Headline
description: Looking Down the Reagan Road

title: Koch Chooses Duck Over Turnip
description: And on the subject of mayoral

title: Market Place;   Stock Advisers Stress Caution
description: BROKERAGE houses often suggest stock portfolios for clients seeking growth, safety or something in between. Standard & Poor's Outlook has assembled a ''master portfolio for 1985'' that is described as ''balanced in terms of income and capital gains potential.''

title: E. German Wins European Skating
description: Andrea Schoene of East Germany won the women's European speed-skating championships today, with Yvonne van Gennip of the Netherlands second and Sabine Brehm of East Germany third.

title: ANGOLAN COFFEE TRADE IN SHAMBLES
description: In 1961, at the height of Angola's coffee boom, African workers sharpened their machetes, rose up from the coffee fields around here and massacred about 1,800 Europeans.

title: REVAMPING OF SCHOOL BOARD IS RAISING QUESTIONS
description: Mayor Koch and Albert Shanker, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, have had their share of differences, but in separate pronouncements in recent weeks they have found ground for agreement: They see a need to reorganize the city's paid Board of Education, which essentially works on a full-time basis.

title: BELLAMY TO GIVE STAFF A DAY OFF TO HONOR KING
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy said yesterday that her office would be closed next Monday to honor the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., even though it is not an official city holiday.

title: HARD WORDS BUT NO TABLE-BANGING IN GENEVA, GROMYKO SAYS
description: ''Of course,'' Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said today, ''we did not bang our fists on the table and did not even fling eyeglasses on the table.''

title: WORST STORM IN A CENTURY PARALYZES PARTS OF TEXAS
description: A winter storm described as the worst in southern Texas in a century left San Antonio staggering under more than a foot of snow today, virtually paralyzing a city more accustomed to sun.

title: MANY POLICY JOBS IN CAPITAL VACANT ON EVE OF 2D TERM
description: On the eve of his inauguration for a second term, President Reagan is presiding over an Administration with numerous high- level vacancies in several departments.

title: JAZZ: JAY MCSHANN LEADS A QUARTET AT FAT TUESDAY's
description: Jay McShann, the pianist whose big band succeeded Count Basie's as the epitome of Kansas City jazz when the Basie band moved out onto the national scene in the 1930's, celebrated his 76th birthday Saturday, leading a quartet at Fat Tuesday's that is a marvelous summation of the joys of Kansas City jazz.

title: RetailerTo Retire At Age 58
description: William A. Andres, chairman of the Dayton-Hudson Corporation's executive committee, said Friday that he would retire next August. He also will leave the board of directors. Dayton- Hudson, with more than 1,100 department stores and annual sales exceeding $7 billion, is the nation's fifth-largest retailer.

title: G.O.P. IS WINNING OVER 'SHOW ME STATE' VOTERS
description: When John D. Ashcroft takes the oath of office at noon Monday, becoming Missouri's 49th Governor, it will be the first time since 1928 that a Republican has succeeded a Republican in that post.

title: GUNMEN KILL LIBYAN DIPLOMAT ON A ROME STREET
description: A Libyan diplomat was shot dead near his home today but managed to fire on his assailants before collapsing on an icy street, the police said. He died clutching a gun in his hand.

title: A DIFFERENT REPUBLIC FOR CYPRIOT TURKS
description: To the Editor:

title: Coach Has Heart Surgery
description: Jack Hartman, the 59-year-old Kansas State basketball coach, underwent heart surgery early today after experiencing severe chest pains Saturday night at his home in Manhattan, Kan., university officials said.

title: AN EXPLOSIVE OFFENSE THAT SCORES EVERY 16 PLAYS
description: Don't get into a shootout with the Dolphins. They're never out of a game, and they play on the shortest field in football.

title: IN CITIES, WHO IS THE REAL MUGGER?
description: Bernhard Hugo Goetz has become a folk hero. Respectable citizens have identified with his shooting of four teenagers who ''harassed'' him on the subway and asked him for $5. In so dealing with these potential ''muggers,'' Mr. Goetz personified and aroused the general and pervasive fears, anger and sense of personal powerlessness of a large segment of the public faced with rising urban crime. The outrage over lawlessness in our cities has masked the lawless act of an individual. But this incident cannot be understood in isolation.

title: N.C.A.A. Rejects Florida's Appeal
description: Florida lost its appeal to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Council today and was placed on three years' probation for football program abuses.

title: Bridge:QAgain in Regional Play
description: A group that has been highly successful in recent months had another victory at the Tri-State Regional Championship in Port Chester, N.Y., Saturday.

title: LAST-SECOND BASKET BRINGS NETS VICTORY
description: One second. It usually takes about as long to say as it does for the time to expire. But after Otis Birdsong sank a fadeaway 20-footer from the left corner to give the Nets a 100- 99 lead over the Houston Rockets with just one second remaining, the Nets had to wait more than five minutes before they could celebrate.

title: A U.N. Mission's Chauffeur Is Held in Westchester Rape
description: A chauffeur with the Ivory Coast mission to the United Nations was arrested yesterday in the rape of a woman at the Mount Vernon residence of the Representative to United Nations from Sierra Leone on Saturday, the police said.

title: DATAPOINT RESPONDS TO BIDDER
description: The Datapoint Corporation, a computer company based in San Antonio, has told a New York investor that his interest in acquiring the company is welcome, but the substance of his proposal is not.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Has a World Series ever ended with a batter in the ninth inning of the seventh game striking out with a chance to change the outcome of the game? How many times has a home run by the final batter won the seventh game?

title: DUCKS ELUSIVE IN TRIP TO SOUND
description: BRANFORD, Conn.

title: JAZZ: LARRY WILLIS QUINTET
description: The pianist Larry Willis made his quintet work hard Thursday as he opened a three- night stand at Seventh Avenue South. He chose an opening set of complex tunes recalling many Blue Note Records sessions of the late 1960's - tunes that took hairpin harmonic turns at daring tempos.

title: 1984 WAS ALSO THE YEAR OF THE PEACE INSTITUTE
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMES BALDWIN'S 'GO TELL IT ON THE MOUNTAIN'
description: The idea for a television adaptation of ''Go Tell It on the Mountain,'' James Baldwin's first novel, began as a possible mini-series. That was around 1977. But Robert Geller, the producer dedicated to the project, soon ran into fund-raising problems and the scale of the project was cut back to a two- hour movie with the National Endowment for the Humanities supplying the greater part of the $1.3 million cost. The film, now being presented in association with public television's American Playhouse, can be seen on WNET/13 tonight at 9.

title: And on the 7th Day. . .
description: Out of the mouths of lobbyists, it seems, come the most compelling descriptions of their work. Following are excerpts from a letter soliciting clients for a Washington lobbying concern and describing its ''accomplishments'' in Congress in the 1981-82 and 1983-84 sessions:

title: HUNGARY'S NEW BONDS TAP FUNDS
description: Hungary's Communist leaders, evidently regarding stocks and bonds as so much capitalist tinsel, in the 1960's turned the once- thriving stock exchange here - an immense Art Nouveau granite heap opposite the United States Embassy - into television studios.

title: Fire Said to Kill 27 On Bangladesh Train
description: The Government said 27 people were killed today when three cars of a passenger train caught fire.

title: New U.S.-Soviet Talks On Mideast Expected
description: The United States informed Israel and Egypt last week that Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, agreed to hold Soviet-American discussions on the Middle East, diplomatic sources said today.

title: FOR NANCY REAGAN, 3 INAUGURAL DESIGNS
description: The White House has announced three of the designs Nancy Reagan will wear at inauguration festivities.

title: Rabbi Jeffrey SalkinWeds Nina J. Rubin
description: Nina Joan Rubin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mel Rubin of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Rabbi Jeffrey K. Salkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Salkin of Old Bethpage, L.I. Rabbis Haskell M. Bernat, Daniel H. Freelander, Simeon J. Maslin and Robert A. Raab and Cantor Jeffrey A. Klepper officiated at the Central Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: DANCE: HORST TRIBUTE AT RIVERSIDE FESTIVAL
description: The Riverside Dance Festival celebrated its 10th anniversary and honored a modern- dance pioneer with its sampler program on Saturday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: MusicNoted in Brief;   'Robin Hood' PresentedAs a Ballad Opera
description: Gilbert and Sullivan found much of their inspiration in the 18th-century ''ballad opera.'' So did the Monty Python troupe. But these hybrid operas - actually spoken plays peppered with songs based on traditional and popular melodies - have all but vanished from the repertory. Therefore, we owe an automatic debt of gratitude to Boston's Friends of Dr. Burney, an enterprising early-music group, which presented an anonymous ballad opera setting of the Robin Hood legend at the Museum of Fine Arts here Thursday night.

title: Wilson Still a Leader
description: When Ben Wilson, the star of the Simeon Vocational High School basketball team in Chicago, was murdered shortly before Thanksgiving, it appeared that the team, which had been rated one of the best in the United States, would have a difficult time just getting through the season.

title: People
5 in Sacramento Area Accused of Molestation
description: Five men have been arrested and charged with 169 counts of sexual molestation and abuse of nine children.

title: No Super Balls
description: A certain compelling logic suggests that there can't be a Super Bowl without a Super Ball, so the folks at the Wilson Sporting Goods Company can hardly be faulted for trying to cash in on the Super Bowl hoopla by producing one.

title: King Out 3 More Games Bernard King, the Knick captain and the league's leading scorer,
description: will be sidelined for at least the next three games because of his

title: Seeing Orange
description: Bernard Kalb, who spent the last eight years covering the State Department for NBC News, performed for the first time yesterday in his new job as spokesman for the State Department.

title: Clashes in Western Sahara
description: Three Moroccan warplanes were shot down and their pilots were killed in renewed fighting in Western Sahara over the weekend, according to the Polisario Front guerrillas fighting for the territory's independence. Morocco confirmed there were clashes Saturday between the guerrillas and Moroccan troops building a defensive wall through the territory, but it said nothing about aircraft losses or casualties.

title: COLONIAL BANCORP (WATERBURY, CONN)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HEALTH CARE REGULATION: BANE? BALM? ACCIDENT?
description: President Reagan has consistently argued that the size and role of the Federal Government must be reduced. But in one area, the effort to control health costs, his Administration appears to have accepted a bigger role for Government.

title: PETER BOWMAN, AUTHOR
description: Peter Bowman, author of the 1945 war novel ''Beach Red,'' died on Saturday of a heart ailment at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 67 years old.

title: U.S. Continues to Study Missile Blast in Germany
description: United States missile experts continued their investigation today of a Pershing 2 rocket accident that killed three American soldiers and spurred debate in West Germany over the missile's safety.

title: PRESSURE MOUNTS FOR ANALYSTS TO PROVE THEORY IS SCIENTIFIC
description: THE scientific credentials of psychoanalysis are being weighed anew in what some see as an effort to demolish its intellectual status, and what others see as a defense of its viability.

title: ELECTRO SCIENTIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share results for 1983 have been restated to reflect the 2-for-1 split of the corporation's stock during the second quarter of 1984.

title: $100 Million Issue By Texas agency
description: The Brazos River Authority in Texas is offering $100 million of adjustable-rate bonds to finance pollution control facilities for the Houston Light and Power Company.

title: ONLY WORDS? NOT TO THESE TEACHERS
description: POLLUTION threatens the language as much as it threatens air and water, and an aroused band of English teachers is fighting a determined battle against the polluters.

title: K MART IN BID FOR PAY LESS
description: The K Mart Corporation, rounding out a $1 billion diversification drive in the last four years, reached an agreement yesterday to buy Pay Less Drug Stores Northwest Inc., a leading West Coast chain, for $27 a share, or some $500 million in cash.

title: STANDARD SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Court to Rule on Private RICO Suits
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve a growing legal controversy over the use of the powerful Federal anti-racketeering law in civil lawsuits that allege ordinary business fraud.

title: 21 JEWISH GROUPS DEPLORE ISRAELI BILL
description: A coalition of 21 major American Jewish groups said yesterday that a proposal before the Israeli Parliament that would alter the definition of who is a Jew was ''morally and religiously offensive to us.''

title: Smith Hopes to Avoid a Ban
description: Tomas Jonsson left the Islanders this morning with his left arm in a sling. And Billy Smith went to Vancouver with the rest of his teammates, hoping the league would not put his career in a sling.

title: STAGE: CAST OF 2 in 'PRIVATE SCENES'
description: NUDITY has long been a commonplace on New York stages, but usually there's been a catch: The actors most likely to appear nude in the theater are often the people one might least like to see nude, whether in the theater or elsewhere. Donna Snow and Michael French, the cast of Joel Homer's ''Private Scenes,'' are rare exceptions to this rule. When this actress and actor appear naked - as they do for most of the play's 80 minutes - no one need feel embarrassed.

title: David J. Waller Dies; Senior Mobil Executive
description: David Jewett Waller, a senior executive of the Mobil Corporation, died yesterday at Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital after a short illness. He was 61 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.

title: WAS GOVERNOR IN THE 1950'S
description: Allan Shivers, who was Governor of Texas from 1949 to 1957, longer than any other chief executive of the state, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 77 years old and lived in Austin.

title: New Cadillac Is Allante
description: The General Motors Corporation announced today that its 1987 luxury two-seat convertible from Cadillac would be named the Allante. The car will be assembled in Detroit, using bodies designed and manufactured in Turin, Italy, by the Pininfarina.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Friendly Rivals
description: Dave DeBusschere and Earl Monroe, once Knick teammates, were rivals in another sport last week, when DeBusschere teamed with Ilie Nastase to defeat Monroe and Stan Smith in a tennis match before the start of the Volvo Masters at Madison Square Garden. They will be basketball teammates again on Feb. 9, as part of the N.B.A.'s All-Star weekend in Indianapolis.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Boston Red Sox made official what the entire baseball world had known for a week:

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON MORTAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KENNEDY'S TRIP: 'STIRRING THINGS UP' IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: In South Africa, so the wisdom runs, the problems are easy to identify. The solutions are more elusive.

title: A.C.C. Makes TV Deal
description: The eight-team Atlantic Coast Conference broke away from the College Football Association's television

title: Whither Stone?
description: Marvin L. Stone said yesterday that he was resigning as editor of U.S. News & World Report. Mr. Stone told the staff of the magazine that he was leaving but did not disclose his plans.

title: RANGERS HONOR MAN CALLED 'HEX'
description: With each passing year, the frustration of their fans increases, like rust on a time capsule. Not since 1940 have the Rangers won the Stanley Cup, and they won't win it this year. The team is skating uphill, on a treadmill to oblivion. Coach Herb Brooks and Barry Beck are glowering after controversy over the word ''coward.'' And the other players, as well as all the Ranger followers, are wondering how soon the franchise will return to square one.

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $8,400,000 from the sale of securities. Share earnings have been restated to reflect a 4-for-1 stock split effective April 18, 1984.

title: TIMEPLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring tax benefit of $1,135,000, or 13 cents a share, relating to the previously undistributed earnings of the company's domestic international sales corporations.

title: LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Navratilova Wins No. 100
description: Martina Navratilova captured her 100th career singles title, defeating Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, 6-3, 6-2, tonight in the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Washington tennis tournament.

title: Nortek Bid Vetoed
description: The Unidynamics Corporation said that its board had unanimously rejected a $20-a-share tender offer from Nortek Inc., saying that the bid was inadequate. The board recommended that stockholders reject it. The board added, however, that it had retained Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company and Goldman, Sachs & Company to explore alternatives that would give greater value for Unidynamics shareholders.

title: A DU PONT FORMULA
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE REPUBLICANS PROPOSE WIDE RANGE OF POLICY GOALS
description: House Republican leaders today announced a policy agenda reflecting many of President Reagan's goals, including tax simplification, broad spending cutbacks, continued research into space- based weapons, production of the MX missile and aid to the rebels in Nicaragua.

title: HUGE SOVIET SATELLITE'S MANEUVERING ELICITED SPECIAL U.S. TRACKING EFFORT
description: The Soviet Union recently launched one of the largest satellites in the history of its space program, a device that required special tracking efforts by the Air Force, according to a spokesman for the North American Aerospace Defense Command.

title: NEW THEATER IN HOTEL ASSAILED AND DEFENDED
description: Broadway's first new theater in a decade has become the subject of a debate among theater operators and designers about whether it is the top- flight facility promised by its builders or a deeply flawed design.

title: DETOUR TO ASTEROID FOR JUPITER MISSION
description: THE unmanned Galileo spacecraft, scheduled for launching from a space shuttle in May 1986, will probably make a detour in its course to Jupiter in order to make the first close encounter with an asteroid. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced the revised plans for the Galileo mission after weighing the recommendations of planetary scientists, who wanted the fly-by, against the added risks that the spacecraft might not accomplish its primary objective of orbiting Jupiter and exploring its four major satellites.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: When famous nonfashion names get involved in designing a collection of clothes for the mass market, the results are often not worth looking at. The good ideas are usually deemed too advanced and dropped, as if the benighted members of that market have bad, or nonexistent, taste. Murjani's licensing agreement with Coca- Cola to produce Coca-Cola Clothes, as they are being called, may be an exception. The clothes are surprisingly good, which is why Tommy Hilfiger, who is 33 years old and who designed the collection, has such a big smile these days.

title: Vanderbilt Crackdown
description: Roy Kramer , the Vanderbilt athletic director, said that all of the school's athletes will be subject to random tests to determine the use of anabolic streroids and could lose both athletic eligibility and financial aid if the tests are positive. ''Each athlete will be asked to sign an agreement acknowleding the athlete's willingness to undergo periodic testing to verify the non-use of steroids,'' Kramer said.

title: ;   DON'T LEAVE IT TO THE PROFESSIONAL SOLDIER
description: To the Editor:

title: WEICKER IS ARREST NO. 190 IN PROTESTS AT EMBASSY
description: This was the 55th day of demonstrations against South Africa's racial policies in front of its embassy on Massachusetts Avenue in Washington's northwest sector. Once again, there were arrests.

title: ISRAEL ANNOUNCES THREE-STAGE PLAN TO LEAVE LEBANON
description: The Israeli Cabinet approved a plan today to withdraw the Israeli Army from Lebanon in three stages, beginning within five weeks.

title: Kosar's Option Play
description: Bernie Kosar , the star quarterback for the University of Miami, denies a Florida television report that he has decided to abandon his collegiate career, in which he has two years of eligibility remaining, and declare for the National Football League's draft on April 30.

title: Christine Craft Appeal Heard by Federal Court
description: A lawyer for Christine Craft argued before a Federal Appeals Court today that evidence his client was the victim of sex discrimination was ''brushed asunder'' by the trial judge who found in favor of Metromedia.

title: Advertising;   T.W.A. Ads Stress Leadership
description: STEWART G. LONG, senior vice president, marketing and sales, arrived in his newly created post at Trans World Airlines in mid-August, and by September had asked his agency, Ogilvy & Mather, for a new campaign to replace the five-year-old ''You're Going to Like Us.''

title: SYKES DATATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said results for the latest quarter included charges of approximately $3,400,000 primarily to recognize excess and obsolete inventory and to write down fixed assets. Results for the year-ago quarter include unusual charges of $1,200,000.

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: HOME HEALTH CARE OF AMERCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: THE PAINTING OF MODERN LIFE.

title: SYSTEM OF FIXED SENTENCES PROPOSED
description: Convicted felons in New York State would be required to serve fixed sentences without parole under a set of sweeping proposals issued yesterday to restructure the state's sentencing laws.

description: This is the season to be transported by Super

title: Hotline Talks Set for Today
description: United States and Soviet officials will meet here on Tuesday for technical talks on upgrading the hotline between Washington and Moscow, the State Department said today.

title: OCILLA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for 13wks to Dec 1
DOW JUMPS BY 16.45, TO 1,234.54
description: Stock prices surged yesterday in a rally reinforced in the final hour of trading by news that a major bank had cut its prime rate a quarter point.

title: INAUGURATIONS PAST AND PRESENT
description: When Ronald Wilson Reagan, the 40th President, raises his right hand to take the oath of office at a public ceremony on Monday, it will be the 50th inauguration, the 47th in Washington, D.C., the sixth postponed a day to avoid a Sunday ceremony and the second at the west front of the Capitol.

title: ACCOMPLISHED JUDGE IN SHARON CASE
description: Judge Abraham D. Sofaer, who has presided at the trial of Ariel Sharon's libel suit against Time magazine, seems especially qualified to separate the intricacies of Middle Eastern politics from the subtleties of American press law. A Sephardic Jew of Arab origin, Judge Sofaer speaks some Hebrew and some Arabic and takes vacations in Jerusalem each summer. But his academic interest has always been American history, and as a professor of law, he has served on committees working to enhance press freedom.

title: ADVANCING THE CAUSE OF DISARMAMENT ON THE SOVIET JEWISH FRONT
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A map published yesterday with a dispatch about a rare snowstorm in south Texas transposed the cities of San Antonio and Austin. San Antonio is southwest of Austin.

title: SUPER BOWL XIX;PLAYERS;   CAVANAUGH PASSES ONLY THE SIGNALS
description: Matt Cavanaugh is perhaps the most visible part of the 49ers' brain trust. He had better be, because if Joe Montana does not see him before every play, then Montana has no play.

title: New Center to Spread Public Service Ideas
description: Representatives of every important advertising and media organization will be serving on the board of the American Values Center, which will seek out and disseminate ''ideas that are working to solve social problems that are plaguing people every day.''

title: GEOGRAPHY, A LOST ART
description: NAME the country drained by the Amazon River, American college students were asked in a 1950 survey, and 77.5 percent of them correctly said Brazil. The same question was posed last fall in a statewide college exam in North Carolina, and this time only 27 percent of the students got it right.

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in December.

title: GEORGE ZEE, RESTAURATEUR
description: WHEN George Zee first came to this country, he was an illegal Chinese alien. He had the suit of clothes he wore and $70 in his pocket. What he needed was a place to live and that most precious of all possessions: a Social Security card.

title: NATIONAL WESTMINSTER BANK USA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: This bank is a wholly owned subsidiary of the London-based National Westminster Bank PLC.

title: AN ADMINISTRATION DISMANTLING A GOVERNMENT

title: ROONEY, PACE INC. FILLS PRESIDENCY, A NEW POST
description: Rooney, Pace Inc., the brokerage and investment arm of the Rooney, Pace Group, announced yesterday that it had named Donald Erenberg to the new position of president.

title: CALFED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $9 million, a gain of $4 million attributable to Beneficial Standard Life Insurance Co. and a gain of $4 million representing a nonreurring dividend of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. participating preferred stock. c-Including a gain of $20 million from the sale of loans and investments.

title: Final to Khan
description: Jahangir Khan of Pakistan won the World Professional Squash Championship for the second straight year, beating top-seeded Mark Talbott of Boston tonight, 15-12, 11-15, 15-5, 15-5. Boston tonight, 15-12, 11-15, 15-5, 15-5.

title: FIRST CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The per share net figures were adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split paid in December 1984.

title: EX- C.I.A. ANALYST SAYS WESTMORELAND'S ACITONS COST THOUSANDS OF LIVES
description: Samuel A. Adams yesterday accused Gen. William C. Westmoreland of taking actions that, in effect, cost the lives of thousands of American soldiers.

title: SIMMONS QUITS U.S.F.L. POST
description: Chet Simmons, the first commissioner of the United States Football League, ended months of speculation when he resigned yesterday, and the league said that a search was under way for a successor.

title: ADVANTAGES BLACKS HAVE IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: Edwin Moses Arrested
description: Edwin Moses , the two-time Olympic gold medalist and one of track and field's biggest stars, was arrested in Los Angeles early Sunday on charges of soliciting a female police officer for prostitution and was later released on his own recognizance. The 29-year-old Moses was one of 82 men arrested in a Hollywood prostitution sweep by the police, who said that he had also had a small amount of marijuana in his possession.

title: IN PERU, A LOSS OF HUMAN RIGHTS
description: ONE OF THE casualties of the increasingly charged political atmosphere in Peru is the debate about human rights. In a country threatened by a growing Maoist guerrilla movement, Sendero Luminoso, the Government is dismissing arguments about human rights as left-wing conspiracy, while many in the democratic opposition are using such arguments sensationally as a way to discredit the authorities. Meanwhile, justice has been lost in the shuffle.

title: CITY SUES EXTORTER FOR $4 MILLION
description: New York City filed a civil suit yesterday against a former employee convicted of extorting $1.5 million in a rental racketeering scheme and against a group of landlords accused of paying the bribes, city officials announced.

title: ELIGIBILITY WAIVER IS OPPOSED
description: Delegates to the N.C.A.A. convention, which opened here today, are getting ready to vote on a rule that would have made dozens of members of Brigham Young's No. 1 football team ineligible.

title: Iran Asserts Its Jets Downed Iraqi in Dogfight
description: Iran said its warplanes shot down an Iraqi jet in a dogfight over the Persian Gulf today, and Iraq said its jets hit another ''large naval target'' near the Kharg Island oil terminal in Iran.

title: MAY TESTIFY TO GRAND JURY
description: MARCIA CHAMBERS

title: Indiana Standard To Spin Off Unit
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced today that it planned to spin off its minerals subsidiary to shareholders by midyear in a tax-free distribution.

title: Magoni Achieves First Ski Victory
description: Paoletta Magoni of Italy, a 1984 Olympic slalom gold medalist, scored her first World Cup victory today.

title: COAST CHRISTIAN AID GROUP DENIES MISHANDLING EHTIOPIA RELIEF FUND
description: L. Joe Bass, founder of the International Christian Aid organization, denied today that his group had mishandled millions of dollars in donations meant for victims of famine in Ethiopia. He said his organization had become the target of a ''witch hunt.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''These products do not prevent hair loss or grow hair. How you lose or keep your hair depends on how wisely you choose your parents.''

title: PEACE CORPS GETS 5,000 CALLS IN DRIVE FOR AFRICA VOLUNTEERS
description: The Peace Corps has issued a nationwide appeal for volunteers to begin famine relief and agricultural work in Africa, and officials say it has produced the largest number of inquiries since the heyday of the agency in the early 1960's.

title: DOCTORS' INSURERS WIN 52% RATE RISE
description: A 52 percent increase in medical malpractice insurance rates was approved yesterday for an insurer serving some of New York State's 45,000 doctors.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $856,000. c-After an extraordinary credit of $3,050,000. The company noted that it had gains of $2.3 million in 1984 and $10.5 million in 1983 from the sale-leaseback of banking facilities.

description: THE investment counseling firm of Carret &

title: Italy Has Trade Deficit
description: Italy's current account swung to a deficit of 4.28 trillion lire, or the equivalent of $2.2 billion at current exchange rates, in the first nine months of 1984, from a surplus of 843 billion lire a year earlier, the Bank of Italy said today. The central bank said Italy's merchandise trade deficit widened in the period to 13.1 trillion lire, or $6.73 billiion, from 7.2 trillion lire in the first nine months of 1983. The current account measures trade in merchandise and also in services such as banking, insurance and tourism.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE BANK OF ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures reflect 10 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 5 to shareholders of record Dec. 5, 1984.

title: INNOVATVE JEWELRY: 1940-60
description: If 1950's prom dresses and boomerang-shaped coffee tables are back in favor, it must be time to take another look at the jewelry of the 40's and 50's. That is what the Fifty-50 Gallery is doing now in an exhibition called ''Structure and Ornament: American Modernist Jewelry 1940-1960.''

title: Dexter Acquisition
description: The Dexter Corporation, a specialty chemicals concern, said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Permag Corporation for about 1.2 million common shares. Dexter stock closed at $20 today, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Permag fabricates and distributes magnetic materials and had 1984 sales of about $30 million.

title: NATIONWIDE POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Cosmos Beaten By Comets, 3-2
description: Greg Makowski scored on a power play with 4 minutes 45 seca power play with 4 minutes 45 seconds left tonight to lift the Kansas City Comets to a 3-2 victory over the Cosmos in the Major Indoor Soccer League.

title: Honoring Dr. King
description: ''There is only but so much lawyers can do. After we get the law clear, the hard job begins.'' So said Thurgood Marshall, looking back on his days as a civil rights lawyer. That idea is worth pondering today, the birthday of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who led the huge marches and demonstrations that defined and enlarged the legal boundaries of civil rights. For today American society is faced with the ''hard job'' that Justice Marshall foresaw: conquering social problems that continue to fall disproportionately on minority groups.

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1.3 million and an extraordinary gain of $8.1 million. c-Including a tax credit of $9,470,000.

title: LEBANESE PEACE IN SYRIA'S HANDS
description: The Israeli cabinet voted yesterday to proceed with a unilateral redeployment of Israeli troops in southern Lebanon. We hope that this will ultimately restore Lebanese sovereignty over all Lebanon, revive the country's economy and promote coexistence between its many varied religious communities. Our redeployment will an important step toward this goal, but it will be extremely difficult to achieve without the cooperation of both Lebanon and Syria. Will they participate? We shall soon know.

title: 'NOT MY KID' EXPLORES PERMISSIVENESS ISSUES
description: PERMISSIVE parents are out. That's the message delivered with unmistakable righteousness in ''Not My Kid,'' the television movie on CBS at 9 o'clock this evening. It is not a very good movie in many respects. The script by Christopher Knopf is more of a clinical case history than a fleshed-out drama. But given the air of permissiveness that pervades television in general, the underlying message is startling enough to command more than ordinary attention.

title: NEW TOOL CAPTURES CELLS ALIVE
description: -rays lasting only billionths of a second are giving scientists their first highly detailed looks at individual living human cells. The images, obtained with a new technique called contact X-ray microscopy, can show internal structures as well as surface characteristics. The details are far finer in resolving power than can be obtained with the best of light microscopes.

description: General-merchandise sales are in for ''an unexciting period of growth'' in the rest of the 1980's, a research panel yesterday told retailers at the convention of the National Retail Merchants Association.

description: Lawyers for Jeffrey MacDonald argued in Federal District Court today that a confession and newly disclosed evidence justify a new trial for the surgeon, a former Green Beret captain, who was convicted in 1979 of murdering his pregnant wife and two daughters.

description: Economists' perceptions of business prospects for this year have brightened substantially, only months after growth nearly stalled and experts were predicting a painfully slow start for 1985.

Troublemaking in South Africa
description: Consider first the simpler questions posed by Senator Edward Kennedy's stormy eight-day sojourn in South Africa: Interference in another country's affairs? Cadging liberal votes at home by posturing abroad? Both charges were flung at Mr. Kennedy by Pretoria's all-white regime - and by a small faction of black radicals who disrupted a final meeting in a black township.

description: Curt Dawson, who starred on Broadway and on tour in productions of ''Sleuth'' (1973) and ''Absurd Person Singular'' (1975), died on Sunday at Bellevue Hospital of complications resulting from cancer. He was 43 years old and lived in SoHo.

title: DIVERS TRY TO SAVE TREASURES OF CADIZ
description: OVER the centuries ships of every description sailed into the Spanish harbor of Cadiz, on the Atlantic west of Gibraltar. Phoenicians came from the Levant long ago, and then there were Greeks and Romans, Vikings and Venetians. In the Age of Discovery, this was the bustling home port for the Spanish caravels that found new worlds and the galleons that brought back the new-found riches.

description: Thirty-one Yale University students staged a sit-in today in the office of A. Bartlett Giamatti, Yale's president, urging that the university promise to make substantial compromises to avoid the resumption of a strike by clerical and technical workers.

description: A British baby borne by a woman for pay should live with the couple who contracted for her, a High Court judge ruled today.

description: Those hair restorers that have been advertised for many years in the back of men's magazines and Sunday supplements do not work, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: West Germany Plans to Buy U.S. Missiles for $1.1 Billion
description: West Germany plans to buy nearly 800 Patriot surface-to-air missiles, radars and launching control stations for more than $1.1 billion, the Pentagon said today.

title: Power Cut in Mozambique
description: Rightist rebels sabotaged power lines from South Africa early today, leaving most parts of this capital without electricity, the official press agency reported. This was the fifth time the rebels have cut power supplies to Maputo since October. The rebels have been fighting a hit-and-run war against the left-wing Government of President Samora M. Machel since Mozambique's independence from Portugal in 1975.

description: In a move reflecting the downward spiral in prices of light crude oil, the Norwegian state oil company said yesterday that it would begin negotiating new ''market-related'' prices with its customers. The effect is expected to be a reduction of $1 or more a barrel since the last official price of $29.05

title: SHARON JURY BEGINS ITS DELIBERATIONS
description: A jury began deliberating in Manhattan yesterday to decide if Time magazine libeled Ariel Sharon in an article about a massacre in Lebanon.

title: IN A REVERSAL, INAUGURATION PANEL DECIDES TO PAY ITS 200 PERFORMERS
description: Confronted with protests, picket lines, legal petitions and acute embarrassment, President Reagan's inauguration committee yesterday reversed its plan to use 200 unpaid, nonunion performers for the week's events. It said it would pay them triple the union rate.

description: It is 10:30 A.M. Dr. William C. DeVries stops and talks to the guard outside the hospital room. He learns that the patient inside is asleep and decides to move on.
