description: A meeting of Soviet bloc leaders planned for this week in Bulgaria has been postponed, possibly because Konstantin U. Chernenko is ailing.

title: CANANDAIGUA WINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DEBUT FOR PHYLLIS GEORGE ON 'CBS MORNING NEWS'
description: LET annalists record that Phyllis George's first words on the ''CBS Morning News'' yesterday were ''I'm so excited,'' that she hugged Burt Reynolds after she interviewed him (''Hey, we look good together,'' she said then) and that during this, her debut as co-anchor, the bowl of flowers on her coffee table was changed surreptitiously at least four times. Actually, that was quite a nice touch. The new ''CBS Morning News'' is pretty.

title: U.S.T.A. ACTING ON BEHAVIOR
description: In recent days, the top 30 or so American tennis players have been receiving correspondence from the United States Tennis Association regarding the Davis Cup. A standard application form for those interested in being on the team, schedules, and other pertinent information were included.

title: Key Rates
CAROL WAYNE
description: Carol Wayne, the wide-eyed, breathy- voiced actress who often played a sexy foil for Johnny Carson's ribald jokes on ''The Tonight Show,'' has drowned in Mexico.

title: SCOUTING ;   Crossing Paths
description: Sydney Maree and Eamonn Coghlan are both graduates of Villanova University, both world-class runners, and both missed the 1984 Olympics because of injuries. Now, both are back on the track pursuing comebacks. As luck would have it, they will cross paths one week from Friday night when they face each other in the Wanamaker Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden.

title: Airline Files Court Plan
description: Continental Air Lines outlined to the bankruptcy court in Biloxi, Miss., yesterday a tentative reorganization plan that would pay in full all creditor claims that existed on Sept. 24, 1983, when it filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: 16 INDICTED BY U.S. IN BID TO END CHURCH SMUGGLING OF LATIN ALIENS
description: The Justice Department announced 16 indictments and more than 60 arrests today in a crackdown on church groups accused of smuggling illegal aliens from Central America.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;  $160 Million Bond Sale Announced by M.A.C.
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday announced a $160 million bond sale, with proceeds to be used for refunding some of its outstanding bonds. The financing was not previously announced because M.A.C. officials did not want to disrupt trading in outstanding bonds that are to be refunded.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 15, 1985 International

title: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $13.5 million on the sale of the company's leasehold interest in its headquarters building.

title: FOLGER THEATER TO CLOSE
description: The Folger Theater, which has presented Shakespearean plays for the last 15 years, is closing, it was announced today by the Amherst College board of trustees, which administers the parent Folger Shakespeare Library.

title: MORGAN, J.P. & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per-share figures reflect 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend payable Jan. 15.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 15, 1985

title: KEY TRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 15
Boycott Is Urged For King Holiday
description: A coalition of clergymen yesterday urged the public to boycott the city's transit system today to protest Mayor Koch's refusal to declare a municipal holiday in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: PNC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DAMON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including gain from repurchase of debentures of $144,020. c-Net income, including gain from repurchase of debentures of $70,974.

title: ST. JOHN'S ROLLS OVER PITT BY 31
description: For St. John's, playing here the last few seasons has been hard work.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: -SCI The twin-bill exhibition that opens today at the I.B.M. Gallery, at the I.B.M. atrium on Madison Avenue at 56th Street (407-6100), offers something old, an ancient art, and something new and scientifically modern.

title: FROM THERE TO HERE
description: PARIS Despite Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko's stern repetition of his country's conditions for strategic arms control accords, it can be assumed that talks will be held.

title: COLLECTIONS BENEFIT THE NEEDIEST
description: Donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund often describe their methods of collecting money for the fund and how they add personal significance to their contributions.

title: NORTHERN TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FRESHMAN FROM QUEENS SETS UP SHOP IN ALBANY
description: At 12:37 this afternoon - with her husband, Gerry, and Mom and Dad and Uncle Pat and Aunt Rose and two busloads of neighbors looking on - Catherine T. Nolan was sworn in to the post she has been working for since college, Assemblywoman from Queens.

title: SCHULMAN, A. INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Northwest Write-Off
description: Northwest Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it would take a charge of $31 million after taxes in the fourth quarter because the Supreme Court has declined to review a case involving claims filed by about 3,300 female cabin attendants under the Civil Rights Act and the Equal Pay Act.

title: REAGAN GETS BELGIAN LEADER'S PLEDGE ON MISSILES
description: The Prime Minister of Belgium told President Reagan today that his Government remained committed to the allied decision to deploy new American missiles in Belgium and other Western European nations.

title: MOORE STRESSES WEST VIRGINIA'S TROUBLES AS HE RESUMES POST
description: Arch A. Moore Jr. became West Virginia's Governor again today, succeeding the man who succeeded him eight years ago, John D. Rockefeller 4th.

title: Record Ticket Sales For 'The King and I'
description: The revival of ''The King and I,'' which opened last Monday at the Broadway Theater, has been breaking records for ticket sales, according to a spokesman for the show, who says the box office's three ticket machines have been supplemented with two extras, in the lobby and basement, to cope with the heavy demand.

title: Armco Financial
description: Glendale Federal Savings and Loan Association said it had signed a letter of intent to buy the Armco Financial Corporation, the domestic commercial finance subsidiary of Armco Inc. The proposed price would be based on the audited financial statements of Armco Financial as of Dec. 31, 1984, and is estimated to be between $60 million and $70 million. Glendale is the fifth-largest savings and loan institution in the nation.

title: STATEWIDE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Washington Watch column yesterday misstated the age of George Jaszi, who has just retired as director of the Bureau of Economic Analysis of the Commerce Department. He is 69.

title: BRIEFS
Met Museum President Announces Retirement
description: William B. Macomber, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, announced at the museum's board of trustees meeting last week that he would retire his post June 30, 1986, in adherence to the museum's policy of executive retirement at age 65.

title: Plan Seeks to Curb 2-Way Cab Radios
description: Seeking to raise the number of yellow medallion taxis available to passengers who hail cabs from the street, the Taxi and Limousine Commission has proposed removing all two-way radios from the taxis within two years, city officials said yesterday.

title: PRESSURE PIPING COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $170,000 for the quarter and $238,000 for the 6 months, and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $1,850,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $25,000 for the quarter and $170,000 for the 6 months.

title: Nestle Acquires Hills Brothers
description: Nestle Holdings Inc. has exercised an option it acquired in April to buy all of the stock of Hills Brothers Coffee Inc. The price was not disclosed.

title: OPERA: BERG'S 'WOZZECK' AT THE MET
description: IT is not every year that a company is willing or able to perform all the operas of a major

title: MARYLAND TOPPLES 2D-RANKED DUKE
description: Len Bias and Adrian Branch got 4 points apiece in overtime, leading Maryland to a 78-76 upset of Duke tonight in the Atlantic Coast Conference. Overcoming a 15-point second- half deficit, Maryland snapped the 12- game winning streak of the previously unbeaten Blue Devils, ranked second nationally in both wire-service polls.

title: 'PATENTED' SHOT CLICKS FOR WADKINS
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif.

title: MCCORMICK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes gains from property sales of $1,900,000, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and $24,000,000, or $1.94, for the year. c-Includes gains from property sales of $9,800,000, or 78 cents a share, for the quarter and $10,800,000, or 86 cents a share, for the year.

title: SPEARHEAD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss after a charge of $169,000 for the quarter from a customs ruling against the company.

title: PEOPLE AIR PRESIDENT DEPARTING
description: Harold J. Pareti has resigned as president and chief operating officer of People Express Airlines to pursue other business opportunities, the carrier said yesterday.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE AND REGAN BACK END TO U.S. CURB ON STOCK CREDIT
description: The Federal Reserve Board recommended today that the Government turn over to the nation's stock exchanges its authority to set limits on the use of credit in stock trading.

title: NI Industries To Be Bought TAYLOR, Mich., Jan. 14
description: (Reuters) - The Masco Corporation and Masco Industries

title: RIEGEL TEXTILE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $459,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $407,000 from discontinued operations.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Judge Thom Is Reappointed
description: He studied at Princeton and Yale,

title: Brothers Hold Posts In Adjoining States
description: Charles G. Brown 3d, who took office as West Virginia's Attorney General today, is at the age of 34 the nation's youngest state attorney general. But he is not the youngest elected official in his family.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Jan. 15, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: CLEVER DESIGN CAN ASSIST HANDICAPPED
description: FOR most people, computers are a convenience rather than a necessity. For thousands of disabled people, however, computers are the key to new lives.

title: Salt River Bonds For Nuclear Plant
description: The Salt River Agricultural Improvement and Power District in Arizona is offering $100 million of long- term bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: SCOUTING ;   Agony of Victory Is Felt by Nets
description: The Nets' lineup is no longer injury- riddled, but the return to health has spawned new troubles. The guards Darwin Cook and Otis Birdsong were both less than pleased after Sunday's exciting 100-99 victory over the Houston Rockets.

title: 'HEALING' MAY WORSEN CHOLESTEROL DAMAGE
description: A NEW theory of how high blood cholesterol can lead to congestion in coronary arteries has been proposed by a pathologist at the University of Washington. According to studies by Dr. Russell Ross and his Seattle colleagues, a growth factor that promotes healing may overrespond to cholesterol-caused damage in blood vessels, causing overgrowth of cells that can eventually clog arteries and set the stage for heart attacks.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Moses Malone and the Sixers' other big guns arrive to face a Knick team that will be even more undermanned than usual.

title: TEXT OF THE TIME STATEMENT
description: Following is the statement by Time magazine that appears in the issue of Jan. 21:

title: A TOAST TO AMERICAN FASHION
description: The Council of Fashion Designers of America gave a party at the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue Sunday night. The admission fee was steep ($500 a ticket), the dinner mostly home-style (chicken potpie) and the award winners eclectic (from the trendy Astor Place Hair Designers to James Galanos, the jewel in the crown of American ready-to-wear). The 290 people attending proclaimed it a big success, a lift for American fashion and a harbinger of further achievement by the designers' group, founded in 1963.

title: WAR'S COST IN NICARAGUA: 2 MOTHERS PAY IN GRIEF
description: When the Christmas vacation ended, two distraught mothers in different parts of this capital begged their young daughters not to return to their jobs teaching school near the Honduran border.

title: LAWS TO HELP CHILDREN URGED
description: The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children today called for major revisions in state criminal laws on molestation, abuse, kidnapping and exploitation of children.

title: Sweet Honey at Town Hall
description: Sweet Honey in the Rock will perform at Town Hall on Jan. 26 at 8 P.M. The group of five singers from Washington sings a cappella and with traditional African percussion instruments.

title: ZYMOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a writeoff of $1,600,000 for equipment replaced as a result of wafer fabrication facility upgrade and expansion.

title: LONDON RAISES RATES TO AID POUND
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government, abandoning its hands-off approach, acted today to prop up the pound by forcing a sharp rise in interest rates. But it fell nonetheless. After initially rebounding to $1.13 from about $1.10 on the Government's moves, the pound later sank back to $1.1137, a new closing low in London.

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CAMERA FOR THE COMPUTER SCREEN
description: THE aspect of the Macintosh that sets it apart is its visual approach to information processing.

title: NEW CAMBODIAN PREMIER NAMED
description: Cambodia's 33-year-old Foreign Minister, Hun Sen, was named Prime Minister today, according to Government press agency reports from Phnom Penh.

title: Challenges to Ads Are Basically Upheld
description: Usually the monthly reports from the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus on the challenges resolved during that period contain one or more cases in which advertisers were able to prove their claims to the satisfaction of the industry watchdog. Not so in December.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHASE MANHATTAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CREDIT MARKETS ;   Hanover Bank Cuts Prime
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company yesterday announced a cut in its prime lending rate to 10 1/2 percent from 10 3/4 percent - a decline that reflected the steep drop in other interest rates during recent months. No other banks immediately matched the reduction.

title: Budget Chief Runs Short
description: As he was leaving the ABC News studio in downtown Washington after being interviewed Sunday, David A. Stockman, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, realized that he was acutely short of cash and asked to borrow $5 to get his car out of a parking garage. The employee who came up with the money was Sam Donaldson, the network reporter who is known at the White House as a raffish fellow who asks aggressive, sometimes puckish questions and delights in exchanges with the President. When Mr. Stockman learned who had provided the loan, he said, ''I will find an interesting way to repay him.''

title: Talking Businesswith Rudloff of Credit Suisse First Boston ;   Going Abroad For Financing
description: American companies seeking new financing flocked to London last year like prospectors to the Klondike. In what might be called the Eurorush, they raised $21.1 billion, up more than threefold from 1983. Even the Soviet Union, believed to have been absent from foreign bond markets since the 1917 revolution, took its first plunge by issuing $50 million of Eurobonds through the Moscow Narodny Bank.

title: POLE, IN TRIAL, ACCUSES FORMER SUPERIOR OF LYING
description: As a former Polish security police colonel charged with aiding and abetting the murder of a pro-Solidarity priest ended his testimony today, his co-defendant and chief accuser rose in court and dennounced the evidence of his former superior as ''fundamentally lies.''

title: Chess Game Is Adjourned at 41st Move
description: The 41st game of the world chess championship match was adjourned today after Gary Kasparov, the challenger, sealed his 41st move.

title: A Stake in Scovill
description: A group of companies controlled by Ivan F. Boesky, the New York investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had bought 903,700 shares of Scovill Inc., or 7.4 percent of the total outstanding.

title: CITY SUES FOR $10 MILLION IN DEMOLITION ON 44TH ST.
description: The Koch administration filed a $10 million lawsuit yesterday in connection with the unauthorized nighttime demolition of four buildings on West 44th Street. It also called for a criminal investigation of the matter.

title: USAir to Reward Frequent Fliers
description: USAir Inc. became one of the last major airlines to offer a frequent- flier plan, saying such plans ''have become a permanent feature imbedded in airline marketing'' and necessary to remain competitive.

title: CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The results for the current periods are for 13 weeks and 39 weeks. The year ago results are for 14 weeks and 40 weeks.

title: Baldwin Will Aid Fund
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation agreed yesterday to contribute about $170 million to a fund that would increase the return on annuities bought from the bankrupt company.

title: Anton Karas, 78, ComposerOf 'Third Man' Movie Theme
description: Anton Karas, the Viennese zither player who composed the haunting theme for the film ''The Third Man,'' died here Thursday.

title: SPECTRO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 5
description: The company said results for the latest 9 months include a non-taxable gain of $898,000 from life insurance proceeds paid as a result of the death of a former officer.

title: MOST OF BROOKLYN EXCLUDED FROM ECONOMIC RECOVERY, STUDY FINDS
description: While New York City's economic recovery has helped a few of the more affluent Brooklyn neighborhoods, it has bypassed most of the borough, which experienced some of the city's greatest losses of jobs and population in the last seven years, a study said yesterday.

title: VESSEY SAYS PEACE IS AIM OF CHINA TIE
description: Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that military ties between the United States and China ''are designed to promote peace and understanding, and threaten no third party.''

title: False Fears of Contagion
description: Humans shed a ceaseless torrent of viruses and bacteria. With each movement of the body, some 60,000 bacteria a minute cast off on little rafts of dead skin and puff out in clouds from under the clothes.

title: STORM WASN'T ALL FUN, BUT SAN ANTONIO COPED
description: There was a snowman in front of the Alamo, people went skiing under palm trees, garages collapsed and the city of San Antonio, which does not own a snowplow, had to shut its doors completely today in the wake of a snowstorm even Chicago could not have ignored.

title: Utilities Get Seabrook Delay
description: The Maine Public Utilities Commission yesterday agreed to extend for five weeks the deadline it had given the three utilities in that state to get out of the Seabrook nuclear power project.

title: CENTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $2.6 million. c-After tax credits of $1.2 million for the quarter and $3 million for the year. d-After a gain of $3 million related to a reserve for discontinued operations and a tax credit of $15 million and includes a nonrecurring gain of $6.3 million from the settlement of litigation.

title: M.T.A. Widening Half-Fare Plan
description: All people 65 years of age or older will be eligible for half fares on the city's subway and bus system under a new program the Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to put in effect, transit officials said yesterday.

title: Burger King Shift May 31
description: J. Jeffrey Campbell, chairman and chief executive officer of the Burger King Corporation, said today that the resignation of Jerome B. Ruenheck as the company's president and chief operating officer would be effective May 31.

title: ARTS AGENCY FACES 11.7% BUDGET CUT, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY
description: President Reagan will soon ask Congress to cut the budget of the National Endowment for the Arts by 11.7 percent, according to Administration officials and budget documents prepared by the agency.

title: DEVILS EDGE THE RANGERS, ALLOWING ONLY 13 SHOTS
description: The Devils, with two third-period goals, defeated the Rangers last night, 2-1, and, for once, the game was the thing.

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
EVANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
Storage Head Resigns
description: The financially troubled Storage Technology Corporation said yesterday that Jesse I. Aweida had resigned as chairman. The resignation, which had been widely expected, is effective Saturday. Mr. Aweida, 53 years old, is the company's founder and major stockholder. He will remain a director, Storage Technology said. Mr. Aweida stepped down as chief executive officer on Nov. 19.

title: FIDELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $193,000. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $714,000 and an after-tax gain of $11,079,000 on the sale of building subsidiary.

title: BANK OF VIRGINIA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CENTRAL BANCSHARES OF THE SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INTERNATIONAL MINERALS & CHEMICALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income of $700,000 for the quarter and a loss of $100,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations. c-Including a gain of $6.3 million, or 23 cents a share, from the exchange of the company's common stock and cash for certain of its debentures and a gain of $7.5 million, or 28 cents a share, from changes in tax law. Year-ago sales figures have been restated to exclude sales of discontinued methanol business.

title: CUSTOMS SERVICE RECOVERS 3 ART WORKS STOLEN IN EUROPE
description: The United States Customs Service announced yesterday that it had recovered three art works stolen in Italy and France in recent years, the most valuable of which, an 18th-century Italian painting by Bernardo Bellotto, was to have been auctioned today at Christie's.

title: Italian 9-mm. Chosen To Replace Army's .45
description: The Italian 9-millimeter Beretta has been chosen to replace the Colt .45 as the standard pistol for the American armed forces, the Army announced today.

title: SURGE IN STOCK INDEX OPTIONS
description: Trading in stocks and stock options has languished in the past year, but trading in index options, which reflect the overall movement in the stock market, has grown by leaps and bounds. And no index option has succeeded more than the S.&P. 100 index option, which is traded on the Chicago Board Options Exchange.

title: Caroline Kennedy Denies Being in David's Room
description: Caroline Kennedy never entered the room where her cousin David was staying before he was found dead of a drug overdose, according to sworn statements from her released today.

title: HARVARD, AMID OPPOSITION, PLANS TO SELL UPSTATE FOREST GIVEN BY ALUMNUS
description: When he died in 1949, Dr. Ernest G. Stillman bequeathed a 3,800-acre forest in this mountainous Orange County community to his alma mater, Harvard University.

title: AN ADMINISTRATION DISMANTLING A GOVERNMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST ATLANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
G.M. Truck Plant
description: The General Motors Truck and Bus Group, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, said it would invest $400 million to expand light truck production at a plant in Pontiac, Mich., by mid-1986. It said the funds would be used to produce 1987 model full-size pickups, noting that output would be accommodated by moving heavier truck assembly at the same plant to a nearby plant starting next month.

title: Navy Suspends Top Heart Surgeon
description: The chief heart surgeon at the Naval Hospital in Bethesda, Md., which treats Presidents, Congressmen, and other dignitaries, has been suspended because of concerns over his technical performance, the Navy said today.

title: Pollution-Curb Issue in Florida
description: The Hillsboro County Industrial Development Authority in Florida is offering $85.9 million of pollution-control revenue bonds on behalf of the Tampa Electric Company, through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: ZIEGLER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss reserve of $1,293,000, after taxes, relating to the possible repurchase of securities where payment on principal is unlikely. c-Net income. d-Includes a loss reserve, after taxes, of $2,005,000 for the possible repurchases of securities.

title: DATAPOINT SUITOR TALKS TO 3D PARTY
description: Continental Telecom Inc., the communications company, said yesterday that it had had ''discussions'' with Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, about acquiring the Datapoint Corporation.

title: LINEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Sri Lanka Policeman Is Shot By Rebels in Troubled North
description: A policeman was shot dead today by Tamil separatist guerrillas in Sri Lanka's troubled northern province, a Government spokesman said.

title: DRIVE MOUNTED TO BAN TV BEER AND WINE ADS
description: A coalition of education, religious and public health activists is mounting an effort to ban advertising of beer and wine on television. Advocates of the ban, which include the National Parent-Teacher Association as well as the Mormon and Baptist churches, contend that such messages promote alcohol abuse and lead to such problems as drunken driving.

title: 392 ARE KILLED
description: Officials said today that a train had plunged into a ravine in eastern Ethiopia, killing 392 people and injuring 370.

title: CENTRAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'VIETNAM UNDER COMMUNISM,' ON 13
description: HOW should we regard Vietnam today - as a nation to be pitied, admired, distrusted, despised? ''Vietnam Under Communism,'' the ''Frontline'' documentary on Channel 13 at 9 tonight, straddles the answer. This ought to be a good thing; a dispassionate examination of Vietnam is to be prized. At the same time, the documentary doesn't quite allow us to find our own answer. In part, its even- handedness gets in the way.

title: SPENCER COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
Affiliated Hospital Stake to Be Sold
description: The Smith & Nephew Associated Companies P.L.C. said it had agreed to buy the United Industrial Corporation's 73 percent stake in Affiliated Hospital Products Inc. for $42.7 million in 10-year notes.

title: JUSTICES TO RULE ON RETIREMENT AGE FOR FIREFIGHTER
description: The Supreme Court today expanded its review of age discrimination on the job by agreeing to decide whether a city can force its fire and police officers to retire at the age of 55 without first proving that the mandatory retirement is necessary for safety and efficiency.

title: DESIGNATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to give retroactive effect to a 10 percent stock dividend declared in September 1983 and a 5 percent stock dividend declared in October 1984.

title: HALMI, ROBERT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago results are for the quarter and 6 months ended Dec. 31, 1983. Effective May 31, 1984 the company changed its fiscal year-end from March 31 to May 31.

title: Newsmakers Can't Be News Censors
description: The Central Intelligence Agency cannot sue a news organization for libel, for the courts have long held that prosecutions for ''libel on government'' have no place in American jurisprudence. So the C.I.A., feeling aggrieved by an ABC News report, complained instead to the Federal Communications Commission. Charging news distortion and unfair attack, it asked the commission to investigate the network, perhaps even strip it of some broadcast licenses.

title: STOP CODDLING FARMERS
description: Agricultural policy is probably the Reagan Administration's largest domestic failure. Federal spending for agricultural price supports soared sevenfold between 1980 and 1983. The total cost of farm programs exceeded $50 billion in 1983, yet farm bankruptcies are near record highs, farmland value is falling and farm income is 20 percent below 1979 levels. The more the Government has spent, the worse off farmers have become.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Jerusalem yesterday about the Israeli Cabinet's troop- withdrawal plan for Lebanon incorrectly characterized the position of Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai. Mr. Modai, a Likud official, left the Cabinet meeting before the vote was taken and did not cast a ballot.

title: Equity Stake
description: Equity Group Holding Inc. intends to buy up to 25 percent of the stock outstanding of the Easco Corporation, it said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: AUDIO-VIDEO AFFILIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Bangladesh Dissolves Cabinet and Sets Election
description: Gen. H. M. Ershad, the leader of Bangladesh, dissolved his Council of Ministers today and announced that parliamentary elections would be held April 6, the first in six years.

title: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Master's Voice
description: Dave Zinkoff has not exactly been a voice in the wilderness. For 50 years, he has been the public-address voice at thousands of sporting events, chiefly basketball games, in Philadelphia.

title: SCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special charges of $14,200,000.

title: LAND RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results have been adjusted to reflect a $2.9 million writedown.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income after a loss of $9 million from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $1.1 million from discontinued operations and a loss of $60.7 million on the disposition of discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $29.7 million from discontinued operations.

title: New Names in Town
description: From its ground breaking nearly

title: CORRECTION
description: The Going Out Guide last Thursday gave an incorrect date for the American premiere of the opera ''Dreyfus'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It will be performed at 8 P.M. tomorrow and Saturday.

title: Transfers and Dropouts Mark Season
description: Sometimes it seems as if the only significant distinction between professional and major-college athletics is terminology. Professionals are on salary, collegians are on scholarship; professionals retire, a collegian's eligibility expires. A professional athlete is traded, a college athlete transfers, with the difference that no compensation is allowed in return.

title: MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
description: b-Includes insurance proceeds of approximately $1,600,000 from a fire claim. c-Includes life insurance proceeds of $264,000.

title: BARRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including equity in earnings of unconsolidated affiliate of $143,000 for the quarter and $253,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss including a tax credit of $97,000 and equity in earnings of unconsolidated affailiate of $217,000. d-Including a tax credit of $40,000 and equity in earnings of unconsolidated affiliate of $282,000.

title: DAMON BIOTECH reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
STABLE TAX RATE IS PREDICTED
description: The taxable value of property in New York City has been tentatively set at $52.3 billion, 8 percent higher than last year, the City Finance Department announced yesterday.

title: DOCTORS ASK, WHO LIVES? WHEN TO DIE?
description: It was an ordinary day for Dr. David Finley, the chief of intensive care at a Manhattan hospital. There were seven terminally ill patients in his ward, and he had to decide how long to keep them alive.

title: CRUEL ODYSSEY OF THE HOMELESS SEEKING A BED
description: A caseworker at the Hull Avenue emergency shelter gave Virginia Agosto a fistful of subway tokens at 9 A.M. yesterday and sent the pregnant woman and her five exhausted children back to their local welfare office in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx.

title: INTEREST RATES DROP ON ECONOMIC DATA
description: Interest rates declined modestly yesterday as weaker-than-expected economic statistics for December helped keep alive hopes that interest rates might decline further - or at least would not rise soon.

title: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION UP BY 0.6%
description: Industrial production spurted by six- tenths of 1 percent in December, the biggest increase in five months, in another sign that the economy is picking up steam after its fall pause, the Government said today.

GENERALS (USFL) - Signed Heyward Golden, free safety; John Tautolo and Al Steinfeld, offensive tackles; Derrick Hatchell and Bill Hill, cornerbacks; Jim Dumont, linebacker, and Vaughn Broadnax, fullback. OAKLAND (USFL) - Joe Pendry, offensive coordinator, resigned. MacArthur Lane was named running backs coach. Signed for 1985 were Ed Muransky, offensive tackle; Craig Dunaway, tight end; Tom McConnaughey, wide receiver; Tom Morris, cornerback, and Randy Logan, safety. title: Stone and His Offers
description: Marvin L. Stone, who said Monday that he was retiring as editor of U.S. News & World Report, will reportedly be nominated as deputy director of the United States Information Agency. That post has had a long-standing vacancy; President Reagan tried to fill it a year ago with Leslie Lenkowsky, then assistant director of the agency, but the Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted against confirmation after the nominee had denied all knowledge of a blacklisting operation.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ONE of the grimmest firsts of 1985 involves lung cancer, which this year is expected to become the leading cause of cancer death in American women. Breast cancer, long in the forefront, afflicts more women. But its survival rate, about two women in three, is far higher than that of lung cancer, which only one woman in seven survives.

MIDEAST LEADERS READY FOR PEACE
description: Never before has the contemporary Middle East enjoyed a better alignment of leaders who could produce a down-to-earth peace. My recent interviews with both men convince me that the rare combination of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel may indeed produce a breakthrough - on the condition that they are willing to support each other against their own oppositions.

title: CITY BALLET: 'AGON'
description: THE three works that the New York City Ballet presented on Friday night in the New York State Theater looked back upon the past with modern eyes.

title: EXECUTIVES
U.S. REFLECTS ON DREAM OF A BATTLER FOR RIGHTS
description: The country marked the 56th birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. yesterday, with political leaders hailing the slain civil-rights leader as they condemned the arms race and South Africa's discriminatory racial policies.

title: Fink Stops Weighing A Race Against Koch
description: Last week, Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink promised to spend a few days thinking about running for Mayor of New York City.

title: EGYPT PORTRAYS ITSELF AS MAJOR U.S. ASSET
description: Egypt, in a confidential document seeking a $1 billion increase in American aid, has portrayed itself as a critical ''strategic asset'' to the United States.

title: U.S. FINING HONEYWELL $800,000 IN HEATER CASE
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today that Honeywell Inc. had agreed to pay $800,000 in civil penalties to settle charges that it had failed to report defects in some of its gas heater control valves. The commission has linked the valves

title: NETS' DAWKINS BACK TONIGHT
description: With the Chicago Bulls in town Wednesday to face the Nets, one might believe that all talk was about Michael Jordan, the sensational rookie who has become the league's biggest gate attraction. But perhaps for the first time this season, Jordan will have to take a back seat for someone else: Darryl Dawkins.

title: Robert S. Adler, 84; Chicago Civic Leader
description: Robert S. Adler, a civic leader who headed revitalization of the Adler Planetarium in Chicago, died Sunday at Highland Park Hospital after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

HIGH COURT EASES SEARCH STRICTURES IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that the Constitution permits public school teachers and officials to search students as long as there are ''reasonable grounds'' for believing that the search will yield evidence of a violation of the law or school rules.

title: 'Alone Together' Closes
description: Alone Together,'' a comedy by Lawrence Roman about a couple whose three grown children return home, closed after Saturday evening's performance at the Music Box Theater. Directed by Arnold Mittleman and starring Janis Paige and Kevin McCarthy, the play ran for 97 performances after 15 previews.

title: U.S. Facilitates Zero Coupons
description: The Treasury announced plans yesterday to broaden the market for its notes and bonds by making it easier to create zero coupon securities, which do not pay interest but are sold at a deep discount.

title: Digital Computer
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation is making a bid for the small-business segment of the multiuser computer market with the introduction of the Micropdp-11/SV, priced at $5,995. Company officials said the new system can support up to four users simultaneously and includes a central processing unit and 512,000 bytes of main memory.

title: THE KOCH RE-ELECTION CAMPAIGN HAS TAKEN IN $2.8 MILLION SO FAR
description: Mayor Koch has already raised $2.8 million, including hundreds of thousands of dollars from real-estate developers, for his re-election campaign, according to financial reports filed yesterday with the City Board of Elections.

title: AN AFGHAN FOOTNOTE: LEGEND OF A SOVIET FARM BOY
description: After nearly five years of playing down the conflict in Afghanistan, the official Soviet press has found a war hero.

title: Memorial for Edward Mabley
description: A memorial for Edward Mabley, a playwright and television director, will be held on Sunday at 5 P.M. at the New Dramatists, 424 West 44th Street. Mr. Mabley, the author of the Broadway plays ''Temper the Wind'' and ''Glad Tidings,'' died Dec. 16 at the age of 78. He was a director for CBS-TV from 1952 to 1969.

title: 3 DEAD IN JAMAICA AS PROTESTS ERUPT
description: Protest demonstrations erupted across this Caribbean nation today, hours after the Government sharply increased fuel prices.

Albert A. Richman, 88, Dies; Rabbinical College President
description: Albert A. Richman, president of the Rabbinical College of America in Morristown, N.J., died Sunday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Springfield, N.J.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Power Agency Offers $600 Million in Bonds
description: The North Carolina Eastern Municipal Power Agency, which sells electricity to 32 communities in the state, is offering short- and long-term bonds through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. The financing, well received by investors, was raised to $600 million from $450 million.

title: Market Place;   Mutual Funds: 1984 Reviewed

title: HIGHER FEE SOUGHT BY ADMINISTRATION FOR MANY SERVICES
description: The Reagan Administration will ask Congress to increase charges for some financial services the Government provides, including home mortgage insurance, farm credit and export loan guarantees, Administration officials said today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   President Named At First Interstate
description: First Interstate Bancorp, Los Angeles, said yesterday that it had named Edward M. Carson as president of the bank holding company, the seventh largest in the nation.

title: Early-January Auto Sales Rose 12%
description: Opening the new year with higher-than-expected sales, American auto makers reported today that new-car sales in the Jan. 1-10 period rose 12 percent, on a daily selling rate basis.

title: AS A FAVORED FRUIT, ORANGES KEEP BLOSSOMING
description: ORANGES, for those of us living in the snowy North, used to come once a year, a mid-winter treat that was tucked in the toes of Christmas stockings, a flash of color from the tropics to brighten the winter blahs. But since 1946, when Vacuum Foods, a Florida company later known as Minute Maid, produced the first commercially viable can of frozen orange juice concentrate, year-round consumption of oranges in America has grown dramatically, most of it in the form of frozen or reconstituted concentrated juice.

title: ACTIVISTS VOW TO CONTINUE AIDING PEOPLE FLEEING CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Despite the indictment of some of their leaders, church groups here and elsewhere said today that they would continue to give sanctuary to Central Americans they consider to be political refugees.

description: Year-ago share earnings are restated for a 5-for-4 stock split effective Sept. 14, 1984.

title: EDITOR IS CHOSEN AT LE MONDE
description: Journalists at Le Monde elected Andre Fontaine as managing director tonight.

title: STRUGGLING DATAPOINT'S ALLURE
description: For nearly three years, the Datapoint Corporation, one of Wall Street's high-technology favorites in the early 1980's, has been struggling with only modest success to reverse the misfortunes caused by an accounting scandal.

title: Houston Gas
description: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation said a senior management group had agreed to buy its Zeigler Coal Company subsidiary for $55 million. The group is headed by Zeigler's president, Michael Reilly. Zeigler owns and operates four underground mines and coal preparation plants in central and southern Illinois.

title: Copter on Mercy Mission Crashes, Killing 6 Men
description: An Air Force helicopter sent to evacuate a sick seaman from a merchant ship crashed on the vessel today, killing six of the helicopter's crewmen and leaving a seventh missing and presumed dead, the authorities said.

title: JETTA GOUDAL
description: Jetta Goudal, a tall, imposing French actress who played exotic screen sirens in many silent films and a few talkies, died on Monday at her home after a long illness.

description: Gunmen have killed 17 civilians in an area 10 miles northeast of Kampala in the past two weeks, the independent daily newspaper Ngabo reported today.

description: Harold Pressley scored 22 points and Gary McLain added 20 to lead Villanova to an 85-66 victory tonight over Boston College in a Big East Conference game.

description: New York State high schools produced more than one of every three of the semifinalists named yesterday in the annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search, far more than those of any other state.

title: Loss for Rooney, Pace
description: Rooney, Pace Group Inc., the New York investment firm, yesterday reported an operating loss of $2.5 million after taxes for the quarter ended Nov. 30 against an operating profit of $1.94 million in the quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose 59.3 percent, to $18.8 million from $11.8 million. However, the company said that the 1984 quarter's revenue, less interest income, was 3.2 percent lower than the year before.

title: BRITISH SOLDIERS KILL A TEEN-AGER IN WEST BELFAST
description: Soldiers from the British Army's Ulster Defense Regiment opened fire today on a carload of teen-agers after the vehicle crashed into a roadblock. The 30 or so shots killed the driver, Paul Gerard Kelly, a 17-year-old Roman Catholic, and wounded four others, one seriously.

A Mao Remembrance Offers a Mixed Review
description: People's Daily today marked the 50th anniversary of Mao Zedong's accession to the party leadership with a front-page article asserting that Mao got away with his ''leftist errors'' after 1949 because ''the people were not mentally prepared'' for the possibility of his making mistakes.

title: SEVERAL EXHIBITS SOUGHT BY JURY AT SHARON TRIAL
description: Jury deliberations continued yesterday in the two-month-old libel trial of Ariel Sharon against Time magazine in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: A SKILLED POLITICAL HAND
description: When Tancredo Neves became Governor of Minas Gerais on behalf of Brazil's main opposition party in 1983, he seemed content at the age of 73 to end a long political career as the leader of his home state. ''This was always my aspiration,'' he recalled. Yet when the opposition began looking last year for a Presidential candidate who could unite its factions and be acceptable to the departing military Government, they drafted Mr. Neves as the personification of political conciliation and moderation.

title: INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRINCIPAL EXTOLS SEARCHES DECISION
description: The principal of Piscataway High School today hailed the United States Supreme Court ruling involving the school that allows staff members to search students suspected of violating the law or school regulations. But some students expressed reservations.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: JUDITH NEWMAN confesses that she is hopelessly in love with her new VCR, and no more so than when it is showing a movie. Indeed, she wonders how, on these dark winter nights, any movie fan can be without one.

title: THAT OTHER POLITICAL DEMONSTRATION
description: When officials at the Soviet Embassy here open the drapes to look out the windows at 1125 16th Street they cannot help seeing it. For almost two years now, a red and white flag bearing the name of the Polish trade union Solidarity has billowed in front of the International Union of Electrical Workers building directly across the street.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DRAWING CARD Frank Lloyd Wright was an architect well-known for his creation of new forms, for using his talents as artist and meticulous craftsman to translate his visions of the mind into representations on paper. More than 50 of his drawings are now on view at the fourth-floor Max Protetch Gallery, 37 West 57th Street (838-2340).

title: California Top in Population
description: California gained 436,000 people in the year that ended last July 1 and kept its lead over New York as the nation's most populous state. With Los Angeles County leading the way, California's population has grown to 25.62 million, nearly 8 million more than New York's population, California officials said Monday. The state reported that from July 1, 1983, to July 1984, 435,000 people were born in California, 188,000 died and 189,000 moved in.

title: Austria Paces Ski
description: Austrian skiers finished one, two today as Hans Enn edged Hubert Strolz in a men's giant-slalom race on the World Cup circuit.

description: Old senators never fade away until their stationery runs out. Roger W. Jepsen, Republican of Iowa, was defeated in November by Tom Harkin, who has been representing the state in the Senate for two weeks now, but the Joint Economic Committee, with thriftiness, is still sending out its notices in envelopes bearing the franked signature of its former chairman, Mr. Jepsen.

description: The glasses were raised on high last night at the Yale Club on Vanderbilt Avenue. They were raised by 150 alumni and friends at a $125-a-plate dinner to toast the 31 seniors on the football team.

title: 'IN SEARCH OF EXCELLENCE,' ON PBS
description: ''IN Search of Excellence'' probably won't be shown at Ronald Reagan's inaugural, but by golly he'd love it if it were. Mike Deaver and the boys have missed a bet. The documentary is a hymn to capitalist decency and old- fashioned get-up-and-go, saved from sanctimony by not being platitudinous. It's not a bad piece of television, either. The 90-minute work will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 tonight.

title: INTENT DISPUTED
description: President Reagan met today with about 20 black business executives, educators and other officials. The talks were hailed by some as a new attempt to reach blacks but assailed by others as an effort to circumvent the leadership that has historically spoken for blacks.

title: GERIATRIC CENTER TESTS 'DRUG-FREE DAYS'
description: MOST mornings Meyer Haspel visits the nurses' station at Daughters of Jacob Geriatric Center in the Bronx before breakfast. He waits there on line with other residents for his daily medications. Mondays are different, however: they are ''drug-free days.'' On such occasions most residents go without medication, though those known to be essential on a daily basis are continued, among them eye drops, antibiotics, anticonvulsants and substances to control diabetes.

title: Rebels in Mozambique Slay Pair From Britain
description: Mozambican rebels killed two British men Monday in an ambush near the South African border, a British Consulate official said here tonight.

description: More than 200 new subway cars for the D line that were supposed to be delivered to the Transit Authority beginning this month will arrive at least a year and a half behind schedule, transit officials said yesterday.

title: SCHOOLS ENCOURAGE ACTIVE PARENT ROLE
description: WHEN a group of parents in Chappaqua, N.Y., found they were having difficulty understanding their fifth-graders when the youngsters came home speaking ''computer lingo,'' the parents decided it was time to go back to school. They enrolled in a fifth-grade computer language course taught at the elementary school.

Spiegelman, commissioner of boys' swimming for the Public Schools Athletic League and assistant principal at Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn, bemoans the fact that even his own school's team needed an angel with water wings.

Carrots, for example, are cheap and nourishing, but after years of cooking them with no seasoning other than parsley, dill or mint, yet another unpeeled bagful is lacking in charm.

description: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, said today that he would not push this year for major changes in the Senate's rules. But he said he would support a recommendation on procedures that, if approved, might reduce the opportunity for filibusters.

State Senate Honors Kihss
description: The State Senate unanimously approved a resolution today mourning the death of Peter Kihss, a reporter with The New York Times for 30 years until his retirement in 1982. The resolution, sponsored by Senator John J. Marchi, Republican of Staten Island, memorialized Mr. Kihss, who died Dec. 28. ''The Senate of the State of New York,'' the resolution read in part, ''recognizes the enormous contribution of Peter Kihss to the common good of his city, state and nation through his illustrious exertions for the papers he served, and wishes to express its appreciation for the man and his work.''

title: ISRAEL'S NEW VIEW NORTH
description: The decision by the Israeli Cabinet to withdraw on its own from Lebanon over the next six to nine months appears to signal the start of a new Israeli approach toward dealing with its northern neighbor. Since the new national unity coalition came to power last September, two basic strategic conceptions about the threat to Israel arising in Lebanon - and how the Israeli Army should be used to deal with it - have been competing for supremacy among Israeli decision makers. The two trends might best be described as the ''Palestinian school'' and the ''Shiite school.''

title: COOKWARE OF COPPER

There is really no compelling reason to have a poacher made of expensive copper when stainless steel or aluminum would do the job just as well. But for elegance of table presentation nothing is as impressive as a shiny copper vessel.

title: 26 Killed in Brazil Rockslide
description: A predawn rockslide caused by torrential rains killed at least 26 people and injured dozens of others today in a crowded hillside shantytown, the police in the city of Vitoria said. The authorities said they expected the toll to rise as they looked through the shacks covered by mud and stone. The accident occurred in the Tabuazeiro slum on the outskirts of Vitoria.

Takeout shops specializing in sushi, fish markets with sushi bars, supermarkets selling sushi at their fish counters and some Korean produce markets are providing sushi to go, with delivery service. Blooming House Gourmet, 337 Second Avenue, is about to add a sushi counter. A new operation, Sushi Madness, delivers orders of hand rolls and assortments within an hour of a call.

title: CHESS: 41ST GAME IS A 71-MOVE DRAW
description: Gary Kasparov came from behind to draw the 41st game of the world title chess match yesterday in Moscow. The 21-year-old challenger nullified, by careful defense in a long adjournment session, the one-pawn advantage held by the champion, 33- year-old Anatoly Karpov.

title: CALIFORNIA FIRST BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter net includes a $7.1 million possible loan and lease loss provision compared with a $5 million provision in the year-ago quarter. The total provision charged to 1984 net was $29.2 million, down $400,000 from a year ago.

title: Provincetown Air Schedule Changes
description: Provincetown-Boston Airline Inc. said that in a move to strengthen its operations, it would return to demand scheduling, which involves keeping enough airplanes available to accommodate every passenger wanting to fly at any particular time. Since such scheduling requires more aircraft, the company will suspend service to seven stations in Florida, New Orleans and the Bahamas.

title: GARMENT MAKER RENTING FACTORY IN THE SOUTH BRONX

description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today on the constitutionality of searching students in school. Associate Justice Byron R. White's majority opinion was joined by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and by Associate Justices Lewis F. Powell Jr., William H. Rehnquist and Sandra Day O'Connor. Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun concurred in a separate opinion. Associate Justices William J. Brennan Jr., John Paul Stevens and Thurgood Marshall dissented in part.

title: News Merger Set in Canada
description: The Canadian Press, the country's largest news service, is taking over its only competitor, United Press Canada, U.P.C.'s parent company announced today. No financial terms were disclosed for the sale, which is effective Jan. 31 and was announced by Douglas Creighton, president of the Toronto Sun Publishing Corporation, the owner of United Press Canada. The Sun group, which has papers in Toronto, Edmonton and Calgary, in Alberta, and Houston, had held 80 percent of U.P.C. The remaining 20 percent had been held by United Press International, a major American news service. Mr. Creighton said U.P.C. had lost money since it was founded seven years ago.

title: Ex-Coach Testifies

title: All That Democracy Needs Help
description: Add Brazil's Tancredo Neves to the lengthening list of democratic presidents in Latin America. His choice by an electoral college yesterday will end 20 years of military rule in a bellwether country. This is marvelous news, swelling the tide toward free government throughout the hemisphere. Now President Reagan needs a strategy to keep that tide moving and to keep these vulnerable democracies afloat.

title: MUSIC: THE BASIE BAND

Mr. Basie's brilliantly minimalist piano and the subtle direction he brought to the band were so essential, the reasoning went, that without him the band, which had become a polished but predictable machine, would have no distinction.

''We tried not to present a particular viewpoint, but to find things that are different from each other,'' said Rick Kantor, who with Janet Bachant and Roy Wallace is a partner in the new store. Upholstery includes a chair, above right, ($2,450 with a sofa and love seat), platform beds (from $189), pottery ($70 to $350) as well as a fiberglass Statue of Liberty, $900. City Life, at 15 West 19th Street, is open Monday to Saturday, 10 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Sunday, noon to 5 P.M.

title: Ethnic Turks in Bulgaria Said to Fight for Names
description: Official attempts to get minority ethnic Turks to assume Bulgarian first names have led to violent disturbances in this country, diplomats said today.

title: Topics ;   More Education, Less Science ;   AphrodisiacsNonprescription nostrums cannot correct either a lack of hair or a lack of ardor, says the Food and Drug Administration, responding to Congressional interest in over-the- counter drugs. The findings are not, in any scientific sense, surprising. Claims of miraculous cures for baldness probably date back as far as baldness. And aphrodisiacs, like the legendary Spanish fly, probably have never worked any place outside the imaginations of fevered schoolboys. The F.D.A. report is unsettling nonetheless, because of its lack of science. The agency implies that, apart from a still-experimental drug made from male hormones, there are no aphrodisiacs at all, not liquor and not even perfume. It sounds as though the F.D.A. is getting too caught up in the rigor of its own research.
description: True, clinically speaking, alcohol is a depressant, not an erotic stimulant.

title: THEATER: 'THE ORESTEIA'
description: HAVING previously shown its classical mettle with Sophocles's Theban trilogy, the City Stage Company has opened its season with ''The Oresteia'' of Aeschylus, performed in repertory. Robert Fagles, the author of the translation used in the production, aptly describes the three interwoven tragedies of the House of Atreus as ''our rite of passage from savagery to civilization.'' The translation, felicitous as well as idiomatic, is the most impressive aspect of the production.

The show tells the story of Dennis (Matthew Ashford), a clean- cut young man from the Middle West, who drifts into a seedy downtown new-wave club where he meets and becomes infatuated with Joey (Roma Maffia), a defensive, disenchanted young woman who grew up on the streets of New York.

title: Nancy Reagan Aide to Quit

title: Hartman Stable
description: Jack Hartman could be back at his job as Kansas State's basketball coach in six weeks, according to his doctors. ''He's stable, he's resting comfortably, examination of his heart is quite normal,'' said Dr. Robert E. Roeder, a cardiologist who visits the 59-year-old coach daily at Stormont-Vail Regional Medical Center here, where Hartman has been hospitalized since suffering a heart attack Saturday night.

title: Change, and More Change, at Treasury First Coin Riddle: If an archeologist told you he'd found a stamped silver coin marked 699 B.C., how would you know he was fibbing? A: Because no ancient coin maker could have known that Christ would be born in seven centuries.
description: Second Coin Riddle: The United States, the most advanced country in the world, each year mints five general-purpose coins. Why is only one of them useful? Finding a sensible answer to that riddle is a task that Treasury Secretary-designate James Baker ought to take seriously.

title: No Defense
description: Sam Colson , former Clemson strength coach, will plead guilty if indicted on charges of dispensing prescription drugs to student athletes, because, his lawyer says, ''I don't have any valid defense.'' Colson is one of several people under scrutiny of the South Carolina authorities, who, along with the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation, have been looking into what was apparently a drug pipeline for athletes that developed between Vanderbilt and Clemson.

description: Volkswagenwerk A.G. said today that it was considering acquiring part of SEAT S.A., the Spanish motor company that imports cars made by Volkswagen and its subsidiary, Audi A.G.

description: A national medical society opened a major campaign today to see that adult Americans are as well protected by vaccines as their children are against a variety of diseases.

title: Report Cites Increase In Anti-Semitic Acts
description: Acts of vandalism against Jews or their institutions or property increased 6.7 percent, to 715, last year, after declining for two years, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith reported yesterday.

title: THE IMPRESSARIO OF THE INAUGURAL GALAS
description: The sign on the door of a temporary office at the Washington Convention Center says ''The Boss.'' The boss was not in today, and Joseph W. Canzeri, a fabled detail man for the rich and powerful, had taken over Frank Sinatra's office.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 17, 1985

title: 'GULAG' DRAMA ON HOME BOX OFFICE
description: cable operation, is not racking up many impressive artistic coups with its ''Premiere Films,'' those made-for-cable movies designed to supplement the primary schedule of theatrical releases. ''Draw!'' with Kirk Douglas was simply a tired Western with a foul mouth. Joseph Wambaugh's ''The Glitter Dome'' managed to be, perhaps intentionally, almost as sleazy as its cocaine-snorting, child-porno subjects. And now ''Gulag'' can't seem to make up its mind whether it is a significant political statement or a prison-break caper. It ends up being merely silly.

title: TEXAS EXECUTION IS THIRD IN THE NATION IN A WEEK
description: Doyle Skillern was put to death by lethal injection today for the murder of a narcotics agent another man says he shot. He was the fifth person executed in the United States since Dec. 25, the fourth this year and the third in a week.

title: SEEING CENTRAL AMERICA WITHOUT BLINDERS
description: As the Reagan Administration begins its second term, insiders and outsiders agree that its policy toward Central America is going nowhere. As one State Department official admitted: ''The two main alternatives - outright military intervention or a political solution - are both unacceptable, but there's no agreement on what else to do.'' In fact, the Administration has created a false dilemma for itself - as it might readily see if it could look at Central America without the blinders of ideology.

title: NEW CALEDONIA: A DIVIDED, DEADLY PARADISE
description: President Francois Mitterrand said in Paris that he was leaving for New Caledonia. Page A4.

title: SINGLE OR LIVING TOGETHER, HAVING A WILL IS IMPORTANT
description: ''MANY young adults think they will live forever, or at least until a very old age,'' said Steven L. Gittleson, a New York lawyer who has written a number of wills for younger people. ''They may think that doing a will or estate planning just doesn't apply to them.''

title: ROBERT FITZGERALD, 74, POET WHO TRANSLATED THE CLASSICS
description: Robert Fitzgerald, Emeritus Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory at Harvard, whose translations of the Greek classics became standard works for a generation of scholars and students, died yesterday at his home in Hamden, Conn. after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: Call Me a Cab. O.K., You're Two Cabs Give Mayor Koch an unusually large and shiny apple for the taxi idea he has just advanced. It's an offer the New York City taxi industry should not be permitted to refuse.
description: The Mayor wants to give every taxi owner the right to operate a second medallion taxicab, relieving the chronic taxi shortage without directly attacking the value of existing franchise rights. The ideal policy would be to abolish the medallion system altogether and let consumers decide how many taxis the city could support. But the Mayor's plan is an astute and constructive compromise.

title: FINDING HANDS TO MEND CERAMICS
description: WHEN a cherished porcelain cherub loses its wings, an antique bowl breaks or the dinnerware chips, there are specialists to do the repairs. Some will leave the imperfection virtually invisible. Some prefer, especially on ancient pieces, to leave the repair evident. When repairing such fragile ceramics as pottery and porcelain, some add extra strength with a pin or rivet in the broken piece.

title: BOOK SAYS HOWARD HUGHES TRIED TO BRIBE U.S. LEADERS, BUT AIDE CHALLENGES PROOF
description: From 1966 through 1970, Howard R. Hughes wrote hundreds of notes ordering his assistants to use his fortune to buy the services of Presidents and other prominent political figures, according to a new book that draws on the memorandums.

title: Chinese Airbus Talks
description: The Chinese Government will order five A310 commercial jets from European Airbus Industrie, a French Government official said today. While a spokesman for Airbus denied that a firm contract with the Chinese had been signed, she acknowledged that the consortium had had discussions with the Chinese authorities. A Chinese order would represent a major breakthrough for Airbus in its effort to win orders in Asia.

title: With Net Gone, Rangers Settle for a Tie
description: There were 20 seconds gone in overtime, and at the top of the circle on the right was Reijo Ruotsalainen. He shot. The puck bounced off the goalie's chest to Barry Beck, in close. He raised his stick high. Mark Pavelich was charging in to Beck's left. Beck's stick came down to shoot, and Pavelich tripped.

title: POLISH ARGENTINE DEBT PACTS
description: The United States and 16 other industrialized nations agreed today to let Poland postpone billions of dollars of debt repayments to ease the pressure on its ailing economy.

title: MARCOS FOE'S BACKERS HOPEFUL ON RETURN TO MANILA
description: Supporters of a self-exiled opposition leader predicted today that he would not be arrested or detained on longstanding subversion charges when he returns to the Philippines next Monday.

title: ITT PLANS $1.7 BILLION ASSET SALE
description: The ITT Corporation, continuing its sweeping restructuring, said yesterday that it would sell off assets worth an estimated $1.7 billion to reduce the company's huge debt and to finance its push into high technology.

title: ROCK MUSIC, OR SONGS ON THE END OF THE WORLD
description: WHILE mainstream pop music reverts to a juvenile frivolity that looks back in spirit to the late 1950's and early 60's, many of today's hits still convey very dark undercurrents. In its lyrics and in cold, mechanized dance rhythms broken by nervous electronic flurries that sound like miniature detonations, pop music is anxiously contemplating nuclear war.

title: Darden Named Conductor
description: Charles Darden has been appointed principal conductor of the Dance Theater of Harlem. Mr. Darden was the first recipient of the Martin Luther King Memorial Fellowship from the San Francisco Conservatory. He received his training at the Curtis Institute of Music and has conducted for the Ballet Rambert in London, the Oslo Philharmonic Orchestra and the Den Norske Opera in Oslo.

Quick to Plunge
description: Jens-Peter Berndt , the East German swimming champion who defected to the United States on Jan. 7 and then made a bee line to Tuscaloosa, has been formally admitted to the University of Alabama and could be competing as early as Saturday, when the Crimson Tide meets Auburn. ''I've been notified that he has passed his admission test to be enrolled,'' said Don Gambril, Alabama's swimming coach. But Gambril explained that because Berndt did not have transcripts from his East German schools, the National Collegiate Athletic Association was reviewing his test scores to determine whether he meets eligibility requirements.

Like the movie - an anthology of dance-on-film excerpts that opens in New York tomorrow - Mr. Kelly himself represents a wide range of dance over the decades.

title: 2 Disney Directors To Step Down
description: Walt Disney Productions said two of its directors, Philip M. Hawley and Robert Baldwin, would not stand for re-election at the company's annual meeting on Feb. 6. Disney made the disclosure in a proxy filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Hawley is chairman of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. and has been a member of the board since 1975. Mr. Baldwin, chairman of Morgan Stanley & Company's advisory board, joined Disney's board in 1983.

title: Cuomo Offering Bank-Insurer Bills
description: Legislation to let banks go into the insurance business - and to let insurance companies go into the banking business - was proposed today by Governor Cuomo.

title: Hottest Hand
description: When an athlete is hot, in the modern idiom, he is ''on a roll.'' Well, nobody has been on more of a roll lately than Maurice Cheeks, the Philadelphia 76ers' guard.

title: DISMAY OVER COMPANY CARS
description: The company car is no longer a free ride. Since the beginning of the year, new tax laws have severely crimped both the large deductions that companies customarily claimed for their cars and the liberal personal use employees made of them. All this has spurred a wave of grumbling by those who deplore this threat to a cherished corporate tradition.

title: Reynolds Metals Net Up
description: The Reynolds Metals Company, the nation's second-largest producer of aluminum, said today that cost-cutting efforts helped it triple its profit in the fourth quarter from a year earlier, despite declines in revenue and tonnage shipments of aluminum.

title: JOHN MCENROE GIVES $10,000 TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND

title: Saatchi Co-Founder Joins Howard-Spink
description: Just short of a year ago when Tim Bell, a co-founder with the Saatchi brothers of London's Saatchi & Saatchi agency, left for an extended vacation it was necessary for the management of the publicly held company to assure the world that he was not leaving for good.

title: U.S. Urges the Recall Of 1,600 Transit Buses
description: The Federal Government has urged the voluntary recall of more than 1,600 transit buses from about two dozen cities, including Los Angeles, Pittsburgh, Philadelphia and Atlanta, because of suspension problems that investigators say could cause drivers to lose control.

title: Aspin Is Stirring
description: Representative Les Aspin, new chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, has long said that there was no committee in Congress dealing adequately with arms control and overall United States military policy. So the Wisconsin Democrat has told some House colleagues that he may propose to the full committee the creation of a subcommmittee to deal exclusively with such matters. The new unit might be named the subcommittee on arms control or on military policy.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SILENT MOTION New York, the dance capital of the United States, never misses a step, it seems, in keeping up with its reputation. Tonight, the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, 10th Street and the Bowery (674-8112), enters its 10th season, a milestone for a group that devotes much of its time searching for what are called the new and emerging figures in choreography.

Exxon Cuts Crude Oil Price
description: Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, yesterday cut the price it will pay for the most common kind of American oil by $1 a barrel, to $28, joining the second round of reductions since October.

title: Coast Homosexuals Force Removal of Offensive Sign
description: A sign offensive to homosexuals that has hung behind the bar of the popular Barney's Beanery restaurant for a half century was taken down Tuesday, a victory for officials of the newly incorporated, predominantly homosexual community.

title: Bonn Panel Rejects Proposal To Limit Pershing 2 Training
description: The West German Parliament's defense committee rejected a proposal today to halt all military training with American Pershing 2 nuclear missiles until a reason is found for last week's fatal accident.

title: Isn't Conrail Becoming a Silk Purse? Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Dole reportedly wants to sell Conrail to the Norfolk Southern Railroad for $1.2 billion. That would be no disaster. The Government would recoup some of the $7 billion it spent to create an efficient regional freight rail system out of the wreckage of seven bankrupt carriers. The Northeast would likely continue to receive adequate rail service.
description: So why not go along with the idea? Because Conrail's current managers think they can provide better service as an independent competitor. More: given a little time, there's a good chance the railroad could be sold, to the public, for much more than $1.2 billion. They deserve a chance to try.

title: Market Place
description: BETWEEN the late summer of 1982 and the spring of 1983, chemical stocks moved in the forefront of a bull market rally. This reflected optimistic forecasts of future earnings, as well as the historical pattern of chemical issues performing well at the start of a market recovery cycle.

It looks like a fancy bistro with a decidedly un-Neapolitan decor - white, gray and pink walls, theatrical lighting, wood wainscotting, potted palms, mirrors and attractive tables. Soft rock music supplants the scratchy radio usually found in pizza parlors.

title: Skier Is Injured
description: The first practice session for a women's World Cup downhill race was canceled today after 24 of the 63 skiers had fallen on icy slopes. One of them was Diana Haight of Canada, who tore all the ligaments in her right knee. Organizers said she would not race again this season.

title: RURAL SOUTH'S RICH CULTURE IS EXPLORED IN CONCERTS
description: TO most listeners, rural music of the South means the blues and nothing but the blues. In recent decades, however, research into folklore and American music has found that the blues is only part of a rich rural culture - one that still flourishes, in isolated communities, at house parties and picnics and all sorts of local gatherings. It is a culture that embraces poetry, songs, dances and parade music - and one that New Yorkers will have a rare opportunity to sample this weekend in concerts tonight at the Alternative Museum and tomorrow at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: SCREEN: 'MARIA'S LOVERS'
description: NASTASSJA KINSKI may not perfectly embody the chaste, angelic heroine of ''Maria's Lovers,'' but she is radiant all the same. As directed by Andrei Konchalovsky, the Soviet director of ''Siberiade,'' in his first English-language feature, Miss Kinski brings an immense vibrancy to the role of a small-town girl with many suitors, including one who becomes her father-in-law, in a rambling and populous story that is eventually less than the sum of its parts. However, as photographed by Juan Ruiz Anchia, Miss Kinski is even able to make a great deal out of a sequence in which she wears a damp, diaphanous housedress and scrubs the floor.

Mr. Bellow, who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1975 for ''Humboldt's Gift'' and the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1976, will answer questions from the audience after the reading, then attend a reception. description: THE time is a mythical 1984 and the place London, the capital of that part of Oceania known as Airstrip One. Winston Smith (John Hurt) is 39, but he has the skinny, wizened look of a perpetually chilled, undernourished child, whose face is that of an old man. He lives alone in a drab one- room flat furnished with a cot, a table and a chair, all dominated by a giant television screen, which monitors him even as he is monitoring it.

That's what happened in the most recent round of Concert Artists Guild auditions when Joseph Lulloff, a saxophonist, ended up a winner.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: WHENEVER a restaurant uses that overworked term ''new American cuisine,'' I cringe, the way I do when a telephone solicitor offers me a ''prime acre'' of south Florida real estate, sight unseen, for a ''modest'' down payment. Arcadia, a delightful new place on East 62d Street, does use the term, but the restaurant's imaginative and well-conceived performance erased any skepticism on the first visit.

title: Thatcher to Visit Reagan
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain has accepted an invitation from President Reagan to meet on Feb. 20 at the White House, Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, announced today. He said the official working visit would be part of the continuing discussions between Mr. Reagan and Mrs. Thatcher, and that the talks might ''conceivably'' center on arms control issues and on the Administration's proposal for research on a spaced-based shield against nuclear weapons, a concept popularly known as ''Star Wars.''

title: A 'SERIOUS COMEDY' FESTIVAL
description: Manhattan Punch Line, which is presenting its first festival of one-act comedies starting tomorrow at the Judith Anderson Theater, is dedicated to the proposition that the future of American theater may rest in ''serious comedy.''

description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced late today rules designed to protect the public from radioactive air pollution.

title: 49ERS' PRO BOWL SECONDARY

title: FILM: 'THAT'S DANCING!', AN M-G-M ANTHOLOGY
description: THERE'S no denying the appeal of many of the film clips included in ''That's Dancing!'' - especially those depicting Busby Berkeley's wildest flights of fancy and some of Fred Astaire's finest hours. But it's equally clear that this anthology film, which opens today at Loew's Tower East and other theaters, devotes almost as much energy to back-patting as it does to footwork. Many of the performers here are the greatest. Others are the best. Some are merely sublime. And no one made musicals the way Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer did. Of all the horns being tooted here, it is M-G-M's that toots most loudly.

title: But Was Senator Hatfield Ethical?

That report, just out, will disappoint any who hoped for ethical leadership. Even the Senator, though absolved of corrupt activity, might wish for a cleaner bill of health.

title: New With Newsweek
description: Morton M. Kondracke, executive editor of The New Republic, is scheduled to become Washington bureau chief of Newsweek early next month. He will succeed Mel Elfin, who reportedly told executives of the magazine several months ago that he would like to surrender the administrative responsibilities of running the bureau. Before joining The New Republic, Mr. Kondracke, 45 years old, was a reporter for The Chicago Sun-Times in Chicago and Washington.

title: MAYORS APPEAL TO U.S. AID FOR CITIES' POOR
