title: REWARDS OF 'JEWEL IN CROWN'
description: GRANADA TV's towering production of ''The Jewel in the Crown'' reaches the sixth of its 14 episodes this weekend - Sunday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13 - and the moment is as appropriate as any for taking stock of its sumptuous rewards. As the story continues to unfold of British colonials in India in the years leading up to independence in 1947, certain strong points are obvious. It is a visually splendid production, its settings and period costumes adding up to a solid substance of their own. And it has been directed with unerring insight and sensitivity by, in alternating episodes, Christopher Morahan and Jim O'Brien.

title: I DON'T DETEST A SIESTA
description: I read with great sadness of the recent decision by China's Communist Party to end the traditional two-hour lunch break in favor of one hour. Inefficiency was to blame. Word of this development reached me in a caption under a photograph of a Chinese worker contentedly dozing during what may well have been the last of his midday constitutionals.

title: ART: ISLAMIC WEAPONS, AT THE MET MUSEUM
description: AMONG the instruments with which men can do bodily harm to other men on a one- to-one basis and at very short range, it would be difficult to rival the swords, the sabers and the daggers of the Islamic world when it comes to beauty of form and perfection of workmanship. Whether they originated in Turkey, in Persia, in Mogul India or in Moorish Spain, they are terrifying to behold. Any one of them, rightly placed and firmly thrust, would settle an argument once and for all. But so compelling are they that even the most pacific among us has been known to dream of plunging one of them, just once, six inches deep into someone we don't much care for.

ART: 6 SCULPTORS DISPLAY A RATIONAL IMPERATIVE
description: ''A RATIONAL IMPERATIVE'' is a welcome show. Its main subject is the link between the geometric and the primordial, a link that was also the focus of the contemporary art section of the recent '' 'Primitivism' in 20th-Century Art'' exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art. Each of the six sculptors whose work is on display at the Sculpture Center, 167 East 69th Street, through Jan. 29, approaches abstract geometric shapes in an analytical manner. Their aim, however, is usually to lead us to states of being that have to do not with science and reason but with irrationality and myth.

description: Motorola Inc. said it had bought a plant in Taiwan that would be used to manufacture, assemble and test electronic products, including integrated circuits.

description: The city's Corporation Counsel said yesterday that City Council President Carol Bellamy did not have the authority to declare a paid holiday for her staff next Monday to mark the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Money Supply Up $2.1 Billion
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday a $2.1 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply for the week ended Jan. 7, a smaller-than-expected rise that was the catalyst for a rally in the long-term bond market but had little effect on short-term interest rates.

title: LEADER IN MOVEMENT THAT SHELTERS ALIENS WINS A COURT ROUND
description: A Federal district judge said today that freedom of religion was a legitimate defense in the case of a leading figure in a movement to afford sanctuary in the United States to refugees from Latin America.

title: Swiss Wholesale Prices
description: Wholesale prices in Switzerland were unchanged in December from November and were up 2.9 percent from December 1983, the Government reported today.

title: POLISH COURT TOLD ABOUT KIDNAPPING
description: A friend of a pro-Solidarity priest described today how he had dived, handcuffed, to escape from a speeding unmarked police car and spread the alarm that the priest had been abducted.

title: Folk Songs
description: John McCutcheon will play the Appalachian hammer dulcimer and sing traditional and new folk songs tonight at 8 at P.S. 41, 116 West 11th Street. Tickets are $7 for adults and $4 for children and the elderly., Information about the program, which is sponsored by the Pinewoods Folk Club, can be obtained at 594-8833.

title: HOUSING STARTS ROSE LAST MONTH
description: Construction of new homes rose 2.1 percent in December from November, the Commerce Department reported today, and analysts expect further gains early this year because of falling interest rates.

title: WHERE TO GET OFF THE BEATEN TRACK
description: NEW YORK is full of discoveries waiting to be made, for those who are willing to try something new. Turn suddenly into an unfamiliar theater to see a play or dance. Catch a concert by a group with an intriguing name. Who made the painting in the window of the gallery passed by? There is much to be seen, experienced and listened to for the inquisitive and adventurous.

description: For nearly seven weeks, New Yorkers have been deprived of reruns of ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' for the first time in seven years. The reruns of the popular situation comedy, which acquired a devoted nightly following of 75,000 viewers at various times from 2 to 4:30 A.M., were taken off the air by WNBC-TV last Dec. 3.

title: Decker, in a Comeback, Breaks 2,000-Meter Mark
description: Mary Decker, competing tonight for the first time since her controversial collision with Zola Budd in the Olympics last August, ran a world-indoor best in the 2,000-meter run with a time of 5 minutes 34.52 seconds in the Sunkist Invitational indoor track and field meet at the Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena.

(She refuses to deal with the question of whether and how much to tip the ma^itre d'h^otel.) My friend puts the combined tip for the captain and the waiter right through the middle of the two lines. ''Let them fight it out,'' is her theory.

description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, said today that a second team, the New Orleans Saints, sent him a letter this week telling him that the club reserved the right to relocate under Federal court decisions in the case that enabled the Raiders to move from Oakland to Los Angeles three years ago.

description: Dan Johnson, the Miami Dolphins' starting tight end, complained of severe stomach pains today but does not appear to be suffering from appendicitis, as originally suspected, the team doctor said after studying blood tests. Johnson, who is still questionable for Sunday's game, missed the afternoon workout after complaining about the pains. Dr. Charles Virgin said a blood test taken today was inconclusive, and Johnson's condition would be closely watched.

title: TEXAN'S BID TO SAVE MUSE AIR
description: M. Lamar Muse, who has spent 36 of his 64 years in the airline business, says he would like nothing better than to call it quits, and spend the rest of his life in his condominium in Austin, Tex., and at his summer home in Vancouver, British Columbia, where he can fish for salmon.

title: FLORIO AGAIN FOCUS OF DEMOCRATS' PLANS
description: Representative James J. Florio, the Camden County Democrat who lost to Thomas H. Kean in the 1981 gubernatorial race by fewer than 1,700 votes, is again the focus of attention as Democrats begin the process of choosing a candidate this year.

title: '84 INCOME RISE BIGGEST IN 2 DECADES

title: PAUL THEODIS GIPSON
description: Paul Theodis Gipson, who rushed for more yards as a University of Houston football player than anyone else except Robert Newhouse, died Wednesday morning here on a sidewalk where he had been found unconscious. He was 38 years old, and the Harris County Medical Examiner ruled that the cause of death was a heart attack.

title: CUOMO OFFERS LEGISLATIVE PACKAGE TO EASE VOTING
description: Governor Cuomo today sent the Legislature a package of bills that he said would ''expand the opportunity for all New Yorkers to participate in the election process.''

description: Tug McGraw, the exuberant reliever who seemed at once the soul and the voice of that championship team, is 40 - too old, apparently, to fit into the club's plans. McGraw, who finished strong at the end of an injury-plagued 20th major league season last year, said he had been told that his pitching days with the Phillies were over but that he could have another job in the organization if he did not sign on with anyone else.

88 Held in Embassy Protest
description: Union and labor relations officials from Pennsylvania and Michigan were among 88 people arrested today in front of the South African Embassy in a protest against that country's racist policies, District of Columbia police said. The arrests brought to 332 the number of protesters arrested since the daily demonstrations began Nov. 21, the police said. None of those arrested have been prosecuted.

title: Feeding Ethiopia, Without Illusions
description: Americans grasp this much about Ethiopia: the horror of a famine that threatens million of lives, the brutality of a civil war in northern provinces, the cynicism of a Marxist regime that gets $2.5 billion in weapons from the Soviet Union but asks the West to meet the food bill. Now a hard new question is raised by Ethiopia's seizure of a food shipment destined for the rebel-held regions. Why do business with those who starve whom they cannot conquer?

title: JAMAICAN PROTESTS: PREMIER MAY FACE MORE TROUBLE

G. Seaga. Opponents of Mr. Seaga, confronting what they describe as the Prime Minister's intransigence and arrogance, are expected to try to put pressure on him in the form of more public protests.

title: THE OPERA: 'DREYFUS' PREMIERES
description: The orchestral world is probably poorer in important young conductors today than at any time in this century, a situation that gave special interest to the New York debut of Simon Rattle, who led the Los Angeles Philharmonic on Friday night at Carnegie Hall. Why this famine has come about while symphony orchestras themselves have been proliferating so wildly is a complex question, but there is nothing difficult to understand about Mr. Rattle's steady rise to prominence in recent seasons. The young man has played his career cards shrewdly so far and happens to be good.

title: Rome and Carthage Plan a Peace Treaty

title: CAR SAFETY: BUCKLE UP CORRECTLY
description: CAR seats and seat selts do save lives, said David B. Shinn, president of the National Child Passenger Safety Association, but only if they are used correctly. Perhaps the most vulnerable are infants and toddlers, who cannot buckle themselves up. Although all states and the District of Columbia, except Nevada, have child- restraint laws, nearly 80 percent of child-restraint seats are still used incorrectly or not used at all, Mr. Shinn said.

title: Cypriots Apparently Fail To Reach an Agreement
description: Greek and Turkish Cypriot leaders appeared tonight to have failed to reach an agreement on a draft plan for the reunification of Cyprus but are to meet again Saturday afternoon.

title: How to Protect the Technology Gap The Soviet Union relies heavily on foreign technology to improve its weapons. So every Administration struggles for ways to reduce the seepage of militarily valuable technology from West to East without crippling trade. Mr. Reagan's has insisted it will stanch what it regards as a hemorrhage, yet has little to show for four years of effort. Wrangles between the Commerce and Defense Departments were only recently resolved and Congress remains confused about how to tighten export controls. If the solution is so difficult, could the problem be less clear than it seems?
description: The argument for controlling technology is that Western weapons must be technically superior to offset the Soviet advantage in numbers. Everyone acknowledges that sooner or later the Russians can buy, steal or invent almost any technology they want. But it's well worth trying to delay their acquisition of technology so as to maintain the West's technical lead.

title: ART: 12 BY SANDRO CHIA AT THE CASTELLI GALLERY

Yet it seems a lot older,and the prices commanded by its leading exponents are immense. Which brings to mind Robert Hughes who, writing about art and money in a recent issue of New York Review of Books, referred to the prototypical ''art starlet,'' who waddles about like a ''Strasbourg goose, his ego distended to gross proportions by the obsequies of the art market.''

title: ALBANIA OPENS NEW DOORS TO ITS NEIGHBORS

title: PRAGMATIC BRAZIL CHANGES COURSE
description: BRASILIA THE political map of Latin America changed dramatically last week when Brazil, the region's largest and most populous nation, joined the growing list of ''new'' democracies south of the border by electing its first civilian President in 21 years. Yet it did so in a surprisingly undramatic way. When Argentina held elections in late 1983 and Uruguay did so a year later, both countries exploded in glee at the imminent departure of heavy- handed military regimes. Brazil, in contrast, is displaying little of the excitement that normally accompanies a country's abrupt passage from dictatorship to democracy.

title: ''A LANGUAGE OF EXILE, WITHOUT FRONTIERS''
description: When Isaac Bashevis Singer accepted the 1978 Nobel Prize in Stockholm, he told his audience, in Yiddish, which he then translated into English, ''The high honor bestowed upon me by the Swedish Academy is also a recognition of the Yiddish language - a language of exile, without a land, without frontiers, not supported by any government.'' The point is that despite its detractors, Jews and others, who relegate it to the status of ''dialect'' and ''jargon,'' Yiddish is a language, with its own grammar and vocabulary, no more a subsidiary of modern German than other languages in the Germanic family.

The fact is, neither addresses the biggest political- economic problem of our time - that of a great and growing population in less developed countries that is too poor to buy goods produced throughout the world.

description: The brass industry was thriving and the Naugatuck Valley was its capital when Jack Mayers's father went to work for American Brass in Ansonia, and he worked there all his life. But 15 years ago, when Jack went to work as a machinist at the Bridgeport Brass factory in Seymour, a few miles upriver, the industry - and the valley - had begun their decline.

title: D.E.P. GETS PLAUDITS AND DEMERITS ON ITS RECORD
description: In the 1960's, New Jersey was the first state to recognize the need to protect aquifers and to provide a Green Acres program to help local governments save and create parklands and other open spaces. It also was the first to have its own environmental agency, establishing one even before there was a Federal Environmental Protection Agency.

title: COLT .45 GOES TO THE TROPHY ROOM
description: WASHINGTON

title: ON LOCATION WITH THE CHILD STARS OF 'MISS PAT'S PATIO'
description: YOUNG Westchester residents tuning in to ''Miss Pat's Patio,'' the weekly children's cable television program, will hear a familiar refrain. ''We'll be back after these important messages,'' 5-year-old Elena Goldstein says solemnly. Viewers are in for a surprise.

title: Jordan Susan Brener Wed to Robert J. Nell
description: Jordan Susan Brener, the daughter of Mrs. Carl Ruff of New York and Amagansett, L.I., and the late Daniel A. Brener of New York, was married yesterday to Robert J. Nell, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William S. Nell of Philadelphia. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church of the Unitarian Church of All Souls in Manhattan performed the ceremony at the New York home of the bride's mother and stepfather.

title: KARPOV RUNS OUT OF STEAM IN CHESS PLAY
description: Anatoly Karpov came at Gary Kasparov with a lot of high-powered opening analysis in the 43d game of their world title chess match in Moscow on Friday, but it was all well-known stuff and the 33-year-old champion failed to get more than a draw out of it.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN COMPUTER PSYCHOLOGY
description: According to the International Data Coroporation, market researchers, nearly 12 milion personal computers, terminals, and word procesors have made it into offices across the country. And they are being cursed as often as blessed. Users complain of eye strain and mental stress. Managers question whether electronic messages are being used to the detriment of personal interaction.

title: TOWER, NEW TO ARMS TEAM, HAS WARNED OF SOVIET MIGHT
description: Former Senator John G. Tower, the Texas conservative who will head the negotiating team in the talks on strategic arms, comes to the job with a long history of concern over the Soviet military buildup.

title: Stuart Wasser to Marry Jill Abramson in Summer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Abramson of Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jill Lynn Abramson to Stuart Wasser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Wasser of Bayside, L.I. A summer wedding is planned.

title: THE STUNNING FRANCHISE EXPLOSION
description: CAROL DONOUGHE, 39, walked out on her job as a newspaper's advertising manager in late 1983, and bought a Pop-Ins maid service for $9,500.

title: SMALL RADIO STATION LEAVES THE AIR
description: LAST Monday, Jay Crawford was getting ready to announce the weather report on WNVR- AM. A commercial for a bridal show was on the air. Unexpectedly, a tape then was played that stated, ''WNVR now ends its broadcast. WNVR, Naugatuck, Waterbury.''

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION ;

HOW TO SQUEEZE BLOOD OUT OF THE TURNIP THAT SOME REFER TO AS CITY HALL
description: THE spring rut in the street in front of your house has become the fall crater that could swallow a car. The garbage truck scheduled to appear at your home on Tuesday and Friday swoops past your driveway on Monday and is never seen again. The beginning-of-the-week wisp of foul odor becomes the end-of-week toxic fumes from a backed up sewer.

title: KNICKS DEFEAT HAWKS
description: Darrell Walker's 18-foot jumper with four seconds remaining enabled the Knicks to defeat the Atlanta Hawks, 88-86, last night at the Garden and end a six-game losing streak.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Contemporary folk music may not be flourishing in New York the way it did in the early 60's when Bob Dylan held court in Greenwich Village, but it is by no means dead. Saturday at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, the Second Annual Fast Folk Music Show, hosted by Jack Hardy and Christine Lavin, will showcase some of the city's most talented young folk-pop singers and songwriters, many of whom have honed their skills in downtown songwriting workshops.

description: The Parti Quebecois, which came to power in 1976 with a vision of independence for Quebec, today set aside separatism as a goal for the foreseeable future.

description: When Southfork Ranch, the home of J. R. Ewing in the ''Dallas'' television series, was sold to a developer last summer, a news report said the big white house would be turned into a hotel with a top rate of $2,500 a night for a three-bedroom suite.

description: At the recent World Team Olympiad in Seattle, two leading Dutch bridge personalities were able to swap stories about old, bad times.

title: DELEGATION TO ALBANY DEBATES ORGANIZATION
description: THE county's representatives in Albany are facing their first major policy decision of the new legislative session: how to structure their 13-member delegation. Discussions, which have been heated, are expected to resume Tuesday, and the outcome could affect the county's ability to achieve its state legislative priorities, some of which were released late last month in a package prepared jointly by the County Executive and the Board of Legislators.

title: NEIGHBORS REPORTED HELPING SOUTH AFRICA TO CURB REBELS
description: The leader of the main exile group fighting white minority rule in South Africa acknowledges that his war effort has slowed in the last three months as a result of actions against his guerrillas by neighboring, black-governed countries.

title: IRAQ'S TANKER WAR MAY MISS THE MARK
description: When Iraq announced that it would blockade shipping at Iran's main oil-loading terminal, Kharg Island, last year, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein hoped to internationalize the conflict and halt Iran's oil shipments, forcing the Iranians to the peace table. Indeed, as Iraq began attacking tankers and Iran threatened to hit back by closing the Strait of Hormuz, which would cut off much of the oil exported to the West, Iraq's Gulf neighbors and the big foreign powers feared they would become directly involved in the stalemated war.

title: DRUG USE BELIEVED TO EXTEND BEYOND TWO SCHOOLS IN SOUTH
description: NASHVILLE

title: SECRET PAPERS FOUND IN INDIA ESPIONAGE CASE
description: An Indian magistrate said today that intelligence officials had found many incriminating documents, including photocopies of military deals and secret military information, in the homes of several Government officials and others arrested in a major espionage scandal here.

title: Army Coach Honored
description: Jim Young, who coached Army to an 8-3-1 record that included a victory over Michigan State in the first Cherry Bowl, has been named winner of the 16th annual Joseph M. Sheehan Memorial Award as coach of the year in the East from Divisions 1-A and 1-AA.

title:
OUTDOORS;

description: This action was the culmination of more than two years of investigation that began in Pennsylvania and eventually spread to the District of Columbia, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Delaware, Maine, Maryland, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina and Virginia.

title: NOTEBOOK: AWAITING THE SHARON VERDICT
description: Ariel Sharon has been reading, resting and keeping in touch with Israeli affairs as he waits in a back room of the Federal courthouse in Manhattan during jury deliberations in his libel case against Time magazine.

title: GIFTS TO NEEDIEST CITE U.S. RECOVERY
description: Despite some favorable economic indexes and forecasts, many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund feel that the optimism overlooks the plight of those who somehow fail to benefit from the reported recovery and predictions of better times ahead.

title: Toll in Peru's Guerrilla War
description: The Marxist Mayor of Peru's southeastern city of Ayacucho said today that at least 3,000 people had disappeared in the region in the four-year campaign by the Maoist Shining Path rebels to overthrow President Fernando Belaunde Terry. Mayor Leonor Zamora said at a news conference that he could document several cases in which people had disappeared after being detained by the security forces.

title: THE DIRECTOR: RUNNING THE C.I.A.
description: Joseph Lelyveld is a staff writer for this magazine.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN COMPUTER PSYCHOLOGY;

TAKING THE STRESS OUT OF TRAINING
description: ''WHEN people are introduced to computers, many of them experience the same alienation that people who move to foreign countries do,'' said Sara Kiesler, a professor of social psychology at Carnegie-Mellon University. And like many foreign visitors, she said, computer neophytes are put at ease when they run into people from their own backgrounds.

title: Occupied Co-ops
description: To the Editor:

title: LEBANON SAYS TALKS ON AN ISRAELI PULLOUT ARE TO BE RESUMED
description: Prime Minister Rashid Karami said today that Lebanese and Israeli negotiators would resume their suspended talks next week on ''the program and timetable for an Israeli withdrawal'' from southern Lebanon.

title: Miss Latchford, Nurse, Is Married to a Lawyer
description: At St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan yesterday, Joanne Eugenie Latchford, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Latchford of New York, was married to James Kevin O'Neill, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. O'Neill of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Paul McKeever performed the ceremony.

title: INSIDE THE THINKING ANIMAL
description: BRAIN AND PSYCHE

title: A GLIMPSE INSIDE POLAND'S MINISTRY OF FEAR
description: For ordinary Poles, the most amazing revelations in the public murder trial here of four secret policemen deal less with the crime than with the day-to-day life and thinking of the police.

title: ISRAEL'S DILEMMA/LIVING WITH A DIRTY WAR
description: AVRAHAM BURG, A YOUNG ISRAELI PEACE activist and the son of Yosef Burg, Israel's Religious Affairs Minister, was trying to explain recently what the last two-and-a-half years of Israeli involvement in Lebanon have done to his country. He tried several images until he finally hit upon what he thought was the appropriate one. ''Jaundice,'' he said. ''In the old days when there was a plague of jaundice, the very religious had their own healing system. They would come to the hospital and bring pigeons with them. Then they would place the healthy pigeon on the sick person's stomach right over the liver. After a couple of seconds, according to the story, the pigeon would turn yellow with jaundice and the patient would become healthy.''

title: Cycling Coach Bitter
description: Eddy Borysewicz, the coach of the United States cycling team, says it was wrong of the United States Cycling Federation to suspend him for 30 days because of his involvement in a blood-doping scheme at the Summer Olympics. ''I don't agree with the decision,'' said Borysewicz, asserting that he did not ''feel guilty.''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

ARTS BRUNCHES
description: Brunch customers at Corniche can now support the arts while eating their omelets and pasta with prosciutto. Throughout the year, the restaurant, La Reserve in White Plains, will be donating some of the proceeds from each Sunday brunch to a variety of arts organizations and institutions countywide.

title: ATLAS TRACES HISTORY OF LOCAL PROPERTY
description: THE first thing a person asks when looking through one of Frances Lee's atlases is, ''Where's my house?'' If the house dates to the Revolution, it probably appears in one of the earlier pages, but even if it doesn't, the searcher can learn something about how a neighborhood has changed and grown since earlier times.

title: IN CALEDONIA, INDEPENDENCE CUTS AT LEAST TWO WAYS
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France may have had a sense of repeated history during his encounter last week with the political antagonisms that have prevailed for three months on this Pacific island territory. Mr. Mitterrand, after all, was the minister directly in charge of Algeria when the revolution erupted there in 1954.

title: 14 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 14 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: MYSTERY OF COSMIC RAY ORIGIN MAY BE SOLVED
description: Astronomers believe they have discovered several sources of cosmic rays, the penetrating radiation that bombards the Earth from all directions. The origin of these high-energy particles has been one of the most profound mysteries of the universe.

description: R. W. APPLE Jr. is chief of the London bureau of The New York Times.

title: Splurging Youngsters: A Case of Values

No, we don't all go to Acapulco for the winter holidays, nor do all our kids sport Benetton sweatshirts.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The photographs of Ralston Crawford on view at the Robert Miller Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, through Feb. 2, strongly suggest the spare, stripped-down, semi-abstract paintings of the American industrial landscape for which he is best known. The subjects are the same - machines, buildings, ships and so on - and though the textures and details are photographic, Crawford frames and lights these pictures to achieve the same stark, geometric compositions.

title: Dr. Elisabeth Morris to Wed
description: Dr. Elisabeth Ann Morris and Stephen Cavanaugh plan to be married in May, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Charles Morris of Stamford, Conn., have announced. Dr. Morris graduated from Brown University, as did her fiance, and from the Tufts University School of Veterinary Medicine. Mr. Cavanaugh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Cavanaugh of Cohasset, Mass., is an alumnus of the Salisbury School.

The concert is the third performance of a seven-concert tour of the United States that Badura-Skoda will play with the ensemble,which is conducted by Mark Mostovoy, its founder and music director. For Ticket information call 247-7800.

title: SELECTIVE GUIDE TO POSH LONDON
description: Sydney Smith, the early 19th-century wit and divine, said that the parallelogram formed by Oxford Street, Piccadilly, Regent Street and Park Lane ''enclosed more intelligence and ability, to say nothing of wealth and beauty, than the world has ever collected into such a space before.'' That would be harder to maintain of the Mayfair of today. The wealth and beauty has fled to Belgravia or Chelsea or obscure tax havens in the West Indies. The intelligence and ability, or such of it as has remained in London, is probably in Hampstead or Islington. Many of the buildings familiar to Smith have gone, too, thanks to speculators and the Luftwaffe.

PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;

A SHOW THAT REVEALS AN ARTIST AT THE HEIGHT OF HIS POWERS

But it is in parts a very angry show, attacking the President of the United States and some of his supporters in ways that are bound to give offense even to some who may, in a general way, share Michals's views.

description: ''Freud,'' a carefully researched five-part biography of the father of psychoanalysis produced for the British Broadcasting Corporation by John Purdie, gets underway this Wednesday evening at 9 on cable TV's Arts & Entertainment network. The occasion is auspicious for two reasons: The production is intelligent and demanding, a combination somewhat rare but always welcome on the television schedule. And the presentation, I believe, marks a palpable turning point in the development of the A&E network as a significant entity in quality programming.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Doublas Boyd, who made his New York debut Tuesday night at the 92nd Street Y, is one of the finest young oboists it has been this reviewer's plesaure to hear. Mr. Boyd, the principal oboist and co-founder of the Chamber Orchestra of Europe, grew up in Scotland and stuided at the Royal Academy of Music in London. He won the first prize for wind instruments at the 1980 International Young Artists Competition and has recorded Bach and Mozart concerts with Alexander Schneider and the Chamber Orchestra of Europe.

title: Lisa Diserio Betrothed
description: Lisa Michelle Diserio, the manager of special events for CBS Sports, and Mark Stuart Wolff, an associate producer for CBS Sports, plan to be married May 11. Mr. and Mrs. Eugene A. Diserio of New Canaan, Conn., and Vero Beach, Fla., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry M. Wolff of Tarzana, Calif.

title: INAUGURATION FOG

title: AT THE SPAS: SHEDDING HOLIDAY EXCESSES
description: To some, January is the quietest month. Others might even say it's boring. The social schedule screeches to a halt as people hunker down after the holidays, and the weather is usually miserable. It's a time for contemplating navels, novels and new beginnings.

title: Article 228561 -- No Title
description: The cleanup of dioxin-contaminated sites in the Ironbound section here will get into full swing next week, but the thousands of cubic yards of dirt and the tons of scrap metal to be removed will not be going far, according to the state official in charge of the project.

title: RIGHTS CONFERENCE HEARS BLACK POET
description: SECAUCUS ''THE mood is convivial, but the occasion is meant to reaffirm our serious commitment on vital issues,'' said Dr. James P. Connerton, executive director of the New Jersey Education Association, in describing the group's 11th annual Human- Rights Conference here last weekend.

title: FORDHAM DEFEATS MANHATTAN, 73-67
description: George Jones, a reserve guard inserted into the lineup after Tony McIntosh fouled out, scored 7 points in the final 1 minute 17 seconds of overtime to lead Fordham to a 73-67 victory over Manhattan College in a Metro Atlantic Conference game yesterday afternoon at Draddy Gymnasium in Riverdale.

title: LAURELS ARE BESTOWED ON TOP AUDIO EQUIPMENT
description: They don't hand out Oscars or Emmys in audio, but the nearest thing to it is the special Grand Prix award bestowed each year on outstanding stereo equipment by Audio Video International, a leading trade publication. Ballots are cast mostly by audio dealers, who are in some ways the toughest critics because they have to sell their customers on the merits of a product. The awards - all glory and no cash - carry considerable prestige, and this department was pleased to find that several recent winners had already been singled out in this column for special commendation at an earlier date.

title: Louisa Hasen, J. E. Mattson Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. George M. Hasen of New York and Greensboro, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Louisa Bronson Hasen, to John Edward Mattson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Tauno W. Mattson of Lunenburg, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: JERSEY CITY REJECTS BATTERY FERRY PLAN
description: To the Editor:

title: 6-1 SHOT, 9-5 PICK WINNERS ON TURF
description: Although rich year-round purses and winterized dirt tracks in the Northeast have kept some top stables from heading south as they once did, no one has figured out a way to race horses over frozen grass, so Florida still attracts the best turf horses from around the country for the Gulfstream and Hialeah meetings.

title: DYSON RESIGNS AS POWER AUTHORITY CHAIRMAN
description: John S. Dyson, who devised the ''I Love New York'' campaign and held several posts in the last two Democratic state administrations, has resigned as chairman of the State Power Authority.

title: A CRITICAL LOOK AT BUSINESS SPREADSHEET SOFTWARE
description: -computer fever in business a few years ago was not the machines themselves, with all their heralded but unfulfilled promises. Rather, it was the first spreadsheet program, VisiCalc. Basically a computerized accountant's worksheet that allowed one effortlessly to ask the ''What if'' questions of financial planning, VisiCalc became an instant hit with anyone involved in number crunching. The reason was simple. You did the thinking and the computer did the drudging.

title: Barbara B. Brink Weds J. B. Gulley
description: The marriage of Barbara Breed Brink, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Brink of Kansas City, Mo., and J. Bartlett Gulley took place yesterday at St. Philip's Episcopal Church in Garrison, N.Y. The Rev. William S. Reisman performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph G. Gulley of New York.

title: Camacho Returns And Pounds Burke
description: Hector (Macho) Camacho, who would like the world to believe he is a sheep in wolf's clothing, returned to the ring today like a tiger in leopard-skin trunks - with matching shoes - and stomped a rugged snake collector named Louie Burke in five rounds.

description: The steady stream of Bach recordings may well reach torrential proportions in 1985. The tricentennial of his birth is just around the corner, March 21, to be exact. Even at this early date there are many new recordings, only two of which (decidedly lesser in substance) are tied to the anniversary.

title: ANOTHER OPENING, ANOTHER SHOW
description: REVIEW NIGHT, WHICH will be held this Friday, at the Winter Antiques Show is not so very different from an opening night on Broadway. Crowds flock outside the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue and 67th Street. There is an air of anticipation, an aura of excitement. Some people come simply to be seen, since the preview party has long been considered one of New York's liveliest charities. Others are serious collectors from all over the world whose mission is to inspect the contents of the booths that have been assembled as theatrically as set designs.

title: ACTOR'S CASE REFLECTS BRITISH DRUG CRACKDOWN

description: The Compagnie Jo Lechay is the latest dance troupe from Montreal to testify to the fervent if uneven level of dance activity in that city. Miss Lechay, whose company performs this afternoon at Riverside Church, is actually an American, and her artistic roots seem firmly planted on this side of the border.

title: BIBLICAL NAME AND JAPANESE FOOD
description: AS Japanese restaurants go, Naomi in Great Neck is somewhat unusual. First, the name, according to the owners, is that of the Old Testament figure, which they selected because they felt the people of Great Neck would appreciate it. They added that since the pronunciation and the meaning of the name is the same in Japanese as in English, it would also be easier.

The owners would be required to use the medallions to place new taxis in service or sell them to someone who would.

title: DON'T EXPECT TAX REFORM
description: The Administration's new tax plan is causing a stir, with good reason. Its approximation of flat taxes, with progression retained; its abandonment of most interest deductions; the end of accelerated depreciation; and the near destruction of charitable deductions - all make it one of the most radical reform programs in recent memory. What is one to make of a proposal that will mobilize so many millions of people against it? After all, when its provisions are considered piece by piece, it makes changes that stick in the throats of almost everybody.

title: HUMANA'S BET ON INNOVATION
description: WHEN Humana's chairman, David A. Jones, and its president, H. Wendell Cherry, were interviewed recently in Louisville, Ky., about William Schroeder's heart transplant, they were photographed in front of Humana's striking new post-Modern headquarters building, now under construction. Even before being finished, the building has started to represent the company.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

THREE COINS PROPOSED FOR THE STATUE OF LIBERTY
description: The House of Representatives is considering legislation to authorize the issuance of three coins to commemorate the centennial of the Statue of Liberty. The coins - one gold, one silver and the other copper- nickel - would be sold to the public at a premium. Part of the proceeds would help finance restoration of the statue and Ellis Island.

title: Jamboree Stays in Virginia

Hill, Va., was contaminated by dioxin and that the 1985 Jamboree was still scheduled for the Army post. Scouting officials, including Dr. Walter Menninger of the Menninger Foundation in Topeka, Kan., said no dioxin, which is known to cause cancer in laboratory animals, was found at levels above those considered safe.

title: CARING ON COUPLE-TO-COUPLE BASIS
description: WARREN and Joyce (not their real names) had what most middle-aged couples in America aspire to - good jobs, a rapidly appreciating home in an affluent community and teen-age children who were on the whole pretty decent kids. They could afford three vacations a year and opera tickets when they felt like it. Married for 22 years, they seemed to be a very happy couple.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Basketball

title: STATISTICS SHOW RECOVERY IS BACK
description: After a four-month absence, the economic recovery reasserted itself strongly in the statistics. Housing starts showed a 2.1 percent gain in December, rounding out a year that was the best since 1979. Industrial production was up six-tenths of a percent, the biggest increase in five months; capacity use was up three-tenths of a percentage point, to 81.9 percent; and personal income rose five-tenths of a percent. And data from November showed a sharp, 1.1 percent rise in sales of manufactured goods.

title: HOW ONE ACTOR MOVES BETWEEN POLAR OPPOSITES
description: Self-effacing to the point of disappearance, Derek Jacobi likes to down-play the difficulty of performing two plays, two utterly contrary roles, in the space of a single day. ''It's a knack you acquire, doing repertory theater,'' he says simply. Having just completed a dazzling three-and-a-half-month run on Broadway, Mr. Jacobi and the Royal Shakespeare Company will this week begin a month-long engagement at the Kennedy Center in Washington. There, as in New York, matinee days can be pretty daunting: at 5:30, Mr. Jacobi walks off the stage, as Cyrano de Bergerac, Edmond Rostand's swaggering, swashbuckling hero. Two hours later, showered and recostumed - Cyrano's huge, latex nose, discreetly removed - he returns to the stage, reincarnated as Benedick, Shakespeare's reluctant lover in ''Much Ado About Nothing.''

title: TAKING PERMANENT CARE
description: Along with the shampoo and cut, the permanent wave has become a standard part of hair care for women. Depending on how it is used, a permanent can give hair just the boost it needs to look buoyant, or it can create lasting waves and curls where none existed before. But despite the permanents' widespread use, they are not treatments to be taken lightly.Perming the hair is a chemically violent process. It alters hair chemistry and, if not used carefully, can visibly damage hair, weaken it, and cause it to look drab, brittle and unhealthy.

Negley Farson left New York for a job in Manchester, England, a stint in the Royal Flying Corps, truck selling in Chicago, roughing it on Vancouver Island and reporting from Ireland, Egypt, Russia and India. ''The Way of a Transgressor'' delighted our reviewer, R. L. Duffus, in 1936. ''The first thing to say about this autobiography,'' he wrote, is that its many pages ''are not a page too much.''

title: THE ART OF PETER NICHOLS: COMEDIES OF DESPERATION
description: ''Every cloud has a jet black lining,'' says Bri, the protagonist of Peter Nichols's ''Joe Egg,'' and the line echoes throughout the author's body of work. In ''The National Health,'' an injured motorcyclist, released from the hospital, suffers another accident and becomes a basket case, just as in ''Joe Egg'' a married couple have a brain-damaged daughter who is as responsive as a vegetable. No matter how tragic the situation, the plays are essentially comic. Nichols writes comedies of desperation. The emphasis is not on despair but on the lengths people have to go in order to maintain their sanity.

description: South Africa, saying the time is ''not opportune,'' denied the Rev. Jesse Jackson a visa today to visit next month.

title: LETTER CARRIER BACK ON JOB
description: -Frank DePlanche, a letter carrier who was suspended for giving unstamped Christmas cards to people on his route, is back on the job. He had been told Dec 22 he would be dismissed this month. But members of Congress complained to Postmaster General William Bolger and postal officials decided Tuesday to reinstate the carrier, who had been on the job 29 years. but he had to pay $70.20 in postage.

title: MUSIC: SIMON RATTLE MAKES NEW YORK DEBUT
description: The orchestral world is probably poorer in important young conductors today than at any time in this century, a situation that gave special interest to the New York debut of Simon Rattle, who led the Los Angeles Philharmonic on Friday night at Carnegie Hall. Why this famine has come about while symphony orchestras themselves have been proliferating so wildly is a complex question, but there is nothing difficult to understand about Mr. Rattle's steady rise to prominence in recent seasons. The young man has played his career cards shrewdly so far and happens to be good.

title: Bolivian Workers Free 200 Hostages
description: Workers at 34 factories freed about 200 executives and technicians today who had been held hostage for three days, but kept to their demand for pay raises and went ahead with a nationwide general strike.

title: FRAUD IN DRY-WALL BUSINESS ALLEGED IN INDICTMENTS OF 10
description: A construction company based in Brooklyn, nine of its officials and supervisors, and an official of the carpenters' union have been charged with scheming to defraud the Government and the union's benefit funds of a total of more than $1.2 million.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article in The Times Magazine today analyzes Israeli involvement in Lebanon. On page 32 it discusses the division in Israel's unity coalition Cabinet on how, or whether, to withdraw Israeli troops. The magazine went to press before the Cabinet - still divided - voted on Monday to withdraw in stages over six to nine months.

title: Reagan Aide Finishes Latin American Tour
description: Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's national security adviser, traveled to five Latin American countries this week to outline the Administration's future policies in the region, the White House said tonight.

title: Rose-Red Petra
description: To the Editor: My husband and I were delighted to see Petra, the ''Red City'' of Jordan, get front-page cover

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: CROWN HEIGHTS
description: CROWN HEIGHTS is being rediscovered. Regarded for years as a dangerous ghetto, the central Brooklyn neighborhood now attracts many newcomers in search of affordable housing near the more prosperous Park Slope.

title: Sunrise Side of the Gulf of Siam
description: Business visitors and tourists based in Bangkok looking for a cool and quiet weekend out of the busy city now have a welcome alternative to the overdeveloped, increasingly unpleasant (for its aggressive sex industry) resort town of Pattaya on the Gulf of Siam.

title: UNEXPECTED EXPOSURE
description: A close glance at this year's spring collection by designers at home and abroad reveals that some standard wear has been given zany cutouts, exposing the body in surprising ways.

title: PASSION FOR PRINTS IS PROFITABLE
description: THE June I Gallery in Bethlehem draws print collectors from all over the country, but only by appointment. It could scarcely be otherwise, given the schedule of the gallery's proprietors, Norman and June Kraeft, who have just produced their second book, ''Great American Prints 1900-1950'' (Dover, $9.95, softcover).

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

COUNTY ATLAS
description: The County Chamber of Commerce has put Westchester on the map. Or, to be more cartographically correct, on 62 maps published in the first edition of its Westchester County Atlas. The 150-page spiral-bound booklet, which was released late last year, contains individual street-indexed maps for all county communities, as well as for Westchester's Federal, state and interstate routes, railroad lines, parks and ZIP code areas. The atlas also provides information on county historic sites, meeting and lodging facilities, colleges and universities, and hospitals.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ''Dance Black America,'' a film by Chris Hegedus and D. A. Pennebaker that will air on Friday at 9 P.M. on the ''Great Performances Series'' on channels 13 and 49, may be one of the most exuberant and touching dance programs ever to be seen on television. It takes the viewer through the Dance Black America festival presented by the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the State University of New York at the Academy in April 1983. Just about everyone who performed in that ambitious, joyous festival is included, in a flowing 90 minutes that reproduces to a shout the vibrant atmosphere of that occasion.

title: CAMPUSES COME ALIVE WITH CONCERTS
description: CAMPUS life is bustling again after the holiday layoff, and that is good news for the Connecticut music lover, since there are a lot of fascinating concerts being offered at bargain rates, if not free.

title: Trustees at Princeton Vote to Increase Fees
description: The trustees of Princeton University today approved a 7.25 percent increase in tuition and fees for the 1985-86 academic year, the university president, William G. Bowen, announced.

title: Drug-Smuggling Figure Released From Prison
description: The reputed leader of the ''French Connection'' ring that smuggled huge amounts of heroin into the United States from 1968 to 1971 was released from Federal prison Friday.

title: NETS FALL TO PISTONS, 109-107
description: Bill Laimbeer was in the wrong place, but for him and his Detroit Piston teammates, it was the right time.

title: Susanne Meyer To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Susanne Hendrickson Meyer to Jon Thornton Dayton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Dayton of Lexington, Mass., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Jan H. H. Meyer 3d of Riverside, Conn., and Bridgehampton, L.I., parents of the future bride.

title: Session on Cyprus Adjourns; Another Meeting Scheduled
description: The United Nations-sponsored Cyprus peace talks were adjourned after a four-hour session today and the principals agreed to meet Sunday morning in what the Turkish Cypriot leader, Rauf Denktash, called ''a last attempt'' to reach agreement.

title: U.S. CLINIC BOMBINGS INQUIRY NOW PLEASING MORE GROUPS
description: Leaders of several groups concerned about the bombings of abortion clinics around the country say they are now satisfied with the efforts of the Federal law-enforcement authorities.

title: Duke Trounces North Carolina
description: Rebounding from consecutive overtime losses, Duke ended an 18-year losing streak in North Carolina's Carmichael Auditorium and re-entered the Atlantic Coast Conference race with a 93-77 victory this afternoon.

title: DISPUTE SNAGS MEALS PROJECT FOR THE ELDERLY
description: ARTHUR BAUER, blind since childhood, was caning chairs in the back of his Fort Salonga home while he waited for the knock on his door that comes every weekday about noon. Right on schedule one Monday, Marilyn Hopkin and Dorothy Mandel, volunteers for Meals on Wheels of Huntington, began moving with familiarity around Mr. Bauer's antiquated kitchen.

title: HOW MANY WILL SHARE NEW YORK'S PROSPERITY?
description: FOR

title: Meg
description: Margaret Suber Price and Michael S. Bruno Jr. plan to be married in April. The future bride is the daughter of Mrs. Raymond Price Jr. of Stroudsburg, Pa., who has announced her engagement, and the late Mr. Price.

title: THE BATTLE OF THE BULGE
description: For one who was a 19-year- old Pfc. at the time, Drew Middleton's article brought back a flood of memories. The 11th Armored Division was an untried division rushed from Cherbourg on Dec. 16 to defensive positions on the Meuse River.

title: MITTERRAND ENDS VISIT TO NEW CALEDONIA
description: President Francois Mitterrand left this French territory in the South Pacific after a 12-hour visit today. There was little sign that his talks with groups for and against independence had narrowed the differences between them.

title: A Rolls-Royce Is Still a Car
description: one that is widely shared - a

title: DANCE AT MONTCLAIR STATE
description: MONTCLAIR THE dance program at Montclair State College is among the most innovative and diverse in the state, and the 1985 season will open Friday with Jennifer Muller and the Works peforming original modern pieces.

title: LOUIS A. ABRAMSON
description: Louis Allen Abramson, whose career as an architect spanned seven decades, died Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. He was 98 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Harris Beats Brown
description: He went through a nine-year National Football League career without a disabling injury, but

title: Iraqi Planes Said to Raid 'Naval Target' in Gulf
description: Iraqi jet fighters ''scored a direct hit on a large naval target'' near Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal today and returned safely to base, an Iraqi military spokesman announced in a communique read over the state television.

title: SCHOOL AID: CASE REMAINS UNRESOLVED
description: HARTFORD NEARLY 11 years after it began, litigation over the way Connecticut finances its public schools reached another milestone last week, although the battle is far from over.

title: Connecticut Upsets Syracuse by 70-68
description: Earl Kelley, a guard who had not scored for 16 minutes 37 seconds of the second half, erupted for three field goals and six free throws in the final 3:23 to help Connecticut upset highly ranked Syracuse, 70-68, in a Big East Conference game tonight.

title: FEW TAP METHANE SOURCE
description: -based Public Service Electric and Gas Company, has taken advantage of the potentially profitable use of the 300 or so landfills that have been voluntarily closed or ordered shut in New Jersey since the late 1970's.

title: A MASTER'S MARK ON POLITICS
description: WASHINGTON RONALD WILSON REAGAN is to formally begin his second term as President today at a private swearing-in ceremony in the White House. Tomorrow, Mr. Reagan is to be the star of a nationally televised ceremony in which he will swear the oath again, deliver a speech sounding his hallmark themes, and then review the inaugural parade as it passes before the White House. The theater of the display is somehow emblematic. When Mr. Reagan entered politics, his show business background was counted among his greatest liabilities. But in four years, he has demonstrated, more successfully than any President since Franklin D. Roosevelt, the potency of the symbolic and ceremonial aspects of the nation's highest office.

title: HOW WE TRIED TO BE GOOD
description: Israel Rosenfield is the author of ''Freud: Character and Consciousness'' and, with Edward Ziff, of ''DNA for Beginners.'' His ''Brain for Beginners'' will be published this spring. THE SIMPLE LIFE

title: MUSEUM PRESERVES 'DINOSAUR' COMPUTERS
description: In the gallery the children come and go, talking of fractals.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;

 FOOTBALL ALTERNATIVES
description: If, indeed, there are folks around who couldn't care less about who wins the Super Bowl and by how many points, there are some alternatives on tap today, especially on the free library concert circuit. For example, pop music enthusiasts might want to catch ''Hooray for Hollywood,'' the film musical montage that Rhonda Kay, soprano, and Milton Kraus, pianist, offer at 2 P.M. at the Elmont Public Library, 1735 Hempstead Turnpike. Or lovers of dance can take in ''Dance Around the World,'' a performance by the Allegra Danse Artists at 2:30 P.M. at the Haborfields Public Library, 31 Broadway in Greenlawn.

title: CAMERA CAPTURES OLD SUFFOLK
description: IN one scene in ''Suffolk County,

title: Bradford Utz to Marry Elizabeth P. Hoffmann
description: Mr. and Mrs. William J. Hoffmann Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Patricia Hoffmann, to Bradford Bradley Utz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore N. Utz Jr. of Savannah, Ga., formerly of Larchmont. A June wedding is planned.

title: RECORDINGS ;   LAURIE ANDERSON UNFURLS A POP OPERA ABOUT AMERICA
description: ''United States Live'' (Warner Bros. 25192-1), the five-disk aural record of Laurie Anderson's celebrated multimedia collage, turns out to be a complete work of art in itself - a structurally cohesive pop opera about the American experience, constructed of interwoven stories, songs and spoken pop poetry. Along with the illustrated texts for ''United States,'' published by Harper & Row, the album completes the documentation of this epic performance art work. But the record, it should be emphasized, is artistically self-sufficient.

title: U.S. CITIES SEEKING FOREIGN INVESTING
description: Mayors of the nation's larger cities have opened ambitious campaigns to lure foreign investors in an effort to offset their domestic economic woes.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

SEND ME MORE CARDS
description: A COUPLE of years back, I had reached a state of ennui where sending greeting cards was concerned. Perhaps it was due to the state of the economy, and the assertion of friends that they were also cutting down their card-sending. Or I could have thought I was saving time, not having to shop for and address these harbingers of significant and happy events. But the satisfaction of telling my spouse and friends that my lists were now carefully depleted, first down to a half of the previous amount, then roughly down to a third, was quickly dissipated the following year.

title:
DINING OUT;

ITALIAN FARE NORTH OF THE BORDER
description: JUST across the New York State line is Piermont, a time-forgotten village hugging the banks of the Hudson River that made the news when Woody Allen used it as the setting for his coming film ''The Purple Rose of Cairo.'' For the movie, the building facades of Piermont's main street were returned to their Depression-era appearance.

title: WHERE ANCIENT INDIANS PLAYED
description: MORTON N. COHEN is a writer who spends part of the year in Puerto Rico.

title: Frank Johnson to Wed Susan Galbraith in July
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Matthew W. Galbraith of Barrington, R.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Susan H. Galbraith, to Frank M. Johnson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Johnson of Bronxville, N.Y. The wedding is to take place in July.

title: DESPITE A CRACKDOWN, 7 GUATEMALANS ARE SMUGGLED INTO U.S.
description: Despite a crackdown by the Government, church workers here have resumed transporting aliens from Central America into this country.

title: Cowboy Is Arrested
description: Ron Springs, the Cowboys running back, was a free man yesterday after posting a $5,000 bond to gain release from the Dallas County jail. He had been held there since Friday night when he was arrested at a topless bar and accused of harassing the dancers, refusing to leave and assaulting the police officers called to eject him.

title: The President and the Experts
description: The man who raises his hand today to be sworn in again as President has defied many odds. He has defied age, an assassin's bullets and the vicissitudes of office to win a second term by an unprecedented margin, drawn from almost all slices of the electorate. And he has prepared for the term ahead the same way he conducted the one just completed: by confidently defying the experts.

title: CO-OPS FOR CARROLL GARDENS In the heart of the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn, a neighborhood distinguished by its graceful brownstones with deep front yards, a local developer is building two new cooperative residences, one of which will also have medical office space.
description: At the intersection of Third Place and Court Streets, work is nearly completed on the first of two apartment buildings, which will include eight residential cooperative apartments and one unit to be sold as a medical cooperative.

title: Breeding Squirrels
description: After an absence of a half century, Delmarva fox squirrels returned to Delaware last fall with tiny radio transmitters around their necks.

title: 3 Men Charged in Bombings Of Seven Abortion Facilities
description: Three men were arrested this evening and charged with planting bombs at seven abortion clinics in Maryland, Virginia and Washington, the Federal authorities said.

title: THE WORLD;
description: U.S. BoycottsWorld Court

title: SUDANESE 7 1/2-FOOTER PLAYS IN BRIDGEPORT
description: AMONG the Big Men on Campus at the University of Bridgeport this school year, Manute Bol is far and away the biggest. Indeed, at 7 feet, 6 inches, Mr. Bol may be the the biggest man on any American campus.

title: Far Rockaway
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSTON OVERTURNS RIGHTS FOR HOMOSEXUALS
description: Houston voters today overwhelmingly rejected extending protections against job discrimination to homosexuals.

title:
ANTIQUES;

UTENSILS FROM A FARMHOUSE
description: THE East Granby Historical Society was organized just eight years ago, but almost immediately began to make a name for itself as the sponsor of an annual country antiques show. Next weekend, 63 dealers from Connecticut and Massachusetts, along with colleagues from New Hampshire, Vermont, Rhode Island and New York, will stage this year's sale at the Carl Allgrove School, Route 20 in East Granby.

title: 50,000 SAMPLE GUSTATORY TRIBUTE TO PRESIDENT
description: The throngs of people gathering here to celebrate the inauguration of President Reagan are tasting not only the fruits of victory but also some of America's best cuisine.

title: Verbatim: Black Balance Sheet
description: 'While our report paints a grim picture of the state of black America, today I want to stress the hopeful side of the picture. For there were signs in 1984 of a new spirit in America that refuses to accept the prospect of a nation divided between a prosperous majority and an impoverished minority.

title: DEGAS, FAURE, AND FRENCH ROMANTICISM
description: Edgar Degas (1834-1917) and Gabriel Faure (1845- 1924) were contemporaries in France and while there was no close association between the painter and the composer, they inhabited a world which is being recalled in both New York and Washington. This French connection came to mind recently during the New York City Ballet's exceptionally fine performances of two ballets that George Balanchine set to Faure's music and during a visit to a thought- provoking exhibition at Washington's National Gallery of Art (through March 10), entitled ''Degas: The Dancers.''

title: ON THE LITERARY ROAD: AMERICAN WRITERS IN CHINA
description: One midautumn evening last year, eight American writers checked into a Peking hotel called the Bamboo Gardens, in a part of the capital where Manchu princes once had their palaces. The Bamboo Gardens is, in fact, a luxurious courtyard establishment that belonged to a Ching Dynasty noble family until the coming of the Chinese Revolution in 1949. After the People's Republic was established, it became the residence of Kang Sheng, notorious chief of the secret police.

title: TO KEEP ELECTIONS HONEST, A FORMER POLITICIAN STEPS IN
description: AT the age of 65, Murray Schwartz of Roslyn couldn't be faulted if he chose to take life easy and look back on his accomplishments. After all, he has been a successful businessman with interests in oil, travel, insurance, real estate and mail-order sales. In addition, he served as a Democratic State Senator from Queens from 1965 to 1972. And, from 1974 to 1976, during the Beame administration, he was New York City's Commissioner of Commerce and Industry.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

ON 'LON GISLAND,' WHERE DREAMS (THEY SAID) COME TRUE
description: OTHER children's idea of paradise was Oz or maybe Wonderland; mine was Long Island. Or, more specifically, ''Lon Gisland,'' as it was pronounced in postwar Brooklyn.

title: Judith A. Shindul, Nurse, to Be Wed To a Psychiatrist
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold John Shindul of Sherborn, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Anne Shindul, to Dr. Anthony Joseph Rothschild, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Leo Rothschild of Roslyn, L.I. The wedding is to be May 19.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: HIDDEN in recently approved legislation empowering the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to build a stadium for baseball was permission to construct aquariums. The site for one of them may be Liberty State Park on the Jersey City waterfront.

title: ABORTION CLINICS REPORT ANXIETIES
description: Although bomb threats have become almost routine for those who work in abortion clinics, there was a heightened sense of anxiety this weekend with the approaching Presidential inauguration and the 12th anniversary of the Supreme Court decision making abortion legal.

title: ;    International
description: -control positions by President Reagan and his new team of negotiators will be made Tuesday morning in the first major meeting of Mr. Reagan's new term, a White House official said. The meeting is meant to dramatize Mr. Reagan's commitment to making progress in arms-control negotiations during his second term, the official said. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: HAIL TO THE CHIEF!
description: WASHINGTON

title: Even Broadcasters Need a Game Plan
description: For the last 15 years, ABC has been televising National Football League games on Monday nights and occasionally on other nights, but it has never televised a Super Bowl. That shutout will end Sunday when ABC televises Super Bowl XIX over 211 stations to an audience it estimates at more than 100 million in the United States and millions more in 32 other nations.

title: LEGISLATORS STUDY DEFENSES TO KEEP TEAMS IN PLACE
description: WASHINGTON

title: FANS ARE AT ODDS WITH ODDSMAKERS
description: The Miami Dolphins are the American public's favorite to win the Super Bowl, even though the San Francisco 49ers are a 3-point favorite in the game today, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.

title: Rain and Snowfall in West Assure Ample Water Supply
description: Rain and snowfall in the West in the fall and early winter have been normal to above normal, assuring abundant water supplies for the region this summer, the Government said Friday.

title: Sophie Maillard, Teacher Wed to Harvey Stevenson
description: Sophie Madeleine Maillard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Maillard of Incheville, France, was married yesterday to Harvey Stevenson, a son of James Stevenson of Guilford, Conn., and the late Jane Walker Stevenson.

title: MUSEUMS IN SCRAMBLE FOR MONEY
description: DURING economic hard times all public institutions suffer, and those involved with the arts are among those that suffer the most.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN MONTREAL
description: ROCHELLE LASH BALFOUR is a writer who lives in Montreal.

title: HERE COMES 'AUTHENTIC' ROMANTICISM
description: About the most exciting trend in classical-music performance of recent years has been the ''authentic'' recreation of early music. Pioneered by musician- musicologists and now affecting even mainstream performances, this sober fashion has changed the very way we hear music of the Renaissance, Baroque and Classical periods.

title: DISCOVERING THE PRESIDENCY
description: The office Ronald Reagan will publicly assume for a second time tomorrow occupies the same central position in political scholarship that it does in the political life of the United States. Academic reputations rise more quicky with an analysis of the Presidency than with practically any other political topic. Top publishing houses fight to pubish books whose authors, were they to write about anything else, would be welcome only at university presses. To cap things off, an academically respectable work on the Chief Executive can find a popular as well as an intellectual market.

title: IN NEWARK, A 2-BLOCK REVIVAL
description: IT has taken the better part of a decade, but

title: MIDBLOCK TOWER
description: A dearth of developable midtown sites on Manhattan's East Side is underscored again with the construction of yet another midblock office tower, this time on East 52d Street between Madison and Park Avenues.

title: LORD WOLFENDEN, AN EDUCATOR AND BRITISH SOCIAL REFORMER
description: Lord Wolfenden, the man who helped change the way male homosexuals and female prostitutes are treated in Britain, died Friday in a hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Pro Bowl Is Sold Out In Hawaii Next Sunday
description: The last of 49,800 tickets for the National Football League's Pro Bowl on Jan. 27 was sold Friday, Al Ward, a league spokesman, said today.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: WHEN students at the State University of New York at Stony Brook return for spring classes this week, they will have access for the first time to computers that have been provided as part of a campuswide instructional network being developed there.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

'GOODBYE, BEAUTY, LOVE,' HE SAID
description: WHAT a beauty. She was the kind of dog that just the sight of her set your mind to painting pictures of her bounding about a street or a grassy yard with children.

title: THIS DANCE COMPETITION DOES MORE THAN GIVE PRIZES
description: The United States has had its own international ballet competitions in recent years. But an established European competition will be held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday, Saturday and next Sunday, when New Yorkers will be able to watch approximately 30 teenaged dancers compete in the closing rounds of the 13th annual Prix de Lausanne International Ballet Competition, normally held in Lausanne, Switzerland.

title: BRAIN SCANNER TESTED IN EFFORT TO DETECT DRUG USE
description: The police in Monmouth County, N.J., are testing a new device that they believe can scan brain waves to detect drug use.

title: Scorning the World Court
description: Strictly speaking, there being no world government, there's no such thing as world law. There is no parliament to write the law and no policeman to enforce it. Yet there sits this thing called the World Court, pretending for much of this century not only to adjudicate some disputes between governments but also to define some norms of international behavior and rights of nations, even some individuals. It's a strange but real institution.

title: RANGERS TROUNCED BY CAPITALS, 7-1
description: The corridor between the Capitals' and visitors' dressing rooms here is long enough so that the Rangers did not have to hear the belly laughing. The Capitals, the newest power in hockey, rejoiced in another victory tonight, 7-1, over the Rangers.

title: SKEPTICAL OPTIMIST FOR TALKS: MAX M. KAMPELMAN
description: In turning to Max M. Kampelman to head the new arms negotiations with the Soviet Union, President Reagan has chosen a Democrat with a reputation for skepticism in bargaining with adversaries and for an optimism that keeps him bargaining. The 64-year-old lawyer, whose ideals and negotiating skills are rooted in early service with Hubert H. Humphrey, was a holdover from the Carter Administration when he worked out a difficult agreement with the Russians at the East-West conference in Madrid in 1983, impressing the Reagan Administration.

title: A Correction
description: An article in The Week in Review last Sunday incorrectly described the disposition of John A. Zaccaro's legal case. Mr. Zaccaro, the husband of Geraldine A. Ferraro, pleaded guilty to a single misdemeanor charge. No other charges were brought against him.

GARDENING;

title: THE IGNORED VEAL SHANK
description: WHERE FOOD IS CONCERNED, we are living in an unparalleled age of adventure and excitement. The markets - in metropolitan areas, at least - are filled with exotics that were largely unknown to the general public as recently as five years ago: fresh ginger, arugula, raddichio, mustard cress, domestic goat cheese and fresh foie gras, among other items.

title: REAGAN'S ACHIEVEMENTS POSE HARD TESTS FOR SECOND TERM
description: President Reagan approaches the start of his second term Sunday with the most dramatic successes of his first four years framing the most important and difficult tests of his second.

description: Thank you so much for the beauty, spirit and sensitivity of the Dec. 23 issue of The New York Times Magazine. ''A Christmas Sampler,'' ''The Spirit of Giving,'' ''A Single Father'' and the wonderful illustrations throughout were enchanting. When I threw away the rest of the paper, I tucked these treasures into a safe place to be enjoyed again. LINDA LOPEZ

description: Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, led a U.S. delegation that met with Chinese

title: CUOMO SAYS STATE EFFORTS IN '84 SAVED $40 MILLION
description: New York State saved $40 million last year through improvements in management and by increasing the productivity of state workers, Governor Cuomo said this week.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

A GRANDMOTHER TAKES NO NONSENSE - EVEN AS A MEMORY
description: SOMETIMES seeing her made me angry. I don't know what things combined to do this, whether it was her slowness and feebleness of movement or the way she repeated questions; maybe the quavering of her voice coming faintly to me over the running water as I cleaned up after our dinner. What upset me the most were the little signs of lost control, the food left in the cracks of her lips or spotted on her robe. I didn't want to kiss her, but suffered it anyway; then wiped it off as soon as I got in the elevator and hated myself, hated her for making me face how little, really, I could handle.

title: RESIDENTIAL INFILL
description: A low-rise warehouse that was the only commercial intrusion on the residential atmosphere of East 62d Street between First and York Avenues is being replaced by an 18-story condominium building.

title: ARE SOME HELPING HANDS HELPING THEMSELVES?
description: Scenes of starving African children have brought an outpouring of American generosity in recent months, a large part of it in the form of contributions to churches and other religious groups. But reports that an evangelical group in California may have collected money for relief that never reached the famine victims in Ethiopia have cast a shadow over the fund-raising drive. Several officials of private charities were quick to call for some kind of government regulation of religious appeals, a proposal that has proved unpopular in the past. Without some controls to reassure the public, they say, the highly praised charity efforts of most religious groups will be hurt. The problem, said Robert Hohler, a Boston fund-raising consultant, is that most church groups have no legal responsibility to spend the contributions on famine aid or otherwise account for their expenditures because they are exempt from the financial accountability regulations that apply to other nonprofit organizations. ''Nobody in this business is enforcing standards,'' he said. ''You have people receiving enormous sums of money but in the field you see so little effect, you wonder where the money has gone.'' And the lack of enforcement, he said, ''imposes a tremendous burden on genuine assistance agencies.'' Some government officials agree. ''The thing about fraudulent fund raising is that it gives legitimate fund raisers a bad name,'' said Arthur E. Dewey, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State in the Bureau of Refugee Affairs. He has criticized what he called the ''false and misleading'' advertising by International Christian Aid, or I.C.A., which came under investigation after the local prosecutors received complaints about the organization's famine relief drive.

These shows have covered major as well as minor feels of fashionable dress, and have dealt with both designers and the people who wear their clothes. One year, the glamour of Hollywood was the subject, another featured the colorful costumes of Russia, and last year there was the highly succesful ''Yves Saint Laurent: 25 Years of Design.'' None of the exhibits, though, were quite as special, or specialized, as the current ''Man and the Horse.''

title: WOMEN VS. MEN IN THE WORK FORCE

Surely, these young men will do what countless young women have done in the past. They'll find themselves a spouse - and then they'll have dinner ready when she comes home, they'll have bathed and fed the children, and they'll be ready to say at frequent intervals, ''Gosh, you're wonderful!'' Women shouldn't find that hard to get used to. MARGARET G. MCGARRAHAN

title: JERSEY TAKES 'RIGHT TO DIE' A STEP FARTHER
description: NINE years ago, the New Jersey Supreme Court allowed Karen Ann Quinlan to be removed from a respirator. Last week, the Court again ventured into new territory when it ruled that all life support can be withheld from incompetent as well as terminally ill competent patients, provided that is what the patient wants or would want. In what was viewed as a victory for the ''right to die'' movement, the decision was the first by the highest court of a state to eliminate the distinction between feeding patients and other kinds of life support.

title: CIRCUS DATE MARKED
description: SOMERS SOMERS, which calls itself ''The Birthplace of the American Circus,'' is now marking the 150th anniversary of an agreement setting up a cooperative of menagerie owners. ''That was the culmination of a lot of circus activity going on around here,'' said the Somers Town Historian, Florence Oliver. An exhibit on the circus in America will be open to the public in the Somers Town Hall - the one-time hostelry that is also known as the Elephant Hotel, where the cooperative agreement was signed. The exhibit is open from 2 to 4 P.M. every Friday through this year and for groups by appointment (call 277-4977).

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF ;   Bowery Ensemble Plays Morton Feldman Work

Last fall, he produced a four-hour, uninterrupted string quartet that the Kronos Quartet dispatched with its usual modernist bravado for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation in Toronto. But New York City, with its tight schedules, hurry-up energy and ''uptown'' lack of sympathy for Mr. Feldman's musical meditations, has not heard many of these recent works.
