title: IF THE ARMS TALKS ARE TO SUCCEED
description: Now that the United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to resume arms control negotiations, we should be reconsidering our negotiating strategy. Without some fundamental changes in our position - and that of the Soviet Union - the chances of reaching an arms control agreement will be extremely limited.

title: ILL CHILDREN AND PAIN OF ISOLATION
description: MILLIONS of television viewers saw a 3-year-old Maryland boy walking to school recently. He was holding his mother's hand and carrying a book bag. His feet, in tiny sneakers, seemed to float above the ground like a character in a ''Peanuts'' comic strip.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Amfac Inc. of San Francisco, a diversified company with interests in food processing, hotels and resorts, agriculture and property, appointed Melburn G. Whitmire president of its Amfac Health Care division.

title: STAGE: 'DYSAN' OPENS AT THE CIRCLE REPERTORY
description: ONLY last month the venerable but slumping Circle Repertory Company seemed to have hit bottom with ''Bing and Walker,'' a comedy that asked whether a mental defective could find true happiness in the merchant marine. But anyone who sees the new Circle Rep attraction, ''Dysan,'' may well find himself wishing he were at a ''Bing and Walker'' revival. If ''Dysan'' doesn't prove to be the silliest play of 1985, it's not for lack of trying. A meditation on reincarnation, love and the decline of Western civilization, this work gives us a rough inkling of how Thornton Wilder might have written ''The Skin of Our Teeth'' if he'd fallen under the spell of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon.

title: Israel Starts First Stage Of Its Lebanon Pullout
description: Israel began the first stage of its military pullback from Lebanon today as scores of trucks and armored vehicles rolled south from the Sidon area.

title: U.S. SAYS 3 PLANNED MORE CLINIC BOMBS
description: Law-enforcement officials who were involved in the arrests Saturday of three men accused of abortion clinic bombings in this area said today that evidence had been discovered indicating the suspects had planned further bombings.

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 21, 1985 International

title: Offer to Knox Is Reported
description: Chuck Knox, coach of the Seattle Seahawks, has reportedly received an offer through a third party to coach in Detroit and become part-owner of the Lions.

title: Bulgarians Trained Him To Shoot, Agca Says
description: Mehmet Ali Agca, the man convicted of shooting Pope John Paul II, was quoted in an Italian newspaper today as having told investigators that he was trained as a marksman by Bulgarian agents in Syria.

title: Dr. King's Daughter Assails Her Generation
description: Nearly 1,000 people gathered yesterday in the Bronx to remember the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and heard one of his children assail her own generation.

title: 3 EX-OLYMPIC BOXERS OVERWHELM OPPOSITION IN PRO BOUTS
description: As pre-game entertainment, marching bands have been more competitive. Three of ABC's Olympic medal-winning boxers did not lose a round today as they outclassed seasoned veterans as part of the network's pre-Super Bowl show.

title: Bangladesh Lawyers Are Boycotting Courts
description: Lawyers in Bangladesh began an indefinite boycott of courts today in a bid to force President H. M. Ershad to restore democracy and the powers of the judiciary.

title: Harrell-Firkusny Duets
description: The cellist Lynn Harrell and the pianist Rudolf Firkusny will perform together at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Jan. 31 at 8 P.M.. The pair will play several pieces for piano and cello, including Stravinsky's Suite Italienne, Beethoven's Sonata No. 5 in D Major, Op. 102, No. 2, and Chopin's Sonata in G Minor, Op. 65. Tickets are available at the box office.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 21, 1985: *2*MONDAY Eastern Utils Southern Co Midwest Energy *2*TUESDAY Amsted Indust Public Serv Co New Mex Ball Corp Santa Fe So Pacific Central Ill Lt Schering-Plough Great Western Fin Smucker (JM) Co Kansas Gas & Elec Standard Oil Ind Loral Corp Taft Brdcstng Natl Gypsum Tenneco Inc Norfolk Southern Corp Thrifty Corp Norwest Corp US Life Corp Overnite Transp Wicor Inc *2*WEDNESDAY Baker Intl SmithKline Beckman Bearings Inc Southland Corp Eaton Corp Standard Pacific Edison Bros Stores Sybron Corp Hillenbrand Indus Todd Shipyards Inland Steel Transworld Corp Philips Indus Wisconsin Elec Pwr Sheller Globe Corp *2*THURSDAY Acme-Cleveland Natl Distil&Chem Delta Air Lines Papercraft Corp Dravo Corp Parker-Hannifin First Wis Corp Potlatch Corp Handy & Harman RLC Corp Kennametal Inc Ranco Inc Libbey-Owens-Ford Sonat Inc Mark Controls Standard Oil Ohio Mead Corp *2*FRIDAY Copperweld Corp McDonnell Douglas Ferro Corp Mobil Corp Florida Steel Omark Indus Harland Pan American Bks Holly Sugar Corp Pennzoil Co Kysor Industrial Rowan Cos

title: A Canine Success Story
description: As Joseph F. Lisa's daughters were

title: Futures/Options;   New Twist Offered In Bonds
description: A new element of uncertainty entered the bond futures market last Tuesday, when the Treasury said its bonds to be auctioned as part of the February refunding would no longer be subject to redemption after 25 years. Existing bonds are still callable after 25 years, the Treasury noted.

title: JAPAN'S OIL IMPORT ARGUMENT
description: Taiji Sato had a modest proposal: He wanted to buy inexpensive gasoline from Singapore and sell it to Japanese consumers for less than they now pay.

title: Military Contracts
description: General Dynamics Land Systems Inc., a unit of the General Dynamics Corporation, won a $103.2 million Army contract for the production of 840 M-1 Abrams tanks, the Defense Department said.

title: Drifting Gasoline Barge Caught Off Block Island
description: A runaway barge with 20,000 barrels of gasoline broke away from its tug and drifted near Block Island for 14 hours before the tug recaptured it today.

title: KING IS STILL UNABLE TO PLAY
description: Bernard King, sidelined the last four games with a sprained right ankle, will be re-examined today by Dr. Norman Scott, the Knicks' team physician. However, the league's top scorer, averaging 31.5 points a game, is still limping and is not expected to play tomorrow night when the Knicks oppose the Seattle SuperSonics at Madison Square Garden.

title: Heidi Joseph, Lawyer, Wed to David A. Saltzman
description: The marriage of Heidi Rita Joseph, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert R. Joseph of Wyckoff, N.J., to David Andrew Saltzman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Saltzman of Fair Lawn, N.J., took place yesterday. Rabbi Fredric Dworkin performed the ceremony at the Meadowlands Hilton in Secaucus, N.J.

title: MARCOS FOE RETURNS TO MANILA
description: The opposition leader Jovito Salonga stepped off a commercial airliner at the Manila airport today, ending nearly four years of self-imposed exile in the United States.

title: How the Poll Was Done
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 14 through 17 with 1,534 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: Studio 54 Shooting Injures Employee
description: An employee at Studio 54 was shot and critically injured early yesterday after an argument with six men he had turned away from the nightclub, the police said.

title: SUPER BOWL SUMMARY
description: Scoring

title: Debt
description: Arizona Public Service Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $200 million of first mortgage bonds, through underwriters led by First Boston Corp.

title: Wirnsberger Prevails
description: Austria's Peter Wirnsberger, in his ninth World Cup ski season, survived a challenge from two Swiss veterans in winning a downhill race today on the Lauberhorn course, his first victory in five years.

title: DANCE: MIRMDANCE PERFORMS 7 WORKS
description: EVERY so often dance comes along that is so engagingly warm-hearted and exuberant that the quality of the performance as well as of the choreography and its relation to the music seems almost beside the point. Miriam Hertzson created such dance in a program performed by Mirmdance on Friday at Washington Square Church. The seven pieces by this assured young choreographer were well crafted, imaginative and intelligent. But what stood out about the dances - and Miss Hertzson's skillful young performers - was their generosity of spirit.

title: Protecting the Polls, Both Kinds
description: Now is the time for the TV networks to come to the aid of the exit polls - and now, to their credit, the networks have done just that. ABC, NBC and CBS News have told a House study panel that they will not use exit polls to give away the outcome of an election while people are still voting.

title: THEATER: BILL TALEN IN HIS PLAY
description: IN the last few years, the Dance

title: Sports World Specials ;   Cooking for a Dolphin Diet
description: The Miami Dolphins and their wives are preparing a new recipe book, and it appears there is hardly anything on the list for a football player to sink his teeth into.

title: 49ERS STOP MARINO IN SUPER BOWL, OVERWHELMING DOLPHINS BY 38-16
description: In a record-breaking performance watched by 84,059 fans in Stanford Stadium and on television by 120 million in the United States and millions more in 30 other countries, the San Francisco 49ers won Super Bowl XIX yesterday when they stopped Dan Marino and overwhelmed the Miami Dolphins by 38-16.

title: FIGINI WINS ICY DOWNHILL
description: Michela Figini of Switzerland, mastering an icy course that only 35 racers finished, won her third consecutive downhill today and took a 20- point lead in the women's overall World Cup standing.

title: STUDENTS AND PRIVACY
description: In 1969, when it upheld 15-year-old John F. Tinker's right to wear a black armband to class to protest the Vietnam War, the United States Supreme Court reflected on the constitutional status of students. ''Students in school as well as out of school are 'persons' under our Constitution and are possessed of fundamental rights which the state must respect,'' the Court held in Tinker v. Des Moines Independent Community School District. Young people do not, it stated, ''shed their constitutional rights at the schoolhouse gate.''

title: Inauguration Schedule on TV
description: Television network plans for coverage of inauguration activities were thrown into confusion yesterday after the White House announced the cancellation of the inaugural parade. NBC, which will begin live coverage at 10 A.M., tentatively planned to return to regular programming at 2 P.M. CBS and ABC planned to begin live coverage at 11 A.M., but were uncertain last night whether they would continue until 4 P.M. as all three networks originally planned.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: HELL'S KITCHEN Hell's Kitchen, a name that is attached to no community board, was an area that reached from about 10 blocks below to 10 blocks above West 42d Street, west of Eighth Avenue. It had a mixed population - Irish, Italian, German, others - and was regarded by other New Yorkers as a singularly tough neighborhood. Yet many people made decent lives for themselves there and recall it with affection. An exhibition that recalls the old Hell's Kitchen and portrays what is happening there today is on view at the Municipal Art Society's Urban Art Center, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street (935-3960).

title: FREDDIE MAC STOCKS SALE SET DESPITE OBJECTIONS
description: Trading in the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation's preferred stock is scheduled to begin Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange, unless the Justice Department decides to intervene.

title: CONCERT: MUSIC TODAY EMBRACES 2 EXTREMES
description: WEDNESDAY'S Music Today concert at Merkin Concert Hall balanced itself between two extremes of the expressive range. At one pole lay Hindemith's Kammermusik No. 3, a four-movement piece from 1925 using a solo cello and an ensemble of 12 instruments, mostly winds and brass. At the other was ''TreeStone from 'Finnegan's Wake.' '' a new work for two singers and chamber group by Stephen Albert.

title: Jury Deliberates In Sharon Trial
description: Jury deliberations continued yesterday for a seventh day in the libel trial of Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli Defense Minister, against Time magazine in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Lynn Hackstaff Wed To Dr. Glenn Goldis
description: Lynn Hackstaff, a daughter of Mary Hackstaff of Medford, L.I., and the late Donald F. Hackstaff of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Glenn Goldis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Goldis of Hicksville, L.I. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan.

title: Latin Lending in Jeopardy
description: United States opposition to loans for Nicaragua now threatens all of the $5.3 billion that the Inter- American Development Bank plans to lend to 22 Latin American countries. At issue is a $59.8 million agricultural loan requested by Nicaragua in June 1982.

title: WEST GERMAN UNIONS: AN ATYPICAL SUCCESS STORY
description: Karlheinz Weihs is a manual worker at the big Thyssen steel combine at Duisburg, just north of D"usseldorf in the Ruhr.

title: THE INAUGURAL MINT
description: Tomorrow morning, when the inauguration festivities are over, the Administration will sit down to tally up the bill for this year's ceremony.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Competing With the Regionals
description: By easing the way for ''upstairs'' member firms to own specialist firms, the New York Stock Exchange would be leveling out the playing field in its competition with regional exchanges.

title: Offenbach's 'Bluebeard' And the Bronx Opera
description: The operettas of Jacques Offenbach provide one of life's most reliable secondary pleasures. Like meringue or a good comic novel, they are lightweight and not particularly nourishing, and would probably not make our first list of commodities to take to a desert island. But Offenbach was a wonderful composer - a French Rossini or, perhaps, a purveyor of Gallic Gilbert and Sullivan. His works are built on sturdy, formulas - one slips into an Offenbach work as into a comfortable bath - and it is doubtful that the composer ever wrote an inferior tune. For these reasons, his operettas are virtually indestructable and provide more delight than many a grander, more self- consciously ''serious'' work.

title: FRANCE RECALLS AIDE IN INDIA AFTER REPORT OF SPYING LINK
description: France recalled its deputy military attache in India today after an Indian newspaper reported that a French diplomat was being deported for involvement in an espionage ring that funneled secrets to the United States Central Intelligence Agency.

title: SHIVERING VISITORS IN WASHINGTON MOSTLY RELIEVED ON CANCELLATION
description: This shivering city reacted with relief tonight to the announcement that the inaugural parade had been canceled.

title: POP: NYDIA CARO AT FREDDY'S
description: born pop singer who has been an international star for more than a decade, returned to New York last week for a two-week engagement at Freddy's Supper Club. Miss Caro, who sings both in English and Spanish, possesses the cultivative glamour of a well-bred ingenue along with a voice that's sweetly pretty but not especially dramatic.

title: Castle Gets Court Order
description: Castle & Cooke Inc., the food packing company, said it had obtained a 10-day restraining order on Saturday barring a group of investors from acquiring its common stock or convertible securities.

title: FRANCE BOLSTERING NEW CALEDONIA BASE
description: President Francois Mitterrand tonight ordered the strengthening of the military base on the Pacific island of New Caledonia to protect what he called France's strategic interests in the southern Pacific.

title: HOW THE BEST DEFENSE SWITCHED OFF THE BEST OFFENSE
description: The best offense and the best defense in professional football met on the grass of Stanford Stadium yesterday, and they set Super Bowl records. But almost all the records were set by the San Francisco 49ers, who not only annihilated the Miami Dolphins' storied offense but also devastated them with one of the unrelenting performances in the 19-year history of the game.

title: MARINO LAMENTS AN UNPRODUCTIVE EFFORT
description: The highest compliment anyone paid to Dan Marino last week came from Bill Walsh, the coach of the San Francisco 49ers. Walsh said he and his staff kept studying the films to find ''one off game'' by the young quarterback of Miami, but that Walsh and his aides could not find one.

title: Outdoors: Ideal Craft for a Sportsman's Needs
description: WHAT outdoorsman has not dreamed of a small boat that could carry him and a companion on a camping and fishing trip through some remote lake chain, that would sail in sprightly fashion on a sparkling bay and also serve as a stable, floating blind in a waterfowling marsh?

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Midway Airlines To Get New Chief
description: David R. Hinson, a director of Midway Airlines, will become chairman and chief executive officer of the carrier on Feb. 15. He replaces Arthur C. Bass, who is resigning ''to pursue personal interests.''

title: Wife of Pincay Dies of Wounds
description: Linda Pincay, wife of Laffit Pincay Jr. the jockey, died today of a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head incurred on Friday, authorities said.

title: RANGERS BATTERED, BRUISED
description: One Ranger moved his arm slowly and stiffly, as if he were raising the heavy hand of a cathedral clock. That was Ron Greschner putting on his shirt.

title: Darden Named Conductor
description: Charles Darden has been appointed principal conductor of the Dance Theater of Harlem. Mr. Darden was the first recipient of the Martin Luther King Memorial Fellowship from the San Francisco Conservatory. He received his training at the Curtis Institute of Music and has conducted for the Ballet Rambert in London, the Oslo Philharmonic Orchestra and the Den Norske Opera in Oslo.

title: BOURNE LOST FOR TWO MONTHS
description: The Islanders' veteran forward, Bob Bourne, underwent a two-and-a-half-hour operation on his right hand and wrist this morning at California Hospital Medical Center after severing five tendons in an accident in Saturday night's game against the Los Angeles Kings.

title: ST. BART'S SETS TOWER DISPUTE ASIDE TO CELEBRATE ITS 150TH ANNIVERSARY
description: Long before there was a Landmarks Commission and talk of skyscrapers, there was St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: NEW INTEREST IN SPECIALISTS
description: The winds of change are whipping the flags of the venerable New York Stock Exchange faster and faster these days. The Big Board has been exploring 24-hour trading in stocks of companies listed on the exchange and is studying the possibility of a merger with the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: NOT JUST ANOTHER DANCE AT THIS INAUGURAL BALL
description: Philip Johnson calls it ''America's largest ballroom.'' Another architect, Tad Stahl, says of it: ''It violates all the rules; it is a very quirky, very bloody- minded building.''

title: U.S. ALLIANCES GAIN IN ITALY
description: By almost any standard, the International Business Machines Corporation and Selenia-Elsag S.p.A. would appear to be the odd couple of European business.

title: OPTIMISM IN NATION IS INCREASING, POLL FINDS
description: The public's satisfaction with the country's present condition and optimism about its future have climbed to the highest levels in several years, according to The New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Heidi Goennel, Artist, Weds A. Peter Lubitz
description: Heidi Goennel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Goennel of Rowayton, Conn., was married yesterday to A. Peter Lubitz, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jesse Lubitz of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I. Justice Edward J. Greenfield of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Sheraton- Russell Hotel in New York.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS COMPANY MAKES TV MARK
description: Scholastic Inc., a major publisher of magazines and books for children and teen- agers, has begun to make a mark in television production as well.

title: 'NOON WINE' EXPLORES PSYCHOLOGICAL TRUTHS
description: THE year is 1896. A tall, strange man with a Swedish accent comes to the run-down Thompson farm in sweltering South Texas looking for a job. He turns out to be an invaluable worker but insists on being left alone. As his own life becomes more comfortable, Mr. Thompson carefully respects the man's wishes. But one day, nine years later, another stranger comes looking for the man, and Mr. Thompson's world is destroyed, almost while he isn't looking.

title: Washington Watch;   Simpler Rules On Use of Cars
description: WASHINGTON

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   The Second-Term Outlook
description: As President Reagan begins his second term, the financial markets are one area in which he can point to progress during his first four years in office.

title: Low Stars for Devils The heroics of Ron Low, the goaltender, and John MacLean, a right wing, enabled the Devils to come away with a 4-4 tie against the Canadiens in Montreal Saturday night.
description: MacLean tied the score with his second goal of the game, deflecting in a blue-line blast by Phil Russell with 1:58 seconds to play.

title: ISLANDERS COMPILE POSTGAMME JOURNAL
description: Simply ''to give them something else to think about,'' the Islander coach, Al Arbour, has asked all his players, veterans and rookies alike, to write their postgame thoughts on paper.

title: Fuel Rod Loading Complete At Shoreham Nuclear Plant
description: The Long Island Lighting Company announced today that fuel loading at the Shoreham nuclear power plant had been completed.

title: 58 Held in Seattle Rally Against South Africa
description: The police said they arrested 58 people today on trespassing charges at a rally at the South African consulate to protest South Africa's policy of racial separation.

title: OPEC Panel Looks at Prices RIYADH, Saudi Arabia,
description: The Saudi

title: High Risks in Low-Rent Housing
description: The rich alone escape the pains of New York's housing scarcity. That's why Governor Cuomo proposed a $3.5 billion, five-year plan to build and rehabilitate housing for others. The part intended for relatively affluent families is safer than the rest, but less urgent. The part meant for the very poor, though badly needed, would bring New York dangerously close to the flame that burned it so badly in 1975. The voters need to be asked about this risk of a second singeing.

title: SUDAN'S PRESIDENT SAYS ALL REFUGEES ARE FREE TO LEAVE
description: President Gaafar al-Nimeiry said today that Ethiopian Jews and all other refugees living in Sudanese camps were free to leave the country, provided they did not go directly to Israel.

title: Advertising;   Publicker's Cleanser Strategy
description: PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES of Greenwich, Conn., which is committed to taking on the huge household cleanser industry, has selected four-year-old Gleckler & Spiegel Advertising to help.

title: MUSIC: BY MUSICA SACRA, SCHUTZ AND BRAHMS
description: WITH the 300th anniversaries of the births of Bach and Handel preoccupying us this year, the 300th birthday of Domenico Scarlatti and, especially, the 400th birthday of Heinrich Sch"utz tend to be overlooked. Richard Westenburg and his Musica Sacra chorus turned their attentions Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall to Sch"utz, neatly coupling him with Brahms.

title: H. MALCOLM BALDRIGE
description: H. Malcolm Baldrige, a lawyer who represented Nebraska in the United State House of Representatives, died Saturday at the Lutheran Home here, his family announced today. He was 90 years old, and until recently had lived in Washington, Conn.

title: International Harvester And Union in Accord
description: The International Harvester Company and the United Automobile Workers union reached a tentative contract agreement tonight, ending a walkout by more than 11,000 workers that had begun less than 48 hours before, a company spokesman said.

title: ACTIVISTS PROTEST AT DOOR OF CHURCH
description: Thirty union activists, five dressed in robes simulating those of bishops, went to St. Paul's Roman Catholic Cathedral here today and taped to the door ''95 theses'' condemning the Catholic Church as uninterested in helping the region's unemployed and saving its steel industry.

title: CRAIG BECOMES A STAR IN QUICK ORDER
description: The touchdowns seemed to happen so quickly and so often that by the time the game ended, Roger Craig had a difficult time telling one from the others.

title: THE 49ERS' ASTRONAUT
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.

title: Market Place;   Analysts View Bank Stocks
description: -center banks, best typified by the big banks in New York City, have been climbing since last summer, and they turned in another good performance last week. This reflected the release of improved fourth-quarter profits by a number of banks as well as diminishing concern over their international loan problems. On the latter score, although the problems certainly have not disappeared, a crisis that dampened enthusiasm for bank stocks last summer appears to have been averted for the present.

title: A DIARY: EXCESSES ARE TOO MUCH
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.

title: ERROL FLYNN'S STORY, FROM HIS OWN BOOK
description: Hollywood's quintessential swashbuckler - may have been many things, but it almost certainly had to be more exciting than the faintly rakish genteel existence that is portrayed in ''My Wicked, Wicked Ways . . . The Legend of Errol Flynn.'' The three-hour dramatization of the star's autobiography, which is being broadcast tonight at 8 on CBS, begins in 1935, when the 26-year-old actor arrived in Hollywood as a contract player for Warner Brothers, and ends eight years later, after his acquittal in a highly publicized trial on charges of statutory rape. Although Mr. Flynn's career sputtered on until 1959, when he died, a dissipated wreck at 50, these eight years were Errol Flynn's golden period, in which he starred in one hit after another, beginning with ''Captain Blood'' and continuing with ''The Charge of the Light Brigade,'' ''The Adventures of Robin Hood'' and ''The Private Lives of Elizabeth and Essex.''

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball

title: Presidents Appointed At Three Beatrice Units
description: The Beatrice Companies named three new presidents for units in its consumer durables group. The appointments become effective immediately.

title: The Eucalyptus Bowl
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.

title: People
description: Denis P. Crosley, Robert W. Freeman, Milt K. Harkrader and

title: AUGURING WELL
description: WASHINGTON The word ''inaugurate'' comes

title: U.S. CRUDE PRICES STEADILY ERODING
description: Company by company, dollar by dollar, the price of American crude oil has fallen by up to $4 a barrel at the producer level in the last three months. In the last week alone, most big companies trimmed $1 off the price they will pay for a barrel of crude oil.

title: Dr. Donald Granger, 55, Dies; Neurology Chief in Bridgeport
description: Dr. Donald P. Granger, chief of the department of neurology at Bridgeport Hospital in Connecticut and clinical associate professor of neurology at Yale University, died of cancer Saturday at the hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: Bridge:Dramatic Moments of Play Are Described in New Book
description: The world team championship played in Stockholm in the fall of 1983 was surely the most dramatic in the history of the game. Italy's veterans barely survived the qualifying stage and then won a squeaker against France in the semifinal playoff.

title: Business Week's Pierce Leaving to Join Lotus
description: James R. Pierce, publisher since mid-1982 of Business Week magazine, surprised his fellow workers last week by turning in his resignation.

title: THE SHIFTING PICTURE OF CRIME BY U.S. VIETNAMESE
description: The police in this southern California town recently encountered a teen-age Vietnamese who had been shot outside a fast-food restaurant at 2 A.M.

title: Dolphin Problems Grew and Grew
description: All the things that had worked so well for the Dolphins suddenly stopped working tonight in their 38-16 loss to the 49ers.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Last year, much was made of the fact that in winning their division title, the Detroit Tigers never spent a day out of first place all season. Has a team ever won a pennant or division title without being in first place until the last day of the season?

title: Briefcases
description: - Jay Rockefeller, the freshman Senator from West Virginia, is seeking a place on the Energy Committee.

title: CELTICS STOP 76ERS
description: Larry Bird put on his superstar act today and led the Boston Celtics to 113-97 victory over the 76ers that snapped Philadelphia's 13-game winning streak.

title: Pipeline Shutting for Repair
description: The trans-Alaska oil pipeline will be shut down briefly Monday to repair a sagging section of the line running from Prudhoe Bay to Valdez, a project that will cost $20 million, officials say.

title: ;   TEMPORARIES ARE A WAY OF LIFE ON THE CAMPUS
description: To the Editor:

title: FINDING THE PROPER PATH IN REJUVENATING WASHINGTON'S GREAT BOULEVARD
description: For two decades - longer than it took to fight the Revolutionary War, declare independence and frame the Constitution - planners and politicians have struggled over what is to happen to the 15 blocks of Pennsylvania Avenue that link the Capitol and the White House, long a mix of the grandiose and the tawdry.

title: Sports World Specials;   Real to Reel
description: You may have been in the stands in Stanford Stadium in Palo Alto, Calif., or you may have been watching on television at home, but the way Steve Sabol sees it, you have not really seen Super Bowl XIX until you see the official Super Bowl film that he and his crew of ''weasels, moles and trees'' were shooting during the game for NFL Films.

title: FRANCIS KILCOYNE, EDUCATOR, IS DEAD
description: The Rev. Francis Patrick Kilcoyne, a former president of Brooklyn College who was active in New York City education for 48 years, died Saturday at Kings Highway Hospital Center in Brooklyn. He was 82 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Shake-Up Expected At Renault
description: A power struggle is under way at Renault, the French state-owned car manufacturer, which owns the American Motors Corporation in the United States.

title: 33 Killed in Sri Lanka As Train Is Blown Up
description: A train was blown up 180 miles north of here Saturday night and 22 soldiers and 11 civilians were killed, the police reported today. The police blamed Tamil separatist rebels for the explosion.

title: Talks Intensify With Firefighters
description: The Koch administration and a key municipal labor union are in the midst of what participants described as their most intensive negotiations since the last contract expired more than six months ago.

title: REAGAN'S VIEW OF TAX PLAN
description: James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff who is scheduled to take over the Treasury Department, said today that he expects President Reagan to ''embrace'' the Treasury's plan to overhaul the tax system after some revisions in the measure.

title: THE LIGHT AT THE SOUTHERN END OF THE AFRICAN TUNNEL
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS ORGANIZATIONS RECONSIDER CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICIES AS TRIAL OPENS
description: In April a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission and recently dismissed by the newspaper, described how he had given information on forthcoming articles to outsiders who then profited from stock transactions.

title: Famine-Relief Campaign
description: Madeline Cuomo, the 20-year-old daughter of Governor Cuomo, is heading a statewide campaign by college students to raise funds for Ethiopian famine victims. Miss Cuomo, a junior majoring in English at the State University at Albany, said Saturday that she and her older sister, Maria, had come up with the idea. She is chairman of a group of student leaders organized as Students Opposed to Poverty.

title: PRO SCOUTS FLOCK TO CREIGHTON STAR
description: Three years ago, Benoit Benjamin was the most-heralded schoolboy ''big man'' in the nation. College basketball coaches converged on Monroe, La., to try to recruit the 7-foot Carroll High School center.

title: DEPAUL BEATS IRISH 6TH TIME IN ROW
description: Tyrone Corbin hit 16 of his 18 points in the first half, as DePaul defeated Notre Dame, 71-66, in basketball today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TIME'S ARROWS: Scientific Attitudes

title: Professor Powell
description: Jody Powell, the White House press

title: FOR UPROOTED ETHIOPIANS, LIFE IN THE GREENER HILLS
description: A freshly cut dirt road leads to this new settlement spread across a wide valley in southwestern Ethiopia.

title: MOYNIHAN SUGGESTS COMBINING OF POLICE TO PROTECT SUBWAYS

On the enclosed card is a Special Savings Token marked ''YES!'' that would-be subscribers are to tear out and stick on the reply card. As a further lure, those who succumb also qualify for ''our annual sweepstakes'' with free foreign travel as the top prize.

title: Bad Guess
description: The weather has helped Livingstone Bramble, the World Boxing Association lightweight champion, enhance his reputation for being flakey. Bramble was training in Houston for his Feb. 16 rematch with Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini, but according to the promoter, Dan Duva, left ''because it was too cold for him.'' Bramble is now training in New Jersey.

title: Sparkman Suit
description: The Sparkman Energy Corporation said that it and its unit, the Esperanza Transmission Company, had filed suit seeking to recover $13 million from its former chairman, Wallace C. Sparkman, and several former officers. It said the suit, which was filed in Corpus Christi, Tex., was seeking damages of $39 million. The suit charges that Mr. Sparkman and the other former officers engaged in an illegal-kickback scheme.

title: THE DANCE: CITY BALLET REVIVES 'IN THE NIGHT'

At Friday night's performance in the New York State Theater, when Gordon Boelzner was the fine piano soloist, the cast's three pairs of dancing lovers were, for the most part, convincing and often eloquent.

title: HETEROSEXUALS AND AIDS: NEW DATA EXAMINED
description: AS the world epidemic of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, continues unabated, a new apprehension has begun to take hold among some medical experts. They say their suspicion is growing stronger that the disease may now pose a threat to the heterosexual community, though they hasten to add that this suspicion is based on preliminary interpretations of figures collected mainly in Africa and Haiti and on only scant data from the United States. Other health authorities still contend, however, that the risk to heterosexuals in the United States is so small that no new public health recommendations are warranted.

title: MUSIC: DA CAPO ENSEMBLE
description: GEORGE PERLE'S understanding of serial and atonal music has in large part become his generation's understanding through decades of influential teaching and writing, and he has embodied that understanding in a series of lively, straightforward compositions. He has explored 12-tone ideas, and techniques arising from them, in ways that are varied, imaginative and not exclusively atonal.

title: THE INAUGURAL LOOK FOR '85: OPULENCE IS STILL IN FASHION

For others, though, the Reagans symbolized an uplifting, welcome change. But whatever one felt, the Reagan style - one part tailored suit, one part ball gown and one part ranch mink - was discussed, debated, dissected and finally described as opulent.

title: STAGE: 'TRACERS,' DRAMA OF VIETNAM VETERANS
description: AT the beginning of ''Tracers,'' the new arrival at the Public Theater, a snaking line of Vietnam veterans gyrates about the stage to a driving rock beat. It's an unexpectedly energizing sight. ''Tracers'' is a play about a grim war, written and performed by men who were there, and yet this opening sequence provides the electric lift of the Jets' song in ''West Side Story.'' The pride, fellowship and shared tribal codes of these men - expressed only in kinetic body language and fraternal glances, not in words - fuse into a palpable spiritual force. It doesn't make any difference what ideological side we chose during the war - we're on the side of these veterans as soon as we meet them.

title: Grain Trades Despite Protest

About 200 farmers gathered outside the Board of Trade and two of their leaders - Wayne Cryts and Carlos Welty, Missouri farmers who had urged farmers to disrupt trading or go to jail - were among 12 arrested and charged with trespassing.

title: SECURITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE OPERA: MET DEBUT FOR SOPRANO
description: MAJOR singers who come late to the Metropolitan Opera for one reason or another are not rarities. Voice fans can rattle off a dozen famously delayed debuts and work up a head of steamy indignation in doing so. Even so, the debut of Margaret Price, in the season's first ''Otello'' last night, must rate among the least understandable of such cases. Miss Price, a Welsh soprano who has been busy in many of the world's opera houses for more than 20 years, owns a major voice, and in the role of Desdemona she proved she knows how to use it. Her singing of the death scene, one of the juiciest moments for soprano in all of opera, was a model of tonal purity, with enough depth of expression to keep one involved in her portrayal of the bewildered Desdemona.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: pages. Pantheon. $13.95. ''HOTEL DU LAC'' is a novel about romance, and reality, and the gap between them - which is both comic and melancholy - and the way the need for romance persists in the full knowledge of that gap - which is both melancholy and comic. It has a good deal to say about loneliness and vulnerability, about sensitive losers and insensitive winners; it takes a wan view of the career open to ''modesty and merit'' (''very poor cards to hold,'' as one character observes). In the abstract, it could easily be made to sound like a study in shades of gray. But that would be to take no account of the writing, which is witty and energetic, or of the storytelling, with its cunningly timed disclosures, or of the piercing accuracy of the book's observations.

title: Stake in Cantel

The company said it would introduce cellular mobile telephone service in Montreal and Toronto by July, and gradually extend the service to 21 other major Canadian cities by the end of 1986. The acquisition, for about $11.1 million, was through Pan Canadian Communications, a new Canadian subsidiary of Ameritech Mobile.

ISSEL CALLING IT A CAREER
description: Dan Issel made it official yesterday. At a news conference in Denver, the 6-foot-9-inch Nugget center announced he would retire after the end of the season. By then, Issel will have completed his 15th pro season, played in more than 1,200 pro games, second only to Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, and scored more than 27,000 points.

title: REBELS SAY DUARTE, PRESSED BY RIGHT, SHUNS TALKS
description: Leaders of El Salvador's leftist opposition said here today that chances for future peace talks had been damaged by a ''political crisis'' in the Government of President Jose Napoleon Duarte.

title: PET BLOODHOUNDS HUNT WHAT POLICE CAN'T FIND
description: His card says: ''Have Bloodhounds - Will Search. Day or night. Free.''

title: NETS FALL TO JAZZ
description: Trailing from start to finish, the listless Nets looked as though they would rather have been elsewhere tonight, losing to the Jazz by 102-99. Even when the Jazz allowed them an opportunity to recover, missing 7 of their 12 free throws in the final period, the Nets failed to take advantage, losing their third game in a row.

title: COMMISSIONERS DISAGREE OVER BABY GATE BAN
description: A member of the Consumer Product Safety Commission disclosed today that the agency acted earlier this month to halt the production and distribution of accordion-style baby gates, which have been linked to at least eight deaths of children.

title: 'HYPOCRISY' OF IN-HOUSE JOB BIAS
description: Congress, says Representative Lynn Martin of Illinois, is like a parent who scolds a child for cheating on an exam and at the same time falsifies the family's income tax return.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE following experiment, as reported by Lil Lulkin and Amy Demant, both teachers, was conducted by 5-year-olds at the Calhoun School in Manhattan:

title: EX-UGANDA LEADER
description: Yusufu K. Lule, who was President of Uganda for 68 days after the overthrow of Idi Amin, died at a hospital here Monday after surgery for kidney failure, a hospital administrator said today. He was 72 years old.

title: Moses Plea Entered
description: Edwin Moses , the track star, formally pleaded not guilty in Los Angeles to a charge that he solicited a female undercover police officer for prostitution on Jan. 13. The 29-year- old hurdler was not present in Municipal Court when his lawyer,

title: ATLANTIC FINANCIAL FEDERAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Chinese Candy Puller TO THE LIVING SECTION:
description: In writing about Chinese noodle maker Kin Jing Mark (''Chinese Noodle Maker Is a Throwback,'' Dec. 12), Nancy Jenkins notes that as far as anyone knows, he is the only such master noodle puller in New York. While that may be true as far as the medium (noodles) is concerned, there is, or was, at least one other practitioner of the technique.

title: CAMBEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
description: b-Including tax credits of $25,000 for the latest first quarter and $18,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: 'FREEZE OF THE CENTURY' DAMAGES 90% OF THE CITRUS CROP IN FLORIDA
description: Two days of record-breaking cold damaged nine-tenths of Florida's orange and grapefruit crop, state officials reported today. They said it was one of the most widespread blows against the industry in its history.

title: CORRECTION
description: A list accompanying an article about Arab banks operating in New York, printed in Business Day on J10, omitted Arab Bank Ltd. It had assets of $405 million on June 30.

title: Topics The Climate, Town and Country
description: Cozy

title: O'NEILL SAYS HE WON'T BLOCK HOUSE VOTE ON REAGAN BUDGET PLAN
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today that he would not attempt to block a vote on President Reagan's economic and budgetary proposals in recognition of the public mandate received by the President in his re-election.

title: 25 Farmers Arrested At Chicago Exchange
description: Farmers marched for the second day today to protest low grain prices, and 25 were arrested at the front door of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: Bridge:Swiss Team Events Proving To Outdraw Board-a-Match
description: The past two decades have clearly demonstrated that the great majority of tournament players prefer Swiss team events to the board-a-match format that prevailed for four decades. Board-a-match, with each deal scored as a victory, tie or loss, is hard work, and the most experienced teams can be expected to win.

title: All-Star Women
description: When American University persuaded Jihan el-Sadat, widow of the Egyptian President, to become a distinguished professor in residence this semester, it seems to have guaranteed an all- star line-up for the symposium on ''Women in a Changing World'' that she is conducting. After the lead-off lecture by Mrs. Sadat tonight, speakers include Betty Ford next week and Rosalynn Carter and Dr. Jeane J. Kirkpatrick in February.

title: IN REMOTE NICARAGUAN ZONE, REBELS STRIKE BOLDLY
description: The road north of this remote village is back in Sandinista hands for now, but young recruits guarding it say they fear rebels are waiting to attack again.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from businesses sold of $858,000 for the quarter and $19,754,000 for the year, a gain on the sale of businesses of $56.5 million for the quarter and year, and a provision of $50 million for the quarter and year for impairment of investment in certain foreign locations. c-Including income from businesses sold of $15,587,000 for the quarter and $36,387,000 for the year.

title: TIBOR SZEGEZDY
description: Tibor Szegezdy, structural engineer for a number of major new buildings in New York and other cities, died of cancer yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Complaints Over Heat Not Checked-2 Died
description: Repeated complaints that heat was lacking in a tenement on Avenue D where a man and a woman were found dead on Monday went unanswered because a computer failed to record the complaints, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development said last night.

title: PRESIDENT CALLS CONTROL OF ARMS HIS MAJOR GOAL
description: President Reagan said today that he viewed the United States arms-control negotiating commitments made with the Soviet Union in Geneva ''with the utmost seriousness.''

title: NATO Class Project Draws a Greek Protest
description: Greece lodged a ''strong protest'' against NATO today and instructed three officers and a diplomat to leave a North Atlantic Treaty Organization military college in Rome in reaction to a hypothetical classroom exercise that envisioned a foreign-supported coup in Greece after a leftist electoral victory.

title: ARMS ISSUE STRESSED
description: The Soviet Government press agency Tass today issued a rebuttal of President Reagan's inaugural address.

title: 2 QUEENS DISTRICTS LEAD CITY IN TEST ON STUDENT READING
description: Every elementary and junior high school in the two community school districts that cover northeastern Queens, Districts 25 and 26, had schoolwide reading scores above the national median last year, according to figures released yesterday by the city's Board of Education.

title: A Student Dies After Gym Mishap
description: A freshman at Camden Central High School who knocked heads with another student while wrestling in a gym class has died in a Syracuse hospital, school officials said.

title: Easley Gets Big Pact
description: Kenny Easley has signed a five- year contract to remain with the Seattle Seahawks, his agent said yesterday, and the defensive back's salary reportedly will be among the highest for a defensive player in the National Football League. Easley's agent,

title: PRESIDENT PRAISES FOES OF ABORTION
description: President Reagan today lent his support to one of the largest anti-abortion marches ever in the capital, telling tens of thousands of demonstrators that the tide of history was with them.

title: THE SCREEN: 'A SHORT CONFESSION BY LUIS BUNUEL'
description: LUIS BUNUEL, who officially departed this earth in August 1983 at age 83, is very much alive on film in ''A Short Confession by Luis Bunuel,'' the fine, moving, 30-minute documentary that tops the new bill opening today at the Film Forum.

title: WARSAW GENERAL DENIES SUSPICIONS
description: A general in the security police testified here today that although he directed a criminal investigation into the abduction and killing of a pro-Solidarity priest, he never suspected that a deputy who took part in the inquiry had any connection with the crime.

title: MUSIC: JUILLIARD'S MODERN 'FOCUS!'
description: FOR several years, around this time, the Juilliard School has presented a clutch of admission-free new-music concerts, recently grouped together grandly under the rubric ''The Juilliard Festival of Contemporary Music.'' Good music got played, some of it well. But these were mostly grab-bags, and it is to the credit of Joseph W. Polisi, Juilliard's new president, that he has turned to Joel Sachs of the Juilliard faculty and the Continuum new- music group and let Mr. Sachs bring some order to the proceedings.

title: ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $2,180,188 for the quarter and $3,081,220 for the year. c-Including extraordinary gains of $1,017,710 for the quarter and $1,645,292 for the year.

title: CERTAIN-TEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $18 million for plant closings.

title: The Ghosts of Khartoum
description: What can one make of the erratic ways of the Sudan's President Nimiery? Having done the decent thing in sheltering Jews fleeing Ethiopia, he insists that they cannot go directly to Israel, the one country that wants them. And having earned a reputation for moderation, he soils it by hanging a 76- year-old opponent and by chopping off the hands of thieves under a supposedly Islamic law he decreed in 1983.

title: Brzezinski in the Classroom
description: Classes began this week for the spring semester at Columbia University, and about 300 students crammed into Room A of the Law School to hear Prof. Zbigniew Brzezinski.

title: CIPHER DATA PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods reflect the acquisition of Spectra Logic Corp., which is accounted for on a pooling of interests basis and reflects the absorption of all associated expenses during the second quarter.

title: DEMOCRATS FILL KEY POSITIONS ON COMMITTEES IN THE HOUSE
description: House Democrats today filled 13 posts on key committees for the new Congress, and lawmakers with friends in high places in the party did particularly well.

title: No Headline
description: Tom McMillen scored a season-high 26 points in playing the whole game for injury-riddled Washington, which held off a fourth-quarter rally and handed Golden State its 12th consecutive defeat.

title: Tolerance
description: Aborted Last Saturday, dozens of women - some still groggy from anesthesia, some weeping - stood shivering in the icy wind outside the Eastern Women's Center in Manhattan. They had gone there to end their pregnancies, a right affirmed by the Supreme Court in its Roe v. Wade decision 12 years ago; but that right was obstructed by a bomb threat that evacuated the building.

title: The Magician And the Juggler
description: Sleight of hand and juggling attract some unlikely practitioners.

title: 2 INDICTED IN RING CONSPIRACY
description: Luis Resto, a professional boxer from New York, and Carlos (Panama) Lewis, his manager, were indicted yesterday for assault and for conspiring to defeat Billy Ray Collins Jr. by ''any means, fair or foul'' in their fight at Madison Square Garden on June 16, 1983.

title: DREW IS PENITENT AFTER DRUG RELEASE
description: Coach Frank Layden of the Utah Jazz says he saw the signs that led to John Drew's relapse into cocaine addiction early last December. He recalled such hints as the player's ''lack of responsibility'' and ''sluggishness'' during games.

title: Eric Voegelin, Philosopher, Author and Professor, Dies
description: Eric Voegelin, a German-born philosopher, author and professor who fled the Nazis from the University of Vienna during World War II, died last Saturday at his home on the campus of Stanford University in Stanford, Calif.

title: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: IT is one of those combinations that sometimes work brilliantly: A young designer brings a contemporary look to the

description: The Supreme Court finds itself in

title: OFF BROADWAY TICKET PRICES HAVE INCREASED TO MATCH THOSES OF BROADWAY
description: Off Broadway, which has long been an artistic rival to Broadway, now has the ticket prices to match.

description: b-Including a gain of $7.4 million from petroleum LIFO inventory liquidation. c-Including a gain of $14.8 million from the adjustment of a crude oil entitlements reserve and sale of certain foreign operations.

description: b-Including approximately $950,000, or 12 cents a share, from the settlement of two lawsuits.

William L. White, 47, Teacher At Harvard Business School
description: William L. White, the Sylvan C. Coleman Professor of Financial Management at the Harvard Business School, died of leukemia Monday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He was 47 years old and lived in Newtonville, Mass.

title: DBA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mother's Sp"atzle TO THE LIVING SECTION
description: Your recipe for sp"atzle in ''Pasta of Distinction, Meaning, 'By Hand' '' (Jan.9) reminded me of my mother's: Put some flour in a bowl, put in two eggs and some salt; beat, adding water to make a stiff dough.

title: GOVERNMENT FACES SUIT ON 10 COLOR ADDITIVES
description: A consumer group sued the Government today to ban 10 artificial color additives, including three that constituted half the food dyes consumed by Americans in 1984.

title: BALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: Q.

title: L.I. Trash Carters Are Sued by State
description: Robert Abrams, the State Attorney General, filed suit today against 24 garbage- carting companies on Long Island and 25 of their executives, seeking a restructuring of the industry and millions of dollars in damages.

title: OFFICE WORKERS AT YALE ACCEPT CONTRACT, 890-2
description: Clerical workers overwhelmingly approved a labor contract with Yale University tonight, ending a labor-management struggle that led to a 10-week strike last fall.

title: EXCERPTS FROM CUOMO MESSAGE ON HIS PROPOSED STATE BUDGET
description: Following are excerpts from Governor Cuomo's budget message to the Legislature:

title: WHEN THE MUGGER IS DECLARED THE VICTIM
description: To the Editor:

title: Better Management for Welfare Services
description: By long tradition, New York City has made a point of extending help to residents in trouble. Indeed, some of its welfare programs have become national models. Yet in recent years the city's social service apparatus, mostly embodied in the superagency called the Human Resources Administration, has become so troubled that some people think it would make sense to break up H.R.A. and start over.

title: Jury in Sharon Trial Is Still Deliberating
description: The jury in Ariel Sharon's libel suit against Time magazine continued its deliberations yesterday without reaching a verdict on whether a disputed article was published with reckless disregard for the truth.

title: Alaska Pipeline Repaired
description: About 12 barrels of crude oil spilled today when crews began repairing a section of the trans-Alaska oil pipeline that had settled into the permafrost. The leak occurred as workers prepared to drain a 275-foot section of 48-inch pipe buried about 200 miles south of Prudhoe Bay, according to a spokesman for the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company. The spill was cleaned up, the spokesman said.

title: ;   WHEN THE MUGGER IS DECLARED THE VICTIM
description: To the Editor:

title: 76ers 101, Cavaliers 100
description: Maurice Cheeks tipped in Moses Malone's missed shot with four seconds to play for the victory. Philadelphia, whose 13-game winning streak was snapped with a loss in Boston on Sunday, fought back from a 58-49 halftime deficit to take its first lead at 76-75 on Clint Richardson's layup and free throw with a minute to go in the third quarter.

title: EAST COAST SEA SCALLOP INDUSTRY SEEMS ON WANE
description: Martin Manley had just spent two sleepless days guiding his dredging boat home from a 10-day hunt for scallops, but it was the catch, not fastigue, that was getting him down.

title: CUOMO PROPOSES INCOME-TAX CUTS IN STATE BUDGET
description: Governor Cuomo today proposed a $38.8 billion state budget that calls for an 8 percent increase in spending combined with a broad range of personal income-tax cuts.

title: CONSOLIDATED EDISON CO OF NY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HAPPY EVENTS MOVE MANY CONTRIBUTORS TO AID THE NEEDIEST
description: The celebrators of happy events, such as a birth or a wedding, often express gratitude for their good fortune by contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: U.S. PLANE DOWN IN HONDURAS
description: A United States Air Force transport plane carrying 21 American soldiers crashed today off the northern coast of Honduras, a Pentagon spokesman said tonight.

title: New Offer for Gooden
description: The Mets have improved their contract offer to their star second-year pitcher,

description: b-Net loss.

title: PARAGUAY PLEDGES ACTION ON COCAINE
description: The President of Paraguay and other Paraguayan officials promised two visiting members of Congress last week that the Asuncion Government would destroy 49,000 gallons of chemicals believed to have been intended for the manufacture of cocaine, United States officials said today.

title: U.S. FAILS TO SATISFY HONDURAN DEMANDS
description: A special visit here last week by President Reagan's national security adviser failed to satisfy Honduran demands for greater security guarantees and aid from the United States, according to Honduran and Western officials.

title: CYPRESS SAVINGS ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
France Said to Assure India on Spying Case
description: The French Government has informed India that it wll take ''punitive action'' against a recalled diplomat accused in news reports of spying for the United States Central Intelligence Agency, a newspaper reported today.

title: Feline Mystique
description: Every dog has its day, and now, thanks to a a pair of computer research scientists who were given a Siamese cat as a wedding present 20 years ago, cats will have their weekend. The first Madison Square Garden International Cat Show, with 800 entries from as far away as Japan, France and Alaska, will open Friday at the Garden's Exposition Rotunda and run through Sunday.

title: OFFICIALS RULE OUT PROPELLER LOSS AS CAUSE OF CRASH THAT KILLED 67
description: Government investigators yesterday ruled out the possibility that a loss of propeller blades led to the crash of a chartered airliner in Reno, Nev., Monday that killed 67 people.

title: Namath and Staubach in Pro Hall
description: Joe Namath, the former Jet quarterback whose spectacular passes and outsized personality helped to establish the old American Football League and paved the way for its merger with the National Football League, was elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame yesterday.

title: REAGAN'S FARM BILL SEEKS MARKET BASIS FOR AID, BLOCK SAYS
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, outlining the major provisions of the Reagan Administration's farm bill, says they will call for ''revolutionary'' changes in national agriculture policy.

title: ALZA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,079,000 for the quarter and $2,970,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $290,000 for the quarter and $588,000 for the year.

title: WINE TALK
description: AMONG the victims of the worldwide wine glut are the Chianti growers and wine makers of Italy. In spite of serious efforts on their part in recent years, the image of Chianti remains unclear in the minds of many American consumers. There is the nagging problem for Chianti: the image of the straw-covered flask filled with cheap, rough wine meant to accompany spaghetti - the kind of stuff Rodolfo would have served Mimi in ''La Boh eme.''

title: BUSINESSLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: OPERA: MARGARET PRICE MAKES MET DEBUT IN 'OTELLO'
description: MAJOR singers who come late to the Metropolitan Opera for one reason or another are not rarities. Voice fans can rattle off a dozen famously delayed debuts and work up a head of steamy indignation in doing so. Even so, the debut of Margaret Price, in the season's first ''Otello'' Monday night, must rate among the least understandable of such cases. Miss Price, a Welsh soprano who has been busy in many of the world's opera houses for more than 20 years, owns a major voice, and in the role of Desdemona she proved she knows how to use it. Her singing of the death scene, one of the juiciest moments for soprano in all of opera, was a model of tonal purity, with enough depth of expression to keep one involved in her portrayal of the bewildered Desdemona.

title: AN ELUSIVE KARPOV, AND A DRAW
description: Throughout the major part of the 44th game of the world championship chess match in Moscow on Monday, it looked as though the challenger, 21- year-old Gary Kasparov, held a slight advantage. But he could not pin down the elusive Anatoly Karpov to anything serious, and the result was another draw.

title: John A. Guzzetta Dies at 54; A Trial Lawyer in Manhattan
description: John A. Guzzetta, a trial lawyer who had been on the staff of the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a brief illness. He was 54 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CHILTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid on Nov. 30, 1984.

title: PAPERS INDICATE MENGELE MAY HAVE BEEN HELD AND FREED AFTER WAR
description: Newly declassified United States intelligence documents indicate that Josef Mengele, widely regarded as the most notorious German war criminal still at large, may have been arrested and released in the American occupation zone of Vienna after World War II.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: PLETHORA OF PLAYS Where are the new playwrights? One place they, or their work, will be is at the New Dramatists, 424 West 44th Street (757-6960), which is putting on 36 mini-plays by as many of its members, between today and Sunday. Each piece is new, lasts from two to five minutes, and will be read, script in hand, by as many as eight actors.

title: SELL CONRAIL TO THE PUBLIC
description: It seems likely that the Transportation Department soon will recommend the sale of the Government's 85 percent stake in Conrail to one of three private bidders for $1.2 billion. If approved by Congress, the sale would be the biggest giveaway since Manhattan was sold to the Dutch in 1626 for $24.

title: Propp Suspended
description: The National Hockey League suspended

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: ORWELL: The Road to Airstrip One. By

title: WINGS' 4-GOAL 3D THWARTS ISLANDERS
description: The Detroit Red Wings rallied from a two- goal deficit in the third period and defeated the Islanders, 5-4, tonight with John Ogrodnick scoring the winner with 2 minutes 53 seconds left at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Fleeting Fame In Perspective
description: Ernie Broglio could always laugh about it, even before it became evident that he was a sore-armed pitcher traded for a future Hall of Famer, Lou Brock. Every time there was a one-sided baseball trade, he would laugh. In fact, he said the day Brock retired was one of his saddest ''because now no one will be telephoning me.''

title: WALKER'S SHOT WIN'S AGAIN
description: It is getting to be a habit with Darrell Walker: two games, two pressure shots in the closing seconds, two Knick victories.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TESTING & CERTIFICATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Including a tax credit of $160,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net losses.

description: WASHINGTON In most democratic countries at the

title: SETON HALL REMAINS IN BIGEAST'S PLANS
description: Are the Big East and its weakest member, Seton Hall, headed for a divorce? Dave Gavitt, the conference commissioner, says no. Despite its 10- 62 record in conference play, Seton Hall is on solid ground, Gavitt says.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Landon Turner , the Indiana University basketball star who was paralyzed in an auto accident in 1981, has been hired by Indiana University- Purdue University at Indianapolis. Turner, 24, was named acting cooridnator of minority affairs at the school. He will be responsible for minority recruitment and counseling. . . .

title: APOLLO COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,950,000.

title: PAYCHECKS TO GROW IN JULY UNDER THE CUOMO TAX PLAN
description: Withholding on New York State taxes would decline on July 1 under Governor Cuomo's proposed tax-reduction plan, the Governor said today.

title: CALUMET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POLICE TO ROUND UP HOMELESS WHEN A COLD WAVE GRIPS CITY
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that the police would remove homeless people from the streets during periods of severe cold and take them to municipal hospitals whether they were willing to go or not.

title: BOY, 7, IS WITNESS IN CALIFORNIA CHILD ABUSE CASE
description: A 7-year- old boy testified today that he had played ''naked games'' at the Virginia McMartin Preschool near here and that in at least one of the games teachers at the school had touched his genital organs.

title: A Drought Warning Is Issued By Panel on Delaware Basin
description: A drought warning has been issued because of low levels in the Delaware River basin, which supplies New York City and portions of New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware, the Delaware River Basin Commission said today.

title: READING TEST SCORES FOR NEW YORK SCHOOLS
description: Following are the scores, released by the New York City Board of Education, on the reading tests given in the city's public elementary schools and junior high schools in April 1984.

title: CHEROKEE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $323,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Cruel Climate
description: How cold was it? It was so cold that the cold buffet was frozen. It was so cold that reporters in the press tent were typing with gloves on their hands.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: WHAT does a British pop superstar have in common with a group of young jazz musicians? One of the year's most promising album projects, now getting under way. The Briton is Sting, the songwriter, singer and bassist for the Police, whose mixture of pop and international rhythms has paid off in hit singles; ''Synchronicity,'' the band's most recent album, has sold 11 million copies worldwide. After film roles in ''Dune,'' ''The Bride'' and ''Plenty,'' Sting's next step is a solo album - and giving his latest songs a jazzy twist.

title: WHEN THE MUGGER IS DELCARED THE VICTIM
description: To the Editor:

title: 12 IN NEW YORK WIN SCIENCE AWARDS
description: Twelve high school students from New York State, including four from Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, were among the 40 national winners in the 44th annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search for the nation's most promising future scientists.

title: FEAR OF ICE DELAYS SHUTTLE LAUNCHING
description: The threat of icy weather conditions caused a 24-hour postponement today of the launching of the space shuttle Discovery on the first secret military mission by a crew of American astronauts.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: St. Peter's vs. South Florida, 5:30 P.M., and St. John's vs. Syracuse, 8 P.M., at Madison Square Garden. Both the Redmen and the Orangemen are battling to keep up with Georgetown in the Big East, but Syracuse lost a step when it was upset by Connecticut on Saturday. The Orange may be at a big disadvantage if their star sophomore guard, Dwayne Washington, is unable to play because of a sprained ankle. (Television - USA Network, 8 P.M. live, and 2 A.M. tape. Radio - WCBS 880, 8 P.M. St. John's game only. (Radio - WNJR 1430, 5:30 P.M. live, St. Peter's game only).

title: GRADCO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 5
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $1.1 million related to an adjustment of inventory and other assets. c-Net income including tax credits of $216,000 for the quarter and $817,000 for the 9 months.

title: AGENT'S PURPORTED SPY CONFESSION TO F.B.I. HELD ADMISSIBLE IN COURT
description: A Federal district judge today rejected a motion to exclude what the Federal Bureau of Investigation called a confession and other damaging statements from the trial of Richard W. Miller, the first bureau agent to be charged with espionage.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: FOR as long as I can remember I have had a special fondness for poule-au-pot, a French dish that is basically chicken cooked with vegetables. It must have been created during the cold months, because all the recipes I have seen call for winter vegetables - carrots, onions, parsnips and so on. The most authentic recipes also call for stuffing the chicken with ground sausage meat, bread crumbs, chicken liver or some other ingredient; but this would remove the recipe from the 60-minute category.

title: ORGANIZING WINE CELLARS BY COMPUTER
description: WHEN John A. Chunko, an advertising consultant, decides to select a bottle from the ''state of the art'' wine cellar going into his new home in Princeton, N.J., he will tell his I.B.M. PC XT personal computer, ''Do wine.'' The sole drawback of his custom-designed dBase III softwear program, he says, is that ''it can't print out the label - but it can do anything else.''

title: RESPONDING TO THE CALL TO CUT FATS, CHOLESTEROL
description: AFTER a succession of medical reports over the last 10 years linking cardiovascular disease to a high- fat, high-cholesterol diet, the National Institutes of Health last month issued its own call to Americans to lower their blood cholesterol levels by reducing daily fat intake to 30 percent of total calories and cholesterol intake to 250 to 300 milligrams. On average, the American diet contains 43 percent fat and 485 milligrams of cholesterol.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: FACE OF THE PEACE CORPS TODAY
description: THUMBING through The Greeley Daily Tribune over breakfast last week, Gus Graves read that the Peace Corps was looking for 600 volunteers to provide famine relief in Africa. The article listed a toll-free telephone number and Mr. Graves called. ''I've always felt sorry for those little kids I've seen on TV and all,'' said the 47- year-old mechanic from Greeley, Colo. ''It just gets to you. I guess I'm one of them bleeding hearts.''

title: Odd Number
description: Before this season began, only 86 players had ever worn an Islander jersey in the 12-year history of the club. But in this injury-riddled season, the team has had new faces arriving almost daily, and the count now is up to 94.

title: CHURCH MEMBERS WILL PRESS SANCTUARY MOVEMENT
description: The woman, who is in her 30's and has four young children, does not want to give her name.

title: FILM: 'FALASHA' LIMNS ETHIOPIAN JEWS' PLIGHT
description: SIMCHA JACOBOVICI'S documentary film, ''Falasha: Exile of the Black Jews of Ethiopia,'' is a quietly anguished examination of a 2,000-year- old culture facing extinction. The title, which means ''Stranger'' in Amharic, is the word with which some Ethiopians label their Jewish compatriots. It is considered derogatory by the Jews, who refer to themselves as Beta Israel, or House of Israel. Ethiopia's Jewish community, which according to legend descends from Solomon and Sheba, has remained intact during centuries of anti-Semitism, despite its isolation. Today it numbers about 25,000.

title: THE INAUGURATION OF PRESIDENT REAGAN, AN AMERICAN PAGEANT
description: THE inaugural wasn't really in Washington, of course; it was on television, beginning with the gala Saturday night, and winding down on the news shows yesterday morning. The gala wasn't great; the news shows were repetitious, but the inaugural itself was a smash. Dan Rather got teary, Ronald Reagan held his wife's hand, everyone worried about the high-school bands. Television was an instrument of Government and the great American hearth.

title: BRIEF LUXURY: AN APARTMENT MADE FOR A MOVIE
description: ''YOU can see the Brooklyn, Williamsburg and Manhattan Bridges, the World Trade Center, Ellis Island, the Statue of Liberty and the Empire State Building,'' said Fred Caruso of the dramatic loft space, a set created for the one of the main characters of ''Year of the Dragon,'' a forthcoming movie directed by Michael Cimino. Added Mr. Caruso, who is the executive in charge of production for the film: ''There is traffic and movement, boats, smoke, life - all real.''

title: G.E.-APPLE DEAL
description: The General Electric Company said it and Apple Computer Inc. are offering a new telecommunications service called Applelink, a prototype for a commercial version to be called Dealertalk. The company said Dealertalk, scheduled for commercial availability early in the second quarter, would use Apples's Macintosh personal computer as an intelligent work station linked to G.E.'s worldwide telecommunications network. The system would allow communications between companies and dealers or distributors.

title: J.S. BACH: GENIUS, PASSION AND PFENNIG-PINCHING
description: HERE we are in 1985, honoring the 300th anniversary of the births of Johann Sebastian Bach, George Frideric Handel and Domenico Scarlatti. There is no doubt who bulks largest. All over the world for the immediate future we are going to be hearing the music of Johann Sebastian. Everybody in music is rushing to pay homage, especially in Germany, where Bach is going to be heard in toto. Record companies are geared up. Musicologists are preparing lengthy studies.

title: Juilliard Dance Director Will Retire in May

description: Dr. Paul Harteck, co-discoverer in 1934 of tritium, the heaviest form of hydrogen, and later co-designer of the world's largest atmospheric simulation chamber, died Monday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 82 years old.

title: Pay the Meese, and Jordan, Bills Lawyers for Edwin Meese, President Reagan's nominee for Attorney General, are asking a Washington court to award more than $700,000 in fees for work to clear him of criminal wrongdoing. That creates a problem for the Justice Department, which almost reflexively resists high fee awards. It has asked the court for more time to give its views. If the department wants to advance the aims of the Ethics in Government Act, it won't oppose a generous award.
description: The department has been arguing routinely that successful civil rights plaintiffs deserve no more than $75 an hour in legal reimbursements, an amount Washington attorneys consider meager. Mr. Meese's lawyers are said to ask $250 an hour, close to the going rate in Washington.

title: A.T.&T. Cable
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it and 21 other companies had approved an agreement to construct and maintain the first undersea cable to span the Pacific with laser-powered, digital light- wave communications technology. The system would cost $593 million and is tentatively scheduled to begin service at the end of 1988, A.T.&T. said. United States international service carriers would own about 63 percent of the cable.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Cigna Executive Named President
description: The Cigna Corporation said yesterday that Hartzel Z. Lebed had been named president.

title: Judge Gives Landlord A Jail Term in Death
description: The landlord of an unheated Upper Manhattan apartment building where an elderly woman died was fined $221,000 yesterday and sentenced to 30 days in jail by a City Housing Court judge.

title: SIR ARTHUR BRYANT, BRITISH PILOT AND HISTORIAN
description: Sir Arthur Bryant, the British fighter pilot-turned-popular historian who wrote stirring chronicles of high points in his country's past, died after a brief illness late Tuesday at New Hall Hospital in Salisbury in southern England. He was 85 years old.

title: A DIGNIFIED DEMISE
description: BOSTON Not so long ago it would have been an unthinkable economic notion: the pound worth little more than the dollar. But when it happened last week, when the pound sank to $1.12, there was no great fuss.

description: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y.

title: WALL ST. TRADERS OPPOSING PHILLIPS REFINANCING
description: Wall Street traders are becoming increasingly opposed to the refinancing of the Phillips Petroleum Company amid persistent speculation that Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier, may play a key role in trying to force the big Oklahoma oil company to sweeten the deal.

description: A Colombian plane crashed today and another was reported missing in remote mountain areas, a civil aviation spokesman said.

title: BAKER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ARMS CONTROL ILLUSIONS
description: Even some enthusiasts of arms control acknowledged that there was something almost dementedly disproportionate in the coverage, by the press and television, of the Shultz-Gromyko meeting in Geneva. What troubled these enthusiasts was the danger that excessive expectations might be aroused - hopes that would then lead to disappointments that would in turn bring discredit upon the entire process of arms control negotiations. But what if the journalistic treatment of Geneva in fact inadvertently exposed a truth about the illusions surrounding arms control that have taken root in our political culture in general?

title: Former Flyer Injured
description: Daryl Stanley , a former Philadelphia Flyer who has been playing for the club's minor league affiliate in Hershey, Pa., suffered a dislocated neck verterbrae and other injuries when his sports car ran into a concrete wall Monday night. Yesterday, as he lay in serious condition at the Hershey Medical Center, he was charged with drunken driving.

title: Bell Atlantic-MAI
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said it plans to acquire MAI Canada Inc., the Canadian subsidiary of Management Assistance Inc., for $23 million. MAI Canada sells and services Basic Four computer products and had revenues of $47 million for the 12 months ended Sept. 30.

Foster Winans, the former reporter who is on trial with two others in Federal District Court in Manhattan on charges of conspiring to trade on advance information about what would appear in The Journal's ''Heard on the Street'' column.

title: WARNING TO GO ON ASPIRIN LABELS

title: Money Market Rates Dip
description: The Dime Savings Bank continues to offer the highest yield on money market accounts among a group of 17 banks and savings institutions in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, according to figures compiled by The Bank Rate Monitor of Florida. But yields nationwide eased.

title: TWO HOMELESS PUT IN HOSPTIAL AGAINST WISHES
description: Two homeless people were taken by the police to municipal hospitals against their will Tuesday night under a new city policy to get the homeless off the streets in extreme cold weather.

FREEDOM SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for 1984    Net inc
description: b-Net loss.

City Investing Sets Servomation Sale
description: The City Investing Company, a manufacturing, services and financial concern, said it had reached a definitive agreement to sell its Servomation Corporation foods unit to the Allegheny Beverage Corporation of Baltimore for $225 million in cash.

title: Tandon Sees Difficult Period The Tandon Corporation said
description: that earnings and sales for its
