title: GENERAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
ON BLAMING ISRAEL FOR ARAB REJECTIONISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Juilliard Presents 3d In Contemporary Series
description: Juilliard presented the third concert of its ''Focus!'' series Tuesday in the Juilliard Theater. On the whole the program, though it certainly had its pleasures, made a stronger case for Juilliard as a lively and responsible conservator of history than for the particular slice of history in question - the decade 1945-55 - as an exciting period in music.

title: G.O.P. ASSAILS 'SURPLUS' IN THE CUOMO BUDGET
description: The Republican leaders in the State Senate accused Governor Cuomo today of camouflaging hundreds of millions of ''surplus'' dollars in his budget and said additional tax cuts would be required to win their support.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE FINISHING SCHOOL. By Gail Godwin. 322 pages. Viking. $16.95.

title: CHINA-VIETNAM ATTACKS GROW
description: China said today that its forces had counterattacked against Vietnam in recent days after weeks of ''provocations'' along the border.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Advanced Micro Devices, a computer equipments concern based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it would build a wafer fabrication plant near Dublin.

title: JAMES BEARD, AUTHORITY ON FOOD, DIES
description: James Beard, the bald and portly chef and cookbook writer who was one of the country's leading authorities on food and drink and its foremost champion of American cooking, died of cardiac arrest yesterday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bach Music and Letters In Chamber Concerts
description: ''Bach et Alia: Music and Missives,'' a series of chamber concerts by the flutist Eugenia Zukerman and the harpsichordist Anthony Newman, will present the music of the Bach family, Handel and Scarlatti along with readings from their letters at the Trustees Room (206) of the New York Central Research Library, Fifth Avenue at 42d Street.

title: Debt
description: Air Products and Chemicals Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $200 million of debt securities.

title: 2 Bills Restrict Moves by Teams
description: Two bills introduced in Congress today would prevent professional sports teams from moving from city to city, unless they were losing money or playing in inadequate arenas.

title: DOMINION TEXTILE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Jupiter Symphony Performs Beethoven
description: Jens Nygaard and his Jupiter Symphony of New York freelancers have it in them to make you feel you've really heard the music at hand, even if the execution is occasionally less than expert and the conception not particularly original. So they did Sunday evening at Tully Hall in a pair of familiar Beethoven works, the first Leonore overture and the First Piano Concerto.

title: Meredith Monk
description: Meredith Monk will make her Carnegie Hall debut with a retrospective concert of her music on Feb. 7 at 8 P.M., for singers, keyboards, cello and percussion.

title: United Technologies Up 8.5%
description: The United Technologies Corporation said profits rose 8.5 percent in the fourth quarter on a 13 percent sales increase. It attributed the improvements to cost-reduction programs, increased productivity and higher volume at most subsidiaries.

title: CABOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GUATEMALAN REPRESSION WITH U.S. ASSISTANCE

title: TWO KINDS OF BANKING WORTH KEEPING APART
description: To the Editor:

title: Coast Bank Wins Ruling
description: The Bank of America won a ruling in Superior Court today in a class action lawsuit that charged the bank with breaching its fiduciary duty to its trust beneficiaries by depositing their cash in accounts with no interest or below-market interest rates.

title: General Foods Off 25.2%
description: The General Foods Corporation reported yesterday that its net income fell 25.2 percent in the third fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 29. It blamed the strong dollar and lower earnings from powdered beverages and its Oscar Mayer meat subsidiary.

title: ALASKA MUTUAL BANK (ANCHORAGE, ALASKA) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ENVIRONMENTAL BEDFELLOWS
description: Although usually portrayed as mortal enemies, environmentalists and budget-cutters in the Reagan Administration actually have a great deal in common.

title: COMPUTER SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $9.5 million principally from the sale of Paid Prescriptions Inc. and including the planned phase-down of certain ancillary product and service offerings.

title: HANDMADE RUGS AT CRAFTS MUSEUM
description: A SHOW that opens tomorrow at the American Craft Museum II should interest a broad range of visitors. Called ''For the Floor,'' it deals with handcrafted rugs; the techniques used are weaving, knotting, hooking and felting, with flat weaves most in evidence.

title: French Pact in China
description: The French communications company CIT-Alcatel has concluded a $52 million contract for a telephone exchange in Peking, French officials said here today. The contract is a breakthrough for French technology in China, which announced in October that it would spend $3.7 billion to modernize its telecommunications system by 1990.

title: LUKENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss; the 1983 net includes $4,625,000 writedown of certain assets.

title: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The net income for the latest quarter and year include a pretax gain of $23.5 million from the sale of timberland, a pretax charge of $10.1 million on a reduction in the value of certain assets and a pretax charge of $12 million representing the company's initial estimate of the buyback penalty to be paid under the recently enacted Timber Contract Payment Modification Act. The 1984 net income also includes a pretax gain of $33.6 million from the sale of the company's investment in National Gypsum Co. Net income for the year-ago quarter and year include a gain of $4.8 million from the sale of a fibreboard plant.

title: VULCAN MATERIALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: MAJOR CHANGE IN IMMIGRATION TO CITY IS SEEN
description: New York City, where millions of European immigrants first saw the New World, is still a city with many newcomers. But virtually all of today's arrivals are Asians, blacks or Hispanic people, according to the city's Office of Immigration Affairs.

title: Iona Triumphs For 15-1 Mark NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.,
description: Tony Hargraves scored 19 points to pace

title: Israeli Accord On Economy
description: Israel's Government, workers and manufacturers agreed today on an eight-month package of price controls designed to regulate the economy and control inflation, the State Radio said.

title: Chess: 36 Moves, 39th Draw
description: Anatoly Karpov, the world chess champion, agreed to a draw offered by Gary Kasparov on the 36th move of the 45th game of their title match today.

title: VERSA TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $105,500 from the reversal of previously deferred income tax.

title: LABOR PACT AT YALE
description: The contract ratified Tuesday night by office workers at Yale University is a single labor agreement covering a relatively small work force of 2,500.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bristol-Myers Co. announced that Randall J. Wall had been named president of Unitek Corp., a subsidiary based in Monrovia, Calif., that manufactures orthodontic and dental supplies.

title: Jeanette Kim, Piano, In Bach and Prokofiev
description: Only about 40 people made it through Saturday evening's cold to hear Jeanette Kim play the piano at Merkin Concert Hall. Miss Kim, however, is a good young pianist - one whose technique, taste and musicality are already more or less in place.

title: FIRST NATIONAL SUPERMARETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 8
description: b-Net losses. c-After an extraordinary charge of $120,000 from the reversal of tax credits. d-Including a gain of $2,743,000 on the termination of a pension plan and a tax credit of $1,757,000.

title: DATA CARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Including gains of $105,000 for the quarter and $391,000 for the 9 months from the utilization of prior year's accounting losses.

title: Long, Long Game
description: It may not have been the longest basketball game ever played in high school, but they will remember the game Tuesday night for a long time in Kansas City, Mo. The game went eight overtimes before Park Hill High got the edge on North Kansas City High and ended the marathon, 66-63.

title: 6-1 Shot Wins At Gulfstream
description: Aristocratic Cross, who had traffic trouble when he finished seventh in the Tropical Park Derby 18 days ago, got a clear trip on the outside today and drew off to an eight-length victory in the $41,125 Floridian Handicap for Florida-bred 3-year-olds at Gulfstream Park.

title: Baseball Talks Are Snagged
description: Negotiations for a new labor agreement between baseball's players and club owners suffered another setback yesterday, this time over the effort by the Los Angeles Dodgers to induce some of their players to agree to mandatory drug testing.

title: Remains of U.S. Aircraft Found Off Honduras
description: Rescuers searching the Honduran coastline today uncovered the remains of a United States military transport plane that crashed into the Caribbean Sea but found no trace of the 21 Americans aboard, the American Embassy said.

title: Abbado at Carnegie Hall
description: Claudio Abbado will conduct the Chamber Orchestra of Europe, a group formed by former members of the European Community Youth Orchestra, when it performs Feb. 10 at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall as part of its first United States tour. The program will include Mozart's ''Posthorn'' Symphony in D major (K. 320), Ligeti's ''Ramifications,'' Brahms's Serenade No. 1 in D major (Op. 11) and songs from ''Das Knaben Wunderhorn'' by Mahler, with the soprano Hildegard Behrens. Tickets are $10 to $17.50 and are available through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: Dachau Visit Unlikely
description: Administration officials say that President Reagan has decided against visiting a concentration camp in West Germany this spring because, according to one aide, ''the Germans of today are not a part of that and shouldn't be made to feel that they are.''

title: UTAH BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BROCKWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss after a pretax charge of $14.2 million to cover a plant closing. c-After a pretax charge of $7.5 million to cover the cost of a plant closing and other plant realignments, which was partially offset by an unspecified gain from the sale of a plant. d-After a pretax charge of $14.2 million to cover a plant closing and a $3 million pretax gain from a settlement in an antitrust action.

title: IRAN PREMIER VISITS NICARAGUA
description: The Prime Minister of Iran, Mir Hussein Moussavi, arrived here today for talks with Government leaders. According to an official communique, he is expected to stay until Friday.

title: Lawyer Confirms Role In Death Plot on Barbie
description: A French lawyer who tracked down Klaus Barbie and other accused German war criminals says he joined an assassination plot against Mr. Barbie in 1982 and would support other such plots against important Nazi fugitives if all legal recourse to their seizure were blocked.

PENNSYLVANIA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CREDIT MARKETS ;   Note and Bond Prices Rise
description: Increasing confidence that inflation will remain low and the willingness of some investors to shift funds out of low-yielding short-term securities led to a modest rise in Treasury note and bond prices yesterday.

title: LIMIT ON TESTIMONY IS CONSIDERED IN POLISH TRIAL
description: The seven judges presiding over the murder trial of four security policemen began deliberating today over whether to limit testimony or to call additional witnesses, whose statements in open court could implicate higher-ups in the slaying of a pro-Solidarity priest.

title: Bridge:A New Negative Response To Strong Opening Is Tried
description: Almost all tournament players use the cheapest suit as a negative response to a strong opening, whether that is two clubs or one club. But a few experts with an urge to experiment are trying something slightly different.

title: GRADING THE SPEECH
description: WASHINGTON Every Inaugural Address deserves a review, treating both

title: Outlook Hopeful
description: Shirley Muldowney , the drag racer who has been unable to walk unaided since she suffered severe leg injuries in a crash last June, underwent a three-hour operation in Indianapolis, and afterward her orthopedic surgeon said she should be back on her feet within six months. ''It looks just like the leg's been stuck into an Erector set,'' said Dr.

title: SAVINGS BANK OF PUGET SOUND reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BLACK CABLE NETWORK MARKING 5 YEARS ON AIR
description: For the nation's 27 million black viewers, the selection of programs featuring blacks or highlighting black concerns on broadcast television has always been limited at best.

title: Mr. Cuomo Cuts the Right Taxes
description: There's a silent message attached to Governor Cuomo's proposal to reduce New York's personal income taxes over three years while renewing expiring excise taxes. The Governor believes the income tax cut will help to hold and attract business, creating more jobs. But the shift could also begin to reduce New York's vulnerability to the proposed national tax reform.

Webber's Requiem Set For St. Thomas Benefit
description: Andrew Lloyd Webber's new Requiem Mass will receive its first public performance at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53d Street, Feb. 24 at 8 P.M. before an invited audience as a benefit for the Holy Apostles Church Soup Kitchen for the Homeless and Poor of New York.

title: ADAGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Market Place;   Positive Tilt On G.M. Stock
description: WHEN the blue chips finally came to life on Monday in a surging stock market, a frequent comment on Wall Street was that ''the generals have started to catch up with the rest of the army of smaller issues.'' One general clearly on the move this week is the General Motors Corporation, whose shares sold yesterday at their loftiest price since 1973.

title: 9 PLEAD NOT GUILTY IN TUCSON TO SMUGGLING ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: While nine leaders of the American sanctuary movement pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court here today to charges of illegally smuggling Central Americans into this country, about 100 refugees they helped bring in gathered in a synagogue to condemn United States policy in that part of the world.

title: SHULTZ'S VISITOR REBUFFED
description: A seven-foot figure with a puppet head took up a position in front of the State Department and passed out photos of children killed in Nicaragua. The captions read: ''My children murdered in San Gregorio by U.S.A. trained and armed men. Please.

title: Court Upholds Cleveland On Plan for Firefighters
description: An appeals court today upheld the Cleveland Fire Department's plan to redress racial imbalance in its leadership, overruling assertions by white firefighters that the promotion plan discriminated against them.

title: LOSING, JOHNSON STILL BRASH
description: A year after he beat the Austrians at their own national sport, Bill Johnson says he is supremely hopeful of another skiing victory. The 1984 Olympic champion in the men's downhill has his sights fixed on the skiing world championships starting at the end of the month in Bormio, Italy.

title: VIDEO DISPLAY reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Clark and Volvo Plan Joint Venture
description: The Clark Equipment Company, which produces heavy equipment, agreed yesterday to merge construction machinery operations with A.B. Volvo, the Swedish automotive products concern.

title: Deaver's Ailment Unknown
description: President Reagan said today that chael K. Deaver, his close friend and White House deputy chief of staff, apparently was not seriously ill but that doctors ''can't seem to get a handle on what laid him low.''

title: Union Carbide
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said its board had decided to maintain its regular quarterly dividend of 85 cents a share, payable March 1 to shareholders of record on Feb. 7. Several suits seeking billions of dollars have been filed against the company as a result of the disaster at its Bhopal, India, plant.

title: ETHIOPIA TESTING FOR CHOLERA
description: The Ethiopian authorities say they are testing for cholera at a camp for famine victims.

title: Article 237718 -- No Title
description: The MacArthur Foundation of Chicago said yesterday that it had contracted to sell 10 properties in the New York metropolitan region for nearly half a billion dollars.

description: b-Net income. Net income for the latest year was reduced by a special net charge of $116.1 million related to a consolidation of worldwide manufacturing operations and the reevaluation of certain assets.

title: SOUTHERN METHODIST BEATS TEXAS, 54-46
description: Jon Koncak scored 18 points as Southern Methodist scored a 54-46 Southwest Conference victory over Texas tonight.

description: The latest second quarter and 6 months include operating results of the Bangor Punta Corp., acquired Feb. 1.

BATTLE ON PHONE-BOOTH ADS DELAYING NEW BUS SHELTERS
description: Nearly a decade after New York City's first bus stop shelters were built, a plan to put up new ones has been caught up in yet another dispute - this time about competition from telephone booths.

title: U.S. ISSUES GUIDELINES ON 'VERTICAL' ACCORDS
description: The Justice Department issued guidelines today that are intended to clarify what kinds of arrangements between manufacturers and distributors the antitrust division regards as lawful.

title: Mugger on E. 79th St. Robs Actress of Purse
description: The actress Carrie Nye was mugged yesterday at her East Side apartment building, the police said.

title: HOLMES'S EXIT STYLE: LAUGHS, TAUNTS AND RESPECT
description: Larry Holmes was convincing when he said this indeed was his ''last fight.'' So was Mrs. Larry Holmes.

title: Belcher Hurt in Crash
description: Kevin Belcher , the 23-year-old Giant guard, suffered a broken jaw and other injuries early yesterday when his car skidded under a jack- knifed car carrier on a snow-slick Pennsylvania highway and was then slammed from behind by another car that drove it further under the tractor-trailer. Belcher was reported in serious condition last night as he underwent surgery at Hamot Medical Center in Erie to repair the broken jaw, other facial fractures and a deep thigh gouge.

title: ELECTRONICS CORP OF AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $450,000 and a pretax gain of $8,823,000 from the sale of property. c-Net loss.

PAPAL SCIENCE GROUP RECOMMENDS A BAN ON SPACE WEAPONS
description: A scientific group that advises Pope John Paul II today recommended ''banning the placement and testing of all weapons in outer space.''

title: PROHIBITION URGED ON CIGARETTE ADS
description: The National Advisory Council on Drug Abuse today called for legislation to prohibit all advertising and promotion of cigarettes.

title: LONE RANGER HIDES AGAIN, BY MANDATE
description: The Lone Ranger's mask, which for the last five years has been the subject of a legal dispute initiated by the company that owns the rights to it, can once again be worn by the actor who made it famous.

title: MOSELEY, HALLGARTEN, ESTABROOK $ WEEDEN HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Arkansas Reporter Is Given 1984 Heywood Broun Award
description: A reporter for The Arkansas Democrat has received the 1984 Heywood Broun award from the Newspaper Guild for articles about the beating death of a black man in police custody 24 years earlier.

title: STAGE: MILAN KUNDERA'S 'JACQUES AND HIS MASTER'
description: If ever there was a Cultural Event, it is ''Jacques and His Master,'' the Milan Kundera play now at Harvard's American Repertory Theater. Not only is this production the American premiere of the Czechosolovak writer's sole stage work, but it also marks the American debut of Susan Sontag as a theater director. Leafing through the program, one half expects to discover Irving Howe and Philip Roth in the cast list. They're not, alas - although one is pleased to find such sturdy theatrical hands as Robert Drivas and Priscilla Smith.

title: Pan Am Picks Pratt Engines for New Jets
description: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it had picked Pratt & Whitney and International Aero Engines, a consortium initiated by Pratt & Whitney, to build the advanced engines for 28 jetliners it planned to buy from Airbus Industrie.

title: GATX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: Judges Will Hear Arguments On Trials in Bhopal Disaster
description: A panel of Federal judges will hear arguments Thursday on the proper place to try lawsuits against Union Carbide for the gas leak that killed more than 2,000 people last month at Bhopal, India.

title: REPLICA OF TEMPLE IS SAVED
description: The Indiana University Foundation was granted sole possession today of remnants of a replica of an 18th-century Chinese Buddhist temple built for the 1933 Chicago World's Fair.

title: BURR-BROWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1 million.

title: U.S. MAY INVESTIGATE MENGELE CASE
description: American and Canadian officials moved yesterday to investigate accounts that the Nazi fugitive Josef Mengele may have been captured and released in an American occupation zone after World War II and may have gained entry to Canada around 1962.

title: SYSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: TO achieve a deep, glass- smooth finish on furniture - the kind often referred to as a piano finish - it is essential to use a top-grade furniture varnish applied with the finest-quality soft- bristle paint brush. But the best tools and materials are not enough in many cases; even more important is preparing the wood before the varnish is applied.

title: Fur Coats Unclaimed After Inaugural Balls
description: Sixty guests at two inaugural balls who did not want to fight the crowd at the coat check Monday night went into the frigid air without their furs and other wraps and, by today, 25 still had not returned to pick them up, officials said.

title: Swiss Find Victim Of Reported Kidnapping
description: The 19-year-old grandson of Axel Springer, the head of West Germany's largest publishing empire, was found this evening at Klothen airport, near Zurich in Switzerland, after having been reported missing from a Swiss boarding school since late Sunday evening.

title: THEATER: PING CHONG'S 'NUIT BLANCHE'
description: THE plays of Ping Chong could be approached as the theatrical equivalent of archeological digs. They are many-layered, concealing secrets and containing civilizations within civilizations. As author and director, Mr. Chong is currently represented at La Mama Annex by a revival of his 1981 ''Nuit Blanche,'' to be followed next month by his new version of the ''Nosferatu'' story.

title: SILVERCREST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: BAKER'S STRESS ON TAX ISSUE
description: Repeatedly, at his confirmation hearing today, James A. Baker 3d insisted that no domestic issue was more important to President Reagan than enactment of a fairer, simpler tax code. That reinforced the view, increasingly accepted here, that the President's commitment to a tax simplification program of some kind should not be taken lightly and that the prospects of such legislation are therefore much brighter than they appeared to be a few weeks ago.

title: SHOW OF LANDSCAPE ARCHITECTURE PLANS
description: While gardens and parks lie blanketed by snow, a welcome glimpse of greenery comes from a new exhibition of landscape architecture drawings at Wave Hill's Glyndor Gallery.

title: Rocky Road
description: The way things have been going for Rocky Lockridge, there's a pretty good parlay of boxing underdogs in fights next month: Jorge Lujan to upset Eusebio Pedroza for the World Boxing Association featherweight title on Feb. 2 and Juan LaPorte to upset Barry McGuigan of Ireland on Feb. 23. Lockridge is hoping for big- money bouts with either Pedroza or McGuigan.

title: A YOUNG BALLERINA ON THE RISE
description: now in the spotlight as one of the most exciting young ballerinas of the New York City Ballet - is fire and ice. Her long, slender body is topped by a head of orange-golden hair that gives her the look of a day lily, but her manner is one of eloquent reserve. Her arched back and lyrical arms seem to define the air about them, whether she is dancing ballets by George Balanchine, Jerome Robbins, Peter Martins or Helgi Tomasson.

title: MORE POLICE TO COMBAT 'QUALITY OF LIFE' CRIMES
description: The city's Police Department is expanding a program dealing with such ''quality of life'' crimes as prostitution, drug dealing and vandalism, Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday.

title: Club Med U.S. Account Awarded to N.W. Ayer
description: The N.W. Ayer agency, which already does tourism advertising for the United States and for the Bahamas, has been hired by Club Med as the agency for its 17 United States vacation retreats.

title: SAN DIEGO MAYOR DENIES SECRET FUND SCHEME
description: Mayor Roger Hedgecock, testifying today against his lawyer's advice, denied charges that he had illegally funneled more than $350,000 into his 1983 mayoral campaign.

title: CONTRIBUTORS TO NEEDIEST STRESS HELPING DIRECTLY
description: Confronted by the harsh reality of New York City's poor, some contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are changing their practice of charity. Instead of invariably supporting organizations that emphasize religious affiliation or concern for broad public issues, they are giving to agencies directly helping those who are gravely in need.

title: GENERAL HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
G.M. Aide Hospitalized
description: Joseph Sanchez, the new president of the General Motors Corporation's Saturn car project, suffered a heart attack and has been admitted to a hospital intensive care unit, G.M. said today. Mr. Sanchez, 54 years old, had been head of G.M.'s Oldsmobile division until his appointment to the Saturn post two weeks ago. Saturn is G.M.'s high-technology, car-of-the-future project.

title: Increase in Juice Cost Seen
description: Florida's worst freeze of the century will raise the price consumers pay for orange juice, industry experts said today, but exactly how much of an increase remained uncertain.

title: World Airways
description: An administrative law judge decided that World Airways should be given permission to fly the potentially lucrative route between Miami and London. The judge, John N. Vittone, picked the carrier, based in Oakland, Calif., to replace Air Florida, which had stopped flying last July. The decision still requires approval from the Transportation Department and President Reagan.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report in some editions yesterday about Board of Education action on funds for remedial programs incorrectly reported a vote and debate on the issue. A corrective article appears on page B4.

title: HAPPY HUNDRED In this year of big round-number musical anniversaries - 300th for Bach and Scarlatti, for instance - Jerome Kern, who would have been 100 years old on Sunday, is a comparative parvenu, a youngster and an American who composed some of the best scores for the musical-comedy theater. Even so, a 100th anniversary calls for something special, and that is what is planned at Carnegie Recital Hall, 57th Street and Seventh Avenue (903-9700), starting today.
description: Concert performances are scheduled of three musicals Kern wrote nearly 70 years ago for the Princess Theater on West 39th Street, a 299- seat house not much larger than the recital hall, with room for a small orchestra and a limited number of performers.

title: Education Board Joins Action On Classes in Church Schools
description: The Board of Education has voted to join an appeal to the United States Supreme Court that, if successful, would permit public-school teachers to continue providing remedial classes at parochial schools.

title: SHUTTLE PREPARED FOR LIFTOFF TODAY
description: With a thaw in the air, technicians resumed preparations tonight in a second attempt to launch the space shuttle Discovery on its secret mission carrying an intelligence-gathering satellite.

title: 'Gimpel the Fool'
description: Jewish Opera at the Y will present a new English translation of David Schiff's opera ''Gimpel the Fool,'' based on the short story by Isaac Bashevis Singer, April 20 at 8:30 P.M. and April 21 at 2:30 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, telephone 427-6000. Tickets are $8.50 to $11, and can be charged by calling 831-8603.

title: 10-ALARM BLAZE ON 43D ST. IS FOUGHT BY 420 FIREMEN
description: A spectacular fire engulfed an eight- story warehouse on West 43d Street last night, forcing the evacuation of a neighboring motel, destroying an adjoining firehouse and sending blazing embers across the sky to buildings more than three blocks away.

title: Soviet to Allow Coca-Cola Sale
description: The Coca-Cola Company said today that it had been given permission to sell Coca-Cola in the Soviet Union this year in a deal that breaks Pepsico Inc.'s monopoly on cola sales there. Donald R. Keough, president of Coca-cola, recently completed a week of meetings with Soviet officials in Moscow, working out the details.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day yesterday misidentified a new journal that carries an article on Soviet military spending. It is Soviet Economy, published by V. H. Winston & Sons of Silver Spring, Md.

title: Snow
description: Elsewhere, Central Park slept

title: Waverly Consort Plays Medieval Program
description: The Waverly Consort's ''Music of the Medieval World,'' in five well-contrasted installments, won cheers from a large audience at its second performance Saturday in Alice Tully Hall.

title: ROYAL INTERNATIONAL OPTICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
All-Star Game With a Purpose
description: Professional basketball players will tell you that making the All-Star Game is an honor, but an honor that they would sometimes just as soon skip. The game is played in the middle of the season when legs and spirits are tired and many players would welcome a few days of rest.

title: ROYAL PALM SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BELL CANADA ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $8.8 million for the quarter and $22 million for the year and increases in the book value of a subsidiary of $21.6 million for the quarter and $62.6 million for the year.

title: GARDENIAS: EXOTIC BUT HARD TO GROW
description: WHAT has exquisitely scented white flowers and glossy, dark green foliage and invariably dies about a month after its purchase?

title: ALTOS COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
NEWMONT MINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest quarter include a pre-tax writeoff of $4,500,000 of capitalized costs relating to the cancellation of a copper property lease on the Papago Indian reservation in Arizona. According to the company, this writeoff reduced its net by $2,400,000.

title: THOUSAND TRAILS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ARCHIVES FOR PAPERS OF THE FAMOUS AND NOT VERY
description: Two decades ago Howard B. Gotlieb went to work for the library at Boston University and began collecting the personal papers not only of distinguished 20th-century authors but also of journalists, mystery writers, cartoonists, movie actors and similar figures, many less than famous.

title: Dole Staying Put, She Says
description: Rumors around town that Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole would resign to pursue 1988 political aspirations for her husband, Senator Bob Dole, have not gone unheard at the White House.

title: Key Rates
Monsanto Net Down 43.1%
description: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter fell 43.1 percent, to $41 million, or 55 cents a share, from $72 million, or 87 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: McGraw-Hill
description: Harold W. McGraw 3d, son of the chairman of McGraw-Hill and great- grandson of the founder, has been named group vice president-transportation of McGraw-Hill's Publications Company division and publisher of McGraw-Hill's Aviation Week and Space Technology magazines . He is 36 and formerly was vice president- corporate planning at the parent company.

title: Local Costs Rose By 4.7% Last Year
description: Driven by a modest surge in food and housing prices, the Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey region rose 4.7 percent in 1984, the regional Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: COMPO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Including a net gain of $3.4 million, or 99 cents a share, from the sale of the company's Waltham, Mass., facility.

title: Hiram Walker Shares Purchased
description: The Olympia & York Holdings Corporation of Toronto raised its stake in the Toronto-based Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. to 10,694,530 common shares, or 14.6 percent of the liquor company's shares outstanding.

title: ST. JOHN'S BEATS SYRACUSE, 82-80
description: St. John's played its most exciting game of the season last night as the Redmen, down by as many as 9 points in the second half, rallied to take Syracuse into overtime and then beat the Orangemen, 82-80, before 19,591 fans at Madison Square Garden.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BEARINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Soviet Leader Pledges Effort on Arms Talks
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, today promised a constructive approach to arms control talks with the United States and called for more international campaigns against nuclear weapons, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: Dollar Index Futures Next
description: The New York Cotton Exchange announced plans yesterday for trading futures based on the Federal Reserve's trade-weighted dollar index, calculated against a basket of 10 foreign currencies. If the Government approves the plan, as expected, trading could start by summer.

title: Judge Blocks Help for Cubans
description: An appellate court judge today prohibited Cuban refugees jailed at the Federal penitentiary here from getting any more help from Federal District Judge Marvin Shoob, and said their deportations were likely.

title: 5 WHO DISRUPTED CHURCH GO TO JAIL IN PITTSBURGH
description: Five men who disrupted a Lutheran church service to protest unemployment got six-month jail sentences today from a magistrate who said he would not fine them because they would have difficulty paying.

title: PACIFIC TIN CONSOLIDATED CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations. c-Net income after a loss of $1,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Control Data Drops
description: Ending one of its worst years ever, the Control Data Corporation yesterday reported that fourth-quarter earnings fell 36.3 percent, to $31 million, or 80 cents a share, from $48.7 million, or $1.26 a share, in the comparable period of 1983. However, revenues for the quarter rose 7.2 percent, to $1.34 billion, from $1.25 billion in the 1983 period.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Salvador Elections Delayed
description: Elections for the National Assembly and mayoralties, scheduled for March 17, have been postponed for two weeks at the request of rightist parties, the Central Elections Council announced today. The parties asked for the delay to permit resolution of a dispute, now before the Supreme Court, over an election law that prevented President Jose Napoleon Duarte's son, Alejandro, from seeking re-election as mayor of San Salvador.

title: SPEED-O-PRINT BUSINESS MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SENATOR LUGAR SEEKS TO DEFINE POLICY ABROAD
description: The new chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today called on Americans to forge a new consensus on United States vital interests around the world and whether they should be defended with military force.

title: TRANS WORLD AIRLINES (TWA) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income which is after an extraordinary gain of $23,521,000.

title: Musica Aeterna Plays At the Met Museum
description: Musica Aeterna is a chamber orchestra led by Frederic Waldman that comprises some good players and plays almost exclusively conservative repertory in a decent if unexceptionable way to mostly conservative audiences - or so it would appear - at the Metropolitan Museum.

title: ARMY CHIEF AND 25 CHARGED IN MANILA IN AQUINO KILLING
description: The Government formally charged the armed forces Chief of Staff and 25 other men Wednesday in connection with the 1983 assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: PRODUCTS RESEARCH & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SIGNS OF OLD JAPANESE CRIME GROUP ARE SEEN IN U.S.
description: Federal immigration inspectors at Honolulu International Airport, on special alert for Japanese gangsters, noted a curious similarity last spring among some of the hundreds of tourists arriving from Japan each week: a little finger had been partly amputated.

title: Cedeno Is Charged
description: Cesar Cedeno , the Cincinnati Reds' outfielder, escaped injury early yesterday when he smashed his Mercedes-Benz into a tree in Houston, but he did not get away from the police.

title: EL PASO ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KIMBALL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CBS JURY TOLD OF C.I.A. 'SELLOUT' IN '67
description: George W. Allen, a former deputy chief of Vietnamese affairs for the Central Intelligence Agency, testified yesterday that the C.I.A. had ''sold out'' to the military in 1967 on the issue of enemy strength in South Vietnam and that President Lyndon B. Johnson had been given a ''dishonest and misleading'' estimate that fall.

title: In From the Cold A New York law permits the police to remove homeless people from the streets when their inability to function puts their lives at risk - but only after examination by two psychiatrists. Mayor Koch, alarmed at the prospect of people freezing to death during the recent cold snap, advances a legal argument for delaying the examination under extreme conditions. The legality is for the courts to determine. The humanity is beyond challenge.
description: The two-psychiatrist process involves time and expense, and the city has been hesitant to invoke the law for involuntary removal. Last weekend, however, aware that Mayor Wilson Goode of Philadelphia had empowered his police to remove the homeless from the streets as the temperature dropped, Mr. Koch issued similar orders. Whenever the ''effective temperature,'' including wind chill, descends below 5 degrees, the police may hospitalize those with nowhere else to go.

title: Transit Connection
description: A possible crack in the French

title: INGERSOLL-RAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses. Per share figures for both the quarters and the years include charges of 18 cents and $4.38, respectively, for the restructure of operations.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Nuggets, at Denver. Although the Nets have won 7 of 22 games against Denver over all, they have beaten the Nuggets only once in 11 trips to Denver since both teams joined the N.B.A. and that was on Dec. 18, 1982. Alex English is still the big scoring threat for the Nuggets. (Radio - WNBC, 660; 9:30 P.M.)

title: 1984 AUCTION RECORDS INDICATE TRENDS IN COLLECTING
description: World War II period might just, one day, upstage those of 18th-century France at auction, judging by the fierce bidding and high prices paid in 1984 for Finnish, Italian and American objects dating from 1945 to 1970. These designs are becoming more important - and expensive - for collectors, who were increasingly adventurous last year in exploring new and offbeat areas.

title: FLARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Anaconda Mine
description: The Anaconda Minerals Company, the mining division of the Atlantic Richfield Company, said it was suspending operations at its molybdenum mine and mill near Tonopah, Nev. The company attributed the indefinite suspension to poor market conditions. Anaconda said a number of employees were transferred to its Wyoming coal operations, but the suspension would affect about 260 jobs.

title: Texas Utilities
description: The Texas Utilties Company said it had revised its estimate of the cost of the Comanche Peak nuclear power plant to $4.56 billion, from the $3.89 billion it had estimated in December 1983.

title: HUGHES TOOLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Includes a pretax writeoff of $174.3 million incurred in the second quarter for certain fixed assets and inventory in the latest year compared with a pretax writeoff of $74.1 million in the earlier year.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP 4% LAST YEAR
description: The Consumer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 percent in December, completing the third straight year in which inflation was held to 4 percent or less, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Minstar Seeking Special Investor
description: Irwin L. Jacobs said that Minstar Inc., a Minneapolis-based holding company in which Mr. Jacobs and an investor group has 47 percent control, was looking for a company to buy into Minstar to lessen its tax burden.

title: Nader Group Seeks Warning Of Health Risks for Workers
description: A group founded by the consumer activist Ralph Nader said today that the Federal Government was refusing to make public the names of more than 250,000 workers in the United States who face cancer risks from exposure to chemicals where they work.

title: GOLDEN WEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ERITREAN REBELS SAY ETHIOPIANS MASSACRED PRISONERS
description: An Ethiopian rebel group has accused the Government of killing 27 prisoners of war and wounding another 7 in the port city of Asmara.

title: PREMATURE DEATHS ARE DOWN
description: Fewer people are dying before the age of 65, another indication that Americans are taking better care of themselves, according to Government health researchers.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Stock of Freddie Mac Rises Sharply in Debut
description: Trading began yesterday in newly issued preferred stock of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation that was distributed earlier this month to more than 3,000 savings and loan associations. The stock opened at 40 1/8 and rose sharply to close at 42 1/8, on volume of 233,100 shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SCANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of approximately $7,900,000, or 20 cents a share, from a March order from the Public Service Commission of South Carolina resolving its 1983 retail electric rate case.

title: Sonics Topple Celtics, 107-97
description: Jack Sikma scored a season-high 34 points and Tom Chambers added 26 as the Seattle SuperSonics overcame a 14- point deficit to defeat the Boston Celtics, 107-97, tonight.

title: THE QUINLANS AND THE LATEST RIGHT-TO-DIE RULING
description: ''The central figure in this tragic case is Karen Ann Quinlan. She lies in a debilitated and allegedly moribund state. The matter is of transcendent importance, involving questions related to the definition and existence of death; the prolongation of life through artificial means, the impact on her family and society in general.''

title: Stage: Milan Kundera's 'Jacques and His Master'
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- If ever there was a Cultural Event, it is ''Jacques and His Master,'' the Milan Kundera play now at Harvard's American Repertory Theater. Not only is this production the American premiere of the Czechosolovak writer's sole stage work, but it also marks the American debut of Susan Sontag as a theater director. Leafing through the program, one half expects to discover Irving Howe and Philip Roth in the cast list. They're not, alas - although one is pleased to find such sturdy theatrical hands as Robert Drivas and Priscilla Smith.

title: A Rule Is a Rule
description: One of the requirements of playing in the Pro Bowl game is that the players must arrive in Honolulu in time for a Monday night meeting.

title: Bennett to Coach Bucs
description: Leeman Bennett , the former coach of the Atlanta Falcons, was named to succeed

title: CUOMO SEEKS A 45% RISE IN AID TO HOMELESS
description: Citing ''a glaring and immediate need,'' Governor Cuomo has proposed a 45 percent increase in state aid for the homeless that he said would provide services and shelter for 10,000 more people.

title: CENTRAL ILLINOIS LIGHT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MUSIC: PRAGUE SYMPHONY IN DVORAK
description: ONE common complaint lodged against foreign orchestras that visit New York is that too often they bring programs of standard works that leave the listener with no clear impression of the ensemble's native voice and character. At the top international levels nowadays, orchestra A's Beethoven or Brahms program is hard to distinguish from orchestra B's, partly because the world's cultures are rapidly becoming homogenized. Most if not all important orchestras now aim for a similarity of instrumental techniques and interpretations that would have been out of the question even a generation ago.

title: No Headline
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 24, 1985 International

title: THE LORDS ARE ON CAMERA, LIVE AND QUITE LIVELY
description: The House of Lords - live, from Parliament - had its world television premiere today. It was five hours long.

title: VIETNAM WAR ALSO HAUNTS CANADIANS WHO VOLUNTEERED
description: They are invisible veterans of an unpopular war, so reticent about their experience that next-door neighbors may never know that they served in Vietnam.

title: Clearing the Air
description: Dale Berra , the Yankee infielder who was obtained in a trade with the Pirates last month, said yesterday that he had testified before a Federal grand jury investigating possible drug offenses in Pittsburgh, but stressed that he had been called to testify as a background witness only and was not a target of the investigation. Berra issued the statement through his agent,

title: AEROFLEX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HERS
description: MOVEMENTS that do not take themselves seriously tend not to last, but then movements that take themselves too seriously do not last either or else have unexpectedly unpleasant results. So I was delighted when the leading organ of the women's movement, Ms. magazine, chose Cyndi Lauper as one of its ''women of the year,'' along with half a dozen more conventional female achievers, including Geraldine Ferraro. For those who are forced to live without radios or teen-agers, Cyndi Lauper is the rock star who created such stirring anthems to women's and sexual liberation as ''She Bop'' and ''Girls Just Want to Have Fun.''

title: NEW 22-CENT STAMP HONORS JEROME KERN
description: The country's newest first-class postage stamp had its premier yesterday at Lincoln Center with a new price, 22 cents, and a new face, the composer Jerome Kern.

title: Bonn Backs Nuclear Unit
description: The West German Government today approved plans for construction of a $3.1 billion reprocessing plant for spent fuel from civilian nuclear reactors.

title: Letter: On Deregulation ;   A New Phase in Air Travel
description: To the Editor:

title: AMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EX-CHIEF OF TRANSIT AUTHORITY
description: Joseph E. O'Grady, New York City's first Labor Commissioner and a head of the Transit Authority during the 1950's and 60's, died of a heart attack yesterday at Morton Plant Hospital in Clearwater, Fla. He was 82 years old and had lived in Clearwater for eight years.

title: VERA LACHMANN
description: Vera Lachmann, a poet and Professor Emeritus of Classics at Brooklyn College, died Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. She was 80 years old.

title: DANCE: GALLOROTTA'S 'ADVENTURES OF IVAN VAFFAN'
description: ''THE ADVENTURES OF IVAN VAFFAN,'' the second dance-theater piece presented at the City Center by Jean-Claude Gallotta for France's Groupe Emile Dubois, is not to be taken seriously but it can certainly be enjoyed.

description: The world's oldest bridge magazine seems to be near death, condemned by love.

title: Boy Recants Testimony In Child Abuse Case
description: The first of 41 children to testify in a preliminary hearing against seven former teachers accused of 200 counts of child molestation backed down under cross-examination today, recanting his sometimes graphic testimony.

title: EXPERTS SAY SATELLITE CAN DETECT SOVIET WAR STEPS
description: A likely major use of the satellite taken aloft yesterday by the space shuttle is to help warn of Soviet preparations for a nuclear attack on the United States, according to military experts not working for the Government.

title: NI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Exxon to Sell Unit To Italy's Olivetti
description: Exxon Enterprises, a unit of the Exxon Corporation, said that Ing. C. Olivetti & Company of Italy had agreed to aquire the overseas operations of its Exxon Office Systems Company, a maker of facsimile machines, electronic typewriters and other office equipment. Terms were not disclosed, but an Exxon spokesman, Ann Frechette, said Olivetti planned to offer jobs to most of the division's 300 employees in six European countries.

title: ISSUE OF NATIONAL NUCLEAR WASTE DUMP POLARIZES THREE STATES
description: In the three states selected as the possible site for a national nuclear waste dump, the ensuing argument divides those attracted by the money the project would bring and others who fear contamination. For most, the fears predominate.

title: SCRIPPS-HOWARD BROADCASTNG reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Deaver's Directions
description: Michael K. Deaver, who has announced his resignation as White House deputy chief of staff to join the private sector, is reportedly planning to open a Washington public relations concern of his own rather than join any of the existing concerns with offices in the capital, some of which have been bidding for his services. Associates say he may be joined in this enterprise by Craig S. Fuller of the White House staff, who was secretary of the Reagan Cabinet in the first term.

title: Jazz and Hoofin'
description: The Legends of Jazz, a New Orleans band, and the Original Hoofers, a tap-dance troupe, will perform in ''1000 Years of Jazz,'' tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College. ''St. Louis Blues,'' ''Satin Doll,'' ''When the Saints Go Marchin' In'' and ''A-Train'' will be on the program, with boogie-woogie, ragtime and blues selections. Tickets are $12, $10 and $8. Reservations: (718) 434- 1900.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $4,000,000.

title: 12 ABORTION PROTESTERS GIVEN TOKEN SENTENCE IN PLEA DEAL
description: A dozen of the 29 anti-abortion protesters arrested last Tuesday for kneeling in prayer on the steps of the United States Supreme Court were sentenced today to a day in jail and fined $10.

title: PORTER, H.K. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $20,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $8,643,000 from discontinued operations.

description: The company said results for the latest quarter included an after-tax charge of $50,000,000 related to certain regulatory issues pertaining to Alaskan crude oil operations. The company said results for the year-ago quarter include a writeoff of the Mukluk exploratory well in Alaska, a gain from the liquidation of low cost crude oil and petroleum product inventories, and the reduction of a previous estimated loss related to withdrawal from abrasives manufacturing.

description: Berenter, Greenhouse & Webster has released news on two new bits of business.

Year-ago results for the quarter and year have been restated to reflect an accounting change. Result for the latest year have been restated to reflect an accounting change. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

Polish Court Hears Data From Autopsy on Priest
description: The club used to beat the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko was displayed here in the courthouse today as material from the autopsy of the pro-Solidarity priest was reported at the trial of four security policemen charged with his murder.

title: Orders Rise in Canada
description: Orders received by Canadian manufacturers rose 3.5 percent in November, to the equivalent of $14.7 billion in American money, from October's $14.2 billion, the Government said today.

description: b-Net income. c-Including a gain of $405,000 on the sale of land. d-Including a tax credit of $663,000.

title: Dominican Agitation Follows Price Increases
description: Disturbances broke out in the capital today in response to a round of price increases, but the police said they had brought the situation under control quickly.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline in some editions of Sports Pages yesterday incorrectly identified the winner of the St. Francis-Fairleigh Dickinson basketball game. St. Francis beat Fairleigh Dickinson, 62-49.

title: AMDAHL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $3.2 million. Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: ISSEL'S SPURT SPARKS NUGGETS OVER NETS
description: There is still some life left yet in Dan Issel. Playing in his first game since announcing that he will retire at the end of this season - his 15th as a pro - the 36-year-old Issel scored 10 critical points in the final period to help stave off a late rally by the Nets and give the Denver Nuggets their fourth straight victory, 119-110, before 7,452 fans at McNichols Sports Arena.

title: UNITED BANKERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are adjusted to include banks acquired in 1984 that were recorded on a pooling-of-interest basis. Share earnings are adjusted to reflect stock dividends paid in 1983 and 1984.

title: Consolidated Sets Vote on Name
description: Consolidated Foods Corporation stockholders will be asked at a special meeting in March to approve a change in the company's name to the Sara Lee Corporation, the company said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The possibility of national bankruptcy is a distinct possibility if we persist in unabated spending across the board.'' - Senator Barry Goldwater. (D16:4.)

title: TIME CLEARED OF LIBELING SHARON BUT JURORS CRITICIZE ITS REPORTING
description: A jury found yesterday that a 1983 Time magazine article - although it contained a false and defamatory paragraph - did not libel Ariel Sharon because the magazine did not publish it with ''serious doubts as to its truth.''

title: U.S. AND CANADA NEAR PACT ON NEW ARCTIC RADAR
description: Officials of the United States and Canada said today that the two countries were near an agreement on a $1.2 billion project to modernize an Arctic network of radar stations for the defense of North America against a Soviet attack.

title: Micronesian Weavings
description: Fans, headpieces, mats and belts made in late 19th-century Micronesia are among the 40 objects on view in ''Weavings From the Micronesian Islands,'' the first exhibition of objects from that part of the world organized at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 82d Street and Fifth Avenue, in the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing.

title: EXXON FALLS 11.7%
description: Three of the country's biggest oil companies reported lower fourth- quarter earnings, reflecting the worldwide glut of oil and the period of warmer weather last year that touched off a slide in prices.

title: 3 Eritrea Rebel Groups Merge But Largest Force Stays Out
description: Three rival guerrilla groups seeking to free Eritrea from Ethiopia announced today that they were joining forces in their 22- year-old struggle.

title: WESTWAY LANDFILL WINS THE SUPPORT OF ARMY ENGINEER
description: An official of the Army Corps of Engineers recommended yesterday that a crucial landfill permit be granted for Westway, the $2 billion highway and development project that has been stalled in litigation since it was proposed more than a decade ago to revive Manhattan's West Side.

title: Apple Settles Lawsuit
description: Apple Computer Inc. will pay an undisclosed sum to Management and Computer Services Inc. to settle a trademark-infringement lawsuit, the companies said today. The software company sued Apple for using ''Mac'' to describe items associated with its Macintosh personal computer. Management and Computer Services uses ''Macs'' as a trademark.

title: Another Homeless Person
description: Coming and going through the city,

title: Honk, Honk, Conable
description: Barber B. Conable Jr., freshly retired from 20 years in the House of Representatives, reports that he is surprised by the number of requests he now gets for speeches, an activity he deprecates as ''honking like a silly old goose.'' Mr. Conable, an upstate New York Republican now at the American Enterprise Institute, observed at one of the inaugural parties this week: ''I find I am in great demand as a speaker. The minute you leave Congress, they think of you as a statesman.''

title: Goodbye, Ruckelshaus
description: President Reagan has finally acknowledged, in a joking and

title: U.S. MOVE ON DOLLAR REPORTED
description: The United States Federal Reserve sold off $46 million last Tuesday as major central banks intervened on the currency markets to curtail the dollar's rise, a senior French Finance Ministry official disclosed today.

title: CLOROX CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ken McIntyre
description: The saxophonist Ken McIntyre will lead a jazz orchestra Sunday at 3 P.M. at the fourth-floor loft of 109 West Broadway , above Chambers Street (619-4879) . Admission is $5.

title: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a charge of $18.5 million for the quarter and year from a provision for the restructuring of operations and a credit of $17.7 million for the quarter and year from the elimination of deferred income taxes relating to the qualified undistributed earnings of Ex-Cell-O Corp. domestic international sales corporation.

title: EXXON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wanting to Play
description: How badly did 24-year-old Pace Mannion want to play in the National Basketball Association? Well, when he heard his agent had rejected an offer from the Utah Jazz because it had a one-year, not a two-year guarantee, the 24-year-old free agent took matters into his own hands.

title: Economic Scene ;   Budget Gloom Vs. Optimism
description: President Reagan's budget, which some Congressmen said would be ''dead on arrival'' when it reaches Capitol Hill Feb. 6, now looks live and kicking. The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, and House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. have accepted Mr. Reagan's budget as the basis for their own. Despite their moaning about the deficit, neither Republicans nor Democrats have any appetite for raising taxes or for making bigger cuts in the budget than those the President is proposing.

title: Airline Is Grounding 2 Planes
description: In the aftermath of a crash of a Lockheed Electra that killed 68 people Monday, the president of Galaxy Airlines announced today that the small charter airline would temporarily shut down operations while its two remaining Electras were inspected for safety.

title: Chapter 11 Filing By Wells Benrus
description: The Wells Benrus Corporation, a maker of gears, bearings and fasteners based in Middlebury, Conn., said it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: CITY'S SINGING UP A STORM ON KERN'S CENTENNIAL
description: THE centenary of Jerome Kern's birth, which falls on Sunday, was already inspiring Kern enthusiasts to start celebrating as early as last fall. Sandy Stewart and Arthur Siegel spent September at Michael's Pub singing Kern's songs. And Town Hall marked the occasion of its reopening in October with a Kern Centenary Gala.

title: A Student Who Left Baby Faces Charges
description: A college student who left her newborn son in a Dumpster will be charged with attempted murder and endangering the welfare of a child, the Bergen County Prosecutor said today.

title: EDUCATIONAL COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ORBIT FOR THE DEPARTED
description: A group of Florida undertakers has joined with a former astronaut in the world's first commercial space venture, with plans to rocket human ashes into an orbit of the Earth.

Northeastern Air
description: Northeastern International Airways said that it would resume flights to Chicago, Orlando, St. Petersburg and West Palm Beach. The Fort Lauderdale-based carrier was forced to cut service from 12 cities to only one route after announcing on Jan. 8 that it was filing for Federal bankruptcy court protection. The company said the resumption of service to the four cities would be the first step in its recovery process.

title: M-1 DOWN
description: Treasury bond yields - a benchmark of interest rates - fell sharply again yesterday, hitting their lowest level since July 1983.

description: LONDON China's attempt to redefine Marxism as a system of ''seeking truth from facts'' is only a dramatic reflection of a widespread trend.

AS COMPANIES BUY HOSPITALS, TREATMENT OF POOR IS DEBATED
description: Fiscally pressed public hospitals are increasingly being taken over by for- profit hospital chains, and the mixed results have touched off a sharp dispute among health professionals and public officials.

title: PUBLISHING: GERMAN NOVELS BY A JAPANESE AUTHOR
description: HISAKO MATSUBARA was in New York recently to celebrate the publication of her new book, ''Cranes at Dusk'' (Dial Press/Doubleday), a novel set in 1945, when the American conquerors occupied the ancient city of Kyoto.

title: Exchanges Study Link
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange and the Hong Kong Commodity Exchange are discussing possible joint ventures, including linked trading of currency options, the Philadelphia exchange's president, Nicholas Giordano, said. He added that discussions would continue next week.

title: GENEVIEVE CLEARY
description: Genevieve Cleary, one of four sisters who founded the Cleary School for the Deaf in Ronkonkoma, died Sunday at John Mather Memorial Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I. She was 85 years old and lived at the school.

title: 21 Dead in Honduras Crash
description: There were no survivors among the 21 American servicemen who were aboard a military cargo plane that crashed on Tuesday off Puerto Castilla, Honduras, the United States Embassy here said today. The Air Force Reserve plane was based at Billy Mitchell Field in Milwaukee. It had been carrying the soldiers on a flight from Howard Air Force base in Panama to Trujillo, on the northern Honduras coast.

title: ACETO CHEMICAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $150,000 for the quarter and 6 months due to a credit of deferred federal income taxes.

title: South African Gold
description: South Africa's gold mines produced 21.88 million ounces of gold last year, up from 1983's 21.85 million ounces, the Chamber of Mines said today.

title: Northview Sells Stake in Financial
description: The Northview Corporation, a San Diego- based company controlled by Ivan F. Boesky, the New York investor, has sold its 9.8 percent stake in the Financial Corporation of Santa Barbara.

title: MORRIS NEUWIRTH
description: Morris Neuwirth, a painter and commercial artist for Newsday for more than 15 years, died Wednesday of heart failure in the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: BISHOP CALLS ABORTION SUIT RIGHTS ISSUE
description: A dozen years ago, Howard J. Hubbard was known as a street priest, a liberal fighter against the Establishment.

title: ROSE LEHMAN STEIN
description: Rose Lehman Stein, a lawyer and a former president of the New York Women's Bar Association, died yesterday in the Central Island Nursing Home in Plainview, L.I. She had suffered a major stroke two and a half years ago. She was 83 years old and lived in North Miami Beach, Fla.

title: NEW BRANDS CITED
description: The Procter & Gamble Company reported today that its earnings dropped 36 percent for the quarter ended Dec. 31, largely because of the cost of introducing new brands and of making improvements in its Pampers disposable diaper line.

title: SEOUL APPEARS TO DISAVOW ITS THREAT TO IMPRISON EXILE
description: The South Korean Embassy said today that the Government had disavowed a threat to imprison the opposition leader Kim Dae Jung if he returned from exile in the United States as planned next month.

title: 'SPOT' BUILDERS IN QUEENS CATERING TO A 'NEW MARKET'
description: Here and there, now and then, a piece of land becomes available for new housing construction in established residential communities such as Middle Village, Maspeth or Elmhurst in central Queens. When it does, the ''spot'' builder takes notice.

title: UNION CARBIDE HAD BEEN TOLD OF LEAK DANGER
description: Last fall, Union Carbide safety inspectors warned managers at the company's plant in Institute, W. Va., that a ''runaway reaction'' at a tank storing methyl isocyanate could lead to a ''catastrophic failure'' of the tank.

title: PAUL NEWMAN THE PHILANTHROPIST: A REAL-LIFE ROLE
description: When Paul Newman began what was for an actor the unlikely business of bottling and selling his home- brewed salad dressing, he made a promise: he would donate the profits to charities. Two and a half years later things are working out just as he expected.

title: RANGERS WIN WITH PATRICK
description: The Rangers showed something for the new coach that they did not often show for the old coach - sheer force. With it, the Rangers overcame some of the same old mistakes and defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 3-1, last night at Madison Square Garden, making the return of Craig Patrick as their coach a success and easing his jitters.

title: D'AMATO'S 'PANIC'
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Court Upholds Ban on Sunday Gambling
description: The Florida Supreme Court today unanimously upheld a state ban on Sunday gambling and horse racing, rejecting arguments by parimutuel interests that the ban was unconstitutional.

title: Clare M. Tousley Dies at 95; Social Worker for 5 Decades
description: Clare M. Tousley, a social worker whose career spanned five decades, died Monday at her home in the Gramercy Park section of Manhattan. She was 95 years old.

title: Friday MEWS OF THE WORLD
description: A cat resembling E. T. and bearing his name is in town from Paris to join 800 participants in an international cat show that opens this evening (5 to 10 P.M.) and continues Saturday and Sunday (9 A.M. to 6 P.M.) at Madison Square Garden. The extra-terrestrial lookalike has no hair or whiskers, huge ears that stick out from the sides of its head, wrinkly skin and an amiable disposition - a new breed called Sphinx that resulted from a mutation. E. T. will vie with cats of three other new but not officially recognized breeds. Most entries, however, are recognized breeds competing in five categories: pedigreed kittens, adults and altered cats, and nonpedigreed kittens and adult household pets. Admission: $6 ($4 for over-65's and under-12's). Information: 564-4400. A SPACE FESTIVAL

Marilyn Sokol Sings Rarely Heard Songs
description: There's a bit of Gracie Allen in Marilyn Sokol's performance at Michael's Pub. She is not as muddle- headed as Miss Allen and she does not have George Burns to feed her her comic opportunities.

title: Goetz Will Not Testify In Inquiry on Shooting
description: Bernhard H. Goetz will not testify before a grand jury considering whether to indict him on charges of trying to murder four youths on a subway train last month, his lawyers said yesterday.

title: SONGWRITER WHO SPANS THE AMERICAN GENRE
description: WENDY WALDMAN, who will be making her first New York appearance in four years tonight at the Bottom Line, calls herself ''an American songwriter.'' The term is not used idly. In 1973, Miss Waldman, then only 22, made her first album of original songs, songs that forged powerful links between the tradition of George Gershwin and the soft-rock confessional styles of Laura Nyro and Joni Mitchell. Maria Muldaur included two songs from that record - ''Mad, Mad Me'' and ''Vaudeville Man'' - on a hugely successful solo album, and Miss Waldman seemed poised to follow in Miss Muldaur's footsteps to massive commercial reward.

title: Adjustable Stock From U.S. Steel
description: The United States Steel Corporation has offered two issues of money market preferred stock totaling $125 million, with an initial dividend yield of 6 1/2 percent, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman/American Express.

title: FEDERAL SCREW WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Wright Stuff
description: ''Early Flight: 1900-1911,'' a free exhibition of 56 photographs taken by airplane inventors Wilbur and Orville Wright, will be displayed at the Hudson River Museum, 511 Warburton Avenue, Yonkers, from Sunday through April 21.

title: Prime Computer Gains
description: Prime Computer Inc. said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 48 percent, to $14.8 million, or 31 cents a share, from $10 million, or 21 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue climbed 19.6 percent, to $170.8 million, from $142.8 million. Prime attributed the improvement to a strengthened product line, a broader overseas presence and the expansion of its distribution channels.

title: SHARON CASE AND THE LAW
description: When Judge Abraham D. Sofaer asked the jury in Ariel Sharon's suit against Time magazine to consider the case in three stages, he was merely seeking to simplify the difficult task it faced. It had to apply the complicated law of libel to a morass of conflicting testimony on the reporting process at Time, Israel's actions in Lebanon and Mr. Sharon himself.

title: Jockey Hits Right Groove at Gulfstream
description: Long shots are winning the major races, form is shaky every day and the crop of 3-year-olds is almost depressing in its mediocrity, but Gulfstream Park horseplayers have been able to count on one thing this winter: Jose Santos.

title: U.S. Condemns Private Raids Into Laos for Missing G.I.'s
description: The United States Government said today that it strongly opposed private raids into Laos in search of Americans still missing from the Indochina war.

title: BARON DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CSX Corp., Richmond, said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its CSX Beckett Aviation unit to Aero Services International Inc. of Teterboro, N.J. Terms were not disclosed.

title: SCREEN: 'FANDANGO,' COMING OF AGE IN 1971
description: THE GROOVERS, a pack of college buddies, turn graduation into the occasion for one last blowout in ''Fandango,'' which takes place in the shadow of the Vietnam War. The year is 1971 and draft notices have arrived for several of the group's members, so their antics have both fraternity-house humor and a hysterical edge. Kevin Reynolds, who wrote and directed ''Fandango,'' is for the most part making just another coming-of-age film. But at its best, his debut feature has an appealing boisterousness, and it successfully walks a fine line between sensitivity and swagger.

description: To loyal residents as well as admiring visitors, the streets of New York City often tell a story of distress and destitution, and many witnesses to such scenes express their concern with donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Control Data Picks Peripheral Unit Chief
description: The Control Data Corporation said yesterday that Lawrence Perlman had been named president of its Peripheral Products Company, which sells disk drives and other computer- related business products.

title: G.M. Recalls 225,000 Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation is recalling about 225,000 1981 and 1982 cars to fix potentially defective pollution control equipment, the Environmental Protection Agency said today. The vehicles, equipped with 4.1-liter V-6 engines, include the 1982 Buick Regal and Regal Estate Wagon; the Pontiac Bonneville, Bonneville Wagon and Grand Prix and the 1981 and 1982 Cadillac DeVille, Fleetwood Brougham, Eldorado and Seville; Buick Electra, LeSabre and Riviera; and the Oldsmobile Ninety-Eight and Toronado.

title: PURDUE DEFEATS INDIANA, 62-52
description: Purdue, slamming Indiana with an 11-2 burst in the final two minutes, defeated the Hoosiers, 62-52, in a Big Ten game tonight.

description: Delta Air Lines reported yesterday that the quarter ended Dec. 31 was the most profitable it has ever had. Earnings in the period, the airline's second fiscal quarter, were $73.9 million, or $1.85 a share, up 81.6 percent from $40.7 million, or $1.02 a share, a year earlier. Revenues in the latest quarter were $1.13 billion, up 5 percent from $1.07 billion.

title: THE NEW, 'SUPER' DRUGSTORES
description: The old-fashioned drugstore business is entering a new phase. Although drug chains have long dotted shopping malls, many of the chains are going heavily into general merchandise, some are going into deep- discount pricing and the general merchandisers themselves are getting more into the drugstore business.

description: Angel Cordero Jr. suffered a broken right hand when his horse collapsed in a race at Aqueduct yesterday. His horse, Barrilla, and two other horses injured in separate races were humanely destroyed.

Italy Quake Alert Stirs Panic
description: Warnings from the Civil Defense Ministry that a dangerous earthquake might soon strike sent 100,000 people fleeing in panic from 14 mountain villages in central Italy, the authorities said today. The warning was broadcast Wednesday night, following a moderate quake on Wednesday, and the traffic police said most villagers drove away Wednesday night, taking few personal belongings. A second and stronger tremor occurred today.

title: Trout Fishing in Manila
description: Thoreau once remarked that circumstantial evidence can be pretty persuasive, like discovering a trout in the milk. By that test, the Philippines has reeked of fish ever since the airport murder of Benigno Aquino in August 1983.

title: BANGKOK DISPLAYS VIETNAM SOLDIERS
description: Huynh Quoc Tuan, his rumpled shirt too big for his small frame, was barefoot and trembling this morning when Thailand's top military chiefs paraded him before the press.

title: ART: NEW PAINTINGS BY GEORGE MCNEIL
description: -headed, carnivalesque female figures in George McNeil's new paintings at the Gruenebaum Gallery, 38 East 57th Street, is one of the more energizing experiences now available in the galleries. McNeil loved painting them, the people in the paintings are having a wonderful time and the brushmanship has zip in abundance. Antic behavior in the discos and elsewhere has rarely been portrayed with such a compulsive identification. George McNeil may be 76, but in spirit he is right in there on the dance floor.

Allen, a former deputy chief of Vietnamese affairs for the Central Intelligence Agency, testified yesterday that the production in late 1967 of a ''misleading'' intelligence estimate on enemy strength in South Vietnam was part of a broader ''self deception'' by the Administration of President Lyndon B. Johnson regarding progress in the war.

description: The Ford Motor Company said it would place 1,950 workers on temporary layoff for a model change-over at its St. Louis assembly plant, effective Monday. Ford said about 450 workers would remain on the job as the plant was converted to make the new Aerostar mini-van, instead of the Crown Victoria and Grand Marquis cars. Production of the mini-van is expected to begin in May.
