description: The company said earnings in the latest 6 months benefitted from one- time gains resulting from the sale of an insecticide business in Australia and the Lavoris mouthwash business in the U.S. during the first quarter, and from the sale of a parcel of undeveloped land in the second quarter.

title: IN CHICAGO, E.P.A. ACCUSES AND IS ACCUSED ON WASTES
description: On the same day the Federal Environmental Protection Agency sought a multimillion-dollar fine against a toxic waste handler based in one suburb of Chicago, the agency was accused of dragging its heels in handling a dioxin- contaminated site in another suburb.

title: RIBLET PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RIVAL BILLS INTRODUCED TO AMEND COURT'S LIMIT ON RIGHTS LAWS
description: Rival bills were introduced in Congress today aimed at rolling back a Supreme Court decision that limits the scope of four major civil rights laws.

title: WADKINS LEADS BY 2 ON 63
description: ''We caught Riviera on a very vulnerable day,'' Lanny Wadkins said today after he had tied the club's course record of eight-under par 63 in the opening round of the 59th Los Angeles Open golf tournament.

title: U.S. WILL INVESTIGATE ALLEGATIONS OF DRUG USE AT COMMUTER AIRLINE
description: The Federal authorities announced investigations today into a news report that pilots and other workers at Provincetown-Boston Airline used drugs.

title: 3 PICKED IN FREE AGENT POOL
description: The California Angels, making positive use of the loss of Fred Lynn as a free agent, shored up their depleted relief corps yesterday by plucking Donnie Moore of the Atlanta Braves from the free-agent compensation pool.

title: MOBIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The decline in earnings for the latest quarter and year includesspecial items: the $110 million provision for closure of the Wilhelmshaven refinery in Germany for the quarter and year; a $41 million lower LIFO drawdown benefit for the quarter and $117 million for the year and the initial adverse income effect of the acquisition of the Superior Oil Co., $21 million after financing for the quarter and $73 million for the year. These items were partially offset by the net unfavorable effect in the 1983 periods of exploration and producing adjustments, including the Mukluk writeoff, of $36 million.

title: Europe Curb on Fakes
description: Tougher rules to keep counterfeit goods out of the Common Market were proposed today. Imports found to be counterfeit would be seized.

title: BANDAG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $2,261,000 for the quarter and year.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: McEnroe Moves To Quarterfinals
description: John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors posted straight-set victories tonight and reached the quarterfinals of the $300,000 United States Pro Indoor tennis championship.

title: John Kresse of Boys Town
description: John A. Kresse, the last of the five boys with whom the Rev. Edward T. Flanagan began Boys Town, died of cancer here Wednesday. He was 79 years old. Mr. Kresse had been a ward of Omaha's Juvenile Court in 1917 when Father Flanagan borrowed $90 to rent an old house, founding a shelter that became Boys Town. Mr. Kresse, born on May 17, 1905, spent two years there. In 1938 he moved to Brainard where he was a farmer.

title: GERBER PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WALL ST. WORRIES OVER INSIDER LEAKS
description: Some Wall Street executives are expressing a growing concern that the wave of corporate mergers in recent years has spawned a pattern of illegal insider trading in stocks of companies that receive takeover bids. Such trading, it is believed, has reached sizable proportions and, if allowed to continue, could tarnish the credibility of the securities markets.

title: MEDIQ INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,000. The 1983 revenue was restated to reflect consolidation of Packaging Coordinators Inc.

title: 'Soho' Opening Delayed
description: The opening date of Albert Innaurato's ''Coming of Age in Soho,'' a play about a writer and two runaway boys, has been postponed to Feb. 3 at the Public Theater.

title: CITY BALLET: NEW WORK FOR A GALA
description: THE NEW YORK CITY BALLET'S program on Wednesday night in the New York State Theater was a gala benefit for the School of American Ballet, the company's school, and the festivities included a preview and a surprise.

title: JERSEY SHELTER FOR HOMELESS DIRECTS SOME TO MANHATTAN
description: On nights when the shelter for the homeless at St. John's Lutheran Church in Hoboken, N.J., runs out of beds, Sister Norberta gives the people who have no place to go 75 cents each and sends them across the Hudson River to New York City.

title: MUSIC: PRAGUE SYMPHONY IN DVORAK
description: ONE common complaint lodged against foreign orchestras that visit New York is that too often they bring programs of standard works that leave the listener with no clear impression of the ensemble's native voice and character. At the top international levels nowadays, orchestra A's Beethoven or Brahms program is hard to distinguish from orchestra B's, partly because the world's cultures are rapidly becoming homogenized. Most if not all important orchestras now aim for a similarity of instrumental techniques and interpretations that would have been out of the question even a generation ago.

title: EX-BROKER TESTIFIES ON LINKS TO WINANS
description: Peter N. Brant, a former stockbroker at Kidder, Peabody & Company who has pleaded guilty to three counts of securities fraud, testified yesterday about the arrangement under which R. Foster Winans, a former reporter at The Wall Street Journal, passed information to him about what would appear in the paper's ''Heard on the Street'' column.

title: SEABROOK FINANCING IS REVISED
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire announced yesterday that it had agreed with securities dealers on a plan to raise the funds needed to complete the Seabrook No. 1 nuclear power plant.

title: WICAT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
ANAREN MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
QUAKER OATS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The net income for the year-ago quarter and 6 months includes a gain of 10 cents a share from a debt-for- debt exchange. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in November 1984.

title: Stock Prices Ease, With Dow Off 4.30
description: The stock market fluctuated sharply yesterday, rising in early trading before falling back to close slightly lower in a generally mixed performance. Trading remained heavy.

title: 3 GOLDS CHANGE LITTLE IN BRISCO-HOOK'S LIFE
description: The larger-than-life billboards of Mary Decker, Edwin Moses and Carl Lewis that lined the road to the 1984 Olympics were like cardboard status symbols that relegated their American track and field teammates to supporting roles even before the Games began. Valerie Brisco- Hooks said she understood how the star system worked and how difficult it might be to make a breakthrough. But as she learned, even success did not guarantee her a billboard of her own.

title: BROADWAY
description: THE new musical ''Big River: The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' is scheduled to open at the Eugene O'Neill Theater April 23, so one can assume that the money is there somewhere - but a calculator might come in handy. The play will have 20 actors playing 65 characters in 45 scenes, to say nothing of 17 new songs, ranging from gospel and spiritual to folk and blues, by the multi-Grammy award winner Roger Miller.

title: NYNEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-There are no comparable figures because this is the first year of operations since the spin-off from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on Jan. 1, 1984.

title: BRIEFING ;   Firewood and Ice
description: Officials who moved the inaugural ceremony inside the Capitol may have been influenced in part by the fact that the historic home of the national legislature, much of it predating central heating, has 130 fireplaces tucked away in offices, restaurants and hearing rooms.

title: END OF BAR TO JAPAN'S CARS URGED
description: Most of President Reagan's Cabinet advisers are urging an end to import quotas on Japanese cars, and a final decision may be made as early as next week, Administration officials said today.

title: Wyoming Frees Woman Who Helped Kill Father
description: Deborah Ann Jahnke, whose prison sentence for aiding in the 1982 slaying of her abusive father was commuted by Gov. Ed Herschler of Wyoming, was released today from a Denver youth center, her attorner said.

title: GUILFORD MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: Results for the latest 6 months include 12 cents a share from the reversal of taxes previously provided for foreign source income which is no longer considered necessary.

title: STATEMENT FROM TIME INC.

title: New Jersey Percussion At Symphony Space
description: The New Jersey Percussion Ensemble, in residence at William Paterson College, presented a program devoted entirely to compositions by Charles Wuorinen at the Symphony Space Tuesday night, and demonstrated, once again, that, even without the benefit of strings, brass and winds, this is a genuine orchestra, capable of producing an extraordinary array of sonic textures. As many as 24 musicians at once shared the stage, pounding, rubbing, bowing and striking an impressive collection of cymbals, glockenspiels, pianos, gongs and miscellaneous instruments.

title: Debt
description: First Bank System is issuing $150 million of 12-year floating-rate notes, through underwriters led by Credit Suisse First Boston, with interest 1/8 point above the London interbank rate.

title: Buyout of Denny's
description: Denny's Inc. said that its shareholders had approved a $753.4 million leveraged buyout of the company, and that the deal was expected to be closed Friday.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said results reflect the acquisition of First Capital National Bank & Trust Co. of Kearny, N. J. from Oct. 1

title: THE WACKIEST MILLROSE GAMES
description: Around 5 P.M. today, Howard

title: UNITED STATES HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Concern Won't Feed Antibiotics to Cattle
description: The nation's largest cattle breeder said today that it would end the routine feeding of antibiotics to its herds because of concern that the practice could endanger human health.

title: ART: WRIGHT DRAWINGS AGAIN OFFERED TO PUBLIC
description: WHEN the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation announced plans to sell some of the architect's drawings, it was as if the Department of the Interior had proposed turning redwoods into pencils. Architectural scholars and ever-acquisitive museum curators protested that a public trust was being violated. Despite foundation assurances that a mere 1 percent of some 20,000 works would be offered and that enough similar pieces remained, the critics felt that drawings indispensable to researchers would be irretrievably lost in the black hole of private collections.

title: ANTIQUES FAIR TAKES ADVENTUROUS TURN
description: THERE'S a dramatic change at

title: Owens-Illinois To Buy Alliance
description: Owens-Illinois Inc., the glass container maker, said that it had agreed to acquire the Alliance Mortgage Company for $115 million from Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. Under the terms of the deal, Owens- Illinois, which is based in Toledo, Ohio, would receive $10 million to cover delinquency and foreclosure costs.

title: LOCTITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POLAND'S SHOW TRIAL
description: As the trial of the alleged murderers of the pro-Solidarity priest, the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, gets bogged down in minute details of the crime, it becomes more and more obvious that we shall learn everything, or nearly so, about the rag that was used to gag him but nothing at all about the important issue - namely, who gave the order to kill.

title: Unsanitary Conditions
description: The Sanitation Department's medical clinic has been declared by the Health Department to be ''unfit for human habitation.''

title: Bakery Unit Talks
description: The Interstate Bakeries Corporation said disagreements had arisen with privately held G.S.F.C. Inc. on the proposed sale of Interstate's western region operations, and the transaction might not be completed.

title: BOSTON EDISON CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
KENNEDY CENTER HAS PLAN FOR A NATIONAL THEATER
description: The director Peter Sellars yesterday announced his theatrical agenda for the Kennedy Center in Washington. The plan calls for free and moderately priced plays and a repertory ranging from Shakespeare to the avant-garde.

title: SKIPPER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WASHINGTON ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RESTAURANTS
description: THE new genre of downtown restaurants has become as predictable as January snowstorms. Someone buys a cavernous former industrial space or bank lobby with ceilings high enough to shag fly balls, neo-classical columns and acoustics like the trading floor of the stock exchange. The room gets a fresh coat of paint - pastel or white - a long bar with a Cruvinet wine machine and an aggressive public relations agent. Oh yes, the place also serves food, but that is usually an afterthought.

title: A THREAT TO THE REPUBLIC: 'DEBTMAIL'
description: By now, there cannot be a single literate person in the United States who is not aware that the country is in a very dangerous financial situation. Since the first of the year, almost as many newspaper column inches have been lavished on the Federal deficit and what should be done about it as were devoted to the Super Bowl.

title: THREE JURORS SAY THEY FELT TIME'S WORK WAS CARELESS
description: The six jurors who heard Ariel Sharon's libel suit against Time magazine felt strongly that Time's journalists had been careless in their reporting, but that they had not deliberately sought to harm Mr. Sharon, three of the jurors said yesterday.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $315,000. c-After a gain from discontinued operations of $31,000. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,566,000.

title: Summer Camp Survey
description: Families considering summer camp for their youngsters will have an early opportunity to survey the possibilities on Sunday from noon to 5 at the Walden School, 88th Street and Central Park West.

Paris Moves to Extend New Caledonia Decree
description: The French Government won final approval from Parliament today for an extension of the state of emergency in New Caledonia until June 30.

title: YOUTH RECEIVES MAXIMUM TERM IN ARCADE DEATH
description: An 18-year-old convicted last month in the random beating death of a high school student in an Upper East Side video game arcade was sentenced yesterday to the maximum penalty, 7Y to 22 years in prison.

title: GREAT AMERICAN FIRST SAVNGS LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STAGE: 'LIFE AND LIMB,' A DARK COMEDY
description: FOR a brief while, one might mistake Keith Reddin's ''Life and Limb,'' the new play at Playwrights Horizons's Studio Theater, for another straight-faced account of an alienated veteran's homecoming. The evening's hero is a Korean War enlistee, Franklin Roosevelt Clagg (Robert Joy), who returns home to bucolic Morristown, N.J., after having lost an arm at Pork Chop Hill. Once an optimist, Franklin is now depressed. He can't find a job, and he can no longer talk to his sweet wife, Effie (Elizabeth Perkins). Pretty soon, Effie is spending afternoons away from home, seeking out movies and another man.

title: 'Potters at Work,' a Look At Artisans in Japan
description: Though few words are spoken during ''Potters at Work,'' and none of them are in English, this brief documentary about Japanese artisans merits summation as eloquent.

title: FIRST WISCONSIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
49ER ROUT HURT TV
description: About 80 million Americans watched Super Bowl XIX last Sunday on ABC, about the same number as last year, tying it with Super Bowl XVIII as the fifth-highest rated Super Bowl and the eighth-highest rated television show.

title: Diner's Journal
description: TENTH Avenue and 46th Street is not the sort of neighborhood frequented by window shoppers pondering a cute spot for lunch. If David Ludtke has his way, however, his eccentric little restaurant, called Mike's American Bar & Grill, might be reason enough to venture into Manhattan's western frontier. How about grilled game hen with moist and crumbly cornbread dressing and vegetable salad for $4.75? Or nicely charred fresh vegetables on a skewer with a red pepper cream sauce ($5)? Or grilled bluefish with red tomato salsa ($5.50)?

title: U.S. PANEL HEARS ARGUMENTS ON BHOPAL SUITS
description: Six Federal judges heard arguments today on whether lawsuits against the Union Carbide Corporation filed after a toxic gas leak in India should be tried together and on where the litigation should begin.

title: ART: WORKS BY A FIGURE OF THE COUNTERCULTURE
description: JOHN ALTOON was a prominent figure in the southern California art scene during the 1950's and 60's. Born and trained as an artist in Los Angeles, he spent four years in New York during the heyday of Abstract Expressionism. When he returned to southern California in the mid-50's, he took with him a firsthand knowledge of the New York School and an energy and charisma that made others eager to know what he had learned. Like Jackson Pollock, Altoon died at the age of 44, and his artistic achievement must now compete with the myth of a hard- working, hard-drinking, hard-living counterculture hero.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $824.9 million, to $218.48 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Memorial at Kent State To Honor Slain Students
description: Trustees of Kent State University have agreed to build a memorial to the four students who were killed in the shootings by the National Guard in an antiwar demonstration on May 4, 1970.

title: Kicker's 2-Way Deal
description: Luis Zendejas, the Arizona State place-kicker who set a major-college career scoring record with 368 points, has joined the Arizona Outlaws of the United States Football League under an unusual agreement that could pave the way for a jump to the National Football League in the fall. He signed a one-year contract with an option clause that allows the Outlaws to match any offer he receives from an N.F.L. team. ''I see this as a long tryout,'' he said.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Jersey Transport Fund In First Bond Offering
description: The New Jersey Transportation Trust Fund Authority made its bond market debut this week with a $62 million financing through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. The bonds were offered with yields ranging from 4.75 percent for those due later this year to 8 percent for those due in 1994.

description: With his penchant for tough, emphatic pronouncements, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan has put out the public word that he will take firm command as President Reagan's top lieutenant the moment he becomes White House chief of staff, which could happen in the next day or two.

description: Visa USA, the credit card outfit with headquarters in San Mateo, Calif., has decided after a decade of doing its advertising in-house that it is time to retain an outside agency. Since the billings are about $15 million, that should awaken considerable interest along Madison Avenue.

title: Happy Birthday, Streit
description: Clarence K. Streit, a pioneer of the international federalist movement, is to be taken to lunch at the National Press Club today by friends and admirers in observance of his 89th birthday last Monday. He wrote ''Union Now,'' a widely discussed book published in 1939 proposing a federal union of 15 countries in the North Atlantic community, and he has devoted much energy since then to the concept.

description: The trumpeter Terumasa Hino and a quintet with David Liebman on saxophones and Kenny Kirkland on piano will appear tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil (242-1785), 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: CHURCH WORKER ACQUITTED IN ALIEN CASE, BUOYING MOVEMENT
description: Members of the church-based sanctuary movement for Central American refugees, meeting here, were buoyed today when a Roman Catholic lay worker was acquitted in Texas on charges of transporting illegal aliens.

description: A judge today halted closed Federal hearings on the Wilberg Mine fire that killed 27 people last month unless at least one reporter could attend.

description: Former Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that the decision in Ariel Sharon's libel case against Time magazine was a ''moral victory,'' even though the jury did not find that the magazine had libeled Mr. Sharon.

title: Occidental's New Find in Colombia
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said that tests confirmed an oil discovery at its first exploratory well in a promising field, three miles west of its huge Cano Limon find in northeast Colombia.

title: Topics ;   Across the Channels ;   AppearancesOn an average day, only a few dozen of the nearly 1,200 members of Britain's House of Lords attend. But on Wednesday, 300 showed up. There wasn't anything on the agenda that could shake the empire. Nor could the peers have done much about it if there were, except debate it eloquently. The attraction was their television debut, a chance to be seen and heard by the entire kingdom.
description: The camera's allure for the House of Lords parallels what's happened in the gavel-to-gavel coverage of the United States House of Representatives on the C-SPAN cable network.

description: Governor Cuomo yesterday began a new drive to persuade the Legislature to permit judges to sentence murderers to life in prison with no chance of parole.

description: A graphic film showing an abortion has become the latest focal point in a growing national debate over the procedure.

title: 'OTHERWORLD,' A NEW FANTASY-ADVENTURE ON CBS
description: ONE fairly reliable yardstick for determining the probable silliness of a television show is seeing how much of the plot is revealed in the opening teasers. ''Otherworld,'' a CBS series beginning tomorrow night at 8 on Channel 2, spills just about all of its story in a few seconds of clips. That may be a silliness record.

title: Dow Jones Net Up 2.7%
description: Dow Jones & Company, the publishing concern, said yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter rose 2.7 percent, to $34.4 million, or 54 cents a share, from $33.5 million, or 52 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues in the period rose 10 percent, to $257.1 million, from $233.7 million. It said comparisons were difficult because of a surge in revenues and earnings in the last two quarters of 1983.

description: The last Nazi war criminal held by Italy was freed from prison today, five months ahead of schedule. He immediately flew to Austria, where he was met by that country's Defense Minister.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: HAVING spent the last few months on tour to promote ''1984,'' John Hurt and Michael Radford, the film's star and director, have had ample opportunities to explain why it opened in the United States in 1985. For one thing, they say, the film is already playing in England, France, Australia and plenty of other places; the United States is one of the few countries in which it missed George Orwell's deadline. For another, the year 1984 began with a barrage of Orwell- related publicity that might not have helped the film at all.

title: HEAD OF DAVID'S COOKIES OFFERING TO BUY ZABAR'S

title: Beyond an Absence of Malice
description: A meticulous jury has found Time magazine negligent and careless in printing a false and defamatory report about Gen. Ariel Sharon of Israel. But after deliberating five days on the most crucial question, the jury found no malice. And that, given how American law treats public figures, means no libel and means the end of his $50 million damage claim. General Sharon wins much of his case but Time wins the suit. An issue that should never have had to come to trial has been resolved in a constructive way.

title: Spanish Exports Surge

title: Helgi Tomasson Retiring
description: Helgi Tomasson, a principal dancer and choreographer with the New York City Ballet, has announced that he will retire from performing. His last appearance as a dancer will be tomorrow night, when he dances Balanchine's ''Divertimento From 'Le Baiser de la Fee,' '' a role created for him in 1972. Also on the program will be Mr. Tomasson's ballet, ''Menuetto.'' Mr. Tomasson, who was born in Iceland, joined the City Ballet in 1970.

title: R.J. Reynolds

Reynolds said it was selling the unit as part of its efforts to focus on consumer-related businesses.

title: CONCERT: JUILLIARD ENSEMBLE AT TULLY HALL
description: Time has dealt kindly with John Cage's Concerto for Prepared Piano and Chamber Orchestra, which he composed in 1951. Performed as the opening work in the ''Focus!'' concert presented by the Juilliard School at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night, the concerto had a post-Webern pointillist sound with a gamelan touch. The fact that Mr. Cage did not arrive at the result through use of the serial technique favored by Webern made no difference at all.

title: Computer Layoffs
description: Commodore International Ltd. said today that it is temporarily laying off 540 workers at two Pennsylvania factories because of lagging sales of its Commodore 64 home computer. A company spokesman said the layoffs, which would last up to 10 weeks, would help the company reduce its inventories of computers. The company said 240 production workers would be furloughed at its plant in West Chester, and another 300 workers would be laid off at its Valley Forge semiconductor plant.

title: SCOUTING ;   The Missing Man
description: George Steinbrenner usually gets what he wants, and for a long time he wanted to see the University of South Florida play basketball in Madison Square Garden. After all, he is a leading patron of the university, which is situated in Tampa, where Steinbrenner lives and keeps his office as chairman of the American Shipbuilding Company.

title: Low Inflation in Japan
description: Lower oil prices helped Japan record a 2.2 percent inflation rate in 1984, its second lowest in 25 years, the Government reported today. The Management and Coordination Agency said 1984's 2.2 percent rise in nationwide consumer prices was slightly higher than the 1.9 percent of 1983, but was the second lowest since a 1 percent increase in 1959.

title: 2 Abortion Clinics Delayed by Judge
description: An order blocking the opening of two abortion clinics, which had been obtained by the Roman Catholic Bishop of Albany, was continued today in State Supreme Court.

description: Orders to factories for durable goods fell 2.1 in December, for the third decline in four months, the Commerce Department said today. Still, orders for the full year rose a strong 14.9 percent.

The ceremony was performed by Town Justice Mercator Kendrick at his home in Southampton, L.I.

title: Federated to Sell Boston Store Unit
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the Cincinnati-based retail company, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Boston Store division to P.A. Bergner & Company for $80 million.

description: The Florida Citrus Commission has ordered a seven-day ban on shipping fresh oranges and grapefruit to keep fruit damaged by the state's worst freeze of the century out of the marketplace.

title: CARBIDE SAYS IT AVERTED THREAT AT U.S. PLANT

75 'HONEYMOONERS' EPISODES FOUND
description: Jackie Gleason has gone into his vaults and come up with 75 episodes of ''The Honeymooners'' produced between 1952 and 1955 that were believed to have been lost. Most passionate fans of the series believed those programs to be unrecorded television signals that were last seen on earth in the Eisenhower years and were probably hurtling through deep space.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a table and article in Business Day Thursday about corporate write-offs misstated one taken by the Colgate-Palmolive Company. It was $174 million before taxes in the fourth quarter.

title: POLISH COURT SEES VIDEOTAPE ON PRIEST
description: Three former security police officers on trial for murdering a dissident priest buried their heads today as a videotape was played in court showing the recovery of the priest's bound body from a reservoir.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: HARLEM EXHIBITION The civil rights movement erupted a little more than 20 years ago, and as with most great tides of change, it inspired art - much of it, in this instance, by black painters and photographers. With the rush of events in those years of radically changing perceptions, large bodies of work failed to receive the critical analysis that only the passage of time allows.

description: Floods caused by monthlong rains have killed at least 71 people and left thousands homeless in three southeastern Brazilian states, civil defense spokesmen said today.

title: Deficit Up 14.4% in Quarter
description: The Federal Government spent $15.2 billion more than it collected in December, making the deficit for the first three months of the 1985 fiscal year 14.4 percent worse than a year earlier, the Treasury Department said today.

title: O'CONNOR LAUDS VATICAN PLAN
description: Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York, welcoming Pope John Paul II's call for a review of the Second Vatican Council, said last night that he believed the move reflected concern that the Council's work ''has been misinterpreted and perhaps misused.''

description: A Federal appeals court today restored the right of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. to use the initials in its name.

title: New Talks Scheduled In British Coal Strike

title: The Real Trouble With the Dollar The dollar is now worth 70 percent more than in 1980. That's a mixed blessing, at best. It's good news for bargain-hunting Americans in London and Paris and for any American who buys foreign goods. It's a major factor in holding down inflation because American products must remain competitive. But there's a high cost for these benefits.
description: The lower prices abroad are drastically shrinking America's older industries. The ''strong'' dollar is causing American farmers to lose overseas customers. Even I.B.M., the titan of American exporters, complains that the rising dollar has depressed its computer profits. Only this currency gap keeps farmers and I.B.M. from holding their own in world markets.

description: A senior Taiwan official said today that Henry Liu, a Chinese-American author killed in California last October, had been a paid informant for the Nationalist Government for more than three years before his death.

description: The Reagan Administration has begun talks with key members of Congress on whether to continue trying to support the anti-Government rebels in Nicaragua with covert aid or whether to try different approaches, State Department officials said today.

description: Austria's Chancellor publicly censured his Defense Minister today for meeting and escorting a returning Nazi war criminal who had been freed from an Italian prison.

A Research Tool For Leukemia Cases
description: A method of separating charged particles such as proteins was patented this week by two specialists at the University of Maryland Cancer Center in Baltimore. Timothy P. Karpetsky and Glenn E. Brown assigned patent 4,495,279 to the Department of Health and Human Services in Washington.

title: FLU RISING AND U.S. URGES SHOTS
description: The Centers for Disease Control said today that influenza outbreaks around the country were striking people of all ages and that those in high-risk groups should immediately have vaccinations.

description: ''The guy who owns a pickup truck and uses it to take his wife to a movie on Saturday night ought not to be put through a blizzard of paper work.'' - James A. Baker 3d, nominee to be Secretary of the Treasury. (1:3.)

title: U.S. AND SPECIAL COUNSEL QUESTION MEESE REQUEST FOR PAYMENT TO LAWYERS
description: In court papers made public today, both the Justice Department and the independent counsel who investigated Edwin Meese 3d question whether he is entitled to the $720,923 he is seeking to pay lawyers who represented him in the investigation.

title: STAGE: KERN'S 'OH, BOY!' CELEBRATES A CENTENNIAL
description: It is gratifying that with all the justified hoopla being accorded the anniversaries of Bach, Handel, Scarlatti and Sch"utz, we aren't forgetting our own Jerome Kern, whose 100th birthday would have been tomorrow. And of all the Kern celebrations, none could be classier than the series of three lovingly reconstructed Princess Theater musicals being offered in concert form at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Companies Held Liable In Any Bias by Managers
description: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that a company is responsible under Federal antidiscrimination law when its supervisors sexually harass employees they oversee, even if the employer is not aware of allegations of harassment.

title: AT ANTIQUES SHOW, A SENSE OF DRAMA
description: More than in previous years, there was a sense of exuberance as the 31st Annual Winter Antiques Show got under way last night at the Seventh Regiment Armory. Perhaps it was because the booths were more spacious and beautifully appointed or because more rare and unusual objects were on display or because the decorations were unusually stylish. Whatever the reasons, the opening-night parties had a special air of drama.

title: Doubts Cited On Conrail Sale
description: The Department of Transportation's private financial adviser on the sale of Conrail has asserted that the carrier's proposal to allow the public to buy the Government-owned rail network would not satisfy the department's concerns over the best way to dispose of it.

title: ACTIVIST TREND FOUND IN RELIGIOUS CHARITIES
description: Although religious organizations continue to provide billions of dollars in traditional charity for the hungry and homeless, a new survey has found a growing trend among religious groups to increase financial support for social change, human rights and advocacy issues.

title: New Vaccine Reported For a Bacterial Illness
description: A vaccine awaiting Government approval is a cost-effective way to protect thousands of children from a bacterial illness that can lead to a serious form of meningitis, according to a study published today.

title: Revolving in South Korea
description: Reaching for a word to throw at the returning exile Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's ruling soldiers have resorted to an all-purpose oldie: revolutionary. This is accurate in the sense that Jefferson, too, was a revolutionary. Mr. Kim agitates for free elections and civilian government - so strenuously that after a strong run for President in 1971 he was kidnapped from Japan, jailed and sentenced to death after a suspect military trial in 1980.

title: SCOUTING ;   Boys of Winter
description: Other baseball players appeared this week, and can spring be far behind? On the manicured stage of Dodger Stadium, 27 members of the Los Angeles Dodgers took part in the opening workouts that will be held there until the team leaves for spring training in Florida next month.

title: MCDONNELL CLIMBS 11%; SHELL OIL GAINS 5.8%
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1984 rose 11 percent on a 27.2 percent increase in sales, which were bolstered by the inclusion of the results of three recently acquired companies.

title: Nicaragua Tells 5,000 Youths To Report for Military Service
description: The Nicaraguan Government today ordered all youths from 19 to 24 years old in the central province of Managua to report for compulsory military service or face imprisonment.

title: KIRKPATRICK: IN-FRONT-OF-SCENE TALKS
description: Just when it seemed that every approach and maneuver had already been tried, the fine art of seeking top-level Administration positions appears to be undergoing a new refinement. description: A former Government official told the House of Commons today that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had rejected sexual advances from a drunken dignitary by telling him, ''I just don't think you would make it at the moment.''

title: Alaska Pipeline Reactivated
description: Oil is running again through the Alaska oil pipeline after a 65-hour shutdown to allow workers to seal off a section of sagging pipe and replace it with a temporary section for bypassing the faulty area. Kay Herring, spokesman for the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, said pump stations along the 800-mile line were activated beginning at 4 P.M. Thursday. The line had been shut down Monday night.

Mary Decker was cheered and booed before the women's mile, but there were only cheers after she won.

description: Eight vintages of Ch^ateau Latour, one of the five wines officially designated as the greatest Bordeaux, were offered at several tastings in New York last week in what appeared to be part of a new marketing effort by the famous vineyard in the Haut-Medoc. All five first growths, as they are designated, are well known, but Latour probably less than the rest: Ch^ateaux Haut-Brion, Lafite- Rothschild, Margaux and Mouton-Rothschild.

title: U.S. MOVING TO DEPORT WIFE OF A CITIZEN
description: Federal immigration authorities have begun deportation proceedings against a Salvadoran woman whose husband and 2-year-old son are American citizens. The action reverses earlier decisions that have allowed her to remain in New York City for nearly five years.

The Rev. Seymour St. John performed the ceremony at Christ Memorial Episcopal Chapel in Hobe Sound, Fla.

title:

This week we will discuss the sunny location with good soil, and next week we will finish the series with the shady location with adequate light.

title: RED BANK FRESHMAN WINS 440-YARD DASH

title: The Right-to-Life Debate

I am an internist and oncologist, and nearly every day deal with issues for adults in some ways analogous to the ones described in the article.

title: THE VIETNAM WAR AS THEATER AND AN ACT OF EXORCISM
description: When John Di Fusco came back from the Vietnam War, he bought himself a sports car with his earnings, and then drove it over a cliff. He did not succeed in killing himself, although the car was demolished; but the feelings that had propelled him did not go away, and he repeatedly broke both hands smashing them through walls.

title: SETTING PRICES OF ZERO-COUPON BONDS
description: THE virtues of zero-coupon bonds - ones that pay no interest and are sold at deep discounts - have become so familiar that it is almost axiomatic to say they are the perfect investment vehicles for retirement accounts or a child's college education. Although they have been available for less than three years, an estimated $20 billion of the bonds have been sold to individuals.

title: UP FROM THE GARRET: SUCCESS THEN AND NOW
description: What ever happened to the literary underground? The image of the avant- garde writer in resistance to the status quo, keeping a critical distance from the establishment, used to be part of a sustaining myth for many poets and novelists well through the 50's. Today, if you raise the old question of ''selling out'' among writers, the response is likely to be not a tortured ''whether?'' but an ironic ''how?'' The 60's, Ronald Sukenick is working on a nonfiction narrative about the American cultural underground. A novel, ''Blown Away,'' will be published this year, as well as two other books. with an avant-garde vitality yet to be assessed, redefined much in American culture, including middle-class esthetic standards, but at the same time eroded the mystique by which artists had resisted the pressures of the marketplace. Nobody planned it that way, but there is a logic in the history of the situation. Subterraneans wanted simultaneously to rant at Moloch and be part of Moloch, as if you could bite the hand of oppression and then demand it feed you. However, the contradictions that caused the collapse of the underground, once apparent, may finally define its legitimate relation to the culture.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

RUNNING WOTHOUT GUILT
description: A NEIGHBOR of mine jogs by my house every morning with his daughter. On the surface there is nothing remarkable in that fact, except that he is 45 and she is only 6 months old. No matter how often I see them pass, a smile steals over me, not only because it is rare and to my mind wonderful for a man in his mid-40's to father a child but because the image they present is marvelously comic. Dressed in running shorts, sneakers, and wearing headphones, my neighbor, stooping slightly forward, pushes his daughter's stroller before him with one hand while his little girl reclines regally, smiling at the world as it races by. She is still too young to blow kisses or wave, but I suspect one day, as a result of this early training, she will run for public office. As for my neighbor, he has become a great source of inspiration to me.

title: QUEBECERS SEEM INTERESTED IN SUCCESS, NOT SECESSION
description: As Montreal's French language press told it, a menagerie ran loose at a stormy special convention of the Parti Quebecois last weekend. There were the ''caribous'' - party hard-liners who seemed prepared to plunge to self-destruction rather than abandon the dream of an independent Quebec. The allusion was to the thousands of caribous that drowned fording a swollen river in northern Quebec last autumn. Then there were the ''kangaroos'' - moderates who wanted to tuck the emotional issue of separatism in their pockets as the only way to hold power in Quebec's next provincial election, probably this year. The kangaroos beat the caribous nearly 2 to 1, but at the cost of aggravating party divisions. A walkout by several hundred independence militants raised questions about the political survival not only of Quebec Premier Rene Levesque, but also the party itself. The split, as a party member analyzed it last week, was ''a cleavage in generations,'' not so much in age as in thinking. For some French-speaking Quebecers, the vision of a Quebec independent of English-speaking Canada is undimmed. For the rest, including Mr. Levesque, the founder of the party, the ideal has been overshadowed by more prosaic realities. The Parti Quebecois came to power in 1976 on a wave of disgust with the Liberal Party's corruption and mismanagement. Labor unrest was so severe that Quebec was losing six million work days a year through strikes and lockouts, roughly one day for every citizen. Mr. Levesque promised better government and then, as now, soft-pedaled the sovereignty issue.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES

But this traditional music and movement, which will be performed by four virtuoso drummer-dancers at Asia Society Friday through next Sunday, has much appeal for the urban sensibility, exposed as it is to minimalistic and trance music and dance and the vitality of the punk influence.

Last year The Knitting Room was added for sale of Brother home knitting machines and domestic and imported yarns and knitting supplies.

DIVERSITY MARKS BELL STREET GROUP
description: THE East End Arts and Humanities Council in Riverhead is currently playing host to the Bell Street Artists, a five-person group based in Bellport. The association was formed eight years ago, according to its brochure, ''to increase public awareness and enjoyment of all the visual arts.'' To this end, its members have exhibited in various galleries around the Island.

O'Neill Jr. when they met in private: ''In my 50 years of public life, I've never seen a man more popular than you are with the American people.''

A moment later he seems to contradict himself. At other times, he repeatedly says, ''Don't remember,'' when asked about experiences he described to psychologists months ago.

title: Article 243984 -- No Title
description: Ammi Phillips's 1830's ''Portrait of a Girl in a Red Dress,'' purchased for $60 more than a half century ago, sold yesterday at Christie's for $682,000, the highest price paid at auction for an American folk-art painting.

title: Elizabeth Hochstadter To Marry A. P. Dicker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fred Hochstadter of Montreal have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Carolyn Hochstadter, to Adam Paul Dicker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Zachary J. Dicker of Great Neck, L.I. An August wedding is planned.

title: CORRECTION
description: The article headed ''Selective Guide to Posh London'' in last Sunday's Travel section misstated Lord Byron's weights and the dates he visited Berry Brothers wine merchants. He weighed 194 pounds in 1806 and 137 1/2 pounds in 1811.

title: NEW STORES WITH OLD REPUTATIONS
description: Two stores - Abercrombie & Fitch and Aquascutum - recently opened in New York, and each has brought with it, aside from a veritable ton or two of merchandise, an equal amount of reputation leavened with helpings of nostalgia.

title: BUNDLING THE MILITARY BUDGET
description: RARELY has any industry enjoyed a better operating environment than the nation's military contractors do today. Not since the Vietnam War has there been such heavy demand for weapons. The Reagan Adminstration has been progressively increasing budgets for military hardware since it arrived in Washington four years ago, and the Pentagon, for its part, has been working overtime to help contractors overcome their reputation for gross industrial backwardness and woefully inefficient production.

title: Clash at Shipyard
description: Three weeks after the Boston Shipyard Corporation began to overhaul the frigate Connole, the Navy canceled the $8.5 million contract. It said it was dissatisfied with the work.

title: CRIME: HOW IT DESTROYS, WHAT CAN BE DONE
description: Roger Starr is a member of the editorial board of The Times. This article is adapted from ''The Rise and Fall of New York City,'' to be published by Basic Books later this year.

title: GREAT AMERICANS SERIES
description: Abraham Baldwin, considered the ''father'' of the state university system, was honored by the release of a 7-cent stamp in the Great Americans Series last Friday. The ceremony was part of the Founders Week ceremonies held at the University of Georgia, Athens. Mr. Baldwin wrote the charter for Franklin College, the oldest college at the University of Georgia, in 1785.

title: NO TIME TO SAVOR VICTORY IN TOPSY-TURVY SEASON
description: STILL wearing a sweat-soaked blue uniform, the Duke senior forward Dan Meagher sat before an unfamiliar locker and eagerly entertained reporters' questions in the aftermath of his team's 16-point conquest of North Carolina. ''Now I know what the Duke-Carolina rivalry is all about,'' said the Canadian Olympian from St. Catherines, Ontario. ''People don't even care if we go to the tournament, or win in the A.C.C. tournament, as long as we beat Carolina.'' He was speaking of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Atlantic Coast Conference tourneys.

title: FROM SUN AND SUGAR AN ISLAND BREW
description: FLORENCE FABRICANT writes frequently about food and wine for The Times.

title: NEGLECTED OPERA AND FAMILIAR SINGERS SHARE THE SPOTLIGHT
description: Ermanno Wolf-Ferrari (1876- 1948) is not exactly a repertory composer, but he has his coterie of followers, who respond to his fine Italianate melody coupled to a touch of German post-Romanticism. Thus his ''Segreto di Susanna,'' ''Le donne curiose'' and ''I quattro rusteghi'' remain at least on the periphery of the repertory, and attractive works they are. His most notorious work, however, seems virtually to have disappeared. That is ''I gioielli della Madonna'' - ''The Jewels of the Madonna'' - his one verismo opera, which made such a sensation in 1911.

title: Fire Kills 2 Children; Parents Are Arrested
description: A 6-year-old girl and her 3-year-old brother were killed in a fire at their suburban split-level home here early today, and their parents were later arrested, the East Hanover police said.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND

title: JORDAN SCORES 45 IN BULLS' TRIUMPH
description: Michael Jordan dazzled Atlanta with a 45- point barrage tonight to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 117-104 triumph over the Atlanta Hawks.

description: As a Soviet-West German trade commission met in Bonn last week, Deputy Prime Minister Aleksei K. Antonov was heard to remark that Soviet traders were seeking ''the technology of tomorrow, not of yesterday or today.''

description: In order to broaden its scope of activities for field dogs, the American Kennel Club yesterday disclosed that in 1986 it would hold hunting tests leading to titles.

description: James Galway, a great flutist, is only a journeyman conductor, and so the most rewarding moments of his Wednesday evening concert at the 92d Street Y came when he set aside his baton and picked up his flute.

title: CD'S AND LASERDISKS ARE AT HOME IN A SINGLE PLAYER
description: Audio and video used to inhabit different spheres, serving different publics. Even technical standards were far apart, with the video audience being less demanding in terms of quality than the seasoned audiophile. But now the gap has narrowed, and unified audio/video home entertainment centers with high technical performance standards seem to be a rising trend.

title: Dr. Robert McCaffrey To Marry Miss Levine
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert Levine of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Sara Beth Levine to Dr. Robert McCaffrey, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis McCaffrey of West Bridgewater, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

description: In her account of the Baby Jane Doe case, Marcia Chambers describes lawyer A. Lawrence Washburn Jr.'s intervention as unwelcome, intrusive and expensive to all concerned. However, she neglects ample evidence that Mr. Washburn was correct in all essential points.

title: THE DISADVANTAGES OF OBVIOUS GAMBITS
description: One of the strengths demanded of a really good gambit is that it not be obvious. It should entice the opponent to accept the sacrificed pawn or other material, not scare him off.

Bernstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Bernstein of Scarsdale, N.Y. Miss Heller is a senior at Boston University. Her fiance, an associate in the New York law office of Gaston, Snow, Beekman & Bogue, graduated from Lake Forest College and cum laude from the Boston University Law School. A July wedding is planned.

title: THE TOWER BLIGHT HAS STRUCK WEST 57TH STREET
description: This is an only-in-New York story as much as it is an architecture story, and it is not one that will endear anyone to the ways of New York. It is a tale of cultural institutions and real estate developers and architects and city planners, and how they seem unable, even with the best of intentions, to pull together to make a coherent city.

title: THE DANCE: ALICE FARLEY
description: Brilliantly colored lines and objects appear and disappear, flying self-propelled across the dark stage of the Marymount Manhattan Theater, where Alice Farley and Dancers opened on Wednesday in ''No Dry Land.'' The accompanying music and sound scores seem to come from eerily unidentifiable instruments or machines, and stage and lighting effects add, too, to the look of living fantasy.

title: OPERA: 'ARIADNE' CAST SHIFTS
description: The three changes in the cast of ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' at the Metropolitan Opera Thursday night brought a sense of respectability to Strauss's music, though nothing new or glowing. Teresa Kubiak - who has twice replaced Jessye Norman as the Prima Donna in recent weeks - sang with a sure soprano, which in the lower registers tended to fade but otherwise bore the vocal burdens of ''Ariadne'' in a dignified and utilitarian way.

title: FEWER BALD EAGLES SIGHTED
description: PRELIMINARY counts show that 23 bald eagles were sighted in Connecticut during the National Wildlife Federation's mid-winter bald eagle survey, in which more than 100 volunteers participated.

title: THE NEW, IMPROVED OHIO RIVER
description: The Ohio River twists its way through a thousand miles of smokestack America, and its problems go back a couple of generations. The factories that brought prosperity to the Ohio Valley a half century ago also dumped millions of gallons of unidentified, untreated sludge and other wastes into the river, killing fish and causing health problems among the people who lived or worked near its banks.

description: Len Ceglarski became the fourth coach in college hockey history to win 500 games in his career when Boston College defeated Providence, 5-2, on Jan. 19.

title: INDIA'S UNITY IS CELEBRATED AMID STRAINS
description: As usual, elephants in billowing satin blankets carried children who had won awards for heroism. Helicopters flew by, showering the delighted crowd with marigold and rose petals. Tribal dancers marched to the music of bells and drums.

title: KEAN KEEPS HIS DOOR OPEN AND AN EYE PEELED FOR A MIKE
description: Governor Kean's desire to be New Jersey's most visible chief executive has made him a daunting political presence as he prepares for the coming campaign. If the Governor runs for re-election, as expected, the Democrats will encounter a Republican incumbent whose popularity rivals that of President Reagan and Senator Bill Bradley, according to polls by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.

title: CLOGGED DRAINS: PREVENTION AND CURE
description: LIKE many other annoying maintenance problems around the house, a clogged sink drain is a lot easier to avoid than to take care of after it happens. Although many homeowners seem to think that clogged drains are almost inevitable, this is not necessarily true. There is no reason why the problem cannot be avoided by following some common-sense precautions and by seeing to it that all members of the family avoid practices that can easily lead to a clogged sink drain.

title: Melinda B. Crane To Be the Bride Of Jurgen Engel
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David A. Crane of Dover, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Melinda Beth Crane to Jurgen Engel, a son of Marlies Engel of D"usseldorf, West Germany, and the late Wilhelm Engel. A late summer wedding is being planned.

title: HOWARD ENDS LONG DAY ABOVE REST
description: It was a long day for Jim Howard. A good one, too, he agreed.

title: MORE TWO-SEAT MODELS TO ENTER MARKET

title: KEAN WILL PROPOSE $8.8 BILLION BUDGET, INCLUDING TAX RELIEF
description: Governor Kean will ask the New Jersey Legislature Monday to approve an $8.8 billion 1985-86 state budget that is up by 11 percent over this year's but includes $794 million in programs designed to provide tax relief.

title: O'NEILL TO SEEK MORE SPENDING FOR EDUCATION
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill has proposed increases of about 12 percent in state spending for education and criminal-justice programs.

title: ADS FOR ILLEGAL APARTMENTS BANNED
description: JOSEPHINE McGrath was not alone in her anger and frustration. She had taken to the podium before the Smithtown Town Board, she said, to speak for 20 of her neighbors who also were disturbed at what she called the ''epidemic'' of illegal multifamily houses on their block.

title: Elizabeth Kearns To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. David T. Kearns of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth C. Kearns, to Van G. Young, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Young of Atlanta, formerly of New Canaan. The wedding is to take place on May 25.

title: SCREEN: 'THE PERILS OF GWENDOLINE'
description: If imitation is flattery, then ''The Perils of Gwendoline'' could be considered a big compliment to Steven Spielberg, Roger Vadim, John Derek, Frederick of Hollywood and Bruce Lee. Just Jaeckin, the director of ''Emmanuelle,'' has this time concocted a ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' knockoff that eventually turns into ''Barbarella,'' with a heroine (Tawny Kitaen) whose doe-eyed dopiness recalls Bo Derek, although her looks do not.

title: Debra Groark Is a Bride
description: Debra Ann Groark, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Groark of Deer Park, L.I., was married there yesterday to Brian Fogarty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Fogarty of Massapequa Park, L.I. The Rev. James Peters performed the ceremony at SS. Cyril and Methodius Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Fogarty is a special-education teacher at Public School 45 in Brooklyn. Her husband is a New York City police officer.

title: SERIES OF WOMEN'S MURDERS UNSETTLES FORT WORTH
description: The Tarrant County Medical Examiner's office Thursday made what had become a chillingly commonplace announcement. For the fourth time since Jan. 1, the remains of a woman had been found in the area; for the fourth time, the body belonged to one of five young Fort Worth woman who had disappeared since September.

title: GEORGE GRIZZARD RECALLS A LIFE ON STAGE
description: GEORGE GRIZZARD'S life as an actor began some 50 years ago in Washington, where he grew up. He remembers taking long rides in the car with his parents, while he concocted elaborate scenarios for himself and his imaginary playmates in the back seat.

title: SPIRITED ALBANIAN IMMIGRANTS ADAPT AS LANDLORDS
description: The Shalas are an Albanian-American family who started out as building superintendents in Brooklyn 16 years ago and now own four apartment buildings and a theater in the Bronx as well as a restaurant in Manhattan.

title: COUNTY CONFERS ON OUTLOOK FOR U.S. AID
description: WESTCHESTER'S elected officials focused on the Federal level last week in their continuing efforts to raise money for major projects. They said that they felt the effort was successful in terms of opening new channels of communication but that the outlook for financial aid was sobering.

title: THEY'RE GETTING BETTER ABOUT PREDICTING THE WEATHER (EVEN THOUGH YOU DON'T BELIEVE IT)
description: James Gleick is an assistant metropolitan editor of The Times.

title: JAILED SOUTH AFRICA REBEL GIVES TRUCE TERMS
description: Nelson Mandela, South Africa's most prominent jailed nationalist, was quoted today in a rare interview as saying his armed followers would call a truce in their war against white rule if the authorities would ''legalize us, treat us like a political party and negotiate with us.''

title: TOWNS SEEK TO JOIN REFUSE DISTRICT
description: WHITE PLAINS CONCERNED about vanishing landfills, a half dozen northern Westchester communities who declined to join the county's Refuse Distict No. 1 when it was created in 1982, are now applying to get in.

title: Ambulance Service: The Need to Act Now
description: Shelly Feuer Domash provided an invaluable service to the public in her article ''Ambulance Service Debated'' (Dec. 9).

title: FAST FOOD TOUCHES RAW NERVE ON FIFTH
description: KENT L. BARWICK, president of the Municipal Art Society, has nothing against fast food per se. ''Fast food is an integral part of our society,'' he said. Then, his tone becoming more severe, he added: ''But there's a place for it. It's wrong to have a Roy Rogers on Fifth Avenue.''

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

WANTED: A CLEAN, SAFE LAND
description: THE article ''Farewell to Our Private Wilderness,'' by Diana Hogan (Opinion Page, Jan. 6), struck a familiar chord in my heart. I also remember Long Island as it used to be some 30- odd years ago when I was growing up. The only difference between us is that Diana Hogan remembers it as a young parent and I remember it as a child.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER/PLAYTIME
description: -ups, there is a theory. For the children, there is play, play, play. But for the grown- ups, sometimes, there is also play. Big pieces of equipment - red, blue, yellow, green - are scattered about the cavernous gymnasium. They are set up for the babies and toddlers, who bounce, crawl, climb in and over and under them. When the youngsters are finished frolicking, their parents are handed little cards imprinted with intellectual explanations of what their children have been doing. The adults read these cards - but they also play.

title: BEIRUT CABINET SHAKEN BY A RESIGNATION
description: A widely respected political figure resigned from the Government today in a move that could threaten the collapse of Prime Minister Rashid Karami's Cabinet.

title: U.S. PRELATES SURPRISED BUT PLEASED OVER SYNOD
description: American Cardinals, Bishops and theologians said yesterday that they were stunned by Pope John Paul II's announcement that he is calling an extraordinary synod of bishops to examine the results of the Second Vatican Council, which ended 20 years ago. But they welcomed the synod as an opportunity for bishops to discuss developments since Vatican II directly with the Pope.

title: Translating H"olderlin To the Editor:
description: I would like to add a brief note to W. S. Merwin's review of Richard SiEburth's translation of the s ''Hymns and Fragments'' of Friedrich H"olderlin (Dec. 30). Mr. Merwin notes what he calls a ''lapse'' in Mr. Sieburth's language: ''It is hard to imagine that 'But much / to be retained. And loyalty a must' bears close similarity to the idiom of H"olderlin.''

title: IN THE POCKET
description: -fi and pocket television, so why not pocket encyclopedias? As a matter of fact, we do. And if it's true that good things come in small packages, then they should be very valuable indeed. Of course, like a true curmudgeon, I denounced them when they first appeared. Now I use them all the time.

title: Tremor Shakes Westchester
description: A minor earth tremor shook windows and alarmed Westchester County residents near here today, according to the Yonkers police. There were no reports of damage or injuries from the tremor, which measured 2.2 on the Richter scale, the police said.

title: BRITAIN'S ROCK UNDERGROUND IS WORTH EXPLORING
description: The Fall has been active, in one form or another, since the beginnings of the punk rock scene in the British industrial city of Manchester, in the mid-1970's. But mention the group to most American rock fans, even Anglophiles, and you are likely to draw a blank. You won't find a representative range of Fall disks in many import stores, and with one or two exceptions the group is rarely featured in the music press.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE Meadowmere Park Firemen's Benevolent Association has won its case in State Supreme Court in Mineola and will be allowed to sell the pie-shaped property it owns on West Avenue in the small waterside community of 80 homes that lies on the Queens border on Jamaica Bay, 1,000 yards from Kennedy Airport.

description: FOR the teachers and administrators from the Scarsdale school district who gathered for an exercise class at the Heathcote School, the course catalogue promised they would ''improve posture, tighten muscles and banish unwanted inches.''

title: COMPOSERS' BIRTHDAY CONCERTS ARE IN ABUNDANCE
description: AS everybody with even a glimmer of musical awareness must surely know by now, this is the 300th birthday year of Handel, Bach and Scarlatti, and as the actual dates approach (in February, March and October, respectively) concert celebrations proliferate.

title: RESTING PLACES Wrong PartySixteen months ago, President Reagan signed a bill creating a commission to plan celebration of the bicentennial of the Constitution in 1987. He hasn't named a single member, but if that were the only sign of his interest it might not warrant notice. There's still plenty of time to arrange a fitting tribute to this greatest of all American inventions.
description: But the White House has chosen one person to work up some preparations. He is former Senator Roger Jepsen of Iowa, whose devotion to the Constitution was imaginatively demonstrated recently in a traffic incident. Mr. Jepsen invoked the Constitution to justify driving, alone and defiantly, in an expressway lane reserved for car poolers.

description: President Hafez al-Assad has declared an amnesty for some members of the outlawed Moslem Brotherhood organization who are imprisoned in Syria and has invited those in exile to return to the country, state-controlled newspapers reported today.

description: FOR more than 25 years the problem of anabolic-androgenic steroids has been plaguing the field of athletics. The conflicting reports in the medical and athletic literature, along with the widespread testimonial type pronouncements, has continued to muddy the water on this subject.

description: OPEC oil ministers, gathering here for an emergency meeting that begins Monday, seemed today to be headed for a collision over how to cope with a glut of oil that has been eroding prices.

title: THE STATES ENTER THE VENTURE CAPITAL GAME
description: IRONICS INC. of Ithaca, N.Y., was nearly out of cash last February. The founders of the two-year-old company had gone through their own initial investment and they had used up a $120,000 loan from the Small Business Administration. The microcomputer they had developed for factory automation systems was selling, but not well enough. And Ironics could not get fresh money from a bank or from a venture capital firm, which considered the little electronics company too risky.

title: TATIANA TROYANOS SINGS THE PRAISES OF HANDEL

Miss Troyanos, the versatile American mezzo-soprano, hopes to bless Handel as well when she sings the title role in his ''Ariodante'' tonight as part of Carnegie Hall's continuing Handel Opera Festival.

title: 17 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 17 food establishments cited for violations of the health code.

title: UNDER ARREST: ONE DRIVER'S STORY
description: I'D had one of those days at the office that makes you want to fall on your sword. Instead, I did the civilized thing and reparired to the bar across the street for a few tension relievers. Then a few more. Before I knew it, I was threading my way home through Los Angeles traffic - calm, relaxed and drunk. It happens sometimes.

title: THE ISRAEL-EGYPT BEACH TUG-OF-WAR

title: A RAIL RUN IS TESTING STEAM USE
description: Ever so slowly, Engine 614 moved out of the train yard at Huntington, gray plumes of smoke rising rhythmically from the smokestack, at the start of a 150-mile run through the mountains of West Virginia to this town.

title: LASTING LONDON
description: LONDON IS A MAN'S TOWN, there's power in the air,'' wrote Henry van Dyke, the American clergyman and author, at the turn of the century. He was right - at the time. Englishmen, in their dark, meticulously tailored suits, provided London with a somber sartorial glory. Then, but no longer. Beginning in the l960's and continuing into the early part of this decade - first with the ''mods'' and later with the ''rockers'' and the ''punks'' - Britain gained more notoriety for fashion fancy than for fashion permanence.

title: DANCE: 'FLAMENCO MORO,' WITH MARIA ALBA
description: ''Flamenco Moro' did much to make one forget the winter chill Sunday afternoon. Presented in the Park Royal Theater, the program was a concert of Spanish flamenco and Middle Eastern dances choreographed by Maria Alba, Victorio Korjhan, Manolo Rivera, Curro Saraya and Elena.

title: Virginia Neaher Weds S.M. Pape
description: The marriage of Virginia Ann Neaher, director of government relations for the American Stock Exchange in Washington, to Stuart Michael Pape, a partner in the Washington law firm of Patton, Boggs & Blow, took place yesterday at the Jefferson Hotel in Washington. Rabbi Harold White performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. Myer Tobey, a Roman Catholic priest, participated.

title: MORE AMERICANS MAY DIE IN LEBANON
description: The Lebanese groups that have attacked Americans over the past two years have repeatedly made clear their intention to elimi nate the American presence from Lebanon. Yet the American reaction has been to disbelieve them. This is a serious mistake that has cost many lives and, unless repaired, promises to consume many more.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Travel Advisory item on Jan. 6 misidentified Penshurst Place in England. It is the seat of the family of the Elizabethan poet Sir Philip Sidney; the Viscount de L'Isle is head of the family. The accompanying photograph, incorrectly labeled, was of John Keats's house in Hampstead.

description: Morris Lipsett, who took down Penn Station and the Third Avenue El and scrapped Navy dreadnoughts and luxury liners as one of the world's largest demolition and salvage experts, died of cancer yesterday at Mt. Sinai Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: Helen Frank's article ''Whatever Happened to Manners? Where's the Golden Rule?'' (Jan. 13) did not engage my sympathetic agreement. The same week I received a 'thank you' letter from a 15-year-old grandson.

title: Iran: Obsessed With Martyrdom
description: John Kifner's article, ''Iran: Obsessed With Martyrdom'' (Dec. 16), is certainly welcome, but it illustrates how strange and unintelligible events there still seem. The reason is not too hard to find.

title: MOSCOW LINK IN ARMS TALKS
description: The Soviet Union said today that agreement on arms control could be achieved only if the proposed separate talks on space weapons, strategic arms and medium- range arms were interrelated.

title: A MORE ELABORATE MENU
description: SAN REMO in Westbury has been under new management for a number of months, a change that has affected the menu but not the decor. The restaurant still consists of three small dining rooms, the vista expanded by one mirrored wall and the use of simple, neutral off-white and beige tones. The lighting is fairly bright without being glaring, and at the lunch the room is pleasantly daylit, thanks to several skylights. Tables are formally set.

title: Blue Jays Get Lavelle
description: The Toronto Blue Jays announced tonight that they traded Jim Gott, a pitcher, and two minor leaguers to the San Francisco Giants for Gary Lavelle, a veteran reliever.

title: Double Duty Rouses Ftorek
description: The little hockey player showed some red in his face. He argued with the referee, held back two teammates who wished to argue more forcefully, and when a goal was scored because of his miscue, he kicked at the bristles in the ice. It was strange to see Robbie Ftorek have any reaction at all.

title: STATISTICS SHOW RECOVERY IS BACK
description: Auld Lang Syne, once more. The last of the numbers on 1984 are coming in, usually accompanied by the phrase ''the best year since. . .'' Not since 1951 has gross national product, for one, performed better than its 6.8 percent growth rate last year; 1967 was the last time inflation was lower than the 3.7 percent rise recorded in the G.N.P.'s implicit price deflator. The Consumer Price Index rose only 4 percent in 1984, marking the third year that the indicator had been that low or lower. Revelers at the inaugural balls in Washington got some advance word of all this when a jubilant President Reagan couldn't resist dropping some pre-release hints about the statistics.

title: CONSISTENT WINNER IN GREENWICH
description: AS restaurants in Fairfield County go, Boodle's, at 14 years, is well into middle age. Even so, the Greenwich restaurant retains a youthful spirit and sense of excitement that continues to make it a fun place to be.

title: ANOTHER PUSH FOR CAPITAL PUNISHMENT
description: Four years ago, in a strong dissenting opinion, Justice William H. Rehnquist accused his Supreme Court colleagues of permitting the death penalty to become ''virtually an illusion,'' surrounded by so many ''arcane niceties'' that few death-row inmates faced any real prospect of execution. How dramatically the climate has changed since then, both at the Court and on death row, was underscored last week by another Rehnquist opinion, this time for a 7-to-2 majority. Revising a 17-year-old standard for the selection of juries in capital cases, the Court made it easier for prosecutors to dismiss jurors whose qualms about voting for a death sentence might make them sympathetic to the defense. Now it was the turn of Justice William J. Brennan Jr. to dissent. ''This Court,'' he asserted, ''increasingly acts as the adjunct of the State and its prosecutors in facilitating efficient and expedient conviction and execution irrespective of the Constitution's fundamental guarantees.'' The change in the Court's mood is reflected in the rising numbers of executions. For nearly 16 months after Justice Rehnquist's expression of impatience in 1981, there were no executions in the United States. There were five in 1983. In 1984 there were 21, and in the first weeks of 1985 four states carried out four executions within a 12-day period. The Court's emphasis has been on speeding up the process. In a series of rulings during the last two years, it instructed judges of the lower Federal courts to expedite the handling of death penalty appeals.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I know how tough this is going to be. We are certainly going to try but I would not want to confine it to four years because I know how long some negotiations have taken.'' - President Reagan on the arms talks. (1:6.)

title: FOR HALO, 1-2, FAILS IN GULFSTREAM DASH
description: On a day filled with big-name horses suffering defeats at short prices, the heaviest favorite to lose was For Halo, who went off at 1-2 and finished a tiring second to Key to the Moon in the $71,000 Gulfstream Sprint Championship Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

title: BUS VS. TRAIN? ONE GROUP'S CHOICE

''We have express buses coming in from Queens now, and it takes them an hour to go 10 miles,'' said Mr. Pushkarev, the vice president for research and planning for the Regional Plan Association.

title: TEEN-AGE SUICIDE WORRIES TOWN
description: EVEN before an 18-year-old high school student killed himself in New Canaan two weeks ago, teen-age suicide had been a concern to school officials, who engaged a psychologist to conduct a workshop for teachers there last December.

title: NEWMAN DONATES TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: Paul Newman, the actor, has contributed $100,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the largest corporate gift ever received by the fund. Mr. Newman's donation came from profits realized by his food products company, Newman's Own Inc., of Westport, Conn.

title: BID TO SAVE 1740 FARMHOUSE REVIVED
description: Frayed and curling linoleum covers wooden floors laid more than 240 years ago. The modern, boarded- up windows bear little resemblance to the remaining 18th-century one. The fireplace mantel, painstakingly finished, has been covered with layers of paint and no longer reflects the craftsmanship of the 1740's.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

CAMPAIGN FUNDS: A FALSE ELECTION ISSUE
description: AFTER every election campaign, we read reports about how much money was spent by this or that candidate. Then, as night follows day, the editorials and columns follow, decrying the role of money in political campaigns.

title: FROM THE BAROQUE AGE, A MODERN SPIRIT
description: As much as anyone, Caravaggio ushered in what we now know as the Baroque age. With his beams and blasts of light, his bloated stomachs and unwashed feet and his boulderlike monumentality, he helped sweep away the flabby idealism and refinement of mid- and late 16th-century Italian painting. Caravaggio's bare backgrounds, distilled gestures and almost sculptured figures cut the fat not only off religious representation but off painting itself.

title: ST. JOHN'S, BEHIND MULLIN, UPSETS GEORGETOWN, 66-65
description: Third- ranked St. John's, playing perhaps its finest game of the season, upset top- ranked Georgetown today, and for the moment at least, dispelled the notion that the Hoyas are invincible.

title: INTERVIEW: FORD'S CHAIRMAN SEES ANOTHER BANNER YEAR
description: Philip Caldwell is retiring Feb. 1 after five years as chairman and four as chief executive of the Ford Motor Company. Mr. Caldwell, the first nonmember of the Ford family to run the company, directed it through some of its most difficult times. Though never considered a brilliant salesman, a manufacturing expert or a financial genius, he was credited by colleagues with having mastered all three disciplines. Under his leadership, Ford sharply improved its labor relations and rapidly developed high-technology cars. He recently discussed the prospects for the industry as he prepared to end a 32-year career at Ford.

title: Gates, Guards, Guns and Goetz
description: There's little to be pleased with in the fact that Bernhard Goetz has now been indicted only for possessing an illegal weapon. The public explosion he set off a month ago was not for owning the gun but for using it, and perhaps not so bravely at that. Two of the four men were shot in the back.

title: Philippine Floods Kill 43
description: At least 43 people died and more than 400 others lost their homes last Sunday when floods spawned by a waterspout hit 11 villages on the island of Negros in the central Philippines, civil defense officials said today.

The musicians are members of the Vermont Symphony Orchestra, and the occasion is the 50th anniversary of the orchestra, the oldest and one of the nation's few surviving state symphonies.

The Reagan Administration has been progressively increasing budgets for military hardware since it arrived in Washington four years ago, and the pentagon, for its part, has been working overtime to help contractors overcome their reputation for gross industrial backwardness and woefully inefficient production.

Offsetting the clean good looks of the unblemished paper itself, however, is the print quality now embellishing so much of its surface.

title: ON SECRET SHUUTLE, SILENCE IS LEADEN
description: The silence is haunting. Somewhere out in orbit, the space shuttle Discovery circles the earth once every 90 minutes like a ghost ship. Five men on board go about their business, and messages pass between them and Mission Control, but all is in code. Not a sound of life on the Discovery reaches the news center here, not a single televised image.

title: THE RIGHT-TO-LIFE DEBATE
description: I find it curious that A. Lawrence Washburn Jr. and others in the ''right-to-life'' camp are pushing so hard to take away parents' rights in decisions regarding the care of newborn children while insisting that all young women, even those who may be victims of incest, be required to obtain parental consent for abortion. It would seem more logical that parents of infants, who need so much parental care, should have the right to make the decisions regarding such care, while parents of emancipated minors should have less say in their medical decisions.
