title:
ANTIQUES;

AMERICAN ITEMS ON VIEW IN STONINGTON
description: DURING hard winters 200 years ago, the small communities that make up Stonington often were separated from each other because snow and sleet made roads impassable. The three settlements - a fishing village along the shoreline, a cluster of older homes near the center, and an outlying circle of small farms - are all still there. But 20th-century roads are kept clear and collectors should have no difficulty making their way to the 15th annual Stonington Antiques Show.

title: THE HOPE FOR BETTER LATING POLICY

In fact, this modest change was but the latest example of a larger shift that emerged during the first Reagan term. The Administration's obsessive war against the Nicaraguan Government is one of the few policies that remain unchanged - room perhaps for more improvement during the second term.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: FOR years, M. Mattson, a native and resident of Plainfield, pitched her tent in Oklahoma, Minnesota, Florida, New York, Michigan and parts of Canada. It is not so surprising, then, that she ended up as a photographer of gypsies, especially Irish ones.

title: THE CUBAN CONNECTION
description: ALTHOUGH I TAKE A MODEST PRIDE IN my ability to trace the origins of a food dish, the imprecision in determining the exact date that one ''borrowing'' or another may have created it can be extremely nettlesome. For example, we more or less know when the first tomatoes were taken into Europe from the New World, and when they were first accepted by the French, the English, the Italians and so on. And we can speculate with some degree of accuracy on how Cajun and Pennsylvania Dutch dishes appeared in this country. Other distinct forms of cookery are less easily chronicled.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

PICKING THE POCKETS OF TIME
description: TIME and lint have a lot in common: They both gather in pockets. Once I read an article that suggested that if all the lint from one's clothing pockets was saved, at the end of a year there would be enough lint to stuff a pillow. This helpful hint could be truly appreciated only by those excruciatingly frugal souls who flatten and wash used aluminum foil. But I found myself much more intrigued with the idea of accumulating pockets of time, rather than lint.

title: AMBASSADOR TO U.S. IN 1960'S

title: Don't Forget the Tax Reform
description: Two long months ago, the Treasury's tax reform plan was big news. Some hailed it as a triumph for justice and efficiency, others pilloried a threat to charity, home ownership and economic growth. Though the President is said to be eager to go out and sell some version of the plan, the discussion simmers mostly among lobbyists, officials, selected experts and bureaucrats. Many hope quietly to strangle tax reform or put it off indefinitely during the struggle over deficit-cutting.

It should be be one of the highlights of the year.

title: GANDHI IS COUNTING ON INDIA'S YUPPIES
description: Indira Gandhi scornfully called them ''the five-star culture,'' but India's newly affluent, Western-oriented, younger businessmen, managers, technocrats and professional people are the soulmates of her son, Rajiv Gandhi, who became Prime Minister after she was assassinated on Oct. 31. Like many of these fast-rising influential people, the Prime Minister considers the computer something of a talisman. Like them, his habit of mind appears to be that of the manager, the problem-solver, rather than the career politician or civil servant. He, too, favors a measure of free- market competition, decries over- regulation of business, and apparently intends to liberate the growing but still somewhat hamstrung private sector of the economy. In addition, after his landslide election victory late last month, he launched an efficiency drive in the public sector. 'A Good-Time Class'The somewhat amorphous ''five- star culture'' got its name from the salons and restaurants of glittering, relatively new five-star hotels such as Bombay's Taj Mahal and Oberoi Towers, which are frequented by the younger generation of business and professional people. Often attacked as self-seeking, profligate and uncaring about the malnourished masses, they are largely a ''have-a-good-time class,'' according to Aroon Purie, editor of India Today magazine. But they are also gaining recognition as people who hold the keys to industrial expansion and productivity and thus to the growth India is counting on as its population nears 800 million. Mr. Purie said the group harbors ''such an amount of energy and talent and enterprise that if it is let loose, the world had better watch out.''

title: PETER MARTINS TURNS TO DRAMA IN HIS NEW BALLET
description: ''Poulenc Sonata,'' Peter Martins's new ballet, hardly keeps the viewer thinking about Poulenc or a sonata. The French composer wrote the music for two pianos, two pianists and two page-turners, as the ballet's opening moment recalls. Yet the governing image onstage quickly grows remote from any musical concerns. It is thoroughly dramatic, concentrating upon a dancer - Kyra Nichols as a wild girl. We see her chest lifted, ponytail flying up, head back as she lopes around the stage, flings herself about or wraps the arms of any man she encounters around her own sleek body. She is splendidly reckless.

title: A TAX RISE COULD BUOY THE RECOVERY
description: WITH the current and projected Federal budget deficits reaching unprecedented heights, the need for a tax increase has never been greater. Yet that prospect creates a dilemma for economic policymakers. According to traditional analysis, any tax increase - especially one large enough to reduce the deficit significantly - slows spending and increases the likelihood of a recession. Such an economic contraction, in turn, adds to the already- bloated deficit as unemployment pushes upward again.

This was the message heard by textbook publishers, editors and marketing directors who met last week in Port Chester for the yearly divisional gathering of the School Division of the Association of American Publishers.

title: CAMELOT REVISITED, WITH ALL THE ICONOGRAPHY
description: ''Robert Kennedy and His Times'' is good of its kind. Hagiography is served, but the conventions of respectable biography aren't entirely flouted. The seven-hour CBS mini- series sentimentalizes Mr. Kennedy, without quite sanctifying him. It dramatizes his life, without making it unrecognizable. At the same time, familiar icons are brought forth while history is revisited. Sometimes this is like a processional: Here are the Freedom Riders; then comes the Cuban missile crisis; now President Kennedy is shot in Dallas. Touch football in Hyannis Port is interspersed. Robert Kennedy, as played by Brad Davis, is an upper-class urchin, a tough kid with a veneer of arrogance, who finds wisdom with the years. Camelot is very much on display here, only in this televised version it is the death of Robert, not John, that we mourn. He is the king who would have saved us all.

title: DEMOCRACY GAINS STEAM IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: MANILA LAST week's indictment of the Chief of Staff of the Philippines Armed Forces and 25 other people in the plot to assassinate opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. seems part of a slow but steady re turn of democracy here.

title: A View to Preserving 'Residential Flavor'
description: We deeply disagree with the findings of Stuart R. Shamberg and George M. Raymond in their recent article (''Plans Are Needed for Development in North of County,'' Opinion Page, Jan. 6). Surely, we do not disagree that there is a housing shortage, but the solution to these problems is not with the dismembering of our current zoning laws. Residents of communities have purchased their homes just in view of these zoning laws and have every right to expect their local governments to make sure that there is orderly development of undeveloped lands.

title: ONE ROAD TO HIGH-DEFINITION TV
description: Prospects for high-definition television - HDTV for short - are looking up at last. As explained previously in this space, HDTV is a radically improved system of television, yielding sharper pictures and better color. Instead of the 525 scanning lines used at present to delineate the picture on the screen, HDTV employs upward of a thousand lines, giving the image the visual fidelity comparable to that of a fine photographic print.

title: 70 Boats Enter S.O.R.C. Race
description: Cold weather and grand prix yacht racing events inevitably do not mix. Organizers of the annual Southern Ocean Racing Conference in Florida were reminded of that last week when temperatures plummeted to 22 degrees at the St. Petersburg Yacht Club, where the race series will begin this week.

title: BOREDOM, IF NOT BITTERNESS, WAS THIS ARTIST'S MEAT
description: Art is ''like family.'' In art, as in family life, we coast along for years with an idea of what people are like and then - vroom! our favorite uncle turns out to be the most terrible crook, the brother-in-law to whom we turned for advice and support does not return our calls and our dull cousin in Australia, the one whose letters we always forgot to answer, gets the Nobel Prize for her pioneer work on the coccyx of the cassowary.

title: MISSION CALLED SUCCESSFUL
description: The space shuttle Discovery was scheduled to end its secret military mission and land here this afternoon, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced early today. The landing was set to occur at 4:23 P. M., depending on weather conditions at the Kennedy Space Center. The announcement also indicated that the shuttle's primary mission of deploying what was widely reported to be a $300 million electronic intelligence-gathering satellite had been successful. According to the Air Force, the rocket propulsion system, called the inertial upper stage, that was carried by the Discovery was deployed and ''successfully met its mission objectives.'' The 32,000-pound, solid-fuel rocket system was attached to the 5,000-pound secret payload to boost it toward its higher operational orbit. The shuttle was presumably flying at an altitude of less than 200 miles.

title: Airline Resumes Operations After F.A.A. Check of Planes
description: Galaxy Airlines resumed operations today after Federal officials finished inspecting its fleet, said Galaxy's president, Phillip Sheridan.

description: To the Editor:

title: 'DREAM HOUSE' HALTED IN BEACH DISPUTE
description: -shaped design of August Wade's proposed home depicts its controversy, swelling with unresolved litigation against Southold Town, neighborhood opposition and allegations of environmental violations.

title: BASEBALL IN PACT ON CABLE
description: The commissioner of baseball, Peter V. Ueberroth, has concluded agreements with the Yankees and the Atlanta Braves on a television revenue-sharing plan under which the teams will make annual payments to other clubs for extending television coverage of their games beyond their home markets.

title: AT HOME, WORDS FAILED THEM
description: A Memoir of Fathers and Sons. By Lance Morrow. Illustrated. 249 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: ;    International
description: SUNDAY, JANUARY 27, 1985 The President said he was ''not euphoric'' about reaching an arms agreement with the Soviet Union before the end of his second term. The White House announced that the talks with Moscow would begin March 12 in Geneva. A similar announcement was made in Moscow. But Mr. Reagan said he said he was ''a little more optimistic'' than his advisers over the prospects of an arms pact with Moscow. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: 40 YEARS LATER, A RETURN TO AUSCHWITZ
description: HE had wavy blond locks and very blue eyes. The boy was strikingly handsome and, the doctor noted, he was possessed by a defiant and fierce will.

title: Alice Fleming and Gary J. Feder Marry
description: Alice Carew Fleming, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Fleming of New York and Westbrook, Conn., was married yesterday to Gary Jay Feder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Feder of Old Westbury, L.I. The Rev. H. Scott Matheney, the Presbyterian chaplain at Columbia University, and Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman, executive director of the Center for Creative Jewish Living in Manhattan, performed the ceremony at the Colony Club.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: MODERN TIMES: The World From the Twenties to the Eighties, by Paul Johnson. (Harper & Row, $9.95.) This 60-year history covers all major countries, East and West. It is filled with people as well as events and historical changes and emphasizes what Nietzsche called the will to power. Our reviewer, Robert Nisbet, commented two years ago that Paul Johnson ''is most interested in drawing conclusions, many of them provocative.'' He said, ''We can take a great deal of intellectual pleasure in his book, which is a truly distinguished work of history.'' The Book Review chose it as one of the best books of 1983.

title: Director of Planning Is Named by M.T.A.
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has announced the appointment of a director of planning, a new position intended to help the agency determine the shape of transportation in New York in the next decade.

title: TOURING LA PAZ: UP AND DOWN WALKING GUIDE
description: PETER McFARREN is a journalist based in La Paz.

title: FROM PUBLIC HOUSING TO PRIVATE INCENTIVE
description: Large powers and large personalities have shaped the character of the New York State Urban Development Corporation ever since Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller pushed it through a reluctant Legislature on the evening of Dr. Martin Luther King's funeral in 1968. As Governor Rockefeller explained its purpose then, the new agency would build housing for low- and moderate-income New Yorkers on a scale rarely before possible. By the time the U.D.C.'s fourth chairman, William J. Stern, stepped down last week to return to private business, its mission had changed. It has now become a public agency interested primarily in stimulating private development.

description: Mayor Koch said last night that he had ordered ''a comprehensive review of all the matters raised'' in the investigation of the Medical Examiner's office by The New York Times.

description: ROBERT ABRAMS, the State Attorney General, is seeking to restructure the way garbage carting companies do business on Long Island.

title: 6 MAYORAL CONTENDERS GIVE VIEWS TO BLACK GROUP
description: Six prospective Democratic candidates for mayor, including two new contenders, yesterday gave their views on city problems to black Democratic leaders who have said they will endorse a mayoral candidate within the next month.

title: DEVELOPERS SEEK CHANGES IN STATE LAW
description: DEVELOPERS, saying they want to keep housing costs down, are backing a proposal to change the state law regulating subdivisions. But planning and zoning officials, the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities and regional planning agencies, have joined forces against the measure.

description: At St. George's Ukrainian Catholic Church in Manhattan yesterday Mary Ann Zo"e Kocur, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ihor E. Kocur of Lapeer, Mich., was married to Howard Allen Pollack, a son of Roy Howard Pollack of Princeton, N.J., and the late Margaret Jones Pollack. The Rev. Patrick Paschak performed the ceremony.

title: TAX SAVING SPURS RENOVATION
description: JERSEY CITY FOR MORE than a decade, there has been a brownstone movement in this city's downtown, an area of stately residences and some commercial and industrial buildings dating almost to the Civil War. But it was not until 1981, with President Reagan's tax package, that the smoldering renaissance blazed into activity.

title: ONTARIO'S RULING PARTY CHOOSES NEW LEADER
description: The governing Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario today elected Frank Miller, the province's Industry Minister, as its new party leader. He will automatically become Premier of Canada's most populous and economically powerful province.

title: U.N. Chief Seeks Talks On Fighting in Cambodia
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar called today for negotiations to end the ''suffering, destruction and agony'' in Cambodia, and prepared to visit refugees from a Vietnamese offensive against rebel camps near the Thai border. About 62,000 Cambodians have recently been moved to the camp after fleeing the fighting.

title: New Rules Urged on Use Of Steel Shot by Hunters
description: The Reagan Administration proposed new regulations Friday to require hunters to use shotgun pellets made of steel, not lead, in areas where lead poisoning has killed waterfowl.

title: 6-COURSE MEALS PREPARED IN YOUR HOME
description: CAN a senior merchandise manager at J. C. Penney and a horseback riding instructor who enjoy cooking but have no professional experience find success launching a catering business unlike any other in Fairfield County?

title: Heidi C. Stegemann To Wed Karl Nelson
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hans Christian Stegemann of River Vale, N.J., and Stowe, Vt., of the engagement of their daughter Heidi Christina Stegemann to Karl Stuart Nelson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. O. William Nelson of De Kalb, Ill. The wedding is to be on April 27.

title:
GARDENING;

GROUND COVERS THAT LOVE THE SUN
description: HAVING discussed the two most difficult places to grow ground covers - the hot, dry south-facing slope and beneath highly competitive trees - we are ready to tackle the sites thatare easiest. This week we will discuss the sunny location with good soil, and next week we will finish the series with the shady location with adequate light.

title: WHAT THE DEMOCRATS MUST DO TO RECOVER
description: The 378 members of the Democratic National Committee are to select a new chairman this week, but many party regulars have already declared that the outcome isn't really important. They are right that this choice won't remedy all the party's problems. But they are reacting like an anxious student who excuses a bad quiz grade by hoping it won't count. In the party's efforts to resurrect itself, every score matters.

title: RURAL HOMESTEADERS SEEK SELF-SUFFICIENCY AND CHERISH SOLITUDE
description: With clouds of steam pulsing from his nostrils, Sparky, a brown draft horse, trotted up the snowy slope towing a log from a dead elm.

title: TV REVIEW;'THE JOY THAT KILLS,' ON WNET
description: The joy that kills'' is a small gem, not bright and glittering like a diamond, but darker, quieter - an amethyst, say, or a topaz. There are depths. The ''American Playhouse'' production is about a woman's repression, redemption and final fate, and in a narrow sense it is feminist, although nothing about it suggests a tract. The entirely worthwhile hour will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: ADVERTISING;Magazine Ad Pages Up
description: For magazines that are members of the Publishers Information Bureau, meaning most of the major ones, collective advertising pages in December were up 5.7 percent, to 13,673, from December 1983. Revenues grew 15.8 percent, to $437.8 million.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;Pressure to Help Farmers
description: The first agricultural item on the plate of the new Congress will be quicker and more generous emergency credit for hard-pressed farmers. Legislators from farm states have returned from the pre-inaugural recess saying that large groups of farmers are in the worst financial shape since the Depression.

title: AUSCHWITZ ECHOES TO PRAYER AS MENGELE'S VICTIMS RETURN
description: Eva Kor, from Terre Haute, Ind., and her sister, Miriam Czaigher, from Ashkelon, Israel, stood this morning at the railroad ramp at Auschwitz where in 1944 Dr. Josef Mengele, chief physician at the Nazi death camp, separated them as 10-year-olds from their mother.

title: NETS LIMITED BY INJURIES
description: Four months ago, the Nets entered training camp riding a crest of boundless promise born of their surprising success in last season's playoffs. That promise remains unfufilled with more than half of this season now passed because of an unparalleled rash of injuries. Instead, the Nets are a team clouded by uncertainty and a host of questions.

title: Study Predicts Delay In Cleanup in Jersey
description: New Jersey's program to clean up toxic waste sites may fall behind schedule unless more money is spent, according to a study prepared for the Legislature.

description: largest advertising agency, Ogilvy & Mather

title: ADVERTISING;New Agency for Cliftex
description: Chalk, Nissen, Hanft has been chosen by the Cliftex Corporation, a Bedford, Mass., manufacturer of men's and women's tailored apparel. The ad agency puts the billings at $1.25 million. Rubin-Walter handled the account for 10 years.

title: Mellon Officer to Retire
description: William B. Eagleson Jr., chairman and chief executive of Mellon Bank (East), said he intends to retire as an active officer in April. No one was named to succeed Mr. Eagleson, who is 59 years old, as chairman, but Vincent E. Furey Jr., 45, executive vice president and head of community banking at Mellon Bank (East), was named president of the Philadelphia- based bank.

description: A 26-year-old woman was killed by a bullet fired by a man plinking with a rifle from an apartment window in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn on Friday, the police said yesterday.

title: OPERA: TATIANA TROYANOS IN HANDEL'S ARIODANTE'
description: Handel's Italian operas have been creeping into the international repertory in recent years and this season's tricentennial celebration of his birth should give the movement a push. In the past, his operas have suffered both from a lack of audience understanding and from a shortage of singers capable of getting deep into the music, vocally and expressively. Slowly, however, a cadre of first- class Handel singers has been developing, people with a feeling for the style and the talent to manage its technical difficulties. As a result, not surprisingly, a public for the operas has been growing.

title: Japan-U.S. Trade Talks
description: High-level trade talks between the United States and Japan open Monday and a battle is shaping up over access to Japan's telecommunications market.

title: STORE CAVE-IN HURTS 9 UPSTATE
description: Part of the snow-laden roof of a department store in suburban Clarence collapsed today, sending at least nine people to hospitals, as Buffalo battled its way out of a week of storms that left almost four feet of snow on the ground.

title: CAPITALS DEFEAT ISLANDERS AGAIN
description: The Washington Capitals scored three goals in the final 10 minutes today, squelching an Islander rally and beating their Patrick Division rivals for the second time in less than 24 hours, this time by 5-2 at Capital Centre.

title: FAMILY OF VICTIM LEVELS CHARGES OF DECEIT IN AUTOPSY CONCLUSION
description: A police van bearing the unconscious body of Michael Stewart pulled into Bellevue Hospital at 3:22 A.M. on a warm September day in 1983.

title: Robin Dissin, Teacher, Weds A. H. Aufses 3d
description: Robin Joan Dissin, an English teacher at Paul D. Schreiber High School in Port Washington, L.I., and Arthur Harold Aufses 3d, an associate with the New York law firm of Kramer, Levin, Nessen, Kamin & Frankel, were married yesterday. Rabbi Donna Berman officiated at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Battle at Fortune Financial
description: John B. Sweger, the 65-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of the Fortune Financial Group Inc., whose principal subsidiary is the Fortune Federal Savings and Loan Association, admits that he has not had much operating experience in the thrift business.

title: Helen H. Burgess Dies at 88; Historic Preservation Leader
description: Helen Hamilton Burgess, a leader in historic preservation, died Friday in Mystic, Conn. She was 88 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Nora Gabel Winkelman Married in Philadelphia To Marc Bennett Mazur,Salomon Brothers Aide
description: Nora Gabel Winkelman, the daughter of Anne Winkelman of Philadelphia and the late Dr. Nathaniel William Winkelman Jr., was married yesterday to Marc Bennett Mazur, the son of Jay Mazur of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and Barbara Mazur of New York. Rabbi Elliott Holin performed the ceremony in the home of the bride's mother.

title: NEW DONORS PLEDGE TO CONTRIBUTE YEARLY TO FUND FOR NEEDIEST
description: The tradition of supporting The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is enriched every year by donors who contribute for the first time and expect to continue giving in the years to come.

title: MULLIN HOLDS TO THE RULE
description: Chris Mullin appeared as calm as if he were alone in a yellow meadow, while all around him was madness. The St. John's guard-forward stood out of bounds at the baseline holding the basketball Saturday afternoon as the sellout crowd of 19,035 fans screamed like crazy, rocking the Capital Centre in Landover, Md., and Georgetown players ran frantically to press St. John's.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;Looking Ahead to Camp
description: Yesterday's chill did not prevent visions of canoeing and campfires from dancing in the heads of about 4,000 children and parents at the National Children's Camp Show at the Walden School on West 88th Street.

title: BRIEFING;Behind Closed Doors Dept.
description: By tradition and practice, the Smithsonian Institution holds its business meetings in private. It is run by a board of regents headed by the Chief Justice of the United States and includes the Vice President, senators, representatives and leading citizens.

title: STAGE: CAROLE SHELLEY HEADS NEW 'NOISES OFF' CAST
description: Over a year after its arrival in New York, Michael Frayn's farce ''Noises Off'' remains the funniest show on Broadway. This says something about Broadway, of course: There haven't been a lot of laughs around Times Square as of late. But, even if the competition were stiffer, ''Noises Off'' would continue to hold its own. Between London and New York, I've now seen Mr. Frayn's circus of theatrical mayhem four times and still find new laughs in its ingeniously constructed chronicle of a tatty acting troupe's catastrophic tour through the English provinces.

title: JAGGER FINISHES FIRST SOLO ALBUM, 'SHE'S THE BOSS'
description: After more than 20 years as lead singer for the Rolling Stones, Mick Jagger has recorded his first solo album.

title: Role of Taxes In Investing
description: A study of 238 large United States corporations has found that lower-taxed companies decreased their investments between 1981 and 1983 while higher- taxed companies increased their investments. The study, released today, was conducted by Citizens for Tax Justice, a tax research group supported by labor unions.

title: Reagan Said to 'Berate' Blacks
description: The head of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference charged today that President Reagan has used a ''wall of Presidential immunity to deride and berate'' black civil rights leaders but has failed to meet with them ''for an honest exchange of views.''

title: BRIDGE;LOS ANGELES PLAYER COLLECTS 3,270 MASTER POINTS IN A YEAR
description: Bridge:Los Angeles Player Collects 3,270 Master Points in a Year

title: SANDINISTA PRIESTS PRESSED TO RESIGN
description: Four Roman Catholic priests who hold Government posts here will be stripped of their priesthood if they do not reconsider their decisions to remain in public office, according to the leader of Nicaragua's bishops.

title: INDIANA STANDARD'S STRATEGY
description: The decision earlier this month by the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) to spin off its money-losing minerals subsidiary to stockholders is the latest strategic withdrawal in a general retreat by oil companies from the mining industry they embraced just a few years before.

title: IMPROBABLE REVIVAL IN CHINA
description: Each morning at daybreak, a group of old capitalists gather in a drafty warehouse here to plot a little competition for the Communist shipping company that more or less expropriated the Yangtze River 30 years ago.

title: MEDICAL INFLATION SLACKENS SLIGHTLY
description: The rise in the cost of health care slowed last year, but medical costs still climbed much faster than prices in general.

title: A PERFECT VENUE FOR RENTAL FURNITURE
description: The chairs on which the President and Nancy Reagan sat at the inaugural gala were rentals. So were the desks, sofas and cocktail tables in Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin's dressing rooms in the Convention Center here. And it is with rented furniture that former Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt equips his Washington office and that a handful of Congressmen have outfitted their homes.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: JAMES CAMERON, A JOURNALIST AND COMMENTATOR IN BRITAIN
description: James Cameron, a leading figure in post-World War II British journalism and television, died Saturday night at his London home after a long illness. He was 73.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS;Entropy Shares Dead-Heat Finish
description: Entropy, the favorite, got up in the last jump to finish in a dead heat with Muskoka Wyck yesterday in the $71,200 Coaltown Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS;Steamers Down Cosmos by 4-2
description: Don Ebert's third-quarter goal proved to be the winner as the St. Louis Steamers evened their Major Indoor Soccer League record at 12-12 today with a 4-2 victory over the Cosmos.

title: 4 TOP CHURCHES INVITED TO MOVE TO INDIANAPOLIS
description: Indianapolis is courting four major Protestant churches, trying to persuade them to move their headquarters from Manhattan to the Middle West.

title: KOREANS PLAN U.S. CAR SALES
description: The Hyundai Motor Company of Korea will begin selling cars in the United States later this year when it introduces a new, front-wheel-drive subcompact as a 1986 model. The company said its initial plans are to build an additional 100,000 cars a year for sale in the United States.

title: GROSS SAYS HE WILL BE VINDICATED
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had ordered a ''comprehensive'' investigation into allegations against the Chief Medical Examiner. The Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot M. Gross, said that he would cooperate and that he expected to be ''completely vindicated.''

title: REVAMPED INDIANA ROUTED
description: Illinois regained sole possession of first place in Big Ten with a 52-41 victory over Indiana on today.

title: ADVERTISING;Ally & Gargano Gains
description: Ally & Gargano has announced its results for the fiscal second quarter, ended Dec. 31. The agency's revenues rose 7.5 percent, to $7.3 million, from $6.8 million a year earlier. Net income was $885,000, or 40 cents a share, up from $873,000, or 41 cents a share. The per-share figure shrank because more shares were outstanding in the latest period.

title: TWO-PRONGD ATTACK ON NEW YORK CITY'S DROPOUT PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ: THE EDDY DAVIS TRIO PERFORMS AT THE RED BLAZAR
description: When the Red Blazer Too closed its doors on New Year's Day as the result of losing its lease, the seven jazz groups that played there regularly, each on its own day of the week, became musical orphans while the owner, Dennis Carey, looked for a new location.

title: Montana Legislator Quits After 51 Years
description: State Senator Dave Manning resigned Friday after more than 51 years in the Montana Legislature. He cited poor health.

title: LINE OF SONG PROVIDES A CLUE ON ANCIENT TROY
description: Three months ago Prof. Calvert Watkins, a linguist at Harvard, was examining some dry documents in an extinct language of ancient Anatolia when he came upon a string of words that filled him with excitement. Translated, the words said:

title: UPDATE DEFENSES, CANADA IS URGED
description: A Canadian Senate committee has urged an overhaul of the nation's air-defense system, but the Defense Minister has suggested that Canada cannot afford all the panel's recommendations.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Comfed Savings Bank, Lowell, Mass., announced the appointment of Joel Rosenberg as senior vice president and treasurer. The bank also named Henry W. Brodeur head of its new Corporate Relationship Funding Center.

title: ISLANDERS' HRUDEY SAVES A CAREER HE DID NOT WANT
description: Perhaps three months from now or maybe in July when he is summering back in Medicine Hat, Alberta, Kelly Hrudey will look back at what he had done since Dec. 29 and say that was when his transition began.

title: GASTINEAU M.V.P. IN A.F.C. VICTORY
description: Art Still, a Kansas City Chiefs' defensive end, returned a fumble 83 yards for a touchdown in the fourth quarter to give the American Football Conference all-stars a 22-14 victory over the National Conference today in the Pro Bowl.

title: A DRAFT CANNOT CURB MILITARY RECKLESSNESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Hughes TV Satellites
description: The Federal Communications Commission has granted Hughes Communications Inc. permission to build and launch two Galaxy satellites to beam television programming directly into American homes. The F.C.C. said in its order, issued Thursday, that the Galaxy satellites must be in operation by Dec. 7, 1990. It also granted orbital slots for the two satellites, which would be able to send signals to small roof-mounted receiving dishes, bypassing local television stations.

title: JOSEPH J. SANCHEZ OF G.M. DIES AT 54
description: Joseph J. Sanchez, a General Motors executive who was chosen three weeks ago to head the company's new Saturn Corporation, died Sunday at the Edward W. Sparrow Hospital in Lansing, Mich., of complications following a heart attack. He was 54 years old and lived in East Lansing.

title: WHAT SUNY NEEDS
description: To the Editor:

title: I KNOW WHAT HAPPENED'
description: More than five months later, Mary Decker and Zola Budd remain handcuffed in history, as they will be forever, as so many others in sports have been for so many different reasons - Bobby Thomson and Ralph Branca, Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier, Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd, Wilt Chamberlain and Bill Russell, Pete Rozelle and Al Davis. But when Mary Decker was asked if her link to Zola Budd might someday be forgotten, she nodded.

description: Laurie Boschman and Paul MacLean scored two goals apiece and Dave Ellett added a goal and two assists to pace Winnipeg.

title: OPEC UNIT STILL SPLIT ON PRICES
description: Members of a special committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries remained deadlocked today over a new price structure for differing grades of oil, to bring them into line with the market and end price discounting.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Telling D From B
description: For those who need a spelling refresher, the Transit Authority can help. One of its conductors announces: ''Ladies and gentlemen, this is a D train. D as in dog.'' Then, for emphasis: ''Ladies and gentlemen, this is a D train. D as in dog. D-O-G.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Urban League Celebrates
description: About 1,000 people gathered yesterday at St. Mark's United Methodist Church in Harlem to celebrate the 75th birthday of the National Urban League.

title: LAWYER SAYS GOETZ DOES NOT FEEL 'REMORSE' OVER SUBWAY SHOOTING
description: A lawyer for Bernhard H. Goetz, who was cleared of charges of attempted murder last week by a grand jury in the shooting of four teen-agers on a subway train, said yesterday that his client felt no ''remorse'' over the shootings.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Swedish Fighter Jets Grounded After Crash
description: Sweden has grounded most of its fighter planes because it suspects a recent crash may have been caused by sabotage, the daily Svenska Dagbladet reported today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Basically, I am coming to this place because this is the beginning of the end. My children asked me so often what happened. I do not have the answers. My biggest problem is that I never said goodbye to my mother.'' - Eva Kor, from Terre Haute, Ind., at Auschwitz. (A1:2.)

title: MIXTURE OF NEW TAX BENEFITS AND HARSHER RULES FOR MANY
description: Taxpayers will find a sprinkling of new tax benefits in filling out their 1984 income tax returns. But many individuals will also run up against harsher rules that will make a number of cherished deductions harder to claim and will make more income subject to tax.

title: KEAN'S BUDGET PLAN DRAWS QUALIFIED PRAISE
description: The $8.8 billion budget proposed by Governor Kean of New Jersey drew qualified praise yesterday from both Republicans and Democrats, who said the Republican Governor had muted partisan criticism in an election year by endorsing programs previously put forth by Democratic legislators.

title: A SOVIET INVITATION REPORTED BY LEADER OF KEY JEWISH BODY
description: Edgar M. Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress, said today that he had been invited by the Soviet Government to visit Moscow. It would be the first such visit by a head of the international federation of Jewish organizations.

title: New President Set for Citgo The Southland Corporation

title: HOTEL IS HAVEN FOR WOMEN
description: I love my room,'' said Caroline Harrell, bouncing on the carefully made-up bed in Room 48 of the Traveler's Hotel. ''I've been here two years now and I like the neighborhood. I go to the Ninth Avenue shops and I find there's nothing funny going on down there. Not like Eighth Avenue. I avoid the nightclubby things there.''

title: A Renewed Offer for Pabst
description: The S&P Company has renewed its bid for the Pabst Brewing Company while a rival bidder has been blocked from proceeding with its plans by a Federal Court judge.

title: WOMEN AND BLACKS WERE KEYS IN VOTING RISE
description: Higher voting rates among women, blacks and the elderly were the key factors in slightly increased voter turnout in the 1984 Presidential election, the Census Bureau reported yesterday.

title: NEW HOTEL IS A SYMBOL OF CHANGE IN BROOKLYN
description: Avital Shcharansky was looking for a place to stay. It was a Thursday night, and Mrs. Shcharansky, the wife of the jailed Soviet dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky, had got to Kennedy International Airport too late to catch her plane for Israel.

title: Bucks 106, Spurs 93
description: Terry Cummings scored 30 points, including 7 in a 26-8 Milwaukee rally at the end of the first half, to lead Milwaukee.

title: MELLOW NAMATH ENJOYS LIFE AFTER FOOTBALL
description: Jerry Rubin, the 1960's activist who put war paint on his face and advocated revolution and anarchy, is roaming the country these days in a business suit, praising the pursuit of wealth and free enterprise. To a generation that made him a hero, his transformation from Yippie to Yuppie flatly symbolizes the end of that era.

title: EGYPT AND ISRAEL TACKLE BEACH ISSUE
description: Egyptian and Israeli officials began trying to work out a solution today to the long-festering dispute over Taba, a 750-yard stretch of desert, but the two sides still appeared to be far apart.

title: BRIEFING;Architects' Drawings
description: In 1907, the American Institute of

title: Stacy Victor on a Birdie Putt
description: Hollis Stacy sank a 20-foot birdie putt on the final hole today to break a three-way tie and win the $200,000 Mazda Classic at the Deer Creek Country Club, the first event of the season on the women's professional golf tour.

title: ADVERTISING;People
description: Johnson Couch Jr. has joined D'Arcy MacManus Masius/New York as senior vice president/management supervisor and

title: ISRAELI CHILDREN'S BOOK: WHEN DADDY IS IN UNIFORM
description: The next great best seller in Israel may turn out to be a 24-page book written for 4-year-olds whose fathers are between the ages of 21 and 55.

title: ESSSAY;THE SHARON PLAN
description: After battling Time magazine to an expensive standoff of the stiffnecked, Ariel Sharon returns to Israel with a plan in mind to help lift his country out of its economic morass.

title: ABROAD AT HOME;THE SHARON VERDICT
description: BOSTON In law, Time Inc. won. In professional credibility, it suffered a defeat that does injury to all the press. And there is no sign that the people at Time understand that - no sign of genuine regret.

title: VIETNAM IS CALLED DESPARATE FOR AID
description: Vietnam has lived without you for a thousand years, and we can live without you for a thousand more,'' a Foreign Ministry official told a group of visiting Americans recently.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS;Foster Hurdles To Indoor Best
description: Greg Foster achieved a world indoor best time of 6.30 seconds in the 50- meter hurdles, and Ireland's Eamonn Coghlan edged Steve Scott to win his second mile in 48 hours today at the Bally Invitational track meet.

title: AROUND THE NATION;10% of U.S. Defendants Rearrested, Report Says
description: Approximately 10 percent of Federal criminal defendants awaiting trial are arrested, either for committing new crimes, violating the conditions of their release or failing to appear for trial, the Justice Department said in a report made public today.

title: How Much Research Is Enough?
description: Medical researchers are spluttering outrage. Last year Congress approved 6,500 new grants for them. But the Office of Management and Budget has now directed that only 5,000 be awarded, as the Administration requested in the first place. The researchers say the promise of their field has never been higher and more research will hasten the conquest of disease. So how much research is enough?

title: DISPUTE LOOMING ON NO. 1
description: St. John's impressive victory over top-ranked Georgetown Saturday opens the door for the Redmen to be ranked No. 1 in the nation. But if they get the top ranking, it will not be with the help of their coach.

title: Boeing Expected to Lose Thai Bid
description: The Boeing Company appears headed for defeat by Airbus Industrie in the battle to supply Thailand's domestic airline with a new generation of planes for its expanding fleet.

title: Whoopi Goldberg Reading
description: Free Theater Productions will present the performer Whoopi Goldberg, who will read works by her favorite writers, tomorrow at 12:30 P.M. at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street. The free program is part of Free Theater's ''Great Theater Artist Series,'' which offers literature presented by actors, writers and well- known personalities. Information: 737-0073.

title: FIREFIGHTERS AND THE CITY
description: There is a noncommittal phrase that union leaders and public officials use sometimes to describe labor settlements, the way people fall back on the word ''interesting'' to describe babies who defy more facile labels. ''Fair and reasonable'' is the union-management equivalent, and that is the cautious description coming from both sides as they evaluate the settlement reached a week ago between the city and the firefighters union.

title: AFTER 4,000 CIVILIZED YEARS, CHINA STARTS TO HURRY
description: The dust that blows across Peking from the Gobi Desert had left the apartment windows opaque with grime, so the new tenant dialed the diplomatic housing service and asked for window-cleaners. Quickly two men bustled in, slung safety ropes around their waists and clambered onto the 11th-story ledges.

title: EMBASSY ROW;HILL WITH TOPFLIGHT ELECTRONIC VIEW
description: In intelligence circles, the site of the new Soviet Embassy in Washington is considered the biggest giveaway since Peter Minuit got Manhattan in 1626 for the equivalent of $24.

title: Cleanup of Chemical Begins After a Derailment in Illinois
description: Work crews today began draining an explosive chemical from overturned tanker cars after the derailment of a Norfolk & Western freight train here.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: The U.N. Today
description: Jan. 28, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: AROUND THE WORLD;4 Bombs Explode Overnight on Corsica
description: Four bombs exploded overnight on the French Mediterranean island of Corsica, causing extensive damage but no injuries, the police said today.

title: AN AMERICAN'S NIGHTMARE IN NIGERIA
description: To many Nigerians, Susie Martins is a household name, an African model and television personality. A symbol of fashion and wealth, she was seen for seven years on television commercials and on billboards advertising soap.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Long-Distance Cheating Linked to 3 Teen-Agers
description: Three teen-age computer experts face charges that they used their home computers to cheat telephone companies out of hundreds of thousands of dollars of service.

title: POPE, ON VENEZUELA TOUR, SAYS MASS BEFORE A MILLION
description: Pope John Paul II continued his tour of Venezuela today by saying masses before over a million people here and in Caracas.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Union Locals End Strikes At 2 G. M. Factories
description: A tentative settlement was reached today in an 11-day strike by 1,600 employees of the nation's only Corvette sports car plant, a union official said.

title: Sudan Rebels to Release 4
description: Southern Sudanese rebels said today that they would release four employees of a French construction company who have been held hostage for the last year. A rebel radio monitored by the British Broadcasting Corporation said the leader of the Southern People's Liberation Army, John Garang, had ordered them freed on humanitarian grounds. The four prisoners are believed to be two Frenchmen, a Briton and a Kenyan pilot.

title: Swiss Watch Trade Up
description: Swiss watch exports staged a comeback in 1984, rising in value by 13 percent and probably recovering some lost ground in the world market, the industry association said Friday. The total value of exported watches and parts rose to $1.4 billion, only 1.6 percent off the 1981 record.

title: Dole Begins Re-election Bid
description: Senator Bob Dole formally began his 1986 re-election campaign Saturday. The Senate Republican leader said farm programs must be cut to help reduce Federal deficits but not so much as to ''pull the rug out'' from under farmers. Asked if he would use his new Senate post as a springboard to run for the Presidency in 1988, Mr. Dole said: ''I don't know yet. It may be a springboard to oblivion. But I do look at the calendar from time to time.''

title: A Double Winner In Dog-Sled Races
description: Doug McRae, a 21-year-old musher from Rhinelander, Wis., won both the eight-dog and unlimited categories today in the Alpo International Sled Dog Championships.

title: MIDWEST JOURNAL;DOG'S LIFE, MAN'S LIFE, CAR'S LIFE
description: On Judge Edward Sosnick's docket, the case was listed as City of Birmingham v. Schwarb. But to the spectators who filled the courtroom last week, it was a murder case and the defendant was King Boots, a prize-winning Old English sheepdog.

title: SOVIET PRISON ESCAPE IN NEW BOOK DISPUTED
description: A dramatic escape from a Soviet prison, detailed in a new book by an American who spent four years in Soviet custody, has been characterized as total invention by former officials of the United States Embassy in Moscow.

title: Unneighborly Lawsuit
description: Piracy on the Hudson - that's how New York City officials view new office projects on the New Jersey waterfront, which are luring some New York businesses to relocate their back-office space. They charge that Federal subsidies for urban development are being used unfairly to hasten the exodus and they are trying to sabotage the Federal support for New Jersey's deals.

title: Texas Surgeon Fined $5,000 For Buying Peregrine Falcons
description: A plastic surgeon was fined $5,000 and placed on one year's probation Friday for illegally buying peregrine falcons from a Federal undercover agent and transporting the birds to Texas.

title: Timothea MacLaury Weds M. R. Comstedt
description: Timothea Nowell MacLaury, a daughter of Mrs. Edgar Alsop Riley of Tesuque, N.M., and Robert Manson MacLaury of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Richard Comstedt, a son of Walter Comstedt of Los Angeles and the late Mrs. Comstedt. The Rev. James Poe performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Ryssby Church in Longmont, Colo.

title: SILENCE ATTENDS SHUTTLE'S LANDING, ENDING 3-DAY TRIP
description: The brief and secret military mission of the space shuttlecraft Discovery came to a safe conclusion this afternoon with a smooth landing here at the Kennedy Space Center.

title: Let a Salute Be Your Umbrella
description: It is truly wonderful what the women's movement has done for men. They don't have to take off their hats in the elevator any more. They no longer have to run around to the other side of the car and open the door. They can walk on the building side of the sidewalk if they want to, and they can go in the door first. They can have hairdos, and not just haircuts. They can wear moisturizer. They can smell pretty. And if they feel like choking up in the movies, well, hey, that's O.K. too.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;Questions for Hodel
description: Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel is expected to be closely questioned at a Senate confirmation hearing Friday on his shift to the Department of the Interior.

title: Letter: On the Mideast What Israel Sought in Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;It's Same Game
description: High school football fans can relax. The rules committee of the National Federation of State High School Associations has completed its annual modifications, and it appears that the game next fall will be pretty much the same that has been played for years.

title: LAWYER SEEKS RIGHT TO CROSS STATE LINE TO WORK
description: Kathryn Piper lives 400 yards from New Hampshire. She can see it from her living room window, drive there on Route 18 in a few minutes or swim there without much exertion. In fact, she crosses the state line the moment she sets foot in the Connecticut River, which borders her property.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 28, 1985

title: ONE-DAY RALLIES PERPLEXING TRADERS
description: The stock market has always known sudden moves. Lately, however, buying waves have hit the market with such force that share prices have soared toward the stratosphere, only to stop their rise a day or two later.

title: Officer's Heart Transplanted
description: A security guard was progressing well today after receiving the heart of a policewoman who was run over by a car, officials said. The patient, Donald L. Moore, 49 years old, received the heart Saturday at the University of Kansas Medical Center, a spokesman said. The officer, Deanna Rose, 26, died of injuries after being run over when she tried to arrest a driver on suspicion of drunkenness.

title: Futures/Options;A New Market For Dollars
description: IF the main purpose of trading futures on commodities or any other market instrument is to

title: THE CITY;O'Connor Departs On Ethiopian Trip
description: Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York left yesterday on a 10-day trip to Ethiopia to lead an effort to determine the best way to help relieve the famine in that nation.

title: CIVIL LIBERTIES UNIT AFFIRMS POLICY ON HIRING FROM MINORITY GROUPS
description: The American Civil Liberties Union said Sunday that it had made some progress toward resolving a dispute over whether it was giving members of minority groups fair consideration in its search for a new director of its Washington office, though it had not yet made a choice.

title: Leslie S. Bennetts, 80, Dies; Maker of Documentary Films
description: Leslie S. Bennetts, a documentary- film director, writer and producer, died of pneumonia Friday night at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: BRIEFING;Spoilers at Work
description: The letter addressed to Governor

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Iraq Says It Hit 2 Ships; Greece Confirms 1
description: Iraq said its warplanes hit two ''naval targets'' in the Persian Gulf tonight, and Greek officials confirmed that a Greek tanker had been hit.

title: Washington Watch;S.E.C. Seeks A Bank Rule
description: WASHINGTON

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE GATE BEHIND THE WALL: A Pilgrimage to Jerusalem. By Samuel Heilman. 201 pages. Summit. $15.95.

title: Japan Credit System in Flux
description: Just a few months ago, Promise, a large consumer finance company here, hovered on the verge of bankruptcy. Rumors about cash shortages flew and financial backers pulled out in the wave of unfavorable publicity about Japanese lending practices.

title: NEW RECORDS IN '84, BUT FILM STUDIOS TALLY LOSSES
description: In 1984, for the first time, the nation's movie theaters sold more than $4 billion worth of tickets. Also for the first time in a single year, two movies - ''Ghostbusters'' and ''Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom'' - brought their distributors more than $100 million apiece in film rentals. Was 1984, then, the best of years for Hollywood? Not by a long shot.

title: RANGERS CHARGE PAST NORTH STARS
description: The immediate diagnosis: Change has changed the Rangers.

title: World Bank Is Seeking $1 Billion for Africa Aid
description: The World Bank hopes to raise an extra $1 billion for Africa at a special fund- raising meeting of donor countries in Paris this week, but there are doubts that the target will be reached.

title: BRIEFS
description: General Homes Corp. is issuing $50 million of 15 1/2 percent, 10-year subordinated notes, at a price of 100, through Shearson Lehman/American Express.

title: CARBIDE SAYS ITS INVESTIGATION HAS FOUND IRREGULARITIES
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, responding to a series of questions about the events leading to the accident at its subsidiary's pesticide plant in Bhopal, India, said over the weekend that its own investigation of the matter had revealed irregularities at the plant.

title: EUPHORIA AT 'TODAY' AFTER TYING ABC FOR 1ST
description: It was dark all around Rockefeller Center last Friday at 6 A.M., and tired men and women were trudging in to work, but in NBC's Control Room 3K there was raucously giddy laughter: For the first time in almost three years, ''Today'' had finished first in the ratings, tying ABC's ''Good Morning America.''

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS;Oliver Key Link In Phillies' Deal
description: The Philadelphia Phillies have reached agreement on a trade to send Al Oliver to the Los Angeles Dodgers, but the deal cannot be made until contract terms are worked out, Bill Giles, the Phillies president, said today.

title: Susan Rosenthal Wed To Mark Henrique Jay
description: Susan Barbara Rosenthal, the daughter of Frances Rosenthal of Brooklyn and the late Murray Rosenthal, was married yesterday to Mark Henrique Jay, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Jay of Weston, Conn. Cantor Nathan Kissner performed the ceremony at Le Fin de Si ecle, a loft at 126 Fifth Avenue.

title: ASSOCIATION RUNS 'COLLEGE' FOR EXECUTIVES
description: The American Management Association, which for many years has run short-term seminars and other educational programs for executives, also offers a series of courses it is seeking to have accredited as a master's degree program in management.

title: Indian Judge Orders Seizure Of Union Carbide's Property
description: A city magistrate hearing compensation suits filed by victims of the poison gas leak that killed more than 2,000 people ordered the seizure today of the United States-based Union Carbide Corporation's Bhopal property.

title: EMIL KAHN
description: Emil Kahn, who performed as guest conductor for major symphony orchestras and wrote ''Conducting,'' a standard text, died Friday of natural causes at his home on the Upper West Side. He was 88 years old.

title: YOU STILL CAN'T SEE FOREST FOR THE BILLBOARDS
description: This year marks the 20th anniversary of the Highway Beautification Act, but the law that was thought to have relegated outdoor advertising to the dustbin of cultural grotesqueries has failed.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 28, 1985:

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ;Nice Guy Award Goes to Decker
description: Mary Decker has become the first woman to win TV Guide's Mr. Nice Guy award, given annually to a sports figure for boorish behavior, the magazine said today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;American Security Chairman Resigns
description: W. Jarvis Moody, chairman and chief executive of the American Security Corporation and its principal subsidiary, the American Security Bank, has resigned, effective immediately.

title: Lloyd Topples Navratilova
description: Chris Evert Lloyd, playing what she called the best tennis of her career, defeated Martina Navratilova, 6-2, 6-4, in the final of the Virginia Slims of Florida tournament today, ending more than two years of losses to the world's top-ranked player.

title: OUTDOORS;IN SEARCH OF RABBITS
description: With waterfowling over in most of the Northeast, that time of year has come when the voice of the beagle is heard upon the land.

title: ADVERTISING;Del Monte Consolidates Account Outside Y.&R.
description: Because Del Monte and Young & Rubicam, Chicago, have agreed that the Del Monte assignments at the agency were not billing enough to pay the agency for the quality of service the client wanted, the food company has decided to consolidate its account, not at Y.& R. but with the Marschalk Company in San Francisco.

title: LOCKRIDGE KEEPS TITLE, WINNING IN 6TH
description: Rocky Lockridge retained his World Boxing Association junior lightweight title by stopping Kamel Bou Ali of Tunisia in the sixth round tonight after Bou Ali's corner threw in the towel.

title: Bishop Joseph Hodges Dies; Led Diocese in West Virginia
description: Bishop Joseph Hodges of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Wheeling-Charleston died today of lung cancer at Wheeling Hospital, diocesan officials said. He was 73 years old.

title: EARNINGS SOLID, BUT NOT SPECTACULAR
description: As corporate earnings from last year's fourth quarter pour in, the early returns suggest that, in general, profits were sound, but not spectacular.

title: JAZZ: PIANIST, TERRY WALDO
description: A restaurant called Pizza Piazza, which opened a year ago at Broadway and 10th Street and specializes in what you would expect it to specialize in, has now added a pianist, Terry Waldo, to its bill of fare.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Tough Biathlete
description: Kari Swenson may not be the toughest American athlete, but it will apparently take more than a bullet through the chest to knock her off her skis.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;Treasury's Line of Succession
description: If, as some expect, Beryl W. Sprinkel, the Treasury Department's Under Secretary for Monetary Affairs, is named to head the President's Council of Economic Advisers, the clear front-runner for Mr. Sprinkel's job would be David C. Mulford, the Assistant Secretary for International Affairs. Mr. Mulford, who has worked overseas for some 20 years, is regarded by bankers as particularly well suited for the No. 3 Treasury post.

title: Goldwater Backs Rise In Budget for Military
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, the new chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said today he supported a continued buildup in the military budget, suggesting an increase only slightly less than what the Reagan Administration is proposing.

title: Treasury Offerings Confined to Bills
description: The Treasury's only public financing this week is today's regular auction of new bills due in three and six months. But on Wednesday, Government securities dealers expect the Treasury to announce plans for several auctions next week.

title: WHAT THE DEMOCRATS MUST DO TO RECOVER
description: The Democratic Party is the Chrysler Corporation of American politics. Nearly bankrupt after two successive defeats, the party is now searching for its version of Lee Iacocca to lead it back to competitive respectability.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: THE SPOKEN LYRIC The avowed aim of the ''Writers in Performance'' series, which opens its 14th season tonight at 7:30 at the Manhattan Theatre Club's newly acquired space at City Center Theater, 131 West 55th Street, is to present contemporary writers and their works ''within a wide variety of literary genres.''

title: Machine Tool Orders Up in '84
description: Domestic machine tool orders rose 72 percent last year from near-record lows in 1983, the industry's trade association said yesterday.

title: ILL-PROTECTED FOREIGN EMBASSIES
description: To the Editor:

title: LOWER RATES SPARK OPTIMISM
description: As interest rates on long-term Treasury bonds fell last week to the lowest level since July 1983, the financial markets were awash with optimism that inflation would remain low, while lower interest rates would keep the economy growing at a healthy rate.

title: AROUND THE NATION;State Ponders Penalties On Long-Overdue Books
description: Slow readers beware. The State Legislature is considering a proposal that could mean a five-year prison sentence for people who don't return library books on time.

title: U.S. COMPANY SAID TO HAVE HAD CONTROL IN BHOPAL
description: The Union Carbide Corporation of Danbury, Conn., had the authority to exercise financial and technical control over its affiliate, Union Carbide India Ltd., and the American parent often used that right, according to former officials of the Indian company and others with knowledge of the concern.

title: NEMESIS CALCULATED TO BE NEAR LITTLE DIPPER
description: A possible location of Nemesis, the star blamed by some scientists for mass extinctions on the earth every 26 million years, has been calculated to be in the constellation Draco, not far from the Little Dipper.

title: GIRARDELLI TAKES 7TH SKI RACE
description: PARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Jan. 27 (UPI) - Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg increased his lead in the World Cup ski standing today by taking a supergiant slalom race. It was his seventh triumph of the season.

title: HONDURAS REPORTED RELUCTANT TO AID NICARAGUAN REBELS ALONE
description: The Honduran Government may decide to stop supporting Nicaraguan anti-Government guerrillas if the United States Congress votes not to renew funding for the rebels later this year, according to several Honduran and Western officials here.

title: BIRD'S SHOT AT BUZZER WINS
description: Larry Bird capped a 48-point performance with a basket from the corner at the buzzer that gave the Boston Celtics to a 128-127 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers today.

title: CUOMO PREPARES TO SELL HIS BUDGET TO LEGISLATURE
description: Upstaters will never let Governor Cuomo forget the forest rangers. Someone brought the topic up in the Executive Mansion the other night as he explained this year's budget proposal to editors.

title: BOOMING CORPORATE EDUCATION EFFORTS RIVAL COLLEGE PROGRAMS, STUDY SAYS
description: Educational programs run by business and industry have become a ''booming industry'' that now constitutes an alternative, if not a threat, to traditional colleges and universities, according to the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching.

title: SABRES DEFEAT QUEBEC
description: Mike Foligno scored two power-play goals tonight to power the Buffalo Sabres to a 3-2 victory over the Quebec Nordiques.

title: QUESTION BOX;
description: QUESTION: I recall a baseball game in New York during World War II in which the Yankees, Dodgers and Giants played against each other. Could you supply some details?

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CBS JURY CAUTIONED ON SHARON PARALLELS
description: Last Thursday, when word spread of a final verdict in the libel trial of Ariel Sharon's $50 million suit against Time magazine, there was an exodus of reporters and spectators from room 318 in the United States Courthouse on Foley Square.

title: Journal Writer Disaccredited GENEVA, Jan. 27 - OPEC
description: officials today suspended indefinitely the accreditation of a

title: WADKINS WINNER BY 7 AND SETS MARK
description: Lanny Wadkins insists he is not a streak golfer who wins in short bursts. But he is the hottest on the tour, maybe the hottest in many years.

title: DANCE: PRIX DE LAUSANNE CONTEST
description: A 16-year-old American dancer won the gold medal last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where the 13th annual Prix de Lausanne international ballet competition was held. Edward Stierle, a dance student at the North Carolina School of the Arts in Winston-Salem, is the second American to win the medal, the competition's highest award, which carries with it a cash prize of approximately $2,350. Mr. Stierle also received the Roberta Pew-Bandy/Astral Foundation U.S.A. prize.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Los Angeles Clippers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. This is the only scheduled appearance for Bill Walton in the Garden this season. The Clipper center played 37 minutes, scoring 14 points and grabbing 12 rebounds, in a 107-105 victory over the Knicks at Los Angeles in the third game of the season. Fashion Institute of Technology plays Bronx Community College in a preliminary game at 5:20 P.M. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT, 930; WFAS, 1230; and WGBB, 1240; 7:20 P.M).

title: AROUND THE NATION;Man Queried in Deaths In Fort Worth Is Let Go
description: Remsen Wolff, a 44-year-old photographer who was held for two days for questioning in a series of disappearances and slayings in this Texas city, was released from jail Saturday night, said a police spokesman, Doug Clarke.

title: GEORGIA TECH BEATS NORTH CAROLINA BY 4
description: Surviving a customary late game comeback by host North Carolina, Georgia Tech thrust itself into the thick of the Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season race with a 66-62 victory at Carmichael Auditorium today.

title: Tautolo Signed
description: John Tautolo, a former lineman with the New England Patriots and the New York Giants of the National Football League, has signed with the Portland Breakers, officials of the United States Football League team said today.

title: BRIEFING;Ratings, Ratings
description: The news people over at WETA,

title: THE BHOPAL DISASTER: HOW IT HAPPENED
description: The Bhopal gas leak that killed at least 2,000 people resulted from operating errors, design flaws, maintenance failures, training deficiencies and economy measures that endangered safety, according to present and former employees, company technical documents and the Indian Government's chief scientist.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Ask Ike
description: Gene Sarazen's approach shot rolls across the green and into the skirt of a young woman seated on the ground. Jack Nicklaus, preparing for a chip shot, finds a peanut hull resting against his ball. Byron Nelson's caddie inadvertently kicks his ball. As Sam Snead is about to putt on the 18th green, his playoff opponent, Lew Worsham, demands a measurement to determine who is away. Roberto DeVicenzo signs a scorecard that records 4 instead of a 3 on the 71st hole of a Masters tournament.

title: Orange Juice Loss
description: Last week's cold wave will cost the Florida citrus industry more than 25 percent of its frozen orange juice production this season, according to an estimate today by the state's largest grower cooperative. An embargo on shipment of fresh citrus fruit from the state began today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Plans for Site of Old Garden
description: Building plans are taking shape

title: Nurses in Newark Strike at Hospital
description: About 400 registered nurses went on strike today at the United Hospitals Medical Center, one of the largest hospitals in New Jersey. A State Health Department inspector was dispatched here to monitor the care of the 175 patients who remained at the hospital.

title: CASTRO TELLS U.S. BISHOPS HE'D LIKE TO MEET POPE
description: Fidel Castro has expressed a desire to meet with Pope John Paul II and reiterated his hopes for a ''normalization'' of relations with the United States, according to a member of a delegation of American Roman Catholic bishops.

title: Icahn Seen as Buyer of Phillips Block
description: A 2.7-million-share block of the Phillips Petroleum Company changed hands late yesterday for nearly $130 million in cash amid strong indications that the buyer was Carl C. Icahn, the Wall Street financier.

title: L.I. Man Charged In Woman's Death
description: An unemployed laborer was accused today of strangling a 19-year- old woman on New Year's Day in what a prosecutor called a sex attack.

title: CRAY RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Topics ;   Encouraging Words ;   Magical Mystery Ride
description: What the subway system really needs, a longtime rider realized recently, is a daily infusion of 8-year- olds from out of town.

title: BETZ LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMMUNITY SHARES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. c-There are no share earnings available for the year-ago 9 months because Community Shares went public in February 1984.

title: EMPLOYERS AND WORKERS JOIN FORCES TO AID NEEDIEST CASES
description: Many New York City employers and their employees, equally concerned by the evidence of poverty around them, often cooperate in efforts to ease the distress by contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: MCDONALD'S CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Duracell Appeal
description: Dart & Kraft Inc.'s Duracell Inc. said it had filed an appeal in the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, seeking to reinstate an International Trade Commission order prohibiting the import into the United States by third parties of foreign-made Duracell batteries designated for sale abroad. The commission found in October that importing the Duracell batteries without authorization was unfair under American law. On Jan. 4, however, the President disapproved the commission's determination.

title: GENOVA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Vietnam Veterans' Rate Of Death Found Higher
description: Researchers studying death certificates have reported that a sampling of Massachusetts veterans of the Vietnam War died at a higher rate than nonveterans and veterans who did not serve in Vietnam.

title: Man, 61, Charged In Molesting Case
description: A 61-year-old candy stand employee in a Greenwich Village roller skating rink was arrested yesterday and charged with sexually abusing three 10-year-old girls.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch on the Washington Talk page yesterday about furniture rentals carried an incorrect byline. The writer was Amy Wallace, not William N. Wallace.

title: RIGOROUS STUDY OF AUTISM POINTS TO A GENETIC FACTOR
description: AUTISM, a severe mental disorder that becomes evident in infancy, seems to have a genetic cause, according to a study of twins reported in the current issue of The American Journal of Psychiatry.

title: Knight Under Fire
description: While the Indiana Hoosiers ride a three-game losing streak, key players are riding the bench, and fans and alumni are screaming for answers from Coach

title: STEIGER TRACTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: HORIZON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
The U.N. Today
description: Jan. 29, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Today, the 22d of January 1985, I am well and my friends Benjamin Weir and Jeremy Levin are also well.

title: TOMMY JARRELL
description: Tommy Jarrell, the influential Appalachian fiddler who appeared in the Les Blank documentary film ''Sprout Wings and Fly,'' died Monday of heart failure in Mount Airy, N.C. He was 83 years old.

title: School Superintendent In Cleveland a Suicide
description: Frederick Holliday, superintendent of schools in Cleveland, shot himself to death in a school over the weekend, and left a note saying his suicide was a result of the school system's ''petty politics,'' the authorities said today.

title: Room at the Top In Westchester
description: Westchester has risen to become a major Eastern center for volleyball - home, for example, of Saturday night's second Westchester Volleyball Classic - simply because there was room to rise. It will be the company's 45th production on Broadway and follows No"el Coward's ''Design for Living,'' which closed Jan. 20 after 245 performances.

description: Brian O'Neill, league vice president, said he had reviewed films of the Islanders' game against the Black Hawks and concluded that Smith swung his stick three times in an ''irresponsible manner.'' Curt Fraser, the Chicago left wing, suffered a fractured cheekbone and other facial injuries in one of the incidents and is expected to be sidelined for six weeks.

VATICAN SYNOD: TIMING DRAMATIC, INTENT UNCLEAR
description: Pope John Paul II's unexpected call for a special synod to consider the results of the Second Vatican Council has presented Roman Catholics with an unusual, somewhat puzzling set of possibilities. John Paul's announcement last Friday, on the 26th anniversary of the summoning of the Council by Pope John XXIII, stated little more than the Pope's desire to set aside two weeks to ponder the changes brought about by the Council. At the least, the timing of the synod - it is to end on the 20th anniversary of the close of Vatican II - is seen as an expression of the Pope's sense of drama and occasion.

title: Data General Line
description: The Data General Corporation said it had introduced a new high- end superminicomputer, the Eclipse MV/10000 SX, which can process 3.6 million instructions a second. The company said pricing starts at $223,000 for the processor, four megabytes of memory and system software. The new system increases performance about 30 percent, Data General said.

title: Xerox Office Sale
description: The Xerox Corporation said it would sell its headquarters building to a limited partnership organized by Integrated Resources Inc. of New York for $51.5 million, a company spokesman said. Xerox, in turn, signed a 25-year lease on the 250,000- square-foot building and parking garage with renewal options for another 30 years. Thomas Abbot, a spokesman for Xerox, said the sale would have no effect on the company's earnings.

title: Union Carbide Suit Filed
description: A New Jersey lawyer filed suit against the Union Carbide Corporation in Federal court today on behalf of 1,400 Indian nationals who were killed or injured in the gas leak at the company's chemical plant in Bhopal in central India. The lawsuit, filed here by Bernard Kuttner, seeks an unspecified amount of damages. Mr. Kuttner said the suit was filed in United States District Court here because the company has seven plants in New Jersey.

DANCE CLUBS PUT SPIN ON NEW DISKS
description: From the disk-jockey booth on the second floor of Danceteria, Mark Kamins looks out on a shadowy, undulating mass of purple-lit heads and shoulders. The Saturday-night dancers are active, but Mr. Kamins moves faster than any of them. Dressed for mobility in a black T-shirt and jeans, he pivots to his record racks, thumbs through 20 disks in five seconds, pulls out the one he's looking for, turns around, flips it onto one of his two turntables, and listens to it through an earphone. ''Let's see if we can make them scream,'' he says, turning the knob that will put Liquid Liquid's ''Cavern'' through the sound system. Sure enough, a collective shriek of pleasure greets the song.

title: Stock Proposal Study
description: The public policy committee of the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it was seeking public comment on a proposal to allow listed companies to create a second class of common stock with disproportionate voting rights. An exchange subcommittee made the proposal on Jan. 3. If the committee approves after receiving the public's comment, the proposal would still need the approval of the exchange's board and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Mr. Meese Doesn't Measure Up Eleven months have passed since Edwin Meese went before the Senate Judiciary Committee seeking confirmation as Attorney General. Though slight of legal stature, he had the warm endorsement of a popular President and seemed easily confirmable. But questions arose about his fitness for that office, serious enough to require a special investigation by an independent counsel. The counsel concluded that none of the charges warranted a criminal indictment, so the President renewed the nomination. This week the Senate returns to the crucial question: What qualifies Mr. Meese for this job?
description: There is much to be said for letting Presidents have their choice in Cabinet officers. But unless the qualifications are cut to fit the candidate, Mr. Meese is not a desirable choice. Some senators seem in no mood to measure the nominee. For them the key factors now are President Reagan's landslide re-election and the independent counsel's report that Mr. Meese has done nothing criminal. Yet senators, in voting to confirm or reject, should apply a higher standard of what the Attorney General ought to be.

title: Castle & Cooke, Jacobs in Deal
description: Irwin L. Jacobs has agreed not to purchase more stock in Castle & Cooke Inc. until after March 31, the company said. The announcement came after a scheduled hearing in U.S. District Court here was canceled.

title: HALLEY'S COMET OBSERVED IN INFRARED
description: ASTRONOMERS atop Hawaii's highest volcano have made what they believe to be the first infrared observations of Halley's Comet. From the results they estimate the radius of its nucleus to be four miles.

title: STAGE: 'HENRIETTA,' AN URBAN COMEDY
description: ANY character actress in her right mind would probably kill to play the title role in ''Henrietta,'' a new urban comedy at the Negro Ensemble Company. Henrietta is a lovable derelict - a spunky, middle-aged Harlem bag lady whose every line is either a truth-telling wisecrack or a well- honed aper,cu asserting an idiosyncratic, street-smart philosophy of life. Like so many bums in plays, Henrietta does seem too good to be true: She is all too concertedly the most unforgettable character anyone has ever met. But she's made to order for an actress in search of a star turn, and the lucky recipient of the role at the N.E.C., Frances Foster, can hardly hide her delight at the assignment.

title: ON S.I., A FIGHT TO STAY GREEN
description: When a work crew began chopping down three acres of trees at Corson's Brook Woods on Staten Island two months ago, the residents of The Woods, a nine-block cluster of homes just across the road, were stunned.

title: PROMISING EDUCATIONAL SOFTWARE
description: ANY marketing manager in the personal computer industry will happily assure you that one of the best reasons for buying a home computer is education. A grave problem faces educational software, however, and that is its failure to fulfill its promise.

title: JOHN PAUL SAYS CHURCH MUSTN'T ACCEPT JUSTICE
description: Pope John Paul II said today that the church must not ''resign itself passively'' to social injustice.
