title: Winans Trial Hears of Plans to Flee
description: Peter N. Brant, the former Kidder, Peabody & Company stockbroker who has pleaded guilty to fraud for arranging to trade on advance information about The Wall Street Journal's ''Heard on the Street'' column, testified yesterday that he made plans last March to flee to Brazil with David W.C. Clark, a New York lawyer who was one of his largest clients.

title: Woman's Plea in Death Of Belushi Is Delayed
description: The lawyer for Cathy Evelyn Smith, the former rock singer accused of unintentionally killing John Belushi with injections of cocaine and heroin, today put off accepting a prearranged plea bargain and said he might take the case to trial.

title: THE OPERA: TROYANOS IN HANDEL'S 'ARIODANTE'
description: HANDEL'S Italian operas have been creeping into the international repertory in recent years and this season's tricentennial celebration of his birth should give the movement a push. In the past, his operas have suffered both from a lack of audience understanding and from a shortage of singers capable of getting deep into the music, vocally and expressively. Slowly, however, a cadre of first- class Handel singers has been developing, people with a feeling for the style and the talent to manage its technical difficulties. As a result, not surprisingly, a public for the operas has been growing.

AUSTRIAN APOLOGIZES FOR MEETING A WAR CRIMINAL
description: The Austrian Defense Minister publicly apologized today for having met with an Austrian Nazi war criminal who was released from an Italian prison last week.

title: BRUSH WELLMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: PHONES HAVE VIEWERS TALKING BACK
description: The telephone has become the newest gimmick in the increasingly competitive world of ''info-tainment'' on television.

U.N. Secretary Confers With Vietnam Leaders
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar held another round of talks with Vietnam's Foreign Minister today that were believed to have centered on Cambodia and other problems in Southeast Asia.

title: COMMITTEE USES THE ARTS TO HELP THE HANDICAPPED
description: William Britt, a retarded man who had lived most of his 38 years at the Willowbrook State School on Staten Island, was hostile and easily frustrated at the time of his admittance in 1974 to the Margaret Chapman School in Hawthorne, N.Y. An art workshop led to his participation in an arts festival for the handicapped, and his success affected him deeply. Today, Mr. Britt, rarely anti-social, is getting A's in drawing at Westchester Community College, and is starting a professional career as an artist.

title: 'DIAMOND LIFE,' SADE'S DEBUT ALBUM
description: THIS week, Epic/Portrait Records is releasing ''Diamond Life,'' the debut album of yet another English pop sensation, the pop-jazz quartet Sade. ''Diamond Life'' has already sold just under a million copies in England (the equivalent of three million in the United States) and has spawned three international hits. The star of the group is a self-possessed 24-year-old singer-songwriter of Nigerian and British descent, named Sade Adu, who was born in Nigeria and brought up in the English coastal resort town of Clacton. Stunningly photogenic, Miss Adu possesses a dusky, haunting pop-jazz alto whose blase sensuality perfectly matches her sleek appearance. As an icon of a ''new pop elegance,'' Miss Adu already has the American fashion press stampeding after her.

title: WHITE HOUSE EXAMINES INTRUSION BY ADVENTUROUS INAUGURAL VISITOR
description: A meter reader who walked into the White House says he ''just wanted to see how far I could get.'' And what he got, he decided after 15 minutes just below the Reagan family quarters and a week in a Washington jail, was ''an adventure - a real adventure.''

title: Regulator Discusses BankAmerica Write-off
description: A California mortgage packager and a Delaware insurance company apparently were key participants in in faulty mortgage securities that forced the BankAmerica Corporation to take a $37 million fourth-quarter write-off, a Delaware state official said today.

description: b-Include investment gains of $50,000 for the quarter and $8,756,000 for the year. c-After investment loss of $802,000 for the quarter and investment gains of $2,059,000 as well as a gain of $5,840,000, or $1.62 a share, from the sale of an office building.

OPEC Still Divided On Pricing
description: Ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries failed today to reach an agreement to overhaul the group's pricing system and planned to meet again on Wednesday.

description: Leon Spinks, the former heavyweight champion who has not fought in nearly two years, has postponed his scheduled comeback in a cruiserweight bout against

title: HUNGARIAN STRUDEL, MADE BY A MASTER
description: PACKAGES of frozen strudel and phyllo leaves are sold in grocery stores and food shops throughout the area. Why bother making the pastry from scratch?

title: Man Survives 50-Foot Fall
description: Gary Syfert, 40 years old, jumped from a balcony 50 feet above the marble floor of the Utah State Capitol on Monday as the Legislature was about to begin its morning session. Mr. Syfert gave no warning, security officers said. He survived and was listed in serious condition in a hospital with fractures to the skull, pelvis and one leg.

title: UNITED STATES TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a provision of $1,800,000 related to inventory writedown resulting from lower grape harvest yields.

title: Coalition Time
description: ''Coalition'' is de rigueur in the current political year.

title: DANCE: 'CARMEN' BY ANTONIO GADES
description: ANTONIO GADES is presumably still the best Spanish dancer in the world and he has not danced in New York since 1972. He doesn't dance very much either in his flamenco version of ''Carmen,'' which opened last night at the City Center for a run through Feb. 17.

title: OPERA: CAST CHANGES FOR :ARIADNE' AT THE MET
description: FEW works of art are so delightfully scrambled as ''Ariadne auf Naxos,'' an opera in a prologue and one act by Richard Strauss. An arresting mixture of silliness and profundity - imagine the Marx Brothers turned loose within a Greek tragedy - ''Ariadne'' contains some of the most affecting music Strauss ever wrote, as Monday night's performance at the Metropolitan Opera House made clear.

title: CHURCH AND FOES CLASH AGAIN ON ST. BART'S PROJECT
description: For the second time in a year, church leaders and preservationists have clashed at a public hearing on a plan to build an office tower on the site of the community center of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, at Park Avenue and 50th Street.

title: DEATH ASKED FOR POLISH OFFICER, 25 YEARS FOR OTHERS
description: The Government today demanded the death penalty for the key defendant in the trial of four state security men accused of having slain a pro-Solidarity priest.

description: THE animosity among the oil ministers at the

title: TOYOTA CALLS TUNE IN ITS G.M. VENTURE
description: Japanese auto manufacturers help insure that the interior of a car is installed properly by taking off the doors, so they will not be in the way, and then putting them back on farther down the assembly line. American auto executives have resisted the technique, saying it is too hard to get the doors to fit right the second time.

title: 52% RATE RISE DISPUTED ON MALPRACTICE POLICIES
description: The state hearing officer who recommended a 52 percent rate increase for a small medical-malpractice insurance company said yesterday that he never intended the increase to be applied to the other medical-malpractice insurers in New York State.

title: 2 DIE AS TANKER FALLS ATOP AUTO ON RAMP BELOW
description: Two women traveling on a Bronx highway interchange were killed yesterday when a tanker trailer on a ramp overhead sheared loose from its cab, jumped a barrier and landed on the roof of their car.

title: CONGRESS IS URGED TO RESUME ANTI-SANDINISTA AID
description: A high- ranking Administration spokesman on Latin America engaged in a sharp debate today with Congressional critics over covert United States aid to rebels fighting the Government of Nicaragua.

title: Conrail Unions Back Alleghany
description: Railroad union leaders today decided to support the Alleghany Corporation's bid to buy the Government- owned Consolidated Rail Corporation.

description: The Massachusetts Municipal Wholesale Electric Company, a seller of electricity to 28 municipally owned utilities in the state, is offering about $114 million of speculative rated, long-term bonds through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: KASPAROV PLAYS WELL BUT FAILS TO BEAT KARPOV
description: Gary Kasparov subjected the 33- year-old world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov, to Ruy Lopez torture on Monday in the 46th game of their title match in Moscow, but the 21- year-old challenger failed to deliver the coup de gr^ace, and the game was drawn.

Dailey's Complaint
description: Quintin Dailey , the Chicago Bull guard, has complained that he has been singled out unfairly for criticism by Coach

title: Composers Orchestra Will Have New Home
description: The 1985-86 season of the American Composers Orchestra, which is devoted to 20th-century American music of all styles, will take place under the auspices of Carnegie Hall - previous concerts have been held in Alice Tully Hall - and will include two commissioned scores by David Diamond and Milton Babbitt.

title: DANCE: ARTISTS GIVE PERFORMANCE SPACE BENEFIT
description: PERFORMANCE SPACE 122, the former school in the East Village that has been transformed into an arts center, is something of a plain space. Audiences seeking glamour should not venture there. However, as a center for new dance and performance art, it is an unusually lively place. And because one senses that it is a home for an artistic community, it can seem a jolly place.

title: Preserving the Monitor

description: Jan. 30, 1985 SECURITY COUNCIL

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Suns, at Phoenix. The Knicks have won four straight, but the victories have all been at home, and they will be trying to end a club-record string of 12 straight defeats on the road. They have not won a game on the road since Nov. 23 when they beat the Detroit Pistons in Pontiac, Mich. (Television - Channel 9, 9:30 P.M.)

title: GALLAGHER, ARTHUR J & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ADMINISTRATION AIDE PUTS BUDGET BEFORE TAXES
description: Richard G. Darman, the President's nominee to be Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, told the Senate today that it would be a ''couple of months'' before the Administration could introduce legislation to overhaul the nation's tax system. Efforts to cut Federal spending, he said, would have to come first.

title: AVON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest year and for the year-ago quarter and year have been restated to reflect the company's acquisition of Foster Medical Corp. which was completed on May 30, 1984. Results include operations of Tiffany & Co. through its date of sale, Oct. 15, 1984.

title: REICHHOLD CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PUBLISHER FOR ONE OF SEVEN SISTERS
description: CBS MAGAZINES has named Anne Sutherland Fuchs publisher of Woman's Day, its flagship publication with 7 million circulation. And that makes her the first woman to be named publisher of a Seven Sisters magazine, the largest of the women's service magazines. And, according to the Magazine Publishers Association, she is also the first woman to become publisher of a magazine of the 5-million-and-up circulation class.

title: Jameson Campaigne, Ex-Newspaper Editor
description: Jameson Gilbert Campaigne, acting editorial page editor of The Daily News from 1973 to 1976 and former editor in chief of The Indianapolis Star, died of cancer Jan. 23 at his home in Encinitas, Calif. He was 71 years old.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: SHE was in a friend's car in midtown Manhattan when Bern Weishoff, who played a nun in the original Broadway production of ''The Sound of Music,'' spotted a woman walking nearby who also had been one of the nuns. Mrs. Weishoff's instinct was to shout hello, but she could not remember the woman's name, and traffic moved on.

title: MIDCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Knox Stays at Helm
description: Chuck Knox has signed a new contract with the Seattle Seahawks, ending speculation that he might take over as coach of the Detroit Lions. No terms were disclosed yesterday, but it was understood that the contract included a hefty raise and assured the 52-year-old coach employment for several years.

title: HALE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Stalled Shelters
description: New Yorkers, not known for their forbearance, have behaved like saints in the matter of bus shelters. A few went up 10 years ago in central Manhattan.

title: REAGAN SAYS HE WON'T SEEK END TO EDUCATION DEPT. NOW
description: President Reagan, seeking to clear the way for confirmation of his nominee for Secretary of Education, assured a Senate panel today that he would not ask Congress to abolish the Education Department ''at this time.''

title: F.C.C. DENIES BID TO SILENCE CHILD ADS
description: The Federal Communications Commission has rejected a proposal that would have enabled viewers to use electronic boxes on their television sets to delete commercials aimed at children.

title: CLEVELAND PONDERS 'PETTY POLITICS' AFTER SCHOOL CHIEF'S SUICIDE
description: Frederick D. Holliday spent Saturday morning in a radio studio, the guest on a talk show. Then the 58-year-old superintendent of Cleveland's schools went to a local high school, where his single-engine plane sat parked in a hangar.

title: THE STATEMENT ON GROSS'S LEAVE
description: Following is the statement issued yesterday by Howard J. Rubenstein, a public-relations consultant, on behalf of Dr. Elliot M. Gross, New York City's Chief Medical Examiner:

title: High Fashion
description: Some people think Steve Garvey started it two years ago when he signed with the San Diego Padres, tried on their gold-and-brown uniform and reportedly said: ''It makes you look something like a taco. At least, you feel something like a taco.''

title: FEAR ENTERS LEBANESE CITY AS ISRAELIS LEAVE
description: The Israeli convoys, sometimes 30 to 40 vehicles long, have been rumbling through the closed-off streets of this ancient port for days.

title: ISLANDERS, BEHIND BY 4-0, RALLY AND TIE STARS, 4-4
description: Bryan Trottier may not be an All-Star, but he is the best all-round center in hockey today, as he proved tonight in rallying the Islanders from a 4-0 deficit to a 4-4 tie with the Minnesota North Stars.

title: N.F.L. TO WEIGH ROSTER CUT
description: With projections by the National Football League that every team could lose money by the 1986 season, owners are studying ways to cut costs. One way, they think, is to reduce the size of rosters from the current 49 to 45, and to limit the number of players a team can have under contract.

Results for the latest year and the previous year have been restated to reflect the discontinuation of the company's industrial instruments business in September 1984. Year-ago results have also been restated to reflect the acquisition of Charles River Laboratories in a pooling-of-interests transaction.

This House housekeeping panel calculates, for the purposes of reimbursement of Congressional travel, the cities that constitute ''high-cost geographical areas.''

title: IONA CAPTURES 10TH IN ROW
description: Iona extended its winning streak to 10 games and ran its record in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference to 5-0 with a 53-47 victory over Fordham tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: New Woman Magazine Picks O.&M. Partners
description: Elsewhere in magazine publishing for women, but not in the Seven Sisters, Pat Miller, publisher and editor of New Woman magazine, has just selected Ogilvy & Mather Partners to be her ad agency. Even though seven agencies were in competition for what will probably turn out to be a $1 million account, Ogilvy was the emotional favorite. Not only is Mrs. Miller English, but at one point in her busy career she wrote advertising copy for O.&M.'s London office.

title: LIBEL LAW PROBLEMS
description: As one of Ariel Sharon's attorneys, I've been amused by Time magazine's efforts to proclaim victory. For even though the jury was unwilling to find that Time

Foster Winans, a former Wall Street Journal reporter, passed him advance information about what was to appear in the paper's ''Heard on the Street'' column.

TREASURY BOND PRICES SURGE
description: Treasury bond prices rose sharply late yesterday as traders and speculators were encouraged by reports that agreement on a price cut by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was possible and by a late afternoon decline in short-term interest rates.

title: NEW RESTRICTIONS PUT ON CAR, COMPUTER USE
description: Taxpayers who bought cars or personal computers since last summer, with the intent of writing off part of the cost as a business expense, may be disappointed to find the tax benefits have been sharply restricted.

title: ADMINISTRATION SEEKS TO DOUBLE AID FOR PERU
description: The Reagan Administration plans to ask Congress to double military aid to Peru next year, which would make that country the largest recipient of United States military aid in South America, State Department officials said today.

title: Mr. Carter, Meet Mr. Brooks
description: It has been worrying Gary Carter ever since he was traded last month to the Mets by the Montreal Expos for Hubie Brooks and three other players: ''What in the world will I say to Hubie Brooks the first time we meet?''

title: MOST AT PLANT THOUGHT POISON WAS CHIEFLY SKIN-EYE IRRITANT
description: Virtually all of the workers at the Union Carbide pesticide plant here knew that methyl isocyanate was dangerous, and some knew it could kill people, according to present and former employees at the plant.

title: IN NUTLEY, GUESSES ON LAYOFFS BEGIN
description: After six months of festering rumors and anxieties about layoffs at the sprawling Hoffman-LaRoche pharmaceutical plant here, word came Monday that 1,000 of its 8,000 workers over the nation faced dismissal.

description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today released documents showing that lawyers for the Office of Government Ethics had found that Edwin Meese 3d violated several Federal ethical standards, and that their supervisor had apparently changed his position on the lawyers' findings Monday evening.

description: Baseball's labor representatives took another step yesterday toward turning their negotiating efforts back to the basic agreement.

title: FOR ROMANTIC LUNCHEONS, FOUR EASY-TO-COOK RECIPES
description: WHEN couples celebrate anniversaries, birthdays and other special occasions like Valentine's Day, they need all the help they can get. Too often, such occasions are marked by timeworn, even trite observances. The hackneyed card hardly bespeaks singular delight. The obligatory box of chocolates is a threat to the waistline, while the elaborate dinner - charged on a credit card in a devil-may-care moment - is an invitation to insolvency.

Such loans had previously been handled only by the larger and more powerful commercial banks.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: GAMES PEOPLE PLAY There are several kinds of games occupying minds and walls at the Museum of American Folk Art, 125 West 55th Street (581-2474). One exhibition, ''Winning Moves: Gameboards of North America,'' presents 100 wood gameboards made for checkers, parcheesi, cribbage, beanbag toss, ringo and other standards of old-time entertainment centers. But the game's not so much the thing in this show; it is the art that provides a fascinating display of design and color, in all hues and shapes that made the playing that much more fun.

title: Transactions
description: Steve Crawford, right- handed relief pitcher, who had filed for salary arbitration, agreed to one-year contract. Crawford's arbitration request will be withdrawn. FOOTBALL GENERALS (USFL) - Acquired Rick Partridge, punter, from Memphis for undisclosed 1986 draft choice. NEW ORLEANS (USFL) - Johnnie Walton, quarterback, announced his retirement as a player and accepted position as quarterback coach of the Portland Breakers. ST. LOUIS (NFC) - Named Dick Jamieson offensive coordinator to replace Rod Dowhower. Jamieson had been coach of running backs. SEATTLE (AFC) - Signed Chuck Knox to new coaching contract. HOCKEY RANGERS (NHL) - Sent Chris Kontos, left wing, and Mike Blaisdell, right wing, to New Haven farm in American League. ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Acquired Luc Dufour, left wing, from Quebec Nordiques in exchange for Alain Lemieux, center. SOCCER ST. LOUIS (MISL) - Signed Charlie Cook, goalkeeper, to replace injured Slobo Ilijevski.

description: The three crew members of a Staten Island Rapid Transit train that struck and killed a teen-ager in the Grant City section last November had alcohol in their blood at the time, the New York City Transit Authority said yesterday.

Frontier in Accord To Sell Five Planes
description: Frontier Airlines, which had met resistance when it sought further credit from its banks, said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its five McDonnell Douglas MD- 80 jets to United Airlines for $96 million.

Ferguson, chairman of the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company, to its board. Ten of the company's directors stepped down last month.

title: CBS Hopes St. John's Is Catching On
description: CBS hopes that St. John's elevation in the national rankings will be beneficial for all concerned.

title: Long Time to Grow Young
description: Guess who's going to give today's National Press Club luncheon audience ''a bold new program for revitalizing the Democratic Party'' that ''will move the New Deal into the 21st century''? Gary Hart? Governor Cuomo? Bill Bradley? None of the above. It's Claude D. Pepper, the 84-year-old chairman of the House Rules Committee. He came to Washington as a Senator in 1936, took a dozen years off beginning in 1950 when the Florida voters turned on him but has been back in the Capitol since 1962 as a Representative, never doubting at lowest ebb that he and the party would rise again.

title: ARSON REJECTED BY CITY INQUIRY ON TRANSIT FIRES

title: SWEET VICTORY AND NEW GOAL FOR LLOYD
description: When she reflects on her career, Chris Evert Lloyd prefers to think in terms of how she has grown, not aged. It is a subtle but an important distinction.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SOME of the foods I most admire are available only at certain times of the year. This is true of fresh cod, whose seasonal high is in midwinter. One of the most tender and delicate fish to be had at this time, it is also one of the easiest to prepare - deep fried, sauteed or grilled. My favorite technique involves putting pieces of skinless, boneless cod into a skillet, covering them with a mixture of cold water, milk and seasoning and bringing the liquid briefly to a boil. After being covered and allowed to stand for a few minutes, the dish is ready for the table.

title: CORRECTION

Brant, a former stockbroker, about funds withdrawn from the accounts of David W. C. Clark, a client of his at Kidder, Peabody & Company. Mr. Brant testified that he was aware that the client contended Mr. Brant had stolen the money. The testimony did not suggest that the theft was Mr. Clark's.

title: Required Reading;   Courage for Hard Look

We must take a hard look at the deficit that is going to grow. We will have to look at tax rates that will have to be raised. We must look at an economy that is good now, but might not be so good in the future.

title: THE DISASTER IN BHOPAL: WORKERS RECALL HORROR
description: About 12:40 A.M. on Dec. 3, a worker at the Union Carbide pesticide plant here went to investigate a growing leak of methyl isocyanate. As he stood on a concrete slab above three large, partly buried storage tanks holding the chemical, the slab suddenly began to shake beneath him. ''There was a tremendous sound, a messy boiling sound, underneath the slab, like a caldron,'' the worker, Suman Dey, later recalled. ''The whole slab was vibrating.'' He said he started to run away, heard a loud noise behind him, turned to look and saw 60 feet of concrete at least 6 inches thick crack. ''The heat was like a blast furnace,'' he said. ''I couldn't get within six feet of it.''

title: STOKOWSKI AWARD TO FALLETTA

title: THEATER: LEWIS CARROLL SET TO MUSIC
description: THROUGH its various artistic transformations, ''Alice in Wonderland'' has a theatrical hold on our imaginations far beyond that of most literary classics. The text has been dramatized, musicalized, cinematized and psychoanalyzed. ''Once on a Summer's Day,'' a biographical musical by a promising new team, Arthur Perlman and Jeffrey Lunden, restores innocence to ''Alice'' - no small feat - but the restoration is at a price. Anyone looking for the real story of Charles Dodgson's strange attachment to little Alice Liddell should look elsewhere.

Electric colors and snugly draped dresses that emphasized rather than obscured anatomical features were the basis of Emanuel Ungaro's wildly applauded collection. By contrast, Karl Lagerfeld, designing for the House of Chanel, took a panoramic view of fashion, pausing for long looks at the styles of 18th-century dandies and shepherdesses, 19th- century bustles and 20th-century Art Deco embroideries.

title: SHARON WINS?
description: Ariel Sharon lost his libel suit against Time. Yet some post-trial assessments have suggested that Time was the real loser. The verdict sullied Time's reputation for careful journalism, say these observers, while it boosted Mr. Sharon's political fortunes. But try as I might, I simply cannot locate in the trial court record either the legal victory or the moral vindication that the General and his supporters have proclaimed.

title: FOR MANY YOUNG PROFESSIONALS THE WAY TO EAT IS ON THE RUN
description: -year-old vice president of Sotheby's, starts the day with a freshly opened can of Nutrament, which he describes as a ''sort of grown-up baby formula.'' Cheryl Garnant, 36, a professional masseuse, skips lunch in favor of a late breakfast of Chinese takeout food, bought the day before. Sam Bemiss, 29, an investment banker at Goldman, Sachs & Company, never eats breakfast, tries not to eat lunch and exists on nibbles of this and that throughout his 12-hour workday. Thirty-five-year-old Cherie Tripp, a self- described entrepreneur, snacks on Lean Cuisine, often consuming as many as three or four of the frozen, single-portion diet meals in a day.

title: POPE SAYS WORKERS MUST NOT BE 'SLAVE OF MACHINE'

description: Coach Bobby Knight of Indiana University announced today that his leading rebounder, Mike Giomi, who was benched the last two games for poor play, had been dismissed from the basketball team for academic reasons.

title: INTERNATIONAL SETS TIMBER UNIT SALE
description: The International Paper Company said yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a plan to form a limited partnership that will own 6.3 million acres, or substantially all, of its timberland.

title: French Gasoline Prices Freed
description: France today scrapped its 50-year-old system of price controls on gasoline and most other refined petroleum products, after Europe's Supreme Court declared them illegal under Common Market law.

title: CHECKMATE FOR ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: DOW SURGES 14.79, TO RECORD 1,292.62
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, which has lagged behind other major stock market indicators in the recent rally, suddenly soared late yesterday afternoon and closed at a record high.

title: ISRAELI WARNS OF VIOLENCE AFTER LEBANON PULLOUT
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that massacres might occur next month in southern Lebanon after Israel completes its withdrawal of troops from the area around the city of Sidon.

title: PACCAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $2,567,000 for the quarter and year.

title: WHAT HITLER KNEW AND WHEN HE KNEW IT
description: To the Editor:

title: Decker to File Charges
description: Mary Decker has consulted her lawyer and plans to file a report with the police in Oregon about the Jan. 19 mugging that she says left her with a bruised hip and may have cost her a world indoor best in the mile at the Millrose Games last week. Her husband,

title: Harlem Dancemobile Series
description: Fourteen modern, jazz and Afro- American dance companies will take part in the Harlem Cultural Council's 10th Dancemobile Winter Series, at Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway, Feb. 21 to 24 and Feb. 27 to March 3.

title: MILESTONE FOR NEW MT. VERNON MAYOR
description: Ronald A. Blackwood, who came from Kingston, Jamaica, to this southern Westchester County city 30 years ago ''seeking a better life,'' today became the first black to be elected Mayor - the first to be elected a mayor in New York State. ''This should have happened a long time ago - a long time ago,'' Mr. Blackwood said. ''Perhaps we will reach a point, when we will no longer speak of our achievements in terms of firsts.''

title: CITICORP WIDENS LEAD OVER BANKAMERICA
description: Citicorp widened its lead in size during 1984 as its closest rival, the BankAmerica Corporation, continued to struggle with poor earnings and large loan losses.

title: Midland-Ross To Sell 2 Units
description: The Midland-Ross Corporation said it planned to sell its National Castings and Bay City Foundry divisions, resulting in a $51 million charge against 1984 results.

title: 3,200,000 Quarters Dumped
description: A tractor-trailer loaded with $800,000 in quarters tipped over on a ramp approaching the Commodore Barry Bridge at 12:50 A.M. Monday, spilling coins and blocking the ramp for six hours, the police said. Workers used a forklift truck to transfer bags of coins from the trailer to two armored trucks and shovels to pick up loose change.

title: CULLUM COMPANIES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Jan 12
MEESE, TESTIFYING, DEFENDS HIS PAST CONDUCT AS ETHICAL
description: Edwin Meese 3d, in confirmation hearings on his nomination to be Attorney General, said today that he had met ''ethical as well as legal'' standards of conduct for public officials. But he acknowledged that he would do some things differently in the future to avoid creating ''the appearance of impropriety.''

title: J. Owen Grundy Dead at 73; Official Jersey City Historian
description: J. Owen Grundy, the official historian of Jersey City and chairman of the city's Municipal Historic Districts Commission, died Monday at Christ Hospital in Jersey City. He was 73 years old and a native of Jersey City.

title: Iran Executes Drug Dealers
description: Iranian authorities executed 29 convicted drug dealers in Teheran and in Meshed, the semi-official newspaper Kayhan of Teheran said Monday. A total of 258 people in Iran have been put to death for drug offenses since February 1984.

title: Bridge:The Crucial Word for Today Is Also the Name of a Knot
description: For the student, it is a means of transportation. If he joins the Navy, it will be a knot, and in the Army, a term of duty. It may suggest marriage or an obstacle.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Williams Promotes Head of Subsidiary
description: In one of several top-level changes, the Williams Companies said yesterday that Vernon T. Jones had been elected president.

NEGOTIATING COMMUNIQUE TO KEEP THE BALL ROLLING
description: Space- based systems and nuclear arms, strategic and medium-range, will be ''resolved in their interrelationship.'' So read the key sentence of the communique of the recent Geneva meeting between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko.

title: INTERNATIONAL LEASE FIANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE director of community affairs for a Miami television station was having a hard time doing her job. Despite potent medication, the pain and stiffness in her twisted, arthritic hands was constant and crippling. She could not hold a cup or a telephone, and she was unable to type. At home, simple chores like wringing out her hand wash or putting on panty hose were a struggle.

title: INTERIOR AND AGRICULTURE AGENCIES PLAN HUGE SWAP OF LAND IN WEST
description: In what could become one of the largest land transactions of recent times, two Federal agencies are planning to exchange more than 30 million acres in the West to improve management efficiency.

title: WARNER-LAMBERT COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gandhi Party Wins in Bhopal But Loses 3 of 4 Other Votes
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party won a parliamentary seat in Bhopal, where more than 2,000 people were killed last month by a gas leak, but it lost three out of four other elections, according to results released today.

title: Bill Gavin, the Founder in '58 Of List on Air Play of Records
description: Bill Gavin, publisher emeritus of the Gavin Report, a national compilation of radio record-play lists, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Mill Valley, Calif. He was 77 years old.

title:
FALLOUT FROM THE SHARON TRIAL;

JOURNALISM LOSES
description: I spent some 20 gratifying years working in journalism at Time Inc. So I may be forgiven for taking personally the outcome of the Sharon case. Consider the moral confusions flowing from the excellent verdict of a scrupulous jury instructed by an innovative judge. Minutes after the verdict, reporters and onlookers shoved for position on the courthouse steps, waiting to interview the winners and losers. But who was who?

title: THETFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bad Weather Forced Early Shuttle Return
description: The Defense Department confirmed today the space shuttle Discovery was brought home a day early after completing its secret military mission because of bad weather expected at the landing site here.

title: Water-MainBreak Blocks Highway
description: A rupture in a 12-inch water main flooded eastbound lanes of Route 3 this morning, backing up rush-hour traffic west of the Meadowlands Sports Complex, Hackensack Water Company officials said.

title: FORD HEAD IN WARNING ON IMPORTS
description: A removal of import quotas on Japanese automobiles would sharply worsen the trade gap between Japan and the United States, the Ford Motor Company's incoming chairman, Donald E. Petersen, said today.

title: A FEBRUARY FIRESTORN THAT DRESDEN CAN'T FORGET
description: Two very different German visions of the past are coming into focus with the approach of the 40th anniversary of the Nazi surrender on May 8, 1945.

title: Senate Confirms Judge Alexander
description: Fritz W. Alexander 2d was unanimously confirmed by the State Senate today to become the first black judge appointed to a full term on New York's highest court.

title: Bird Does it Again
description: For the second straight time, Larry Bird won a game for the Boston Celtics at the buzzer.

description: The Reno law firm of Frank J.

title: VIDEO FOR A POETTO THE LIVING SECTION:
description: I was amused to see the item about myself in the Metropolitan Diary of Jan. 16. Judith Newman might be relieved to know that I'm only human, and that the video I was renting was ''Going Berserk.''

title: 7 CHEFS COOK UP AN ADVENTURE IN INDIA
description: With the exception of Vietnam and, more recently, Japan, French chefs have not looked to the East for culinary inspiration. They have never turned to India. Yet a few days ago, seven European chefs from some of the top restaurants in France, Belgium and West Germany - including Michel Rostang, Pierre Troisgros, Alain Dutournier and Eckart Witzigmann - came to this city to begin a culinary passage through India.

title: The Unforgotten in Soviet Prisons
description: The Soviet Union periodically eases repression after reaching agreement with the West on what may appear as unrelated subjects. Thus, because others care about dissidents and ethnic minorities, the Kremlin has seemed to manipulate their fate for bargaining leverage. To the extent that is true, there's no reason it can't be turned around to urge the Soviet Union to demonstrate a desire for better relations by loosening some locks.

title: Time Inc. Climbs 21.5%
description: Time Inc., buoyed by solid magazine results, said yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1984 climbed 21.5 percent as revenues rose 11.5 percent.

title: Du Pont Staff
description: The Du Pont Company said it would offer a special, one-time incentive to make voluntary early retirement more attractive for employees.

description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in December 1984. Results for the latest periods are for 13 and 26 weeks. Year-ago results are for 14 and 27 weeks.

DEVILS FRUSTRATED BY KINGS AGAIN, 6-3
description: Dave Taylor scored a pair of second-period goals 14 seconds apart to complete a hat trick tonight and lead the Los Angeles Kings to a 6-3 triumph over the Devils.

title: El Salvador's Rights Record Is Termed 'a Mixed Picture'
description: Torture and assassinations of civilians by El Salvador's security forces and ''death squads'' dropped substantially last year, primarily because of United States pressure, a private human rights group reported today.

title: Deaver Leaves the Hospital
description: Michael K. Deaver, the deputy White House chief of staff, has been released from Georgetown Hospital, where he was treated for a kidney ailment because of an allergic reaction to medicine, a White House spokesman said today. Larry Speakes, President Reagan's chief spokesman, said Mr. Deaver, who is 46 years old, went home from the hospital Tuesday after 10 days of medical tests because of a kidney inflammation and was feeling better. Mr. Speakes did not indicate when Mr. Deaver would return to work.

title: Missile Purchase Delayed
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, unhappy with the skyrocketing costs of the Air Force's newest air-to- air missile, has ordered a delay in production and left open the possibility that he might cancel the program.

title: GUIDE SET ON ROTATION OF CIGARETTE WARNINGS
description: The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had ordered cigarette manufacturers to submit plans to begin rotating the health warnings on their packages and advertising.

Sweden Deficit Is Cut
description: Sweden's current account deficit narrowed in November to 200 million kronor, or $22 million, from a deficit of 700 million kronor a year earlier, the central bank said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Correction

title: New York City Rebounding
description: For New York City, an improved economy and tight fiscal controls have thawed the January budget chill. Observing the 10th anniversary of fiscal collapse and the start of his campaign for a third term, Mayor Koch dares to turn toward costly remedial programs. He is properly proud of New Yorkers and conciliatory to minorities, and rightly proposes new initiatives in education, public safety and housing.

title: Chinese Plan 'Film City'
description: China is planning to build its own Hollywood, a $70 million ''film city'' in a legendary park at Xian, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: BRIEFS
76ERS DEFEAT CELTICS AS MALONE STARS
description: Moses Malone scored 38 points and grabbed 24 rebounds as the Philadelphia 76ers surged to a 122-104 triumph over the Boston Celtics tonight.

title: PATRICK SEEKS ROLE AS A PLAYERS' COACH
description: When Craig Patrick was a child, he was often told the story about the bump on the back of his head. The story grew with each telling, and in such detail that he now thinks he remembers for himself how the bump came to be.

description: To the Editor:

title: Picking Juries for Capital Cases
description: Can a citizen who strongly opposes the death penalty still be a conscientious juror in a case that may lead to execution? There is little evidence that verdicts have often been skewed by how that question is answered. Yet the question has been warmly debated for 25 years, and has again been addressed by the Supreme Court.

description: Ariel Sharon returned home today after his libel trial against Time Inc. and immediately jumped back into the domestic political fray - and into a controversy over who has been paying his legal expenses.

title: The Dictionary of Dumb
description: What joy Americans take in calling each other stupid, and how restlessly we grope for new ways to do so. The latest variation is ''airhead,'' a teen-age term now raised to the level of political controversy. Airhead, says Nancy Pelosi, who grew up in Baltimore politics, is the insult pitched at her by labor officials who back someone else for Democratic National Committee chairman.

title: Alleghany Bid Backing Delays Conrail Decision
description: The surprise unanimous endorsement by railway labor of the Alleghany Corporation's bid to buy the Consolidated Rail Corporation was significantly influenced by a warning from Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole that there was no way she would support a public sale of the railroad, several union leaders said.

title: Big Loss Expected By Financial Corp.
description: The Financial Corporation of America expects to report in the next few weeks that it lost more than $100 million in the fourth quarter, William J. Popejoy, chairman and chief executive, said today.

title: IT'S A BIRD, A PLANE-NO, A PHONE BILL
description: Telephone rates are skyrocketing, bills are incomprehensible and service has deteriorated. Many people would lay blame for this sorry state of affairs to a Federal judge named Harold Greene, who supposedly broke up the world's greatest telephone system out of allegiance to some outdated theory of antitrust law.

description: Five National Guard helicopters today dropped food, fuel and medical supplies to hundreds of Indians stranded on snowbound reservations and flew two sick babies and an elderly man to a hospital.

description: Maoist guerrillas have bombed a hydroelectric dam, cutting off power to the town of Churcampa, only 30 miles from Ayacucho, where Pope John Paul is to visit Sunday, officials said today.

description: Guido Calabresi's ''Tragic Choices'' class at the Yale Law School deals with such vexing issues as organ transplants, population control and war. But in his first lecture of the semester today, Mr. Calabresi, who was about to be named the school's new dean, talked to the overflow crowd about other things.

title: H.P. PATTERSON, BANKER, IS DEAD
description: Herbert P. Patterson, a former president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died of pulmonary failure Tuesday at his home in New York City. He was 59 years old.

title: Italian Prices Increase
description: Consumer prices in Italy rose 1 percent this month from December and were up 8.5 percent from a year ago, the State Statistical Institute said today. In December, prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent from November and were up 8.8 percent from December 1983.

title: ST. JOHN'S SURGE TOPS PROVIDENCE
description: St. John's played its first game tonight as the country's top-ranked team. And, while it was not a vintage performance, the Redmen's 77-60 victory over Providence was something of a relief from the perspective of history.

title: DU PONT DE NEMOURS, E.I. & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: A CENTRAL vacuum cleaning system enables one to clean floors, furniture, draperies and walls without having to lug a heavy cleaner from room to room and without the noise typical of most home cleaners. These systems are so quiet you can listen to music while vacuuming, in most cases.

title: A Women's Coalition
description: Muriel Siebert gathered the leaders of more than 35 local women's organizations at her River House apartment Tuesday night and started a coalition to lobby for more female appointees in government, and for such causes as day care and child support.

title: Lindbergh Sister Dies at 92
description: Eva Lindbergh Christie Spaeth, the sister of the flier Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., died Monday.

title: Advertising;   New Chief At Nadler Sets Goals
description: -year-old Nadler & Larimer in the fall as president, has now become chief executive. Arch Nadler, a co-founder who had been in the post, is assuming the less taxing designation of Florida-based consultant.

title: A Ford Merger In South Africa
description: The Ford Motor Company said that it agreed in principle to merge its South African operations with the Anglo American Corporation, the South African conglomerate, with Ford becoming the minority owner of a new company called the South African Motor Corporation. Both companies said the timetable for the merger had not been worked out.

title: GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a 100 percent stock dividend on Oct. 1, 1983.

title: SLUM DWELLERS UNAWARE OF DANGER
description: Sabir Khan looked toward the now quiet Union Carbide factory that looms across the street from the squalid slum in which he, his wife, Shaida, and their two children live.

title: ANOTHER INDECISIVE DECISION ON OIL PRICES
description: OPEC ministers gathered in Geneva this week needing to make a bold stroke that would change the psychology of an oil market so weak that buyers have nothing to lose by continung to defer purchases in the expectation of still lower prices. What they produced instead was more evidence of a lack of cohesion that could make inevitable the very price declines the group sought to arrest.

title: OVERHAUL OF STAFF AT WHITE HOUSE TO INCLUDE NEW POLITICAL POSITION
description: Reagan Administration officials said tonight that Donald T. Regan, the newly appointed White House chief of staff, was undertaking a major staff overhaul that would include the creation of a powerful new post for a broad array of political tasks.

It did not identify the company and gave no other details. AVX closed today at $24.875, up $3.875 a share, in New York Stock Exchange trading, making it the biggest percentage gainer.

description: Paul G. Kirk Jr. won a test vote in the race for the Democratic chairmanship today when his supporters defeated a procedural move to cut their strength on the Democratic National Committee.

Among the artists represented are Picasso, Manet, Toulouse-Lautrec, Susan Rothenberg and Terry Winter.

description: ''In private life - perhaps even more than in public life - I can speak out clearly on behalf of such shared foreign policy objectives as restoring and preserving American strength, supporting democracy and independence in the Hemisphere, defending our friends, our principles and our interests in the Middle East and elsewhere.'' - Jeane J. Kirkpatrick. (A6:4.)

title: MUSIC: GIDON KREMER
description: -star assemblages are less common in music than they used to be. Decades ago, before our present-day ''chamber music explosion,'' artists like Jascha Heifetz, Arthur Rubinstein, Emanuel Feuermann and Pablo Casals would group and regroup for occasional chamber performances. Ensemble was often tentative, for all the virtuosity; soloists are used to going their own way. But there were some magical evenings - and recordings.

He pledged to uphold the Constitution by stepping down and holding elections in 1988. In 1984, he freed some political prisoners, lifted some political bans and reinstated some student demonstrators expelled from college. Lately, Mr. Chun talks as if South Korea is well on the road to democracy. It isn't.

title: HERS
description: ONE of my favorite sociologists, Richard Sennett, has warned that we are losing the art of impersonal civility, without which urban life can only be nasty, brutish and frequently short. In particular, in the absence of a blackout or a major garbage strike, we have nothing to talk to strangers about - a fact that is tragically illustrated by Bernhard Goetz and his intemperate behavior on the IRT. Reportedly, one of the victims approached him with the one acceptable interstranger conversational opener: ''Got the time?'' When that subject was exhausted, either because Goetz lacked a watch or had not read Sennett's book ''The Fall of Public Man,'' the victims-to-be were left with the one other question suitable for use between strangers of vastly different social classes: ''Got five bucks?'' Goetz pulled a gun because, as far as he could tell, the conversational possibilities had been used up.

It is helpful though not absolutely required in an opera singer, who can project other interesting qualities and is always surrounded by so much theatrical paraphernalia that the absence of such a slight thing as charm can go unnoticed. A song recital without charm as a basic ingredient, however, may be a worthy event in many ways but it struggles against a serious if not fatal handicap.

title: Critic's Notebook;   BE IT ENGLISH OR IRISH, THE POEM'S THE THING
description: A NUMBER of correspondents have written complaining that in a recent review I committed the blunder of describing Seamus Heaney as a ''British'' poet. I apologize, though I should point out that I was following a well- established precedent. There is ''The Penguin Book of Contemporary British Poetry,'' for instance, in which Mr. Heaney is given pride of place. But I should also add that not long after that anthology was published, a couple of years ago, Mr. Heaney wrote an open letter in verse addressed to the two editors, Blake Morrison and Andrew Motion, taking amiable exception to the designation.

title: ROMANCE ACROSS THE GALAXIES
description: JOEY is a garage mechanic and Mary is from another planet, and when they meet they fall in love. ''Starcrossed'' wants to be sweet-tempered about this, and sometimes it really is, but vacuity overtakes it. The ''ABC Thursday Night Movie'' will be seen on Channel 7 at 8 o'clock

title: SCREEN: 'MOVING OUT,' BY AUSTRALIAN DIRECTOR
description: THE Australian Film Festival's second black eye in as many weeks is ''Moving Out,'' a negligible coming-of- age film about a teen-age boy named Gino who has emigrated from Italy with his parents and is growing up in Australia. Though this situation promises to be of at least some anthropological interest, the producer- director, Michael Pattinson, manages to make it seem surprisingly ordinary.

title: MEDICAL REPORT SAID TO BACK GROSS ON '83 DEATH IN SUBWAY
description: The head of the Transit Patrolmen's Benevolent Association released an unpublicized medical opinion yesterday concluding that there was no evidence of strangulation in the death of Michael Stewart, who died after he fell into a coma while in police custody in 1983.

title: RAYCHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain from the sale of an office building in West Germany of $1,500,000 for the quarter and a credit from a tax settlement of $1,061,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits from the company's domestic international sales corporation of $1,231,000 for the quarter and $5,023,000 for the 6 months.

title: White House Intruder Is Said To Have Been Mental Patient
description: Robert Latta, a Denver man arrested last week after strolling uninvited into the White House, ''hears voices'' and spent time in a mental hospital last June, according to documents filed in District of Columbia Superior Court.

title: 9 IN OPEC APPROVE MOEST PRICE CUT, BUT 3 ASSAIL PACT
description: Nine of 13 oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today approved a modest cut in oil prices in a major step toward linking its official prices to free-market levels.

title: MUSIC: NEW LAAROF WORK FOR VIOLA
description: HENRI LAZAROF'S ''Volo,'' a set of three ''songs of requiem'' for viola and a pair of symmetrically grouped string ensembles, is a serious work of notably direct theatrical and emotional impact. Composed in 1975, it had its New York premiere Monday at Merkin Hall as the finale of a viola recital by Milton Thomas, to whom it is dedicated.

title: British Miners Reject New Demand
description: Striking miners today rejected management's demand for a written guarantee to discuss the key issue of closing money-losing mines, thus stalling new negotiations to end the nation's 10-month-old coal strike.

title: DUQUESNE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income and share earnings figures are pro forma.

title: ILLINOIS IS SMOTHERED BY PURDUE, 54-34
description: James Bullock scored 18 points and Purdue made 16-of-20 free throw attempts tonight as the Boilermakers upset Illinois by 54-34 in the Big Ten.

title: HUMOR TAILORED TO FIT THE CAPITAL'S POLITICAL NEEDS
description: Humor is taken seriously here. It can ease tension, provide an escape valve from pomposity and dispel awe in the pressurized world of politics.

title: A Police Officer Is Accused Of Shooting Her Boyfriend
description: An off-duty police officer shot and seriously wounded her boyfriend during an argument yesterday in the Queens apartment they shared, the police said.

title: NEXT SHUTTLE'S CREW TO PLAY WITH TOYS IN LESSONS ON SPACE
description: In the long hours aloft on the next space shuttle flight, David Griggs, a crew member, will while away the time with a yo-yo, presumably doing such tricks as walking the dog and sleepers and, of course, 'round the world.

description: Witnesses say it first appeared as a yellow light, then as a white ray. Then, it became a green cloud that turned into something resembling a plane.

title: KOCH, IN STATE OF THE CITY SPEECH, PROMISES MORE POLICE FOR SUBWAY
description: He promised more police protection on the subways and more housing. And he proposed new programs for the city schools and said, with some tempering of his usual optimism, that the city had not quite bounced back from the financial turbulence of the mid-70's but was well on its way.

title: FOR OLDER PEOPLE, COMMUNAL LIVING HAS ITS REWARDS
description: AFTER health and money problems, the biggest concern for many elderly Americans is housing. Several million older but physically fit people face the stark choice of struggling alone at home or moving into an institution of one kind or another.

description: Scientists have developed a potential vaccine against gonorrhea, and they hope to begin testing it on human volunteers this year.

description: To the Editor:

title: Scholars and the Comet
description: There is still ample time to prepare for the next return of Halley's Comet, due to be visible from earth again, if the laws of the heavens and Newton are still intact, early in 1986. The appearance will mark the fourth time the comet has showed up at the predicted time. Those gazers who need to know more are adivsed that the Library of Congress has just published ''Halley's Comet: A Bibliography.''

title: New York Prelate Urges Cooperation on Ethiopia
description: Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York said today that regardless of political differences, the Governments of the United States and drought- stricken Ethiopia could ''accomplish miracles together.''

description: Jan. 31, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

NEW BREED OF STAND- UP COMICS IN THE CLUBS
description: ''My grandfather used to sneak up behind me with half a canteloupe, put it on my head, and say, we've got a new Pope!'' remembers Jimmy Brogan, the tall, skinny young stand- up comic on the stage at Caroline's, New York's hottest comedy club.

title: Tanner Guilty Plea
description: William B. Tanner, former owner of William B. Tanner Broadcast Services of Memphis, pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of mail fraud and three counts of income tax fraud, Federal authorities said. Under the plea bargaining agreement, Mr. Tanner, 54 years old, would face a maximum sentence of four years in prison and fines of $16,000, according to Dan Clancy of the United States Attorney's office in Memphis.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Central Louisiana Electric Co. , Alexandria, La., has appointed William F. Terbot president and chief operating officer.

title: Libbey-Owens, Brown & Sharpe
description: The Brown & Sharpe Manufacturing Company, which is based in North Kingstown, R.I., said it had sold its worldwide fluid-power operations to a unit of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company, an automotive and industrial glass producer based in Toledo, Ohio.

title: Barbie Trial Scheduled For Later This Year
description: The Nazi war criminal Klaus Barbie will go on trial here sometime this year, probably in December, on charges of crimes against humanity, the chief prosecutor's office announced today.

title: LENS PRESCRIPTIONS

PARIS: ELEGANCE BY SAINT LAURENT, GIVENCHY
description: Unlike some other couturiers showing their spring and summer collections here this week, Yves Saint Laurent does not believe that the very rich are all that different from you and me. Along with ordinary mortals who get around by subway and bus, he believes that the limousine and Concorde crowd often prefers simple styles that are practical and not all gussied up.

title: EX-IM BANK FACES LOAN CURB
description: President Reagan, as part of his deficit-reduction effort, will ask Congress for a deep cutback in operations of the Export-Import Bank, which finances the purchase of Boeing airplanes, General Electric turbines, Caterpillar tractors and other American products abroad.

title: Bank, Fund Yields Fall
description: Yields on bank and money fund investments continued their decline for the week ended yesterday, the Donoghue Money Market Report and The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: Hanoi Is Called Open To U.S. Role in Region
description: Vietnam's Foreign Minister said today that Hanoi would welcome a more active American role in solving the problems of Southeast Asia.

title: GREAT LAKES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ANOTHER BROKER SAYS HE USED WINANS TIPS
description: Douglas McCaskey, a stockbroker formerly with Shearson/American Express and now with Oppenheimer & Company, testified yesterday that he, too, had traded on the advance information that R. Foster Winans, a former Wall Street Journal reporter, passed to Peter N. Brant and Kenneth P. Felis, two former stockbrokers at Kidder, Peabody & Company. The information concerned stocks that would be featured in the newspaper's ''Heard on the Street'' column.

title: 5TH AVE. TOWER BLOCKED BY VOTE FOR LANDMARKS
description: The former Rizzoli bookstore at 712 Fifth Avenue and the adjoining Coty building have been designated landmarks by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

description: The only proven, risk-free way for travelers to avoid contracting diarrhea is to follow ''sensible dietary practices,'' in the opinion of the panel of experts convened by the National Institutes of Health.

REAGAN IS TOLD BY KIRKPATRICK SHE WILL LEAVE
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick emerged from a meeting with President Reagan today and said that she would soon leave her post at the United Nations to resume teaching, writing and speaking out on public issues.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Erie County's Bonds To Yield 5.5% to 8.2%
description: New York's Erie County is refinancing a budget deficit accumulated over the last two years with a $75.7 million bond issue, offered yesterday through underwriters led by Ehrlich- Bober & Company.

title: BILL SEEKS TO END INTEREST SUBSIDIES TO MILITARY CONTRACTORS
description: Legislation was introduced in Congress today to abolish a Defense Department practice of paying an interest subsidy as an incentive to corporations that build weapons and military equipment.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Treasury Rates Gain Slightly
description: The Treasury announced yesterday a larger-than-expected, $19 billion package of note and bonds for sale next week, but expectations of good demand from individuals and institutions kept prices from falling after the announcement.

title: RTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Caterpillar to Cut Up to 1,400 Jobs
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said that a consolidation of operations could result in the loss of about 1,400 jobs at plants in Mapleton, Ill., and Davenport, Iowa.

title: SALAD GREENS: AN EARLY CROP
description: SALAD greens are just about the easiest crops to raise: the planting doesn't take much effort and the growing doesn't take much space.
